Not for Redistribution HONG KONG 1 '2 Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.146631 gram of fine gold per Hong Kong Dollar. The central rate is HK$5.0850 per US$1, correspond- ing to HK$6.13431 = SDR 1, and Hong Kong avails itself of wider margins, the official limits being HKS4.9706 and HK$5.1994 per US$1. On January 1,1974, the banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were HK$5.0650 and HK$5.1050, respectively. Administration of Control There is no exchange control. Import and export licensing is carried out by the Director of Commerce and Industry. Prescription of Currency The Colony of Hong Kong is part of the Sterling Area, although it has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947. No prescription of currency requirements are in force; settlements between resi- dents of Hong Kong and nonresidents may be made and received freely in Hong Kong dollars or any other currency. Nonresident Accounts The treatment of nonresident accounts does not distinguish between those of residents of other parts of the Sterling Area and those of nonresidents outside the Sterling Area. Imports and Import Payments Except for certain dutiable or dangerous commodities, im- ports are free of license. However, all goods originating in or shipped from Rhodesia require an import license. All imports must be declared to the Department of Commerce and Indus- try. Payments for permitted imports may be made freely, at any time and in any currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to any destination of plastic raw materials and certain strategic goods are subject to restrictive licensing; textiles are also subject to licensing because of a number of bilateral agreements with specified countries under which the export of certain textiles is restricted. All exports must be declared to the Department of Commerce and Industry, which is also the export licensing authority. Export proceeds may be collected at any time and in any currency. They need not be repatriated or surrendered. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles There are no limitations on payments for or receipts from 1 Hong Kong is a nonmetropolitan territory in respect of which the United Kingdom has accepted the Fund's Articles of Agreement. 2 In view of changes that took place on January 1, 1974 (see note at the end of this survey), this survey presents the position on that date. invisibles. Resident and nonresident travelers may freely bring in and take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes, travelers checks, and other means of payment. Capital ' No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents. Gold There is a free market for gold in which dealings by resi- dents and nonresidents are unrestricted. Imports and exports of gold in any form (including finished jewelry) are freely permitted and do not require licenses. Residents may hold gold in any form in Hong Kong or abroad. Changes during 1973 January 1. Exchange control was abolished. The distinc- tion between authorized banks and nonauthorized banks was terminated. All exchange control circulars were canceled and the use of exchange control forms E.C. 15 and E 2 was ended. Banks were asked to continue to cooperate in providing sta- tistical information, particularly with respect to their posi- tions in foreign currencies. Furthermore, until September 1973 banks were requested to consult the Exchange Control Office before running any position in foreign currencies other than sterling beyond those limits agreed under previous ar- rangements; banks remained free, however, to increase or decrease their sterling holdings. February 14. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, it was announced that the value of the Hong Kong dollar was being maintained in terms of gold. The central rate in terms of U.S. dollars, previously HK$5.6500 = US$1, became HK$5.0850 = US$1, and Hong Kong continued to avail itself of wider margins. The upper limit for the U.S. dollar became HK$4.9706 and the lower limit HK$5.1994. September 24. Banks became free to run positions in any currency without consultation. Licenses ceased to be required for the import of gold and diamonds and for the export of gold, diamonds, and currency notes and coins. 200 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ICELAND Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.00830471 gram of fine gold per Icelandic Krona, corresponding to IKr 107.008 = SDR 1. A central rate has been established of 0.00792269 gram of fine gold per Icelandic krona, which corresponds to IKr 112.168 = SDR 1. No exchange transactions take place at the par value or the central rate, since no announced margins are being observed for the time being. The official rates on Decem- ber 31,1973 were IKr 83.60 buying and IKr 84.00 selling, per US$1. Rates for other currencies are based on the official rates for the U.S. dollar and the dollar rates for the currencies concerned in international markets. Rates for settlements through the clearing account with the U.S.S.R. are fixed; the buying and selling rates maintained for clearing kronur by the Central Bank of Iceland on December 31, 1973 were IKr 0.9986 and IKr 1.0014, respectively. The authorized banks are permitted to carry out exchange transactions among themselves and to engage in arbitrage in foreign mar- kets. Administration of Control The Ministry of Commerce, after consulting the Central Bank, has the ultimate decision on matters concerning import and export licensing and on payments for invisibles. The Central Bank of Iceland is responsible for the regulation of foreign exchange transactions and of exchange control, in- cluding capital controls, and for ensuring that all foreign exchange due to residents is surrendered to authorized banks and that such exchange is disposed of as authorized. The two largest commercial banks, the National Bank of Iceland and the Fisheries Bank, are the only authorized banks. The autho- rized banks issue import and exchange licenses in consulta- tion with the Ministry of Commerce. Export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Commerce. Prescription of Currency Iceland has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Iceland maintains a bilateral payments agreement with the U.S.S.R., and all settlements with that country must be made exclusively through a clearing account denominated in kronur. As a general rule, exchange receipts from other countries must be obtained in convertible currencies. In practice, settlements with countries in the dollar area and with Brazil are made in U.S. dollars; with countries in the Sterling Area and some other countries, in sterling; and with certain other countries, in their respective currencies. Nonresident Accounts There are two categories of nonresident kronur accounts: Foreign Accounts and Special Accounts. The opening of non- resident accounts requires individual approval. Foreign Accounts may be credited with the proceeds from the sale of foreign currency to authorized banks and with authorized payments due to nonresidents from residents. Bal- ances on Foreign Accounts may be used freely for payments to residents and may without a license be converted into the currency of the country of residence of the account holder. These accounts are in practice seldom used, payments for international transactions generally being made in U.S. dol- lars, sterling, or other convertible currencies. Special Accounts in kronur or foreign currency may be opened by agreement with an authorized bank. The most important of these accounts are those of foreign banks and foreign insurance companies. They may be credited freely, up to certain limits, with approved payments from residents. Imports and Import Payments All goods not included in the restricted list or subject to state trading (see below) may be imported freely (and, with minor exceptions, without an import license) from any coun- try; * about 93 per cent of total imports (1972 basis) is liberal- ized. Some 30 commodities or groups of commodities are included in the restricted list and are subject to quantitative restriction. Some of these commodities are admitted, subject to individual license, under seven global quotas (1973) that apply to all countries with which Iceland does not maintain bilateral payments agreements. 2 The remaining goods on the restricted list are admitted from the same countries on the basis of individual licenses issued on a discretionary basis ("other licensing"). The principal items involved are gasoline, gas oil, and fuel oil; they are imported mainly from the U.S.S.R. All goods on the restricted list require individual licenses when imported from bilateral payments agreement countries; licenses in this case are in principle issued in accor- dance with bilaterally agreed quotas, but in practice they are granted freely upon application for global quota items. Cer- tain imports are admitted only under state trading; these include fertilizers, tobacco, matches, and alcoholic beverages. Furthermore, fresh vegetables and potatoes are imported un- der the auspices of the Agricultural Production Board in accordance with a government authorization. None of these commodities, however, is subject to quantitative restriction. For imports from all sources, when requiring a license, a fee of V2 of 1 per cent (minimum IKr 10.00) is charged as a license fee on the krona amount of the import license when the license is issued; for petroleum products, however, this fee is 0.1 per cent. The commercial banks normally require cer- tain advance deposits in connection with import transactions. Importers of goods not requiring licenses do not have to obtain a foreign exchange permit prior to shipment from abroad, provided that the purchase is payable at sight. On the other hand, the goods will not be cleared by the customs unless payment has already been made or the importer has arranged with an authorized bank for payment. An importer 1 The liberalized commodities include agricultural commodities that are purchased from the United States under P.L. 480 agreements (at the end of 1973 no such agreement was in force). In order to ensure the implementation of the agreement, the authorized banks are empowered to control the foreign exchange allocations for purchases of these commodities. 2 For these goods, moreover, additional licenses may be applied for outside the global quotas. 201 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ICELAND may either open a letter of credit or obtain a payment certifi- cate which enables him at any time to buy foreign exchange to pay for the goods. For imports that require individual licenses, foreign exchange is granted in accordance with the terms stipulated in the license. Importers may freely accept suppliers' credit for up to three months from the date of arrival at an Icelandic port for listed goods corresponding to some 70 per cent of 1970 imports; the goods not listed are mainly building materials and nonessen- tial goods (including motor vehicles for personal use). Credit in excess of 3 months and not exceeding 12 months requires permission by an authorized bank and the Ministry of Com- merce. Foreign credit in excess of 12 months is subject to government authorization. Imports from all sources of motor vehicles and motorcycles are subject to an import surcharge of 25 per cent ad valorem; the surcharge is 15 per cent, however, for buses and heavy trucks, and ambulances and certain other utility vehicles are exempt. Payments for Invisibles No exchange license is required for government payments (such as interest and amortization on external loans, expenses of the foreign service, payments to international organiza- tions, payments for postal, telegraphic, and telephone ser- vices), for banking commissions, or for bank charges on foreign exchange transactions. Most other outgoing payments are licensed freely on the basis of bona fide documents. The basic allocation for tourist travel is the equivalent of IKr 25,000 (about US$300) a per- son for one trip a year (IKr 12,500 for children): if a second trip is made in the same calendar year, an additional alloca- tion of 50 per cent of the basic allocation is granted. Applica- tions for exchange for major repair of ships, repair of means of transport other than ships and aircraft, transactions and transfers in connection with direct insurance, and insurance business operations abroad are considered on their merits. The chartering of foreign ships usually is not allowed when Icelandic vessels are available for charter on normal terms. Resident and nonresident travelers may take out up to IKr 1,500 in Icelandic banknotes and coins, in denominations not exceeding IKr 100. Nonresident travelers may re-export any foreign exchange they brought in upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds All commercial exports require licenses. The shipping doc- uments must be lodged with an authorized bank. Exchange receipts accruing from exports must be surrendered without undue delay. All fish products are subject to export levies. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered without undue delay. The owners of Icelandic ships and air- craft are, with the approval of the authorized banks, permit- ted to retain their foreign exchange receipts from freight, passenger tickets, or other charges, and to use them for oper- ating purposes and for purchases of necessities for the home- 202 ward journey of the ship or aircraft. Icelandic insurance com- panies which reinsure abroad are permitted to retain foreign exchange earned from premiums and indemnities and to use it to pay reinsurance premiums, claims, and other regular expenditures of the insurance business in the country where the foreign exchange was earned. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in up to IKr 1,500 in Icelandic banknotes and coins, in denominations not exceeding IKr 100. There are no limitations on the import of foreign banknotes and coins. Capital All investments by nonresidents in Iceland are subject to individual approval. The participation by nonresidents in Ice- land's joint stock companies may not exceed 49 per cent, and is not allowed in the fishing industry. Nonresident-owned foreign capital entering in the form of foreign exchange must be surrendered. Nonresidents may be authorized to open non- resident accounts for these funds, in which case their retrans- fer abroad may be permitted. Residents are obliged to surrender foreign exchange accru- ing to them on account of capital transactions and payments. Without the approval of the Government, residents may not obtain loans abroad, including loans for financing imports, for periods exceeding one year. Applications for the contract- ing of financial credits and loans abroad for a period of less than one year are considered on their merits and approved only in exceptional circumstances. The contracting of com- mercial credits abroad for a period of between 3 and 12 months is also approved only in exceptional circumstances, e.g., in connection with the import of industrial raw materials for which the production process is lengthy, the import of construction materials, and so forth. The authorities permit the use of suppliers' credit of up to 90 days, except for the financing of a number of specified imports, including motor vehicles for personal use, various household appliances, speci- fied foods, various types of clothing, precious and semipre- cious stones, watches and clocks, toys, and portland cement. The authorities may in special circumstances allow import credit in excess of 90 days for such items as machinery, air- craft, or ships. Transfers of capital abroad by residents re- quire approval, which is granted only in exceptional cases; transfers by individuals are generally limited to IKr 50,000 a year. However, direct investment abroad for the purpose of assisting the marketing of Icelandic products is normally per- mitted. Portfolio investment abroad by residents is prohib- ited. Outward transfers of inheritances, legacies, and emigrants' assets are considered on their merits and are re- stricted. Nonresidents may acquire Icelandic securities and other assets with imported funds; the transfer abroad of the pro- ceeds from the sale of these assets and securities requires authorization. Securities held in Iceland by nonresidents must be registered, and all transactions and operations concerning them are subject to licensing. The import and export of secu- rities by residents are subject to the approval of the Central Bank. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold in Iceland, subject to certain legal requirements. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Central Bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for im- ports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. However, citizens returning to Iceland after a period of residence abroad may freely bring in any gold in their possession. Changes during 1973 January 1. A central rate of Rs 18.9677 = £ stg. 1 has been established. The Reserve Bank of India maintains fixed buying and selling rates for sterling and consequently transactions in all currencies other than sterling and currencies directly linked to sterling take place at fluctuating rates. At the end of December 1973, the Reserve Bank's buying and selling rates for its operations in sterling with authorized dealers were Rs 18.75 and Rs 18.85 per £ stg. 1. The rates of exchange for transactions in sterling have been prescribed by the Reserve Bank. Transactions in foreign currencies other than sterling and currencies directly linked to sterling are conducted through authorized dealers at rates fixed on the basis of market conditions, subject to spot transactions being done at or between the London mar- ket rates for sterling against the other currency concerned. In addition, the Reserve Bank stands ready to purchase U.S. dollars, spot and forward. 2 Authorized dealers are permitted to cover their require- ments of foreign currencies in the London market and to cover their permitted transactions in certain listed currencies (the "permitted currencies") 3 against rupees or any one of these currencies, either spot or forward for periods not ex- ceeding six months, with authorized banks in any country outside the Bilateral Account group. 4 On December 28, 1973, market rates for telegraphic transfers on New York were US$12.42 buying (clean) and US$12.19 selling, per Rs 100, and the Reserve Bank's rates were US$12.3375 buy- ing spot, and US$12.2875, US$12.2200, US$12.1650, and US$12.0175 buying forward (for 1, 2, 3, and 6 months' deliv- ery, respectively) per Rs 100. The Reserve Bank provides forward cover to authorized dealers by purchases of sterling, for up to 9 months' delivery initially (and extendable up to 12 months), and U.S. dollars, for 1, 2, 3, and 6 months' delivery (see footnote 2). Under the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, the general or specific approval of the Re- serve Bank is necessary for the continuance of commercial, industrial, and trading activities in India of companies with more than 40 per cent nonresident interest or for the estab- lishment by them in India of any branch, office, or other place of business for carrying out any such activity. Import and export licenses are issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports. Prescription of Currency India has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. For prescription of currency purposes, countries are divided into two groups: Bilateral Account countries,4 and External Account countries (all other countries). Payments to and from Bilateral Account countries must be settled in Indian rupees through the appropriate clearing ac- count. Payments to 14 External Account countries 5 may be made in rupees to the credit of the account of a resident of any country in this group or in the currency of any country or territory in this subgroup. Payments to all other External Account countries may be made in (1) the currency of the country concerned; (2) the currency of any country of the subgroup mentioned; or (3) rupees to the account of a resi- dent of any country in the External Account group. 6 Re- ceipts from 14 External Account countries (see footnote 5) may be obtained in rupees from the account of a bank in any External Account country, or in the currency of any territory in this subgroup. Receipts from all other External Account countries may be obtained in (1) the currency of the country concerned; (2) the currency of any territory in the subgroup mentioned; or (3) rupees from the account of a bank in any External Account country. Notwithstanding the foregoing, special rules may be applicable in respect of Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Egypt, the Sudan, and exports under lines of 6 The countries listed are Austria, Belgium-Luxembourg, Canada, Denmark and the Faroe Islands, French Franc Area, Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, Japan, Netherlands Monetary Area, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, United Kingdom, and United States and territories under U.S. sovereignty. 6 The prior approval of the Reserve Bank is required for all remittances to Pakistan. All remittances by nationals of the People's Republic of China to any country outside India and all remittances to the People's Republic of China by any person resident in India, whether for personal or trade purposes, were stopped with effect from November 3, 1962. Nonresident Accounts The accounts of Indians and of Nepalese and Bhutanese nationals resident in Nepal and Bhutan, as well as the ac- counts of offices and branches of Indian, Nepalese, and Bhu- tanese firms, companies, or other organizations in Nepal and Bhutan are treated as resident accounts.7 Accounts related to all other foreign countries are treated as nonresident ac- counts. The treatment of these accounts distinguishes be- tween those of banks and of others. The accounts of banks are classified in two groups corre- sponding to the division of countries for prescription of cur- rency purposes, i.e., Bilateral Accounts and External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with payments for imports, interest, dividends, and other authorized purposes, with authorized transfers from the nonresident accounts of private firms (including banks) or persons, with proceeds from sales of the currency of the country or monetary area of the account holder, and with proceeds from sales of the cur- rencies of External Account countries. They may be debited for payments for exports and for other payments to residents of India. These accounts may also be debited for transfers to nonresident accounts of persons and firms (including banks), provided that both the transferor and transferee accounts are of External Account countries. Transfers may be made from External Accounts to other External Accounts. All other entries on Bilateral and External Accounts, with the excep- tion of debits by way of payments to residents, require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Ordinary nonresident accounts of private individuals or firms may be credited, without prior approval, for payment of dividends and interest on securities, shares, and deposits; refunds of amounts previously debited or overcharged; pro- ceeds of remittances in appropriate foreign currency or trans- fers from appropriate nonresident banks' rupee accounts (see section on Prescription of Currency, above); proceeds from checks issued by the Life Insurance Corporation in respect of maturity or death claims and surrender value of policies held by nonresidents, provided that the Corporation certifies that premiums had been received in India in an approved manner and that actuarial reserves are held in India; and proceeds of checks, provided that the aggregate of such credits during a month does not exceed Rs 2,000 and no individual credit is in excess of Rs 750. Where the nonresident account holder is an Indian national, maturity proceeds of all types of securities as well as sale proceeds of securities sold on stock exchanges in India and the repurchase price of units issued by the Unit Trust of India may be freely credited to his account. Where the account holder (in the case of a joint account, any of the account holders) is a foreign national, authorized dealers may freely credit the sale and maturity proceeds of all types of securities and the repurchase price of units, provided that the securities had been originally purchased either out of funds held in the account or by remittance from abroad, and in the 7 However, residents of Nepal have to obtain their foreign exchange requirements from the Nepal Rastra Bank. INDIA case of sale proceeds, that the sale was made on the stock exchange. Ordinary private nonresident accounts, as well as blocked accounts maintained by persons of Indian nationality or ori- gin who are resident abroad, with a balance of Rs 50,000 or less may be freely debited for local payments. Other ordinary private nonresident accounts may be debited without prior approval for such items as payments for premiums on life insurance policies of the account holder or his dependents; all taxes due from the account holder in India; contributions to the National Defence Fund, the Prime Minister's National Relief Fund, or any government-sponsored charity; allow- ances not exceeding Rs 1,000 a month to relatives and depen- dents in India; investments in Indian Government securities and in units issued by the Unit Trust of India; and for checks up to Rs 1,000 a week drawn in favor of beneficiaries resident in India or in favor of the account holder while temporarily resident in India. For ordinary nonresident accounts of Indian nationals or persons of Indian origin, as well as blocked accounts of such persons with balances in excess of Rs 50,000, the holders may draw up to Rs 2,000 a week during their stay and, in addition, a lump sum of up to Rs 10,000 annually may be debited for any purpose during an account holder's stay in India. Other credits and debits require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Transfers are not normally permitted from nonresident accounts of individ- uals or firms to nonresident accounts of banks, unless the amounts originally credited to such accounts could have been transferred abroad. Special regulations cover funds lodged in National Defence Remittance Scheme Special Accounts representing rupee pro- ceeds of inward remittances for the account of nonresidents and rupee proceeds from sales of certificates issued under the Scheme, which expired on May 31, 1966. Balances in such accounts cannot be remitted abroad; they may, however, sub- ject in some cases to prior approval by the Reserve Bank, be invested domestically or be used for other expenditures in India. Withdrawals from such accounts with balances of Rs 50,000 or less held by persons of Indian nationality or origin may be made freely for any payments in India. Nonresident (External) Accounts may freely be opened by authorized dealers in India for persons of Indian nationality or origin resident outside India. They may be freely credited with new funds remitted through banking channels from the country of residence of the account holder. They may also be credited, after approval by the Reserve Bank, with funds from any other nonresident account of the holder, provided such funds are eligible for remittance. The accounts may be freely debited for disbursements in India and for transfer abroad. Interest on moneys standing to the credit of such accounts is exempt from income tax and freely transferable. There are also blocked accounts, to which are credited capital proceeds and payments that are due to nonresidents and may not be remitted abroad. Assets in India of Indian emigrants in excess of the amount allowed to be remitted are also required to be credited to blocked accounts. Balances in blocked accounts may be placed on fixed deposit or invested in Indian rupee securities and shares quoted on stock ex- changes in India (other than bearer securities); the income 205 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA derived from such investments can be remitted to the own- er's country of residence in accordance with the special in- structions issued by the Reserve Bank at the time of opening a blocked account. For Indian nationals who were granted emigration facilities prior to January 1,1963, net income from investments financed from blocked accounts is allowed to be remitted in full. For those granted such facilities between January 1963 and April 1968, remittances of income from assets left behind are limited to Rs 20,000 a year. No income of any kind is remittable to persons who obtained emigration facilities after April 30, 1968. Imports and Import Payments Specified items may be freely imported under an open gen- eral license. Practically all other imports require individual licenses. Imports of specified raw materials, spare parts, and components required by "core" and "priority" industries, in- cluding small-scale industries, and by units in other industries that had an export performance of 10 per cent or more of their production during the previous year, are licensed liberally. Licenses for raw materials and components are issued on a continuing basis generally by way of importers claiming re- plenishment of goods actually consumed during a period of not less than 3 and not more than 12 months. As for spare parts, licenses are issued annually on the basis of prescribed percentages of the c.i.f. value of the imported machinery and of indigenous machinery having imported components. Li- censes to actual users for imports of raw materials, compo- nents, and spare parts are not granted wholly against free foreign exchange, but partly against tied-aid credits from particular countries or against rupees in bilateral clearing accounts. However, a greater preference with respect to the permitted origin of imports is accorded to actual users with specified minimum export performance. Individual licenses may be issued (1) ad hoc, (2) on the basis of quotas allocated to established importers in accordance with their imports in a base period, (3) to actual users on the basis of their require- ments, and (4) to registered exporters in accordance with the import content of their exports. Generally, licenses may be used to import from any coun- try except Namibia (South West Africa), Pakistan, Portugal, Rhodesia, South Africa, and Tibet; imports from these countries are prohibited. 8 Such licenses are referred to as General Currency Area Licenses, as distinct from Specific Licenses, which are issued for capital goods and other supplies against tied aid and are valid only for imports from the country or countries providing the assistance. Single Country Licenses are issued for certain imports from countries with which bilateral trade or payments agreements are in force. Licensing policy generally accords priority to foodstuffs, fertilizers, capital goods, raw materials, and other industrial requirements, while the import of other items is severely lim- ited or prohibited. The import program for the period ending March 31, 1974 contains a prohibited list 9 of 1,015 commod- ities and a list of 394 items that are licensed on a "restricted basis," i.e., in minor amounts and only if comparable domes- tic products either are not available or are inadequate. Licens- ing is in most cases on an annual basis. There are special procedures applicable to imports of capital goods, heavy elec- trical plant, and goods imported to fulfill government con- tracts and for irrigation projects. Favored treatment in allocating foreign exchange for imports of capital goods and equipment is given to "core" industries and "priority" indus- tries. An import replenishment scheme enables registered ex- porters to obtain specified raw materials and other items needed for their export production; these commodities in- clude certain items whose import otherwise is banned. In licensing imports of a capital nature, their essentiality, their potential for earning or saving foreign exchange, and the availability of medium-term or long-term credits for financ- ing such imports are taken into account. Import licenses for machine tools and other capital goods valued at more than Rs 750,000 are not granted until Indian producers have been given an opportunity by public advertisement to supply them; licenses are only issued if offers by domestic producers are disproportionately expensive or unacceptable for other rea- sons, or when no offers are received within 45 days. For certain types of steel castings and forgings, this policy applies to all orders of more than Rs 50,000. Where a valid import license is held, the required exchange is released by an authorized bank on presentation of the exchange control copy of the license. License holders may make payments by opening letters of credit or by remitting against sight drafts. Advance remittances before shipping documents can be submitted are not normally allowed; but in special cases, e.g., imports of machinery and capital goods, where deposits have to be made with overseas manufacturers, the Reserve Bank grants special authorization for advance payment for a part of the value of the import. The import of certain commodities, including foodgrains, certain oils and fats, a number of pharmaceutical products, corkwood, raw cotton, raw jute, cashew nuts, most fertilizers, most nonferrous metals, and many categories of steel is re- served for the Government or state trading enterprises, the most important of which are the State Trading Corporation (STC), the Jute Corporation of India, the Food Corporation of India, Hindustan Steel Ltd., and the Minerals and Metals Trading Corporation. For 1973/74, the number of such com- modities was raised by 20 items to 202 items. In addition, imports of natural rubber, sulphur products, vitamins, and antibiotics are normally arranged under the auspices of the STC. Bulk imports of certain raw materials that are not re- served for the public sector may also be arranged by state agencies, including the Industrial Raw Materials Assistance Centre (IRMAC). In addition to any applicable import duty, imports are subject to an auxiliary duty of 5, 10, or 20 per cent ad valo- rem. Exemptions include foodgrains, raw cotton, tallow, and books. 8 The importation from Nepal of commodities originating in countries other than Nepal or India also is prohibited. 9 Imports of certain prohibited items are permitted either ad hoc or under the import replenishment scheme. 206 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Payments for Invisibles In general, payments abroad for invisibles require ap- proval. Foreign exchange is granted freely for a few such payments, mainly for expenses incidental to trade transac- tions and transfers of recurring contractual obligations. Premiums on insurance policies issued in foreign currency to foreign nationals temporarily resident in India may be paid in rupees or in the currency in which the policy is issued; Indian residents are prohibited from taking out life insurance policies in foreign currencies. Branches of foreign banks are not allowed to transfer abroad any profits arising from the sale of nonbanking assets. Profit remittances by branches of foreign firms established on or after March 1, 1969 require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Remittances of dividends by branches and subsidiaries of foreign companies and by companies in which 40 per cent or more of the shares are held by nonresidents, as well as remittances of dividends on individual nonresident holdings of 25 per cent or more of the shares, also require prior Reserve Bank approval. Remittances of dividends by entirely foreign-controlled companies are limited when re- serves are drawn on to finance the dividends. Otherwise there are no restrictions on the remittance of profits, dividends, and interest to beneficiaries permanently resident outside India (except any income accruing to beneficiaries of the National Defence Remittance Scheme), provided that all current tax and other liabilities in India have been cleared, except where such repatriation rights have been voluntarily surrendered. However, remittances to Indian nationals who were granted exchange facilities for emigration on or after January 1, 1963 but before April 30, 1968 of dividends and interest on shares, securities, and deposits held in India are subject to an overall limit of Rs 20,000 a year and to any special directions given to the person concerned when he was granted emigration facilities. For persons who have been granted emigration fa- cilities afrer April 30, 1968 on grounds of hardship, no remit- tance of income is allowed. Foreign nationals temporarily resident in India on account of their business, profession, or employment are permitted to make reasonable remittances to their own countries to pay insurance premiums, for the support of their families, and for other expenses. Authorized dealers may allow such remit- tances by foreign nationals, other than nationals of the Peo- ple's Republic of China, Pakistan, Portugal, and Rhodesia, to the extent of 50 per cent of net income, subject to a maximum of Rs 2,360 a month (Rs 1,500 a month for nationals of Bangladesh). Requests for the remittance of larger amounts are considered on their merits by the Reserve Bank. Applications for foreign exchange for travel or education abroad are considered on an individual basis and require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Under the Foreign Travel Scheme, 1970, residents are permitted to travel abroad without "P form" formalities provided they have not visited any place outside India, other than Bangladesh, Mauritius, Nepal, or Sri Lanka, during the period of three years immedi- ately preceding the date of the journey; if traveling by Indian carrier on a round-trip ticket, they are entitled to foreign exchange up to US$ 100 or its equivalent. The scheme is appli- INDIA cable to all destinations except Bangladesh, Mauritius, Ne- pal, and Sri Lanka. Under a Mauritius Travel Scheme, substantially the same facilities are available for travel to Mauritius, except that any visits to Mauritius with either a grant of foreign exchange by the Reserve Bank or passage booked with the prior approval of the Reserve Bank, as well as visits to other countries under the Foreign Travel Scheme, are to be ignored for determining the traveler's eligibility under the three-year rule. There are no restrictions on travel to Bangladesh and Nepal, while passages may be booked freely for air travel from Madras, Tiruchirapalli, or Trivandrum to Colombo, Sri Lanka. The schemes mentioned do not preclude access to other travel facilities (for purposes such as business travel or attendance at conferences or seminars, etc.) that may be approved under normal procedures. Foreign exchange for tourist travel, how- ever, is not normally granted except under the two schemes mentioned above. Travel agents and airlines and steamship companies are not permitted to book passage abroad for persons resident in India (other than foreign nationals tempo- rarily resident in India) unless the traveler is eligible under the Foreign Travel Scheme or the Mauritius Travel Scheme, has been granted travel exchange by the Reserve Bank, or has been specifically granted permission by the Reserve Bank to book his passage. 10 Travel abroad to attend conferences is unrestricted provided expenses are covered by the host insti- tution. The export of Indian currency notes and coins, except to Nepal, is, in general, prohibited. The export to Nepal of Indian currency notes in denominations of Rs 100 or higher is also prohibited. Deck passengers to Burma, Malaysia, Sin- gapore, Persian Gulf ports, and East Africa and passengers to Bangladesh, Pakistan, or Sri Lanka may take with them Rs 20 a person at any one time in Indian notes and coins (within the limit of Rs 30 for Indian and foreign currency notes combined). Residents may take out foreign notes and coins up to £ stg. 3.50 or its equivalent a person; exchange bureaus of authorized dealers and authorized money changers at airports and seaports are permitted to sell foreign currency notes up to a value of £ stg. 3.50 or its equivalent a person to all passengers, whether Indian or foreign, but not to deck passengers or travelers proceeding to Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, or Sri Lanka, or to foreign nationals who are transit passengers or passengers holding open-dated tickets (including return tickets) issued outside India. Travelers to Pakistan may take Pakistan rupees in notes or coins up to the equivalent of Rs 30 a person; travelers to Sri Lanka and deck passengers to Burma, Malaysia, Singapore, Persian Gulf 10 Prior permission to book passages abroad is not necessary, however, for the following: deck passengers to or from Burma, Malaysia, Pakistan, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Persian Gulf ports, or East Africa; UN staff members and their families whose tickets are purchased by or on instruction from UN agencies; staff of airline and steamer companies traveling on official duty, and families of such staff posted on du ty abroad on a long-term basis; foreign diplomatic personnel stationed in India; families of persons gainfully employed abroad proceeding to join the head of the family or persons gainfully employed abroad returning to their country of employment after a visit to India, provided the fares are paid abroad; employees of Indian insurance companies and banks posted on duty with their branches abroad and their families; persons employed by foreign governments provided the fares are paid abroad; travel between India and Pakistan by persons holding restricted travel documents issued by the High Commission for Pakistan in India or India-Pakistan passports; air travel between Madras /Tiruchirapalli /Trivandrum and Colombo, Sri Lanka; and travel between India and Nepal and between India and Bangladesh. 207 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA ports, or East Africa may take £ stg. 1.50 a person. Nonresi- dents may take out the foreign currency which they declared on entry, less the amounts sold to authorized dealers and authorized money changers in India. A foreign travel tax, at the rate of 15 per cent on first class fares and 10 per cent on economy/tourist class fares, is pay- able where the fare for an international journey is paid in Indian currency; tickets paid for in foreign exchange are ex- empt from the levy. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are required for only a few items, and most commodities may be exported without a license. Most of the controlled commodities are licensed freely to all shippers; a few may be exported through established shippers; and a few commodities are subject to export quotas. Exports to Namibia (South West Africa), Pakistan, Portugal, Rhodesia, South Africa, and Tibet are prohibited. Exchange control is exercised over the proceeds of exports to countries other than Bhutan and Nepal. An exporter must declare that the full export proceeds will be received and dealt with in accordance with the prescription of currency regula- tions. Foreign exchange holdings, including the proceeds of ex- ports, in most currencies ll must be offered for sale against rupees to an authorized dealer, unless the holder has been authorized by the Reserve Bank to retain them, or he is a foreign national not permanently resident in India and the funds do not represent the proceeds of an export. Export proceeds must be surrendered within six months of shipment or, if the goods are sold to Afghanistan or Pakistan, within three months of shipment. The Reserve Bank may allow an extension of the six-month period where exports of capital goods or engineering goods are concerned. Some major exports, including ju te manufactures, are sub- ject to export duties. Exports of mica, tobacco, handwoven woolen carpets, and lac are subject to minimum prices. Some exports receive cash assistance; they are mainly new manufac- tures, such as engineering goods. The cotton textile industry also receives cash assistance. An import replenishment scheme provides preferential import licensing facilities for producers of manufactured goods for export. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles in most currencies 11 must be sur- rendered. All bills rendered by hotels to foreign tourists and to nonresident Indian nationals, other than bills rendered to nationals of Bilateral Account countries, Bhutan, and Nepal, and such other foreign nationals and nonresident Indians as are specifically exempted from compliance with this rule by the Indian Government, must be collected by the hotels in foreign currency. The import of Indian currency notes and coins is, in gen- eral, prohibited. However, deck passengers from Burma, Ma- 11 Canadian dollars, U.S. dollars, most Western European currencies (including sterling), Djibouti francs, East African shillings, Hong Kong dollars, Iraqi dinars, Malaysian dollars, Moroccan dirhams, Panamanian balboas, Philippine pesos, Tunisian dinars, and Vietnamese piastres. 208 laysia, Singapore, Persian Gulf ports, and East Africa, and travelers from Pakistan and Sri Lanka, may import into India Rs 20 a person against presentation of evidence that they previously had exported this amount from India. Persons coming to India from Burma, other than deck passengers, are allowed to bring in Indian currency notes up to a value of Rs 50 for an adult and Rs 25 for a child between the ages of 12 and 18. Travelers from Nepal may bring in up to Rs 75 a person. Foreign currency notes may be brought into India without limit, provided that a declaration of the total amount brought in is made to the customs authorities upon arrival if the value of foreign notes and coins together with the value of the travelers checks brought in exceeds US$1,000 or its equivalent. Persons holding foreign currency notes may sell them to any authorized dealer in foreign exchange or to any authorized money changer. Capital Inward capital transfers are, in general, unrestricted, but their subsequent utilization in India in most cases is subject to approval. Foreign investments, once admitted, are eligible for the same treatment that Indian enterprises receive. Banks in India may borrow freely from their branches and correspondents abroad, provided that borrowings in excess of Rs 2 million are utilized for the purchase of rupees from the Reserve Bank or in the interbank market to finance their normal business operations in India; repayment of such bor- rowings requires the prior approval of the Reserve Bank and may be effected only when the debtor bank has no outstand- ing borrowings in India from the Reserve Bank or any other bank. Foreign borrowing by nonbank Indian companies is sub- ject to Reserve Bank approval; only in exceptional cases is permission granted for any loan which has not been obtained as an official or officially guaranteed credit by the Central Government. Reserve Bank permission is required for initiating, expand- ing, or continuing in India any business activity, or holding or acquiring shares of any company carrying on a trading, commercial, or industrial activity in India, by nonresidents, noncitizens, nonbank companies not incorporated under Indian law, and Indian companies with over 40 per cent nonresident interest. The Reserve Bank will allow the latter companies to continue their activities, provided Indian partic- ipation is not less than 26 per cent of the equity of the com- pany and the company is engaged in production in "core" industries, in predominantly export-oriented production (i.e., at least 60 per cent of output for exports), or in manufacturing activities which require sophisticated technology; tea planta- tions are included among companies benefiting from this pro- vision. Companies engaged predominantly in trading activities or not meeting the other criteria listed will be re- quired to reduce their foreign shareholding to 40 per cent within a specified period or convert their character to meet the above criteria or wind up their activities in India. In exceptional cases, companies not meeting the criteria but which have developed skills, expertise, or facilities, or use technologies, not indigenously available may be permitted ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution greater than 40 per cent foreign participation, provided that the latter does not exceed 76 per cent. Branches of foreign companies other than airlines and shipping companies must in all cases convert themselves into Indian companies. All companies are subject to "dilution" formulas, as fol- lows: companies with foreign direct holdings exceeding 75 per cent must raise 40 per cent of the estimated cost of expansion through additional equity capital issued to Indians; for com- panies with foreign holdings above 60 per cent but below 75 per cent, and above 51 per cent but below 60 per cent, the corresponding proportions are 33V3 per cent and 25 per cent, respectively. No fresh foreign equity is permitted in compa- nies engaged predominantly in internal trading and commer- cial activities. Without the permission of the Reserve Bank, residents are prohibited from lending to, or depositing money with, a nonbank firm or company in which the nonresident interest is more than 40 per cent. Noncitizens, non-Indian firms, and nonbank Indian firms with more than 40 per cent foreign participation must obtain Reserve Bank permission in order to acquire, hold, transfer, or dispose of immovable property within India (except when a lease for a period of not more than five years is involved). Nonresidents besides the above categories of persons and companies must obtain Re- serve Bank permission to allow the use of their trademarks by others for any consideration, and to obtain or continue em- ployment in India as agent or technical or management ad- viser of Indian persons or companies. Residents are prohibited from engaging in any transaction which increases the nonresident share of a business outside India in which the nonresident interest is 49 per cent or less, and they are prohibited, except with Reserve Bank permis- sion, from holding, acquiring, transferring, or disposing of immovable property outside India (except where a lease of not more than five years is involved). Residents also require Reserve Bank approval for transferring any interest in a busi- ness in India to a nonresident, a noncitizen, a nonbank com- pany not incorporated under Indian law, or an Indian company with over 40 per cent foreign participation. Further- more, Reserve Bank approval is required for residents export- ing Indian securities to any place outside India and transferring Indian securities to nonresidents. Residents are prohibited—except with Central Government or Reserve Bank permission —from guaranteeing the obligation of a non- resident or the obligation of a resident in favor of a nonresi- dent, and are also prohibited, except with Central Government permission, from associating with or participat- ing in any business concern outside India. Capital invested in approved projects after January 1, 1950 by residents of other countries, including capital appreciation on the original investment, may be repatriated at any time; the public has been advised, however, to obtain the Reserve Bank's prior approval before effecting a sale when repatria- tion of the assets may exceed Rs 1 million. The proceeds of approved sales are allowed to be remitted in installments, usually of Rs 1 million a year, when the amounts sought to be repatriated are significant. The proceeds from liquidated foreign investments not eligible for repatriation are blocked (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). INDIA Indian nationals (including persons permanently resident in India) are not normally granted any foreign exchange facil- ities for emigration purposes. In exceptional cases of hard- ship, foreign exchange may be released up to a limit of the equivalent of Rs 25,000 in one lump sum at the time of emigration; the remainder of the emigrant's assets and income are blocked and no further remittances, including pensions, if any, are allowed. Foreign nationals who are temporarily resident in India (other than foreign diplomatic personnel and Bangladesh, Chinese, Pakistani, Portuguese, and Rhodesian nationals) are permitted at the time of their retirement to transfer to their own countries the proceeds from the sale of their investments, subject to a limit of Rs 100,000 for each family at the time of retirement and the remainder in annual installments not exceeding Rs 30,000, provided that the shares and securities concerned are quoted on recognized stock exchanges in India; in addition, they may transfer all their current remit table assets in India. Bangladesh nationals temporarily resident in India are permitted to transfer, be- sides their current assets in full, the sale proceeds of their capital assets up to a limit of Rs 50,000 for each family at the time of their retirement, and the remainder in annual install- ments of Rs 20,000. There are no restrictions on the import into India of Indian or foreign securities. The acquisition, sale, transfer, export, or other disposal of foreign securities requires approval. Persons resident in India are permitted to hold foreign securities that have been acquired in a manner not involving a breach of the Indian exchange regulations; residents, other than foreign nationals not permanently resident in India, who are private persons are not normally permitted to purchase securities or personal real estate outside India. Indian nationals resident abroad and wishing to return to India to take up employment or to set up small industrial units are upon application exempted, for a period of three years, from the requirement that any foreign currency bal- ances in their possession be surrendered within 30 days of arrival. As an alternative to holding such balances in the form of foreign currency, the holder may use the funds for the import, subject to import license, of equipment and capital goods. Furthermore, these persons have the option of surren- dering their balances immediately, with the right to reacquire them within three years in the event of their deciding to go back to a foreign country. These various facilities are not available in respect of earnings arising from employment abroad with any Indian-owned organization. Gold Detailed control is exercised over the manufacture, acquisi- tion, possession, and disposal of gold in various forms through a Gold Control Administrator. There is a total ban on private possession of primary gold. Although there is no ban on possession of finished articles of gold (including coins) previously declared, there is restriction on their manufacture and fresh acquisition. There is no restriction on the manufac- ture, acquisition, disposal, or possession of gold ornaments, except that holdings of such ornaments (which may be of any purity) above specified limits are subject to the requirement 209 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA of declaration. The consumption of gold by industrial users is regulated through permits and authorizations. Control is exercised over dealers and goldsmiths through a system of licensing. Gold refining is under state management. The Gov- ernment Mint is licensed under the Gold Control Law to accept tenders of gold for purposes of refining and conversion into standard gold bars, for which strict specifications as to fineness, weight, dimensions, and markings are prescribed. Forward trading in gold or silver is prohibited, as is the export of silver. 12 With the exception of jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler, imports of gold in any form by residents other than the monetary authorities require special authoriza- tion from the Reserve Bank and are not normally permitted; established jewelers, however, are from time to time granted licenses to import gold for the manufacture in their work- shops of jewelry for export. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry produced in India for export and jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler are prohibited unless the export is made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. The export of gold ornaments and jewelry to the Bilateral Account countries and Pakistan is prohibited. Changes during 1973 January 1. A special clearing arrangement for travel expen- ditures was added to the existing payments agreement with Bangladesh. The arrangement provided for settlements in nonconvertible Indian rupees. January 1. Following the expiration on December 31, 1972 of the bilateral payments agreement with Yugoslavia, settle- ments with that country took place in convertible currencies, with certain exceptions for existing import and export con- tracts. The amount of Indian currency notes and coins that residents traveling to Bangladesh for business and pri- vate visits could take with them freely was reduced from Rs 500 to Rs 20 a person a trip. Circular No. 2 withdrew, with effect from February 1, the general permission granted to autho- rized dealers to open freely, without any exchange control formalities, rupee accounts in the names of residents of for- mer East Pakistan temporarily resident in India; the accounts of such persons who had returned to Bangladesh would be treated as nonresident accounts with effect from February 1. January 13. The Reserve Bank would henceforth entertain requests from authorized dealers for extensions of forward sterling purchase contracts only near the due date of the contract, and in any case not earlier than two weeks before the due date. January 31. The trade agreement of 1939 with the United Kingdom expired. February 12. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the Reserve Bank suspended its spot and forward purchases of U.S. dollars. On February 13, 12 With effect from February 19, 1974, the prohibition on exports of silver was lifted. On February 21, it was announced that exports of silver would be subject to license but not to quantitative restrictions. 210 the Bank suspended its forward purchases of sterling, while continuing to purchase and sell sterling for ready delivery in dealings with authorized dealers at the rates prevailing on February 12. However, these rates were treated as provi- sional. Authorized dealers were instructed to restrict their transactions in foreign currencies and to put through transac- tions for amounts above Rs 2,000 on a provisional basis, except in the case of the bona fide and unavoidable require- ments of travelers (up to the equivalent of Rs 2,000 a trav- eler). The February 12 rates for the Reserve Bank's spot purchases and sales of sterling were subsequently treated as final, with retrospective effect from February 13. The Indian rupee continued to float with sterling. February 16. The Reserve Bank resumed its purchases of spot U.S. dollars, but only as cover in respect of authorized dealers' purchases in the form of banknotes and travelers checks; it was prepared to purchase any surplus U.S. dollars from authorized dealers at a special rate of Rs 7.60 per U.S. dollar, against purchases of U.S. dollar banknotes and trav- elers checks made by the authorized dealer concerned at rates not lower than those prescribed on the same date by the Reserve Bank. (The prescribed rates were modified on May 16 and on several occasions subsequently.) February 16. The limit of Rs 2,000 on foreign currency transactions of authorized dealers with the public (including travelers) was withdrawn. Authorized dealers were also per- mitted to conduct all transactions on the basis of firm rates. March 8. The Reserve Bank resumed its forward purchases of sterling, for periods up to six months only, at the same rates as before February 13. Forward contracts initially made for three months could be extended for a further period of three months. March 20. A 10 per cent export duty was imposed on tanned cattle hides. March 26. Exports of cotton yarn were suspended until July 1, except under existing approved contracts. No new contracts for shipment before September 1 could be entered into. March 28. The trade agreement with Bangladesh, which had been in force from March 28, 1972, was extended up to June 27, 1973. On June 28 it was further extended up to September 27, 1973. April 1. The import policy for 1973/74 came into effect. Changes in import policy included (1) for exporters of manu- factures who had doubled their exports between 1971/72 and 1972/73, the value limit for the import of restricted items was raised from 5 per cent to 10 per cent of export value; (2) 11 industries were added to the list of priority industries; (3) nonpriority industries became subject to the scheme of com- pulsory export obligation, by which large-scale units failing to export 5 per cent of their production are liable to a reduc- tion in their import licenses and are no longer granted prefer- ences with regard to sources of supply; (4) units exporting at least 10 per cent of their production were made eligible for preferred sources of supply and other import privileges, while units exporting at least 25 per cent were to receive substan- tially greater preference in these regards; (5) small-scale units in nonpriority industries were to be granted import licenses for a value 20 per cent higher than the year before, while ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution import entitlements for new units in the small-scale sector were raised from 30 per cent to 40 per cent of the value of initial investment in machinery; (6) provisions for the import of machinery by exporters were liberalized; (7) the scheme of eligible export houses was enlarged to enable small-scale units to set up consortia for exporting their products; (8) 20 com- modities were added to the list of imported items channeled through state trading agencies, increasing the number of these items to 202; (9) 220 items were added to the list of prohibited imports; (10) 55 items were added to the restricted list; and (11) the import quotas for 26 items were reduced. April 1. Several important changes in import duties came into effect. They included the following: (1) auxiliary import duties were introduced of 20, 10, and 5 per cent, applying, respectively, to imports with effective ad valorem duties of 100 per cent or more, 60 per cent to 100 per cent, and less than 60 per cent, with the main exemptions being for food- grains, raw cotton, tallow, and books; these duties replaced the previous "regulatory duties" which had ranged from 2.5 per cent to 10 per cent; (2) rates of duty bound under the GATT were revised upward on 42 items; and (3) duties were increased also on a number of other items, including raw cotton, stainless steel plates, sheets, and strips, copper, and machinery. April 1. Exports of goods of Bhutanese origin to countries other than Nepal were required to be declared on prescribed exchange control forms of a distinctive color, to facilitate the transfer of the foreign exchange proceeds to Bhutan. April 1. The export of manganese ore containing more than 46 per cent manganese was suspended. April 1. The suspension of exports of mustard seed, rape- seed, and mustard oil was continued for the 1973/74 licensing period. April 16. Exports of fertilizers, including superphosphates, were banned. April 21. Remittances that may be effected by authorized dealers on behalf of Indian newspapers and magazines in payment of copyright materials, special articles, news photos, or pictures contributed by persons permanently resident out- side India were limited to £ stg. 15 an article or item and to cases where the beneficiary was an individual. April 28. The export du ty on "black" iron ore was raised from Rs 4 to Rs 7 a ton. May 8. Authorized dealers required the Reserve Bank's approval before transferring from one branch to another the accounts of branches in India of foreign firms, companies, or other organizations, or of firms in India controlled by persons resident outside India. May 11. The limits on the release of foreign exchange for business travel to Bangladesh were raised to the levels appli- cable to visits to countries other than the United States and Canada. June 4. The value limit of the general permission granted to Indian residents to take at any one time out of India (except to Pakistan) personal jewelry made mainly or wholly of gold was raised from Rs 2,000 to Rs 5,000. June 5. The cover facility available from the Reserve Bank since February 16 in respect of authorized dealers' purchases of U.S. dollar banknotes and travelers checks was withdrawn. INDIA June 12. The export duty on carpet backing was reduced from Rs 300-700 a ton to Rs 200-300 a ton. June 26. A 25 per cent export duty was imposed on raw wool. July 1. The ban on exports of cotton yarn was continued, except for certain specified varieties, until July 31 or until such further time as might be decided. July 5. A "two-tier agreement" including a "balanced trade and payments agreement" was signed with Bangladesh. It came into effect on September 28, 1973, when the trade and payments agreement of March 28, 1972 expired, which had provided for "three-tier arrangements." Trade between the two countries in listed commodities up to earmarked values was placed on a balanced basis for a period of three years; such trade was to be settled through special accounts at two designated banks. Other trade with Bangladesh would be settled in sterling or other convertible currencies. The provi- sion for border trade in small quantities of specified commod- ities, which existed in the earlier trade agreement, was discontinued. July 27. Exports of rayon filament yam were banned. July 30. Restrictions were placed on the export of indige- nous raw wool during the 1973/74 licensing period. August 20. The Reserve Bank was prepared to purchase sterling forward for delivery up to 9 months. One or more extensions of a forward contract (which could be initially for 3, 6, or 9 months' delivery) would be permitted, for both existing and fu ture contracts, subject to the condition that the total period of delivery should not exceed 12 months, from the date of the original contract. August 27. Authorized dealers were required to submit authenticated copies of the relevant firm export orders (against which foreign exchange had been purchased by the authorized dealers from their customers) with all offers of forward sterling to the Reserve Bank of £ stg. 150,000 or more. August 28. The export du ty on hessian was reduced from Rs 600 to Rs 200 a ton. The export duty on sacking was abolished. September 3. The Reserve Bank resumed its purchases of U.S. dollars, both spot and forward, the latter for three months' delivery only. Spot dollars would be purchased at the cross rate between the London market's spot buying rate for the U.S. dollar at the close of the preceding working day and the Reserve Bank's spot buying rate for the pound sterling on the date of purchase. The Reserve Bank's forward buying rate for the U.S. dollar would be determined in a similar manner. Deliveries under forward sale contracts for three months en- tered into by the authorized dealers were to be made only on the due date indicated on the contracts. September 19. The Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973 was enacted, replacing with effect from January 1, 1974 the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947. It was published in the Official Gazette on September 20. The new or modified provisions of this Act were as follows: (1) Legal sanctions were provided against false invoicing of imports or exports and against remittances of funds into India through unofficial channels. The Central Government was given the right to specify goods which, if exported on a consignment basis, 211 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA could not (without Reserve Bank permission) be sold at a price less than the price declared at time of shipment. (2) The Reserve Bank was given the right to block securities of per- sons who had emigrated abroad as well as the bank accounts and securities of prospective emigrants. (3) The Central Gov- ernment was given the right to require payment in foreign exchange for specific goods and services from persons resi- dent outside India who are on a visit to India, and to exempt any person or class of persons from this requirement. (4) Residents were prohibited, without Reserve Bank permission, from holding, or engaging in any transactions with respect to, immovable property outside India; exempt from this provi- sion was the acquisition or transfer of such property by lease for a period not over five years. (5) Residents were prohibited from engaging without Reserve Bank permission in any transaction which increased to more than 49 per cent the nonresident share of a business outside India in which the nonresident interest was 49 per cent or less. (6) Residents were prohibited from transferring, without Reserve Bank permission, any interest in a business in India to a nonresident, a noncitizen, a nonbank company not incor- porated under Indian law, or any company in India with a nonresident interest of more than 40 per cent. (7) Residents were prohibited, except with Reserve Bank permission, from giving a guarantee in respect of any obligation of a nonresi- dent or in respect of any obligation of a resident due or owing to a person resident outside India. (8) Residents were prohib- ited, except with Reserve Bank permission, from lending to, or depositing money with, a nonbank firm or company in which the nonresident interest is more than 40 per cent. (9) Residents were prohibited, without Central Government per- mission, from associating with, or participating in, any busi- ness concern outside India. (10) Nonresidents, noncitizens, nonbank companies not incorporated under Indian law, and companies with over 40 per cent nonresident interest, could not take up new employment or continue to be employed in India as agent or technical or management adviser of Indian persons or companies without Reserve Bank permission. (11) Compensation for the use in India of trademarks be- longing to the four categories of persons or companies listed in (10) above was made subject to Reserve Bank permission. (12) Reserve Bank permission was made mandatory for car- rying on in India any activity of a trading, commercial, or industrial nature, or establishing a place of business in India for such purposes, or acquiring the whole or any part of any undertaking in India (including the purchase of shares) by the four categories of persons or companies listed in (10) above. Reserve Bank permission would be required even for continu- ing already established businesses of the type described or continuing to hold shares already acquired. However, the Reserve Bank was empowered to exempt both specific indi- viduals (or companies) and classes of individuals (or compa- nies) from the requirement of obtaining its permission for continuing already established businesses or continuing to carry on activities of the types described. (13) Reserve Bank permission was made mandatory for non-Indian nationals taking up any employment, practising any profession, or car- rying on any occupation in India, in cases where the individ- ual involved wished to acquire foreign exchange in order to 212 remit abroad earnings from such activities. (14) The four categories of persons and companies listed in (10) above were prohibited, unless with Reserve Bank permission, from ac- quiring, holding, transferring, or disposing of any immovable property in India, except in the case of acquisition or transfer of such property by a lease for a period not exceeding five years. September 24. Dealings in U.K. and U.S. banknotes be- tween authorized dealers and authorized money changers were allowed to take place at rates determined by market conditions, as in the case of other foreign currency notes. This was done to enable money changers to offer their customers, in the same way as authorized dealers could, better dollar and sterling rates than the maximum and minimum rates laid down from time to time by the Reserve Bank. September 26. The Reserve Bank henceforth would pur- chase U.S. dollars forward also for one, two, and six months* delivery. Delivery three days before the due date would be accepted for one, two, or three-month forward contracts, and seven days before the due date for six-month forward contracts, without any adjustment in the contract rates. The rate for the Reserve Bank's forward purchases of U.S. dollars for delivery on completion of one month or two mon ths would be the cross rate between the London mar- ket's buy ing rate for forward dollars for the appropriate deliv- ery at the close of the preceding working day and the Reserve Bank's buying rate for forward sterling for three months' delivery ruling on the day of purchase. The rate for the pur- chase of six months' forward dollars would be based on the London market forward buying rate for six months' dollars and the Reserve Bank's buying rate for six months' forward sterling. October 1. Residents of India holding sums in pound ster- ling accounts prior to July 8, 1947 ("pre-zero accounts"), who had been permitted to maintain these accounts in sterling and to make foreign or domestic transfers out of them without special permission from the Reserve Bank, were required to repatriate before November 1, 1973 any balances held in such accounts unless they obtained special permission from the Reserve Bank to maintain such accounts and operate thereon. October 3. Imports of hides, skins, and tanning substances were permitted under Open General License until March 31, 1974. October 20. Exports of raw silk were suspended until De- cember 31, 1973. October 23. The Central Government appointed January 1, 1974 as the date on which all sections of the Foreign Ex- change Regulations Act, 1973 would come into force. December 13. An agreement with the United States was initialed under which that country would relinquish its claim to the major part of its rupee holdings; the agreement was signed on February 18, 1974. December 17. A commercial cooperation agreement was signed with the EEC. It came into force on April 1, 1974. December 20. The Ministry of Finance published guidelines for administering the foreign investment provisions of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973. Like the Act itself, these guidelines were to be put into effect on January 1, 1974. Major features of these guidelines were as follows: (1) All ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution branches of foreign companies, except airlines and shipping companies, would be required to convert themselves into Indian companies. (2) Indian companies with more than 40 per cent foreign shareholding engaged in production of prior- ity industries, or exporting at least 60 per cent of their total production, or engaged in manufacturing requiring sophisti- cated technology, or consisting of tea plantations, would be permitted to continue their activities if they increased Indian participation to not less than 26 per cent within a specified period. (3) Indian manufacturing and trading companies with more than 40 per cent foreign shareholding, and not engaged in the activities specified in (2), would be required either to bring their foreign shareholding down to 40 per cent within a specified period or to change their character to predomi- nantly manufacturing activities of the type listed in (2); cer- tain exceptions might be made where such companies had developed expertise or facilities not indigenously available and were contributing significantly to exports. (4) Indian manufacturing companies with more than 40 per cent foreign shareholding engaged in trading activities in respect of prod- ucts not manufactured by them would be permitted to trade products in the overall interest of the consumers provided the value of such products did not exceed 25 per cent of the value of total production or Rs 50 million, whichever was less. NOTE.—The following changes came into effect early in 1974: January 1. The Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973 came into force (see September 19 entry, above). The Ministry of Finance guidelines on the foreign investment provisions of the Act also came into force (see December 20, above). The Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947 was revoked. January 1. The Reserve Bank issued two Press Notes and a Circular to authorized dealers regarding Sections 28 and 29 of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973. In terms of these sections, persons resident outside India (including Indian citizens), foreign citizens resident in India, and compa- nies (other than banking companies) incorporated abroad or in which the nonresident interest was more than 40 per cent, as well as branches of such companies, were required to ob- tain the permission of the Reserve Bank for the following: Under Section 28: (1) To act, or accept appointment, as agent in India of any person or company, in the trading or commercial transactions of such person or company. (2) To act, or accept appointment, as technical or management ad- viser in India of any person or company. (3) To permit any trademark, which the said persons or companies are entitled to use, to be used by any other person or company for any direct or indirect consideration. Under Section 29: (1) To carry on in India any activity of a trading, commercial, or industrial nature. (2) To establish in India a branch, office, or other place of business for carry- ing on such activities. (3) To acquire, either wholly or partly, any undertaking in India of a person or company carrying on any trade, commerce, or industry. (4) To purchase shares in India of Indian companies. (5) To continue to hold shares of INDIA Indian companies which were acquired before the commence- ment of the new Act, i.e., prior to January 1, 1974. The permission of the Reserve Bank also was required for the continuance of the arrangements relating to items (1), (2), and (3) under Section 28 above, which were entered into by the said persons or companies prior to January 1, 1974, as also for the continuance of their existing trading, commercial, or industrial activities.
