Not for Redistribution Exchange Rate System Nonresident Accounts INDONESIA No par value for the Indonesian Rupiah has been estab- lished with the Fund. In the Jakarta foreign exchange Bourse, transactions in U.S. dollars are effected at rates within 1 per cent either side of Rp 415 per US$1; on December 31, 1973 the buying and selling rates were Rp 414.50 and Rp 416.00, respectively, per US$1. Exchange rates for other currencies are determined on the basis of the Jakarta rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, and rates for the currencies concerned in international markets. An additional effective exchange rate results from the application of a 10 per cent exchange tax to the proceeds from the export of most com- modities; a 5 per cent exchange tax on the proceeds of exports of coconut oil is ineffective, since at present such exports are prohibited. In the Jakarta foreign exchange Bourse three calls for ex- change are conducted each week under the management of Bank Indonesia. Bidding for exchange in the call is restricted to the foreign exchange banks and licensed foreign exchange dealers. Bank Indonesia is committed to deal with any will- ing buyer or seller at the going rate. Representatives of the foreign exchange banks notify Bank Indonesia of their sup- ply to the market and each presents a bid for the total of his bank's requirements at a particular rate. Bank Indonesia clears the market at the intervention rate. The Bank also offers authorized banks certain facilities for forward contracts in respect of aid exchange and for swap transactions. Sabang is entirely outside the Indonesian exchange and trade control system, but the Indonesian rupiah is legal tender there. It is also legal tender in Irian Jaya (West Irian), where the Irian Barat rupiah has ceased to be legal tender. All laws and regulations concerning foreign exchange and the foreign trade control system are applicable also in Irian Jaya. Administration of Control The implementation of exchange and trade control is en- trusted to Bank Indonesia, the Ministry of Trade, the Minis- try of Finance, authorized foreign exchange banks, and the customs authorities. Exchange control is administered by Bank Indonesia and the Ministry of Finance. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected through the autho- rized banks and are normally effected in convertible curren- cies. Export proceeds must be received in Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Malaysian dollars, Netherlands guilders, New Zealand dollars, Norwegian kroner, Portu- guese escudos, pounds sterling, Singapore dollars, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, or U.S. dollars. Indonesia has no opera- tive payments agreements. * 1 Indonesia maintains an inoperative bilateral payments agreement with the People's Republic of China. No distinction is made between resident and nonresident accounts, as the 1964 Foreign Exchange Act recognizes only foreign nationals and Indonesian nationals. There are no re- strictions on the opening by foreign nationals of accounts in Indonesia in rupiahs or foreign currencies. Imports and Import Payments There is a registry of authorized importers and an initial deposit is required for registration. Since October 31, 1968, only Indonesian nationals may obtain an importer's license, but certain established foreign firms have been enabled to retain their licenses and new foreign investors can obtain an importer's license restricted to the import of materials re- quired for their own projects. Imports from Angola, Rhodesia, and South Africa are pro- hibited, as are imports from all sources of specified commodi- ties, including built-up commercial vehicles and motorcycles; radio and television sets in built-up or seraiknocked-down condition; sarongs; galvanized iron sheets; iron roofing sheets; mosquito sticks; secondhand goods; matches; mono- sodium glutamate; mattresses; and specified types of textiles, car tires, batteries, printed matter, office supplies, animal traps, bottles, and lamps and bulbs. 2 The importing of cloves, fertilizers, rice, refined sugar, and wheat and wheat flour is restricted to specified approved importers. No licenses are required for imports. All permitted imports may be paid for either with general exchange (Devisa Umum) or aid ex- change (Devisa Kredii). For imports financed with aid ex- change a compensation payment is granted after customs clearance; this payment ranges from Rp 20 to Rp 45 per U.S. dollar of the import value, depending on country of origin and/or donor country. Importers may without bank guarantee contract short-term credit under "merchant letters of credit," 3 but otherwise sight letters of credit are required for all private sector imports with the exception of parcel imports, goods brought in by travelers of a value not exceeding US$100, and imports specifically authorized by the Ministry of Trade (such as goods constituting part of a foreign investment). A rupiah deposit of 100 per cent of the amount of the letter of credit must be lodged with Bank Indonesia when a letter of credit is opened in respect of government imports; for non- government imports financed with general exchange, import- ers are required to make an advance deposit of at least 40 per cent of the letter of credit value when they submit applica- tions for letters of credit to authorized banks, and to settle the balance within 75 days of the opening of the letter of credit. Importers' requests for registration of merchant letters of credit with foreign exchange banks must be accompanied by a deposit of 25 per cent of the value. The deposits are released * On January 22, 1974 imports of built-up sedans and station wagon sedans also were prohibited, as were imports of components for the assembly of luxury-type automobiles. 3 A merchant letter of credit is a payments form providing for short-term suppliers' credit. It is not a bankers' letter of credit and carries no commitments on the part of the bank through which it is opened. 215 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDONESIA to the importer only for payment or when he presents corre- spondence from suppliers indicating that the merchant letter of credit has been canceled; if the import is declared free of payment, however, the deposit is released after the issuance of the KPP document. The amount of the deposit against letters of credit for nongovernment imports financed with aid exchange is left to the discretion of the authorized bank if the latter purchases aid exchange forward from Bank Indonesia. Import duties, which are almost without exception ad valo- rem, are imposed on the c.i.f. value of the commodities con- verted at the customs valuation rate (Rp 415 per US$1 on December 31, 1973). Sales taxes of 5, 10, and 20 per cent are levied on most imports on their c. & f. value plus import duty. Items which are exempted from import duties are also ex- empted from sales taxes. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted or subject to control. Proceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered. Travelers may take out and bring in any amount in foreign banknotes but only Rp 2,500 in Indonesian notes and coins other than gold and silver commemorative coins; Indonesian commemorative gold and silver coins may be taken out freely up to Rp 65,000 a person. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Angola, the People's Republic of China, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, as are exports to all countries of gold ore and pure gold; copra; coconut oil; certain types of corn; clove seeds; pepper seeds; fertilizers; rawhides of cattle; certain categories of unpro- cessed or low-quality rubber; certain logs and timber; and scrap bronze, copper, and iron (other than scrap bronze and copper from Irian Jaya). The prior authorization of the Minis- ter of Trade is required for the export of flatbark crepe, cinchona bark, scrap iron (from Java and Madura), silver, and antiques of cultural value. Otherwise, all commodities may be freely exported by registered private firms and state trading firms. All exporters except the petroleum companies, certain min- ing companies, and licensed "border-crossing" traders must require their buyers to open a bank letter of credit covering the value of the goods to be exported. For certain minor exports, including handicrafts, the exporter must surrender the full foreign exchange value prior to shipment if there is no buyer's letter of credit. 4 For the principal export commodi- ties other than petroleum, the sales price must not be lower than "indication" prices ("check" prices) determined periodi- cally by the Minister of Trade. The full proceeds from exports other than petroleum, products of certain mining companies, and goods exported by licensed "border-crossing" traders are subject to surrender (except in "border-crossing" trade, see below) and, except for finished goods, batik textiles and other handicrafts, plywood, fresh fish, and a number of other items, are subject to a 10 per cent exchange tax. Exports of petro- leum and of products of certain mining companies are also 4 There are separate arrangements for exports of orchids. 216 exempt from exchange tax. The exporter settles the tax on receipt of the export proceeds. A specific cess is levied on exports of certain agricultural products and on interisland trading in the same products. Certain commodities produced in border regions may be exported to Malaysia and Singapore in exchange for certain eligible goods. In this "border-crossing" trade, the value of import or export shipments must not exceed MS600 a month, if transported overland, and M$600 a shipment, if trans- ported by sea. Capital The Foreign Capital Investment Law of January 10, 1967, as amended in August 1970, provides various incentives for the investment of foreign capital in Indonesia. Investments in specified fields of activity (including harbors, electric power, shipping, railroads, and commerce) may be undertaken only through a joint venture with an Indonesian partner. 5 The Investment Law specifies a system of investment priorities; it assigns the highest priority to certain specified fields, fol- lowed by investments which are located outside Java, invest- ments which generate or save foreign exchange, and investments in infrastructure. All investments in Indonesia require the approval of the Capital Investment Coordinating Board (BKPM). Enter- prises that are wholly or largely operated in Indonesia as separate business units must be incorporated under Indone- sian law and must have their domicile in Indonesia. The operating permit for foreign investment is usually valid for a maximum of 30 years. Among the inducements offered are exemption from, or reduction in, corporate and dividend taxes for a certain number of years. Joint ventures by Indone- sians and foreigners may benefit from similar tax incentives. Other inducements include exemption from customs duties, accelerated depreciation allowances, and permission to offset initial losses against subsequent profits; foreign investments with a minimum capital of US$15 million may receive addi- tional benefits. Investors are granted the right to transfer profits (after settlement of taxes and financial obligations in Indonesia) and to make transfers relating to expenses con- nected with the employment of foreign nationals in Indone- sia, and in respect of depreciation allowances after the expiration of the tax holiday from corporation tax. The law provides that no transfer permit shall be issued for capital repatriation as long as the investments benefit from tax relief; at present, however, foreign payments do not require a trans- fer permit. The law implicitly provides guarantees against nationalization of foreign investments. Equitable and mutu- ally satisfactory arrangements are stipulated for resolving the issue of just compensation in the event of nationalization of any specific foreign investment. A special regime applies to enterprises previously national- ized but now restored to the original owners. Such enterprises are allowed tax holidays for a period of three years on new capital in foreign currency brought in within the context of rehabilitation and expansion programs that have been ap- 5 On January 22, 1974 this requirement was extended to all new foreign investments in Indonesia. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution proved by the Government. The transfer of proceeds from the sale of the assets of those restored enterprises which ceased operations could take place with effect from January 1, 1972 at the rate of one f i f th of the proceeds each year, with a full guarantee as to their value in foreign currency. The transfer of proceeds from the sale of assets of enterprises whose period of operation has expired or whose operations have been termi- nated by the Government is allowed at the rate of one f i f th a year effective from the time of the sale of assets. This trans- fer is guaranteed as to its value in foreign currency. A Debt Investment Conversion Scheme (DIGS) exists for the benefit of foreign creditors holding nonguaranteed claims against Indonesia. Rupiahs covered by the Scheme are ad- ministered in two kinds of DIGS-Rupiah Accounts, A and B, the former relating only to claims of which the creditor is the first holder. Private creditors willing to accept the terms of the Scheme and prepared to make investments under the Foreign Investment Law of 1967 are paid in rupiahs in settle- ment of their claims. These claims are transferable to other potential investors in Indonesia, but only the original credi- tor's DIGS rupiahs may be used, in the creditor's own projects that have been approved under the Foreign Invest- ment Law of 1967, for the purchase of foreign exchange for the import of equipment and raw materials necessary for the establishment and operation of those projects. There are no limitations on the remittance to Indonesia of capital in the form of foreign exchange or in commodities. Both residents and nonresidents may hold foreign currency deposits with foreign exchange banks. Foreign exchange banks, however, are subject to Bank Indonesia directives with respect to borrowing abroad, the acceptance of deposits from nonresidents, and the issuance of certificates of deposit to nonresidents. Furthermore, a uniform reserve requirement of 30 per cent is applicable to the foreign currency liabilities of the foreign exchange banks. Certain other borrowing abroad is subject to direct control. The prior approval of the Minister of Finance is required before any public enterprise or public sector body may accept a loan from abroad. Indonesian citizens and residents of foreign nationality may freely transfer, negotiate, import, and export securities denominated in rupiahs or in foreign currency. Gold Indonesia has issued five commemorative gold coins, which are legal tender. Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold and gold coins in Indonesia. Exports of gold ore and pure gold, unless made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, are prohibited by virtue of Decision No. 6 8 /K P / IV / 70 of April 17, 1970 of the Minister of Trade. Travelers may freely take out Indonesian commemorative gold and silver coins up to Rp 65,000 a person; amounts in excess require the prior approval of Bank Indonesia. Imports of gold are free of license but require prior notification to the Ministry of Industry and are subject to an extra levy of Rp 25 per US$1. INDONESIA Changes during 1973 During the year a number of minor exports were exempted from the 10 per cent exchange tax. The export cesses levied on a number of other commodities, including some major exports, were increased. January 31. A new import tariff came into force, based on the Brussels Tariff Nomenclature. February 12. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the exchange rate of Rp 415 = US$1 was maintained unchanged. March 20. The export cesses on certain types of copra were increased. March 31. The Irian Barat rupiah ceased to be legal tender in Irian Jaya. April 1. Exports of rawhides of cattle were prohibited. April 12. A uniform reserve requirement of 30 per cent became applicable to the liabilities denominated in foreign exchange of foreign exchange banks, including all advance import deposits. The existing differential requirements were abolished. May 1. The advance import deposit requirement for non- government imports financed with general foreign exchange was reduced from 100 per cent to 40 per cent. May 18. Bank Indonesia prohibited the opening of usance letters of credit by foreign exchange banks. May 22. Detailed regulations were issued for the implemen- tation of Presidential Decree No. 59/1972 of October 12, 1972. They related to procedures for the approval and report- ing of foreign credits with a maturity in excess of one year (except when obtained from international institutions) and shorter-term "roll-over" credits. June 1. A Capital Investment Coordinating Board (BKPM) was established to replace the Technical Committee on Capital Investment and its subcommittees (the Foreign Investment Board and the Domestic Investment Board). The BKPM would be responsible for approving all domestic and foreign investment in Indonesia. June 6. Exports of fertilizers were prohibited. July 1. Exports of rawhides of sheep and goats were prohib- ited. July 4. Exports of certain types of com and cassava were prohibited. August 1. The BKPM reaffirmed that reporting to Bank Indonesia was required by foreign investors covered by the Foreign Capital Investment Law. The requirement related to the progress of the project, and to all outward transfers ef- fected in respect of profits and dividends, repatriation of capital, and fulfillment of payments obligations. August 1. Exports of copra and of coconut oil were prohib- ited. August 2. For state foreign exchange banks, the definition of "liabilities denominated in foreign exchange" was broad- ened to include rupiah time deposits originating from foreign exchange and owned by resident or nonresident banks, as well as certificates ot deposit sold to nonresident banks. Not for Redistribution Exchange Rate System Nonresident Accounts IRAN1 The par value is 0.0108055 gram of fine gold per Iranian Rial, corresponding to Rls 82.2425 = SDR 1 or Rls 68.1747 = US$1, and Iran avails itself of wider margins. The official rates for the U.S. dollar, the only currency that is officially quoted, are Rls 67.50 buying and Rls 67.75 selling, per US$1. Exchange rates for currencies quoted by the commercial banks 2 are based on these buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar and the exchange rates of the currencies con- cerned in London; the commercial banks are not permitted to quote buying rates of less than Rls 67.493 per US$1 or selling rates higher than Rls 68.850 per US$1, and on Decem- ber 31, 1973 their rates for the U.S. dollar were the same as those at the Bank Markazi Iran (the central bank), subject in certain cases to commissions. The central bank publishes daily exchange rates for 13 currencies 2 for purposes of the calculation of import registra- tion fees and import duties; these rates are based on the official rates for the U.S. dollar and the London market rates for the currencies concerned. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the central bank. In principle, all foreign exchange transactions must take place through authorized banks. The import and export of goods is governed by regulations issued annually by the Ministry of Economy and approved by the Council of Ministers. Import policy is formulated within an overall foreign exchange bud- get. Foreign trade relations with Albania are under the con- trol of the Foreign Transactions Corporation within the Ministry of Economy. Prescription of Currency Transactions with six of the nine countries with which Iran has bilateral payments agreements3 must be conducted through agreement accounts denominated in U.S. dollars, while those with the People's Republic of China, Eastern Germany, and North Korea must be conducted through ac- counts denominated in Iranian rials. Payments to and from Pakistan and Turkey relating to visible trade (excluding bor- der trade, petroleum and petroleum products, and defense materials) are settled over clearing accounts maintained by the respective central banks in U.S. dollars. Proceeds from exports to India may be accepted in Indian rupees. Payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Settlements with other countries normally are settled in the quoted currencies (see footnote 2). 1 This survey presents the position on December 31,1973. Certain important developments that took place in January 1974 are summarized in a note at the end of the survey. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 3 Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, North Korea, Poland, Romania, and U.S.S.R. Foreign nationals are permitted to maintain accounts freely, in rials as well as in foreign currencies, with authorized banks; rial accounts may be freely used only for payments in Iran, their conversion into foreign currencies being subject to central bank approval. Foreign nationals may also maintain time deposits in foreign currencies in Iran. Foreign currency accounts of foreign nationals may be used freely for transfers abroad or for sales to authorized banks, provided that such funds originate abroad. Iranian nationals may freely maintain time deposits in for- eign currencies in Iran; they also may freely retain, on current accounts with domestic banks, all foreign exchange they re- ceive other than export proceeds. Imports and Import Payments All imports into Iran are subject to control by the Govern- ment. The import policy is re-examined annually, and a new Import List, effective for the next Iranian year, is published by the Ministry of Economy. The Import List distinguishes between "authorized," "unauthorized," and "prohibited" goods. "Authorized" imports, consisting of nonluxury goods which either are not produced in Iran or are produced in Iran but not in quantities sufficient to meet domestic require- ments, are divided into two main categories: (1) imports for which orders may be placed without prior approval by gov- ernment agencies, 4 and (2) imports that are subject to prior approval by government agencies (generally the Ministry of Economy) before the import order is placed. "Unauthorized" imports are goods that may be permitted occasionally by the Ministry of Economy when the supply of the protected local product is considered insufficient. For "prohibited" goods, no authorizations are given; these comprise only a few items such as opium and firearms. Imports without payment of "authorized" goods require prior approval by the Ministry of Economy and the central bank; permission is given for the following: imports destined for official charitable institutions or government organiza- tions; machinery, spare parts, and raw or intermediate mate- rials for productive institutions, up to US$500 a shipment; and all other imports of "authorized" goods up to US$150 a shipment. The import of gifts, whether "authorized" or "unauthorized" commodities, is restricted to Rls 10,000 for each person a year. Specified commodities, such as sugar, tobacco, and ciga- rette paper, are imported under state monopoly. Unless otherwise specifically authorized, payment for all commercial imports must be made through the official ex- change market, with foreign exchange obtained from the banking system. Payments may be made either against bills for collection or documentary letters of credit. Payments against bills for collection may be made without authoriza- tion for goods (mainly capital goods and raw materials) listed 4 Exports and imports of goods that are not included in the bilateral export/import list for countries with which Iran has bilateral payments agreements require special approval by the Ministry of Economy. 219 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAN in the Schedule attached to Circular No. 116 of August 3, 1965 (Iranian date 12.5.1344). Payments for imports of other goods required by domestic industries may also be made against bills for collection with special permission from the central bank. All other import payments must be made against documentary letters of credit. All orders for imports must be registered with the central bank through an autho- rized bank; registration is effected against a pro forma invoice. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited and special regula- tions apply to certain commodities when originating in Hong Kong. No import registrations are accepted for commodities originating in Eastern Germany. At the time of registration of imports, an import registra- tion fee of 5.5 per cent of the amount of an import order, calculated on the basis of the official selling rate of Rls 67.75 per US$1, is collected by authorized banks. Imports brought in under the Law for the Attraction and Protection of Foreign Investment in Iran are exempted from the fee, as are some essential imports such as corn and certain vegetable oils. For goods for which payment must be made against a documen- tary letter of credit, importers must at the time of registration deposit with the central bank, through an authorized bank, a deposit of 100 per cent of the invoiced value.5 The deposit is reduced for many commodities to 40 per cent or 15 per cent, depending on their essentiality. The deposit is refund- able upon presentation of the customs clearance certificate after the respective goods have been cleared through customs, or if and when the order is canceled. The advance import deposit is not required for commodities which may be im- ported on a collection basis, whether they are in fact imported against a bill for collection or not. The central bank may permit the shifting of imports from the category in which an advance import deposit is required and financing must be on a letter of credit basis to the category in which bills for collection (with or without advance deposit) are permitted. Authorized banks make payments for permitted imports against the presentation of shipping documents. Approval of the shipping documents by the authorized banks represents approval of the foreign exchange transfer. Almost all imports are subject to commercial profit taxes, which are either specific or ad valorem and are in addition to any applicable customs duty. The ad valorem commercial profit tax ranges from 1 per cent to 200 per cent. Monopoly taxes are included in the commercial profit taxes. The author- ities specify in the Import List the commercial profit taxes for each year. These taxes are paid to the customs before customs clearance. The clearance through customs is authorized upon the presentation of shipping documents endorsed by the au- thorized banks, specifying that payment has been made or will be made, and, when required, that the special import authorization has been received from government agencies prior to lading of goods in the country of origin. 5 The registration deposit also is 100 per cent for all imports permitted under the Export-Import Regulations for the Iranian year 1352 that were unautho- rized in the Iranian year 1351. 220 Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to imports are made on the same basis as payments for those imports. Exchange is granted to merchants for insurance of imports against bills for collection; for imports covered by documentary letters of credit, insurance must be taken out in Iran. Exchange is not granted to merchants for insurance of Iranian exports sold f .o.b. Exchange is not granted for the payment of other insur- ance premiums, although reinsurance premium payments are permitted. Foreign nationals working in Iran as technical assistants whose employment has been recognized as neces- sary by the Government may take out in foreign exchange about 50 per cent of their net salaries. The travel allowance for Iranian nationals, the equivalent of Rls 50,000 a person a trip, may be made available by authorized banks upon presentation of a valid travel document and exit permit; each accompanying member of the passport holder's family is enti- tled to the same allowance, and there is no limit on the number of times an Iranian national may avail himself of this facility. Bona tide requests for additional funds in respect of business travel are granted liberally by the central bank. Banks may sell up to the equivalent of Rls 200,000 a person to Iranian nationals traveling or residing abroad, for medical treatment; additional foreign exchange can be obtained against medical bills certified by an Iranian consul abroad. In addition, authorized banks may at any time sell foreign exchange up to the equivalent of Rls 10,000 against a written request, to Iranian nationals for assistance to persons abroad, or for other personal use without the submission of support- ing documents, provided that the remittance is made in the form of a mail or telegraphic transfer; authorized banks charge a commission of Rls 130 on each such transfer. Iranian nationals may also freely make remittances abroad from do- mestic current accounts in which they retain foreign exchange received from sources other than exports; balances in such accounts are freely transferable. Purchases of foreign cur- rency from the banks for payments in respect of noncommer- cial invisibles not mentioned above require licenses from the central bank. Iranian nationals leaving the country are required to pay a travel tax of Rls 10,000 for each single-voyage exit permit, except for pilgrimage travel, for which the tax is Rls 3,000. Lower rates apply to family members traveling on the same passport (wife and children from 7 to 18 years of age), viz., Rls 750 a person for pilgrimages and Rls 2,500 a person for other travel. Iranians resident abroad and students studying abroad but visiting home temporarily are exempt from pay- ment of the tax. Travelers leaving Iran may take with them Rls 20,000 in Iranian banknotes. Travelers of foreign nationality may not export foreign currency in excess of the amount they im- ported less the amounts they have sold to authorized banks, as recorded in their passports; they may, however, convert rials up to the equivalent of US$100 into other currencies upon presentation of their visaed passport. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports of some com- modities require licenses. A commercial profit tax is imposed on a few exports, mainly consumer goods or raw materials. The commercial profit tax and customs duty charged at the time of import of raw materials contained in manufactured goods for export may be returned to the exporter after the export has taken place. Certain minor exports are granted incentive payments by the Center for the Promotion of Ex- ports. The central bank offers preferential discount facilities for export bills. The exporter must execute an exporters' commitment by which he undertakes to offer for surrender the foreign ex- change value of his exports, as appraised by the customs, within eight months after the goods have been exported. Au- thorized banks accept export proceeds only in specified cur- rencies (see footnote 2) or, for exports to India, in Indian rupees. Exporters who do not have foreign exchange proceeds from exports at their disposal may meet their surrender obli- gation by delivery of either foreign exchange from their own holdings or foreign exchange sold to an authorized bank by a third party; the central bank's permission is required to meet the surrender requirement through these alternative means. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles may be retained in a foreign currency account with an authorized bank, where they remain at the free disposal of the account holder (except for payments in respect of commercial imports). Travelers may freely bring in Rls 20,000, in Iranian bank- notes; higher amounts require the prior approval of the cen- tral bank. The repatriation of Iranian banknotes through the mail is not permitted. Nonresident travelers may sell their exchange only to an authorized bank at the bank's buying rate. Capital Iranian nationals may retain in domestic foreign currency accounts any capital receipts accruing in foreign exchange; transfers abroad from such accounts may be made freely (except for payments in respect of commercial imports), as may domestic transfers to other Iranian nationals. Transfers of capital abroad which would involve the purchase of foreign exchange from the banking system require the approval of the central bank; except as noted below, such approval is given only in exceptional circumstances. In accordance with the Law for the Attraction and Protec- tion of Foreign Investment in Iran (1955) and regulations implementing the law, foreign capital invested in approved development or productive activities in industry, mining, ag- riculture, or transport may be repatriated, together with net profits (in accordance with Article 1 of the Law for the At- traction and Protection of Foreign Investment and the provi- sions contained in the implementing regulations), in the form of foreign exchange and /or goods. Transfers of exchange must be made at the selling rate prevailing at the date of IRAN transfer. However, the central bank has the option of buying the exchange or accepting it as a deposit to be converted into rials at a rate mutually agreed upon in a separate agreement, and this rate is applicable to the funds when they are repatri- ated. Capital imported in the form of foreign exchange must be in currencies acceptable to the central bank; the exchange is converted into rials at the buying rate prevailing at the date of application for conversion. The law does not set up any limit of participation with respect to the ratio of foreign to domestic investment, but the Supervisory Board encourages participation by Iranians in the proposed investment. Gold No Iranian gold coins are legal tender. 6 Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Iran. In practice, all imports of nonmonetary gold are made by the Bank Melli Iran (an authorized commercial bank) and exports are prohibited. The import and export of gold for monetary purposes or for international settlements is reserved for the central bank. Imports of gold for medical and dental purposes, for making medallions or medals, and to meet certain requirements of the Government may be made on the authorization of the Monetary Council through the Bank Melli Iran. Imports of gold and silver jewelry constitut- ing the personal effects of a traveler7 are permitted, as are imports and exports of gold coins in limited amounts by a traveler; the import and export of medals and medallions and of gold and silver coins for numismatic purposes requires the prior authorization of the central bank. Imports of gold are free from customs duty and commercial profit tax but are subject to the 5.5 per cent import registration fee. The weekly quotations of Bank Melli Iran for domestic sales include the import registration fee and a 4 per cent commission. Com- mercial imports of articles containing a minor quantity of gold, such as watches, require licenses issued by the Ministry of Economy. Changes during 1973 January 20. Since the receipt of short-term foreign ex- change credits was contrary to current policy of the central bank, banks were requested to provide the necessary foreign exchange to their correspondents abroad as soon as amounts under letters of credit, bills for collection, or payments orders were due. From time to time during the remainder of 1973 commercial profit taxes and customs duties on many items were reduced, the import ban for many items on the "unauthorized" list was lifted, and the import registration fee was abolished for some basic imports. The allocation for medical treatment abroad was increased from US$2,000 to the equivalent of Rls 200,000. The coverage of the facility under which autho- rized banks could at any time sell foreign exchange for personal remittances was increased from the equivalent of £ stg. 50 to the equivalent of Rls 10,000 for each transfer. The remaining effective surveillance over exchange transactions was limited in principle to capital movements. June 20. The amount in domestic banknotes that travelers could take out freely was increased from Rls 3,000 to Rls 20,000, and the amount they could bring in freely, which previously was unlimited, was also set at Rls 20,000. NOTE.—The following developments took place in January 1974. The text of the above survey has not been updated to take them into account. The central bank of Iran took the following measures on January 10 and 14, 1974, which it instructed banks in Iran to execute immediately: (1) Exporters were exempted from the obligation of execut- ing an exporters' commitment and were given an option ei- ther to sell their foreign exchange earnings to authorized banks at the official rate or to sell these proceeds in the "noncommercial free market." (2) Banks were allowed to purchase foreign exchange earn- ings resulting from exports and services at current market exchange rates and to sell this foreign exchange in any man- ner and for any purpose. (3) Banks could also purchase, either at their own discre- tion or on the basis of central bank regulations, the foreign exchange proceeds from capital transfers, and sell this ex- change in any manner and for any purpose. (4) The central bank stood ready to purchase at the official rate any excess supply of foreign exchange resulting from proceeds of exports and services. (5) Individuals and institutions wishing to sell to the cen- tral bank the foreign exchange proceeds from inward capital transfers and to repurchase these subsequently at the official rate for retransfer abroad, had to obtain the prior approval of the central bank and to abide by any existing regulations prior to making the inward transfer. (6) Provided they observed the relevant central bank regu- lations, banks could accept foreign currency deposits from any physical or juridical person and make use of such depos- its in any way they wished. (7) Foreign exchange purchased or accepted on deposit in accordance with the rules under (2), (3), and (6) would be referred to as "noncommercial foreign exchange," and banks were required to record the relevant transactions in a separate account. (8) The amount of "noncommercial foreign exchange" sold by any bank could not at any time exceed the amount it had purchased from customers. (9) In order to maintain an orderly exchange market, banks were required to compile, in a manner to be prescribed by the central bank, all data relating to the purchase and sale of foreign exchange, and to submit specified data to the central bank at the close of business on each Thursday and also at the end of each month. (10) The central bank's sales of foreign exchange to banks at the official rate for imports and other purposes would continue to take place on the same basis as previously. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAQ Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Iraqi Dinar or ID 0.357143 = SDR 1, corresponding to ID 1 = US$3.3778, and Iraq avails itself of wider margins. Transac- tions in the official market are carried out in any of the listed currencies l or in Iraqi dinars through nonresident accounts in Iraq. The Central Bank of Iraq quotes official rates for the listed currencies for its transactions with authorized dealers. The Bank's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar, which is the intervention currency, were US$3.394678 and US$3.377778, respectively, on December 31, 1973. Administration of Control The Board of Administration of the Central Bank of Iraq is entrusted with all powers and responsibilities in connection with exchange control; it has delegated this authority to the Foreign Exchange Committee (headed by the Governor of the Central Bank, his Deputy, or a member specified in ad- vance by the Board of Administration), to the Department of Foreign Exchange of the Central Bank, and to the licensed dealers. Foreign exchange transactions must take place through a licensed dealer unless otherwise authorized by the Board of Administration. Import and export policy are deter- mined by the Council for the Regulation of Trade. The Direc- torate-General of Economics (Government and Private Import Section) in the Ministry of Economy, the General Organization for Trade, the General Department for Indus- trial Promotion in the Ministry of Industry, and the Indus- trial Organization in the Ministry of Industry are the principal licensing authorities for imports and exports, but import licenses are also issued by certain other public organi- zations and government departments. A foreign exchange budget, including an import program, is established annually, and foreign exchange allocations under the import program are supervised by the Import Program Committee. Prescription of Currency Settlements must be made in any of the listed currencies l or, under the bilateral payments agreements with the People's Republic of China, Egypt, and Yugoslavia, in dinars or pounds sterling through the appropriate clearing account. Payments to and receipts from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The opening of a nonresident account requires the approval of the exchange control authorities. Transactions permitted in convertible currencies may alternatively be settled in Iraqi dinars through nonresident accounts. Nonresident accounts are divided into ordinary nonresident accounts, which arise from transactions in respect of current payments, and special nonresident accounts, which arise from transactions in re- 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. spect of capital transfers. Furthermore, Iraqi nationals who have been working abroad for at least a year or who become residents after having been nonresidents may open accounts in foreign currencies with banks in Iraq and credit these with up to 50 per cent of their foreign savings. Balances in such accounts may be used for a variety of purposes, including imports for the holder's personal use, imports of certain capi- tal goods, or meeting expenditures abroad for travel, medical treatment, and study purposes; payments from these ac- counts up to the equivalent of ID 500 a year do not require Central Bank approval. Imports and Import Payments Imports of many commodities, including jute, sugar, tea, edible oil, certain medical supplies, machine tools, and auto- mobiles, are a government monopoly. All private imports except those of the private sector oil companies require li- censes; in principle these are issued in accordance with an annual import program, but this program has been made increasingly flexible, also for consumer goods. All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa and all imports from Hong Kong other than certain essential goods are prohibited. Imports of some commodities on a Protection List are in principle prohibited from all sources. A tax is levied on the amount of the import license at the following rates: V2 per mill for producer goods, 1 per mill for consumer goods, and, in addition, up to 15 per cent on any supplementary import licenses above a private importer's an- nual quota. To finance the Export Subsidy Fund, a tax of V2 per cent is levied on imports of capital goods and a tax of 1 per cent on imports of consumer goods. All imports subject to import duty are also subject to a customs surcharge of 15 per cent of the applicable customs duty. Licensed dealers make exchange available upon presenta- tion of the exchange control copy of the import license, except in some instances where reference has to be made to the Central Bank. Payments for Invisibles With the exception of certain payments from foreign cur- rency accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above), all payments for invisibles require permission. Exchange is usually granted for educational and medical expenses abroad, freight on exports carried on a c. & f. basis, insurance premi- ums, royalties, etc. Exchange is not granted to merchants for the insurance abroad of their imports or exports. Licensed dealers are permitted to transfer up to ID 50 a month for family maintenance on behalf of foreign nationals resident in Iraq, provided that remittances do not exceed half of the resident's monthly income; it is necessary to refer to the exchange control authorities for amounts exceeding this limit. There is a basic exchange allowance for tourist and busi- ness travel of ID 150 a calendar year for each person 18 years of age or over and of ID 100 for persons under 18 years of age, for trips of at least one week to Arab countries, socialist countries, Iran, and Turkey (ID 100 a person, irrespective of 223 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAQ age, for trips of less than a week, or for five or more members of a family traveling together, irrespective of the length of their stay abroad). For travel to other countries, the basic allowance is ID 200 for each person 18 years of age or over and ID 100 for each person under 18, regardless of the length of the trip. In addition, there are special allocations of up to ID 1,000 a person for medical treatment abroad, and of ID 200 for persons accompanying a patient. Travelers may take out ID 5 in Iraqi currency notes, in addition to 50 per cent of the domestic currency equivalent of the foreign ex- change allocated, which is considered part of the basic travel allowance, and the balance of that allowance in travelers checks. Residents on a pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia are permit- ted to take out the equivalent of ID 150 in listed currencies or in Saudi Arabian riyals (ID 75 for persons over 5 and under 18 and ID 25 for children 5 years of age or younger). Travelers leaving Iraq must deposit with an authorized bank 10 per cent of the Iraqi dinar equivalent of the foreign exchange granted. The deposit is refunded upon the travel- er's return to Iraq, subject to the fulfillment of certain formal- ities. Exempt from the deposit requirement are officials of government, semigoverament, and public utility depart- ments; students traveling for study purposes; pensioners; for- eigners, except non-Iraqi wives of Iraqi nationals; and persons leaving on a pilgrimage. On leaving the country, Iraqi nationals must pay an exit tax of ID 20, except when traveling to Gulf countries or on an official mission the entire expense of which is borne by the Government. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Hong Kong, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa and exports of certain goods to all other countries are prohibited. The Ministry of Economy has authority to pro- hibit the export of any commodity when supply falls short of domestic demand. The Council for the Regulation of Trade may also prohibit the export of certain commodities. All other exports are licensed freely. Exporters must generally undertake to repatriate their for- eign exchange proceeds through a licensed dealer and to sur- render them. Proceeds from exports of dates taken by sailing boats to countries of the Gulf area (excluding Iran) and India are exempt from these requirements when the amount does not exceed ID 600. Some commodities may be exported on a compensation (barter) basis. This system links the export of certain "new" exports to the import of prohibited items. Ex- ports of certain goods are subsidized through an Export Sub- sidy Fund. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surren- dered to a licensed dealer. Travelers may bring in foreign exchange, including currency notes (other than Israel cur- rency), in unlimited amounts, provided that the funds are declared on an exchange control form; amounts not intended to be taken out of the country are exempt from declaration. Travelers may bring in ID 25 in Iraqi notes. 224 Capital Nonresidents may import capital freely, except from Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa, but they must deposit it with a licensed dealer; such deposits may be converted into local currency at the official rate, and repatriation to the country of origin is permitted. With minor exceptions, foreign compa- nies starting operations in Iraq must use Iraqi capital to the extent of at least 51 per cent of their total capital. The transfer of profits net of income tax from foreign investments is lim- ited to 10 per cent per annum of the paid-up capital for trading companies, and to 20 per cent of the paid-up capital for industrial companies. These percentages are applicable for each year separately. They also apply to profits on capital resulting from the mandatory reinvestment of profits in ex- cess of the transferable percentage. Arab capital invested in Iraq is exempt from these percentage limitations and entitled to preferential treatment in several other respects; interest payments are not subject to any ceilings. All transfers of capital abroad by residents, whether Iraqis or foreigners, re- quire exchange control approval; such transfers are severely restricted. Special facilities allow Arab investors to bring in convertible currency freely through a licensed dealer for spec- ified investment purposes; such capital and any net profits may be transferred abroad in convertible currency. Similar facilities permit Iraqi nationals to bring in convertible cur- rency through a licensed dealer and deposit the funds in foreign currency accounts, balances in which are freely trans- ferable abroad. Under the Industrial Promotion Law (No. 22 of 1973), certain incentives and guarantees may be granted to approved investments of domestic or foreign capital in Iraq. Under the Iraqization Law of June 1961, all branches of foreign firms and all foreign-owned firms except banks 2 must have a ma- jority of equity capital held by Iraqi nationals; this law does not cover export agencies and operations requiring special skills. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in Iraq in any form other than gold bars. Imports and exports of gold in any form require the approval of the Central Bank. Since mid-1961, the Rafidain Bank has held a monopoly over the import and domestic distribution of gold needed for indus- trial purposes; it sells gold to registered goldsmiths only, under a quota system based on their past turnover of gold. Travelers may freely bring gold into Iraq, provided that it is declared at the point of entry on a foreign exchange form. Changes during 1973 February 13.
