Not for Redistribution IRELAND Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Irish Pound, corresponding to £Ir 0.416667 = SDR 1. Since June 23, 1972, however, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the Irish pound within prescribed mar- gins, except for sterling. The Irish pound is at par with the pound sterling, and therefore all transactions, except those in sterling or currencies maintaining a fixed relationship with sterling, take place at a fluctuating exchange rate. Transac- tions in sterling take place at parity, free of any commission. As of December 31, 1973, the Central Bank's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$2.3240 and US$2.3220 per Irish pound. Certain capital transactions in- volving investment currency (see section on Capital, below) take place at different effective rates. Forward transactions between authorized banks and their customers must have an underlying commercial transaction. On February 15, 1961, Ireland formally accepted the obli- gations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Exchange control is operated by the Central Bank. Much of the authority for approving normal payments is delegated to commercial banks authorized for this purpose. Import licenses, where necessary, are issued by the Department of Industry and Commerce if the goods are of an industrial nature, or by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries if the goods are agricultural in character. Import licensing is not used for exchange control purposes. Import and export con- trols are administered by the Revenue Commissioners. Prescription of Currency Ireland is a member of the Sterling Area and continues to be a Scheduled Territory for the purposes of the U.K. Ex- change Control Act, 1947. Irish exchange control regulations distinguish between the Scheduled Territories, consisting of Ireland, the United Kingdom (including the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man), and Gibraltar; the External Account Area; and Rhodesia. Payments to and from other Scheduled Territories may be made freely in Irish pounds or pounds sterling; certain insurance payments between Scheduled Ter- ritories, however, may be made in foreign currencies. * Au- thorized payments to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia may be made in Irish pounds or sterling through an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. The proceeds of exports to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia must be received in Irish pounds or sterling through an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. The proceeds of permitted exports to Rhodesia must be received in foreign currency other than 1 Foreign currencies are all currencies other than those of a Scheduled Territory. 226 Rhodesian currency; payments to Rhodesia are subject to special regulations. Nonresident Accounts Accounts of persons resident in the Scheduled Territories are treated as resident accounts. Accounts of persons resident in countries outside the Scheduled Territories are treated as nonresident accounts and, with the exception of Rhodesian Accounts, are designated External Accounts. These may be credited with payments authorized for transfer to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia, with transfers from other External Accounts in Irish pounds or in sterling, and with the proceeds in Irish pounds of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency sold by a resident of a country outside the Scheduled Territories to an authorized bank in Ireland. Balances on these accounts may be trans- ferred freely to other External Accounts in Irish pounds or in sterling, used for payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories, or converted through an authorized bank in Ire- land into any foreign currency other than Rhodesian cur- rency. Accounts held by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia are designated Rhodesian Accounts. The opening of such ac- counts, and all debits and credits thereto, require the prior approval of the Central Bank. Imports and Import Payments All imports of commodities originating in Rhodesia re- quire a special license. With this exception, the import of goods into Ireland is subject to two types of administrative control. Under one type, which covers only a limited range of commodities for protective and other nonbalance of pay- ments purposes, imports of certain commodities are subject to quantitative restrictions, which, in most cases, are on a world-wide basis. 2 Individual import licenses are required for these goods and are used to limit the quantity of goods imported. In addition, special quota restrictions apply to cer- tain textiles and yams originating in any of 16 specified countries or territories. 3 All other imports are free of quanti- tative restriction. Under the other type of control, prior per- mission of the Central Bank is required before orders may be placed for goods originating outside the Scheduled Territo- ries, if they are not to be used in Ireland or are to be delivered more than nine months after the date of the order. For permitted imports, appropriate exchange or permis- sion to credit Irish pounds or sterling to an External Account is granted automatically. Exchange control forms are re- quired for import payments exceeding £lr 2,000 to countries outside the Scheduled Territories. 2 Most of the remaining quotas are being gradually increased in accordance with EEC commitments and with an obligation in the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Area Agreement; the enlargements are made on a global basis, although the obligations relate only to goods originating in the United Kingdom and the other EEC countries. 3 Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hong Kong, Hungary, India, Japan, Macao, Malaysia, Pakistan, Poland, Romania, U.S.S.R., and Yugoslavia. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Payments for Invisibles Payments to the Scheduled Territories are not subject to exchange control unless they are for transactions outside the Scheduled Territories. Payments to residents of countries out- side the Scheduled Territories require approval. Approval to make payments for most invisibles is delegated to the autho- rized banks; for other invisibles, it is given by the Central Bank. For tourist travel outside the Scheduled Territories (other than to Rhodesia) there is a basic allowance for residents of the State of £lr 250 a person for each trip. For business travel, up to £Ir 1,500, at a rate of £lr 20 a day, is allowed for each journey. Limits are also established for allowances for educa- tion and other purposes. Applications for larger amounts are approved, provided that no unauthorized export of capital is involved. Not more than £lr 250 of an allowance of foreign currency may be issued in the form of currency notes. Persons traveling to destinations outside the United Kingdom (other than to Rhodesia) may also take with them up to £Ir 25 in Scheduled Territory currency notes. Travelers who are resi- dent outside the Scheduled Territories (other than Rhodesia) may take with them any foreign currency notes that they brought into Ireland. There is no restriction on the amount of Irish or other banknotes that may be taken to the United Kingdom. Exports and Export Proceeds A system of export licensing is applied to a limited range of goods. There is a special restriction on the export of a number of items to Rhodesia. Exporters of goods to countries outside the Scheduled Territories must obtain payment for the goods within six months of shipment, if the value of the goods exceeds £Ir 100. When payment is received in foreign currencies, the exchange must be offered for sale to an autho- rized bank. Exchange control forms are required for exports exceeding £lr 2,000 to countries outside the Scheduled Terri- tories. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no specific requirements governing exchange re- ceipts from invisibles, but if foreign currencies are received they must be offered for sale to an authorized bank or permis- sion for their retention must be obtained. Any foreign cur- rency held by a person after his return from a trip abroad may be retained for three months from the date he received the exchange, for use on a subsequent trip abroad. There are no limitations on the import of Irish or foreign banknotes. Capital Inward and outward movements of capital between Ireland and other Scheduled Territories are not subject to exchange control. Exchange control approval is required for all trans- fers of capital to countries outside the Scheduled Territories. Applications for transfer of capital at the official market rate of exchange by residents of the State emigrating to External Account Area countries (including the countries of the Over- seas Sterling Area) are approved up to a limit of £lr 20,000 IRELAND a family; there is no such allowance for emigration to Rhode- sia. Where the total value of an emigrant's assets exceeds £lr 20,000, the transfer of the excess amount is restricted for a period of four years from the emigrant's redesignation as a nonresident, i.e., from the date of departure from Ireland. After the four-year period, the assets are to be treated in the same way as those of non-Scheduled Territory residents who have never been resident in Ireland. However, permission is given at any time after redesignation for the restricted funds to be transferred outside the Scheduled Territories through the investment currency market (see below) or invested in sterling securities. 4 For Irish residents taking up employment and residence in an EEC country other than the United Kingdom, applica- tions are considered to transfer Irish or U.K. assets to their new country of residence in excess of £Ir 20,000; the addi- tional facilities are authorized at the official rate of exchange if they are shown to be appropriate to ensure the appli- cant's freedom to take up employment in the country con- cerned. Applications for the transfer of resident-owned capi- tal for purposes other than emigration are considered on their merits, but there are special facilities for residents taking up employment in EEC countries other than the United King- dom and for direct investment in such countries. There are no restrictions on the inflow of capital, but net inflows into the banks may be subject to guidelines set annu- ally by the Central Bank. Banks have been requested to de- posit with the Central Bank 50 per cent of any net capital inflows after January 16, 1973. Purchases of unquoted Irish securities by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories require exchange control approval, and the purchase of nonurban land by foreign nationals in most cases requires approval by the Land Commission. Incoming capital received in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. However, investment currency, i.e., the foreign currency pro- ceeds from the sale mainly of foreign currency securities 5 sold outside the Scheduled Territories may be fully reinvested in foreign currency securities, provided that the securities sold were held prior to April 7, 1965, or acquired by "switches" from securities so held, and that the investment is carried out within six months from the date of sale through a bank, a stockbroker, or a solicitor. Where the securities sold were purchased with investment currency on or after April 7,1965, 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be surrendered at the official rate, except in the case of foreign currency securities payable in the currency of an Overseas Sterling Area country that on June 23, 1972 ceased to be a Scheduled Territory. Investment currency may be invested temporarily in for- eign currency certificates of deposit and similar paper with up to six months to run to final maturity, without incurring the need to comply with the 25 per cent requirement on maturity or resale, provided that the limit of six months for the holding of investment currency is not exceeded. In certain cases, the proceeds from the sale or liquidation of direct investments outside the Scheduled Territories (but not situated in a mem- ber country of the EEC) are regarded as investment currency 4 Securities solely payable in Irish pounds or pounds sterling. 5 Foreign currency securities are all securities expressed in the currency of a country outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesian currency. 227 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND and are eligible for investment in foreign currency securities, provided that 25 per cent of such proceeds is surrendered at the official rate. The entire foreign currency proceeds from the sale outside the Scheduled Territories of property for personal use owned by residents are normally regarded as investment currency where the whole of the property is sold; in other cases the 25 per cent requirement is applied. Residents may obtain, subject to individual permission, reasonable amounts of investment currency to purchase from non-Scheduled Ter- ritory residents property outside the Scheduled Territories for personal use; payments for attendant expenses and improve- ments must also be made with investment currency. Ap- proval is normally limited to one property a family. Purchases from residents of the Scheduled Territories must be settled in sterling. Transactions in securities are controlled to ensure that capital is not transferred outside the Scheduled Territo- ries. Direct investment outside the Scheduled Territories re- quires prior approval and, depending on the merits of the project, may be financed with investment currency, with offi- cial exchange, or by borrowing foreign currency. Use of official exchange is allowed, however, for all ap- proved new direct investments in EEC member countries other than the United Kingdom, subject to a limit of £Ir 250,000 a project a year, and applications to transfer larger amounts at the official exchange rate are considered on their merits. Dealings in Irish registered securities are permit- ted freely between residents of the Scheduled Territories. Spe- cific approval is required for all dealings by Irish residents in securities payable in Rhodesian currency. Remittances of cash gifts to Overseas Sterling Area countries that on June 23, 1972 ceased to be Scheduled Territories are normally permit- ted up to £Ir 1,000 a donor a calendar year; the corresponding limit for other External Account Area countries is £lr 250 a donor a year. Authorized banks may freely accept deposits in foreign currency from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories and lend such deposits on to other nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories. Application must be made to the Central Bank for nonbank private sector borrowing from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories; such applications are considered on their merits and on the benefit likely to accrue to the economy. Public sector borrowing outside the Scheduled Ter- ritories is undertaken following consultation with the Central Bank. Lending of Irish currency to nonresidents of the Sched- uled Territories is not normally permitted, except to the ex- tent that overdraft facilities may be provided by the banks to members of non-Scheduled Territories' diplomatic and con- sular missions in Ireland, and except that banks may freely make available loan and overdraft facilities in Irish pounds or sterling to residents of Overseas Sterling Area countries that on June 23,1972 ceased to be Scheduled Territories, provided the underlying transaction is a trade transaction or one asso- ciated with the movement of goods. Gold Residents may freely hold, buy, borrow, sell or lend gold coins in Ireland. Dealings in gold bullion are restricted, and no dealings take place in Ireland. Although there are no 228 import restrictions, residents require exchange control per- mission to purchase gold coins or bullion abroad; permission is normally given to numismatists for the purchase of gold coins. Exchange control permission also is required for the export of gold coins and bullion; this is not normally granted except to industrial users. Residents of Ireland are not per- mitted to hold gold abroad. Changes during 1973 January 1. Following a similar measure taken by the United Kingdom, it was announced that arrangements were being made under which Gibraltar would be redesignated a Scheduled Territory under Ireland's exchange control regula- tions. This came into effect formally on January 29. January 1. Ireland became a member of the EEC. The Anglo-Irish Free Trade Agreement remained in force. January 1. Certain measures to relax exchange controls between Ireland and member countries of the EEC other than the United Kingdom formally came into effect. These relax- ations had been in operation administratively for some months and were broadly in line with similar measures adopted by the United Kingdom. (1) Exchange control permission was still required for di- rect investments in the countries concerned. The use of offi- cial exchange would be allowed, however, for all new investments, subject to a limit of £Ir 250,000 a project a year, and applications to transfer larger amounts at the official rate of exchange would be considered on their merits. Since the relaxation would not apply retrospectively, the early repay- ment of foreign currency borrowing already undertaken and applied to existing projects would not be permitted. The foreign currency realized on a sale or liquidation of direct investments in the countries concerned, whenever made, would no longer normally be eligible for sale in the invest- ment currency market. Direct investments were defined as those where the Irish investing company participates in the management or operation of a project either directly or through the intermediary of a company or branch specially established in an EEC country for the purpose. (2) Applications would be considered from residents of Ireland who intended to take up employment in an EEC country, other than the United Kingdom, and who wished to be regarded as resident in their new country of employment, to transfer Irish or U.K. assets to their new country of resi- dence in excess of the previous limit of £lr 5,000. The addi- tional facilities requested would be authorized at the official rate of exchange if they were shown to be appropriate to ensure the applicant's freedom to take up employment in the country concerned. (3) Irish residents taking up temporary employment in EEC countries would, during the period of employment, still be regarded as Irish residents for exchange control purposes. The transfei of funds would be approved to meet such items as settling-in expenses, unforeseen current expenditure, and the cost of accommodation; authorities given would be lim- ited to amounts which were shown to be appropriate to en- sure the applicant's freedom to continue or take up employment in the country concerned. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution January 1. The first annual global quota open to the other member states of the EEC came into operation in respect of vehicles originating in the Community, other than those cov- ered by special treatment under the scheme applicable to the assembly and importation of motor vehicles. January 1. New global import quotas for a number of items came into force for the first half of 1973 (for the calendar year 1973 in the case of textiles and textile piece goods). February 1. Quantitative restrictions on trade between Ire- land and the United Kingdom in agricultural products cov- ered by a common market organization of the EEC were removed. February 6. All banks were requested to ensure that they bring about no net capital inflows by reference to the position as at mid-January 1973. It was proposed in this regard that at least 50 per cent of any net inflows that occurred after that date should be deposited with the Central Bank. Such depos- its would not be included when calculating primary liquidity ratios. These arrangements were still in force at the end of the year. February 12. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the Irish pound remained at par with sterling and continued to float. March 19. New exchange rate arrangements between the currencies of most member countries of the EEC, the Norwe- gian krone, and the Swedish krona came into effect. The Irish pound was not included and continued to float with sterling. March 26. All stock exchanges in the United Kingdom and Ireland were merged into an organization called The Stock Exchange. April 1. A revised customs tariff schedule took effect. The changes included the following: the first reduction, of 20 per cent, in duties on imports of industrial commodities imported from other EEC countries; a reduction of 20 per cent in duties on goods coming under the EEC regulation on beef and veal, together with the first step in the alignment of full, preferen- tial, and special preferential rates in the Irish tariff with the EEC Common External Tariff with respect to beef and veal IRELAND products; and the abolition of duty on imports of newsprint from all sources. There also were reductions in duties on specified imports from Austria, Iceland, Poland, Sweden, and Switzerland, and on specified industrial products of United Kingdom origin. (The first tariff changes toward alignment of the EEC Common External Tariff did not take place until January 1, 1974.) April 1. The geographic coverage of Ireland's generalized system of tariff preferences was extended. July 1. Global import quotas for specified industrial items for the period to July 1, 1974 came into effect. July 1. A revised customs tariff schedule took effect. The changes included the eighth annual reduction in protective duties on imports from the United Kingdom under the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Agreement; a reduction of duty by 20 per cent on imports of certain agricultural commodities from member states of the EEC other than the United Kingdom; and reductions of duty on goods originating in specified countries having concluded trade agreements or association agreements with the EEC. August 27. The capital allowance available to emigrants taking up permanent residence in a country of the External Account Area (other than a country of the Overseas Sterling Area) was increased from £lr 5,000 to £Ir 20,000 a family unit and thus became identical with the allowance for Over- seas Sterling Area countries; emigrants to the countries con- cerned currently holding funds on blocked emigration accounts could apply to have up to £lr 15,000 of such funds released at the official rate of exchange. August 27. Applications would henceforth be considered from Irish residents taking up employment and residence in an EEC country other than the United Kingdom for the transfer at the official rate of exchange of their Irish or U.K. assets to their new country of residence in excess of the new emigration allowance of £Ir 20,000 (previously for amounts in excess of £Ir 5,000). December 28. The first postwar trade agreement with the U.S.S.R. was signed. It came into force on the date of signa- ture. 229 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.194884 gram of fine gold per Israel Pound, corresponding to l£4.56 = SDR 1. Israel has estab- lished a central rate of I £4.20 = US$1, corresponding to IC5.06665 = SDR 1, and avails itself of wider margins. The Bank of Israel's official buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1973 were IE4.2000 and IE4.2030, respectively. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Department of Foreign Exchange Control of the Ministry of Finance, under the responsibility of the Controller of Foreign Exchange and in cooperation with other government agencies and is carried out through authorized banks. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected in the currency and manner prescribed by the exchange control authorities. Set- tlements with countries with which payments agreements are in force ' are usually made in U.S. dollars as an accounting unit. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents' funds are held either on foreign currency accounts or on local currency accounts. The opening of non- resident foreign currency accounts does not require prior ap- proval. The principal type of nonresident foreign currency account is the PATACH account. The holder may freely effect transfers from his foreign currency account; he may also convert funds held in the account into local currency at the official rate of exchange. Local currency accounts of nonresidents are of two types: (1) Registered Accounts—for payments to and holdings of foreign aviation, shipping, insurance, and film companies and for nontransferable holdings of former residents—may be established only with special approval. Funds acquired from the sale of real estate and awaiting repatriation must also be held in Registered Accounts. Aviation, shipping, and insur- ance companies may freely convert at the official rate of exchange any amounts held on these accounts which are surplus to local requirements; film companies may do so under individual arrangements made with each company. Registered Account funds held by former residents may be used for investment in listed Israeli securities, for purchase of real estate, for tourist expenses in Israel up to an amount of I £250 a day for the account holder and for each member of his family, for remittances of up to I£l 5,000 a year in support of relatives who are residents of Israel, for the settlement of taxes payable in Israel by the owner of the account, and for donations to public and charitable institutions. Funds repre- senting the sales proceeds of certain real estate become trans- ferable after five years, in equal installments over the 1 Brazil, Bulgaria, and Portugal. 230 following five-year period. Ownership of Registered Ac- counts may not be transferred. (2) Other nonresident ac- counts in local currency may be used to hold funds derived from former investments that are eligible for transfer at the official exchange rate. Balances may be transferred freely be- tween nonresidents. The accounts may be liquidated at any time by the purchase of foreign exchange at the official rate; such foreign exchange may freely be transferred abroad or credited to a PATACH account. Funds in these accounts may also be used within Israel by conversion into Israel pounds, and no limit is placed on the amount that may be withdrawn. Israeli citizens who are temporarily living and earning abroad may maintain foreign currency in temporary PAMAZ accounts in Israel. Balances in such accounts may be freely used abroad when the holder is abroad; when he is in Israel he may only convert these funds into local currency at the official exchange rate. Resident Accounts in Foreign Currency Residents may maintain foreign currency deposits with authorized banks in Israel on either PAZAK accounts, which may be held by all recipients of foreign exchange other than those to whom exchange has been allocated from domestic sources, or TAMAM accounts, which may be held by recipi- ents of restitution payments and disability pensions. PAZAK accounts are demand or time deposit accounts denominated in convertible currencies. All foreign exchange receipts, except those derived from exchange allocations by the Ministry of Finance but including export proceeds, may be placed in PAZAK accounts. Account holders may retain foreign exchange in this manner or may exchange it into local currency. Account holders may use foreign exchange bal- ances in PAZAK accounts to make any authorized foreign payments. Balances in PAZAK accounts are not negotiable between residents, but only among members of the immediate family of the account holder. TAMAM accounts also are demand or time deposit ac- counts in convertible currencies. One third of convertible exchange receipts derived from personal restitution payments and from pensions, etc., of disabled soldiers who served dur- ing World War II may be credited to TAMAM accounts. The permitted uses of TAMAM accounts include the following: (1) the purchase through the medium of the authorized bank holding the account of foreign securities denominated in con- vertible foreign currency that are registered on a stock ex- change in specified foreign countries; (2) payment of premiums on existing life insurance policies denominated in foreign currency; (3) payment of expenses in connection with travel and subsistence abroad in excess of the basic travel exchange allocation of the equivalent of US$450 a trip, pro- vided that not more than the equivalent of US$1,800 a year is drawn by the account holder and for each member of his family; and (4) payment of legal expenses resulting from resti- tution claims. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NATAD accounts are transfer accounts in foreign ex- change that are used mainly for transactions in foreign securi- ties. As stated above, holders of TAMAM accounts may purchase abroad foreign securities denominated in convert- ible foreign currency and registered on a stock exchange in specified foreign countries. Foreign securities thus acquired may be traded freely between residents, through the interme- diary of the authorized bank that is the depository, against payment either with NATAD or TAMAM funds or in Israel pounds. If the original buyer resells securities bought with TAMAM account funds for foreign currency he may deposit the proceeds in TAMAM accounts. Residents who are not holders of TAMAM accounts may deposit the foreign ex- change proceeds from the sale of foreign securities in NATAD accounts. Balances in NATAD accounts may be used to purchase further foreign securities but are not nego- tiable between residents. If foreign securities are sold between residents against Israel pounds, the conversion factor used to establish their domestic currency value is the so-called NATAD rate. On December 31,1973, it stood at I£5 per U.S. dollar. Imports and Import Payments A few imports are prohibited from all sources and all im- ports from Rhodesia are prohibited. All commodities whose importation is not liberalized are listed in a Negative List. Imports of goods listed in the Free Import Orders are free of all licensing and administrative or quantitative restrictions. All other imports are subject to licensing. For commodities on the Automatic Approval List, licenses are issued automat- ically upon application. All other permissible imports consti- tute the Restricted List. All individual import licenses must be countersigned by the Department of Foreign Exchange Control of the Ministry of Finance. The currency and method of payment are prescribed in each license; if a convertible currency is prescribed, payment may be made in any convert- ible currency. Six basic food products (frozen meat, milk powder, wheat, oilseeds, edible fats, and sugar) are imported exclusively by or for account of the Government of Israel. Exchange to pay for items listed in the Free Import Orders or to pay for licensed imports is granted automatically. If payment is to be made by documentary credit, the foreign currency required may be purchased at the time of opening the credit. Funds not transferred abroad immediately must be deposited in a special account with the Bank of Israel until transfer is made. Licenses are not issued for imports of goods on consignment unless the recipient of the license imports goods valued at US$100,000 within three months and under- takes to deposit 10 per cent of the value of the goods in local currency with the Bank of Israel through an authorized bank. Each license is valid only for a single commodity, and an importer cannot receive more than two such licenses a year. The approval of the Department of Foreign Exchange Con- trol is required for all imports effected under foreign credits. Importers are required to deposit with the customs, at the time of paying the import duty and for a period of six months, 20 per cent of the c.i.f. value of imports. 2 Exempt are com- 2 The deposit requirement was abolished with effect from January 1, 1974. ISRAEL modities subject to customs duty at a rate of less than 50 per cent, imports by or for the Government, immigrants' per- sonal effects, gifts, and imports with a c.i.f. value of I £5,000 or less. The funds are kept on deposit in the Bank of Israel for six months and interest of 6 per cent a year is received by the importer. Virtually all imports are subject to an import surcharge of 25 per cent of the c.i.f. value. The main exemp- tions are for fuels, certain basic foodstuffs, and uncut dia- monds. A purchase tax is levied on almost all imported and domestically produced goods, other than capital goods. Payments for Invisibles Most payments abroad for invisibles require individual licenses. Each resident is allowed exchange equivalent to US$10-250, which is obtainable on demand, for certain pur- poses such as the purchase of books, membership dues, and registration in a university. For tourist travel abroad, there is an exchange allowance equivalent to US$450 a traveler for each journey (US$225 for children under 12); emigrants are not eligible for this allowance. Not more than I£200 in Israel banknotes may be taken out by travelers. Foreign tourists leaving Israel are permitted to repurchase through authorized dealers foreign currency up to US$30. Residents traveling abroad must pay a travel tax; for travel by sea, the tax is I£550 plus 10 per cent of the price of the ticket, and for travel by air, I£595 plus 10 per cent of the price of the ticket. Travelers to specified countries are exempted from the travel tax; these include Cyprus, Ethiopia, and Romania. Exporters doing more than US$100,000 of export business a year are exempt from travel tax on business trips. Immigrants and their families are exempt from travel tax for three years from the date of immigration or of entry as temporary residents. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports do not require licenses if paid for in freely convertible currencies. For some commodities, however, export licensing is retained for the purpose of quality control. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry maintains a check on export transactions with a low value-added content which are made with bilateral partners; this is done to discourage switch transactions. Ex- port proceeds in foreign currencies must be surrendered or held in a PAZAK account. Exports of most commodities are eligible for incentive payments based on value added and designed to rebate estimated internal indirect taxes and the import surcharge. At the end of 1973, the payment for dia- monds was about 81 agorot per US$1 equivalent, and for other commodities the payment ranged from I£l.05 to I£l.21 per US$1 equivalent, with the higher rates applicable to com- modities with a higher proportion of domestic value added. For inputs directly imported by an exporter there is a system of rebate of customs duties, wharf charges, etc. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds from invisibles must, in general, be surrendered. Alternatively, they may be kept in foreign ex- change on PAZAK accounts, balances on which may be 231 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL exchanged into Israel currency at any time or used to make authorized payments abroad. Any resident is free to accept specified convertible currencies from tourists in payment for services and commodities other than commercial exports, securities, and real estate; such receipts must be surrendered within a few days. One third of the foreign exchange received by residents of Israel as restitution payments, and as pensions by disabled soldiers who served in World War II, may be retained in TAMAM accounts and the other two thirds may be held in PAZAK accounts. For ten years after entering Israel, new immigrants are exempt from surrendering their foreign exchange to the Trea- sury, and they may keep these foreign currencies with autho- rized banks in Israel or with banks abroad. Tourists visiting Israel are expected to bring with them the amounts of foreign currency that they will need during their stay. Not more than I£200 in Israel banknotes may be brought in by travelers. Tourists and others visiting Israel who are holders of Registered Accounts (see section on Non- resident Accounts, above) may draw upon such accounts to the extent of I£250 a day for themselves and the same amount for each member of their families; if they are holders of other nonresident local currency accounts, they may draw on them without limit. Capital Foreign exchange representing incoming capital and be- longing to a resident must be surrendered at the official rate or held in a PAZAK account. Capital brought into Israel for the purpose of investment may, subject to approval, be granted preferential treatment in accordance with the Law for the Encouragement of Capital Investments of August 16, 1959, which, inter alia, permits a nonresident who has made an "approved** investment in foreign currency to transfer all his profits abroad in the same currency at the official rate. Repayments and amortization of capital may also be trans- ferred on the following terms: if the investment has been kept for less than five years, the capital may be w i thdrawn in five equal installments; if the investment has been kept for more than five years, it may be withdrawn immediately. Current policy is to grant "approved** status only to enterprises in selected fields of production that fulfill one of the following conditions: (1) that they are established in "priority areas**; (2) that they are export-oriented, i.e., either at least 50 per cent of output is exported or existing productive capacity is increased by at least 50 per cent while at least 50 per cent of the additional output is exported; or (3) tha t, although for economic reasons the enterprise cannot be established in a priority area, its production is of the import-substitution type. There is no longer any difference between an "approved investment** and any other investment made by a nonresident in foreign currency insofar as his rights to transfer abroad the principal or the interest or profits on his investment are con- cerned. The difference does still exist as regards other bene- fits, such as income tax concessions and grants. The principal of foreign investments made prior to January 1, 1958, or made after that date in foreign exchange, can be 232 transferred abroad. The proceeds of investments in real es- tate, however, can only be transferred five years after its purchase, in five annual installments. Proceeds accruing from the repatriation or liquidation of foreign assets held by residents are treated in the same way as proceeds from invisibles. Any resident may retain real estate abroad, but not money, securities, or the income from real estate; new immigrants may retain liquid assets as well. Transfers abroad of a capital nature by residents other than new immigrants are generally not permitted. Owners of TAMAM deposits are entitled to purchase for- eign securities registered at stock exchanges in specified for- eign countries. Foreign securities purchased to the debit of a TAMAM deposit can be sold abroad by their owners, or in Israel either against foreign currency to owners of other TAMAM or NATAD deposits or against Israel pounds. The proceeds of the sale may be credited to the TAMAM account previously debited for the purchase. The owner of foreign securities bought through TAMAM or NATAD accounts is also allowed to sell them to residents against Israel pounds, and the purchaser in his turn may sell them either against Israel pounds or against foreign currency (abroad or to hold- ers of TAMAM or NATAD deposits); he is entitled to de- posit the foreign currency proceeds in a NATAD account. This is the only manner in which NATAD accounts can be established. The holder of a NATAD account may draw on it to pur- chase foreign securities abroad, or to pay to a holder of a TAMAM or NATAD account foreign currency for foreign securities. It is also permissible to purchase gold from monies in TAMAM and NATAD accounts, the procedure being the same. A general license allows authorized dealers to purchase real estate in Israel for nonresidents. Nonresidents may freely purchase shares, provided that purchases are financed with converted foreign currency; debentures, however, may be purchased by nonresidents only if they are quoted on the Tel Aviv stock exchange. Direct loans in any form to or from nonresidents are subject to licensing. Gold Residents, including private persons, may freely hold gold in any form either in Israel or abroad; purchases by private persons must be financed out of TAMAM or NATAD ac- counts, except for purchases of jewelry and of articles con- taining a minor quan t i ty of gold, such as watches. Gold can be sold only to an authorized dealer and can be bought only from an authorized dealer. Other residents are forbidden to trade in gold, to transfer it from place to place, or to take it out of Israel. Imports of gold are permissible only if an import license is obtained. Imports of gold for industrial purposes are transacted by five importing wholesalers. These wholesalers may sell the gold only to purchasers registered with the Pur- chase Tax Administration. The latter checks these purchases by each manufacturer against the gold content of products marked as "purchase tax paid** in order to eliminate the possi- bility of sales of these quantities of gold on the market as bullion. ©International Monetary Fund. By amendment to the Commodities and Services (Control) (Control of Diamonds) Order, 1959 and the Im- ports, Exports and Customs Jurisdiction Ordinance, 1939, the controls on the diamond trade were tightened. January 1. The import deposit in domestic currency that importers were required to lodge with the customs, at the time of paying the import duty and for a period of six months, was reduced from 30 per cent to 20 per cent of the c.i.f. value of the goods. Goods with a c.i.f. value of up to I£5,000 became exempt from the deposit requirement. January 14. As part of the five-year import liberalization program, customs duties on some 1,350 items, mostly indus- trial consumer goods, were reduced by an average of 15 per cent. January 30. An interim trade agreement with the EEC was signed for the period to the end of 1973. February 8. The amount up to which funds held in Regis- tered Accounts by former residents could be used for travel expenses in Israel was increased from I £150 a day to I £250 a day (for the account holder and each member of his family), and the amount up to which they could be used for remit- tances in support of relatives resident in Israel was increased from I£5,000 a year to I£l5,000 a year. February 8. The amount in Israel banknotes that travelers could bring in and take out was increased from I£100 to I£200. February 8. Israeli exporters were allowed foreign exchange equivalent to 10 per cent of their foreign sales but not exceed- ing US$50,000 for marketing and other incidental expenses. February 8. The import privileges accorded to new immi- grants were revised. They were no longer required to pay for purchases with their own foreign exchange. February 8. Authorized banks were permitted to buy and sell foreign currencies at spot rates deviating from the official buying and selling rates quoted by the Bank of Israel. February 8. The basic foreign exchange allowance for study abroad was raised from the equivalent of I£150 to I£250 a month. Family remittances abroad up to US$400 a year no longer required documentary verification. February 14. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, Israel established a central rate of I£4.20 = US$1 and continued to avail itself of wider margins. No changes took place in the list of exemptions from the sur- charge. The process of liberalization of imports was not af- fected. Import du ty on footwear, furn i ture, cigarettes, and a few household items was increased by 20 per cent. Purchase tax on most goods was increased by 5 per cent, and on some luxu ry items by 10 per cent or 20 per cent. December 27. Imports and Import Payments All imports of Rhodesian origin are prohibited. Practically all imports from other countries except Japan, the People's Republic of China, North Viet-Nam, and the CMEA countries are free of quantitative restriction; all goods, how- ever, require a bank certificate for submission to the customs authorities and sometimes also a license issued by the Minis- try of Finance at the request of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. Commodities that still require individual licenses when im- ported from these other countries are included in a negative list (Tabella A Import. 4 Some items in the list require an import license only when originating in Israel or Yugoslavia. The general permission to import goods not included in the Tabella A Import applies to Egypt and Yugoslavia only if the goods both originate in and are shipped direct from the coun- try concerned; in addition, in respect of imports of raw cot- ton, rice, and crude petroleum from Egypt, the payee must reside in that country or in one of the European OECD countries. (Seventy per cent of the value of other imports from Egypt must be paid to creditors residing either in that country or in any OECD country, and 30 per cent must be paid in lire to Egypt's lire account with the Italian Exchange Office.) A more extensive negative list (Tabella B Impori) contains those commodities which require an individual license when originating in and imported from Albania, Bulgaria, the Peo- ple's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, North Korea, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., or North Viet-Nam. There is a special list of com- modities, also included in Tabella B Import, whose importa- tion is unilaterally and de facto liberalized when they both originate in and are shipped from Albania, Bulgaria, the Peo- ple's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, Poland, Romania, or the U.S.S.R. These goods may be admitted by the customs without a license, although some require a visa issued by the Institute of Foreign Trade. A separate negative list applies to Japan indicating the goods that are subject to restrictive import licensing when imported from that country; some other items are included in a special list of commodities for which import licenses are issued freely. All other goods of Japanese origin 5 may be imported freely without an individual license, irrespective of the country from which they are shipped. Imports from non-EEC countries of most products cov- ered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to variable import levies that have replaced all previ- 4 Tabella A Import applies to all countries except Albania, Bulgaria, Peo- ple's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, Japan, North Korea, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, U.S.S.R., and North Viet-Nam. 5 All goods that are included neither in Tabella A Import nor in List A or List B of Circular No. 606360 of May 28, 1963 (as amended). ITALY ous barriers to imports; common EEC regulations are also applied to imports from non-EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products. For imports not exceeding Lit 1 million in value, no ex- change control form is required; for imports from Lit 1 mil- lion to Lit 2 million in value, a form completed by the importer is required; for imports over Lit 2 million in value, an import document completed by an authorized bank is required. The importer must choose an authorized bank as his bank of domicile, through which he must carry out all pay- ments operations related to his import transactions if settle- ment takes place more than 360 days after importation. Advance payments for imports require special approval when they are to take place more than 30 days before importation. All advance payments of Lit 1 million or more must be made with foreign currency borrowed from Italian authorized banks. For all authorized imports, the authorized banks provide exchange or permit payment in Italian lire to a Foreign Ac- count, provided that appropriate payment terms are observed (see section on Capital, below). International postal money orders may be used for import payments, subject in the case of payments to Switzerland to a limit of Lit 100,000 for each remitter and foreign beneficiary. Payments for Invisibles In principle, payments abroad for invisibles require licenses issued by the exchange control authorities. Under general authorization, however, the authorized banks may sell foreign exchange freely, provided that the necessary documents are submitted. Exchange is granted freely for remittances of earn- ings on investments. Residents may use international postal money orders for payments, subject in the case of payments to Switzerland to a limit of Lit 100,000 for each remitter and foreign beneficiary. All advance payments of Lit 1 million or more for imports of services must be made with foreign cur- rency borrowed from Italian authorized banks. Certain transactions (but not the related payments) in re- spect of services are subject to approval by the Ministry of Foreign Trade or the Ministry of Industry. These transac- tions can be divided into two groups: (1) contracts which require a permit if they involve residents of specified countries 8 and (2) contracts which require a permit regard- less of the nationality of the nonresidents involved. The first group includes transactions giving rise to expenditures for chartering ships (excluding charters for a single trip); repairs to ships which are not urgent and not necessary for safety of operation; news agencies and newspaper correspondents (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million a month for the same payee); purchases of publication rights, information agencies, etc. (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million for each contract); copy- rights (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million a year for each contract); services of professional workers and company managers (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million); and services of entertainers and athletes (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 6 Albania, Bhutan, Bulgaria, People's Republic of China (including Mongo- lia), Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, Khmer Republic, North Korea, Poland, Romania, U.S.S.R., North Viet-Nam, and (only for chartering ships) Yugoslavia. 235 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY million). The second group includes transactions giving rise to expenditures for production abroad of films, utilization of films, scripts, synchronization, etc.; collaboration in cinema- tography; insurance of ships and aircraft against risks of oper- ation; 7 and other transactions not permitted by general au- thorization (when the amounts involved exceed Lit 1 million). Residents traveling to foreign countries may obtain from the banks exchange equivalent to Lit 500,000 for each trip for tourism, business, medical treatment, and education (the cor- responding amount for group travel also is Lit 500,000); banks are authorized in exceptional cases to supply foreign exchange above these allowances, up to Lit 1 million a person a trip, provided that they are satisfied that this is justified in the light of the duration and purpose of the trip. Applications for exchange in excess of Lit 1 million a person a trip must be submitted to the Exchange Office. To the extent that he refrains from obtaining an allocation of foreign exchange, a resident traveler may take in addition a proportionate amount in Italian banknotes, up to Lit 20,000. 8 Nonresident travelers may take out any amount in foreign banknotes that they have previously declared upon en t ry as well as Lit 20,000 in Italian banknotes. Foreign banknotes must be purchased in the financial exchange market, while payments with other means of payment, including travelers checks, and credit cards are settled in the ordinary exchange market. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to any country of a few commodities in a special list (Tabella Esport) require export licenses. For exports not exceeding Lit 1 million in value, no exchange control form is required; for exports from Lit 1 million to Lit 2 million in value, a form completed by the exporter is required; for ex- ports exceeding Lit 2 million in value, an export document completed by an authorized bank is required. The exporter must choose an authorized bank as his bank of domicile, through which he must carry out the payments operations related to his export transactions if settlement takes place more than 90 days after exportation. Unless special approval is obtained for different terms of payment (see section on Capital, below), 90 per cent of ex- change receipts must be collected within 90 days of shipment, and these must be offered for sale to an authorized bank w i th in 7 days of receipt, while 10 per cent must be collected within 24 months of shipment. Proceeds in U.S. dollars, Ca- nadian dollars, Japanese yen, and externally convertible Eu- ropean currencies may be retained by authorized banks on behalf of the recipients in Ordinary Foreign Currency Ac- counts (Conti Valutari Ordinari) for one mon th, during which period such balances may be used for permitted trans- actions or be sold to authorized banks; the banks are allowed to sell these currencies to residents for authorized transac- tions or to negotiate them freely with the Italian Exchange Office or among themselves. 9 After expiration of the reten- tion period, unused balances must be sold to the Italian Ex- change Office at the lowest ordinary market exchange rate quoted during the retention period (these ordinary market rates are determined daily on the basis of the average closing rates in Milan and Rome). Export proceeds may also be received by international postal money order, up to Lit 100,000 for each payment, and in certain circumstances, in foreign banknotes that are accepted in the country of issue for credit to bank accounts, balances in which are convertible at official market rates. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from current invisibles are subject to the same collection, retention, and surrender requirements as receipts from exports. 9 Shipping and insurance companies and travel and forwarding agencies may keep operating accounts (Conti Autorizzati) in U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Japanese yen, and externally convertible European currencies. Residents may not retain any foreign banknotes left over from trips abroad but must sell them to an authorized bank. Persons may bring in any amount in foreign banknotes and Lit 20,000 in Italian banknotes. Foreign banknotes may be sold in the financial market only; settlements with travelers checks and credit cards take place at ordinary market rates. Capital Capital transactions between residents and nonresidents must in principle be settled in the financial market. Medi- um-term loans granted or received by Italian banks in con- nection with imports or exports of goods and services are settled in the ordinary exchange market. Inward and outward movements of nonresident capital are free. However, loans of any kind from nonresidents to resi- dents and from residents to nonresidents require specific au- thorization from the Ministry of the Treasury or the Ministry of Foreign Trade, respectively, except, with regard to OECD countries, long-term loans (other than loans from financial institutions to nonresidents) for the purpose of establishing or maintaining lasting economic relations and loans to relatives up to the third degree of relationship, and, with regard to EEC countries, short-term (up to one year and not exceeding Lit 250 million) and medium-term (up to five years and not exceeding Lit 250 million) financial loans (i.e., loans not con- nected with commercial operations or the performance of services); for none of these is any kind of authorization re- quired. Repayment of such loans may be made freely. A deposit requirement is applicable to outward transfers of resident-owned capital for direct investments, portfolio in- vestments, financial loans, purchases of real estate, and per- sonal capital movements. The transferor must lodge a lira deposit equivalent to 50 per cent of the amount transferred (25 per cent for investment fund securities, but mutual funds investing entirely in Italian securities are exempt) in a nonin- terest-bearing account with the bank effecting the transfer. In addition, when foreign investments are transferred between 7 Such transactions need authorization by the M in is try of Indus t ry. 8 Persons living in border areas may not take out more than Lit 20,000 a day in foreign and domestic banknotes and coins combined, of which foreign notes and coins must not exceed the equivalent of Lit 10,000. 9 Foreign currency may be retained in Ordinary or Financial Foreign Exchange Accounts un t il the second weekday after the end of the first calendar mon th following that in which the individual exchange receipt concerned was credited to the foreign exchange account. 236 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution residents against lire, the transferee is subject to the deposit requirement, regardless of the date when the investment was made. The deposits are released only when, and to the extent that, disinvestment operations occur, and their release re- quires the prior approval of the local Bank of Italy office. Purchases by residents of certain bonds issued by specified EEC institutions are exempt. Outward direct investment transactions have from time to time been given an ad hoc exemption. Foreign investment in Italy is, in principle, governed by Law No. 43 of February 7, 1956 and subsequent implement- ing regulations. Foreign investments of any kind in Italy, including both direct and portfolio investment and the pur- chase of real estate, are permitted freely, and no restrictions are applied to their repatriation. Direct investment in OECD countries by physical or juridi- cal persons (other than participation by a financial institution that has its main office in Italy in a foreign company not having the same corporate purpose), is permitted in any form and without any limit. 10 Direct investment in other countries may be made only (under the supervision of the Italian Ex- change Office) by juridical persons in firms that are in the same line of business as that of the Italian firm mak ing the investment; other types of direct investment in such countries require special authorization from the Ministry of Foreign Trade. The general license to make these investments also covers the reinvestment of earnings and the use for this pur- pose of the liquidation proceeds of previous investments (af- ter crediting the proceeds of the disinvestment to bank accounts similar to those established for proceeds from ex- ports and invisibles; see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, above). Residents of Italy are free to buy and sell, through the Bank of Italy or the authorized banks, any foreign securities issued or payable abroad and quoted on foreign stock ex- changes, and to deal in such securities among themselves against payment in lire. Such foreign securities, except securi- ties of Lit 100,000 or less, have to be deposited with an Italian bank or with a bank abroad for account of an Italian bank. The purchase by residents of shares of foreign financial insti- tutions of any kind (including mutual funds), as well as con- vertible bonds issued by such institutions, requires prior approval by the Italian Exchange Office. In practice, how- ever, a resident is able freely to purchase shares of foreign funds that have received authorization from the Ministry of Foreign Trade to sell their shares in Italy, since that authori- zation is in fact valid also for the individual resident sub- scriber. Such authorization is given only to funds meeting certain requirements, including that of investing at least 50 per cent of their portfolio in Italian securities and that of setting up a branch office in Italy. Residents do not require authorization to purchase real estate in EEC countries. All issues of securities by nonresidents on the Italian capi- tal market require the prior approval of the Ministry of For- eign Trade, and are subject to the rules governing the issue 10 Financial investment, i.e., investment not intended to establish permanent relations, is not considered direct investment, pie regulations governing direct investment are also not applicable to participations in "holdings" abroad of any kind. ITALY in Italy of domestic securities. These rules include the prior approval of the Bank of Italy, and, for issues beyond Lit 500 million, that of the Ministry of the Treasury, the Ministry of Indus try, and the Interministerial Credit Committee. Issues are normally restricted to international institutions. Transfers in connection with donations, inheritances, and dowries may be made freely. The transfer of property of residents leaving Italy permanently is allowed in two stages: up to the equivalent of Lit 6 million a person upon presenta- tion of specified documents to an authorized bank at the time of leaving Italy, and the remainder subject to examination of the documents by the Italian Exchange Office, when resi- dence has been established abroad. Special regulations apply to commercial credits and credits related to the performance of services. Advance payments for imports must be made with foreign currency borrowed from an authorized Italian bank; in other cases, the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade is required. When prepay- ments for imports exceed Lit 5 million, an advance deposit of 5 per cent is required. Deferred payments for imports are permitted freely if settlement is to take place, to the extent of at least 90 per cent, within 360 days after importation, and the balance within 24 mon ths after importation; such pay- ments require the prior approval of the Italian Exchange Office if the settlement is to take place between 12 months and 24 months after importation. In all other cases, the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade is required; where, according to the contract, settlement is to take place more than 360 days after the date of importation, the approval of the Ministry is required to make the payment prior to the due date set in the contract. Advance payments for exports may be received freely if exportation is to take place within 360 days; in all other cases, such receipts require the prior approval of the Italian Ex- change Office. Deferred payments for exports are permitted if settlement is to take place to the extent of at least 90 per cent within 90 days after exportation, and the balance within 24 months after exportation. For settlement between 90 and 360 days after exportation, the approval of the Exchange Office is required; in all other cases, such receipts require the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. Virtually identical regulations are in force for the permitted credit terms for imports and exports of services. In relations w i th EEC countries, the reciprocal granting of credits for commercial transactions or the performance of services, with a ma tur i ty longer than the time limits that banks are authorized to approve and up to five years, may be effected after examination of the documents by the Italian Exchange Office. This applies also in relations with Austria, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland. Loans and credits (the latter only beyond a certain dura- tion, generally 180-360 days) not connected with commercial transactions or with the performance of services require the approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. However, finan- cial loans may be granted to or by residents of EEC countries as indicated above. The export of Italian and foreign securities is permitted only when they are owned by nonresidents and have been purchased against U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Japanese 237 ©International Monetary Fund. Permitted debits to Capital Accounts (related to the finan- cial market) included those in respect of the following: con- version into foreign currency in the financial market; transfer to a Special Account Under Law No. 43 of February 7, 1956 of lire stemming from foreign currency sold on the financial market for investment in accordance with that law; amortiza- tion of loans in lire by nonresidents; donations and endow- ments; dowries; inheritances and bequests; capital funds and annuities certain owed by insurance companies operating abroad for life insurance policies; foreign investments in Italy in securities and real estate; loans in lire from nonresidents to residents; other financial transactions allowed under the regu- lations in force; transfer to a domestic account (conto interno) when the holder of the account transferred his residence to Italy; and transfer to another Capital Account. January 22. The system of nonresident lire accounts was reorganized. Capital Accounts henceforth related to the fi- nancial exchange market only and Foreign Accounts to the ordinary exchange market. Correspondingly, two types of resident foreign currency accounts were henceforth distin- guished: Ordinary Foreign Currency Accounts (Conti Valutari ITALY yen, or externally convertible European currencies, or against funds on a Capital Account. The net external position of the banks is subject to control by the Exchange Office. This control encompasses (1) the spot position vis-a-vis nonresidents in foreign currencies and lire together; and (2) the overall position, spot and forward combined, in all foreign currencies; a balanced foreign cur- rency position on a daily basis is required separately in (a) U.S. dollars, (b) EEC currencies, and (c) all other conto valu- tariocurrencies combined. Authorized banks are permitted to incur a net foreign liability position and are prohibited from ma in ta in ing a net foreign asset position. Gold All transactions in gold between residents and nonresi- dents are settled in the ordinary exchange market. Residents may freely hold and negotiate gold in any form in Italy, w i th the exception of unrefined gold imported under ministerial license for industrial purposes. The monetary authorities may freely acquire unrefined gold abroad. Agent banks that have been authorized by the Ministry of the Treasury may acquire unrefined gold abroad upon submission of licenses issued by the Ministry of Foreign Trade to Italian firms for industrial use. Exports of wrought and semimanufactured gold, other than jewelry, are subject to licensing. Impor ts of unrefined gold are subject to value-added tax at 12 per cent. Imports of gold coins for numismatic purposes are subject to value-added tax at 18 per cent. Changes during 1973 January 2. The import regulations applicable to EEC mem- ber countries became applicable also to Denmark, Ireland, and the United Kingdom, except for goods covered by com- mon market organizations of the EEC, for which this oc- curred on February 1. January 2. A value-added tax came in to effect. It replaced the cascade-type turnover tax. January 5. Borrowing and lending between residents of I ta ly and residents of Austria, in respect of imports of Aus- trian origin and exports to Austria, with maturities in excess of those which banks could approve but not in excess of five years, henceforth were permitted subject to prior examination of documents by the Exchange Office. A corresponding mea- sure w i th respect to Sweden and Switzerland was taken on January 18, 1973, and with respect to Finland and Norway on March 6, 1974. January 22. A dual exchange market came in to operation. Current transactions were to be channeled through the ordi- nary exchange market, where IMF and EEC margins would continue to be observed, while capital transactions were to be settled in the financial exchange market, where quotations would be freely determined by supply and demand. The exist- ing exchange control regulations, including those of June 28, 1972 concerning Italian banknotes, were maintained (with the exceptions mentioned in the following January 22 entries). Payments and receipts eligible for the ordinary market included those in respect of the following: imports and ex- funds held in Special Accounts Under Law No. 43 for trans- fer abroad following disinvestment had to be channeled f irst into a Capital Account. Foreign Currency Accounts in existence on January 20, 1973 were designated Ordinary Foreign Currency Accounts. Capital Accounts in existence on the same date became sub- ject to the new rules for Capital Accounts. Capital Accounts could be held w i thout special authoriza- tion, at any Italian bank, by persons resident abroad. They could be credited with lire derived from: the sale of foreign currency on the financial market; loans in lire to nonresidents (except loans made under Law No. 131 of February 28, 1967); sales of securities and real estate by nonresidents; amortiza- tion by residents of loans in lire obtained from nonresidents; gifts and endowments; dowries; inheritances and bequests; capital funds and annuities certain payable to nonresidents by insurance companies operating in Italy, on account of life insurance contracts; other financial operations allowed by the existing regulations; transfers from domestic accounts moti- vated by a change in residence of the holder of the domestic account to a foreign country; transfers from other Capital Accounts; transfers from Special Accounts Under De- cree-Law No. 211 or Under Law No. 43 for the transfer abroad of the amount concerned; and interest on amounts credited to Capital Accounts. Capital Accounts could be debited for: conversion into foreign currency in the financial market; transfers to Special Accounts Under Law No. 43 of lire derived from the sale of foreign exchange on the financial market for purposes of investment as defined by that law; amortization by nonresi- dents of loans in lire; gifts and endowments; dowries; inheri- tances and legacies; capital funds and annuities certain payable by insurance companies operating abroad under life insurance contracts; foreign investment in Italy in securities and real estate; loans in lire from nonresidents to residents; other financial operations allowed by the existing regulations; transfers to domestic accounts motivated by the transfer to Italy of the residence of the holder of the account; and trans- fers to other Capital Accounts. The same debits and credits were permitted to Financial Foreign Currency Accounts held by residents. Lire amounts corresponding to the utilization of lines of credit granted to nonresidents for operations of a financial nature had to be credited to a Capital Account in the name of the beneficiary, and the lire required to reimburse this financing had to be drawn also from a Capital Account. Forward transactions against lire carried out with nonresi- dents in connection with financial operations had to be closed on ma tur i ty with lire from a Capital Account. Banks had to effect spot or forward cover for forward operations against lire in the same exchange market in which the underlying operation was to be effected at maturity. Swap operations against forward lire had to be concluded with lire drawn from an account of the same type as that to which the lire were credited when the swap operation was initiated. All outstand- ing drawings on lines of credit in lire granted by Italian banks to nonresidents had to be paid off on maturity with lire from Foreign Accounts. All existing forward operations against ITALY lire also had to be paid off on ma tur i ty with lire from Foreign Accounts. "Financial operations" were defined as all operations that could not be documented as being of a commercial or service nature. January 22. The period normally allowed for advance pay- ments for imports was reduced from 90 days to 30 days prior to importation; as a result, payments 31 days to 360 days (five years for EEC countries) prior to importation were subject to prior examination of documents by the Exchange Office. The period within which export proceeds must normally be col- lected was reduced from 360 days to 90 days after shipment; as a result, collection 91 days to 360 days (five years for EEC countries) after exportation was subject to prior examination of documents by the Exchange Office. The shortened collec- tion period was applicable to 90 per cent of the export pro- ceeds, while 10 per cent remained subject to the previous term of 24 months after exportation. January 22. The period during which authorized banks were permitted to retain export proceeds in foreign currency accounts (conti valutari) on behalf of the recipients was re- duced from six months to one month after collection. This was applicable also to foreign currency accounts in the finan- cial market (see below). January 22. The use for the financing of current noncom- mercial transactions of existing lines of credit obtained abroad henceforth was subject to prior examination of docu- ments by the Exchange Office, provided that each transaction was to take place w i th in 180 days. January 29. Banks were informed that swaps of lire against foreign currencies could take place in the financial market only, and that outright forward transactions in lire against foreign currencies w i th foreign correspondents could not be effected in the ordinary market unless there was a specific underlying commercial or services transaction. February 1. Transactions in foreign banknotes denomi- nated in specified convertible currencies were shifted to the financial market; these were banknotes in the 10 out of 16 conto valutario currencies that, when repatriated to the coun- try of issue, could be credited to bank accounts, balances in which were convertible at the official exchange rate. Transac- tions in travelers checks and settlements through credit cards remained in the ordinary market. February 1. The basic foreign exchange allocation for travel abroad was reduced from Lit 1 million a person a trip to Lit 500,000 a person a trip. The corresponding ceiling on the export of Italian banknotes and travelers checks denomi- nated in lire by resident travelers also was reduced from Lit 1 million to Lit 500,000 a person a trip. Banks could in exceptional cases grant foreign exchange up to Lit 1 million a person a trip if this in their view was justified in the light of the duration and purpose of the trip; applications for allo- cations in excess of Lit 1 million a person a trip had to be submitted to the Exchange Office. February 2. Banks were informed that the conversion of other means of payment into foreign banknotes had to be effected through a separate sale against lire. 239 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY February 8. It was clarified that debits to Capital Accounts for transfers to Special Accounts Under Law No. 43 were permitted. February 13. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, Italy announced that for the time being the exchange rate for the lira in the ordinary market would not necessarily be confined within announced limits either in respect of the U.S. dollar or in respect of EEC currencies. Henceforth, the exchange rates in both exchange markets were fluctuating rates. February 19. The period within which export proceeds (as well as proceeds from current invisibles) in foreign currency had to be deposited in a foreign currency account or offered for sale to the Exchange Office was reduced from one mon th to seven days after receipt. February 19. The period within which holders of Financial Foreign Currency Accounts were required to offer for sale to the Exchange Office any unused foreign exchange held in such accounts was shortened to the second weekday after the end of the first calendar mon th following that in which each individual credit en try was recorded. February 19. Since the crediting and debiting of Authorized Accounts for capital movements had been prohibited by Cir- cular No. A /262 of January 20, the holders of such accounts were permitted to credit and debit Financial Foreign Cur- rency Accounts for the purposes for which the use of their Authorized Accounts had been permitted prior to Janu- ary 20. February 19. Applications for the modification of ministe- rial authorizations for the granting of commercial credit could be submitted to the Exchange Office, provided that they were necessary for the execution of the transaction and did not change the basic structure of the transaction. February 21. The Special Accounts of international organi- zations and institutions were divided into Ordinary Special Accounts and Financial Special Accounts, related to the ordi- nary market and the financial market, respectively. February 23. Banks were instructed that the sale of foreign currency to nonresident travelers leaving Italy was to be lim- ited to the amount and currency previously sold against lire by the traveler concerned. February 23. Banks were informed that the screening of applications for the authorization of the acceptance or issu- ance of guarantees vis-a-vis nonresidents in respect of certain types of transactions was with effect from March 1 being taken over by the Exchange Office. (On April 13 the Ex- change Office took over the screening of all guarantees vis- a-vis nonresidents, whether of a banking nature or not.) March 1. Specified foreign exchange transactions con- nected with the making of films that previously required ministerial authorizations henceforth only required a declara- tion of nonopposition (nulla osta) from the Exchange Office. March 11. Imports of many goods originating in Eastern Germany were liberalized. The degree of liberalization ac- corded to that country was approximately the same as that already enjoyed by most Eastern European countries and the People's Republic of China. March 15. When its dollar swaps with Italian authorized banks began to fall due, the Italian Exchange Office informed 240 them that it would settle the swaps only in part but, in order to compensate the banks for continuing to hold the dollars, would pay them a premium of up to 1.50 per cent on repay- ment. March 20. The Exchange Office renewed its dollar swaps with authorized banks. On April 11 it began to unwind them in part. On June 13 the remaining swaps were extended for a fur ther three months and the Exchange Office again offered banks a premium to compensate them for interest rate differ- entials. On July 2, a further unwinding of the swaps took place. March 27. Applications for foreign exchange for resi- dents temporarily living abroad for reasons of study, etc., had to be submitted to the Exchange Office when in excess of Lit 500,000 a mon th. April 1. Imports from non-EEC countries of tape recorders were restricted. April 9.
