April 12. A law providing for exchange risk guarantees for Italian exporters was approved. April 19. Settlements in respect of imports from and ex- ports to Eastern Germany became subject to the normal procedure applicable to any other country. April 30. Banks were prohibited, except on the basis of ministerial authorizations, from opening credits for imports of tape recorders from countries that are not members of the EEC. May 8. The supervision over the use of imported unrefined gold was tightened. July 27. Payments for imports and services contracted on a deferred payment basis (for settlement more than 360 days after the date of importation) could no longer be made at any date earlier than the one agreed in the contract, unless the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade was ob- tained. July 27. A deposit requirement was introduced against outward transfers of resident-owned capital for direct invest- ments, portfolio investments, financial loans, purchases of real estate, and personal capital movements. The transferor had to lodge a lira deposit equivalent to 50 per cent of the amount transferred (25 per cent for investment fund securi- ties, but an exemption was granted to mutual funds investing entirely in Italian securities) in a noninterest-bearing account w i th the bank effecting the transfer. The latter had to pass the deposit on to the Bank of Italy. In addition, when foreign investments were transferred between residents against lire, the transferee was subject to the deposit requirement, irre- spective of the date when the investment was made. The deposits were released only when, and to the extent that, disinvestment operations occurred, and their release required the prior approval of the Exchange Office. (On September 21, this approval authority was shifted to the local Bank of Italy offices with which the deposits have been lodged.) Exemp- tions from the deposit requirement were subsequently granted on a case-by-case basis for certain direct investment operations and by exchange control circular for residents' ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution subscriptions to certain bond issues of financial institutions of the EEC. July 27. Certain reporting requirements were introduced for "money brokers" operating in Italy as intermediaries in transactions in foreign exchange, securities, etc., with foreign countries. July 30. Advance payments for imports of goods and ser- vices could be made only with foreign exchange borrowed from authorized Italian banks. July 30. Banks, which (although permitted and encouraged to incur a negative overall external position) already had to maintain a balanced overall foreign currency position (overall position in conto valutario currencies, spot and forward com- bined), were required to keep balanced foreign currency posi- tions separately in U.S. dollars, EEC currencies, and all other conto valutario currencies combined, on a daily basis. August 3. An exemption from the deposit requirement against outward investments of Italian capital was given for the subscription to, and the transfer against lire between residents of, shares of mutual funds authorized to operate in Italy that specifically undertook to comply with the condition that the increase of investments in Italy after July 30, 1973 would never be less than the total new net savings taken up in Italy by the fund concerned. August 21. The limit up to which credit cards could be used abroad was raised to 80 per cent of the basic exchange alloca- tions for travel for purposes of tourism, business, study, or health. August 29. Prepayments for imports of goods and services valued at less than Lit 1 million were exempted from the requirement that foreign exchange should be borrowed from authorized banks; the facility was not applicable where the payment formed part of a larger transaction. September 7. An exemption from the deposit requirement was granted for purchases by residents of securities of the European Investment Bank (EIB), limited to new issues ad- mitted for placing in Italy; a similar exemption was granted on November 8 for bonds issued by the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) and the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) after the en try into force of the Min- isterial Decree of July 27, 1973, an exemption limited to those loans of which a part had been or would be allowed to be placed in Italy; bonds from the portions of those loans placed in other countries could be purchased free from deposit once they were quoted on the foreign stock exchanges concerned, and this was made applicable also to the EIB securities men- tioned in the regulation of September 7. October 9. Controls were imposed on exports of certain petroleum products to non-EEC countries. On November 15 ITALY these controls were extended to other petroleum products and applied also to the EEC countries. October 22. In connection with the fiscal reform, a require- ment was introduced that the shares of all companies located on Italian territory must be registered. Previously, companies in certain regions with a special constitutional status were exempt. November 8. Residents' purchases of all bonds issued by the ECSC and EURATOM after the en try in to force of the special deposit requirement (see July 27, above) were ex- empted from the deposit. NOTE.—The following changes took place early in 1974: January 1. A new tax law came into effect. Among other things, it introduced a 15 per cent withholding tax on interest payments, but it exempted bank deposits held by nonresident banks from this tax. February 3. The amount of the swap agreement between the Bank of Italy and the U.S. Federal Reserve System was increased from US$2 billion to US$3 billion. March 5. The Bank of Italy announced that public sector borrowing in the Euro-markets had amounted to US$5.6 billion in the second half of 1973. March 5. It was announced that notes to be issued shortly by the ECSC would not be eligible for exemption from the deposit requirement against capital outflows. March 8. The amount of Italian banknotes that resident and nonresident travelers could freely bring in or take out was reduced to Lit 20,000 a person a trip (previously Lit 500,000 for departing travelers and unlimited upon entry); for persons living in border areas, the same daily limit was applicable for imports and exports of Italian banknotes, but within this limit they could take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the equivalent of Lit 10,000. The foreign exchange allowances to residents for all types of personal foreign travel were main- tained unchanged but henceforth had to be marked in the traveler's passport. Furthermore, returning residents no longer were permitted to retain any leftover foreign bank- notes or travelers checks for subsequent use. Additional re- porting requirements were introduced for certain outward remittances. March 12. Medium-term loans granted or received by Ital- ian banks in connection with imports or exports of goods or services, whether expressed in lire or in foreign currency, henceforth had to be settled in Foreign Account lire or in foreign currency related to an Ordinary Foreign Currency Account. Previously, such loans were settled through the financial exchange market. 241 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IVORY COAST Exchange System No par value for the currency of Ivory Coast has been established with the Fund. The un it of currency is the CFA Franc, 1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transactions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02, free of commissions. Exchange transactions relating to countries other than France, Monaco, and the countries whose ins t i tu te of issue is linked to the French Treasury by an Operations Account take place in a dual exchange market, at rates based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange rate for the currency concerned in either the official exchange market or the financial f ranc market. Settlements eligible for the official exchange market are payments and receipts in respect of imports, exports, and most other current transactions, as well as all current payments by or in favor of domestic and foreign public authorities and public bodies. All other settlements w i th foreign countries, as well as all transactions in bank- notes, take place through the financial franc market at freely f luc tua t ing rates. The principal current payments and receipts channeled through the financial franc market are those relat- ing to travel expenses, capital earnings, and workers' remit- tances. Exchange rates for certain European currencies in the official market are based on par values and central rates; the effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar in this market is not confined w i th in any announced margins. With the exception of those relating to gold, Ivory Coast's exchange control measures do not apply in financial relations w i th (1) France and its Overseas Departments and Territories (except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is l inked w i th the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Ivo ry Coast itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only w i th foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Directorate of External Finance and Credit of the Directorate-General of Public Accounts and the Treasury in the M in is try of Econ- omy and Finance, which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securi- ties in Ivory Coast, foreign inward direct investment, and all ou tward investment in foreign countries. The BCEAO is au- thorized to collect any informa t ion necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics, either direct or through the 1 The CFA f n > nc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de POuest (BCEA«J, and is the common currency in Dahomey, Ivo ry Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 242 intermediary of banks, other financial institutions, the Postal Administration, and notaries public. All exchange transac- tions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks or the Postal Administration. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate for Licenses and Foreign Trade Regulations in the Directorate-General of Economic Affairs and External Economic Relations. Import attestations for liberalized commodities are made out by the importer himself. Prescription of Currency Ivory Coast is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Opera- tions Account with the French Treasury; settlements with France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except that of the Afars and the Issas), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign or Financial Accounts in Francs. All settlements with Rhodesia are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO banknotes may be credited to Financial Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Abidjan by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of such banknotes is pro- hibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Certain imports f rom the People's Republic of China, Hong Kong, Japan, and Portugal are suspended. A few imports from all sources are prohibited (e.g., a specified type of coffee-husking machine and wheat flour) or subject to import license (e.g., sugar, paints, matches, and detergents). Imports of certain com- modities, including rice, are linked to purchases of the domes- tic product. All other imports from countries in the French Franc Area may be made freely. Virtually all imports origi- na t ing in EEC countries other than France or shipped from those countries also are free from quantitative restrictions and free of license; the exceptions are some 16 items on a special list. As a rule, imports from non-EEC countries outside the French Franc Area require import licenses and may be made in accordance w i th an import program, which is determined annua l ly by the Directorate of Economic Affairs and Exter- nal Economic Relations. Under this program, semiannual global quotas are established for imports from such countries and special quotas for imports from countries with which Ivory Coast maintains bilateral trade agreements. 2 The pro- 2 These inc lude Republic of China, Denmark, Egypt, Hungary, Israel, Japan, No rway, Poland, Sweden, and Switzerland. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution gram also includes indicative quotas for the EEC countries and a quota for Hong Kong and Eastern European countries. The quotas establish limits up to which import licenses may be issued, for specified commodities, to licensed importers and, in exceptional cases, to industrial or agricultural produc- ers who are considered as end-users of the imported goods. Certain products, contained in separate liberalized lists, may be imported freely from any source, from the former OEEC countries, or from Canada and the United States, respec- tively. All import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value ex- ceeds CFAF 500,000; transactions of lower value must be domiciled if a financial transaction is to be undertaken before customs clearance. The import licenses or import attestations entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles Payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Payments for invisi- bles to France, Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to approval. Payments for invis- ibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authoriza- tion. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely when the basic transaction has been approved. Any resident may freely and at any time make remittances abroad up to the equivalent of CFAF 50,000 w i thout indicating their purpose. Residents traveling to countries other than France, Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation for tourism of an amount equivalent to CFAF 175,000 a person a year (CFAF 87,500 for children under ten); any foreign exchange remaining in excess of CFAF 5,000 after return to Ivory Coast must be surrendered. The transfer of the full basic salary of a foreigner work ing in Ivory Coast is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, provided that the transfer takes place w i th in three months of the pay period. Resident and nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may take out BCEAO banknotes up to CFAF 25,000. Travel- ers to other Franc Area countries may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes, but if going to a country that is not a member of the West African Monetary Union, the amount taken out must be declared to the customs if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may freely take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the equivalent of CFAF 175,000 as well as any travelers checks, etc., issued abroad. Subject to documentation, they may also take out any amount of travelers checks, etc., in foreign currency es- tablished in their name after conversion of foreign currency into CFA francs or drawn against a Foreign Account in Francs or a foreign currency account in Ivory Coast. Nonresi- IVORY COAST dents who have made a currency declaration upon entry or are able to show the proper banking notices may take out higher amounts. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports are free of license and require a declaration only. Exports of agricultural commodities, however, require the visa of the Directorate for Licenses and Foreign Trade Regulations. Ex- port proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Operations Account country must be sur- rendered within two months of the due date, which must not be later than 180 days after the arrival of the goods at their destination. All export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when valued at CFAF 500,000 or more. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France, Mo- naco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date or the date of receipt. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue maintaining an Opera- tions Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area; residents bringing in foreign banknotes or other foreign means of payment must sell any amount in excess of CFAF 5,000 to an authorized bank within eight days and must declare them to the customs upon en try. Capital All capital movements between Ivory Coast and Rhodesia are prohibited. Capital movements between Ivory Coast and France, Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control ap- proval, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control re- quirements that may be applicable) are maintained over bor- rowing abroad, over foreign inward direct investment, over all outward investment in foreign countries, and over the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Ivory Coast; these controls relate to the transactions them- selves, not to payments or receipts. With the exception of those relating to foreign securities, these control measures do not apply to relations with France and its Overseas Depart- ments and Territories (except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas), Monaco, the other member countries of the West African Monetary Union, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account. Special controls are maintained also 243 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IVORY COAST over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special controls also apply to France, Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All investments abroad by residents of Ivory Coast require prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Fi- nance. 3 Foreign direct investments in Ivory Coast, 4 must be declared to the Minister of Economy and Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to him. The liquida- tion of investments, whether direct investments or not, in Ivory Coast or abroad must similarly be declared in advance to the Minister. Both the making and the liquidation of in- vestments, whether these are Ivory Coast investments abroad or foreign investments in Ivory Coast, must be reported to the Minister within 20 days following each operation. Direct in- vestments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign secu- rities in Ivory Coast requires prior authorization by the Min- ister of Economy and Finance, as do issues by Ivory Coast companies. Exempt from authorization, however, are opera- tions in connection w i th (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Ivory Coast Government and (2) shares similar to securi- ties whose issue, offering, or sale in Ivory Coast has previ- ously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans cons t i tu t ing a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance transactions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports into or exports from Ivory Coast, or by approved international trading houses to finance inter- national merchanting transactions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; and (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, inc lud ing the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 50 mil- lion for any one borrower, and provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment re- quires the special authorization of the Minister if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. 3 Including those made through the intermediary of foreign companies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Ivory Coast and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Ivory Coast. 4 Inc lud ing those made by companies in Ivory Coast that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Ivory Coast of foreign companies. 244 Lending abroad is subject to exchange control authoriza- tion. The lending of CFA francs to nonresidents for periods of up to two years, however, is freely permitted. Law No. 59-134 of September 3, 1959 provides tax and customs du ty benefits and other special privileges for new enterprises recognized as having priority status. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Ivory Coast. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance, which is rarely granted. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold articles up to a weight of 250 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports and exports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Changes during 1973 January 29. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.900364 gram of f ine gold per Jamaica Dollar. A central rate of J$l = US$1.10 has been established, corresponding to JS1.09668 = SDR 1 or 0.810328 gram of fine gold per Jamaica dollar. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar and Jamaica avails itself of wider margins. In practice, the Bank of Jamaica's dealings against Jamaica dollars are confined to transactions in U.S. dollars and ster- ling, to purchases of U.S. and Canadian banknotes, and to purchases of certain Caribbean banknotes and coins (see be- low). It deals in other currencies only against U.S. dollars and sterling. The Bank buys and sells U.S. dollars at par, plus a commission of 3/16 of 1 per cent on the selling side. Exchange rates for currencies other than the U.S. dollar (except the Barbados dollar, the East Caribbean dollar, the Guyana dol- lar, and the Trinidad and Tobago dollar) are based on the Bank of Jamaica's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar and the rates against the U.S. dollar for the currencies con- cerned in international markets. The Bank of Jamaica sets daily official buying and selling rates for dealing with the banks in sterling and Canadian dollars on the basis of the previous day's closing quotations in New York. On the basis of these rates, the Bank also fixes daily rates at which com- mercial banks must deal with their customers in transactions up to J$25,000 involving Jamaica dollars against sterling or Canadian dollars. The Bank of Jamaica is authorized by law to fix its buy ing and selling rates of exchange. On December 31, 1973 these rates relating to spot dealings with the commercial banks reflected no commission charge on purchases but a charge of %6 of 1 per cent on sales. The commercial banks applied a commission charge (premium) of % of 1 per cent on sales of foreign exchange to customers and a commission charge (dis- count) of Yg of 1 per cent on purchases. For purchases equiva- lent to J$ 1,000 or more, the commission charge (discount) was waived. Under an arrangement with the central banks of Barbados, Guyana, and Trinidad and Tobago and with the East Carib- bean Currency Au thor i ty, the Bank of Jamaica purchases banknotes and coins issued by these monetary authorities and repatriates them in return for reciprocity of treatment w i th respect to collections of Jamaica dollars. The Bank's pur- chases are made at the middle rate determined on the basis of the prevailing sterling/U.S. dollar rate; for transactions in these currencies, the commercial banks charge a commission of V4 of 1 per cent either side of the middle rate, buying and selling. There is a "bourse" (interbank exchange market) in which all commercial banks participate and in which only sterling and Canadian dollars are traded against U.S. dollars. Capital transactions between nonresidents and nonbank residents are channeled through an investment currency mar- ket. Transactions are subject on the buying side to a premium of 10 per cent on the Bank of Jamaica's buying rate and on the selling side to a premium of 20 per cent on the Bank of Jamaica's buying rate (plus the normal commission charged on sales of exchange). Jamaica formally accepted the obligations of Article V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from Febru- ary 22, 1963. Administration of Control The Bank of Jamaica administers exchange control on be- half of the Minister of Finance, subject to certain limitations in respect of which the approval of the Minister is required. The commercial banks are designated as authorized dealers and have authority to provide foreign exchange for imports up to J$ 10,000, and for basic travel allowances and certain other payments up to specified lesser amounts. Import li- censes are issued by the Trade Administrator, who is respon- sible to the Minister of Industry, Commerce, and Tourism. Prescription of Currency Jamaica has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Payments to all countries may be made by crediting Ja- maica dollars to an External Account or in any foreign cur- rency. 1 Receipts from all countries must be received by debit of an External Account or in any foreign currency. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia, and all pay- ments to Rhodesia require specific authorization. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts in Jamaica dollars may be held by persons who are regarded for exchange control purposes as normally permanently resident outside Jamaica. These ac- counts are fur ther designated External Accounts or Blocked Accounts. The commercial banks are empowered to open External Accounts in Jamaica dollars for nonresidents except residents of Rhodesia, provided that no credit of Jamaica dollars is made to the accounts w i thout the specific approval of the Bank of Jamaica. The funds on these accounts may be trans- ferred freely between nonresidents. External Accounts may be credited with payments by residents of Jamaica approved by the exchange control authorities, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from the sale to an authorized dealer of gold or foreign currencies. They may be debited for payments to residents of Jamaica, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for the purchase of foreign currencies. Accounts which are credited w i th funds that may not be placed at the free disposal of nonresidents of Jamaica (includ- ing the proceeds from the sale of undeveloped land) are desig- nated Blocked Accounts. Blocked funds may be invested in Jamaica dollar securities; the income from such securities is 1 All currencies other than the Jamaica dollar are considered foreign currencies. All foreign currencies have been designated as specified currencies. 245 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA normally available for credit to an External Account. Funds originally held on a Blocked Account and the proceeds of Jamaican securities purchased with blocked funds are nor- mally available for credit to an External Account four years after the date of blocking. Applications for the release of funds in Blocked Accounts for use in Jamaica by the nonresi- dent owner must be referred to the Bank of Jamaica. The assets of residents emigrating to countries outside Jamaica in excess of the prescribed settling-in allowance of J$ 10,000 are restricted for a period of four years (see section on Capital, below). Imports and Import Payments Many goods may be imported freely under an open general license.2 Virtually all imports from CARIFTA countries and countries of the Caribbean Common Market are unrestricted. Imports originating in Rhodesia are prohibited and all im- ports originating in the People's Republic of China, the CMEA countries, Cuba, Portugal, or South Africa require individual import licenses. A number of tar iff items or groups of tariff items included in a special schedule of exceptions to the open general license are subject to individual licensing irrespective of country of origin unless (for some of the items in this schedule) the goods originate in and are consigned from other CARIFTA countries (Antigua, Barbados, Belize, Dominica, Grenada, Guyana, Montserrat, St. Kitts- Nevis-Anguilla, St. Lucia, St. Vincent, or Trinidad and To- bago). The special schedule comprises (1) goods for which specific quotas are assigned to importers according to their past performance, e.g., certain types of footwear, cheese, rice, and various consumer durables (for these items import li- censes are granted by the Trade Administrator against allot- ted quotas); (2) goods which are prohibited, e.g., certain automobiles, radios, television sets, canned milk, cement, ci- gars, citrus products, cheap clothing, household detergents, sugar, and coffee; (3) goods the licensing of which depends upon local supply, e.g., poultry, eggs, and vegetables; and (4) goods licensed to meet the requirements of the tourist indus- try only (including some liquors and sports goods). 3 Payments for imports equivalent to J$ 10,000 or more are subject to prior registration with the Bank of Jamaica and all payments for imports are subject to the licensing require- ments, if any, being met, and the importer presenting a copy of the settlement invoice or other evidence of purchase and value, together with documentary evidence that the goods either have been shipped or are about to be shipped, or that the importer is under contract to make prepayment up to six months prior to shipment; specific exchange control approval 2 The open general license applies to all countries except Albania, Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hun- gary, North Korea, Poland, Portugal (and associated territories), Rhodesia, Romania, South Africa, U.S.S.R., and Nor th Viet-Nam. Goods imported under the license must be consigned from one of the permitted countries and must also originate in a permitted country. (On January 21, 1974 it was announced that the ban on trade with Cuba would be revoked in June 1974.) 3 On January 23, 1974 it was announced that imports of consumer goods in 1974 would be reduced from estimated 1973 levels by J$79 million; certain items were banned, textile quotas were reduced, and imports of automobiles would be limited to J$5 million, subject to a c.i.f. value limit of J$3,000 for each vehicle, and those of commercial vehicles to J$10 million. Certain goods are subject to a consumption tax, whether they are imported or manufactured domestically. Where such goods are imported, the tax is collected at the port of entry and is calculated on the sum of the value accepted for customs and the customs du ty. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles require the approval of the ex- change control authorities. Except for transactions involving residents of Rhodesia, the following applies. With the excep- tion of payments in respect of foreign travel, bona fide current payments are not restricted. Approval is granted freely for payments for all commercial transactions, when the applica- tion is supported by the appropriate documentary evidence. A basic exchange allocation of JS500 a person for each 12-month period for foreign travel other than for business and professional reasons is made available automatically to residents by the authorized dealers. Additional amounts are granted in cases of hardship. Facilities for travel for business and professional reasons may be provided by authorized banks at the rate of J$60 a day for up to ten days a trip while applications for higher amounts are dealt with by the central bank. Expenses for hotel accommodations, meals en route, etc., that are settled in Jamaica in domestic currency must be deducted from the travel allocations. Authorized dealers may, subject to the presentation of sup- porting evidence, approve payments for the following: re- funds of income tax due to nonresidents; consular fees without limit, as well as transfers from the Ministry of Exter- nal Affairs to accounts in the names of embassies and their established staffs, High Commissioners, and diplomats; up to a limit of J$2,000 for (1) advertising and promotional ex- penses, (2) renewal and refund of premiums due to nonresi- dent insurers, and (3) subscriptions to trade organizations; up to a limit of J$4,000 for commissions and expenses due by Jamaican firms to their agents and representatives and for serial rights in Jamaica of newspaper and magazine articles, photographs, strip cartoons, etc. Requests for additional amounts (except for travel) or for purposes for which there are no standard limits (e.g., remittances by charitable institu- tions) are approved if the authorities are satisfied that no capital flight is involved. 4 Residents going abroad may take with them Jamaica bank- notes not exceeding J$20 and other banknotes not exceeding JS100. Domestic bank credit to nonresidents of Jamaica and to nonresident-con- trolled companies is subject to selective credit controls; for this purpose, firms are considered to be nonresident-con- trolled when the controlling interest is held beneficially, ei- ther directly or indirectly, by persons resident outside CARIFTA. Such lending is subject to approval by the Bank of Jamaica; authorized dealers may, however, w i thout reference to the exchange control authorities, make loans or overdrafts to nonresidents of Jamaica up to J$2,000 for certain specified purposes. Authorized dealers may also without reference to the exchange control authorities make loans or overdrafts to resident companies or branches controlled by nonresidents up to J$20,000, provided that the borrower is not specifically precluded under some prior conditional permission from the exchange control authorities. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, Jamaica established a central rate of J$l = US$1.10, corresponding to 0.810328 gram of fine gold per Jamaica dollar or J$ 1.09668 = SDR 1, and contin- ued to avail itself of wider margins. The effective parity rela- tionship for the U.S. dollar remained unchanged. May 1. The Bank of Jamaica Law, 1960 was amended. Modifications included the following. The provision that the Bank was required to deal in sterling was removed. The spe- cial position of investments in U.K. Government securities was eliminated, the only distinction henceforth made in the law being that between Jamaican Government securities and non-Jamaican Government securities. The Bank was empow- ered to prescribe the maximum amount of working balances that commercial banks may hold in foreign currencies. May 1. The Banking (Amendment) Act, 1973 amended the Banking Law, 1960. Among other things, the minimum capi- tal requirements were increased for both local and foreign banks. A specified minimum amount of the capital of the latter had to be specifically assigned to the financing of their Jamaican operations. May 11. Notice No. 2855 prohibited imports of virtually all footwear. Notice No. 2856 made imports of leather condi- tional on purchases locally or from CARIFTA sources, at a ratio of 1 to 2. June 5. The application of exchange control to the Sterling Area was extended for another six months by a further exten- sion of the Exchange Control (Currency) Order, 1971. On December 5, it was again extended for six months. August 1. The Caribbean Common Market came into ef- fect; Jamaica was one of the four initial members. August 1. The common external tariff of the Caribbean Common Market came into force. August 1. The Jamaica dollar ceased to be legal tender in the Turks and Caicos Islands, where it was replaced by the U.S. dollar. November 1. Commercial banks were required to maintain a minimum of 21 per cent of their deposit liabilities in domes- tic liquid assets. Not for Redistribution JAPAN Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.00246853 gram of f ine gold per Japanese Yen, corresponding to Y 360 = SDR 1. A central rate has been established of Y 308.00 = US$1, corresponding to Y 334.4 = SDR 1, and Japan avails itself of wider margins. Since February 14, 1973, however, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the yen w i th in any an- nounced margins, and therefore all spot exchange transac- tions take place at a f luc tua t ing exchange rate. The in te rbank selling rate for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1973 was about Y 280 per US$1. 1 Authorized banks may freely carry out spot and forward exchange transactions w i th nonresident banks and among themselves; their forward transactions w i th resident customers must have a permitted underlying transac- tion. Japan formally accepted the obligations of Article V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from April 1, 1964. Administration of Control The exchange control system is operated by the M in is try of Finance, the M in is try of International Trade and Indu s t ry (MITI), and the Bank of Japan as the Government's agent. However, most of the au thor i ty for approving normal pay- ments is delegated to authorized banks referred to as foreign exchange banks. Import and export licensing is handled by MITI. Inward direct investments of a long-term character, unless fu l ly liberalized, require the approval of the Minister of Finance and the competent minister (in some cases that of the Minister of Finance only) af ter deliberation in certain important cases by the Foreign Investment Council. Outward direct investments require the approval of the Minister of Finance in exceptional cases only. Prescription of Currency Payments to all countries may be made in any currency, including yen, and receipts also may be obtained in any cur- rency. Settlements in yen w i th foreign countries must be made through a Nonresident Free Yen Account. All payments to Rhodesia require prior approval by the Minister of Finance or the Minister of In terna t ional Trade and Indus t ry; in many cases such payments are prohibited or restricted for security reasons. Nonresident Accounts There are two main nonresident accounts, as described below. 1. Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. These accounts may be opened by any nonresident w i th any authorized bank in Ja- pan and may be credited w i th the yen proceeds from exports of goods to Japan and from other authorized transactions, with yen proceeds from sales of all foreign currencies, w i th transfers from other Free Yen Accounts, w i th balances out- standing on December 31, 1970 on Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts (see below), and w i th the countervalue in yen of authorized ou tward payments. There are no restrictions on payments from these accounts, and balances may be con- verted freely in to any foreign currency. Marginal reserve re- quirements are applied against increases in each authorized bank's liabilities on Free Yen Accounts over the average level in a specified base period. 2. Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts. These accounts may be held by any nonresident with any authorized bank in Japan. They may be credited w i th yen proceeds from transac- tions other than those which are authorized to be credited to Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. Permitted credits to Non- resident Yen Deposit Accounts are limited mainly to pro- ceeds from the sales of debentures and beneficiary certificates sold within six mon ths from the date of validated acquisition. Balances outstanding on December 31, 1970 were permitted to be transferred to Nonresident Free Yen Accounts or to be remitted abroad. Balances accrued after that date are not convertible in to foreign currencies, although remittances are permitted each year up to 30 per cent of the balance at the end of the previous year or the equivalent of Y 720,000, whichever is higher. Withdrawals from these accounts are authorized for certain purposes, such as meeting the outlays involved in managing investments in Japan and the expenses of nonresidents staying in Japan. Transfers to other Nonresi- dent Yen Deposit Accounts may be made freely, thus en- abling the individual account holder to repatriate his funds by selling them to another nonresident in return for foreign cur- rency, but there is no market for such funds in Japan. In addition, there are Foreign Investors' Deposit Accounts in which certain proceeds from investments liquidated by foreigners may be placed. Balances on these accounts may be used for remittances abroad or for making other investments under certain conditions. However, these accounts are of lim- ited importance, because proceeds from foreigners' liquidated investments may be remitted through Nonresident Free Yen Accounts w i thout having been placed in Foreign Investors' Deposit Accounts. Funds remitted to Japan by nonresidents for portfolio investment are channeled through Nonresident Free Yen Accounts, Nonresident Foreign Currencies Deposit Accounts, or Foreign Currencies Securities Special Accounts opened at foreign exchange banks in the name of Japanese securities dealers. Funds in Nonresident Foreign Currencies Deposit Accounts or Foreign Currencies Securities Special Accounts may be channeled through Yen Securities Special Accounts opened at foreign exchange banks in the name of Japanese securities dealers, provided that firm contracts exist for the purchase of specific securities and that the funds will not remain in the account for more than one month. 2 Imports and Import Payments With the exception of books and periodicals, imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Other imports are subject either to individual licensing by the authorized banks or, if liberalized, 1 On Janua ry 7, 1974 the rate moved to about Y 300 per US$1. 2 This l im i ta t ion was removed w i th effect f rom January 17, 1974. 249 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAPAN to declaration to such banks. Most private imports are liber- alized. There are two procedures for imports requ ir ing pay- ment in foreign currencies: (1) Under the Import Quota System (covering imports of goods on the "negative list," wh ich comprises 83 items, in terms of the fou r -d ig it Brussels nomenclature; 32 of the 83 items on the "negative list" have been notified to the GATT as residual restrictions while the other 51 items have been no t if ied as f a l l ing under the na t ional security, public health, and moral protection provisions of the GATT), the importer must f irst obtain from MITI an import quota, which is based on the quan t i ta t ive principle. If the quota is granted, the importer receives an import quo ta certif- icate which entitles him to receive an import license from an authorized bank automatically upon application. Practically all import quota certificates are issued on a global basis, w i thout regard to the coun try of origin or the currency of settlement, by MITI. (2) Under the Declaration System, im- ports are free of quan t i ta t ive restriction and licensing and require only a declaration by the importer to a foreign ex- change bank. All items subject to the Declaration System may be imported from any coun try except Rhodesia. Items under state trading include certain dairy products, certain cereals, salt, and raw and manu fac tu red tobacco. Payment for imported goods must be made under one of the "standard" methods of settlement for imports. When the settlement proposal is not in accordance w i th one of the "standard" methods (i.e., when certain advance payment is proposed or payment is to be made more than four mon ths after customs clearance), prior approval of MITI must be obtained. Payments for Invisibles All payments to Rhodesia are subject to the approval of the Minister of Finance or the Minister of In terna t ional Trade and Indus t ry. Payments to other countries for invisibles also require approval, but current payments are not restricted and most such payments are approved freely by foreign exchange banks w i thout any l im i ta t ion or w i th in certain established limits. Payments for certain invisibles, inc lud ing paymen ts that exceed the established limits, are referred to the Bank of Japan for the purpose of capital control; they are automati- cally approved w i thout undue delay, upon verification of the au then t ic i ty of the current transaction. Exports and Export Proceeds W i th m inor exceptions exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. All exports to Iran, Iraq, and Nigeria require special authori- zation. All exports (except exports w i thout exchange) must be registered w i th a foreign exchange ("bank certification"). Licenses are not generally required, except for goods sub- ject to the following restrictions: restrictions on certain goods to control their export to specified communist countries; re- strictions on goods in short supply in the domestic market (e.g., m inera ls, fertilizers, and staple foods); and restrictions designed to forestall the imposition of import restrictions by other countries (e.g., on sewing machines and certain tex- tiles). Exports under processing and consignment sale con- tracts and exports for which settlement is not under the "standard" method also require ind iv idual licenses. Under the "standard" method of settlement for exports, the value of the exported goods mus t, in general, be settled by d raw ing a bill of exchange payable w i th in five months after sight or w i th in six mon ths af ter sh ipmen t. Certain types of outflows of long-term capital are facilitated by a foreign currency lend- ing system under which government institutions and foreign exchange banks are authorized to make foreign currency loans to residents for up to 90 per c e n tll of their direct investment operations abroad and for advance payments in respect of imports. Outward financial credits and loans are subject to licensing. The issuing of bonds abroad, including issues for conversion in to yen for domestic use, also is subject to licensing; at the end of 1973 such issues were being permit- ted selectively. Securities acquired w i th approval under the Law Concern- ing Foreign Investment may be imported and exported freely. Foreign exchange banks are subject to controls over their overall net position in foreign currency (spot and forward combined). The switching of foreign funds in to yen by foreign exchange banks is also subject to regulation; their interoffice liabilities on Nonresident Free Yen Accounts are regarded as foreign exchange liabilities for the application of this regula- tion. These banks are also subject to marginal reserve require- ments against increases in their liabilities on Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. The interest rates on such accounts and on nonresident-owned foreign currency accounts must not exceed those on resident-owned deposits, but otherwise are not subject to control. Gold Residents, including domestic producers of gold, may freely hold gold and purchase and sell it in domestic transac- tions. The import of gold bullion containing more than 45 per cent gold in weight normally is permitted, provided a pay- ments license is obtained from the Bank of Japan; the volume of gold bullion imports may, however, be restricted at the discretion of the authorities if it reaches a level that would result in a disruptive influence on international gold markets. Imports of other gold bullion, gold coins, and most articles of gold are freely permitted, subject only to verification by a foreign exchange bank. Travelers (resident or nonresident) are freely permitted to bring in up to one kilogram of gold bullion a person a trip and up to the equivalent of US$1,000 in articles of gold and gold coins. 12 Gold bullion, gold coins, and gold articles acquired by donation or inheritance may be imported freely, subject only to verification by the customs authorities. Exports of gold bullion, gold coins, and articles of gold by residents require licenses from the M in is try of Finance; exports of gold bullion are not normally permitted. These countries were Albania, Bulgaria, the Peo- ple's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, North Korea, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and North Viet-Nam. 11 Reduced to 50 per cent w i th effect from Janua ry 7, 1974. 12 Reduced to US$200 w i th effect f rom April 1, 1974. 252 January I. Export control measures were imposed under the Export Control Ordinance and the Export-Import Trans- action Law, as part of the Third Yen Defense Program; they applied to 20 major export commodities. January 16. The prior licensing system applicable to im- ports from countries with which no diplomatic relations were maintained was relaxed in respect of the People's Republic of China. January 30. A Ministry of Finance ordinance was issued describing, for registration statement purposes, the disclosure requirements applicable to foreign private enterprises, thus facilitating public offerings in Japan by foreign corporate issuers. In May, the Ministry of Finance and the Tokyo Stock Exchange announced that they accepted in principle the lis- t ing of foreign stocks on the Exchange by mid-July; applica- tions for listing would be accepted if financial statements were presented on a nonconsolidated basis (i.e., giving data for the parent company only). February 5. The "leeway" provision for nonresidents1 pur- chases of domestic equities was revoked and the use of the "swing system" for such transactions became subject to ap- proval by the Ministry of Finance. February 14. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the Japanese Government decided to allow the Japanese yen to float in the market; with effect from February 14, the market rate of the yen would not necessarily be confined w i th in the margins hitherto observed. The U.S. dollar opened at about Y 271.20. Previously, ex- change rates for the U.S. dollar were based on the central rate of Y 308 = US$1, w i th official limits of Y 314.93 and Y 301.07, per US$1. February 26. The Foreign Exchange Fund Special Ac- count resumed deposits of foreign currency with foreign ex- change banks for forward cover for the exports of small and medium-size enterprises. April 1. Import duties were reduced on 105 commodities. April 1. Japan's scheme of generalized preferences for de- veloping countries was expanded as to country coverage and commodity coverage, and some of the preferential duties were reduced. The scheme was also fu r ther liberalized administra- tively. April 1. The prohibition on private imports of industrial gold (bars and ingots) and of gold coins was lifted. Further- more, resident travelers were freely permitted to bring in up to one kilogram of industrial gold a person a trip. At the same time, it was announced that imports of articles of gold would be liberalized on Ju ly 1, 1973. (The volume of bullion imports could be limited at the discretion of the authorities if it reached a level that exerted a disruptive effect on interna- tional gold markets.) April 13. The remaining import quotas were increased ei- ther by 30 per cent over the levels in the fiscal year 1972 or to 8 per cent of domestic consumption, whichever was larger. April 19. Imports of certain commodities, including digital electronic calculating machines, were liberalized. The number of residual restrictions notified to the GATT was reduced from 33 to 32. May 1. The foreign currency lending system was expanded. The proportion of loans that borrowers could take up in the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution form of foreign currency was raised from 70 per cent to 90 per cent and the use of these loans, which previously was limited ma in ly to outward direct investment, was permitted also for real estate purchases abroad and for advance pay- ments in respect of any type of imports. May 1. The restrictions on the acquisition by nonresidents of Japanese shares in individual companies were relaxed. The new measure eliminated the restrictions on the acquisition of stocks for portfolio investment (as well as those on the acqui- sition of stocks for participation in management), provided that the company concerned consented to foreign participa- tion (and except in the 22 industries to which the liberaliza- tion of inward direct investment was not immediately applicable). Previously, the acquisition on a portfolio basis was permitted only where the combined foreign ownership of a company's shares remained below 25 per cent (or in some cases up to 15 per cent, depending on the type of indus try) and where an individual foreign investor's holdings remained below 10 per cent of the company's share capital; the same 25 per cent and 10 per cent limits previously determined the point beyond which the acquisition of stocks for participation in the management of existing companies was subject to indi- vidual screening by the competent ministries. May 1. Further liberalization measures for inward direct investment were taken. These implied that in and after 1976 virtually all industries would be fu l ly open to foreign owner- ship (provided, in all cases, that the enterprise concerned consented to the investment); most of the industries affected were 50 per cent liberalized prior to May, and the earlier liberalization measures normally were applicable only to the establishment of new firms, not to take-overs or participa- tions in existing firms. As a result of the new measures, the number of nonliberalized industries was reduced to five: pri- mary indus t ry related to agriculture, forestry, and fisheries; the mining indus try (liberalized up to 50 per cent, as before); the oil industry; the leather products manufac tur ing indus t ry; and retailing (liberalized up to 50 per cent, as before, for operations not exceeding 11 stores). For another 17 industries full liberalization was postponed for periods to be determined later but not exceeding three years. All other industries were liberalized, w i th foreign ownership permissible up to 100 per cent. July 1. Impor ts of manufactured articles of gold (jewelry in the form of watch bands, bracelets, brooches, etc., fa l l ing within tariff headings 71.12 and 71.13) were liberalized. It was announced that imports of gold necklaces would remain controlled un t il April 1, 1974. July 17. The basic rules regarding the listing of foreign shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange were announced; they were to become effective on November 6. August 31. The export control measures that had entered into force on January 1 as part of the Third Yen Defense Program were allowed to lapse. Septembers. Forward trading on the Tokyo exchange mar- ket switched to the fixed-date delivery system, for interbank transactions only. Previously, the calendar mon th system was used, under which forward exchange could be delivered on any business day w i th in a calendar month, at the buyer's option. JAPAN September 4. November 15. The Central Bank's official limits for the U.S. dollar are US$3.1811 buy ing, and US$3.0303 selling, per JD 1 and commercial banks deal w i th the public w i th in these limits. On December 31, 1973, the Central Bank's buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$3.0488 and US$3.0303 per dinar, and those for sterling were £ stg. 1.3101 and £ stg. 1.3004 per dinar. l The same buy ing and selling rates were also quoted by the commercial banks. Authorized banks deal in currencies other than U.S. dollars at rates usually based on the rates in the London and New York markets. A fee of 4 per cent is levied on the issue of import licenses. A fee of yio of 1 per cent is levied on exchange permits approved by the Central Bank for sales of exchange for imports, except imports of government departments and certain other ap- proved institutions. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Foreign Relations Department of the Central Bank of Jordan, which also issues exchange licenses; the Central Bank has, however, delegated to authorized banks the issuance of exchange licenses up to a permitted annual limit for payments for educational ex- penses of Jordanians s tudy ing abroad. An Import Committee comprising representatives of the Ministries of National Economy and Finance and Customs and the Central Bank presents from time to time suggestions and recommendations concerning changes in import policy to the Minister of Na- tional Economy. In addition, an Economic Security Commit- tee is empowered to amend existing regulations or issue new ones concerning any aspect of Jordan's economic policies when th is is considered necessary to the national interest. Prescription of Currency Jordan has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. All settlements with Egypt, except those for Egyptian rice exports (paid for in U.S. dollars outside the clearing arrangements) must be made in pounds sterling through clearing accounts under the bilateral payments agreement with that coun try. Payments to other countries may be made in any currency. Proceeds from exports and invisibles must be collected, and surrendered where required, in any convertible currency through an authorized bank in Jordan or in Jordan dinars from a nonresident account with an authorized bank in Jor- dan. 1 In addition to U.S. dollars and pounds sterling, the Central Bank ma in ta ins official quotations for deutsche ma rk, French francs, I ta l ian lire, and Swiss francs. Subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank of Jor- dan, authorized banks may open nonresident accounts in domestic currency. These accounts must be fed w i th appro- priate funds; the approval of the Central Bank is necessary for transfers f rom resident to nonresident accounts, but transfers between nonresident accounts are permitted free ly. In addi- tion, nonresidents, inc lud ing Jordanians wo rk ing abroad, may freely open foreign currency accounts w i th authorized dealers; balances may be w i thd rawn freely in convertible cur- rency. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain items 2 from any source, some imports from Romania, and all impo r ts from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. All other impor ts, unless covered by an agree- ment between Jordan and the expor t ing coun t ry (i.e., agricul- tural products from neighboring countries), require import licenses if their c.& f. value is JD 50 or more. These are granted freely by the M in i s t ry of National Economy, except for certain items 3 which are subject to scru t iny by the Minis- ter of National Economy (whose prior approval is also re- quired for imports of indus tr ial mach inery and of all materials needed for the establishment or expansion of an industrial firm) or scrutiny by the competent ministry. Im- porters of tea must meet 80 per cent of the ir requirements, and those of cast iron or steel tubes 50 per cent of their requirements, from Ind ian sources. Import licenses are gener- a l ly valid for 12 mon ths. The importer must complete the process of impor ta t ion w i th in the period of va l id i ty of the license. Imports should, in principle, enter the coun try th rough the port of Aqaba; goods that do not meet this requirement are subject to a penalty of 20 per cent of the c.i.f. value (10 per cent for foods tuffs; Pharmaceuticals are exempt). The Import Committee may grant exemptions from these rules on a case-by-case basis upon application. Bank guarantees in favor of the M in is try of Finance and Customs are required on most imports shipped th rough ports other than Aqaba. Impor ts that require an import license also require an ex- change license from the Central Bank; authorized dealers, however, have au tho r i ty to approve the opening of a letter of credit. Exchange licenses are granted automatically when an import license has been obtained; the importer holding an exchange license may either open a letter of credit or pay against documents. A fee of V10 of 1 per cent is levied on exchange licenses for imports, except those made by govern- ment departments and certain approved institutions. Payments for Invisibles Capital Remittances by postal order do not require exchange con- trol approval, provided that they do not exceed JD 10 a person a mon th. With this exception, all payments for invisi- bles are subject to exchange control approval. Payments for the fo l low ing types of invisibles are generally permitted up to certain limits: income of nonresidents; savings of foreign na- tionals who intend to return to their own countries; remit- tances to refugee dependents; reasonable l iv ing expenses of Jordanian nationals abroad; expenses of Jordanian residents traveling abroad; expenses for education; expenses for medi- cal treatment; business expenses abroad; and insurance pay- men ts in accordance w i th special regulations. The exchange allowance for travel to Arab countries, Cyprus, and Turkey is the equivalent of JD 100 a person a trip, and that for travel to other countries is the equivalent of JD 16 a person a day for business travel and JD 12 a person a day for other travel (half of these amoun ts for children under 15) for trips of up to 30 days; each person may annua l ly make three business trips and two tourist trips. For fam i ly support, an annual allowance of between JD 600 and JD 1,200 for each donor is permitted; however, remittances by postal order may be made at a rate not exceeding JD 10 a mon th to any one person resident abroad and are not subject to the ceiling of JD 600-1,200. The policy in respect of payments for invisibles is, in general, liberal and nondiscriminatory. Residents traveling abroad may take out up to JD 100 in any combination of Jordanian and foreign notes and coins. Furthermore, all travelers may take out checks, travelers checks, or letters of credit issued by authorized banks in Jordan in accordance w i th exchange permits authorized by the Central Bank. Tourists and other nonresidents may also take out foreign currency notes and coins and any other foreign means of payment that they had previously brought in and declared upon en t ry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Export pro- ceeds exceeding JD 50 must be collected and the foreign exchange surrendered w ih in three mon ths of shipment. Ex- empt are the proceeds from perishable vegetables and f ru i ts. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surren- dered to an authorized bank or, if banknotes are received, to an authorized exchange dealer. Travelers entering Jordan may bring in any amount in Jordanian and foreign notes and coins. 4 Any person regarded for exchange control purposes 4 No approval is given for the cred i t ing of such Jordanian cu r rency to a nonresident account or for the rem i t tance abroad of the equivalent in foreign cu r rency. 256 Capital may be imported freely, but exports of capital re- quire approval and normally are not allowed. Current income resulting from nonresident investments in Jordan may be transferred abroad. Under the Law for the Encouragement of Investment, effective October 16, 1972, profits from approved foreign investments may be remitted, without limitation, in the currency of the original investment or any other convert- ible currency approved by the Central Bank. After two years repatriation of the capital is permitted in three equal annual installments in the same foreign currency in which the origi- nal investment was made. The Investment Committee may approve more liberal provisions. All transactions under the investment law require the prior approval of the Central Bank. Gold Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Jor- dan for numismatic or investment purposes. With this excep- tion, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Licenses for imports of gold in any form other than jewelry are issued by the M in is try of National Economy on the rec- ommendation of the Central Bank, while exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require a license from the Central Bank. Licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. The Central Bank has issued four gold coins under the Gold and Silver Coins Regulation No. 61 of 1968; these coins, although legal tender, do not circulate and are available on ly to nonresidents and domestic numismatists. Imports and Import Payments Some imports from all sources are prohibited for reasons of public policy; imports of certain other goods are not being licensed. All imports from metropolitan Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. W i th certain exceptions, imports from Tanzania and Uganda are unrestricted, but many goods imported from these countries require a specific license unless they are of Tanzanian or Ugandan origin. Many goods may be freely imported from other sources under open general license, but others require a specific license. A number of commodities may be imported only by or to the order of the Kenya National Trading Corporation, Ltd. With minor exceptions, all private sector imports of com- modities in Schedules I, II, I I I, and IV from countries other than Tanzania and Uganda require a foreign exchange alloca- tion license issued by the Central Bank when the ir invoice value exceeds K Sh 2,000; applications must be subm i t ted before firm orders are placed. Impor ts of goods on open general license do not require an exchange allocation license but must be preregistered w i th the Central Bank before f i rm orders are placed. In addition to the open general import license, there are four commodity schedules for imports. All goods in the f i r st three schedules require a specific import license f rom the Director of Trade and Supplies. Once the specific import license has been obtained, foreign exchange is granted free ly for goods in Schedule I and on the basis of quotas reflecting past imports for goods in Schedule II. No foreign exchange is granted for Schedule III items. For the only item in Sched- ule IV, passenger motor vehicles other than buses and special vehicles, a specific import license is not required but foreign exchange is allocated on a quota basis. When an exchange allocation license has been obtained from the Central Bank or when such a license is not required, authorized banks provide exchange automatically. Prior ex- change control approval must be obtained for imports of capital goods on deferred payment terms, and for imports of machinery and equipment when the value is required to be regarded as a contribution toward capital or to be accounted for on a loan basis. Most imports w i th a pro forma invoice value in excess of K Sh 20,000 are also subject to preshipment inspection as to qua l i ty, qu an t i ty, and price by the General Superintendence Company acting for the Central Bank of Kenya. A "Clean Report of Findings" must be obtained before shipment, and authorized banks in Kenya may not issue shipping guarantees for the clearance of imports un t il this "Clean Report" has been received. The buy ing and conf irm ing commission w i th respect to imports in to Kenya may not exceed 3 per cent of the value of the import. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are controlled. Fees for education up to the equivalent of K Sh 14,000 a person for a fu ll scholastic year and fees for other specified purposes may be approved by an authorized bank upon pro- duction of evidence of debt. Facilities exist whereby nationals of countries other than Tanzania and Uganda who come to work in Kenya as employed persons (as well as certain cate- gories of the self-employed, such as doctors and dentists) for not more than four years may remit abroad as savings up to 33 Y3 per cent of their m o n t h ly salaries but not more than K Sh 3,000 a mon th; in add i t ion, they may remit funds to cover fam i ly maintenance, education expenses, etc., provided that the ir total remittances inc lud ing savings do not exceed 50 per cent of their m o n t h ly salaries. Expatriates who have stayed for over four years in the Scheduled Territories 7 may con t inue to effect remittances from salaries as above, but those who avail themselves of the facilities for remittance of savings from salaries are not entitled to exchange facilities upon em igra t ion. Remittances to South Africa, other than those of certain pensions, are prohibited. Nonresident individual p rope r ty owners may remit up to K Sh 20,000 of net rental income in each 12-month period. Any excess of net rent over the permitted transfer is placed in a Blocked Account and may be invested in approved secu- rities w i th at least f ive years to m a tu r i ty, af ter which period the sale proceeds may be remitted to the nonresident benefi- ciary. Real estate companies deriving income solely from rent are permitted to t ran s fer annu a l ly up to 10 per cent of the book value of the ir properties as at September 25, 1970. Where income is derived from rent as well as other sources, the exchange control authorities must approve the remittance of such incomes. The basic allowance for travel outside the Scheduled Terri- tories by adu l ts holding round - t r ip tickets is K Sh 4,000 a person (K Sh 2,000 for children between 3 and 12 years of age) every two years, wh ich may be taken out in foreign banknotes. 8 Holders of one-way tickets are entitled to a basic travel allowance of K Sh 2,000 for adu l ts and K Sh 1,000 for children. The basic allowance is not available for travel to Rhodesia or South Africa. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency notes up to the amount they brought in upon en t ry.
