Not for Redistribution KENYA Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain foods tuffs and agricultural products re- quire licenses and may be subject to restriction in order to ensure sufficient supplies for consumption in Kenya. Exports of tea, certain minerals, precious stones, and strategic materi- als are also subject to licensing. Export licenses for some commodities are required only for destinations other than Tanzania or Uganda. Other goods may be exported without licenses. Exports of coffee are made through the intermediary of the Coffee Marketing Board. All exports to metropolitan Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Export proceeds in foreign currencies must be collected w i th in six months of exportation and offered to an authorized bank in Kenya for conversion into Kenya shillings. 9 Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies (see foot- note 5) must be sold to an authorized bank. Travelers may bring in freely foreign currency notes, with the exception that the import of Tanzania or Uganda shilling notes is not per- mitted. The import of domestic banknotes is prohibited, w i th the exception that residents returning to Kenya on an interna- tional flight may bring in up to K Sh 100 previously taken out by themselves. The import of East African shilling notes also is prohibited. Capital Capital transfers to all countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are restricted. Transfers to Rhodesia or South Africa are not allowed. With the exception of expatriate employees who have opted for remittance of savings from salaries, per- sons leaving Kenya permanently may transfer their assets up to the equivalent of K Sh 50,000 for each fam i ly un it if they take up residence in a country outside the Scheduled Territo- ries; they may additionally every 12 months thereafter, during a period of five years, apply for the release of K Sh 20,000 from their Blocked Accounts. All remaining funds must be credited to a Blocked Account; they may then be invested in approved Scheduled Territory securities, and redemption proceeds become transferable, provided that redemption does not take place earlier than five years from the date of pur- chase. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Kenya, but to ensure eventual repatriation it is necessary to obtain from the Treasury a "certificate of approved enter- prise" for the investment. Foreign and domestic investment in specified types of production requires approval under the East African Licensing Ordinance. Local borrowing by non- resident-owned or nonresident-controlled companies requires exchange control approval and is restricted. Except in respect of Tanzania and Uganda, all imports and exports of securities require approval. Approval is freely granted for the purchase by nonresidents of Kenyan securities on a recognized stock exchange, provided that payment is received in an appropriate manner. The income from such 9 There are m inor exemptions w i th respect to Ethiopian dollars and Somali shillings for persons resident in specified border areas. 260 securities is remittable, but the proceeds on resale must nor- mally be credited to a Blocked Account. Purchases of securi- ties outside Tanzania and Uganda by residents are not normally permitted. A resident of Kenya may not send as a cash gift to a country other than Tanzania or Uganda more than K Sh 200 a year w i thout specific exchange control ap- proval. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Kenya for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require exchange control approval. The import of the following from all sources other than Tanzania and Uganda, and from Tanzania and Uganda when originat- ing in other countries is subject to individual licensing: jew- elry of gold, silver, or platinum; goldsmiths' or silver- smiths' wares, inc lud ing set gems; bullion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coins. Imports of gold jewelry require specific import licenses as Schedule III items and no foreign exchange is allocated for them; import licenses for gold bul- lion (ingots, bars, or sheets) are issued to goldsmiths only and are issued restrictively, while imports of gold coins are not being licensed. Changes during 1973 January 1. As a measure to prevent overinvoicing, virtu- ally all imports were made subject to inspection as to qual- i ty, quan t i ty, and price before shipment. Authorized banks were instructed not to make payments for nonexempt imports un t il a "Clean Report of Findings" had been received from the General Superintendence Company. Exemptions included goods with a pro forma invoice value of less than K Sh 20,000, most public sector imports, supplies for diplo- matic missions and international organizations not involving the provision of foreign exchange from Kenya, and imports from specified countries w i th which trade agreements were in force. Imports of specialized capital equipment could be ex- empted provided prior arrangements were made with the Exchange Control Department of the Central Bank. January 4. Authorized banks were instructed not to issue shipping guarantees for the clearance of imports unless a "Clean Report of Findings" was submitted. February 13. Foreign exchange transactions were sus- pended. They were resumed on February 16. February 19. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the par value was changed from 0.114592 gram to 0.103133 gram of fine gold per Kenya shilling, corresponding to K Sh 8.61675 = SDR 1. Kenya continued to avail itself of wider margins. The effective par- ity relationship for the U.S. dollar remained unchanged at K Sh 7.14286 = US$1. The relationship to the Tanzania shilling and the Uganda shilling also remained unchanged. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution March 2. Foreign exchange transactions were suspended, with the exception of facilities for tourists; dealings were resumed on March 13. March 5. Residents traveling abroad on international flights and holding return tickets were allowed to take out up to K Sh 100 in domestic currency, to be used only to defray minor expenses on return. Previously, there was a total prohi- bition on the import and export of domestic banknotes. March 7. The Central Bank lifted the restrictions on com- mercial bank lending for hire-purchase of most imported goods other than passenger motor vehicles and durable con- sumer appliances. March 9. The Central Bank rescinded most restrictions on credit granted by nonbank financial institutions. It expressed the hope that as a result of the amendments to its credit control directives any additional hire-purchase business would be directed mainly to the finance of capital equipment and commercial vehicles and that new bank borrowing for consumer imports other than private passenger motor vehi- cles would be made available to new African enterprises. March 13. The exchange rate for the U.S. dollar was pegged at K Sh 7.0000 = US$1. April 16. The Sales Tax Bill, 1973 introduced w i th immedi- ate effect a 10 per cent sales tax on a wide range of imported goods. Af ter enactment, the tax was also applied to goods manufactured in Kenya from imported materials. April 27. The Central Bank withdrew all requests to com- mercial banks to restrict credit to importers. June 14. The Finance Bill, 1973 repealed the Export Duty Act. Export taxes on coffee and sisal were eliminated. June 14. The Local Manufacturers (Export Compensation) Bill, 1973 was introduced. It provided for export subsidies on exports of selected manufacturers to countries other than Tanzania and Uganda. The proposed rate of compensation payment was 10 per cent of the f.o.b. value of goods declared for payment or of the payment in respect of such export received in foreign currency (other than Tanzania or Uganda currency) by an authorized dealer, whichever was less. The bill was gazetted on January 11, 1974 but had not been made operational by April 1974. KENYA June 30. Kenya established a central rate of K Sh 6.90000 = US$1, equivalent to 0.106763 gram of fine gold per Kenya shilling and corresponding to K Sh 8.32377 = SDR 1. Kenya continued to avail itself of wider margins. The relationship to the Tanzania shilling and the Uganda shilling remained un- changed. July 1. Exporters and export agencies were required to register w i th the Central Bank and provide information con- cerning their foreign exchange earnings over the preceding two years. July 2. The import system was liberalized. Commodity Schedules A, B, C, D, and E were replaced by four new lists. Schedule I comprised items subject to specific import licens- ing for which exchange allocation licenses would be granted automatically. Schedule II comprised goods subject to spe- cific import licenses for which exchange would be provided on a quota basis. Schedule III comprised items subject to specific import licensing for which foreign exchange would not be provided. Schedule IV covered items not subject to specific import licenses for which foreign exchange would be allocated on a quota basis; only one item was on this list: passenger motor vehicles (other than buses or special vehi- cles), whether or not assembled. Exemptions from the new arrangements included public sector and East African Community imports, capital goods subject to deferred payment terms, and shipments valued at K Sh 2,000 or less c.i.f. (provided the goods concerned did not require a specific import license). All goods not on one of the Schedules were on open general license; such imports had to be preregistered with the Central Bank but were automatically entitled to foreign exchange allocation. July 20. The Central Bank requested nonbank f inan- cial institutions to refrain from financing the activities of foreign-controlled companies in Kenya. November I. Certain benefits w i th regard to the restrictions on local borrowing were granted to foreign firms and compa- nies with substantial equity holdings by Kenyan nationals. Facilities for other companies having resident participation also were improved. 261 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Exchange Rate System Administration of Control KHMER REPUBLIC No par value for the currency of the Khmer Republic, the Riel, has been agreed w i th the Fund. The exchange rate struc- ture comprises a basic exchange rate and a preferential rate. In the closing mon ths of 1973 the margin between the prefer- ential rate and the basic rate was maintained at KR 45 per US$1. The basic or general rate for sales of foreign exchange is set twice weekly by the National Bank of Cambodia (the central bank) in an exchange market referred to as "the new exchange market," in the light of market conditions; on De- cember 31, 1973 the basic rate was KR 302 per US$1, selling; the National Bank buys foreign exchange at a rate 0.4 per cent below the selling rate. l The preferential exchange rate is applicable only to aid imports and related services procured direct from donor countries (other than impor ts under U.S. P.L. 480); on December 31, 1973 the preferential rate was KR 257 per US$1. An effective exchange rate of KR 55 = US$ 1 results from the payment of a subsidy on the basic rate and is applicable to government transfers to Khmer diplo- matic, consular, and religious missions abroad and to trans- fers by students for the purchase of textbooks. On the supply side of the market all export proceeds and other foreign exchange receipts are subject to compulsory surrender. In addition to these receipts the market is also supplied w i th foreign exchange under certain aid programs. Exchange earnings from all permissible exports are channeled through the commercial banks to be converted at the ex- change rate established by the National Bank for any given market day; commercial banks must sell all export proceeds to the National Bank through the foreign exchange market w i thout delay. On the demand side, foreign exchange is pur- chased by commercial banks to finance all imports except for those that are either financed under the U.S. Commod i ty Import Program (CIP) and P.L. 480 programs or are made sans devises; in addition, all permissible payments for invisi- bles and capital are channeled through this marke t. Participation in the market is limited to authorized com- mercial banks which buy and sell foreign exchange in transac- tions w i th the National Bank; they act on behalf of customers only and are not allowed to ma in ta in foreign exchange bal- ances for trade purposes, except as these may arise in connec- tion w i th their normal operations. Foreign exchange transactions of the Government and its depar tmen ts and agencies are subject to the same cond i t ions as transac t ions of the private sector, but are generally channeled th rough the National Bank. The National Bank of Cambodia ma in ta ins official quo ta- tions for 13 currencies.2 These quotations all provide for a spread of 0.4 per cent between the buy ing and selling rate expressed in riels. 1 On Janua ry 3, 1974 the basic rate was depreciated to KR 375 = US$1 and the preferential rate to KR 302 = US$1. 2 Au s t r a l i an dollars, Belgian francs, Danish k rone r, deutsche m a r k, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Japanese yen, Ne the r lands gu i lde rs, pounds s te r l ing, Singapore dollars, Swedish k rono r, Swiss francs, and U.S. do l lars. 262 Exchange control is administered by the National Ex- change Office, an au tonomous agency w i th in the National Bank; th is office is empowered to au thor ize all operations related to settlements w i th foreign countries, to foreign in- vestments, and to nonresident accounts. The Ministry of Commerce is in charge of the adm in is tra t ion of import and export controls. The Exchange Support Fund, an indepen- dent un it w i th in the Na t ional Bank, reimburses the latter for foreign exchange sold for most general impo r ts and for freight and insurance on impo r ts provided under U.S. P.L. 480. Prescription of Currency Settlements w i th f ive countries w i th which the Khmer Re- public has bilateral payments arrangements are made th rough bilateral accounts. Those maintained for Czechoslo- vakia, Eastern Germany, and the U.S.S.R. are denominated in pounds sterling, and those for Bulgaria and Poland in U.S. dollars. Settlements w i th other countries take place in con- vertible currencies. Foreign inves tmen ts must be made in a currency accept- able to the National Bank. Profits on and proceeds from the liquidation of foreign inves tmen ts may be transferred abroad in the currency in wh ich the inves tment was made. Nonresident Accounts The fo l low ing categories of account may be maintained for nonresidents: Foreigners' Accounts in Riels, Capital Ac- counts, Nonresident Accounts, and Foreign Currency Ac- coun ts. In add i t ion, Khmer na t iona ls s tay ing abroad temporarily but not recognized as nonresidents, and foreign- ers staying in the Khmer Republic but not recognized as residents, may ma in ta in In te rnal Accounts of Nonresidents. There are separate regulations concerning nonresident ac- counts th at may be used to f inance transactions in the free trade area of Kompong-Som. Foreigners' Accounts in Riels may be opened, w i thout per- mission, for foreigners residing outside the Khmer Republic. They are related to the coun t ry of residence of the account holder. They may be freely credited w i th (1) proceeds from the sale on the Phnom Penh exchange ma rket of the currency (but not banknotes) of the coun t ry of the account holder; (2) paymen ts for authorized imports ( inc lud ing incidental ex- penses) from the coun t ry of the account holder; (3) earnings on inves tmen ts in the Khmer Republic and receipts from repayments on Khmer stocks and bonds and on other invest- ments made in the Khmer Republic a f ter May 1956; and (4) interest paid by the banks on f u n ds kept in the accounts. These accounts may be free ly debited for normal expenses in the Khmer Republic and, provided t h at it is quoted on the Phnom Penh ma rke t, for purchases of the currency of the coun t ry of the account holder (except in the form of bank- notes). Transfers between Foreigners' Accounts in Riels re- lated to the same coun t ry may be made freely. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Capital Accounts may be opened w i thout permission. Sub- ject to authorization, these accounts may be credited w i th (1) proceeds from the sale in the Khmer Republic of Khmer stocks and bonds; (2) proceeds from the sale in the Khmer Republic of participations in corporations other than by pur- chases of stocks and bonds; (3) contractual or advance repay- ments of Khmer stocks and bonds; (4) proceeds from the sale through an authorized no tary of real estate or businesses located in the Khmer Republic and in the possession of a nonresident since before January 1, 1955 or acquired by him at a later date either through inheritance or w i th the permis- sion of the National Exchange Office; (5) repayment of loans granted to residents prior to Janua ry 1, 1955, or a f ter that date with the approval of the National Exchange Office; and (6) transfers from another capital account related to the coun- try of the account holder. Capital Accounts may be freely debited for (1) living ex- penses of the account holder or his fam i ly up to KR 1,000 a person a day, and up to a maximum of KR 50,000 mon th ly, and (2) expenses connected w i th the administration of foreign assets in the Khmer Republic (stocks and bonds, bu i ld ings, land, etc.). Subject to authorization from the National Ex- change Office, these accounts may be debited for (1) pur- chases in the Khmer Republic of Khmer stocks and bonds; (2) subscriptions to, or increases in the capital of, a Khmer firm; (3) purchases through an authorized no tary of t i t le to real estate or businesses located in the Khmer Republic; (4) loans in riels to residents; (5) transfers to another capital account related to the coun try of the account holder; (6) living expenses in the Khmer Republic of the account hold- er's employees if the account is held by a firm (corporation, bank, etc.); and (7) gifts to individuals and to social, cu l tura l, and religious associations. Nonresident Accounts may be opened on ly upon authoriza- tion. They may be freely debited for (1) taxes in the Khmer Republic, (2) miscellaneous accounting, correspondence ex- penses, etc., and (3) l iv ing expenses in the Khmer Republic of the account holder and his fam i ly. They may be freely credited with the proceeds from foreign currency sold on the Phnom Penh market and w i th interest on funds held in the account concerned. All other operations th rough these ac- counts are subject to individual licensing. Foreign Currency Accounts may be opened only upon au- thorization. They may be freely credited w i th foreign ex- change transferred from abroad. Account holders may use balances on these accounts (1) to cover expenses abroad, such as those related to travel, missions, and the purchase of for- eign merchandise, and (2) to cover expenses of any k ind in the Khmer Republic by converting balances on these accounts into riels on the Phnom Penh exchange marke t. Internal Accounts of Nonresidents may be opened only upon authorization. Balances on these accounts may not be used for transfers abroad. The accounts may be freely cred- ited with (1) proceeds from the sale of foreign exchange on the Phnom Penh market; (2) transfers from Foreigners' Ac- counts in Riels; (3) wages, salaries, allowances, and payments for expenses of Khmer nationals employed by Khmer firms and temporarily residing abroad; (4) income earned in the Khmer Republic by account holders; (5) redeposits of previ- KHMER REPUBLIC ous w i thdrawa ls; and (6) repayment of loans granted to resi- dents out of balances in such accounts. The accounts may be freely debited for (1) l iv ing expenses in the Khmer Republic of the account holder or his fam i ly, (2) administrative ex- penses related to the account holder's property in the Khmer Republic, and (3) loans to residents. All other operations th rough these accounts require authorization. There are separate regulations for resident-held foreign currency accounts. Imports and Import Payments The import of certain commodities is prohibited for rea- sons of health or security and that of certain other goods for protective reasons. In view of the ava i lab i l i ty of subs tan t ial amounts of commercial aid resources, several impor tant im- port commodities have been placed on an "exclusive list"; their impo r ta t ion is permitted on ly against commodity aid f inanc ing, unless a waiver is granted. The list includes to- bacco leaves, cotton fibers, certain vegetable oils, wheat f lour, and cotton thread under the U.S. P.L. 480 program, and some foods tu f fs, rubber and rubber products, petroleum, chemicals, timber and paper products, iron and steel, metals, cars and trucks, and U.S. equipment in general, under the U.S. CIP. For all other permissible imports, including those eligible for CIP f inanc ing that are not on the "exclusive list," cash foreign exchange resources are provided w i thout restric- tions; they are referred to as general imports. General imports of up to US$ 1,000 for each shipment may be made freely when no purchase of foreign exchange is in- volved (sans devises) and the goods are not intended for resale. All imports financed by foreign exchange purchased in the exchange market must be settled against irrevocable letters of credit opened by the commercial banks. Importers are re- quired to subm it their requests for purchases of foreign ex- change to the commercial banks, accompanied by a payment in riels equal to the cost of the foreign exchange requested, calculated at the latest quo ta t ion for the currency concerned. A supplementary deposit in riels, the amount of which is varied from time to time, is also required; at the end of 1973 the supplementary deposit required was equivalent to 300 per cent of the cost of the foreign exchange involved. Certain government agencies and commercial firms are exempt from the supp lemen tary deposit requ iremen t. In the ir requests for exchange importers must state the most depreciated exchange rate they are prepared to pay. Twice weekly the National Bank considers the applications received and sets its selling rate. An importer's application is met in fu ll at the current selling rate if his bid specified that rate or a less appreciated rate; if he has indicated a more appreciated rate than the one actually established, he will not be able to obtain exchange and his deposit is refunded. The supplementary deposits of successful bidders are refunded when the shipping documents are taken up at the bank where the letter of credit was opened. In order to facilitate the efficient utilization of available commercial aid resources, preferential local currency pay- ment facilities have been extended to importers who are will- ing to finance imports th rough aid. The local currency cost of CIP imports is settled as follows: (1) in the case of pur- 263 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KHMER REPUBLIC chases from the United States, the importer must pay 10 per cent of the import value in riels at the time the import applica- tion is approved by the Societe Nationale d'Exportation et d'Importation (SONEXIM), and the remainder at the time of the presentation of documents by the commercial bank; (2) where SONEXIM is buying directly from "Code 941" coun- tries, 3 the importer must pay 25 per cent of the import val- ue in riels at the time of delivery of the import certificate by SONEX IM and the remainder at the time of presentation of documents. The 75 per cent due on presentation of the docu- ments may be financed by commercial bank credits. In the case of imports from the United States, the credits are ex- tended for a period of four months, while two-mon th credits are available for CIP imports from th ird countries. Each importer is required to obtain an import business license. Importers are permitted to trade w i th foreign countries only if they have assumed corporate status (so- cietes anonymes). The equ i ty capital of such corporations should be at least KR 5 million; 51 per cent of the equ i ty should be held by Khmer nationals and one th i rd of board membership should be Khmer. Upon completion of the import transaction, importers are required to submit proof that the foreign exchange has actu- ally been used to finance imports, and that the goods have arrived and have been cleared through customs w i th fu ll payment of import du ty and other levies. Payments for Invisibles Importers include an estimate of the freight and insurance component of the cost of imports in their bids for foreign exchange for imports. If actual fre ight and insurance costs exceed the estimate, a separate bid for the additional amount must be submitted. Foreign exchange for freight and insur- ance for imports under U.S. P.L. 480 is eligible for f inanc ing by the CIP. All other payments for invisibles require individ- ual authorization, and only those transactions explicitly men- tioned in the exchange control regulations are permitted. A foreigner work ing in the Khmer Republic and receiving a mon th ly salary exceeding KR 5,000 in Phnom Penh, or KR 3,500 in the provinces, may in principle t rans fer up to 30 per cent of his net mon th ly salary —after payment of taxes— plus 15 per cent of his mon th ly salary if a dependent w ife stays abroad, plus an additional 10 per cent if dependent children, parents, or grandparents stay abroad. (The addi- tional percentage of transferable income is 2 per cent for each legitimate child or dependent parent or grandparen t, w i th a maximum of 10 per cent of the net mon th ly income for each fam i ly .) Such transfers may not exceed the equivalent of KR 20,000 a worker a mon th. Transfer facilities are not granted for salaries and wages exempt from income tax. Over- time pay is considered transferable income only when it is received in payment for courses given in public educational ins t i tu t ions. Women of foreign na t iona l i ty married to Khmer nationals and wo rk ing in the private sector are not permitted to transfer savings from salaries or wages to the ir coun t ry of origin. 3 Certain developing countries in Asia and Africa. 264 Foreign landlords domiciled in the Khmer Republic may transfer up to 30 per cent of the taxable portion of their income from rent, provided that the rent exceeds KR 5,000 for landlords living in Phnom Penh or KR 3,500 for landlords living in the provinces. Foreign landlords living abroad may transfer up to 20 per cent of the taxable portion of rent. Foreigners residing in the Khmer Republic, when leaving the coun t ry permanently, are permitted to transfer abroad, up to prescribed limits, savings out of their salaries earned in the Khmer Republic, provided that the savings have been regu- la r ly deposited w i th an authorized bank in the Khmer Repub- lic. The transfer of the fu ll net prof i ts from nonresident invest- ments made prior to May 31, 1956 is authorized, subject to proof that the investment was made w i th foreign currency other than the former Indo-Chinese piastre; otherwise, the transfer of profits on pre-1956 investments is limited to 80 per cent and is permitted only if the investment is recognized as useful to the economic development of the Khmer Republic. Net prof i ts that do not exceed 20 per cent of foreign invest- ments made after May 31, 1956 may be transferred annually. Khmer nationals s tudy ing abroad may receive monthly exchange allocations equivalent to up to US$108 for Asian countries and up to US$126 for any other country, in addition to installation, holiday, and clothing allowances. The alloca- tion of foreign exchange for tourist travel and business travel has been suspended. The export of Khmer currency is prohibited and foreign tourists require special authorization to reconvert riels into foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exporters must obtain annual registration licenses from the Ministry of Finance. Exports are classified into three groups: a prohibited list, a licensing list, and a free list. Pro- hibited exports comprise mainly goods whose exports have been banned for social and political reasons, while the pur- pose of the licensing list is to avoid shortages of supplies needed for domestic use. The exportation of rubber and pre- cious and semiprecious stones is a state monopoly and is effected through SONEX IM. All other commodities may be freely exported, provided that the transactions are arranged th rough a commercial bank, which must issue an export cer- tificate for each shipment. A Committee on Export Price Quotations sets weekly m in imum export prices. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered. Approved hotels, airlines, and other organizations authorized to receive payment in foreign exchange are required to keep adequate records of such transactions and to surrender all receipts to the commercial banks at least once weekly. Foreign visitors are required to settle their hotel bills in foreign currency or provide evidence that local currency was acquired by selling foreign exchange to an authorized bank. The import of Khmer currency is prohibited. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Capital All capital transfers require individual licenses. No transfer abroad of proceeds from the sale of property by a foreigner to a foreigner is permitted. Foreigners who sell their property to Khmer nationals and leave the Khmer Republic perma- nently may transfer in i t ia l ly up to 20 per cent of the proceeds of the sale; up to 20 per cent of the remainder may be autho- rized for transfer annually, when the total amount involved is small. Funds representing the repayment of loans originally granted in foreign currency may be considered transferable income. Since May 31, 1956, all foreign investments have been subject to authorization from the Ministry of Finance, which requires that a certain percentage of the capital of an enter- prise should be reserved for Khmer participation and that its employees should be Khmer nationals. Only investments for the creation of activities recognized as useful to the economic development of the coun try and not involving monopoly or special privilege may be authorized. Proceeds from the liqui- dation of authorized investments made after May 31, 1956 may be transferred in yearly installments not exceeding 20 per cent of the total investment. Up to 10 per cent of the proceeds from the liquidation of investment made prior to May 31, 1956 may be authorized for transfer every year. Foreign capital invested after May 31, 1956 is guaranteed the same tax treatment that is applied to resident investments; in addition, special incentives (partial exemption from duties and taxes on reinvested profits and on equipment goods or raw materials imported during the first year of operation) may be accorded to foreign investment considered as excep- tionally useful to the Khmer economy. There is a guarantee of 10-30 years against risks of nationalization or expropria- tion, and for a just and equitable indemn i ty in the event of nationalization or expropriation of investments. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in the Khmer Republic for numismatic purposes. With this exception, resi- dents other than the monetary authorities, SONEXIM, and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require authorization by the National Bank; such authoriza- tion is not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and SONEXIM. Changes during 1973 During the year, the basic exchange rate was gradually depreciated from KR 187 = US$1 to KR 302 = US$1, and the preferential exchange rate from KR 131 = US$1 to KHMER REPUBLIC KR 257 = US$1. January 19. The supplementary deposit required on gen- eral imports was raised from 200 per cent to 400 per cent. Resident and nonresident physical and juridical persons could freely settle these in foreign banknotes and foreign currency travel- ers checks. Not for Redistribution KOREA Exchange Rate System No par value for the Korean Won has been established w i th the Fund. Since March 22, 1965 there has been a fluctu- a t ing exchange rate determined in an exchange certificate marke t. On December 31, 1973 the buy ing and selling rates of the Bank of Korea for the U.S. dollar were W 396.90 and W 398.10, respectively, and the telegraphic t rans fer buy ing and selling rates of the foreign exchange banks were W 396.5 and W 398.5, respectively. Exchange certificates valid for 45 days are issued by the foreign exchange banks against all foreign exchange earnings in prescribed currencies surrendered by residents. All foreign exchange proceeds, however, may a l terna t ive ly be exchanged for won at the buy ing rate posted by the foreign exchange banks. Exchange certificates are in principle required for all foreign exchange expenditures except for paymen ts for im- ports financed under U.S. aid programs, and paymen ts by commercial banks in connection w i th their b ank ing transac- tions, etc. There is a limited forward exchange ma rket re- stricted to exporters covering their export earnings; the foreign exchange banks may in tu rn cover their fo rwa rd transactions with exporters by engaging in such transactions abroad. Administration of Control The Ministry of Finance is in charge of exchange control, subject to the approval of the Cabinet. It carries out policy w i th respect to prescription of currency and method of settle- men t, foreign exchange operations, payments for nonmer- chandise transactions, and capital transactions and transfers. The Bank of Korea, as the Government's agent, executes the above functions in part; it regulates operations in the certifi- cate market and is authorized to intervene in it. The Bank has also been delegated au tho r i ty to control receipts and pay- ments related to invisibles. The Korea Exchange Bank, whose capital is wholly subscribed by the Government and the Bank of Korea, has taken over from the latter all its in terna t ional bank ing and foreign exchange business. The foreign exchange banks, as well as the branch offices in Korea of foreign banks, are authorized to deal in foreign exchange. The trade program for imports financed from Korea's own foreign exchange resources (KFX) is prepared by the Minis- try of Commerce and Indus t ry. Imports financed by foreign grants and loans are programmed separately by the Eco- nomic P lann ing Board in consultation w i th the M in is t ry of Commerce and Indus t ry, and import licenses are issued by the foreign exchange banks. Prescription of Currency All settlements between Korea and other countries are made in convertible currencies. The proceeds of exports must be obtained in prescribed currencies. * The methods of pay- 1 Aus t ra l ian dollars, Au s t r ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche m a rk, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Italian lire, Ne ther lands guilders, Norwegian k rone r, pounds s te r l ing, Swedish k rone r, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 266 ment on account of other settlements require the approval of the M in i s t ry of Finance. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident and Korean workers abroad may maintain foreign currency deposit accounts w i th foreign exchange banks. Remittances from such accounts and withdrawals in the form of currency notes upon departure from Korea may, in general, be made freely. The approval of the bank where the account is held is required for remittances from balances that have accrued f rom remunera t ion for services in Korea, air or ship passage fares, or insurance premiums received in Korea, or f rom exchange deposited in accordance w i th a decision of the M in i s t ry of Finance (except exchange regis- tered at the customs on en t ry or remitted from abroad). The deposits may be disposed of by sale to a foreign exchange bank at the prevailing exchange rate, and they may be debited for salary payments to foreign employees. Foreign residents and nonresidents are permitted to hold time deposit accounts in prescribed currencies w i th the foreign exchange banks. Certain residents of Korean na t iona l i ty, such as the airline and some insurance companies, as well as exporters w i th a specified m in imum annual export performance, may ma in ta in current deposit accounts in foreign currencies w i th the foreign exchange banks. Companies registered to operate in the Ma- san Free Export Zone also may ma in ta in current deposit accounts in foreign currencies w i th the foreign exchange bank w i th in the zone. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. All imports require licenses; for certain impor ts (see below) licenses are issued upon application. No licenses are issued for any goods origi- na t ing in the People's Republic of China, Cuba, No r th Korea, or Nor th Viet-Nam and for certain impor ts from all other countries. Imports are divided in to three categories: those paid for w i th Korean foreign exchange (so-called KFX imports), those paid for w i th foreign aid funds, and those financed by Japanese reparations (PAC imports). KFX imports are clas- sified as au toma t ic approval, restricted, or prohibited items. All commodities may be imported freely (i.e., applications for import licenses are au toma t ica l ly approved) unless they are in a list of restricted or prohibited commodities. Au toma t ic approval items (on December 31, 1973 these were 683 out of 1,312 basic items in the SITC classification) consist ma in ly of essential consumer goods not domestically produced and cer- tain raw materials and capital goods .2 Restricted items (556) in a negative list are subject to ind iv idual licenses. Prohibited items (73) are ma in ly l u x u ry goods, items prohibited for rea- sons of public health or morals, and some domestically pro- duced goods. Imports of raw materials for the production of 2 Some a u t om a t ic app roval i tems require the prior app roval of the M i n i s t ry of Commerce and I n d u s t ry when impor ted f r om Japan. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution exports are normally approved automatically, irrespective of their classification. Foreign aid imports are classified as either automatic approval items or restricted items. In principle, no commodities imported with foreign aid funds are included among the KFX imports, but in exceptional cases payment for imports usually financed with aid funds may be made w i th KFX exchange. For purposes of licensing imports from speci- fied countries, the position of Korea's balance of trade w i th the coun try concerned is taken in to account. Import licenses are granted only to registered traders; to maintain the status of a registered trader, a m in imum value of US$300,000 of exports is required each year for ord inary exporters. The commercial terms of payment on which imports may be contracted are regulated, and advance import deposits are required for most categories of imports by the private sector; these are met, for KFX imports, by deposit of exchange certificates a n d / or local currency at the time of app ly ing for import licenses. The exchange certificate deposits are, in ef- fect, advance payments offset against the import settlement; the won equivalent of any amount of deposit in excess of the import settlement is repaid to the importer at the time of the release of the relative bill of lading. Imports by the private sector under U.S. aid programs are subject to prior won cash payments of part of the import settlement, and imports w i th Japanese Property and Claims Funds (PAC imports) are sub- ject to prior payments of part of the import settlement in exchange certificates. Advance deposits for KFX imports range between 5 per cent and 200 per cent according to the na ture of the import and the commercial terms of payment; the rates are 100-200 per cent for imports against sight letters of credit, 5 per cent to 40 per cent for documents against acceptance (D /A) im- ports, and 20 per cent to 60 per cent for imports on a docu- ments against payment (D /P) basis and bonded warehouse transaction (BWT) terms. Advance deposits for KFX im- ports of raw materials for exports are 100 per cent, except for imports for stockpiling and D /P and D /A imports which are subject to a 10 per cent advance deposit. Imports of equip- ment and facilities for export industries financed w i th domes- tic loans in foreign exchange are not subject to advance deposits; payment (in exchange certificates) of 10 per cent of the import value is required upon the release of bills of lading, with the balance of the payment to be settled in accordance with the terms of the loan. The customs tariff is a "flexible" ta r i f f. Furthermore, the Government may alter import du ty rates adm in is tra t ive ly by up to 50 percentage points. The Government also has author- ity to impose import surcharges of up to 30 per cent on all dutiable imports. KOREA use exchange earnings up to US$2,000 a mon th for the ex- penses of their overseas branches; the authorization is US$3,000 a mon th if exports to the coun t ry concerned exceed US$1 million and US$5,000 a mon th if exports to the coun t ry concerned exceed US$5 million. All residents departing for travel abroad may purchase foreign exchange up to the equiv- alent of US$65 a day; they may purchase an additional US$100 for each tr ip for extra expenses. Students s tudy ing abroad may receive a mon th ly l iv ing allowance of up to US$500. Foreign and Korean currency notes may not be exported w i thout special permission. Nonresident foreigners need not register foreign exchange in specified currencies that they bring in to Korea and, when departing, they may recon- vert unused won notes in to U.S. dollars up to US$200, sub- ject to confirmation of the original sale of exchange (up to US$50 w i thout such conf irma t ion). Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to the People's Republic of China, Cuba, No r th Korea, Rhodesia, and No r th Viet-Nam are prohibited, as are exports of certain goods (such as raw cotton, p la t inum ores, wood charcoal, pu lp, and waste paper) to all other countries. Certain exports require ind iv idual licenses. All other exports may be made free ly under an automatic approval procedure. The export proceeds in foreign exchange must either be sur- rendered to a foreign exchange bank at the market rate or be exchanged in to equivalent foreign exchange certificates. However, traders w i th an annual export performance of US$1 million or more are permitted to retain their export proceeds as foreign currency demand deposits w i th foreign exchange banks, for use for approved payments. Proceeds from Invisibles All proceeds derived from invisibles must either be sold to a foreign exchange bank or be exchanged for equivalent ex- change certificates. Travelers may bring w i th them any amount of foreign exchange. Capital All capital remittances require approval. Foreign capital investment, loans from abroad, and imports of capital goods on a long-term basis can secure a guarantee of repayment and repatriation under the Foreign Capital Inducement Law. No limits are placed on the conversion and remittance of legiti- mate profits and dividends, or on the repatriation of the original capital invested. Gold Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require individual licenses. Pay- ments for invisibles connected w i th foreign trade transactions and for certain other items, such as bank ing charges, insur- ance premiums, communication fees, and periodicals are li- censed automatically. There are certain standard allocations for business travel. In addition, exporters are authorized to Certain commemorative gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. By v ir tue of Law No. 233 of December 23, 1951 residents may freely buy, hold, and sell gold in any form in Korea. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry cons t i tu t ing the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the M in is t ry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on 267 ©International Monetary Fund. The leading producer of gold, a government-owned com- pany, may be required to sell gold to the Bank of Korea at US$42.22 an ounce. Otherwise, domestic production may be disposed of in the free market. The free market price at public gold auctions was about W 1,300 a gram at the end of 1973. Changes during 1973 January 1. The foreign exchange budget for 1973 went into effect. It was based on three general principles: (1) the capac- ity to repay foreign debts was to be increased by balancing the supply and demand for foreign exchange; (2) higher prior- ity was to be given to the expansion of export industries; and (3) nonessential imports and payments for invisibles were to be restricted, but not to the extent of obstructing the efficient supply of raw materials and of goods required for stable economic growth. Guidelines on the expenditure side in- cluded (1) an unchanged ceiling of US$235 million for D /A imports and one of US$480 million for imports on a ship- per's usance basis; (2) importers would in principle be re- quired to contract on an f.o.b. basis and use Korean-flag vessels; (3) the criteria for permission to travel abroad would be adjusted so as to reduce nonessential travel expenditure; (4) transfers of film rentals would not be permitted to exceed an amount fixed by the Minister of Finance; (5) agency com- missions on imports and exports would not normally be al- lowed to exceed 5 per cent of the invoiced import or export value; and (6) so as to improve the foreign debt structure, certain bank loans and commercial loans were to be repaid ahead of schedule. January L The trade program for the first half of 1973 went in to fu ll effect. On the import side, one item was shifted from the automatic approval category and one item in the reverse direction, resulting in a net liberalization of US$148,000 (on the basis of 1971 import values). The program was based on four general principles: (1) ensuring the timely and efficient supply of imported commodities in order to stabilize prices and to protect import industries; (2) checking machinery im- ports in order to foster the machinery industry; (3) improving the balance of payments by means of t ight import control over luxu ry goods and nonessential commodities; and (4) strengthening export support measures and restricting certain imports of raw materials for export in order to promote do- mestic production of these goods. January 15. Ministry of Finance Notice No. 549 amended the foreign exchange regulations with effect from January 16 to allow qualified exporters w i th annual export performance of US$5 million or more to retain their export proceeds as foreign currency demand deposits with Korean foreign ex- change banks. (Previously, this facility was available only to specified industries.) On December 1, the required annual export performance was reduced to US$1 million. January 22. A fu r ther amendment to the Trade Transac- tions Law came in to effect. It permitted trade w i th additional communist countries; trade with hostile nations, however, could be restricted or prohibited by Presidential Decree. (The January 1971 amendment had maintained the prohibition on 268 trade w i th the People's Republic of China, Cuba, North Ko- rea, and Nor th Viet-Nam.) February L New import du ty rates came into effect. They were included in a substantially revised customs law promul- gated on December 30, 1972. The number of import items subject to tar iffs rose from 3,174 to 3,985. The rates of import du ty on 1,068 items, including daily necessities, raw materi- als, and equipment for industrial production, were lowered. Those on 440 items, including certain luxury goods, were raised. These changes reduced the average rate of import duty from 38.8 per cent to 31.3 per cent. February 5. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry an- nounced rules governing the import in the first half of the year of restricted items under its control. The Ministry would continue to restrict imports of nonessential and luxury goods to provide protection to local industries. However, the lists of import quota items and of export-linked import items were reduced. February 16. The Law Regarding the Inducement and Management of Public Loans was promulgated. It provided for detailed procedures to be followed by the public sector in obtaining and using foreign loans. February 17. The M in is try of Commerce and Industry an- nounced an easing of import restrictions on certain key raw materials; an increase in import quotas for the first half of the year from US$505,000 to US$2,375,000; a reduction in the number of quota items from 28 to 25; and a reduction by 18 in the number of items that may be imported only in linkage with export performance, the items concerned becoming eligi- ble for import on the recommendation of the competent au- thorities. February 17. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry raised the ceiling of US$235 million on D /A imports for 1973 by declaring all items, except grains, importable on a D/A basis. The settlement period for D/A imports was reduced from 365 days to 270 days. February 20. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the Government decided to main- tain the existing won /do l lar exchange rate of W 398.90 per U.S. dollar. February 23. The Cabinet approved a bill empowering the Government to invoke import surcharges when deemed nec- essary. Such surcharges could not exceed 30 per cent on dutiable imports. This legislation replaced the authority un- der the special tariff law, which had been abrogated. March 12. The Government promulgated the revised For- eign Capital Inducement Law. The Government would give priority in approving foreign investments to joint venture projects rather than to 100 per cent foreign-owned invest- ment projects, and would in principle limit foreign inves- tors' shares in joint ventures to 50 per cent or less. The Government could, however, grant exceptions to industries producing exclusively for export and not competing with domestic industries, and to industries in which direct foreign investments are generally allowed by other countries because of the introduction of technical know-how. March 22. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry a- mended the trade program for the first half of 1973 by liberal- izing the import of ten items (moved from the restricted to the ©International Monetary Fund. April 12. The Foreign Capital Inducement Law was amended. The amendments gave increased priority to projects in which foreign and Korean businessmen invest jointly; they also provided for approval of investments in kind, and for increased tax exemption. In addition, the amendments required that all enterprises in which foreign capital had been invested submit remittance schedules to the Minister of Finance not later than 90 days before the closing of each fiscal year, showing the amounts to be remitted abroad during the following year. Under the previous law, the remittance overseas of proceeds from sales of stock or shares by a foreign investor was guaranteed only up to 20 per cent of the subscribed capital each year, beginning two years after the start of business operations; the amended law, in princi- ple, removed this restriction on the amounts to be remitted each year. April 14. The Ministry of Commerce and Indus t ry sus- pended, with some exceptions, the use of Korean-owned for- eign exchange (KFX) in financing imports from the United States; instead, the use of repayment letter of credit funds or of proceeds from exports to Viet-Nam (under the U.S. AID program for that country) would be required in order to expedite the utilization of such funds. May 14. The Monetary Board raised the interest rate on short-term bank loans for export financing from 6 per cent to 7 per cent. May 16. The M in is try of Commerce and Indus try an- nounced that six chemical items were importable by domestic manufacturers as well as end-users; in addition, import re- strictions applying to certain metals were relaxed. Not for Redistribution KUWAIT Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of f ine gold per Kuwa i ti Dinar, corresponding to KD 0.357143 = SDR 1, or KD 1 = US$3.37778, and Kuwa it avails itself of wider margins. The Central Bank of Kuwa it quotes daily buy ing and selling rates for sterling and U.S. dollars; on December 31, 1973, these were KD 0.68745 buying, and KD 0.68831 selling, respectively, for sterling, and KD 0.29650 buy ing, and KD 0.29688 selling, respectively, for U.S. dollars. On April 5, 1963, Kuwa it notified the Fund that it was prepared to forma l ly accept the obligations of Article V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control There is no exchange control and residents and nonresi- dents may freely purchase and sell foreign currencies in Ku- wait. Dealings in the currencies of Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa, however, are prohibited. General and indi- vidual import licenses are issued by the M in is t ry of Com- merce and Indus t ry. The limited control over exports is administered by the Customs and Ports Adm in is t ra t ion of the Ministry of Finance and Oil. Prescription of Currency Kuwait has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. There are no prescription of currency requirements. All settlements w i th Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may freely open accounts in Kuwa i ti d ina rs and foreign currencies. The use of such accounts is not re- stricted. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses are required for all private impor ts other than foodstuffs; licenses are issued freely, except for wheat, flour, and asbestos pipe. Registered importers hand l ing a variety of commodities may obtain a general license valid for one year. Other importers must obtain specific licenses for individual commodities, which are also valid for one year. All imports from Israel, including imports of Israeli manu fac tu re and those that contain Israeli materials or are manu fac tu red by companies financed by Israeli capital, and all imports f rom Portugual, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Im- ports of a few items (mainly oxygen, certain steel pipes, alco- holic beverages, and used trucks and buses not using gasoline for fuel and over ten years old) are prohibited from all sources. To be registered, the importer must be either a Kuwa i ti citizen or a firm in which all partners are Kuwa i t is or a shareholding or limited liability company in which Kuwa i t is own at least 51 per cent of all stock. Commercial imports normally are l im i ted to registered importers. Impo r ts from any permitted source may be paid for freely. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely, except to Is- rael, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa. There are no l im i ta t ions on the export of domestic or foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of live sheep and pou l try are proh ib i ted, and those of certain other items, such as sugar and fats, may be either licensed or prohibited in time of emergency or shortage in Kuwa i t. Exports of arms, amm u n i t i o n, and scrap metal re- qu i re licenses. Licenses are not required for other exports or re-exports. All exports to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited and exports of crude petroleum and petroleum products to the Ne ther lands and the United States are suspended. There are no requirements attached to receipts from ex- ports or re-exports, except that these must not accrue in Israel pounds, Portuguese escudos, Rhodesian currency, or South African rand; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surren- dered, and they may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency invo lved. Proceeds from In visibles No requirements are attached to the use or disposal of receipts in any currency other than Israel pounds, Portuguese escudos, Rhodesian currency, or South African rand. Travel- ers entering Kuwa it may bring w i th them any amount in Kuwa i ti or other banknotes except Israel, Portuguese, Rho- desian, or South Afr ican cu r rency. Capital There are no exchange con trol obligations on the t ran s fer to Kuwa it of resident or nonresident capital in any currency. Government agreement is necessary for the participation of nonresident capital in corporations in K uw a i t, and a license is required for the establishment and operation of industries in Kuwa i t; except for petroleum companies, 51 per cent of ownership of new Kuwa i ti companies must be held by Ku- wa i ti nationals. No restrictions are imposed on ou tward capital payments by residents or nonresidents to other countries except Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa. A number of in terna t ional bond issues have been placed in Kuwa i t, some of which were denominated in Kuwa i ti dinars. Not for Redistribution Exchange Rate System Imports and Import Payments LAOS No par value for the Laotian Kip has been established w i th the Fund. The official exchange rate is K 600 = US$1. This rate applies to a few specified imports, to government pay- ments covered by the foreign exchange budget for official transactions, to a few types of private sector payments in respect of current invisibles, to the portion of export proceeds that must be surrendered (except for exports of timber, logs, plywood, and furn i ture) and to any proceeds from invisibles or capital voluntarily sold to the banking system. An ex- change rate of K 840 per US$1 results from the application of an exchange tax of 40 per cent to the official rate. This rate is applicable to all outward payments not eligible for the official rate. An exchange subsidy of K 220 per US$1, appli- cable to the official exchange rate, is granted on the proceeds from exports of timber, logs, plywood, and furn i ture. The exchange market is supplied mainly by the Foreign Exchange Operations Fund (FEOF), which sells to banks at K 605 = US$1. The commercial banks' selling rates are K 606 per US$1 for transactions eligible for official exchange and K 846 per US$1 for other transactions. Administration of Control FEOF sells and buys foreign exchange only in transactions with the four commercial banks and the Development Bank of Laos, which act for the account of their customers. The National Bank of Laos (the central bank) conducts foreign exchange transactions only with exporters mak ing the obliga- tory surrender of export proceeds, w i th Laotian public agen- cies selling their exchange receipts, and with foreign embassies and international organizations; receipts from these sources are used to meet the foreign exchange expendi- tures of the Laotian Government. The approval of the Ex- change Control Commission (Commission d'Octroi des Devises Etrangeres or CODE) in the Ministry of Finance is required for purchases of exchange by the public at the rate of K 600 = US$1; exchange authorization for certain invisi- bles eligible for this rate is granted, however, by the National Exchange Office in the Ministry of Finance, acting on behalf of CODE. The Foreign Trade Department of the Ministry of Economy issues export licenses and keeps an annual register of importers and exporters. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are imposed on receipts or payments, but the National Bank provides and accepts only U.S. dollars, French francs, and pounds sterling. There is a bilateral payments agreement with the U.S.S.R. providing for payments to be made through a clearing ac- count maintained in French francs as the unit of account. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents other than foreign embassies and interna- tional organizations are not permitted to maintain accounts in foreign currencies with authorized banks. Importers must be listed on the annual register of import- ers, for which a yearly registration fee has to be paid to the Government. Imports of charcoal, bricks, matches, rubber sandals, coffee, ice cream, soft drinks, beer, detergents, oxy- gen, and plastic bags are prohibited, although they may be authorized when shortages arise. Financing at the official rate is permitted for a short list of commodities deemed essential. Letters of credit must be opened with the commercial banks for all import transactions settled at the official rate. * Import transactions at the official rate are subject to ex- change control approval. To apply for this approval, the importer is required to complete an exchange control form obtainable from the banks, which are to forward the form to the CODE. The latter applies various criteria in deciding on exchange applications, including the applicant's compliance with prevailing requirements regarding letters of credit, ad- vance import deposits, payment of import duties, and appro- priate use of previous exchange purchases. Import transactions for which no exchange is granted at the official rate may in practice be made freely at the rate of K 840 = US$1 or settled in the unofficial free market, where the rate is also about K 840 per US$1. On being notified that exchange approval will be granted the importer must w i th in 7 days (14 days outside Vientiane) make an advance import deposit in kips at the Treasury. The advance deposit requirement is 40 per cent of the c.i.f. value for imports from the Republic of China, Hong Kong, Singa- pore, and Thailand and 30 per cent of imports from all other sources; it is only applicable when imports are financed at the rate of K 600 per US$1. The CODE requires evidence of payment of this deposit before forward ing the exchange au- thorization form to the commercial bank. Before the deposits can be returned by the Treasury, the importer must show proof, including customs evidence, that the goods have ar- rived in Laos, that they have been properly priced, and that the transaction has generally conformed with the prevailing regulations on imports. Raw material imports by export in- dustries and installation equipment imported by firms bene- f i t ing from investment incentives are exempt from advance import deposit requirements. For customs valuation purposes, the exchange rate used for all imports is K 600 per US$1. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles other than expenses for medical treatment abroad and expenses of nonscholarship students are subject to the 40 per cent exchange tax. Payments eligible for the official rate are subject to exchange control approval by the CODE and most are restricted. Payments for all invisi- bles, however, may be made freely, provided that the 40 per cent exchange tax is paid. In all cases, applicants for exchange for current invisibles are required to complete forms indicat- ing their identity as well as the intended use of the desired 1 W i th effect from January 15, 1974 corrugated iron sheets ceased to be eligible for the official rate. 273 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LAOS foreign exchange. There is a foreign exchange budget detail- ing the Government's payments in foreign exchange during the fiscal year; for such payments the National Bank of Laos makes exchange available at the official rate. There are no regulations limiting the export of domestic or foreign bank- notes by travelers. Exports and Export Proceeds Exporters must pay an annual registration fee to the Gov- ernment. Exports of gold and silver are prohibited, except when made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. All other exports are subject to authorization, but licenses nor- mally are automatically issued. Exports of timber and other forestry and wood products require the opening of a letter of credit. The fu ll proceeds from exports of timber and other wood and forestry products and 80 per cent of proceeds from all other exports must be surrendered to the National Bank in U.S. dollars, French francs, or pounds sterling at the off i- cial rate; the remainder may be kept abroad or used freely. Exporters are required to deposit w i th the National Bank, prior to domiciling the export license w i th th is Bank, the portion of their anticipated export proceeds that is subject to surrender; the National Exchange Office gives its visa only on export licenses that have been anno ta ted by the National Bank to show that this requirement has been complied w i th. Except for timber, an exporter may, however, be permitted to make a prior surrender of only 40 per cent of export value, the remaining 40 per cent being due in a max imum of ten days from the settlement of the transaction; a commercial bank's guarantee may be accepted by the National Bank in lieu of the in i t ial deposit. For timber, the corresponding advance surrender requ irement is 50 per cent of export va lue. Should an exporter be paid in a currency other than U.S. dollars, French francs, or pounds sterling, he must exchange the part that is subject to surrender in to one of the acceptable curren- cies. Exports of timber, logs, plywood, and fu rn i tu re are enti- tled to an exchange subsidy of K 220 per US$1. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange converted by foreign embassies, missions, representatives, and in s t i tu t ions to cover their official ex- penses in Laos must be surrendered at the official rate. All other receipts from invisibles may be retained by the recipi- ent. There are no regulations l im i t ing the import of foreign or domestic banknotes by travelers. Capital Under the Investment Law of February 1970, various in- centives are available to foreign investors in Laos. Capital inf low is free from exchange control regulations and the for- 274 eign exchange need not be surrendered; capital outflow is subject to the 40 per cent exchange tax but is not restricted. The purchaser of foreign exchange must iden t i fy himself, however, and indicate the purpose of the payment or transfer. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form w i th in the country. Banks and other residents who are recognized as industrial users or as importers of gold also may freely import gold in any form, subject to payment of 3.5 per cent customs du ty (calculated at the official rate for the U.S. dollar and US$42.22 an ounce). Exports of gold by or on behalf of physical or juridical persons other than the mon- etary authorities norma l ly are prohibited, w i th the exception of gold coins issued under Decree No. 784/PC of June 26, 1969. Commercial imports and exports of articles containing a m inor qu an t i ty of gold are freely permitted. Changes during 1973 February 7. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few goods from any source and all imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Import licenses for raw and refined sugar are conditional on purchases of domestic sugar. All other com- modities may be imported freely w i thout license. Exports of most types of feeds tuffs were suspended. 275 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LESOTHO Exchange and Trade System Lesotho's currency is the South African Rand. The par value of the rand is 1.04550 grams of fine gold per rand, which corresponds to R 1 = SDR 1.17648. However, no exchange transactions take place at the par value. The South African Reserve Bank quotes a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.4900 per R 1. Exchange rates are based on the South African Reserve Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar against rand (US$1.4937 buying and US$1.4862 selling, per R 1) and the London market rates for the currencies con- cerned against the U.S. dollar. Lesotho has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Lesotho also forms part of the Rand Monetary Area, which is a single exchange control territory comprising Botswana, Lesotho, South Africa, and Swaziland. For purposes of exchange con- trol over transactions in securities or gold, residents of a member country of the latter area are not regarded as resi- dents of another member country. The M in is try of Finance controls all external currency transactions. No restrictions are applied to payments within the Rand Monetary Area, and in principle these are uncontrolled and unrecorded. In relation to countries outside the Rand Mone- tary Area, Lesotho applies exchange controls that are gener- ally similar to those of South Africa. Payments to nonresidents for current transactions, while subject to con- trol, are not restricted, but applications for outward transfers of capital are considered on their merits. The rulings on appli- cations for inward and outward capital transfers may depend on whether the applicant is a temporarily resident foreign national, a nonresident, or a resident. Au thor i ty to approve some types of current payments is delegated to commercial banks up to established limits; this is true, for example, of the basic exchange allowance for tourist travel (the equivalent of R 2,000 in a calendar year for an adult and R 800 for a child) and a smaller annual allocation for travel to neighboring countries. There are no bilateral payments arrangements. Lesotho is a member of a customs union with Botswana, South Africa, and Swaziland, and there are no import restric- tions on goods originating in any country of the customs union. Imports from South Africa do not require licenses and include an unknown quan t i ty of goods originating outside the customs union. Insofar as Lesotho imports goods direct from countries outside the customs union, such imports are usually licensed in conformity with South Africa's import regula- tions. Import licenses are valid for all countries and entitle the holder to buy the foreign exchange required to make the import payment. Lesotho's trade licensing arrangements, however, are designed mainly to raise revenue and to prevent tax evasion and are confined in practice to exports of dia- monds; permits are issued by the Department of Industry and Commerce. Certain tax incentives for inward direct investment are provided by the Pioneer Industries Encouragement Act, 1969 to manufac tur ing activities approved by a Pioneer Industries Board. Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell certain Lesotho gold coins that are legal tender. Changes during 1973 February 14. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the par value of the South African rand was maintained in terms of gold. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar, previously R 0.782891 = US$1, became R 0.704603 = US$1. The South African Re- serve Bank announced a middle rate for the U.S. dollar of R 1 = US$1.4193, and its fixed rates for the U.S. dollar were changed to US$1.4229 buy ing and US$1.4157 selling, per R 1. June 5. The South African Reserve Bank henceforth quoted a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.4900 per R 1. New official buying and selling rates were set at US$1.4937 and US$1.4862, respectively, per R 1. 276 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBERIA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.736662 gram of fine gold per Liberi- an Dollar, corresponding to $1.20635 = SDR 1 or $1 = US$1. U.S. currency is in circulation along with Liberian coinage and is legal tender. Official accounts are kept in dollars and cents. There are no restrictions on foreign ex- change transactions. surrender of the proceeds of exports is not required, and exchange receipts are freely disposable. An export tax is lev- ied on diamonds. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles There are no limitations on payments for or receipts from invisibles. Prescription of Currency Capital No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports and Import Payments There is no general system of import control. A few items (e.g., arms and ammunition, explosives, used clothing, and Pharmaceuticals) require prior licenses; no imports of shot- gun shells are permitted at present and only certain types of cement are imported. Also, imports of certain goods (e.g., obscene literature, narcotics other than for medicinal pur- poses) and all imports from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. In practice, meat is imported primarily by the Liberian Supply Corporation and petroleum and pe- troleum products only by the Liberian Refining Company. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are pro- hibited. Export licenses are required for precious metals, pre- cious stones, ivory, agricultural products other than rubber, and certain other items, such as arms, ammunition, and ex- plosives. Licenses are issued freely; they serve ma in ly to en- force taxation or, for agricultural products, to assure certification of quality and origin and to safeguard the mo- nopoly of the Liberian Produce Marketing Corporation. The No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents. Under an Investment Incentive Code, enterprises undertaking new in- vestment projects may be granted five-year to ten-year tax exemption and tariff exemptions on construction materials, raw materials, and capital goods to be used in manufacturing operations. Other possible benefits include tariff protection, subject to approval of the legislature. Gold Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form are subject to licenses issued by the Minister of Finance; import licenses are issued freely but export licenses are granted restrictively.
