Not for Redistribution LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of f ine gold per Libyan Dinar, corresponding to LD 0.357143 = SDR 1 or LD 0.296053 = US$1, and the Libyan Arab Republic avails itself of wider margins. The U.S. dollar is the intervention cur- rency. The Central Bank of Libya publishes daily buy ing and selling rates for 15 currencies. 1 It deals w i th commercial banks only in pounds sterling and U.S. dollars, at rates fixed daily. The Central Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar on Decem- ber 31, 1973 were LD 0.29531 buying, and LD 0.29679 sell- ing, per US$1; for the pound sterling the buy ing and selling rates were LD 0.68407 and LD 0.68750, respectively, per £ stg. 1. The commercial banks are permitted to buy or sell other currencies against pounds sterling and U.S. dollars through their foreign correspondents. The commercial banks' buying and selling rates for currencies other than sterling and U.S. dollars are based on quotations in London, New York, and other centers abroad. They may not deal among themselves in foreign currencies. Neither authorized banks nor importers or exporters are allowed to enter in to forward commitments in foreign currencies. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Central Bank, which has delegated some of its powers to the authorized banks. Policy relating to import and export licensing is deter- mined by the Ministry of Economy. Import and export li- censes are issued by the Ministry of Economy; for certain imports the approval of another M in is try (Interior, Health, Agriculture and Agrarian Reform, or Defense) is required. Imports of petroleum and petroleum products, certain cere- als, flour, tea, sugar, salt, tobacco, cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, and a number of other commodities are a government monopoly. Imports of unprocessed gold are confined to the Central Bank. Prescription of Currency Settlements with other countries are made in convertible currencies, usually U.S. dollars or pounds sterling. Certain settlements with Romania, however, are channeled through special accoun ts .2 All settlements w i th Israel, Mozambique, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts A nonresident, as defined by the Central Bank, who is ga infu l ly employed in the Libyan Arab Republic is permitted under the existing exchange control regulations to open and maintain a nonresident account in Libyan dinars w i th any 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Lebanese pounds, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, Tunisian dinars, and U.S. dollars. 2 The bilateral payments agreement of May 23, 1972 w i th Roman ia was terminated on February 15, 1974. 278 authorized bank in the Libyan Arab Republic. Legitimate earnings from employers of such nonresidents, including overtime payments, can be credited to their nonresident ac- counts. Similarly, authorized banks have authority to credit interest earned on balances in these nonresident accounts. All other credits to nonresident accounts require the prior ap- proval of the Central Bank. Remittances abroad from such accounts maintained by nonresident laborers and technicians can be allowed by banks up to 60 per cent of net salary each mon th; for those whose contracts specify that lodging and /or board will be made available free of charge by the employer, remittances up to 90 per cent of net salary are permitted. Banks may issue travelers checks and foreign currency notes to nonresident laborers and technicians within the limits men- tioned. Total permissible remittances in any calendar year from a nonresident account are reduced, however, by the value of specified imported goods (including automobiles and electrical domestic appliances) taken out by a nonresident when going abroad. Funds brought into the Libyan Arab Republic by nonresi- dent contractors undertaking contracts in their own names are required to be kept in "special resident accounts" with a bank in the Republic. Payments received in the Libyan Arab Republic by such contractors in respect of their contracts may also be credited to these accounts. Remittances from the Libyan Arab Republic to the debit of these accounts are subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank after sub- mission of all the prescribed evidence. Nonresident-owned capital that is not permitted to be transferred abroad is credited to blocked accounts. With the approval of the Central BanH, funds in blocked accounts (with certain exceptions) may be used for expenditures in the Libyan Arab Republic up to LD 500 a year to cover the cost of current visits to the Libyan Arab Republic by the owner of the funds or a close relative; for payments in the Libyan Arab Republic of legal fees, taxes, etc.; for remittances to the owner of the funds in his coun try of permanent residence, up to LD 1,000 in a calendar year; and for remittances in cases of hardship. When the funds have been in a blocked account for f ive years, they qua l i fy for remittances in fu ll to the owner in his coun try of permanent residence. The blocked accounts of persons (with certain exceptions) who have left the Libyan Arab Republic permanently are being released in install- ments; balances credited prior to March 31, 1966 have been released. Imports and Import Payments Import transactions are governed by Law No. 63 of 1971. Most imports are under open general license and do not require an individual import license. The import of some items, inc lud ing alcoholic beverages and narcotics, is prohib- ited. Imports of petroleum and petroleum products, sugar, salt, tea, rice, barley, wheat, f lour, olive oil, tobacco, cigars, cigarettes, and cigarette paper are subject to government mo- nopoly; they may be imported only by the National Oil Cor- poration, the National Supplies Corporation, or the Tobacco ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution General Company. The Central Bank has a monopoly over the import of unworked gold. All imports from Israel, Mo- zambique, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohib- ited. Imports from the United Kingdom of specified consumer goods are suspended. Exchange permits required for imports are readily granted by the authorized banks, provided that there is a firm con- tract and any necessary import license has been obtained and, if the import is to be made on a letter of credit basis, that a marine insurance policy from an insurance company in the Libyan Arab Republic is submitted before the letter of credit is established. However, no letter of credit in respect of the import of consumer durable goods may be opened by an authorized bank without obtaining a cash margin of 25 per cent of the import price. Importers must submit to the bank granting the exchange permit, w i th in two months of customs clearance, a customs declaration confirming clearance and stating the valuation. The approval of the Exchange Control Department of the Central Bank is required for advance pay- ments. Deferred payments (for up to 90 days after customs clearance) and payments for consignment shipments may be approved by the authorized banks. Imports are subject to customs du ty and customs sur- charges totaling 15 per cent of the applicable customs du ty. Payments for Invisibles The authorized banks are empowered to approve applica- tions by residents to remit foreign exchange up to LD 100 in a calendar year for meeting genuine personal commitments abroad of a noncommercial nature, including fam i ly assist- ance and gifts. They may also approve transfers abroad of up to LD 1,320 a year for each student (plus tuition fees, an allowance for books, etc.) for educational purposes, as well as allocations for travel as indicated below. Remittances from nonresident accounts may be approved by authorized banks up to certain limits (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). All other payments for invisibles, as well as payments in excess of the approval au thor i ty delegated to the banks, require licenses from the Central Bank. Applications are con- sidered on their merits. Persons leaving the country may take with them Libyan currency notes not exceeding a total of LD 20 (LD 10 for children under 12); these may not be spent or exchanged outside the Libyan Arab Republic, but are intended for im- mediate expenses in the Libyan Arab Republic upon return to the country. Residents leaving for personal travel abroad, including tourist travel may, in addition, take out foreign exchange in the form of foreign currency notes, travelers checks, and letters of credit not exceeding a total value of LD 300 in a calendar year as a basic travel allowance; the exchange may be obtained from any authorized bank in the Libyan Arab Republic. Children under 12 years of age are allowed one half of this amount. Amounts in excess of the above may be granted in special circumstances. Pilgrims are entitled to a special quota of LD 300 in addition to the basic travel allowance. For business travel, residents may take out the equivalent of LD 500 a trip, subject to a max imum of LD 2,500 in any calendar year. All fares may be settled in LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC Libyan dinars in the Libyan Arab Republic. Temporary resi- dents may take out any travelers checks or foreign currency notes which they had previously brought in and declared to the customs. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are only required for commodities which are not of Libyan origin. Export proceeds must be received through an authorized bank within six months of shipment. Exports of nonmonetary gold (other than for processing abroad), vegetable oils, and scrap metals are prohibited. All exports to Israel, Mozambique, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Exports of crude petroleum to the Netherlands and the United States are suspended. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surren- dered. Travelers checks or foreign currency notes may be cashed only at an authorized bank or at an exchange office licensed by the Central Bank of Libya. Travelers entering the Libyan Arab Republic may bring w i th them Libyan currency notes, not exceeding a total of LD 20, and other currency notes, travelers checks, letters of credit, securities, coupons, and other negotiable instruments in unlimited amounts. Capital Many aspects of the activities of oil companies operating in the Libyan Arab Republic are governed by Petroleum Law No. 25 of 1955, as amended. Under the provisions of the Foreign Capital Investment Law No. 37 of July 31, 1968, foreign capital invested in projects deemed to contribute to the economic development of the country, as well as profits thereon, and salaries of foreign staff employed on such projects may be transferred freely to the coun try of origin, provided that the paid-up capital is not less than LD 200,000 and that at least 51 per cent of the shares is held by foreign nationals. Foreign participation in new industrial ventures (i.e., after March 20, 1970) is permitted only on a minority basis, and only if it leads to increased production in excess of local requirements, introduction of the latest technology, and cooperation w i th foreign firms in exporting the surplus pro- duction. Insurance companies and foreign shareholdings in banks have been nationalized. Commercial firms have been Libyanized in varying degrees. Real estate in the Libyan Arab Republic may be sold only to Libyans, save in exceptional circumstances specifed in a law of May 24, 1960 governing this subject. The net sales proceeds after tax of real estate belonging to foreign nationals are transferable, subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank. Nonresident-owned capital that is not permitted to be transferred abroad is credited to blocked accounts (see sec- tion on Nonresident Accounts, above). Residents require the prior approval of the Central Bank to borrow funds abroad. As a rule, residents require prior permission to purchase real estate situated outside the Libyan Arab Republic or to invest abroad in securities. Residents of the Libyan Arab Republic 279 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC taking up permanent residence abroad are permitted to trans- fer up to LD 5,000 for a family; applications may be submit- ted for the elease of the balance of their assets over a number of years. The investment of national capital abroad is ruled by Law No. 25 of April 20, 1973. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form othei *han bars in the Libyan Arab Republic. The Cen- tral Bank has a monopoly over the import of unworked gold. It sells bars to domestic goldsmiths in limited quantities, to meet genuine commercial needs, at prices announced from time to time; at the end of 1973 this price was LD 1,302 a kilogram. Provided that a license is obtained from the Minis- try of Economy, goldsmiths may have such gold processed abroad, after which it must be reimported. Bars purchased from the Central Bank must be melted and processed before they can be sold to the public. Exports of unworked gold not for processing are not permitted unless made by or on behalf of the Government. Unworked gold is subject to an import du ty of 15 per cent. Not for Redistribution Exchange System Imports and Import Payments MALAGASY REPUBLIC No par value for the currency of the Malagasy Republic has been established with the Fund. The un it of currency is the Malagasy Franc, which is officially maintained at the rate of FMG 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transactions in French francs, l the intervention currency, between the Cen- tral Bank of the Malagasy Republic and commercial banks take place at the rates of FMG 50.25 selling, and FMG 49.75 buying, per F 1. The Central Bank quotes seven other curren- cies. 2 The authorized banks are not permitted to maintain an exchange position in any foreign currency. All countries other than the Malagasy Republic itself are considered foreign countries, and financial relations w i th all foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Office of External Finance of the Directorate of the Treasury in the M in is try of Economy and Finance, which also supervises borrowing and lending abroad by residents, the issue, sale, or introduction of foreign securities in the Malagasy Republic, all outward investments, and inward direct investment. Some of the ex- change control approval au thor i ty has been delegated to the authorized banks. All exchange transactions relating to for- eign countries must be effected through authorized banks. Import licenses are issued by the Foreign Trade Bureau of the Directorate of Commerce and Prices in the M in is try of Econ- omy and Finance, including those for gold. Export authoriza- tions are issued either by the Foreign Trade Bureau (and its provincial offices) or by other specified public agencies, ma in ly stabilization funds or marke t ing offices for agricul- tural products. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected through the autho- rized banks, which may deal w i th the Central Bank of the Malagasy Republic only in the currencies quoted by the lat- ter. Nonresident Accounts The principal type of nonresident account is Foreign Ac- counts in Malagasy Francs; these accounts may be debited and credited only for transactions between nonresidents and for explicitly authorized transactions between residents and nonresidents. When Malagasy francs accruing to a nonresi- dent are not immediately eligible for credit to a Foreign Ac- count, they must be credited to a Special Account, balances in which may be used by the holder for personal expenses in the Malagasy Republic, subject to a limit of FMG 10,000 a day during a period not exceeding 30 days. 1 The Central Bank of the Malagasy Republic deals solely in official French francs. Commercial banks requiring financial French francs must acquire them on the French exchange market or th rough arb i trage abroad. 2 These currencies are listed as Belgian francs, deutsche m a rk, I ta l ian lire, Ne ther lands guilders, pounds s ter l ing, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. All imports are subject to import licensing; the import of certain other items from all sources is prohibited or sus- pended until fur ther notice. Imports of fru it juices are conditional on purchases of domestic f ru it juices (jumelage). Imports of household soap are, in principle, conditional on purchases of household soap from Ivory Coast. Imports are effected w i th in the framework of an annual import program. The import program is based on the estab- lishment of global quotas that set the limits up to which specified commodities may be imported. All import transactions valued at FMG 10,000 or more must be domiciled with an authorized bank. The import li- cense entitles importers to purchase the necessary exchange (up to eight days before shipment when a documentary credit is opened); the payment can be made when the shipping documents are submitted to the authorized bank. Payments for Invisibles Most payments for invisibles require the prior approval of the Ministry of Economy and Finance. For some types of transactions the approval au thor i ty has been delegated to authorized banks, either up to specified limits or for any amount that is properly documented. Residents may obtain an exchange allocation for tourism equivalent to FMG 75,000 a person a trip, for up to two trips a year (FMG 35,000 for children under ten); any foreign exchange remaining after return to the Malagasy Republic must be surrendered. There also is an exchange allocation for business travel up to the equivalent of FMG 10,000 a person a day, subject to a maxi- mum of FMG 200,000 a person a trip, for any number of trips a year. Authorized banks may not make available foreign banknotes in excess of the equivalent of FMG 20,000 a person a trip for tourist or business travel. Applications for amounts in excess of the basic tourist and business travel allocations, and applications for exchange for any other type of travel, must be submitted to the Ministry of Economy and Finance. Allocations for different types of travel may not be combined. The transfer of savings from wages and salaries earned by a foreigner working in the Malagasy Republic is permitted, upon presentation of his employment contract and provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period, up to 25 per cent of the net salary for bachelors and persons having their family in the Malagasy Republic, and up to 45 per cent for those whose fam i ly lives outside the Mala- gasy Republic (100 per cent for all concerned during leave spent outside the Malagasy Republic). Resident and nonresi- dent travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to FMG 5,000 in Malagasy banknotes. Nonresident travelers may take out any remaining foreign banknotes and coins and other foreign means of payment declared by them on en try, as well as foreign currency ob- tained by documented reconversion of Malagasy banknotes purchased af ter en try. 281 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAGASY REPUBLIC Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to all destinations of products under quota and of so-called controlled products require an exit permit {automa- tion de sortie) issued by the appropriate commodity stabiliza- tion office; these products include coffee, vanilla, cloves, pepper, sugar, rice, and petroleum and petroleum products. Export proceeds received in foreign currencies must be surrendered; such export proceeds normally must become due not later than one month after arrival of the goods at their destination. All export transactions valued at FMG 50,000 or more must be domiciled with an authorized bank and a com- m i tment to repatriate the proceeds must be signed. Proceeds from Invisibles All amounts due from residents of other countries in re- spect of services, and all income or proceeds accruing in those countries or from nonresidents, must be collected and, when received in foreign currency, surrendered within one month of the due date. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of means of payment denominated in a foreign currency. The import of Malagasy banknotes is prohibited. sale in the Malagasy Republic has previously been autho- rized. Borrowing abroad by physical or juridical persons, whether public or private persons, requires prior authoriza- tion by the Minister of Economy and Finance. However, loans contracted by registered banks or credit institutions with special legal status are exempt from approval. Lending abroad is subject to exchange control authorization and is restricted. In accordance with the Investment Code of September 19, 1973, foreign or domestic enterprises of special interest for the economy may be granted preferential treatment in accor- dance w i th an "order of approval" (arrete d'agrement). Such enterprises may benefit from specified advantages relating to import and export duties, income taxes, supplementary allo- cations above those allotted in the annual import program, the introduction of quotas for competing imports, etc. The same benefits may be granted temporarily to investments not qua l ify ing for an "order of approval." Exceptional treatment beyond the benefits provided for by the Investment Code and other existing legislation may be granted in a participation contract (control de participation). Capital Gold Capital movements between the Malagasy Republic and foreign countries and between residents and nonresidents are subject to exchange control; capital transfers to all countries require exchange control approval, but capital receipts from foreign countries normally are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control re- quirements that may be applicable) are maintained over bor- rowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in the Malagasy Repub- lic. Foreign direct investments in the Malagasy Republic, 3 and Malagasy direct investments abroad, 4 require prior ap- proval of the Minister of Economy and Finance (i.e., the Directorate of the Treasury in the Ministry). The total or partial liquidation of such investments must be declared to the Minister. Both the making and the liquidation of direct investments, whether these are Malagasy investments abroad or foreign investments in the Malagasy Republic, must be reported to the Minister of Economy and Finance within 20 days following each operation. Mere participation is not con- sidered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign secu- rities in the Malagasy Republic requires prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance. Exempt from au- thorization, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Malagasy Government and (2) shares similar to securities whose issue, offering, or 3 Including those made by companies in the Malagasy Republic that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in the Malagasy Republic of foreign companies. 4 Inc lud ing those made through the intermediary of foreign companies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in the Malagasy Republic and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in the Malagasy Republic. 282 Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in the Malagasy Republic. Imports and exports of gold require prior authorization by the Ministry of Economy and Finance. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Central Bank; (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles containing a minor quan t i ty of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports by travelers of gold jewelry and other articles of gold up to 500 grams a fam i ly and collector's coins up to 200 grams a fam i ly. Imports of gold, whether licensed or exempt from license, are subject to customs declaration. Newly mined gold must be surrendered to the Directorate of Mines, which, in principle, must deliver it to the Central Bank af ter processing. Changes during 1973 January 25. Not for Redistribution MALAWI Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.06641 grams of f ine gold per Malawi Kwacha, corresponding to MK 0.833333 = SDR 1. How- ever, no exchange transactions take place at the par value. The Reserve Bank of Malawi sets daily buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar and the pound sterling in light of exchange market developments abroad. On December 31, 1973 the Reserve Bank's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were MK 1 = US$0.8433 and MK 1 = US$0.8391, respectively, and those for sterling were MK 1 = £0.5106 and MK 1 = £0.5128, respectively. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Reserve Bank of Malawi under powers delegated to it by the Minister of Fi- nance. Much of the authority for approving normal current payments is in turn delegated to commercial banks desig- nated as authorized dealers. Import policy is formulated by the Minister of Trade and Indus try, subject to the approval of the Cabinet. The Minister is also responsible for the issue of import and export licenses. Prescription of Currency Malawi has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. For prescription of currency purposes, a distinction is made between the rest of the Sterling Area (the Nonresident Scheduled Area) and all other countries except Rhodesia (the External Account Area). * Settlements w i th residents of other countries in the Sterling Area may be made in Malawi kwacha through a Nonresident Scheduled Area Account, in sterling, or in any other Sterling Area currency. Payments to residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia may be made in sterling or in Malawi kwacha to the credit of an External Account, or in any non-Sterling Area currency other than Rhodesian currency. Payments from residents of countries outside the Sterling Area except Rhodesia may be received in sterling or in Malawi kwacha from an External Account, or in any non-Sterling Area currency freely ex- changeable for sterling. Special regulations apply to settle- ments w i th Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Malawi kwacha held by residents of other parts of the Sterling Area are designated Nonresident Sched- uled Area Accounts. These accounts may be credited w i th the proceeds from sales of any Sterling Area currency, with au- thorized payments to Sterling Area countries by residents, and w i th transfers from other Nonresident Scheduled Area Accounts. Balances on these accounts may be converted 1 Under Malawi's exchange control regulations, all currencies o ther than the Malawi kwacha (or any other currency that may be legal tender in Malawi) are considered foreign currencies. 284 freely into other Sterling Area currencies, may be used to make payments to residents of Malawi for any purpose, and may be transferred freely to other Nonresident Scheduled Area Accounts; these accounts may also be debited for pay- ments to the account holder while temporarily resident in Malawi. Transfers to External Accounts require specific ap- proval. Accounts in Malawi kwacha held with authorized banks by residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized payments by residents to countries outside the Sterling Area except Rhodesia, with transfers from other External Accounts held in Malawi or any other Sterling Area territory, with individually approved transfers from Nonresident Scheduled Area Accounts, and w i th the proceeds from sales of any non-Sterling Area cur- rency except Rhodesian currency by nonresidents to autho- rized dealers. They may be debited for payments for any purpose to residents of Malawi and of any other country of the Sterling Area, for transfers to other External Accounts held in Malawi or any other Sterling Area territory, or to Nonresident Scheduled Area Accounts in Malawi, and for purchases of any Sterling Area or non-Sterling Area currency other than Rhodesian currency from authorized dealers; they may also be debited for withdrawals by the account holder while temporarily staying in Malawi. External Accounts—Rhodesia arc accounts in Malawi kwa- cha that are held by persons regarded as residents of Rhode- sia. They may only be credited w i th (1) the proceeds from the sale of Rhodesian currency to an authorized dealer in Malawi, and (2) transfers from another Rhodesian External Account. The accounts may be debited with (1) payments to residents of Malawi for any purpose; (2) payments to the account holder while temporarily staying in Malawi; (3) transfers to another Rhodesian External Account; and (4) transfers to the account holders in Rhodesia. Blocked Accounts in Malawi kwacha held with authorized banks by residents of any country other than Malawi are credited with nontransferable capital sums in Malawi cur- rency which have accrued to nonresidents. All debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. Normally, approval is given for the investment of balances of Blocked Accounts in Malawian securities, provided that these are held in Malawi to the order of an authorized dealer. The interest on Blocked Account balances is freely transferable to the account holder's country of residence. Imports and Import Payments The statutory basis of the principal import restrictions is the Control of Goods Act, which authorizes the Minister of Trade and Indus t ry to control and regulate the import, ex- port, distribution, disposal, purchase, sale, wholesale price, and retail price of any goods. It also has provisions which, when brought in to operation, will require all importers and exporters to be registered. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution The import from Rhodesia of asbestos, iron ore, pig iron, chrome, tobacco, copper, and hides and skins is prohibited. For a number of i tems ,2 import licenses are required regard- less of the country of origin. All other goods may be imported under an open general license when originating in Common- wealth countries or in non-Commonwealth countries that are members of the GATT. Imports originating in the Republic of China are treated similarly but require an individual li- cense. With respect to other countries, an import license is required for all commodities except certain items such as petroleum products, exposed cinematographic films, bona fide unsolicited gifts not exceeding MK 50 in value, samples, and advertising materials. Payments for imports from all countries must be made within six months after the date of import. Foreign exchange for these payments is automatically granted by the authorized dealers, subject only to the presentation of relevant docu- ments and compliance with import licensing requirements. Any transfer of funds in anticipation of imports is prohibited, except with the permission of the exchange control authori- ties. Advance payments may, however, be made for imports valued at up to MK 100 on presentation of an invoice or other evidence indicating that the seller requires payment in ad- vance. Imports from any Sterling Area country may be paid for in Malawi currency to a local Nonresident Scheduled Area Account, in sterling, or in any other Sterling Area currency. Imports from other areas, except Rhodesia, may be paid for in Malawi currency to a local External Account, in sterling to an External Account held elsewhere in the Sterling Area, or in any non-Sterling Area currency. A surtax of 10 per cent is levied on most goods imported into Malawi, irrespective of their origin; the surtax is calcu- lated on 120 per cent of the sum of the value for customs du ty purposes and any customs du ty payable. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes, such as travel, is provided by the authorized dealers without prior reference to the exchange control authorities. The basic exchange allow- ance for travel is MK 20 a day for an adult, w i th a maximum of MK 600 a calendar year, and MK 10 a day for each child under 18 years of age, with a maximum of MK 300 a calendar year for children between 10 and 18, and of MK 200 a year for children under 10. The annual allowance is not cumulative but may be increased by up to 50 per cent if the traveler has not applied for a travel allowance during the preceding three years. These allocations are subject to a combined maximum of MK 2,000 a year for a family traveling together. Exchange is provided, subject to certain limits, for other purposes, such as education, medical treatment, family remittances, and business travel. Foreign nationals employed in Malawi on con- tracts or holding a temporary employment permit are allowed to remit up to two thirds of their current net earnings to their coun try of normal residence. Travelers may take out up to MK 20 in Malawi currency and the equivalent of MK 20 in foreign currency in addition to their basic travel allowance. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of goods of any description that exceed MK 100 in value are prohibited, unless the Controller of Customs and Excise is satisfied that payment has been made or will be made in an appropriate manner to a resident of Malawi not later than six months after the date of exportation. Certain commodities 3 are subject to export licensing, mainly to en- sure the adequacy of their domestic supplies. Export proceeds in foreign currency must be sold to an authorized dealer. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any foreign currency must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes and coins that may be imported by travelers, but not more than MK 20 in Ma- lawi currency notes and coins may be imported. The import of currency notes and coins of the former Federation of Rho- desia and Nyasaland is prohibited. Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted, with the ex- ception that the taking up of loans from abroad by residents requires prior exchange control approval. This is normally granted, provided that the terms of repayment are realistic. Outward transfers of capital, including those to other parts of the Sterling Area, are controlled, but nonresidents are permitted to repatriate their investments when they have sat- isfied the authorities that the original investment was made with funds brought into the country from sources outside Malawi; there are no restrictions on the transfer abroad of dividends and profits of foreign-owned companies, provided that no recourse is being made to local borrowing. In general, residents are not permitted to transfer capital abroad and, w i th certain exceptions, are required to offer for sale to an authorized dealer any foreign exchange which ac- crues to them. However, residents may purchase foreign secu- rities (except bearer securities) quoted on recognized stock exchanges in the Sterling Area, provided that the securities so acquired are registered in the names of specified nominees and held to the order of an authorized dealer, and that in the event of subsequent disposal of these securities the sales proceeds are permitted to be repatriated by the exchange control au- 3 Implements of war, petroleum products, nickel, atomic energy materials, and certain agricultural and an imal products. 285 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAWI thorities of the country concerned. All income earned from these investments must be repatriated, and the corresponding foreign exchange must be sold to an authorized dealer. Emigrants are granted exchange as follows: (1) Persons 50 years of age and over are allowed exchange up to MK 15,000 whether single or married. (2) Married persons who have not reached the age of 50 are allowed MK 6,000 on departure, together w i th MK 500 for each child, up to a maximum of MK 8,000 for a family. (3) Unmarried persons who have not reached 50 years of age are allowed MK 3,000 on departure. (4) The balance of the emigrant's funds is blocked, but he is permitted to transfer to his new country of residence a sum equal to the original emigration allowance on each anni- versary of his departure from Malawi, up to a maximum of MK 8,000. Applications for emigrants' allowances, whether initial or subsequent, must be submitted to the exchange control authorities for approval. Residents require prior approval to lend to nonresidents or to resident firms controlled directly or indirectly from outside Malawi. Approval to lend to nonresident-controlled f irms may be withheld if it is felt that excessive recourse is being had to local borrowing, and that the firms have brought in in su f f i- cient working capital from abroad. Gold Residents of Malawi may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Malawi for numismatic purposes. With this excep- tion, residents other than the monetary authorities and autho- rized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Minister of Trade and Indus try in consultation with the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Changes during 1973 February 17. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the kwacha remained pegged to sterling at the existing ratio of MK 1 = £0.5. November 19. Malawi ceased to maintain a fixed exchange rate relationship between the kwacha and the pound sterling. The value of the kwacha would un t il fu r ther notice be deter- mined daily by the Reserve Bank of Malawi on the basis of changes in the sterling and U.S. dollar rates and at rates consistent therewith in respect of the currencies of Malawi's other major trad ing partners. 286 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAYSIA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.290299 gram of fine gold per Malaysian Dollar, corresponding to MS3.06122 = SDR 1, and Malay- sia avails itself of wider margins. Since June 21, 1973, how- ever, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate within announced margins, and therefore all transactions take place at a fluctuating exchange rate. The closing buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in the Malaysian foreign exchange market on December 31, 1973 were MS2.4525 and MS2.4545 per US$1, respectively. The commercial banks are free to determine and quote exchange rates for all currencies to customers and are permitted to deal forward in all curren- cies. Malaysia formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from Novem- ber 11, 1968. Administration of Control The Central Bank of Malaysia administers exchange con- trol on behalf of the Malaysian Government throughout Ma- laysia, the Governor of the Bank being the Controller of Foreign Exchange. Much of the authority for approving nor- mal current payments is delegated to commercial banks au- thorized for this purpose. The authority for import control rests with the Central Government. The day-to-day adminis- tration of import control throughout Malaysia is carried out jointly by the Ministry of Trade and Industry and the Royal Customs and Excise. 1 Certain import and export transac- tions are effected by a state trading corporation, the National Trading Corporation (PERNAS). Prescription of Currency Malaysia has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. All payments to countries other than Rhodesia and South Africa may be made either in Malaysian dollars through an External Account, or in any currency other than Rhodesian and South African currencies. Receipts from exports to countries other than Rhodesia and South Africa must be obtained, within six months from the date of exportation, either in Malaysian dollars obtained from the sale of a specified currency to a bank in Malaysia, or in any specified currency. Special regula- tions apply to settlements with Rhodesia and South Africa. Nonresident Accounts The accounts in Malaysian dollars of residents of countries other than Malaysia are treated as nonresident accounts and, unless specially restricted, are designated External Accounts. There are no restrictions on debits to External Accounts. Credits to these accounts for whatever purpose are freely 1 There are at present f ive separate customs areas: West Malaysia, excluding Penang; Sabah, excluding Labuan; Sarawak; Penang; and Labuan. Labuan and Penang are free ports. permitted subject only to the completion of exchange control forms for amounts above M$ 1,000; the proceeds from the sale of any foreign currency may be credited to External Ac- counts. For amounts exceeding M$ 1,000 and up to M$l million, permission may be given by commercial banks; above M$l million, permission is given by the Controller of Foreign Exchange. Balances on External Accounts may be transferred to any other account, whether resident or nonresident, and may be converted into any currency except Rhodesian and South African currencies. Accounts of residents of Rhodesia and South Africa are designated as Rhodesian Accounts and South African Accounts, respectively. All debits and credits to such accounts require prior approval. Imports and Import Payments Tariffs and import controls of the various parts of Malaysia have not yet been fully unified, although steps toward unifica- tion are being taken. Some internal tar iffs and other trade restrictions still exist between parts of Malaysia. Most im- ports are permitted freely under open general license. De- pending on the nature and origin of the goods, specific licenses are required for certain imports for health, security, or moral reasons; various conditions must be satisfied before licenses for such goods are issued. Certain other imports are subject to quantitative restrictions pending the introduction of protective customs duties to protect local industries. Imports into all parts of Malaysia of all commodities from South Africa, Rhodesia, or any territory administered by either are prohibited. Imports into all parts of Malaysia of all commodities from the People's Republic of China are prohib- ited except under specific license. Imports into all parts of Malaysia of all commodities from Eastern Germany and North Korea also require specific licenses. Imports into West Malaysia of primates from all sources, including East Malay- sia, are prohibited except under specific license; imports of bones, bone meal, and other live animals (except sheep and goats) from Brunei, Burma, Indonesia, the Khmer Republic, Laos, Thailand, and Viet-Nam also require a specific license. Imports into Sarawak of sulphur, certain chemicals, and live sheep and goats from all sources, including West Malaysia and Sabah, are prohibited, except under specific license. Im- ports of motor vehicles and certain types of textiles into East Malaysia are also subject to specific import licensing. In re- spect of West Malaysia, imports of rice from any country are conditional on the importer purchasing one ton of rice from the government reserve stockpile for every ton imported; 2 imports of wheat flour, rice bran, and sugar 3 from all sources are subject to quantitative restrictions for protective reasons; licenses for wheat flour are not being issued. Other goods subject to quantitative restriction in West Malaysia include rolled oats, certain cotton fabrics, jute, and fully assembled motor vehicles. Certain imports are effected by PERNAS, which has a monopoly over imports from the People's Repub- 2 This ratio is varied from time to time depending on the turnover of official stocks. 3 Including jaggery, rock sugar, and molasses listed under specified tariff numbers. 287 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAYSIA lie of China. No approval is required for payments for permit- ted imports. Virtually all imports into Malaysia (including Penang but excluding Labuan) are subject to a surtax of 4 per cent ad valorem, unless they are re-exported ex-bond; a drawback may be granted on goods intended for re-export or for export after processing. In addition, most imports in to Malaysia (excluding Penang and Labuan) are subject to a sales tax; the standard rate of tax is 5 per cent ad valorem, but certain luxu ry goods are subject to a rate of 10 per cent ad valorem. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries other than Rhode- sia and South Africa may be made freely after exchange con- trol requirements have been met. There are no restrictions on the amount of foreign exchange made available for travel abroad. Remittances to nonresidents of dividends, interest, and profits on all bona fide investments are freely permitted, subject only to the completion of exchange control forms for amounts in excess of M$ 1,000. Unless special permission is obtained, not more than M$ 1,000 in Malaysian notes and the equivalent of M$ 1,000 in foreign notes may be taken out of Malaysia by travelers. Nonresident travelers are allowed to take out foreign currency notes up to the amount declared upon en try. Exports and Export Proceeds The three territories of Malaysia (West Malaysia, Sabah, and Sarawak) at present maintain separate export control systems, a l though the Federal Government retains the right to legislate in respect of exports from any Malaysian territory. Exchange control forms have to be completed and authorized by banks in Malaysia for exports valued at M$5,000 or more. 4 Proceeds from exports must be received w i th in six mon ths of shipment either in a specified currency or in Ma- laysian dollars obtained from the sale of a specified currency to a bank in Malaysia. Exports of rubber from West Malaysia require a certificate issued by the Malaysian Rubber Ex- change. Exports of rubber and tin to South Africa and any territory administered by South Africa are prohibited, as are exports of sugar to any destination. All exports to Rhodesia and any territory administered by Rhodesia are also prohib- ited. Proceeds from Invisibles The exchange control requirements governing exchange receipts from invisibles are, in general, the same as those for export proceeds. Travelers may bring in up to M$ 1,000 in Malaysian currency notes; otherwise, permission is required for the import of Malaysian notes. No limitations are im- posed on the import by travelers of currency notes of other countries. 4 In the case of exports to Indonesia, in excess of M$ 100,000. 288 Capital Inward portfolio and direct investment in Malaysia may be made w i thout app rova l .5 However, nonresidents making di- rect investment and the registrars of companies are responsi- ble for ensuring that the conditions of the Ministry of Trade and Indus t ry with respect to capital participation are com- plied w i th. The proceeds of investments may be repatriated freely on resale, subject to the completion of exchange control forms for amounts above M$ 1,000. Malaysian residents re- qu ire approval for borrowings from nonresidents in either Malaysian dollars or in foreign currencies. Companies in Ma- laysia controlled by nonresidents are permitted to borrow in Malaysia up to M$500,000 without exchange control ap- proval. The permission of the Controller of Foreign Exchange is freely given for direct and portfolio investment by Malay- sian residents in countries other than Rhodesia and South Africa. Gold Residents other than authorized dealers in gold are not permitted to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than gold that has been materially increased in value by skilled craftsmanship. The manufacture, import, or export of gold coins is prohibited, as is domestic trading in gold coins other than the M$100 gold coin of Malaysian currency and the SS150 gold coin of Singapore currency. Resident and nonresident travelers, however, may freely bring in or take out, on their person, one MS100 gold coin. In addition, each traveler is allowed to bring in from any country outside Ma- laysia one S$150 gold coin issued by the Singapore Board of Commissioners of Currency, and each traveler may take out one such coin, but only to Singapore. Licensed goldsmiths are permitted by the exchange control authorities to purchase certain quantities of gold from an authorized dealer at local free market prices for the manufacture of bona fide jewelry and ornaments. Furthermore, producers of gold are permit- ted to sell their ou tput at local free market prices to autho- rized dealers in gold. Imports of gold are restricted under the Customs Act, 1967, and require licenses from the Ministry of Trade and Indus try. Permission for imports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler is not normally given except for imports by authorized dealers in gold to meet the genuine requirements of goldsmiths for manufac tur ing jewelry and ornaments and for industrial use. Imports are allocated to authorized dealers in gold by means of a tender system; successful tenderers must pay a premium to the Government. Imports are subject to a 2 per cent import du ty and a 4 per cent surtax, 6 as well as a sales tax of 10 per cent ad valorem. Domestic transactions in gold or gold orna- ments are subject only to the sales tax, at 10 per cent ad valorem. Imports of certain types of chemicals, synthetic fibers, woven fabrics of wool and man-made yarn, and certain mechanical appliances became subject to licensing. February 13. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, Malaysia decided to maintain the existing gold parity of the Malaysian dollar. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar, previously MS2.81955 = US$1, became MS2.53760 = US$1. May 8. Under the Exchange Control Act, 1953, the Sched- uled Territories were redefined to comprise Malaysia only. The distinction between Sterling Area and non-Sterling Area countries in the exchange control regulations was thereby discontinued and exchange controls were extended to Sterling Area countries. The prescription of currency regulations and nonresident account arrangements were changed accord- ingly. Simultaneously, the approval authority delegated to authorized banks was broadened (see below). It was an- nounced that the existing regulations on exchange transac- tions w i th non-Sterling Area countries would be liberalized to the max imum extent possible, and that residents would be freely permitted to remit funds for the purpose of direct and portfolio investment in all countries. (Previously, there were restrictions on capital outflows to countries outside the Ster- ling Area only; there were no restrictions on current pay- ments.) May 8. Remittances abroad were permitted freely w i thout limit. Remittances of M$ 1,000 or less did not require ap- proval. Remittances in excess of M$ 1,000 and up to M$l million could be approved by commercial banks. Amounts in excess of M$l million required the approval of the Controller of Foreign Exchange, which was given freely for all purposes. The following basic allocations for transactions w i th countries outside the Sterling Area lapsed: the tourist travel allowance of M$5,000 a person a calendar year; the business travel allowance of M$200 a day; the settling-in allowance for emigrants of M$50,000 for each family un i t; the cash gift allowance of M$2,500 a year per donor or remittor; and the education allowance of M$ 15,000 a student a year. May 8. Residents were freely permitted to make direct and portfolio investments abroad. Remittances up to M$l million could be approved by commercial banks; amounts in excess of M$l million required the approval of the Controller of Foreign Exchange. Inward portfolio and direct investment was exempted from exchange control approval. Nonresidents making direct investments were required to comply w i th con- ditions laid down by the Ministry of Trade and Indus t ry w i th respect to capital participation. May 8. All export proceeds henceforth had to be received either in specified currencies or in Malaysian dollars obtained from the sale of specified currencies to banks in Malaysia; previously this provision was applicable only to exports to non-Sterling Area countries. May 8. Portuguese escudos and Spanish pesetas were de- leted from the list of specified currencies. Australian dollars, MALAYSIA Brunei dollars, Hong Kong dollars, New Zealand dollars, pounds sterling, and Singapore dollars were added to it. May 8. Existing Sterling Area Accounts were redesignated External Accounts. May 8. Prepayments and deferred payments for goods im- ported from outside the Sterling Area henceforth were freely permitted, subject only to the completion of exchange control forms for amounts exceeding M$ 1,000. May 8. The rules governing the opening and maintenance of intercompany accounts with offices in countries outside the Sterling Area, except Rhodesia, were liberalized. May 8. Permission would henceforth be given freely for residents to operate foreign currency accounts in banks out- side Malaysia. Previously, residents were not permitted to operate any account outside the Sterling Area without ex- change control approval, and such approval was given re- strictively. May 8. All nonresident controlled companies in Malaysia required exchange control approval to borrow in Malaysia in excess of M$500,000. Previously, all local borrowings by companies controlled by residents of non-Sterling Area countries required approval. May 8. The limitations on Indonesian and Indian currency notes which could be brought into Malaysia by travelers (Rp 3,000 and Rs 270 a person) were removed. Henceforth, currency notes of any country could be brought in without limit. Furthermore, permission was no longer required for the import of Indonesian and Indian currency notes. May 8. The restriction on fam i ly remittances to the Peo- ple's Republic of China to M$45 a month a family was abol- ished, and such remittances henceforth could be made through banks. May 8. A recording system was introduced under which an exchange control form had to be completed for each remit- tance above M$ 1,000. May 8. Malaysia terminated the currency interchangeabil- ity arrangements with Singapore. The Central Bank of Ma- laysia continued to accept Singapore dollars until August 7, at prevailing market rates. May 8. Malaysia announced its decision to set up a separate stock exchange for Malaysia. The market would remain closed un t il May 13, after which the trading rooms in Malay- sia and Singapore would operate independently. May 8. Restrictions were formally applied to the making of payments and transfers between residents of Malaysia and residents of South Africa and on exports to South Africa; they were identical with the restrictions applicable to Rhodesia. (On March 12, 1974, similar restrictions were applied to Israel.) May 8. Not for Redistribution MALI Exchange Rate System No par value for the currency of Mali has been established with the Fund. The official unit of currency is the Mali Franc, which is officially maintained at the rate of MF 1 = 0 . 01 French franc. There is also a fixed rate of MF 2 for CFA francs. Mali operates a dual exchange m a r k e tl for transactions with foreign countries, i.e., countries other than France (in- cluding its Overseas Departments and Territories except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. 2 Transactions for the follow- ing take place at exchange rates based on those ruling in the official exchange market in Paris: imports, exports, and most other current transactions, as well as all current payments by or in favor of domestic and foreign public authorities and public bodies. All other settlements with foreign countries as well as transactions in domestic and foreign banknotes take place at rates based on those ruling in the financial franc market in Paris. The principal current payments and receipts channeled through the financial franc market are those relat- ing to travel expenses, capital earnings, and workers' remit- tances. Administration of Control The Minister of Finance has sole authority in exchange control matters; certain exchange control powers have been delegated to authorized banks. The bilateral payments agree- ments are operated by the Development Bank of Mali. Li- censes for imports and exports are issued by the Directorate-General of Economic Affa irs in the Ministry of Finance. Exchange control is applicable only to foreign countries. Prescription of Currency Settlements on account of transactions covered by bilateral payments arrangements are made in currencies and through accounts established under such agreements. Bilateral ac- counts are maintained with the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Egypt, Hungary, Mo- rocco, Poland, Romania, Senegal, the U.S.S.R., and North V ie t -Nam .3 Mali is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since its Central Bank maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settlements w i th France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Ac- count countries of the French Franc Area are made in Mali francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with all other countries with which no payments agreement is in force are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the curren- 1 The dual exchange market was unified in March 1974 by the abolition of the financial franc market. 2 These are countries whose ins t i tu te of issue maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury: Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 3 The payments arrangements with Morocco and Senegal are inoperative. cies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign or Financial Accounts in Francs. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are, in principle, based on those applied in France. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few commodities are prohibited for health, safety, and similar reasons, and licenses are not normally issued for certain other goods. Imports of all other goods, irrespective of origin, require individual licenses, and imports from foreign countries must be domiciled w i th an authorized bank. Imports are licensed in accordance with an annual import program drawn up by the Malian authorities and subject to approval by a joint French-Malian Committee. The program consists of two parts: an allocation for clearing countries and one for the convertible area (defined as comprising all other countries, including the French Franc Area). Certain aid- financed imports are not included in the import program and do not require an import license. Imports may be made either by private importers or by state enterprises, among which the Societe Malienne de Tlmport-Export (SOMIEX) is by far the most important, hav- ing a monopoly over the import of a number of items. 4 All imports from and exports to countries that have payments agreements with Mali are made by SOMIEX or UNICOOP. An allocation commission establishes quotas for each pri- vate importer on the basis of his turnover and the number of his employees. Import licenses are issued to the private im- porter up to the limit of the quota accorded to him. In addi- tion, importers may w i th an import license import any goods under the EXIC (Exportation et Importation Concomitante) procedure. The authorized banks are permitted to make for- eign exchange available for all licensed imports. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above) and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to approval. Payments for invisibles related to trade are per- mitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been ap- proved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely. For tourist travel, residents traveling to countries other than France (as defined above) and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to MF 150,000 a person, which may be taken up twice a year; any foreign exchange remaining after return to Mali must be surren- dered. For business travel, there is a special allocation of the equivalent of MF 40,000 a day, subject to a maximum 4 These include cement, cigarettes, f lou r, m i lk, salt, soap, sugar, and tea. 291 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALI of MF 400,000 a t r ip .5 The transfer of the entire salary of a foreigner working in Mali is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period. Resident travel- ers going to foreign countries may take out up to a max imum of MF 50,000 in Mali banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries (MF 5,000 for trips of less than 24 hours). Travelers to other countries of the French Franc Area may take out MF 250,000 in Mali banknotes. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the amount declared by them on en try or up to MF 150,000 if no declaration was made. They may also take out MF 50,000 in Mali banknotes and any payments instru- ments drawn up abroad in their name. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank, and export proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Operations Account country must be surrendered; export proceeds must normally be collected and repatriated within 90 days after the arrival of the goods at their destination. Exports require individual licenses in order to ensure the repatriation of export proceeds. The export of cotton, groundnuts, hides, skins, and meat, which constitute most of the controlled export trade, is re- served for SOMIEX or other public or mixed enterprises. Under the EXIC procedure, exporters may retain 75 per cent of proceeds from exports of commodities of the tradi- tional sector except those covered by the monopoly of state trading companies, for payment for their own imports that are made through regular official channels. Balances on EXIC accounts and import rights under the EXIC procedure are not transferable. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above) and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered. Resident and nonresident travel- ers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the Central Bank of Mali, the Bank of France, or a bank of issue ma in ta in ing an Operations Account w i th the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and 5 Exchange for tourist travel purposes is made available on ly to persons s u bm i t t i ng an exit permit (autorisation de sortie) issued by the Security Services. coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. Capital Capital movements between Mali, France (as defined above), and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital trans- fers to all other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (in addition to any exchange control re- quirements that may be applicable) are maintained over bor- rowing abroad; the Development Bank of Mali is exempt. The special control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above) or to countries whose bank of issue is linked w i th the French Treasury by an Operations Ac- count. Under an Investment Code of May 23, 1969 and Law No. 62 of January 15, 1962, the Government may grant special privileged status, providing for transfer, tax, and other prefer- ential treatment to foreign investments that would be of spe- cial interest to the Malian economy and that are compatible with the goals of the Economic Plan. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Mali for numismatic purposes and for ornaments. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not nor- mally granted. Changes during 1973 February 13. Not for Redistribution MALTA Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Malta Pound, corresponding to £M 0.416667 = SDR 1. A central rate of 2.18613 grams of f ine gold per Malta pound has been established, corresponding to £M 0.406504 = SDR 1, and Malta avails itself of wider margins. As at the end of 1973, the prescribed margins were not, for the time being, being observed, and the Central Bank quoted daily rates for sterling based on developments in the principal exchange markets abroad. The Central Bank of Malta's basic rate for the pound sterling on December 31, 1973 was £ stg. 111.625 buying, and £ stg. 111.375 selling, per £M 100. Commercial bank rates for non-Sterling Area currencies are based on London market rates for sterling against other currencies. The banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1973 were US$2.5889 and US$2.5831 per £M 1. Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Central Bank as agent for the Minister of Finance and Customs; trade controls are administered by the Director of Trade in the Ministry of Trade, Indus try, Agriculture, and Tourism. Certain authori- ties to approve applications for the allocation of foreign ex- change have been delegated to the authorized banks. Prescription of Currency Malta has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Authorized pay- ments to all countries may be made by crediting Malta pounds to an External Account or in any foreign currency, * the proceeds of exports to all countries may be received in Malta pounds from an External Account or in any foreign currency. Nonresident Accounts Residents of all countries outside Malta may maintain with authorized banks nonresident accounts in Malta pounds, des- ignated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited freely with authorized payments by nonresidents, with trans- fers from other External Accounts, w i th the proceeds from sales of gold or any foreign currency (including banknotes), and with Malta banknotes mailed from outside Malta. Exter- nal Accounts may be debited freely for payments to residents, for transfers to other External Accounts, for payments in cash in Malta, and for purchases of any foreign currency (including banknotes). Blocked Accounts are maintained for nonresidents of Malta for certain funds of a capital nature which, under the existing exchange control regulations, may not be transferred outside Malta. The principal type of funds that must be cred- ited to a Blocked Account are assets of emigrants in excess 1 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than the Malta pound. of £M 5,000, for each family, that may be transferred to the new coun try of residence; the remaining funds are normally released four years after the date of departure on application to the Central Bank. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain commodities manufactured in Malta are either prohibited or restricted. All imports from Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, North Korea, Poland, Rhodesia, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and North Viet-Nam are subject to specific licensing, as are im- ports of some 90 items from any country of origin. Imports from countries other than those mentioned that are not pro- hibited and do not require a specific license may be freely imported under open general license. Payments for all autho- rized imports may be made freely, provided that the prescrip- tion of currency regulations are complied with and that supporting documents, including the customs entry form, are submitted to the intermediary bank. Advance payments for imports may be made against the invoice if the goods are to arrive within six months but otherwise require Central Bank approval. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles in excess of £M 50 require the approval of the exchange control authorities; the approval authority has been delegated to authorized banks for certain types of payment. There is a standard exchange allocation for tourist travel of the equivalent of £M 250 a person a trip; a business travel allowance of £M 250 or £M 20 a day (for up to 30 days a trip), whichever is the larger; and an allowance for educational expenses abroad of £M 2,000 a person for an academic year. 2 Applications for allowances in excess of these amounts are approved by the Central Bank if the latter is satisfied that there is no illicit capital outflow involved. The transfer of genuine profits, dividends, and interest for ap- proved foreign investments requires Central Bank permis- sion, which is normally given, after compliance with certain formalities. Life insurance may not be contracted with insur- ers resident in non-Sterling Area countries. Maintenance re- mittances to beneficiaries abroad are allowed on application accompanied by documentary evidence of hardship; autho- rized banks may also approve moderate remittances for fam- ily living expenses. Travelers may export Malta banknotes and coins up to £M 25 for each person. Exports of foreign currencies may be made by resident travelers up to £M 250 for each person and by nonresident travelers up to the amount brought in. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of works of art and strategic war materials are prohibited and, with the exception of some 80 items that may 2 For purposes of exchange allocations for travel and study, residents are defined as physical persons who are at the time living in Malta in the normal course and either have so lived for at least three years or intend to continue so living for at least three years. 293 ©International Monetary Fund. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Travelers may bring in any amount in Malta and other currency notes. Capital No control is exercised over receipts. Receipts in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank, and payments of a capital na ture in such currencies require prior approval. Applications for outward direct investment by resi- dents of Malta and for direct investment in Malta by nonresi- dents are considered on their merits. The purchase of real estate in Malta by nonresidents through a resident procurator requires exchange control approval but is normally not re- stricted; such purchases by foreign nationals tak ing up per- manent residence in Malta after November 14, 1972 are restricted to the dwelling they live in. Purchases of all securi- ties issued outside Malta require prior permission from the authorities. However, permission is normally granted by the Central Bank for the acquisition of securities abroad up to the equivalent of £M 500 a person a calendar year (for persons over 18). Purchases of personal real estate situated outside Malta require prior exchange control approval and are not normally permitted to resident nationals. Foreign nationals who repatriate or take up residence out- side Malta normally are allowed to transfer all their assets to their new country of residence; in certain circumstances, how- ever, restrictions may be placed on foreign assets acquired, other than by way of income or capital appreciation, while the person has been resident in Malta. Maltese nationals who emigrate may transfer abroad up to £M 5,000 for each fam i ly; any excess amount is normally released four years after the date of departure on application to the Central Bank. Banks, other than those licensed to borrow and lend out- side Malta only, are restricted in the acquisition of net foreign assets. Gold Residents other than authorized banks and registered jew- elers are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than coins or jewelry, at home or abroad. Residents may freely purchase, sell, and hold any gold coins. Authorized dealers in gold are permitted to import gold coins for numis- matic purposes from virtually any country. A specific import license is required for imports of gold coins, gold bullion, and manufactured or semimanufactured articles of gold; imports of filigree work of gold or silver are prohibited. Authorized importers are permitted to import gold (bullion and coins) only for the purpose of disposing of it to jewelers and other industrial users. The export of gold by residents other than the monetary authorities requires the permission of the ex- change control authorities. Gold bullion and gold coins are free of import du ty. 294 Changes during 1973 During the year a number of items in addition to those specified below were added to the list of commodities requir- ing specific import licenses. January 30. The distribution began of four legal tender gold coins in denominations of £M 5, £M 10, £M 20, and £M 50. January 31. It was announced that a substantial degree of diversification of Malta's external reserves had been effected. February 1. The prohibition on outward portfolio invest- ment by resident private individuals was revoked. The Cen- tral Bank announced that it was prepared to approve all applications for the purchase of foreign exchange to be in- vested abroad w i th in the equivalent of £M 500 a person over 18 years of age a calendar year, provided these investments were du ly registered w i th the Central Bank. Holders of for- eign currency securities no longer required prior exchange control approval to switch these in to other foreign currency securities. Authorized dealers were empowered to approve such switches, as well as transfers and sales of foreign cur- rency securities and the investment abroad of income arising out of foreign investments already held. February 1. The Exchange Control Act, 1972 (Act. No. XL IX, enacted on December 27, 1972) came into force. It replaced the Exchange Control Ordinance, 1959. The Act designated all currencies other than the Malta pound as for- eign currencies, defined all persons not resident in Malta as nonresidents, and provided a new definition of "residents." Hence, all provisions of the law had global application. Thus, export proceeds received in Sterling Area currencies became subject to surrender requirements, and existing exchange al- locations for countries outside the Sterling Area became ap- plicable also to the Sterling Area. (Previously, a distinction was made between Scheduled Territories and the rest of the world; the Scheduled Territories under Malta's former ex- change control regulations were the territories of the Sterling Area, Rhodesia, and the Libyan Arab Republic, and foreign currencies were defined as all non-Sterling Area currencies). The Act also gave force of law to a previously existing administrative arrangement by prohibiting any restriction on payments in respect of (1) any sums realized from the sale or liquidation of any property in Malta acquired w i th funds originally brought from outside Malta and invested in such property by persons who were nonresidents at the time of the investment, and (2) any sums originally brought from outside Malta by a person who was not a citizen of Malta, when the payment was made upon such person leaving Malta to take up residence elsewhere. The Act introduced reporting requirements in respect of residents' foreign assets. Exempt were persons in Malta hold- ing a valid resident permit in terms of the Imm igra t ion Act, 1970. Such persons were also exempt from the requirement that residents obtain prior permission for all foreign invest- ment. February 1. Three commercial banks were appointed as authorized dealers. A fou r th bank was appointed on Febru- ary 19. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALTA February 13. A bill was introduced to empower the Minis- ter of Finance and Customs to act in accordance with the terms of international agreements entered into by Malta in respect of outward transfers of nonresident-owned capital invested in Malta. The resulting Exchange Control (Amend- ment) Act, 1973 was enacted on May 30 and came in to force on June 8 (see below). March 1. The Minister for Finance and Customs appointed the Central Bank, with effect from February 1, as his agent for purposes of the Exchange Control Act. March 20. Following the announcement that the U.S. dol- lar was being devalued and the reopening of major foreign exchange markets abroad, it was announced that the Malta pound would continue to float; its value would continue to be determined at a level between that of sterling and that of the currencies of the other major trading partners. June 8. Section 9 of the Exchange Control Act was amended. The amendment had the effect that exchange con- trol permission would not be withheld (except insofar as the w i thho ld ing of permission was necessary to give effect to an international agreement, treaty, or convention to which Malta is a party) for the repatriation of foreign capital in- vested in Malta by persons who were nonresidents at the time of the investment or of any sums brought in by noncitizens, when leaving Malta to take up residence elsewhere. July 23. The Development Loan Act, 1972 was amended so as to authorize the Government to borrow not only from foreign governments but also from international or foreign organizations, funds, or other institutions.
