Not for Redistribution MAURITANIA Exchange System No par value for the currency of Mauritania has been established with the Fund. The un it of currency is the Ou- guiya, which is defined as equivalent to 0.016 gram of f ine gold, corresponding to UM 1 = SDR 0.0180044. Ade facto fixed relationship is maintained w i th the French franc, the CFA franc issued by the BCEAO, and the Mali franc, at UM 1 = F 0.10, UM 1 = CFAF 5, and UM 1 = MF 10, respectively. 1 Exchange rates for currencies of countries out- side the French Franc Area are based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the rate of the currency concerned in the official exchange market in Paris. The Central Bank of Mauritania quotes daily buying and selling rates for 17 cur- rencies. 2 The same buy ing and selling rates are applied by the authorized banks. French francs, CFA francs, and Mali francs are purchased at their parity and sold w i th a commis- sion of 1 per cent. Administration of Control Exchange control au thor i ty is vested in the Central Bank and the Minister of Finance and Commerce. The former also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or of- fering for sale of foreign securities in Mauritania, inward direct investment and all outward investment, the purchase abroad of domestic and foreign securities, and the solicitation of funds in Mauritania for placement in foreign countries. The approval au thor i ty in respect of exchange control has been delegated to the Central Bank, which in tu rn has delegated some approval au thor i ty to authorized banks. The Central Bank is authorized to collect, either direct or through the intermediary of the banks and the Postal Adm in is tra t ion, any information necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. All exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks. Import and export licenses are issued by the Foreign Trade Depart- ment in the Ministry of Finance and Commerce, which also issues import certificates for liberalized commodities and ex- port certificates. All import licenses and import certificates require exchange control approval by the Central Bank. The National Import and Export Corporation (SONIMEX) has a monopoly over imports of sugar, tea, rice, and certain textiles and over exports of gum arabic. Prescription of Currency All settlements w i th Israel, Portugal, and South Africa are prohibited. Settlements w i th other countries usually take place in convertible currencies. Nonresident Accounts There are two k inds of nonresident accounts: Convertible Accounts, which may only be credited w i th proceeds from the 1 These fixed relationships were terminated on Janua ry 22, 1974. 2 Aus tr ian schillings, Belgian francs, CFA francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Mali francs, Ne ther lands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 296 sale of foreign currency or transfers from other Convertible Accounts, and Internal Nonresident Accounts, which may be credited w i th domestic banknotes. Convertible Accounts may be debited w i thout Central Bank approval for any pay- ment inside or outside Mauritania. Imports and Import Payments Imports of Israel, Portuguese, and South African origin a n d / or provenance are prohibited. The import of a few goods is prohibited f rom any source for reasons of health or public policy. Most imports are admitted in accordance with an annual import program. Imports from all countries require an import license. Only holders of importer-exporter cards are permitted to engage in import transactions. SONIMEX has a monopoly over the import of sugar, rice, green tea, percales, and Guinea cloth. Import transactions relating to countries of the French Franc Area must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds UM 20,000, and import transactions re- la t ing to other foreign countries when their value exceeds UM 4,000. A f ter the approval of the Central Bank has been obtained, the import license or import certificate entitles the importer to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the com- modities have already been imported. Advance payments for imports require prior approval by the Central Bank. Payments for Invisibles Payments to Israel, Portugal, and South Africa are prohib- ited. Payments for invisibles to other countries are subject to the approval of the Central Bank, which has delegated its approval authority for certain specified payments and subject to conditions laid down in circulars, to authorized banks. For tourist and business travel, residents traveling to any foreign country may obtain an annual exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to UM 10,000 a person (UM 5,000 for children under ten). For business travel, a higher allocation may be granted only w i th special authorization by the Central Bank. The use of all travel allocations must be marked in a personal travel exchange booklet. The transfer of savings from salaries by foreigners work ing in Mauritania is permit- ted in accordance with agreements with their country of ori- gin for technical assistants, and according to family status for the others. Travelers are not allowed to take out domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel, Portugal, and South Africa are pro- hibited. Only holders of importer-exporter cards are permit- ted to engage in export transactions. Export transactions to all countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds UM 5,000. Exporters must sign an unde r tak ing to repatriate and surrender the foreign exchange proceeds. Exports to all countries require an export license or ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution an export attestation. Export proceeds must be surrendered by sale on the exchange market not later than the due date of the payment, which must not normally be more than 60 days after shipment. Exports of gum arabic are the monopoly of SONIMEX. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles must be surren- dered. All amounts due from nonresidents in respect of ser- vices and all income earned abroad from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered w i th in two mon ths of the due date of the payment. The importation of domestic banknotes by travelers is prohibited. Capital Transfers of capital between Mauritania and Israel, Portu- gal, and South Africa are prohibited. Capital movements between Mauritania and all foreign countries are subject to exchange control; capital transfers to all countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital re- ceipts normally are permitted freely, although the subsequent investment of the funds in Mauritania may require approval, as indicated below. Special controls (additional to any exchange control re- quirements that may be applicable) are maintained over bor- rowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, over the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Mauritania, and over the solici- tation of funds in Mauritania for placement in foreign countries; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. All investments abroad by residents of Mauritania require prior authorization by the Central Bank. Foreign direct in- vestments in Mauritania 3 and Mauritania direct investments abroad, 4 must be declared to the Central Bank before they are made. The Central Bank has a period of two months f rom receipt of the declaration during which it may request the postponement of the projects submitted to it. The full or partial liquidation of inward or outward investment also re- quires declaration. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Mauritanian investments abroad or foreign investments in Mauritania, must be re- ported to the Central Bank w i th in 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments im- plying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign secu- rities in Mauritania requires prior authorization by the Cen- tral Bank. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection with loans backed by a guarantee from the Mauritanian Government. 3 Inc lud ing those made by companies in Mauritania that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Mauritania of foreign companies. 4 Inc lud ing those made through the intermediary of foreign companies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Mauritania and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Mauritania. MAURITANIA Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Central Bank. The following are, how- ever, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans contracted by authorized banks; and (3) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed UM 10 million for any one bor- rower and provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authori- zation of the Central Bank if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Furthermore, such prior approval is required for the repayment of all amounts borrowed abroad prior to the publication of Decree No. 72.249 of November 27, 1972. Lending abroad is subject only to exchange control autho- rization. Domestic bank credit is restricted. The Investment Code (Law No. 71-028 of February 2, 1971) provides for various benefits for private investments in Mauritania. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Mauritania. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the Cen- tral Bank. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by the Central Bank, (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles containing a minor quan t i ty of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles), and (3) imports and exports by travelers of certain gold articles. The new economic and financial agreement provided that with respect to trade France would no longer be granted preferential treatment but would be treated like any other member country of the EEC. March 19. Not for Redistribution MAURITIUS Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.159961 gram of fine gold per Mauritian Rupee, corresponding to Mau Rs 5.55555 = SDR 1. No transactions take place at the par value. The official rate for sterling is Mau Re 1 = £ stg. 0.075, and the currency issuing authority, the Bank of Mauritius, maintains fixed rates for sterling of Mau Rs 13.31% buying, and Mau Rs 13.36% selling, per £ stg. 1. Consequently, the Mauritian rupee is floating with sterling, and all exchange transactions except those in sterling or currencies linked to sterling take place at fluctuating rates. Commercial banks are authorized to deal with customers in sterling at spot rates based on the rates of the Bank of Mauritius and in other foreign currencies * at rates based on the London market rates. The commercial banks' rates for sterling on December 31, 1973 were Mau Rs 13.25 buying and Mau Rs 13.40 selling per £ stg. 1, and for the U.S. dollar the rates were Mau Rs 5.71 buy ing and Mau Rs 5.82 selling (for transactions in excess of US$12,000). A different effective rate results from the application of a stamp du ty of 35.70 per cent to outward capital transfers other than transfers of banking funds and to payments for gold coins and gold bullion. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Mauritius under powers delegated to it by the Financial Secretary. The authority for approving practically all current payments is in turn delegated to the commercial banks. The M in is try of Commerce and Indus try is responsible for the issue of import and export licenses, where required. Prescription of Currency Mauritius has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. For prescription of currency purposes Mauritius distinguishes between Ster- ling Area countries 2 and External Account countries. Pay- ments to residents of Sterling Area countries may be made in rupees to a Sterling Area Account in Mauritius or in any Sterling Area currency. Payments from residents of the Ster- ling Area may be received in rupees from a Sterling Area Account in Mauritius or in any currency of the Sterling Area. Payments to residents of countries outside the Sterling Area may be made in rupees to a Sterling Area Account or an External Account in Mauritius, in sterling to an External Account in the United Kingdom, or in any non-Sterling Area currency other than Rhodesian currency. Payments from resi- dents of countries outside the Sterling Area may be received in rupees from an External Account in Mauritius, in sterling 1 The exchange control regulations of Mauritius define foreign currencies as all currencies other than the Mauritian rupee. 2 The exchange control regulations of Mauritius define the Sterling Area as comprising the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, and the Republic of Ireland. from an External Account in the United Kingdom, or in any non-Sterling Area currency other than Rhodesian currency. Special regulations apply to settlements w i th Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts There are two main types of nonresident accounts: Sterling Area Accounts and External Accounts. Sterling Area Accounts, which may be opened by persons and firms resident in countries of the Sterling Area (see foot- note 2), may be credited w i th (1) authorized payments by residents of Mauritius; (2) any transfers from other Sterling Area Accounts; (3) any payments from External Accounts held in Mauritius or elsewhere in the Sterling Area; and (4) the proceeds of the sale to an authorized dealer of any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or gold by nonresi- dents of Mauritius. They may be debited for (1) payments from residents of the Sterling Area to residents of Mauritius; (2) transfers to other Sterling Area Accounts; (3) transfers to External Accounts in Maur i t ius or elsewhere in the Sterling Area in respect of which the permission of the exchange control authorities in the appropriate Sterling Area coun try has been given; and (4) the cost of purchase of any Sterling Area currency. External Accounts may be opened by persons and firms resident outside both Mauritius and the Sterling Area. They may be credited with (1) authorized payments by residents of Mauritius; (2) payments from Sterling Area Accounts in re- spect of which the permission of the exchange control author- ities of the appropriate Sterling Area country has been given; (3) any transfers from other External Accounts; and (4) the proceeds of the sale to an authorized dealer of any non-Ster- ling Area currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or gold by nonresidents of Mauritius and the Sterling Area. They may be debited for (1) any payments to residents of Mauri- tius; (2) any transfers to Sterling Area Accounts; (3) any transfers to other External Accounts; and (4) the cost of purchase of any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian cur- rency) or gold. In addition to the above, there are also Blocked Accounts to which are credited funds owned by persons and firms resident outside Mauritius realized from investments made by them prior to April 5, 1966, as well as funds representing emigrants' assets in excess of Mau Rs 67,000. Such accounts may be credited w i th payments by residents of Maur i t ius that have been specifically authorized for credit to a Blocked Ac- count and may be debited for certain specified transactions. Funds from Blocked Accounts may, with approval, be in- vested in Mauritius. Upon the realization of such invest- ments, the proceeds are directed once more to a Blocked Account. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. There is a list of commodities for which a specific license from the Ministry of Commerce and Indus t ry is required regardless of origin. All 299 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAURITIUS other goods may be freely imported under open general li- censes granted to individual traders when imported from countries of the Sterling Area (as defined before June 23, 1972), but most of these goods require a specific license when imported from non-Sterling Area countries. General licenses are granted liberally. Specific licenses are issued on the basis of domestic requirements. The issue of a general or specific license automatically carries with it exchange control author- ity to make the corresponding import payments, subject to compliance w i th the prescription of currency regulations. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for certain other purposes such as travel, is provided by the commercial banks without prior reference to the exchange control authorities. The basic travel allow- ance for tourist purposes is the equivalent of £250 a person a year for travel to any country in the world except Rhodesia. The allowance for business travel purposes is the equivalent of £250 a tr ip or £20 a day up to a maximum of £1,000 a trip for travel to countries of the Sterling Area (as defined before June 23, 1972), or up to a total of £750 a trip for travel to countries outside the Sterling Area. Applications for ex- change for business travel are examined by the Bank of Mau- ritius when exceeding the equivalent of £250 a person a trip. There are also established limits for payments and transfers to Sterling Area countries and to non-Sterling Area countries in respect of fam i ly support, salary remittances by non-Mau- ritian nationals, trade commissions, subscriptions to clubs and societies, publishing rights, advertising outside Mauri- tius, royalties, professional and technical services, education, and leave salaries. Applications for amounts exceeding the standard allocations may be submitted to the exchange con- trol authorities. Residents and nonresident travelers may take out Mau Rs 350 in domestic currency. Resident travelers may take out foreign currency notes up to the amount of their travel allow- ance. Nonresident travelers may take out any foreign cur- rency declared upon en t ry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Also prohibited, un- less permission is obtained from the Financial Secretary, are exports of (1) articles made wholly or partially of gold, plati- num, or silver; (2) diamonds, precious and semiprecious stones, pearls, and articles mounted with these; and (3) works of art. All exports valued at more than Mau Rs 1,000 and all exports of food valued at over Mau Rs 50 require a license from the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. The Mauritius Sugar Syndicate is the sole exporter of sugar, and a 6-9 per cent export tax is levied on sugar exports. All export proceeds in any currency other than Mauritian rupees must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer. However, permission may be given to large export-import companies to retain export pro- ceeds for a reasonable period of time to meet payments for imports. 300 Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any currency other than Mauri- tian rupees must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes and coins that may be imported, but not more than Mau Rs 700 in domestic currency notes and coins may be imported by travelers. Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted. Outward transfers of capital are subject to certain restrictions. Non- bank residents of Mauritius may transfer a reasonable amount of capital to any country in the Sterling Area (as defined in footnote 2) on payment of a 35.70 per cent stamp du ty (a du ty of 34 per cent plus a surcharge of 5 per cent thereon); they may, subject to permission, which is freely granted, also transfer a reasonable amount of capital to Ex- ternal Account Area countries on payment of the stamp duty. Nonresidents require permission to transfer capital to any country; transfers are subject to the payment of stamp duty at the rate of 35.70 per cent and, if directed toward a country outside the Sterling Area by a resident of the Sterling Area, require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities of the Sterling Area coun try concerned. Foreign-owned com- panies may freely transfer abroad dividends, profits, and in- terest on capital. Permission for the repatriation of capital is not granted for capital brought in before April 5, 1966, irre- spective of the country of origin, but is, in normal circum- stances, given for capital brought in on or after that date. Proceeds from the sale, liquidation, etc., of foreign capital that may not be repatriated must be credited to Blocked Accounts. Emigrants may take out, at the official rate of exchange and free of stamp du ty, the equivalent of Mau Rs 67,000 from their Mauritian assets when emigrating to any country except Rhodesia; this facility is available upon redesignation as a nonresident, which occurs upon departure. The balance of an emigrant's funds must be credited for an indefinite period to a Blocked Account; any releases that may be approved for transfer abroad are subject to payment of the 35.70 per cent stamp du ty. Persons emigrating from Mauritius are not enti- tled to draw their personal travel allowance in addition to the emigration facilities. Gold Residents other than the monetary authorities are permit- ted to hold gold in the form of numismatic coins (including a commemorative gold coin of Mau Rs 200 issued by Mauri- tius in 1971) or personal jewelry and ornaments. The import and export of monetary gold are prohibited, except when made by the monetary authorities. Imports of gold for indus- trial purposes are subject to a quota and specific import license. Exports of articles made wholly or partially of gold, other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a trav- eler, are prohibited. Payments in respect of private imports of gold coins and gold bullion are subject to the 35.70 per cent stamp du ty. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0589330 gram of fine gold per Mexican Peso, corresponding to Mex$ 15.0793 = SDR 1 or Mex$12.50 = US$1. Banks may freely engage in exchange transactions between the peso and any other currency. There are limited forward facilities for Mexican pesos. On November 12, 1946, Mexico notified the Fund that it was prepared to formally accept the obligations of Arti- cle V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Prescription of Currency No obligations prescribing the method or currency for pay- ments to or from nonresidents are imposed on importers, exporters, or others. In accordance with payments agree- ments with Hungary, Poland, and Yugoslavia, payments for direct commercial transactions and related expenses with those countries handled through the Mexican banking system may, with the prior authorization of the Bank of Mexico, be made through special accounts denominated in U.S. dollars. Payments between Mexico and Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, and Venezuela may be settled through accounts maintained with each other by the Bank of Mexico and the central banks concerned, within the framework of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system. Payments to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guate- mala, Honduras, and Nicaragua in respect of trade and invisi- bles may be settled in Mexican pesos or Central American currencies in accordance with the reciprocal credit agreement between the central banks of those countries. Imports and Import Payments Payments and transfers abroad may be made freely. A few imports are prohibited. All imports must be accompanied by an exporter's declaration of shipment. For a considerable number of items, import licenses from the Ministry of Indus- try and Trade are required before firm orders are placed; the issuance of such licenses may be subject to quantitative re- striction, but most of the items concerned do not require an import license when they originate in LAFTA countries. For specified commodities, "open end" import licenses (permisos abiertos) may be granted that permit limited importation dur- ing a specified period of time, such as six months or a year; subject to screening of the importer's performance, repeated renewal of the license is possible. Applications for import licenses are screened by the Ministry of Industry and Trade with the aid of committees composed of importers, produc- ers, and consumers. Import licenses for certain goods, includ- ing leather goods, alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, and automobiles and their spare parts, are subject to an overall annual limit. Imports of certain goods for which licenses from the Ministry of Industry and Trade are required (such as unassembled automobiles and trucks, iron and steel pipe, 302 firearms, watches, synthetic fibers, some types of jewelry, radio and television sets, and whiskey, wines, and other li- quors) are subject to the payment of a fee of usually between 1 per cent and 6 per cent of the value of the import transac- tions, the proceeds of which are allocated to a fund handled by the Mexican Foreign Trade Institute (I MCE) for the pro- motion of exports. Imports by official Mexican agencies are subject to prior approval by the Mexican Foreign Trade Insti- tute; this approval is not given if a reasonably competitive domestic equivalent is available at a price differential of 15- 20 per cent. Many nonessential imports are subject to an import surcharge of 10 per cent ad valorem, the proceeds of which accrue to an export trust fund the Federal Government has established in the Bank of Mexico. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are not restricted. The contracting of insurance for persons in Mexico, or on property of Mexican ownership, or where the risks are for the account of persons in Mexico or may occur in Mexico, is permitted with Mexican companies or with branches of foreign companies established in Mexico in accordance w i th Mexican law. Exports and Export Proceeds Certain exports require licenses. No exchange control re- quirements apply to the proceeds of exports. Tax remission is granted on exports of certain manufactured and semimanu- factured products, provided that at least 50 per cent of the direct cost of production is of Mexican origin and that they are on a list of products authorized by the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit. Certain exports are granted rebates of indirect taxes by means of a system of CEDIs (certificados de devolution de impuestos). Proceeds from Invisibles No exchange control requirements apply to proceeds from invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents. New for- eign investment, other than by private individuals, in the capital of Mexican banking or insurance companies and in- vestment funds is prohibited. Certain sectors, such as petro- leum, basic petrochemical production, radioactive minerals, electricity and nuclear energy, certain mining activities, rail- roads, and telecommunications, are reserved to government investment. Investment in a number of activities is reserved exclusively for Mexican individuals or corporations (radio and television, the public transportation system, forestry, etc., as well as any other areas specified by the Federal Gov- ernment), while new investments in other sectors must have a majority participation of Mexican capital. Foreign invest- ments in Mexico must be registered with the National For- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution etgn Investment Register in the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. Applications by foreign physical or juridical per- sons to acquire more than 25 per cent of the capital of a Mexican company, or over 49 per cent of its fixed assets, require the prior authorization of the competent ministry, after the National Foreign Investment Commission has granted the necessary registration. Borrowing abroad (or within Mexico in foreign currency) by the public sector and by state-owned banks is subject to approval by the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit. Borrowing abroad by private banks is subject to approval by the Bank of Mexico. Gold Domestic transactions in nonmonetary gold are limited to purchases of gold bars by licensed goldsmiths or manufactur- ers. With this exception, residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Mexico or abroad. The Bank of Mexico does not buy or sell gold in transactions with private banks, individuals, or firms. There is a 15 per cent tax on "first hand" sales of newly mined gold. Producers of gold undertaking not to sell it at prices exceeding international quotations plus normal marketing costs are eligible for a subsidy corresponding to the full 15 per cent tax, when selling newly mined gold in Mexico to private banks reselling such gold to licensed goldsmiths or manufacturers in Mexico. Ex- ports of gold are prohibited unless they are made by the Bank of Mexico. Imports of gold are permitted and when licensed by the Bank of Mexico are free of customs duty. Changes during 1973 January 1. The income tax on fixed-income securities of the banking system was modified to increase rates on bearer securities and administration contracts while rates on nomi- native administration contracts were maintained; as a result, interest payable to foreign creditors other than international agencies became subject to tax at a rate of 10 per cent. The withholding tax on interest earned by registered foreign fi- nancial institutions remained at 10 per cent. January 30. A Law for the Registration of Transfer of Technology and Use and Exploitation of Patents and Trade- marks (issued by a decree of December 30, 1972) came into force. Companies domiciled in Mexico were required to regis- ter with a National Register of Technology Transfer in the Ministry of Industry and Commerce all agreements on the use of foreign trademarks and patents and all forms of techni- cal assistance. Registration could be refused under certain circumstances. February 2. The tax rebate granted in the form of CEDIs on exports of manufactured goods (with at least 60 per cent of the direct cost of production of Mexican origin) was in- creased from 10 per cent to 11 per cent; when registered foreign trade firms took part in the export transaction, an extra 4 per cent was granted. February 13. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the Bank of Mexico maintained its official buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar unchanged at Mex$ 12.49 and Mex$ 12.51, respectively. MEXICO May 8. A Law to Promote Mexican Investment and Regu- late Foreign Investment (issued by a decree of March 9, 1973) came into force. The law regulated foreign investment in Mexico, in part by consolidating existing legislation, and cre- ated a National Foreign Investment Register in the Ministry of Indus try and Commerce, as well as a National Foreign Investment Commission. Applications by foreign companies or individuals to acquire more than 25 per cent of a Mexican company's capital, or over 49 per cent of its fixed assets, required authorization by the ministry concerned, after the Commission had granted registration. Foreign participation would, in principle, be limited to 49 per cent even in previ- ously unrestricted activities, but the Commission was em- powered to grant exceptions for investment in certain areas and economic sectors. All shares held in Mexican companies by foreigners must be nominative, and existing bearer shares in companies with a majority of foreign capital must, within 180 days of the law coming into force, be converted into nominative shares. An investment was regarded as foreign also when made by Mexican companies in which a majority of the capital was foreign owned, or by Mexican businesses in which foreigners had the right to control their manage- ment. June 21. A Presidential Decree was issued regulating the operations of development corporations. These corporations would be active in acquiring shares in foreign-owned indus- trial companies. Shareholdings in development corporations were restricted to Mexican citizens. July 11. The National Foreign Investment Commission exempted in-bond industries (maquiladoras) from the re- quirement of 51 per cent Mexican ownership. It announced that border industries (in-bond plants, manufacturing or pro- cessing goods exclusively for export) could continue to be partially or wholly foreign owned; partially foreign-owned companies would be allowed to increase their capital pro- vided that the ratio of foreign to domestic share ownership existing when the Foreign Investment Law came into force, remained unchanged. August 20. The reserve requirements for deposit banks were increased. At the same time, those located in northern border areas were authorized to accept time deposits denominated in U.S. dollars of 90 or 180 days' maturity, but only from for- eign nationals and from residents of the district where the bank concerned was located. September 12. Mexico decided to participate fully, as an observer, in the multilateral trade negotiations of the GATT. October 17. The par value was changed from 0.0654810 gram to 0.0589330 gram of fine gold per Mexican peso. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar remained un- changed at Mex$12.50 = US$1. Mexico did not avail itself of wider margins. October 20. Purchases of Mexican shares by foreign physi- cal or juridical persons henceforth could only be made on the stock exchange; any individual purchase could not exceed 5 per cent of the equity capital of the company concerned. November 2 7. The Bank of Mexico issued guidelines for the credit operations of banks and other financial institutions. Companies having external credit lines would be permitted to 303 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO borrow domestically only after the credit needs of other prior- ity sectors had been satisfied. December 29. Regulations were issued providing for the establishment of a National Foreign Investors Registry; they came into effect on February 12, 1974. Any foreign physical or juridical person acquiring stock in a Mexican company, whether on a stock exchange or otherwise, and any Mexican company selling its shares to a foreign physical or juridical person, were required to register the transaction within 30 days thereafter. 304 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.175610 gram of fine gold per Moroccan Dirham, corresponding to DH 5.06049 = SDR 1. However, no transactions take place at the par value. The Bank of Morocco quotes daily buying and selling rates for the com- mercial French franc and the financial French franc; its rate for the commercial franc is determined in the light of quota- tions for certain major currencies on the official exchange market in Paris and taking into account the geographic distri- bution of Morocco's foreign trade transactions. The Bank of Morocco also quotes buying and selling rates for specified "convertible currencies," l based on quotations in the leading foreign exchange markets abroad and the Bank of Moroc- co's daily quotation for the commercial French franc. The rates of the Bank of Morocco for the U.S. dollar on Decem- ber 31,1973 were DH 4.2802 buying, and DH 4.2996 selling, per US$1, and those for the commercial French franc were DH 0.90973 buying, and DH 0.91247 selling, per F 1. All sales and purchases of foreign currency are centralized in the Bank of Morocco, but the authorized banks are permit- ted to marry (offset) their purchases and sales on behalf of their private customers in each currency separately. The au- thorized banks must purchase from or sell to the Bank of Morocco each day, at the rates communicated to them by the Bank, the balances of their purchases and sales in each cur- rency; compensation between banks is not permitted so that no foreign exchange market exists in Morocco. The Bank of Morocco makes its own purchases and sales of foreign cur- rency in exchange markets abroad. The Bank of Morocco also establishes buying and selling rates for transactions with trav- elers in banknotes, travelers checks, and letters of credit ex- pressed in French francs, CFA francs, and the "convertible currencies"; the authorized banks sell to the Bank of Morocco their excess holdings of banknotes and replenish them at the Bank whenever necessary. Forward exchange transactions are not permitted. Foreign currency repatriated in the form of bank or postal transfers by Moroccan workers abroad is eligible for a pre- mium of 5 per cent payable on the dirham equivalent. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Exchange Office, an agency under the Ministry of Finance. This Office has delegated the execution of certain exchange control measures to authorized banks. Import certificates and export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Commerce; they must be coun- tersigned by the Moroccan Exchange Office. Import commit- ments for liberalized goods are signed by the importer himself; they do not require the visa of the Exchange Office unless the country of origin of the goods is not the country of shipment, or the goods are bought on a c.i.f. basis. A part of the port of Tangier is designated as a free trade zone and 'Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portu- guese escudos, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. is exempt from taxation and from trade, customs, and ex- change control. Prescription of Currency Although Morocco's regulations still make a distinction between the French Franc Area and the so-called area of convertibility, Morocco applies exchange control also to transactions with the former. 2 For prescription of currency purposes, countries are classified as follows: (1) the French Franc Area countries; (2) the payments agreement group, comprising countries with which Morocco maintains bilateral payments agreements; 3 and (3) all other countries, the so-called area of convertibility. Settlements with the French Franc Area are made in French francs or, with the exception of settlements for im- ports, in dirhams through French Franc Area Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, below); certain noncom- mercial settlements with Algeria and Tunisia, however, are made in dirhams, Algerian dinars, and Tunisian dinars through special accounts at the three central banks. Settle- ments with the payments agreement group are made by debit- ing or crediting the payments agreements accounts established for this purpose. Imports originating in countries in the area of convertibility may be paid for only in "converti- ble currencies" negotiated by the Bank of Morocco (see foot- note 1). Other settlements with countries in the area of convertibility may be made only in "convertible currencies" negotiated by the Bank of Morocco or through Foreign Ac- counts in Convertible Dirhams. When settlements between Morocco and the French Franc Area take place in French francs, the Bank of Morocco ap- plies its daily quotation for the commercial French franc when the transaction passes through the French official ex- change market, and its daily quotation for the financial French franc when the transaction passes through the finan- cial market in France. Nonresident Accounts The various types of nonresident accounts are as follows: 1. French Franc Area Accounts are held in Moroccan cur- rency by residents of countries of the French Franc Area. These accounts may be used for settlements with residents of countries in the French Franc Area, except for the payment for imports (and related invisibles) from those countries. 4 They may be freely credited with and debited for sales or purchases of financial French francs (except banknotes) sold to or bought from the Bank of Morocco. Transfers between French Franc Area Accounts may be made freely. * Since February 1967, France has applied to Morocco its controls on foreign investments in France and on French investments abroad. The exchange controls imposed by France on November 25, 1968 in its financial relations with foreign countries are applied also to Morocco. 3 Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Egypt, Guinea, Hungary, Mali, Poland, and U.S.S.R. 4 Imports from the French Franc Area, unless covered by special credit arrangements, must be paid for with commercial French francs purchased from the Bank of Morocco. 305 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO 2. Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams art reserved for residents of countries in the area of convertibility. These ac- counts may be credited freely with authorized payments due to residents of countries in the area of convertibility (but not in respect of imports or related invisibles) and with dirhams obtained from the sale to the Bank of Morocco of "converti- ble currencies" negotiated by it, excluding banknotes. They may be debited freely for payments in Morocco and for pur- chases from the Bank of Morocco of the "convertible curren- cies" negotiated by it, including banknotes. Transfers between Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams may be made freely. 3. Payments Agreement Accounts are held by the Bank of Morocco for central banks (or similar institutions) of the countries with which Morocco maintains bilateral payments agreements (see footnote 3); they are used only for settle- ments with these countries, including settlements for imports and exports. 4. Capital Accounts, which may be held by any nonresident, are credited with funds that may not be transferred abroad. These include the proceeds from the sale on the Casablanca stock exchange of Moroccan securities held under foreign dossier and proceeds from the contractual or accelerated re- demption of such securities. Transfers between Capital Ac- counts related to (1) countries either in the area of convertibility or the French Franc Area or (2) the same coun- try in the payments agreement group, are permitted freely. Capital Accounts may be debited freely for (1) purchases of specified 5% per cent, seven-year government bonds; inter- est and redemption proceeds are transferable, and the bonds are freely negotiable between nonresidents; and (2) personal expenses of the account holder and his immediate relatives during visits to Morocco, up to DH 150 a person a day, subject to a limit of DH 5,000 a year for each account. All other operations through Capital Accounts require individual approval. These include purchases on the Casablanca stock exchange of Moroccan and non-Moroccan securities; pur- chases of Moroccan securities not quoted in Casablanca or of participation in a Moroccan firm; subscriptions to either; investments of any kind, including purchases of businesses or office buildings; lending to residents; payment of local ex- penses in excess of DH 5,000 during the holder's stay in Morocco; any such payments to beneficiaries other than the holder of the account or a close relative of his; any such payments from an account held by a foreign juridical person; gifts to social, cultural, or religious institutions; subscriptions to capital increases of Moroccan companies whose shares are quoted on the Casablanca stock exchange; subscriptions at the time of issue to long-term or short-term securities with a fixed yield issued by a Moroccan public entity; custody charges and commissions on securities; and payment of the costs of maintenance, repairs, real estate taxes, and insurance on real estate taxes, and insurance on real estate located in Morocco. Subject to approval, Capital Accounts may also be debited for investments in Morocco, within the framework of the 1973 Investment Code, provided that the amounts deb- ited do not exceed 50 per cent of the investment undertaken by the nonresident or 25 per cent of the company's total capital. 306 5. Suspense Accounts are used for holding nonresident funds not available for credit to any of the accounts men- tioned above. Balances on these accounts may be used freely to pay taxes due to the Moroccan authorities, but all other debits to these accounts require approval. 6. Two Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are held by the Bank of Morocco for the Central Bank of Algeria and the Central Bank of Tunisia. Specified transactions between Morocco and the two other countries concerned are settled through these accounts. Imports and Import Payments Imports are admitted in accordance with an annual Gen- eral Import Program. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports are divided into three categories applicable to all countries. Goods in List A are liberalized. Goods in List B are restricted, in some cases by a global quota, or are subject to state trading; for a large number of List B items, no quotas are established and imports are approved according to need (SB items). In principle, the importation of goods in List C is not permitted. To import goods in List A, the importer signs an import commitment (engagement d'importation), which does not require administrative approval unless the goods are imported from a country other than that of origin or are purchased on a c.i.f. basis,5 but for goods in List B, an import license (automation d"importation or certificat d* importation) must be obtained. For all imports the import title—import certificate or im- port commitment —must be domiciled (registered) with an authorized bank, which may make payments upon submis- sion of the required documents. Import certificates require the visa of the Exchange Office before the foreign exchange is made available. Import commitments require this visa only when the country of origin and the country of shipment of the goods concerned differ or when imports are contracted for on a c.i.f. basis. Import certificates must be domiciled within 15 days from the date that the Exchange Office approves the license. Import commitments must be domiciled at the time of their subscription. Special procedures are applicable to specified imports financed by foreign aid or loans. Most imports from countries in the payments agreement group are made in accordance with the quotas established in the respective trade agreements. Imports can also be licensed under compensation transactions. Payments for Invisibles Payments for most current invisibles require the approval of the Exchange Office upon presentation of the necessary justification; in several instances the approval authority has been delegated to the banks. The authorized banks are per- mitted to make payments and settle expenses incidental to the commercial transaction covered by the relevant import or export documents. Earnings after tax on approved nonresi- dent investments in Morocco are transferable to the inves- tor's country of residence. The transfer of dividends on non- resident-owned shares of Moroccan companies having their 5 C.i.f. imports of List A goods require prior exchange control approval. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution main office in Morocco requires the approval of the Exchange Office. Undistributed profits relating to the financial year 1968 or later remain transferable indefinitely. Some payments are subject to limitations. A foreign em- ployee may transfer to his country of origin, subject to the initial approval of the Exchange Office, 50 per cent of his monthly wages or salary if his family does not reside in Mo- rocco, or 30 per cent if he is single or his family lives in Morocco. The same percentages of their monthly earnings may be transferred by foreign nationals engaged in profes- sions, subject (except for the medical and related professions) to a limit of DH 12,000 a year. 8 Subject to a monthly limit of DH 300, the same percentages of earnings may also be transferred by foreign nationals engaged in agricultural, in- dustrial, or commercial activities, or in skilled crafts. Foreign nationals employed in the hotel sector are authorized to transfer 65 per cent of their monthly salaries or wages. An allocation of foreign exchange equivalent to DH 100 a person a year is granted to residents of any nationality for travel abroad, provided that they do not make periodic transfers abroad. There is a special allocation for pilgrimages. Resi- dents of foreign nationality may acquire exchange for tourist travel up to the equivalent of DH 2,500 for each passport a year by selling to an authorized bank a corresponding amount in foreign exchange (other than banknotes) from their own foreign assets not subject to surrender requirements. For business travel by persons other than exporters a stan- dard allowance of DH 150 a day is granted; exporters may be granted up to DH 200 a day for up to 60 days a year, up to a limit of 1 per cent of the foreign exchange surrendered during the preceding year. The allocation issued for business travel may be added to the allocation issued for tourist travel. For study abroad, a monthly allocation of foreign exchange up to DH 500-700 is granted, provided that no comparable educational facilities are available in Morocco; Moroccan stu- dents taking college or university level courses abroad are entitled to an annual installation allowance equivalent to DH 1,000. For family maintenance, the Exchange Office gen- erally grants a monthly allocation in the order of DH 250- 300. Travelers are not permitted to take out Moroccan bank- notes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports may be made freely, although export licenses are required for a few items. All fruits, fresh vegetables, canned goods, raw cotton, and cotton by-products may be exported only by a state trading agency, the Office of Marketing and Export (Office de Commercialisation et d'Exportation—OCE). That Office also is in charge of wine exports. All exporters must sign an undertaking to repatriate and surrender the foreign exchange proceeds of their exports. The surrender of the proceeds to the exporter's bank must take place within one month from the date the payment is due. The date on which the payment is due is the ma tur i ty date fixed 6 For all wages, salaries, and professional earnings, monthly transfers which exceed by more than DH 100 the amount transferred in June 1973 require prior authorization by the Exchange Office. MOROCCO in the commercial contract; this date must not be set, in principle, more than 90 days after the date of arrival of the merchandise at the place of destination. When the bank re- ceiving the funds that represent the proceeds from exports receives the advice of credit in foreign currency from abroad, it must surrender the foreign exchange immediately to the Bank of Morocco. Proceeds from Invisibles Residents of Moroccan nationality and Moroccan compa- nies must repatriate exchange receipts accruing from all their noncommercial claims and surrender them to an authorized bank. Other residents must surrender noncommercial re- ceipts only if the receipts result from current transactions, and only when they accrue in foreign currencies other than those of the French Franc Area. Moroccans working abroad must surrender such currencies within one mon th of re-entry, but are permitted, when leaving again, to repurchase 15 per cent of the amount surrendered (the currencies so purchased may also include French francs); they are entitled to a bonus of 5 per cent on the dirham equivalent of any foreign ex- change repatriated in the form of bank or postal transfers. The importation of Moroccan banknotes is prohibited. Non- resident travelers may bring in freely foreign banknotes; for- eign exchange brought in in excess of the equivalent of DH 5,000 must be declared to the customs authorities. Resi- dent travelers also may bring in any amount in foreign bank- notes, but these must be surrendered within 30 days of re-entry. Capital Residents of Moroccan nationality, as well as companies established in Morocco, are obliged to declare to the Ex- change Office all foreign-held assets exceeding DH 250, and to repatriate and surrender certain of these assets. The dis- posal of other foreign-held assets requires permission. The transfer of capital abroad by residents must be approved. Remittances in respect of the assets of emigrants and trans- fers of gifts are not normally approved. Exchange allocations for the transfer of inheritances are limited to DH 35,000 a beneficiary. Those for the transfer of their assets by repatri- ates vary with the length of their stay in Morocco, from DH 35,000 a family with previous residence of 3 to 5 years to DH 100,000 a family where the period of residence has been 15 to 25 years. New foreign investments in specified sectors of the econ- omy may benefit from the provisions of the Investment Code of August 15, 1973. The Code consists of six laws and several implementing decrees providing various tax concessions and other incentives. It guarantees the transfer of dividends dis- tributed to nonresidents and of proceeds from the liquidation of the capital brought in by the foreign investor. Investments financed with funds held in Capital Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above) also are eligible for the bene- fits of the Code; proceeds from the liquidation of investments financed in this manner become transferable after a minimum investment period of 5 years. 307 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO Foreign investments approved under the previous Invest- ment Code (of February 10, 1961) continue to benefit from the retransfer guarantee for the liquidation proceeds. Pro- ceeds from the liquidation of other investments are credited to Capital Accounts. Certain government bonds acquired with funds from Capi- tal Accounts are freely negotiable between nonresidents. All other transactions in securities involving nonresident inter- ests, as well as the import and export of securities, require approval. Banks are not permitted to engage in short-term borrowing abroad except with special authorization from the monetary authorities. Gold Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Mo- rocco for numismatic or investment purposes. Ten different types of foreign gold coins are traded on the Casablanca stock exchange, which does not, however, deal in gold bars or ingots. Imports and exports of gold are prohibited unless authorized by the Warranty Office in the Directorate of Cus- toms and Indirect Taxes, which derives its approval authority from the Minister of Finance. Every year the Minister of Finance fixes a quota for the importation of gold ingots, which is then allocated among jewelers and other users. Changes during 1973 January. Notice to Importers No. 301 was published con- taining the General Import Program for 1973. Its structure remained substantially unchanged from that for 1972. February 15. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the par value of the dirham was maintained in terms of gold. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar, previously DH 4.66097 = US$1, became DH 4.19488 = US$1. March 2. Law No. 1-73-210 (as amended by Law No. 1-73-339 of May 7, 1973) imposed the obligation on foreign investors in the commercial and services sectors (excluding tourism) and in a number of industrial subsectors to share their ownership with Moroccan nationals. The measure was referred to as Moroccanization. March 7. Law No. 1-73-213 of March 2 was published. It provided that, with effect from its date of publication, all agricultural property owned by foreign natural or juridical persons was to be transferred to the State. Joint orders of the Ministries of Interior, Agriculture, and Agrarian Reform were to specify the property to be transferred to the State and the date of their take-over. May 8. Decree No. 2-73-220 was published comprising two lists of economic activities in which non-Moroccan physical or juridical persons had to comply with the Moroccanization measures; for the first list they had to do so by May 31, 1974, and for the second list by May 31, 1975. May 17. The fixed relationship between the dirham and the commercial French franc, previously DH 1 = F 1.09755 or DH 0.9111 = F 1, was discontinued. Henceforth, the rate for the dirham in terms of the commercial French franc was fixed daily, in accordance with variations in the quotations of the commercial franc in terms of certain major foreign currencies 308 and taking into account the geographic distribution of Mo- rocco's foreign transactions. Rates for certain other curren- cies were quoted on the basis of the daily rate for the commercial French franc in terms of dirhams and the cross rates for these currencies against the commercial franc pre- vailing in major foreign exchange markets. May 18. Exchange Office Circular No. 1256 provided that Moroccan workers going abroad for the first time could pur- chase foreign exchange up to the equivalent of DH 300. This allocation was additional to that for tourism. July 5. Exchange Office Circular No. 1252 raised the an- nual installation allowance for Moroccans studying abroad from the equivalent of DH 800 to DH 1,000 and made this exchange allocation available also to those who were not scholarship students. July 19. Exchange Office Notice No. 143 required nonresi- dent travelers entering Morocco to declare to the customs authorities any foreign exchange brought in in excess of the equivalent of DH 5,000. July 30. Dahir No. 1-73-400 introduced with immediate effect a 5 per cent bonus payable on the dirham equivalent of any foreign exchange repatriated by Moroccans working abroad in the form of bank or postal transfers. August 15. A new Investment Code was published. It con- sisted of six laws and several implementing decrees. The Code provided additional incentives for foreign and domestic in- vestment in specified sectors of the economy. Certain blocked nonresident-owned funds held in Capital Accounts also were eligible for investment projects covered by the Code. Pro- ceeds from the liquidation of investments financed by such funds could be transferred freely after a minimum investment period of five years. Law No. 1-73-408 provided that export- ers engaged in specified industrial and handicraft sectors could purchase foreign exchange up to 3 per cent of their export turnover for expenses connected with advertising, for- eign market research, and maintenance of foreign branches. The Investment Code of February 10, 1961 (Dahir No. 1-60-383 of December 31, 1960, published in the Official Gazette of February 10, 1961) was abrogated with immediate effect. The retransfer guarantees previously granted under that Code remained in effect. September 4. Exchange Office Circular No. 1(259) revised the regulations governing Capital Accounts. It established limits up to which the accounts could be debited for invest- ments within the framework of the new Investment Code. The amount that an account holder could withdraw for local expenses during visits to Morocco was raised from DH 100 a day to DH 150 a day, up to a maximum of DH 5,000 a year for each account. Transfers between Capital Accounts related to countries in the area of convertibility and those related to countries of the French Franc Area, previously prohibited, were permitted freely. The approval authority for the transfer of income and redemption proceeds from Moroccan securities held under foreign dossier, and for the transfer of dividends paid to nonresident shareholders by companies having their main office in Morocco and approved by the Exchange Office, ceased to be delegated to authorized banks. Not for Redistribution NEPAL Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0808408 gram of fine gold per Nepalese Rupee, corresponding to NRs 10.9929 = SDR 1. A central rate has been established of NRs 12.7390 = SDR 1, corre- sponding to NRs 10.56 = US$1, and Nepal avails itself of wider margins. The Nepal Rastra Bank (the central bank) maintains fixed buying and selling rates for U.S. dollars and Indian rupees as follows: NRs 10.50 buying and NRs 10.60 selling per US$1, and NRs 139.00 buying and NRs 139.15 selling per 100 Indian rupees. Daily rates are quoted for Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, Japanese yen, pounds ster- ling, Swiss francs, and certain other currencies. Different ef- fective exchange rates arise from the operation of an Exporters' Exchange Entitlement Scheme. Most of Nepal's foreign exchange transactions are in terms of Indian rupees. Residents may freely purchase Indian rupees from Nepalese banks and they may hold any amount of Indian notes and coins, but the Indian rupee is not legal tender. Administration of Control A Foreign Exchange Committee, consisting of representa- tives from the Nepal Rastra Bank and the Ministries of Fi- nance, Foreign Affairs, and Industry and Commerce, prepares an annual foreign exchange budget for foreign cur- rencies other than the Indian rupee and excluding transac- tions with the clearing countries. Permission is required from the Ministry of Finance for all foreign payments, except pay- ments for certain specified invisibles that require authoriza- tion from the Nepal Rastra Bank. Import and export licensing is the responsibility of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. All exchange transactions with countries other than India .must be settled through authorized dealers, i.e., the Nepal Bank Ltd. and the Rastriya Vanijya Bank. Within Nepal there are 58 additional authorized dealers licensed to purchase foreign currencies; any sale of such currencies other than Indian rupees is subject to the prior approval of the Nepal Rastra Bank. All import and export transactions with payments agreement countries, as well as all barter trade, are conducted through a state trading agency, the National Trad- ing Ltd. Most government imports are made through the National Trading Ltd. or through the Agricultural Market- ing Corporation. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements apply to outgo- ing payments to countries with which no payments agreement is in force and these may be made in the foreign currency supplied by the Nepal Rastra Bank. Payments for imports from India normally are settled in Indian rupees, but the Nepal Rastra Bank sometimes makes convertible currencies available for such imports. The proceeds of exports to India are obtained in Indian or Nepalese rupees; the proceeds of exports to other countries must be received in any of the convertible currencies quoted by the Nepal Rastra Bank. Nepal has bilateral payments agreements with Bulgaria, the 310 People's Republic of China, Pakistan, and Poland; payments between Nepal and these countries must be made through special accounts. The agreement with Pakistan is inoperative. Nonresident Accounts The Nepal Rastra Bank permits nonresidents other than Indian nationals upon request to open "convertible rupee accounts" with Nepalese banks, the balances of which may be freely transferred abroad. Indian nationals are allowed to open current accounts in Indian rupees with Nepalese banks. Foreign currencies brought into or received in Nepal by non- residents, which are converted into Nepalese rupees and de- posited with a Nepalese bank, may be reconverted for transfer out of the country, subject to prior permission of the Nepal Rastra Bank. Imports and Import Payments All imports of goods except those originating in India (other than alcoholic beverages, tobacco, and most tobacco products) or the Tibet region require import licenses from the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. Imports of vegetables, vegetable oil, margarine, animal fat, beef, arms and ammuni- tion, explosives, chemicals to be used for explosives, and wireless transmitters are prohibited. Under the Trade and Transit Treaty of August 13, 1971, Nepal and India agreed to freedom of trade between themselves in Nepalese and Indian goods; Indian goods may be imported freely, and reimbursement of tax is made by the Government of India to the Government of Nepal on direct imports from Indian manufacturers of commodities subject to excise du ty in India. With the exception noted below, applications to the Minis- try of Finance for foreign exchange to pay for imports from countries other than India are considered on their merits; any application must, however, be in accordance with the annual foreign exchange budget. Exporters entitled to import goods with exporters' exchange entitlements are, within the limits of their entitlement, granted a license automatically for goods specified by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below); the entitle- ments are transferable and may also be used by other holders. No licenses for consumer goods are being issued to the private sector (other than hotels) except against exporters' exchange entitlements. Many imports payable in convertible currencies are effected through state trading agencies, mainly the Na- tional Trading Ltd. and the Agricultural Marketing Corpora- tion. Certain imports from all sources are subject to import surcharges. Payments for Invisibles Payments to India may be made freely in Indian rupees, but for purchases of Rs 500 or over the purpose of the payment must be indicated. Payments for freight and insurance are given the same treatment as the related import payments. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution For travel to countries other than India for medical treat- ment, foreign exchange is allowed as recommended by a panel of doctors; students studying at their own expense in these countries are allowed up to US$2,160 a year for board and lodging, while payments for tuition fees are allowed as re- quired. Payments for other invisibles depend on the essential- ity of the transaction and the availability of foreign exchange. Ncpalese and Indian currency may be taken out freely to India by Nepalese and Indian nationals only; the export of these currencies to countries other than India is prohibited. Foreign banknotes other than Indian banknotes may not be taken out by residents without permission. Nonresidents may take out the unchanged amount of any foreign banknotes they brought in; however, nonresidents other than Indian nationals may not take out Nepalese or Indian banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of old coins, gold and silver, and coins and jewelry made of these metals, cows, buffaloes, and rhinoceros horns are prohibited. The re-export to India of non-Nepalese goods is not permitted, and re-exports to any destination of goods imported from India are prohibited. All other goods may be exported freely to India. All exports to other destinations require export licenses. The exchange proceeds of exports, except Indian rupees, must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an autho- rized bank at the official buying rate of exchange, within six months of shipment. The exporter receives from the Nepal Rastra Bank an exporters' exchange entitlement correspond- ing to a specified proportion of his export proceeds in foreign currencies other than Indian rupees; the entitlement may be used to obtain exchange at the official rate for the import of goods specified by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. Entitlements are negotiable. Exporters engaged in bilateral trade, i.e., those selling to countries with which Nepal maintains payments agreements, are granted entitlements corresponding to 100 per cent of their export earnings; 40 per cent may be used for imports of their choice from the partner country concerned and the re- maining 60 per cent must be used to import specified com- modities from the partner country concerned. When expxOrts are made to convertible currency countries, exchange entitlements are granted at ratios ranging from 20 per cent for raw jute to 90 per cent for stainless steel goods. Proceeds from Invisibles With the exception of Indian rupees, foreign exchange pro- ceeds derived from transactions in invisibles must be surren- dered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an authorized bank at the official rate of exchange. Nepalese and Indian currency may be brought in from India only, and by Nepalese and Indian nationals only; the import of these currencies from countries other than India is prohibited. Nonresidents other than Indian nationals are not allowed to bring in Nepalese or Indian banknotes. Other foreign banknotes may be brought NEPAL in freely by residents and nonresidents, but residents must declare any foreign banknotes they bring in. Capital No conditions are laid down concerning receipts and remit- tances in respect of capital transactions, but official exchange is not normally provided for capital remittances by Nepalese nationals. Nepalese citizens, whether resident in Nepal or not, are prohibited from making any type of investment in foreign countries except investment specifically exempted by govern- ment notice published in the Official Gazette; the exemptions include the purchase and sale of insurance policies abroad, investments abroad by any banking or financial institution incorporated in Nepal, and the purchase of shares of foreign companies under a rights issue. Foreign investors in Nepal who obtain an investment guar- antee may remit yearly profits of up to 25 per cent of the total profit on the foreign capital invested and, in any one year, up to 10 per cent of the principal; if the exchange situation permits, profits in excess of 25 per cent are remittable. Enter- prises capitalized at NRs 500,000 or more may be wholly owned by nonresidents. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Nepal. Imports for industrial and handicraft use from India, at Indian gold prices, are free of license. No import licenses for gold are issued under the Exporters' Exchange Entitlement Scheme. Imports of gold from any country other than India require a license and are subject to an import duty of NRs 6.65 a troy ounce; such imports are not normally allowed. Exports of gold may be made only by the monetary authorities and require prior approval by the Ministry of Finance. Domestic dealings in gold do not require a license but are subject to sales tax at 10 per cent. Changes during 1973 January 1. The National Trading Ltd. took over all exports of raw jute. February 20. Nepal established a central rate of NRs 12.7390 = SDR 1, corresponding to NRs 10.56 = US$1. Previously, the Nepal Rastra Bank's fixed buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were NRs 10.10 and NRs 10.20, respectively, per US$1. The parity rate for the Indian rupee was maintained unchanged at NRs 139.10 per 100 Indian rupees. Nepal continued to avail itself of wider mar- gins. April 13. The entitlement percentages under the Export- ers' Exchange Entitlement Scheme were revised. April 23. The transfer of exporters' exchange entitlements was freely permitted. August 17. The state-owned Nepal Oil Corporation took over the import and distribution of petroleum products. November 30. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.245489 gram of fine gold per Nether- lands Guilder, corresponding to f. 3.62 = SDR 1. The Neth- erlands has established a central rate of f. 3.35507 = SDR 1, corresponding to 0.264874 gram of fine gold per Netherlands guilder, and avails itself of wider margins. A maximum mar- gin of 2% per cent is maintained for exchange rates in the official market between the Netherlands guilder and the Dan- ish krone, the deutsche mark, the French franc, the Norwe- gian krone, and the Swedish krona; margins of 1V2 per cent either side of the cross-parity are observed for the Belgian franc and, by implication, the Luxembourg franc (BF /Lux F 100 = f. 6.8953). No announced margins are maintained for other currencies. l The authorized banks' buying and sell- ing rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1973 were f. 2.82325 and f. 2.82575, respectively, per US$1. Authorized banks are freely permitted to buy and sell con- vertible and inconvertible currencies, both spot and forward, against convertible currencies, including guilders on Convert- ible Guilder Accounts, and inconvertible currencies; they are free to deal with residents and nonresidents, whether banks or nonbanks. Forward exchange contracts are not limited as to delivery period nor is an underlying transaction required. Residents are permitted to conclude spot transactions with other residents, including authorized banks, and they may conclude forward transactions for any period with authorized banks. Nonbank residents are free to hold foreign currency accounts at home and on application are permitted to hold such accounts (normally demand deposits only) in their own names with banks abroad. The guilder proceeds from the sale by nonresidents to resi- dents of officially listed guilder bonds (O-guilders, see section on Capital, below) are traded in a spot market at free rates. On December 31, 1973, the rate for the O-guilder was about f. 100.50 per 100 O-guilders. 2 The Kingdom of the Netherlands formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory All transactions with the Netherlands Antilles and Suri- nam are subject to exchange control, although they are gener- ally permitted freely. Vis-a-vis any third countries with which payments agreements might be in force, the Netherlands, the Netherlands Antilles, and Surinam constitute the Nether- lands Monetary Area. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Netherlands Bank on behalf of the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Finance, Eco- 1 The currencies quoted in the Amsterdam market include Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 The O-guilder arrangements were abolished with effect from February 1, 1974. 312 nomic Affairs, and Agriculture. Import and export licensing are handled by the Central Import-Export Agency (CDIU) and the delegated offices, under directives from the Director- ate-General for Foreign Economic Relations. Invisibles and capital transactions are licensed by the Netherlands Bank, as are transit trade transactions, except those in strategic goods and scrap, which are licensed by the CDIU. 3 All commercial banks of any importance are authorized to handle foreign exchange transactions within the scope of general and special licenses granted by the licensing authorities. Prescription of Currency Payments to nonresidents, if eligible for transfer abroad, must be made through an authorized bank, either in guilders to the credit of a nonresident guilder account held with an authorized bank in the Netherlands or to the debit of the authorized bank's currency holdings abroad. There are spe- cial regulations, however, for settlements with nonresidents in respect of officially listed guilder bonds (see section on Capi- tal, below) and for payments in respect of direct imports from Egypt. Since there are no bilateral payments agreements, all for- eign countries are included in the "convertible guilder area." Payments to countries in the convertible guilder area may be made in any foreign currency or in guilders to the credit of any nonresident account. Receipts from countries in the con- vertible guilder area may be obtained in any convertible cur- rency or in guilders to the debit of a Convertible Guilder Account (see section on Nonresident Accounts, below); how- ever, receipts may also be collected in other currencies, pro- vided that the amounts received are deposited with the Netherlands Bank or an authorized bank. Payments between residents may be made freely in any foreign currency, provided that the amount involved is deb- ited to a foreign currency account in the Netherlands or abroad and is credited to a foreign currency account in the name of the beneficiary with an authorized bank in the Neth- erlands. Nonresident Accounts The main categories of nonresident guilder accounts are as follows: 1. Convertible Guilder Accounts. These accounts may be held by any nonresident. They may be credited with transfers from other Convertible Guilder Accounts, with permitted payments by residents of the Netherlands to residents of countries of the convertible guilder area, with proceeds from the sale of gold or convertible currencies, and with Nether- lands notes and coins remitted or deposited by nonresidents. They may be debited for payments to residents for exports and services rendered to any country and for other permitted transactions, including purchases of foreign currencies. How- 3 Merchanting transactions involving Rhodesia are prohibited. Most other transactions are freely permitted by virtue of general licenses granted to registered transit traders. The only merchanting transactions still subject to a specific license are purchases and sales of strategic goods and, within the EEC, of scrap. ©International Monetary Fund.
