Convertible Guilder Accounts may not be debited for the purchase of officially listed guilder bonds, Netherlands treasury paper, or guilder bank acceptances; they may not be credited with interest on demand deposits, 4 and may be subject to a negative interest charge (the rate of charge was zero per cent at the end of 1973). Balances on these accounts may be transferred to any other nonresident account except O-Guilder Accounts. No time or savings de- posits may be established on Convertible Guilder Accounts. 5 2. O-Guilder Accounts(see footnote 2). These accounts may be held by any nonresident and by those authorized banks and stockbrokers that have been designated authorized de- positories. The accounts may be freely credited with (1) the guilder proceeds from the sale of officially listed guilder bonds by nonresidents to residents,6 and (2) amounts trans- ferred from other O-Guilder Accounts. They may be freely debited for (1) purchases of officially listed guilder bonds by nonresidents from residents, (2) amounts transferred to other O-Guilder Accounts, and (3) transfers to Convertible Guilder Accounts. Holders of O-guilders may freely sell these to other nonresidents or to resident banks and stockbrokers, for for- eign currency or convertible guilders. Imports and Import Payments Imports from the Belgian-Luxembourg Economic Union are free from import licenses. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Import licenses are required for imports originat- ing in Hong Kong, Japan, and state trading countries, and for the import of goods of unknown origin. In addition, import licenses are required for a limited number of products mainly from the agricultural and textile sectors. Except for imports from Rhodesia, practically all imports that require an import license are free from quantitative restriction. Most imports from Eastern European countries are formally liberalized. Commodities corresponding to some 19 tariff headings or subheadings are subject to quantitative restriction when orig- inating in Japan. Imports from non-EEC countries of most products cov- ered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to import levies that have replaced all previous barri- ers to imports; common EEC regulations are also applied to imports from non-EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products, some of which are subject to variable import levies. Payments for imports may be made freely, provided that the method of payment conforms with the general prescrip- tion of currency regulations. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of imports of commodities,7 but they require prior approval from the Netherlands Bank to accept credit for 4 Balances up to f. 50,000 held by physical persons are exempt from this prohibition. With effect from March 4, 1974 the exemption was increased to f. 100,000 a person. 5 With effect from March 4, 1974 this prohibition was lifted for physical persons, up to f. 100,000 a person. 6 Emigrants must be able to show that they have owned these bonds since a date at least three months prior to departure. 7 Commodities are so defined as to exclude gold. NETHERLANDS periods in excess of those traditional in the trade concerned; such permission is not normally granted. Payments for Invisibles Payments abroad for invisibles are permitted freely. Ex- change for travel is provided in any currency and up to any amount, and the entire amount may be taken, if the traveler wishes, in Netherlands banknotes. A resident traveling abroad may in addition have any further amounts remitted to him through banking channels. Exchange purchased for travel purposes must not be spent for other purposes; it may be used for purchases for personal use, however. Payments for interest, dividends, and contractual amortization due to non- residents are permitted freely by crediting the appropriate nonresident account. The export of domestic or foreign banknotes by resident travelers is not subject to limitation. Nonresidents may ex- port all unutilized negotiable instruments and foreign and Netherlands banknotes and coins which they have imported or have obtained in the Netherlands by drawing on their accounts or exchanging other currencies. Exports and Export Proceeds Virtually all exports to Rhodesia are prohibited; those which are permitted require an export license. For exports to other countries, export licenses are required only for a few commodities, mostly of a strategic character, and for some agricultural products, scrap of iron and steel, certain nonfer- rous metals, and petroleum. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of exports of commodities (see footnote 7), but they require prior permis- sion from the Netherlands Bank to accept payment in ad- vance of delivery where such advance payments are not traditional in the trade concerned; such permission is not normally granted. The surrender of export proceeds is not obligatory, but any surrender that is made must be at the official rate. The collection of export proceeds through an authorized bank is obligatory. A license may be obtained on application, however, to hold a foreign currency account with a bank abroad, to which account export proceeds may be credited. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles must be collected through an authorized bank but need not be surrendered and may instead be credited to foreign currency accounts. A li- cense may be obtained on application to hold a foreign cur- rency account with a bank abroad, to which account proceeds from invisibles may be credited. For incoming exchange ex- ceeding f. 1,000 derived from current invisibles, the recipient must indicate to an authorized bank the nature of the under- lying transaction, as well as the amount and currency re- ceived. Nonresidents may bring into the Netherlands unlimited amounts in Netherlands banknotes, foreign banknotes, and negotiable instruments. These may be sold only to an autho- rized bank, to an authorized exchange office, or, in the case 313 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS of foreign banknotes, to an authorized depository, or they may be used to pay tourist expenses in the Netherlands. Residents are obliged to bring back to the Netherlands any unutilized portion of the banknotes and coins that they took with them on their outward journey; there is no limitation on the amount in Netherlands or foreign banknotes and coins that they may bring in. Capital Inward and outward capital transfers and the shifting of foreign-owned capital within the Netherlands from one asset to another are subject to control, but general licenses have been granted for many types of capital transaction. Borrow- ing and lending abroad by bank and nonbank residents (with the exception of specified banking operations and of the granting of credit in respect of imports or exports of commod- ities) are restricted for reasons of capital market policy and, as far as borrowing is concerned, either to control the con- tracting of foreign debt by local authorities or for reasons of monetary and reserve policy. Apart from guilder issues on the Netherlands capital market (see below), most lending to non- residents is liberally permitted. Borrowing abroad by non- bank residents is at present restricted, in principle, to amounts used for investments abroad (which is considered to include the purchase of ships and aircraft abroad). Borrowing from nonresident banks by private industry and other non- bank residents is not normally permitted, and loans from other nonresident sources (except suppliers' credits with a maturity customary in the trade concerned) are subject to individual approval; licenses for borrowing abroad from non- bank nonresidents are granted on application, provided that the funds are used for direct investment abroad or for lending to nonresidents, but the Netherlands Bank, in principle, does not permit nonbank residents to take up financial credits abroad other than loans with a fixed maturity of at least five years from nonresident enterprises belonging to the same concern as the borrower. There is a general license for loans up to f. 100,000 taken up by residents from nonresidents, provided that a resident in any calendar year does not borrow more than f. 100,000 from the same nonresident. A similar license has been issued for lending to nonresidents. Further- more, a general license permits authorized banks to grant loans for up to 12 months to nonbank nonresidents and for any period to nonresident banks; authorized banks are on application granted licenses to lend to nonbank nonresidents for periods in excess of 12 months. Special regulations exist for borrowing and lending be- tween head offices (in the Netherlands or abroad) of multina- tional companies and their branches and subsidiaries; at present, the Netherlands Bank does not permit financial loans to be taken up abroad within a multinational company, ex- cept as indicated above or by resident subsidiaries located in regions where industrialization is being promoted by means of premiums. Nonbank residents are not normally permitted to purchase foreign treasury bills or other foreign short-term instruments. Purchases of Netherlands treasury paper and guilder bank acceptances by nonresidents, including central banks, are prohibited. Capital transactions, whether freely 314 permitted or not, must be notified to the Balance of Payments Department of the Netherlands Bank; this is true also of all import credit in excess of one year and of advance payments in excess of f. 250,000 to be received for exports. Capital issues in the Netherlands on behalf of nonresidents are restricted. During the last ten years or so, international financial institutions and the authorities of the nonmetropoli- tan areas of the Kingdom of the Netherlands have been the only nonresidents allowed to make bond issues denominated in guilders. Such issues are individually licensed by the Neth- erlands Bank in accordance with the prospects for the domes- tic capital market and the balance of payments. The Netherlands Bank, subject to certain conditions, allows non- residents access to the debt certificate sector of the domestic capital market (the market for onderhandse leningeri). Autho- rized banks may on request be licensed to lead syndicates for the issue of medium-term Euro-guilder notes, the proceeds of which normally must not be spent in the Netherlands. Unless special permission to the contrary is obtained from the Netherlands Bank, authorized banks' foreign liabilities must not exceed their foreign claims, i.e., they are not allowed to maintain a negative net external position. In observing this regulation, each bank has a leeway of f. 5 million; the calcula- tion of the net foreign position is based on the foreign position in all currencies, including guilders, and on the sum of short-term and long-term assets and liabilities. Subject to this limitation, banks may freely accept demand deposits from nonresidents, in domestic or foreign currency, as well as time deposits in foreign currency. However, subject to minor ex- emptions for physical persons, banks are prohibited from paying interest on nonresident-held guilder demand deposits and from accepting guilder time deposits from nonresidents. New capital investments in the Netherlands by nonresi- dents are in general permitted. Inward direct investment is freely permitted and local borrowing by nonresident-owned or nonresident-controlled companies for use in the Nether- lands also is freely permitted. The transfer abroad of the proceeds from the sale or liquidation of nonresident invest- ments in industrial enterprises and other businesses estab- lished in the Netherlands is freely permitted. Nonresidents may freely purchase real estate in the Netherlands for per- sonal use or investment. Direct investment abroad by resi- dents is authorized on application. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in offi- cially listed guilder bonds (including mortgage bonds and "interest savings letters" but excluding guilder notes) are sub- ject to special regulations (but see footnote 2). Trading in such bonds is unrestricted but nonresidents' purchases from residents must be financed with O-guilders (see Nonresident Accounts, above); nonresidents selling such bonds to resi- dents may receive payment by credit either to an O-Guilder Account or to a Convertible Guilder Account. Accrued inter- est and brokerage on bonds purchased and sold must be settled in the same manner as the principal sum, as must stamp duty on transactions in the secondary market. Bal- ances in O-Guilder Accounts are freely negotiable between nonresidents. Authorized banks and stockbrokers may freely deal in O-guilders among themselves and with nonresidents. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Transactions between residents and nonresidents in foreign securities and domestic securities other than listed guilder bonds take place at official market rates and, with minor exceptions, are unrestricted; the regulations concerning secu- rities are not applicable to treasury bills or certificates of deposit. Residents may freely purchase officially listed securi- ties abroad, with the exception of guilder-denominated Euro-bonds issued by nonresidents; foreign bonds denomi- nated in guilders or otherwise linked to the parity of the guilder may be purchased freely only when listed on the Amsterdam stock exchange. The foreign currency proceeds from securities sold abroad by residents must be deposited with an authorized bank or securities broker in the Nether- lands and may be sold or retained. The proceeds of securities sold in the Netherlands by nonresidents (other than O-guilder proceeds) are transferable in any currency, irrespective of the seller's country of domicile or residence. Nonresidents may have their securities, Netherlands or foreign, exported to them; for the exportation of listed guilder bonds an individual authorization is required, which is granted upon application. Domestic and foreign securities held abroad by a resident are subject to a deposit requirement, but the Netherlands Bank grants exemptions on application; securities held in the Neth- erlands are not subject to deposit. Residents may freely purchase real estate abroad. Gifts and donations to nonresidents are free. 8 Emigrants may export any amount in foreign and domestic currency. They acquire the status of nonresidents upon leaving the Netherlands, pro- vided that they have declared their intention to settle abroad for more than three years, and may upon departure have remitted to them their total assets in the Netherlands; the proceeds of any listed guilder bonds sold by emigrants to residents do not qualify for settlement in O-guilders unless the bonds had been held for at least three months prior to departure (but see footnote 2). Payments to nonresident beneficiaries may be made freely in respect of inheritances from estates being distributed in the Netherlands. Gold The Netherlands Bank engages in gold transactions only with monetary authorities and international financial institu- tions. Neither the Bank nor any government agency imports or markets gold for industrial use. Authorized banks and other residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold (fine gold, gold coin, and gold alloys) in the Netherlands or abroad; gold held abroad, however, must be kept on deposit with the foreign correspondent of an authorized depository. Imports and exports of gold require neither exchange licenses nor import and export licenses. There is a free gold market in Amsterdam. Domestic sales of gold coins, if legal tender in the country of issue, are free of value-added tax; those that are not legal tender are subject to value-added tax at 4 per cent. The value-added tax on medallions and commemorative coins is 16 per cent; sales of gold bars and nuggets are exempt. It was announced that with effect from March 26 authorized banks and authorized depositories would be required to charge a special commission (negative interest) on any increases in balances in Convertible Guilder Accounts over the average credit balance in the period Febru- ary 1-February 14, 1973. Exempt were balances up to f. 100,000 held by physical persons, associations, societies, trusts, and foundations (up to f. 10,000 for accounts opened on or after March 30, 1973). The commission, to be trans- ferred monthly to the Netherlands Bank, was initially set by the Netherlands Bank at V4 of 1 per cent a week, but could 315 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS be set at any level up to 2 per cent a week. With effect from May 7, it was reduced to zero per cent. March 19. The Netherlands henceforth maintained mar- gins of up to 2% per cent in exchange transactions in the official market between the Netherlands guilder and the Dan- ish krone, the deutsche mark, the French franc, the Norwe- gian krone, and the Swedish krona; margins of up to 1 % per cent either side of the cross-parity continued to be observed for the Belgian franc and the Luxembourg franc. No an- nounced margins would be maintained for other currencies. The intervention limits for the U.S. dollar were revoked. March 27. The Netherlands Bank announced it had reached agreement with the authorized banks on the intro- duction of an ad hoc, noninterest-bearing cash reserve re- quirement against increases in banks' foreign guilder liabilities since December 31, 1972 or, at their option, since January 31, 1973. The reserve requirement was initially set at 50 per cent, applicable to the week ending April 4. It was canceled with effect from May 3. April 1. Authorized banks charged a handling fee of f. 25 a quarter, payable in advance, on all Convertible Guilder Accounts subject to the commission introduced on March 26. They discontinued the fee with effect from May 7. April 12. Joint Benelux measures were announced aiming at regulating the import from Japan of certain electronic products, including radios and television sets. Imports of such products from all non-EEC countries were placed under license on June 20. The restrictions were lifted after the sign- ing of an agreement between Benelux and Japan on Decem- ber 18. June. The Netherlands Bank resumed intervention opera- tions in the O-Guilder market, in order to prevent the pre- mium from exceeding 5% per cent. These operations were discontinued in August. July 2. The amount up to which payments to, and receipts from, nonresidents were exempt from the submission of an exchange control form was increased from f. 500 to f. 1,000. July 3. The physical exportation by authorized depositories of listed guilder bonds owned by residents was prohibited unless an individual license was obtained, which would be granted on application; previously, the exportation of nonres- ident-owned equities and bonds, domestic or foreign, was covered by a general license. July 13. Liquidity reserve arrangements for banks were announced. The liquidity reserve for each bank, to be held mainly in the form of Treasury paper, comprised a stated percentage of its short-term domestic liabilities plus a stated percentage of its long-term liabilities. For purposes of these arrangements, commercial banks' net foreign assets were not considered liquidities. Included among the liquidities subject to the new arrangements were balances held with the Nether- lands Bank, minus any fixed deposits or balances in S Ac- counts to be held with the Bank as a result of the application of the "5-million-guilder regulation." Foreign currency swaps specifically identified as liquidity by the Netherlands Bank could be included among the liquidities subject to the ar- rangement. July 16. For the implementation of an indemnification agreement with Egypt of February 25, 1971 it was prescribed 316 that 50 per cent of payments for direct imports from that country of commodities other than rice, raw cotton, and crude petroleum had to be made by credit to a special guilder account held by the Central Bank of Egypt with the Nether- lands Bank. 9 August 23. The coverage of the export financing arrange- ment between the Netherlands Bank and the authorized banks was increased from f. 600 million to f. 800 million. August 29. The Netherlands Bank curbed the recourse of the banking system to its advances and discount facility at the official interest rates. Limits on the average recourse during the period from the beginning of September 1973 to the end of February 1974 were set, which were related to each bank's volume of business; for recourse in excess of the limit a penalty commission of Y4 of 1 per cent a month was charged. This action was taken in part because international interest arbitrage had resulted in the financing of the commercial banks' net foreign assets by the Netherlands Bank. On Octo- ber 16 the penalty commission was reduced to % of 1 per cent a month. On December 13 the Netherlands Bank imposed a further curb on excessive recourse to its facilities by charging an additional penalty commission for recourse in excess of 75 per cent of the limit. This additional commission was initially set at ys of 1 per cent a month. It was halved with effect from December 24. September 1. The amount up to which balances in Convert- ible Guilder Accounts held by physical persons could bear interest was increased from f. 25,000 to f. 50,000 per person. The amount up to which nonresident physical persons could establish savings or time deposits with authorized banks also was increased from f. 25,000 to f. 50,000. September 17. The Netherlands established a central rate of f. 1 = SDR 0.298056 (f. 3.35507 = SDR 1), equivalent to 0.264874 gram of fine gold per Netherlands guilder. The 2% per cent and 1 % per cent margin arrangements were con- tinued. September 19. Measures were taken to prevent emigrating residents from obtaining the O-guilder premium on their guil- der bond holdings in an irregular manner. Previously, emi- grants acquired nonresident status upon departure and could immediately transfer all their assets abroad. Henceforth, emi- grants during the first three months of their residence abroad could not sell any listed guilder bonds in the Netherlands except against payment to the credit of a Convertible Guilder Account (i.e., at the official market rate of exchange), unless they could show they had owned the bonds at least three months prior to departure. September 26. The Netherlands Bank undertook swap transactions with the authorized banks, purchasing U.S. dol- lars spot and immediately reselling them forward. By October 6, when this policy was discontinued, the swaps amounted to f. 1.2 billion. In the first half of November expiring swaps totaling about f. 0.4 billion were renewed. Additional swaps were offered from December 13; as a result, the amount out- standing rose by f. 1.6 billion to f. 2.5 billion on Decem- ber 31. 9 This arrangement will be terminated when f. 6 million has been so credited. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS ANTILLES Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.471230 gram of fine gold per Nether- lands Antilles Guilder. l The gold content of the currency has been established at 0.411543 gram of fine gold. The central rate is Ant. f. 1.79000 per US$1, corresponding to Ant. f. 2.15936 = SDR 1, and the Netherlands Antilles avails itself of wider margins. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar. Exchange transactions between commercial banks and the public take place at Ant. f. 1.79 buying, and Ant. f. 1.81 selling, per US$1, plus a tax of %0 of 1 per cent on sales of exchange, making the effective selling rate for the U.S. dollar Ant. f. 1.8245 per US$1.2 The official buying and selling rates for certain other currencies are set daily on the basis of rates for the U.S. dollar abroad. The Bank of the Netherlands Antilles (the central bank) deals with commercial banks at interbank rates. The Bank does not normally deal with the public. Commercial banks require the approval of the central bank to invest or hold foreign currency balances. 3 Administration of Control Exchange licenses, where required, are issued by the central bank. Import licenses are issued by the Department of Econ- omy. The commercial banks are permitted by the central bank to provide foreign exchange for most current transac- tions without prior approval. The central bank may grant an exemption from the obligation of surrendering foreign ex- change, insofar as the assets or moneys concerned were ac- quired from nonresidents and are not being held in favor of or on behalf of, or for the account of, third parties who are residents; the foreign exchange may then be held or used freely until further notice or until revocation by the central bank. Prescription of Currency Payments may be made in any currency except Nether- lands Antilles guilders. Receipts may be accepted in any convertible currency except Netherlands Antilles guilders. For statistical purposes, all payments made by residents through the authorized banks in foreign exchange must be reported to the central bank. Nonresident Accounts an account desirable; balances in such accounts may not without central bank approval exceed Ant. f. 10,000. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain items, such as narcotics and explosives, are subject to license for public policy reasons. Imports into the islands of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curacao of nonvacuum- packed cereals (other than rice), certain wheat meal and wheat flour, certain fodder and fodder concentrates, and cer- tain other commodities, including alcoholic beverages, ciga- rettes, Pharmaceuticals, cement, and new or used automobiles, require a prior import license issued by the De- partment of Economy; for price control purposes only, some other goods are subject to licensing upon customs clearance. Payments for permitted imports may be made freely. Compa- nies with nonresident status normally finance their imports with their own foreign exchange. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles are not restricted. For most types of current invisibles remittances may be made freely through the authorized banks. Licenses are required, how- ever, for the purchase of travel exchange in excess of Ant. f. 180 a person for each day to be spent abroad and for certain personal remittances in excess of Ant. f. 2,500 each or in excess of Ant. f. 10,000 a person a year. Such licenses are freely granted when no illegal capital transfer seems to be involved. For payments representing interest on loans or net income from other investments, and for amortization of loans or depreciation of direct investments, licenses are granted on application, subject to verification of the facts. Nonresidents may take with them on departure any foreign currency which they brought in on arrival. The export of Netherlands Antilles banknotes is limited to Ant. f. 200 a person. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require licenses, which are usually granted. Exchange proceeds must be surrendered to an authorized bank within six months of shipment, with the exception of export proceeds received by companies with nonresident sta- tus. Nonresidents may freely open nonresident accounts in any foreign currency. Nonresidents (including foreign investment funds, etc., with nonresident status) are permitted to hold nonresident accounts in Netherlands Antilles guilders only if the authorized bank concerned considers that they have cer- tain interests in the Netherlands Antilles which render such 1 In the islands of Saba, St. Eustatius, and St. Maarten, the Netherlands Antilles guilder and the U.S. dollar circulate concurrently. 2 Foreign exchange purchased by resident companies with nonresident status for exchange control purposes is exempt from the exchange tax. 3 All currencies other than the Netherlands Antilles guilder are considered foreign currencies. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles (except those of firms with nonresident status) must in principle be surren- dered to an authorized bank within eight days of receipt, but in practice the public is allowed to hold foreign banknotes and coins, since the domestic currency and the U.S. dollar circulate concurrently. Travelers may bring with them checks, travelers checks, or banknotes in foreign currency in unlimited amounts. Each traveler may also bring in Ant. f. 200 in Netherlands Antilles banknotes. 318 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Capital Foreign investment in the Netherlands Antilles requires a license, which is, in general, granted if the investment is in the economic and social interest of the islands; the Investment Incentives Program, as amended, provides for duty-free entry of many commodities as well as tax facilities. New industrial companies primarily engaged in exporting may be granted nonresident status by the central bank, which confers on the company concerned exemption from exchange control (ex- cept in its transactions with residents), including exemption from the requirement of surrendering their foreign currency receipts. Such exemption may also be granted to investment companies, patent holding companies, shipping companies, and insurance companies. Outward flows of resident-owned capital are subject to control, and certain capital transactions by or on behalf of residents are restricted. Life insurance contracts between resi- dents and foreign insurance companies for a minimum term of ten years are licensed freely up to an amount which is fixed annually, depending on the foreign exchange position. Invest- ment by residents in real estate situated abroad requires a license. Investment in foreign securities (i.e., securities issued outside the Netherlands Antilles or payable or optionally payable in the currency of a country other than the Nether- lands Antilles) requires a license only when exceeding Ant. f. 2,500 a transaction or Ant. f. 10,000 a person a year. Investments by residents in officially quoted foreign securities (other than shares in mutual funds, investment in which is not permitted) are licensed freely up to amounts fixed annually, depending on the foreign exchange position. In considering applications by such residents as pension funds and other institutional investors, the central bank takes into account the merits of each case and, in particular, the limited opportunity for domestic investment; the bank may exert moral suasion, however, to discourage excessive outflows of resident-owned capital. Authorized banks may freely borrow foreign currency abroad from nonresidents (including residents with nonresi- dent status), or accept foreign currency deposits from nonres- NETHERLANDS ANTILLES idents, for relending to nonresidents or redeposit abroad; their borrowing from nonresidents for relending to residents is restricted for monetary policy reasons and banks require central bank approval to incur a net foreign liability position. Nonresidents are not normally permitted to acquire balances in Netherlands Antilles guilders. Local borrowing in domes- tic currency by nonresidents (including resident companies regarded as nonresidents for exchange control purposes) is restricted. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in the Nether- lands Antilles for numismatic and investment purposes; au- thorized banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents. Residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed without special permission to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry or coins, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the central bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports of coins by authorized banks, and for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Not for Redistribution NEW ZEALAND Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.99531 gram of fine gold per New Zealand Dollar, corresponding to $NZ 0.892857 = SDR 1, and New Zealand avails itself of wider margins. However, since July 9, 1973 no announced margins have been observed. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand adjusts the exchange rate for the U.S. dollar daily so as to maintain a given effective relationship between the New Zealand dollar and the curren- cies of the main trading partners. Except for the Australian dollar and the Fiji dollar, the rates for spot transactions in other currencies quoted by the New Zealand trading (com- mercial) banks, including the pound sterling, are based on the closing buying and selling rates of the previous day in Lon- don. The banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1973 were US$1.4349 and US$1.4219 per $NZ 1. The trading banks are permitted to conclude with their customers forward exchange contracts in U.S. and Canadian dollars and sterling for up to 12 months to cover trade trans- actions. Forward transactions in sterling and Canadian dol- lars take place at rates of exchange based on the closing buying and selling rates of the previous day in London. For- ward exchange contracts written in U.S. dollars are con- cluded at the relative spot rates, adjusted with a loading of US$0.0020 a mon th on contracts covering exports. U.S. dol- lar forward contracts covering imports are concluded at a loading of US$0.0005 on the spot rate. The Reserve Bank provides a facility whereby trading banks may obtain day-to-day cover for their net positions in these currencies, spot and forward. Contracts in other currencies may be cov- ered through the London or New York foreign exchange markets, against sterling or U.S. dollars. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Reserve Bank under powers delegated to its Governor by the Minister of Finance. The Reserve Bank in turn has given discretionary au thor i ty to the trading banks in New Zealand to approve applications for certain remittances of funds overseas. The Bank also is in charge of the controls over foreign direct investment in New Zealand. Export and import licensing is the responsibility of the Customs Department and the De- partment of Trade and Indus try, respectively. Prescription of Currency New Zealand has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Pay- ments to and from residents of countries other than New Zealand may generally be made or received in any foreign currency. 1 Payment to and from the New Zealand currency accounts held with banks in New Zealand by banks not domiciled in New Zealand or Rhodesia generally also is an acceptable form of payment. Nonresident Accounts The Reserve Bank supervises certain specified accounts in New Zealand of residents of other countries ("controlled ac- counts"). The accounts in New Zealand dollars of overseas banks may be used for the settlement of transactions with other countries, but they may only be funded from overseas or by amounts which would otherwise be remittable from New Zealand. Imports and Import Payments Imports are controlled through an annual Import Licens- ing Schedule, which groups imports into different categories to which various import procedures are applied. On a value basis, about 75 per cent of all private imports are exempt from licensing. The import categories included in the Schedule for July 1, 1973-June 30, 1974, are as follows: Category "E" (exempt) includes petroleum, lubricating oils, certain other raw materials, green coffee, cocoa beans, jute, many textiles, and printed books which may be imported without license. In addition, certain imports of Australian origin are exempt from licensing, irrespective of the licensing category to which they belong. 2 A "Basic" category comprises items for which licenses are granted by reference to qualifying licenses issued or actual imports in a previous licensing period. Category "C" licenses are granted on an individual basis on such criteria as essentiality, availability, and price; for some "C" items, how- ever, an initial allocation based on a previous period is pro- vided, while applications for further licenses are considered individually. Category "D" includes items of a type also pro- duced in New Zealand, for which licenses are issued only in exceptional circumstances. In addition, licenses for small or "token" amounts are issued (to the extent of 110 per cent of 1972/73 licenses for the same goods on a value basis, and at 100 per cent where they are issued for a specific quantity of goods) for "D" items and for certain approved classes of goods, imports of which are generally not permitted under the Schedule. "Administrative basic licenses" are issued auto- matically to ensure continuity of importation for certain regu- larly required goods that correspond to only part of an item code. All licenses issued may be used for imports from any source at the applicant's discretion. Imports from Rhodesia, how- ever, are prohibited. A degree of flexibility in the application of the Licensing Schedule is achieved through the use of Group Schemes (for Industry and Interchangeability Groups) that enable importers to transfer individual entitle- ments to a composite license, instead of holding licenses for separate items, and to import, up to the total amount, any item or combination of items in the group. 1 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than New Zealand currency. 2 Under the terms of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement that came in to force on January 1, 1966. 320 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution "No-remittance licenses" for imports outside the Import Licensing Schedule may be issued in special circumstances, viz., for advertising material supplied free of charge; gifts, passengers' baggage, replacement of faulty or damaged goods; trade samples supplied free of charge; and temporary imports. The trading banks have authority to make foreign ex- change in an appropriate currency available for payments in respect of all licensed imports and all imports that do not require a license. Payments for Invisibles The trading banks are permitted to sell exchange for over- seas payments up to established limits for many categories of invisibles, subject in appropriate cases to the submission of justifying documents. Payments beyond the established limits, and for categories not included in the commercial banks' permitted list, require the specific approval of the Reserve Bank; applications must be supported, where appro- priate, by justifying documents. Banks are authorized to sell foreign exchange for genuine foreign travel purposes without prior reference to the Reserve Bank up to $NZ 1,000 a person a month or part thereof, with a maximum of $NZ 4,000 a person in any 12-month period. Requests for amounts in excess of $NZ 1,000 a month or for a total of more than $NZ 4,000 in any 12-month period must be referred to the Reserve Bank. Larger amounts of exchange for any type of travel are authorized at the discretion of the Reserve Bank, which meets all reasonable requests for genuine travel pur- poses. In addition to the above allocations, banks in New Zealand and their branches or agents in London and Austra- lia may sell foreign currencies, without limit as to amount, to New Zealand travelers against these persons' privately held foreign funds. The remittance abroad of dividends, interest, and profits due to nonresidents is approved, subject to formal authenti- cation; for dividends and interest, the approval authority has been delegated to the authorized banks. Most contractual obligations incurred in the ordinary course of business also are normally approved, but each remittance requires ap- proval and new commitments such as royalty agreements with overseas licensors or overseas borrowing require the prior consent of the Reserve Bank. Allocations for remittances on account of maintenance and /or gifts are made on a yearly basis without discrimina- tion. Remittances by recognized New Zealand religious and charitable organizations or individuals operating as members of such an organization are not subject to any limitation. Allocations to individuals for religious and charitable remit- tances, other than of the type specified above, are approved by the Reserve Bank up to $NZ 100 a remitter, and applica- tions for larger amounts are considered on their merits. Any resident may freely make personal remittances up to $NZ 20 a year to any destination overseas except Rhodesia. Travelers may take with them up to $NZ 50 in New Zealand currency, regardless of destination. Banknotes taken out may not be in denominations larger than $NZ 5. Up to $NZ 4 of the permitted total may be in coins. NEW ZEALAND Exports and Export Proceeds With minor exceptions, all exports require export licenses. These are issued by the Customs Department and carry the condition that the net export proceeds must be surrendered to a trading bank in accordance with the prescription of currency regulations. General export licenses valid until De- cember 31, 1974 are issued to regular exporters. Payments for exports must, unless prior consent is obtained, be received within six months from the date of shipment. Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Certain items classified as strategic goods may only be exported when particular requirements have been met and subsequent to the issue of a permit to export. Temporary restrictions have been imposed on exports of tallow and specified types of mutton. Exports of beef and veal to the United States and cheddar-type cheese to the United Kingdom are subject to restraint. Under an export bonus scheme, manufacturers submitting evidence of exportation may receive a replacement import license of the same value as the imported raw material or components still subject to import control that are incorpo- rated in the exported goods, as well as, subject to certain conditions being met, an additional bonus license; goods im- ported against the bonus license may be used for the manufac- ture of goods for the home market or for export. The bonus license must not exceed the difference between the f.o.b. value of the goods exported and the c.i.f. value of imported materi- als and /or components used in manufacture by the exporter. Proceeds from Invisibles When remuneration for services provided or to be provided in New Zealand for overseas residents by New Zealand resi- dents (including corporate bodies ordinarily resident in New Zealand) is paid in the form of foreign assets, 3 their foreign currency proceeds must be sold to the New Zealand banking system; interest and dividends earned overseas from portfolio investment are excluded from this surrender requirement. If the remuneration is in a form other than foreign currency or a balance with an overseas bank, it must be converted into foreign currency before the surrender takes place. The disposal overseas by New Zealand residents of foreign income from other invisibles such as interest and dividends is permitted, but such income is not eligible for sale in ex- change for New Zealand currency, except that the foreign currency proceeds may be sold to a New Zealand bank. Travelers may bring into the country unlimited amounts of foreign and domestic banknotes and coins, provided that any New Zealand banknotes brought in are in denominations not exceeding $NZ 5. 3 The kinds of remuneration that are involved are (1) the payment or provision of any money; (2) the crediting of any sum in any account at any bank or with any person; (3) the acquisition or provision of any securities, or any real or personal property, or of any right thereto or interest therein (whether actual or contingent); and (4) any benefit, whether by way of doing work or the performance of services, or otherwise, under any contract agreement, scheme, or transaction of any kind (whether or not it is enforceable or intended to be enforceable by legal proceedings). 321 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEW ZEALAND Capital With the exception of certain capital issues outside New Zealand and certain overseas borrowings by corporate bo- dies, there is no restriction on capital receipts; applications to borrow abroad by companies operating in the finance and property sectors are not normally approved. To be eligible for repatriation, capital must have been initially transferred to New Zealand through normal banking channels or in some other way approved by the authorities, e.g., as imports of plant or machinery. Capital so transferred, including capital gains and capitalized profits, may be repatriated, after the formal approval of the Reserve Bank has been obtained. Overseas companies seeking to commence business in New Zealand require the approval of the Reserve Bank. Capital issues outside New Zealand by companies incorpo- rated in New Zealand require the approval of the Reserve Bank; overseas borrowing by such companies also requires prior approval. In order to encourage desirable types of in- flow of private foreign capital, forward exchange cover is provided for borrowings abroad by New Zealand companies and by foreign-owned companies that have received consent under the Capital Issues Regulations to borrow in New Zealand. Foreign borrowings under this scheme must be for a specific project which directly assists the development of New Zealand industry. Forward exchange cover is for the amount of the capital sum only and is normally limited to not less than $NZ 50,000 and not more than $NZ 1 million for each project. New Zealand subsidiaries and branches of overseas compa- nies must obtain the consent of the Reserve Bank if they wish to borrow in New Zealand, whether for long-term or short-term finance; the ratio between New Zealand and over- seas borrowing that is permitted is generally related to that between New Zealand and overseas equity holdings. 4 Non- resident persons or companies desiring to make a direct in- vestment in a New Zealand company through the purchase or exchange of shares are required to give notice of any offer made for such shares whenever the investment would result in the control by the offerer of 25 per cent or more of the New Zealand company's voting capital. Within two weeks of regis- tration the Minister of Finance must notify the offerer as to whether or not the offer is to be considered further. If further consideration is to be given, the Minister of Finance must give a final decision within six weeks of the date of registration. Emigrants to any destination other than Rhodesia may upon designation as nonresidents transfer the whole of their assets to their new country of residence. Applications for the remittance abroad of legacies from the estate of a New Zealand resident are normally approved in full. The authorities do not normally make exchange available to private persons or firms for the purchase of overseas securi- ties for portfolio investment. New Zealand Government bonds purchased overseas by New Zealand residents after September 5, 1969 may not be transferred from the United Kingdom to the New Zealand register. A New Zealand resi- 4 On March 15, 1974 the Reserve Bank reduced permitted local borrowing by wholly or partly overseas-owned nonfinance companies; the ceiling on borrowing for working capital purposes was set at the pre-June 1973 level, i.e., 10 per cent of annual turnover. 322 dent owning overseas securities is free to sell them to overseas residents for any foreign currency, which may be reinvested in other overseas securities, surrendered, or retained at the disposal of the New Zealand resident. With limited excep- tions, sales of overseas securities by one New Zealand resi- dent to another may be made only in exchange for other overseas securities or for any overseas currency. The only overseas securities that may be traded between New Zealand residents in exchange for New Zealand currency are those of any overseas country which were registered in the names of New Zealand residents on June 16, 1966 and for which scrip or other documents evidencing title were issued; the pur- chaser must lodge the share scrip with an approved deposi- tory (i.e., the Reserve Bank of New Zealand). These securities may also be sold for any overseas currency, in which case the proceeds must immediately be remitted to New Zealand through the banking system or reinvested in other overseas securities within three months and the resulting scrip depos- ited. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in New Zealand for numismatic purposes. Since the revocation in 1954 of the Gold Acquisition Notice, 1948, it is no longer necessary to offer gold to the Reserve Bank, and sales within New Zealand do not require Reserve Bank approval. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the per- sonal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Cus- toms Department; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the mone- tary authorities and industrial users. Commercial imports of gold jewelry are licensed restrictively. Changes during 1973 January 15. In a policy statement, the Minister of Finance set out the general approach of the Government to invest- ment in New Zealand by nonresidents, as well as the detailed criteria which would be applied to each proposal on a case-by-case basis. The degree and significance of participa- tion by New Zealand shareholders would be taken into ac- count. Overseas interests wishing to acquire control of an existing New Zealand firm would be required to demonstrate that their proposal would bring substantial new benefits to the New Zealand economy which would not be provided by continued local ownership. No approval would be granted where the interest of the applicant was merely to gain profits from property speculation or other forms of speculation, and where a proposal involved overseas ownership of land, deci- sions would be consistent with the Government's general land ownership policies. The Act was to be administered by the Reserve Bank. The Act came into force on July 30. April 2. A reserve assets ratio system of control over trading bank operations in New Zealand replaced the lending ceiling and guideline systems of control. The minimum liquidity re- quirement was expressed in terms of demand and time de- posit liabilities, without distinction between liabilities to residents and nonresidents. June 9. The fixed relationship between the New Zealand dollar and the U.S. dollar was discontinued; exchange rates would, until further notice, be determined daily, and the exist- ing margins around parity could be exceeded. The Reserve Bank approved, for quotation to the public by the trading banks, opening telegraphic transfer rates for the U.S. dollar of US$1.3768 buying, and US$1.3638 selling, per New Zealand dollar. June 14. It was announced that the export incentive scheme was to be narrowed to cover only processed products. The export market development incentive scheme was extended until March 31, 1977. An Export-Import Corporation would be set up. NEW ZEALAND June 14. The import license allocation for 1973/74 was increased from 110 per cent to 115 per cent of the 1972/73 issue, subject to some exceptions. In addition, licenses for a fu r ther 4,500 built-up cars were to be issued, doubling the allocation provided for in the original 1973/74 issue; the value of these additional licenses would be about $NZ 9 million. Further special licenses would be issued for goods for which a domestic shortage arose. June 15. The Reserve Bank provided details of the relax- ation of restrictions on borrowing in New Zealand by wholly or partly overseas-owned companies operating in New Zealand that had been announced in the budget statement. Under existing regulations, all wholly or partly over- seas-owned companies (25 per cent or more) had been permit- ted to raise a proportion of their working capital requirements in New Zealand. The permitted amount varied according to the nature of the business, but as a general rule a maximum of 10 per cent of annual turnover had applied. In fu tu re the Reserve Bank would take a slightly more liberal attitude on borrowing for this purpose. The rules which broadly related the amount of further funds which companies could raise to the proportion of their equity capital held by New Zealand residents had also been relaxed. Companies which were predominantly owned and also controlled by New Zealand residents (where more than 50 per cent of the voting shares were in New Zealand hands) would normally be permitted to borrow all of their require- ments in New Zealand. Companies with some New Zealand equity, but less than a majority interest, would be permitted to raise additional funds in New Zealand provided they had raised or were about to raise loan funds overseas. In future, a company which was 50 per cent New Zealand-owned would be permitted to raise funds in New Zealand, in addition to the working capital entitlement, equal to three times of the amount borrowed overseas, and a 25 per cent New Zea- land-owned company an amount equal to 60 per cent of the total overseas loans. Companies which were 100 per cent foreign owned would not be given additional access to New Zealand loan funds other than the slightly more liberal alloca- tion to assist them with their working capital requirements. The Capital Issues (Overseas) Regulations, 1965 would not be amended. It remained necessary for all companies which had 25 per cent or more of their voting shares held by "over- seas persons" to apply to the Reserve Bank for the necessary consent to borrow in New Zealand. The Reserve Bank would also treat in terms of the Government's new policy applica- tions submitted through the trading banks for increases in overdraft limits. June 15. The Reserve Bank announced that the Govern- ment had decided to discourage inflows of capital in the form of loan funds. Previously, the Bank had been agreeing freely to all applications to borrow overseas by companies operat- ing in New Zealand, provided the terms were reasonable and the maturity exceeded 12 months. In future, applications by companies operating in the finance and property sectors would be approved in exceptional circumstances only, whether they were New Zealand or foreign owned. Arrange- ments would be made to give foreign-owned firms already 323 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEW ZEALAND operating in these sectors greater access to New Zealand loan funds. June 20. Not for Redistribution NICARAGUA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.105237 gram of fine gold per Nicaraguan Cordoba, corresponding to C$8.44447 = SDR 1 or C$7.00 = US$1. The Central Bank of Nicaragua deals with the commercial banks in U.S. dollars, the intervention currency, at C$7.00 per US$1, buying and selling, and sells exchange to the Government at C$7.0525 per US$1. All exchange transactions between commercial banks and the public take place at the official rates of C$7.00 buying, and C$7.0525 selling, per US$1. The sale of foreign exchange by commercial banks to the public is subject to a stamp tax of V2 of 1 per cent, which results in an effective selling rate of C$7.0875 per US$1. No tax or commission is charged on the buying rate. Nicaragua accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sec- tions 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from July 20, 1964. Administration of Control The control system is administered by the Central Bank, which by law has the sole authority to buy and sell foreign exchange. This authority has been delegated to the commer- cial banks, and the Central Bank deals with the public only to the extent that it accepts deposits in foreign currency, and for purposes of monetary control. Certain agencies are also authorized to buy and sell foreign exchange, but they may sell exchange only for payments for invisibles. The Central Bank is responsible for classifying imports and determining any advance deposits required; no advance deposit requirements are in force at present. Prescription of Currency There is no prescription of currency, but the customs au- thorities have the power to prohibit an export if the currency stipulated for payment is not readily convertible into U.S. dollars in international markets. Payments to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras in respect of trade and invisibles may be settled in Nicaraguan cordobas through the Camara de Compensation Centroamericana, a clearinghouse established by the central banks of Central America to foster the process of economic integration of their countries. Pay- ments to Mexico may also be settled in Nicaraguan cordobas through the clearinghouse. The Central Bank does not accept banknotes of Costa Rica or El Salvador for compensation through the clearinghouse in excess of the following amounts a month: 66,250 Costa Rican colones and 400,000 Salva- doran colones. Imports and Import Payments All importers are required to be registered. There are two categories of registered importers: those who are permitted to import any kind of merchandise and those who may import only for their own industrial needs. Imports from all countries, except the other Central American countries, must be consigned to persons or firms holding a commercial license from the Ministry of Economy. Import licenses are not re- quired, but import transactions must be registered with the Central Bank by means of import declarations. All imports on credit and all prepayments for imports require approval by the Central Bank, which is normally granted only for capital goods, industrial materials, and other essential goods; when payment is not being made on sight of documents, an application for registration of the order must be submitted to the Central Bank. Imports of certain types of footwear and some pharmaceutical and veterinary supplies are prohibited, except when produced in countries signatory to the General Treaty for Central American Economic Integration. Payments for imports must be made with exchange pur- chased from banks.1 Payments are usually made by sight drafts. Letters of credit are mostly confined to imports from Japan. Central Bank approval is not required to open an import letter of credit. The banks are not permitted to sell exchange for import payments in advance of the arrival of the documents. The Central Bank may authorize deferred pay- ment or payment with funds derived from properly authenti- cated credits obtained abroad, provided that the imports are capital goods intended for development or production or for basic works complementary to production; such permission is at present limited mainly to industrial and agricultural machinery and, for certain industries, raw materials. Imports are not released from customs unless evidence is submitted either that payment has been made through a bank (con- stancia depago) or that acceptance has been made through a bank (constancia de aceptaciori). In the latter case, the Central Bank must also approve the importation on credit terms; this requirement does not apply to duty-free imports from mem- ber countries of the Central American Common Market. Most imports originating outside the Central American Common Market are subject to an import surcharge of 30 per cent of the applicable import duty. Certain commodities are subject to a compensatory consumption tax irrespective of their origin. Furthermore, most commodities are subject to a 5 per cent general sales tax, whether they are imported or domestically produced. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are not subject to license and may be made freely. Persons purchasing foreign currency to make payments for invisibles are required, for statistical purposes, to complete a declaration specifying the purpose for which the foreign currency obtained will be used. Domestic and foreign currency notes may be exported freely. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are not required, but a declaration to the customs authorities must be completed for statistical pur- poses. The exchange proceeds of exports do not have to be 1 However, by virtue of Decree No.l-L (effective March 1, 1963) the exchange proceeds from bananas, coconuts, copra, and coconut by-products exported through the ports of the region of El Cabo and the department of Zelaya may be used by the exporters to pay for commodities not produced in Nicaragua which they themselves import for the exclusive use of or consump- tion by the inhabitants of those areas. 325 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NICARAGUA surrendered; however, they may not be used to pay for im- ports (exchange for which must be purchased from a bank, with the exception noted in footnote 1). For certain agricul- tural exports (live cattle, beans, rice, com, and cottonseed), the Ministry of Economy can fix minimum export prices or temporarily prohibit their export in order to avoid domestic shortages. Exports of 17 commodities to countries outside the Central American Common Market are subject to a tax of 10 per cent of the f.o.b. value or of the reference value (aford). Proceeds from Invisibles The surrender of foreign exchange derived from invisibles is not required. Domestic and foreign currency notes may be imported freely. Capital Remittances on account of foreign capital and capital transfers by residents and nonresidents may be made freely under the general provisions of the Exchange Law of March 1, 1963 or under the Law on Foreign Investments of February 26,1955 (effective March 11,1955). Under the 1955 law, foreign investments approved by the Central Bank and registered are guaranteed the following privileges: repatria- tion of the registered capital; transfer of earnings, profits, or interest on the capital; and re-exportation of goods imported for investment. Commercial banks and private investment companies require the prior approval of the Central Bank for all borrowing abroad. Gold Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Nicaragua. Producers of gold sell their newly mined gold at free market prices to buyers abroad. The Central Bank purchases gold abroad for resale to domestic industrial and other users. Nonmonetary imports and exports of gold do not require import or export licenses but must be registered with the Central Bank and require prior government authorization. Commemorative gold coins were issued in 1967. Changes during 1973 During the year, various essential commodities were added to the list of those that may be imported on credit terms. Certain nonluxury goods, required to rebuild inventories, were also added. All these additions were revoked for 1974. January 6. An ad valorem levy of 10 per cent of the f.o.b. value was imposed on the principal exports. The levy was not applicable to exports to countries of the Central American Common Market. Subsequently, reference prices were estab- lished for some of these commodities. January 16. The amount of Salvadoran banknotes accepted for compensation through the Central American clearing- house was increased from 200,000 Salvadoran colones to 400,000 Salvadoran colones a month. On February 1, the limit on Guatemalan banknotes (Q 125,000 a month) was removed. February 13. Not for Redistribution NIGER Exchange System No par value for the currency of Niger has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the CFA Franc 1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transactions in French francs, the interven- tion currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de POuest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02, free of commission. Exchange transactions relating to foreign countries, i.e., countries other than France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area, take place in a dual exchange market at rates based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange rate for the foreign currency concerned in either the official exchange market or the financial franc mar- ket. Settlements eligible for the official exchange market are payments and receipts in respect of imports, exports, and most other current transactions, as well as all current pay- ments by or in favor of domestic and foreign public authori- ties and public bodies. All other settlements with foreign countries, as well as transactions in banknotes of foreign countries and banknotes issued by the BCEAO, take place through the financial franc market at freely fluctuating rates. The principal current payments and receipts channeled through the financial franc market are those relating to travel expenses, capital earnings, and workers' remittances. Ex- change rates for certain European currencies in the official market are based on par values and central rates; the effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar in this market is not confined within any announced margins. With the exception of those relating to gold, Niger's ex- change control measures do not apply to (1) France (as de- fined above) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account (Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mali, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Niger itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only with for- eign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Division in the Ministry of Finance and Sahara and Nomad Affairs which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Niger, and inward and outward investment. The BCEAO is autho- rized to collect, either direct or through the intermediary of banks, financial institutions, the Postal Administration, and notaries public, any information necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. All exchange transactions re- 1 The CFA franc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de POuest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Dahomey, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. lating to foreign countries must be effected through the BCEAO or authorized banks. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Economic Affairs in the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Commerce, and Industry, subject to the visa of the External Finance Division, except those for gold, which are granted by the Ministry of Finance and Sahara and Nomad Affairs. Import certificates for liberalized commodi- ties are made out by the importer himself and, when imports are payable prior to importation, are first approved by the External Finance Division. Prescription of Currency Niger is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Ac- count with the French Treasury; settlements with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Ac- count country. Settlements with all other countries are usu- ally made through correspondent banks in France in foreign currencies or in French francs through Foreign or Financial Accounts in Francs. Certain settlements with Nigeria, how- ever, are made through special accounts. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO banknotes may be credited to Financial Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Niamey by au- thorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the cred- iting to nonresident accounts of BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Trea- sury is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments All imports of commodities originating in Portugal or its overseas provinces, Rhodesia, or South Africa are prohibited. The import from any source of rice, paddy, hulled rice, wheat flour, butane gas, many types of fabrics, and certain footwear and plastic goods requires prior authorization, irrespective of whether an import license or import certificate is also re- quired. A similar regime applies to imports of sugar, except from member countries of the Common Organization of Afri- can, Malagasy and Mauritian States, and to imports of matches, except from countries of the West African Customs Union. Imports from France and the Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area of all goods other than those mentioned may be made freely without a license or certificate. Imports from other countries require either a li- cense or an import certificate. Imports of virtually all goods from Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, and EEC countries, many goods, from other former OEEC countries and their past or present dependent territories, and a smaller number of items from the United States and Canada are liberalized and require 327 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NIGER only an import certificate. Imports of nonliberalized goods from non-EEC countries outside the French Franc Area are made under global quotas in accordance with an annual pro- gram that is determined each year by the Ministry of Eco- nomic Affairs, Commerce, and Industry; the program generally reflects the requirements indicated by importers and is established in mutual agreement within a joint French-Nigerien Committee. Licenses for printed or im- printed cotton fabrics and for jute bags, however, are issued in proportion to duly substantiated imports from France of a specified quan t i ty of these goods. Goods not subject to quantitative restriction may be imported on an import certifi- cate, i.e., a declaration made out by the importer. The Societe Nationale de Commerce et de Production du Niger (COPRONIGER) has a monopoly over the import of specified commodities. These include wheat, wheat flour, green tea, and certain textiles. All import transactions with foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when valued at more than CFAF 25,000 c.i.f. Niger border. The import licenses or import certificates entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, provided that the autho- rized bank is satisfied that the import transaction is genuine and in accordance with the import title. Import certificates require the visa of the External Finance Division if the goods are payable before importation. Payments for In visibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Mo- naco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to the approval of the External Finance Division. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permit- ted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accru- ing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely when the basic transaction has been approved. Residents traveling on tourist trips to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equiva- lent to CFAF 100,000 a person a trip (CFAF 50,000 for children under ten), which may be taken up twice a year; any foreign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 remaining after return to Niger must be surrendered by sale to an authorized bank. The transfer of the full salary of a foreigner working in Niger is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period. Resident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a maximum of CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries, in addition to their travel allocation. Resi- dent travelers to other countries of the French Franc Area may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes but, when traveling to a French Franc Area country outside the West African Monetary Union, must declare these if they exceed CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may freely take out up to CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, 328 and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries, and foreign notes up to the amount declared upon en t ry ,2 or, if no declaration was made, up to CFAF 25,000; they may also take out freely any amount of travelers checks, etc., issued abroad in their name. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. All exports of rice and paddy require the prior authorization of the Directorate of Economic Affairs. Exports of millet and sorghum are pro- hibited unless covered by a shipping document in the name of the OPVN. Gum arabic may be exported only by CO- PRONIGER. With the exception of peanuts, peanut oil, peanut cakes, sisal, cotton, cottonseed, and certain imported com- modities, all of which require a license, all other exports to France (as defined above) and the Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be made freely. Exports to all other countries of domestic products and im- ported commodities require a license and an exchange com- mitment. Export proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Operations Account country must be collected and surrendered within two months of the date on which payment falls due; this date must not, in principle, be later than 180 days after arrival of the goods at their destination. All export transactions with foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their total value exceeds CFAF 100,000. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services, and all income earned in those countries from for- eign assets, must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date or the date of receipt. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or a bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins). Residents must surrender within eight days of entry any foreign currency in excess of CFAF 5,000. Capital Capital movements between Niger and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control ap- proval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. With the exception of those over foreign securities in Niger, these control mea- sures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member countries of the West African Monetary Union, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account. All investments abroad by residents of Niger require prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. 3 Foreign direct investments in Niger 4 must be declared to the Minister of Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to him. The full or partial liquidation of investments, whether direct or not, also requires prior declaration. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Nigerien investments abroad or foreign investments in Niger, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and the BCEAO within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct in- vestment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign secu- rities in Niger requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Nigerien Government, and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issuing or offering for sale in Niger has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constitut- ing a direct investment, which are subject to prior declara- tion, as indicated above; (2) loans contracted by authorized banks; and (3) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 2 million for any one borrower, provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the "normal" market rate and that the proceeds of the loan are immediately sold on the exchange market or debited to a Foreign Account in Francs.
