NIGER exempt from this requirement are loans constituting a direct investment, loans taken up by authorized banks, and any loans exempted by the Minister. Lending abroad is subject to prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. Foreign investments in Niger may be granted certain guar- antees and facilities under the Investment Code of July 31, 1968 (Law No. 68-24/PRN), as amended by Law No. 71-2 of January 29, 1971. Existing benefits accorded under the previous Investment Code (Law No. 61-21 of July 12, 1961) have been maintained. The new Investment Code provides for privileged or regu- lar treatment. The latter provides, for both new and existing enterprises, assurances, with respect to indemnities in the event of nationalization, and concerning nondiscrimination between Nigerien nationals and foreign nationals; tax exemp- tions will be granted to new investments. Privileged treatment is reserved for enterprises deemed to be of special importance to national economic development and falling within speci- fied categories of industrial activities. Such treatment may be accorded under two different regimes, the approval regime and the agreement regime. Gold Residents are free to hold gold in any form in Niger. They are also free to acquire and dispose of gold in any form in Niger. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the Minister of Fi- nance, which is seldom granted. Exempt from this require- ment are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufac- tured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) articles of gold up to a combined weight of 500 grams when carried by a traveler. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Changes during 1973 January 26. Not for Redistribution NIGERIA Exchange Rate System The currency of Nigeria is the Naira. The par value is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Nigerian pound, but a central rate has been established of 1.11973 grams of fine gold per naira, corresponding to N 0.793648 = SDR 1 or H 0.657893 = US$1. Nigeria avails itself of wider margins. The interven- tion currency is the U.S. dollar. The Central Bank of Nigeria twice weekly quotes rates at which it is prepared to deal in U.S. dollars and sterling with authorized dealers and the public; such dealings are for approved transactions and are on a spot basis only. The Central Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar are set at NIGERIA Imports and Import Payments Importers must be registered if they wish to obtain individ- ual import licenses. All imports from Namibia (South West Africa), Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, as is the import from all countries of certain specified commodities for health, safety, moral, or religious reasons; the import of cer- tain other commodities is also prohibited unless specific con- ditions have been complied with and these conditions are specified in the license authorizing such imports. Individual import licenses are required for certain goods from all sources, including rice, corn, and wheat, as well as products the export of which is subject to Marketing Board control (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below). Im- ports which are neither prohibited nor subject to specific licensing may be imported under open general license. A mandatory deferred payment period of 90 days after shipment has been established for most commodities; for these imports, payment may be made either 90 days after the date of the bill of lading or upon customs clearance, which- ever is later. 2 Certain official imports and other specified imports, however, may be settled at sight of shipping docu- ments. Capital equipment with a value in excess of N 100,000 must be imported on specified deferred payment terms. Au- thorized dealers may otherwise grant foreign exchange for authorized imports in accordance with these prescribed pay- ment terms, but not prior to customs clearance. Payment in advance of shipment requires the approval of the Central Bank and is not normally allowed. A "national reconstruction surcharge" of 5 per cent of the applicable import du ty is levied on virtually all imports. 3 Payments for Invisibles Most payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Payments for invisibles to residents of other countries are subject to indi- vidual approval; for some categories of invisibles this is granted by authorized dealers, either up to specified limits or up to the amount of the bill or invoice. Applications for payments that cannot be approved by authorized dealers and are not among those (such as profits and dividends) 4 that require approval by the Ministry of Finance are forwarded to the Central Bank, which gives approval for some types of payment, provided that tax and other requirements have been satisfied. However, certain delays may occur in the granting of the exchange. All insurance other than that for which facilities do not exist in Nigeria must be taken out with a company in Nigeria and all insurance companies operating in the country must reinsure with the National Insurance Cor- poration. Sixty per cent of ship charter payments must be 2 The 90-day requirement was abolished on April 1, 1974. At the same time, the prescribed minimum payments terms for imports of capital goods were made less stringent. 3 This surcharge was abolished on April 1, 1974. 4 Investment income exceeding 25 per cent of the amount accrued to nonresidents in 1972, and all such income accrued or accruing to nonresidents after 1972 are not transferable. On April 1, 1974 it was announced that the arrears from 1972 would be cleared in the new financial year and that new profits and dividends would be considered for remittance as they were desired. It was also stated that remittances of technical fees, management fees, and royalties would be permitted where it could be shown that these related to the import of modern technology. 332 settled in local currency, except when government-sponsored shipping companies are involved. Residents are entitled to a basic tourist travel allowance of fci 200 a person a year for travel outside Africa (N 100 a year a child, subject to a limit of fct 600 for any one family unit). Foreign exchange for this purpose may be sold to residents by authorized dealers. In addition, travel agents and shipping and airline companies in Nigeria may sell transportation tick- ets for any destination, except Rhodesia, against payment in Nigerian currency. The cost of services rendered by travel agents in respect of hotel accommodation, meals en route, etc., must be covered from the basic travel allowance. There is a separate basic allowance for travel within Africa. This allowance is N 50 a person a year (half of that for a child) where the return ticket is valued at less than £ 50, or up to the value of the ticket (subject to a maximum of N 200 for an adult a year or & 100 for a child) where the return ticket is valued at N 50 or more; in either case, the maximum for each family unit is N 600 in any calendar year. There is a separate basic travel allowance of N 300 an adult a year for pilgrimages, which may not be combined with the tourist allocation. Applications for nontourist travel must be submit- ted to the Central Bank. Foreign nationals residing in Nigeria may purchase annually foreign currency up to 50 per cent of their gross taxable earnings in Nigeria for all personal remit- tances (including insurance, education, and medical expenses, but excluding the basic travel allowance), up to a maximum of N 9,000 a person in any financial year. Applications in excess of this limit are examined on their merits by the Cen- tral Bank. Residents are permitted to take out the equivalent of their basic travel allowance in foreign currency notes and travelers checks; nonresident visitors may take out any foreign cur- rency notes and travelers checks that were declared upon entry, minus the amount converted locally into Nigerian cur- rency. The export of Nigerian currency notes and coins is prohibited. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most locally produced goods may be exported freely, under open general license, to any country except South Africa and Namibia (South West Africa), exports to which require individual licenses. Individ- ual export licenses are required for exports of cigarettes and tobacco, columbite, tin and by-products of tin, tantalite, un- refined gold, petroleum products, goods made wholly or partly of imported components, and products subject to con- trol by Marketing Boards (e.g., cocoa, cotton, cottonseed, benniseed, groundnuts, groundnut oil, palm oil, and palm kernels). The selling abroad of all export crops purchased by the Marketing Boards is the responsibility of the Nigerian Produce Marketing Company. The export of certain goods (African antiquities or works of art produced before 1918, objects that are being used or have been used in African ceremonies) is prohibited, except under prescribed condi- tions. The export of explosives, other than industrial explo- sives, and of certain foodstuffs is prohibited. Exports of ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution petroleum and petroleum products are subject to special ar- rangements. 5 Export proceeds must be surrendered, through a commer- cial bank, to the Central Bank within three months of ship- ment. Exports of petroleum and petroleum products, however, are exempt from the surrender requirements. For all exports, the exporter is required to submit an exchange con- trol declaration at the time of shipment. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in foreign currencies must be of- fered for sale to an authorized dealer, who is required to surrender them to the Central Bank. Persons entering Nigeria may freely bring in foreign banknotes. The import of Nigerian currency notes and coins is prohibited. Capital Except for the purpose of financing imports 6 or exports, permission from the Ministry of Finance is required for any individual, firm, company, or branch resident in Nigeria to borrow in any country outside Nigeria. Official agencies and state-controlled corporations require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance for any foreign borrowing. The per- mission of the Ministry of Finance is also required for bor- rowing in Nigeria (1) by any nonresident individual or company, and (2) by any company registered in Nigeria (other than a bank) which is controlled directly or indirectly from outside Nigeria. However, to enable entities mentioned under (2) to meet temporary shortages of funds, licensed banks in Nigeria may grant loans or overdrafts for periods not exceeding 14 days, or may increase the amount of any advance or overdraft by the amount of loan interest or bank charges payable thereon. General permission is also given for any loan, bank overdraft, or other credit facility to be ar- ranged to finance Nigerian imports or exports of goods. Banks have been directed to allocate 40 per cent of their total loans and advances to Nigerians. Residents of Nigeria may not deal in foreign currency secu- rities nor may they buy from or sell to nonresidents of Nigeria any security payable in Nigerian pounds or naira without the permission of the Ministry of Finance. The capital proceeds of securities registered in Nigeria and owned by nonresidents may be collected and negotiated through authorized dealers, provided that the prior permission of the Ministry of Finance is obtained. Remittances of cash gifts to nonresidents normally are restricted to the equivalent of & 100 for each transferor a calendar year in favor of charitable organizations outside Nigeria. Exchange for the transfer of certain assets by emi- grants or repatriates is granted on final departure from the country, but the transfer of the proceeds of assets realized to comply with the Nigerian Enterprises Promotion Decree, 1972 is subject to special rules. 5 On January 16, 1974 exports of groundnuts were suspended. 6 However, the taking up of suppliers' credit abroad (as distinguished from the mandatory deferred payments for imports) is subject to approval by the Ministry of Finance. NIGERIA Nonresidents intending to make direct investments in Ni- geria are invited to apply to the Ministry of Finance for "approved status," the granting of which means that sympa- thetic consideration will be given to future requests to repatri- ate the capital. The granting of "approved status" is not applicable to the purchase of shares on the stock exchange in Nigeria unless this forms an integral part of the approved investment project. Furthermore, this status is not normally granted when internally generated funds from profits, divi- dends, rents, or locally raised loans or bank credit are in- vested in local enterprises. With minor exceptions, foreign-owned companies and commercial banks operating in Nigeria must be incorporated in Nigeria. The repatriation of foreign capital requires approval from the Ministry of Fi- nance. Gold With the express permission of the Commissioner for Fi- nance, residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Nigeria for numismatic purposes. Residents other than the monetary authorities, producers of gold, and authorized industrial users are not allowed without special permission to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry or coins, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require specific licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authori- ties, producers of gold, and industrial users. Furthermore, the import of gold coins current in the United Kingdom requires a license from the Commissioner of Customs and Excise. Imports of gold coins and of gold and silver bullion are duty free when made by the Central Bank for monetary purposes; otherwise, such imports are subject to customs duty at 100 per cent ad valorem. Changes during 1973 January 1. A new currency unit, the naira, was introduced to replace the Nigerian pound at a ratio of 2 naira = 1 Nigerian pound. No appreciation or depreciation of the cur- rency was involved. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar became & 1 = US$1.52, based on the previous relationship of £N 1 = US$3.04. January 1. The Government acquired equity participation in the three foreign-owned commercial banks, raising total Nigerian participation in each to 40 per cent. January. The Nigerian Produce Marketing Company was taken over by the Federal Government. February 14. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, Nigeria established a central rate of 1.11973 grams of fine gold per naira, corresponding to N 0.793648 = SDR 1. Nigeria continued to avail itself of wider margins. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar remained unchanged. The exchange rate for sterling remained unchanged for the time being at N 1 = £ stg. 0.63. April 1. Profits and dividends declared by foreign-owned companies in 1971 and 25 per cent of profits and dividends declared in 1972 could be authorized for transfers, subject to 333 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NIGERIA the exchange control regulations, provided that applications had already been submitted before February 28, 1973. April 1. The Government announced that it would review the control procedure governing the remittance of royalties, patent fees, and management and technical fees, etc., and that there would be strict enforcement of the regulation requiring expatriate control companies to obtain approval from the Ministry of Finance to use local bank overdraft facilities. April 1. Import duties on many types of textiles and textile products were increased. Those on long staple cotton were reduced. April 1. Export duties on produce subject to control by Marketing Boards were abolished and were replaced by a produce tax with a maximum rate of 10 per cent ad valorem. April 1. It was announced that the Central Bank was taking steps to diversify its external reserves. April 2. The mandatory 180-day deferred payment require- ment, which had been applicable to most imports, was abol- ished. With the exception of certain official imports and other specified imports that could be settled at sight of shipping documents (to which cement and other building materials were now added), and imports of capital equipment with a value in excess of fct 100,000, imports became subject to a mandatory deferred payment period of 90 days from the date of shipment; import payments could be made either 90 days after the date of the bill of lading or after arrival of the goods in Nigeria (i.e., upon customs clearance), whichever was later. April 3. Guidelines were issued for the repatriation of for- eign-owned capital that was disinvested as a result of the promulgation of the Nigerian Enterprises Promotion Decree, 1972. Repatriation of capital would not be allowed where the assets, especially real property, were sold to non-Nigerians (in such cases the buyer should pay in foreign exchange from his non-Nigerian income) or where the sales proceeds were in- volved of real estate developed from capital generated locally (except, in the case of private property, on the final emigra- tion of the owner). In the case of sales arising from Schedule I of the Decree (sales of 21 categories of enterprises reserved wholly for Nigerians), or where the seller was emigrating from Nigeria, repatriation of capital would be permitted on the following conditions: up to & 10,000 on approval; for amounts over & 10,000 but under fci 150,000, in six-monthly installments of & 30,000 each; for amounts over & 150,000 the rate of repatriation would be negotiable in order to en- courage the reinvestment of a proportion of the capital sum; where the owner of an enterprise was leaving Nigeria perma- nently, requests for the repatriation of capital would be treated sympathetically, particularly when capital proceeds were required for the re-establishment of a business abroad. For Schedule II enterprises (35 categories of small to me- dium-scale enterprises which have been restricted to Nigerian ownership or, for the large enterprises in this category, where Nigerian participation is to be 40 per cent), the seller must reinvest at least 50 per cent of the sale proceeds in the expan- sion of the business and related activities; the balance could be repatriated according to the regulations applied to cases under Schedule I. Nigerian citizens, including naturalized aliens, would not be granted the above-mentioned facilities for external transactions of a capital nature except in the case of personal savings of a marginal nature for indigenous Nige- rians temporarily resident abroad. April 13. Decree No. 14 set up a Capital Issue Commission. It was to determine (1) the price at which the shares or debentures of foreign-owned companies in Nigeria were to be sold to the public, either through offer for sale or by direct issue; and (2) the timing and amount of any subsequent public issues of shares or debentures by the companies concerned. April 13. The Companies (Special Provisions) Decree, 1973 amended, with retroactive effect to 1968, the Companies De- cree, 1968, which required all foreign companies operating in Nigeria to incorporate locally. Certain companies could be exempted from local incorporation; they would then have the status of an unregistered company. June 11. An agreement was signed whereby Nigeria ac- quired a 35 per cent equity participation in a major foreign-owned petroleum company, with retroactive effect from April 1. July 5. The Nigerian Enterprises Promotion (Amendment) Decree No. 28 amended the Nigerian Enterprises Promotion Decree, 1972. Applications for exemptions under the latter could now be made at any time before the appointed day, i.e., before March 31, 1974. August. The issuance of export licenses for livestock was suspended. September. The issuance of import licenses for stockfish was suspended. October 2. The Nigerian Bank of Commerce and Industry, established on April 1, commenced business. The Bank's principal function was to provide loans to Nigerians wishing to take over, or acquire equity participation in, foreign-owned enterprises. 334 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Exchange Rate System Imports and Import Payments NORWAY 1 The par value is 0.124414 gram of fine gold per Norwegian Krone, corresponding to NKr 7.14286 = SDR 1. A central rate has been established of NKr 1 = SDR 0.145530 or NKr 6.87145 = SDR 1, corresponding to 0.129328 gram of fine gold per NKr 1, and Norway avails itself of wider mar- gins. Margins of 2% per cent are maintained for spot rates in the official exchange market between the Norwegian krone and the Belgian franc, the Danish krone, the deutsche mark, the French franc, the Luxembourg franc, the Netherlands guilder, and the Swedish krona. No announced margins are maintained for other currencies. On December 31, 1973 the buying and selling rates of the authorized banks for the U.S. dollar were NKr 5.715 and NKr 5.74, respectively. Forward premiums and discounts are left to the interplay of market forces. Authorized banks' forward transactions with non- bank residents must have a commercial basis. Norway formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from May 11, 1967. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Ministry of Com- merce and Shipping in cooperation with the Bank of Norway. The authority to approve most current payments has been delegated to authorized banks. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Ministry of Commerce and Shipping and, in certain cases, by the Ministry of Agriculture or the Ministry of Fisheries. Imports and exports of precious metals, and of semimanufactured articles thereof, are licensed by the Bank of Norway. Prescription of Currency Payments between Norway and Rhodesia are prohibited when they relate to imports, exports, or transit trade, and in all other cases are subject to special license issued by the Bank of Norway. Settlements with all other countries may be made in any convertible currency, including Norwegian kroner on Convertible Krone Accounts (see section on Nonresident Ac- counts, below). Nonresident Accounts The main type of nonresident account is the Convertible Krone Account. Such accounts may be held by residents of all countries. They may be credited with authorized payments to any country, with transfers from other Convertible Krone Accounts, and with proceeds from the sale in Norway of convertible currencies. They may be debited for authorized payments from any country to residents of Norway, for trans- fers to other Convertible Krone Accounts, and for purchases in Norway of any foreign currency. 1 In view of certain changes that took place on January 1, 1974 (see note at the end of this survey), this survey presents the position on that date. Most commodities do not require an import license. Indus- trial goods may be imported freely from the import free list area 2 upon presentation of the original invoice. Imports of certain agricultural products are restricted, irrespective of origin. There are two restricted lists for industrial goods for specified countries—one applicable to imports from Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, Poland, Roma- nia, and the U.S.S.R., and the other applicable to imports from Japan and the Republic of Korea; many of the goods on these lists are licensed automatically. Imports from Rho- desia are prohibited. A global quota list contains 9 quotas for agricultural prod- ucts for which imports are permitted up to fixed limits; these quotas apply to all countries. New and secondhand ships built abroad, other than ships that are 20 years old or older and certain categories of fishing vessels, may be imported freely, 3 but special permission is required in order to super- vise compliance with certain regulations regarding payments in advance of delivery. The import of a small number of commodities is prohibited for health and similar reasons, and certain goods (some grains, alcoholic beverages, equipment and materials for the fishing industry, pharmaceutical prod- ucts, and drugs) are imported by government monopolies. If no license is required or when an import license has been obtained, payment may be made without delay, provided that the method of payment is in conformity with the general rules (see section on Prescription of Currency, above). Payments for Invisibles Payments to any country except Rhodesia for all current invisibles, including income from capital and contractual am- ortization, may be made freely. Payments for any purpose to any country other than Rhodesia do not require verification by authorized banks, provided that these payments do not exceed the equivalent of NKr 500. The granting of exchange for travel purposes is not re- stricted. The basic exchange allowance for tourist travel abroad is equivalent to NKr 5,000 a trip for each person. For business travel, the banks may sell reasonable amounts. Each person leaving Norway may take with him up to NKr 800 in Norwegian banknotes, in denominations not exceeding NKr 100. Nonresidents leaving Norway may, in addition, export any foreign banknotes brought into the country by them. Exports and Export Proceeds Most goods may be exported freely to countries in the 2 All countries except Albania, Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, Japan, North Korea, Republic of Korea, Macao, Mongolia, Poland, Rhodesia, Romania, U.S.S.R., and North Viet-Nam. 3 Automatic authorization is not granted for imports from Albania, Peo- ple's Republic of China, Republic of China, Eastern Germany, Macao, Mongolia, North Korea, North Viet-Nam, and Rhodesia. 335 ©International Monetary Fund. All exports to countries outside the export free list area require an export license. Exports valued at not more than NKr 500 to any country are exempt from export license. Exports to Rhodesia are prohib- ited, with the exception of shipments for medical, humanitar- ian, or educational purposes. Payments must be received within 12 months of shipment and in conformity with the regulations (see section on Pre- scription of Currency, above). In principle, all exchange from exports must be surrendered. (The surrender requirement, which had been suspended in August 1971, was restored on February 11, 1972.) Proceeds from Invisibles In principle, receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. Each person entering Norway may bring in any amount in Norwegian currency, in denominations not exceeding NKr 100, and in other means of payment. Capital Inward transfers of capital and investments in Norway by nonresidents must be approved by the Bank of Norway. Out- ward transfers of capital require individual licenses; the granting of these licenses depends on the merits of the case. Licenses for outward transfers of proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments made in Norway by nonresidents are granted freely, and nonresident capital may be repatriated automatically. Payments for contractual amortization are also permitted freely. Most transactions in securities involv- ing nonresident interests are subject to approval. Norwegian securities denominated in Norwegian kroner and purchased by nonresidents from Norwegian residents by special permis- sion may be resold to Norwegian residents who will be granted licenses for the transfer of the proceeds from the sale; the purchase of shares of Norwegian banking and industrial firms by nonresidents is licensed restrictively on a case- by-case basis. Personal capital transfers, such as transfers relating to fam- ily loans, gifts, inheritances, legacies, dowries, emigrants' as- sets, savings of nonresident workers, and amounts in settlement of immigrants' debts, may be made freely. In general, resident-owned capital assets abroad, other than securities, real estate, and other authorized investments, have to be surrendered. Applications for capital transfers to make direct investments abroad are considered on their indi- vidual merits, and portfolio investment abroad is approved only exceptionally. Resident-owned foreign securities quoted on a recognized stock exchange, with the exception of securi- ties issued by foreign investment companies or mutual funds, are freely negotiable between residents, provided that the securities originally were acquired by a resident before Octo- ber 1, 1966, or that they were bought with the proceeds of foreign securities acquired before that date. Transactions in 4 All countries except Albania, Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, North Korea, Mongolia, Poland, Rhodesia, Romania, U.S.S.R., and North Viet-Nam. 336 foreign securities between residents against settlement in kro- ner require a license from the Bank of Norway if the securities were not included in an authorized broker's safe deposit for customers on May 31, 1969. Residents may upon application transfer capital abroad to purchase, for recreational purposes, real estate valued at up to NKr 60,000 a family; 5 such pur- chases by business firms, staff associations, etc., are approved liberally, also for higher amounts. In accordance with guidelines of December 13, 1971, the aggregate net foreign liability position of the banks may not deviate by more than NKr 260 million from the position at the end of October 1971, i.e., it must not be less than NKr 555 million or more than NKr 1,075 million. On May 23, 1972, however, these guidelines were modified slightly to allow the banks some additional flexibility in de- termining their net liability position. There are limits on the commercial banks' borrowing abroad. Thus, they may bor- row funds or accept deposits in foreign currency from foreign banks within a ceiling fixed at 20 per cent above their total foreign borrowing at the end of December 1970. Residents other than banks require the prior approval of the Bank of Norway before raising loans, accepting other forms of capital, or incurring or providing guarantee obliga- tions abroad. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Norway. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Bank of Norway; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authori- ties and industrial users. No customs duties or other charges or fees are payable on imports or exports of gold bullion and gold coins not contained in jewelry. Administration of Control There is neither exchange control legislation nor an ex- change control authority in Oman. ports or re-exports of live animals and foodstuffs may be prohibited in times of shortage in Oman. Exports of crude petroleum to the Netherlands and the United States have been suspended. All other commodities may be exported freely. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surrendered, and they may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Not for Redistribution PAKISTAN Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0744103 gram of f ine gold per Pakistan Rupee, corresponding to PRs 11.9428 = SDR 1, and Paki- stan avails itself of wider margins. The U.S. dollar is the intervention currency, and the State Bank of Pakistan (the central bank) maintains official rates of PRs 9.90 buying, and PRs 9.9156 selling, per US$1. All transactions in foreign exchange must be conducted through authorized dealers, whose transactions with the general public must be effected at rates authorized by the State Bank. Authorized dealers in Pakistan are permitted to cover their requirements of speci- fied currencies in foreign exchange markets abroad. They may also cover their permitted transactions in specified currencies against U.S. dollars or Pakistan rupees, either spot or forward for a limited period, with their agents in the countries con- cerned. Administration of Control The State Bank has delegated to 21 banks and financial institutions authority to deal in all foreign currencies, to su- pervise surrender requirements, and to sell exchange for spec- ified purposes w i th in limits prescribed by the State Bank. The Chief Controller of Imports and Exports is responsible for the issue of licenses and the implementation of import and export policies. Certain foreign trade transactions are conducted through the Trading Corporation of Pakistan, Ltd., a state trading agency. Prescription of Currency Exchange receipts and payments abroad must be effected through an authorized foreign exchange dealer, in any con- vertible currency or in Pakistan rupees from or to nonresident rupee bank accounts. No exchange control is exercised over transactions w i th Afghanistan, and settlements are made in Pakistan rupees or afghanis. Trade transactions under "barter" agreements are settled through special accounts in inconvertible currencies. Trade in specified commodities w i th Bulgaria, the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, North Korea, Poland, Sweden, and the U.S.S.R. is settled through clearing accounts maintained in inconvertible Pakistan rupees. Pay- ments to and from Iran and Turkey relating to visible trade (excluding border trade, Iranian oil, and defense materials) are settled through clearing accounts maintained by the re- spective central banks in U.S. dollars. There is a special trade and payments arrangement with the A.B. Sukab Company of Sweden. Payments between Pakistan and the Republic of China, India, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are suspended. Nonresident Accounts The accounts of individuals, firms, or companies resident in countries outside Pakistan are designated as nonresident accounts. * Authorized banks are permitted to open nonresi- 1 Different rules apply to nonresident rupee accounts of individuals, firms, or companies, on the one hand, and to nonresident rupee accounts of banks, on the other hand. dent accounts for nonbank nonresidents w i thout the prior approval of the State Bank where the accounts are to be opened with funds received from abroad through banking channels or with rupee funds which have been accepted for remittance abroad. Debits and credits to nonresident ac- counts for specified purposes can be made by authorized banks w i thout the prior approval of the State Bank. Accounts of residents of India, other than the accounts of the Indian High Commission and its personnel, are blocked. Pakistan nationals residing abroad and foreign nationals, whether resident abroad or in Pakistan, may open foreign currency accounts with banks in Pakistan without prior ap- proval of the exchange control authorities. There are no re- strictions on the currencies in which the accounts may be denominated and credit balances may be freely transferred abroad. However, a deposit holder wishing to make payments in Pakistan must first convert the foreign exchange drawn from his account into Pakistan rupees. If a Pakistan national holding such an account returns to Pakistan, he may retain the account unless his stay exceeds six months; thereafter the account must be closed and the exchange surrendered. Banks in Pakistan receiving such deposits must sell the foreign ex- change to the State Bank. Imports and Import Payments Permitted imports are classified in two lists: a free list and a tied list. Items on the free list may, in principle, be procured w i thout restriction while items on the tied list may be pro- cured only from tied aid and barter trade sources. Items not on the two lists are effectively prohibited for import except under certain circumstances by export industries, as men- tioned below. Largely for statistical reasons, all imports re- quire licenses, except goods imported by the Central Government for defense or other purposes, goods in transit, personal baggage, certain imports over the land routes from Afghanistan and Iran, and certain other items permitted un- der a M in is t ry of Commerce Notification (No. 335/260/24 of June 12, 1951). Licenses for imports of a value up to PRs 500 incur no fee, but licenses above that amount up to PRs 100,000 are subject to a fee of 1 per cent of the value of the license and licenses above PRs 100,000 are subject to a fee of 2 per cent payable at the time of the issue of the license. The basic two-list import regime is subject to certain sup- plementary qualifications, the most important of which are as follows: (1) Imports from the Republic of China, India, Is- rael, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, as are im- ports of goods originating in these countries but shipped from third countries. (2) In order to facilitate barter trading and aid utilization and to secure economies through bulk imports, the import of specified items, including seven categories of iron, steel, and metals, is restricted to the Trading Corpora- tion of Pakistan, Ltd., 2 unless the items are procured with 2 With effect from January 10, 1974 the import of su lphur and wood pu lp ceased to be channeled through the Trading Corporation. 339 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PAKISTAN U.S. aid. (3) The import of certain other items, including fertilizers and specified electrical and rail equipment (all from tied sources only) is restricted to the public sector. (4) In conformity with Regional Cooperation for Development ar- rangements between Iran, Pakistan, and Turkey governing procurements from joint industrial ventures, the import of some ten items, including six chemical items, is restricted to procurement from Turkey. (5) Special provisions exist for the import for export industries of tied list items from nontied sources and items not on the two import lists. (6) Private sector importers, other than those importing goods for per- sonal use, who apply for import licenses for goods valued at PRs 20,000 or more must be members of approved trade organizations. (7) Licenses for permissible imports of indus- trial plant and equipment are restricted to a c. & f. value of PRs 500,000 for imports against cash, PRs 1 million for imports under tied credit, and PRs 2 million for imports under bilateral payments arrangements (larger plant and equipment are to be procured under the auspices of the fi- nancing institutions and with the approval of the Ministry of Industries). Except for imports of books, periodicals, and newspapers, irrevocable letters of credit must be opened for all commercial imports. Remittances are not normally permitted before ship- ping documents are received, but in special cases, e.g., ma- chinery and other capital goods for which deposits have to be made with foreign manufacturers, the State Bank may autho- rize advance payments for a part of the value of the goods. No import payments are permitted to be made for goods originating in or consigned from the Republic of China, In- dia, Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa. Except for specified items, including items on the tied import list, the State Bank requires banks to take a m in imum margin of 25 per cent against import letters of credit. Imports of all commodities, except machinery, tractors and tractor parts, spices, and betel nu ts and leaves, are subject to a "flood relief surcharge" of 25 per cent of the applicable rate of customs du ty. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are controlled by the State Bank and in many cases require its prior approval. No remittances are permitted to be made to the Republic of China, India, Israel, or Rhodesia. Under authority delegated to them, au- thorized dealers may sell exchange or make remittances in accordance with detailed regulations. Certain remittances of a personal nature are subject to annual quotas, but most are approved at the discretion of the State Bank. Remittances by Pakistan nationals to their families abroad require special authorization. Payments for invisibles connected with imports are gener- ally given the same treatment as that accorded the underlying trade transaction. Transport insurance must, except with re- spect to certain aid shipments, be taken out with insurance companies in Pakistan. The remittance of dividends declared out of current profits is allowed freely to foreign shareholders where the investment was made with the Government's approval. Profits of 340 branches of foreign companies may be remitted freely to their head offices. The same applies to head office expenses charged to a branch's profit and loss account and accepted for tax purposes by the Pakistan income tax authorities. On an ad- ministrative basis, the State Bank approves an exchange allo- cation of US$500 to each applicant for each journey abroad, irrespective of the purpose. Additional exchange for business travel, medical treatment, education, and sponsored cultural trips may be granted on an individual basis. There are also specific allowances for pilgrims' travel to Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern countries. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency not exceeding the amounts they brought in and PRs 20 a person in Pakistan currency notes. Residents leaving for Afghanistan may take out PRs 50 in Pakistan currency notes and coins and any amount of Afghan currency. Persons traveling on Category "A" visas (to India) may not take out any Pakistan currency notes or coins. Residents traveling to other foreign destinations may take out PRs 20 a person in Pakistan cur- rency and any amount in foreign currency notes and travelers checks granted by authorized banks under permissions issued by the State Bank. Pakistan currency notes in denominations of PRs 50 or higher may not be taken out. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of specified commodities to any destination, and all exports to the Republic of China, India, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. 3 Exports of most other commodities are allowed freely. However, export licenses are required for some 24 listed items, as well as for certain types of sports goods and a few other items subject to minimum export prices, and for mill-made cotton piece goods and ready-made garments intended for export to the United Kingdom. Exports of raw cotton are channeled through the Cotton Export Corporation. The Trading Corporation of Pa- kistan, Ltd., has a monopoly over exports of other specified products. The State Bank exercises control over exchange receipts and requires a declaration by the exporter that, when pay- ment in accordance with the prescribed method is received, he will surrender the exchange within a certain period of time. After making certain that the exporter's declaration meets all conditions, the authorized dealer certifies the export form for shipment. Exporters are obliged to collect and surrender ex- port proceeds within four months; the State Bank may, on the merits of each case, allow an extension of this period. The surrender of Afghan currency accruing from exports to Af- ghanistan is not required. Under a Pay-As-You-Earn Scheme, certain industrial units are permitted to utilize up to 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value of exports for the servicing of suppliers' credit on imports of plant and machinery. 4 Export duties are levied on a range of export items includ- ing raw cotton, cotton yarn, rice, wool, hides and skins, fish meal, and leather shoes. 3 Prohibited exports include beef, mu t ton, grains, flour, dairy products, vegetables, poultry, blood meal, meat meal, corn gluten meal, sesame oil cake, certain citrus fru i ts (unless graded), and certain hides and skins. 4 This scheme was revised early in 1974. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Proceeds from Invisibles With the exception of Afghan currency, which may be retained, incoming foreign exchange derived from invisibles must be surrendered within one month. Persons traveling on Category "A" visas (from India) may not bring in any Pakistan currency notes or coins. Other travelers may bring in PRs 20 in Pakistan currency notes a person and Rs 5 in coins that are legal tender in India; Paki- stan currency notes in denominations of PRs 50 and above may not be brought in. There is no limitation on the import of other currency notes and coins. Capital Investments in Pakistan by nonresidents are subject to approval. In order to encourage industrial development in Pakistan, the Government follows a liberal policy toward foreign entrepreneurs, who can, with the approval of the Government, start any industry in the private sector without any conditions being laid down regarding the participation of local capital. It is, however, expected that local rupee expen- diture will ordinarily be met from local equity capital. 5 Repatriation facilities are as follows: (1) Foreign capital invested in approved industries established after September 1, 1954 may be repatriated at any time thereafter to the extent of the original investment, and current profits may be trans- ferred without restriction, to the country of origin of the capital. (2) Profits that are reinvested in approved industrial projects with the approval of the Government may be treated as investment for the purpose of subsequent repatriation. (3) Appreciation of any capital investment under (1) and (2) may also be treated as investment for the purpose of subsequent repatriation. These repatriation facilities do not apply to the purchase of shares on the stock exchange unless the purchase is an integral part of an approved investment project, or to capital invested in Pakistan before September 1, 1954. Guarantees provide for just and fair compensation in the currency of the country of origin of the investment in the event of nationalization of any project. Foreign nationals in Pakistan or abroad may register their investments in National Prize Bonds issued by the Govern- ment of Pakistan, and thus facilitate repatriation at any time of the principal and the prize winnings. Transfers of capital abroad by resident nationals are, in general, not permitted; the purchase of foreign securities by resident Pakistanis requires approval by the State Bank and is seldom permitted. Detailed rules govern the transfer of capital by persons emigrating or retiring from Pakistan, de- pending upon the nationality of the person concerned and the country or monetary area to which the transfer is to be made. Foreign nationals temporarily residing in Pakistan are treated as nonresidents for purposes of transfer of securities. General 5 The Government announced that, with effect from January 1, 1974, it was acquiring the ownership, management, and control of, and all shares held by private persons in Pakistan in the capital of, domestically owned banks, companies marketing petroleum products, and maritime shipping companies. Foreign-owned shares in these enterprises, and foreign-owned banks and petroleum marketing companies operating in Pakistan were not affected by these measures. However, foreign banks would not be permitted to establish new branches in Pakistan. PAKISTAN permission has been given in connection with the issue, sale, or transfer of securities issued in Pakistan in favor of nonresi- dents, provided the securities are registered in Pakistan and investment is made on the basis of nonrepatriation of capital and return. Pakistan securities held by nonresidents may be transferred to other nonresidents against payment abroad with the same facilities in respect of remittance of capital and earnings as those obtained by the transferor. A general license has also been issued allowing foreign nationals temporarily resident in Pakistan to make investments in units of the Na- tional Investment Trust, subject to certain stipulations. Exports of securities are subject to approval. Proceeds ac- cruing from the liquidation of nonresident capital assets that are not covered by repatriation arrangements may be credited to blocked accounts. Subject to approval by the State Bank, balances on blocked accounts may be invested in approved government securities payable in Pakistan rupees or placed on time deposit with banks. A general permission allows Pakistan nationals resident abroad to acquire securities in Pakistan by remittance of foreign exchange or to the debit of their nonresident accounts in Pakistan; dividends or interest thereon, as well as the pro- ceeds upon sale, must be credited to nonresident accounts and cannot normally be transferred abroad. Pakistan nation- als require the prior approval of the State Bank to sell mov- able or immovable assets held abroad, and the liquidation proceeds must be repatriated to Pakistan through normal banking channels. Gold The export and import of gold is prohibited unless autho- rized by the State Bank. No such permission is granted, but there are no restrictions on the internal sale and purchase of nonmonetary gold. Export taxes are imposed on gold, silver, platinum, manganese, other minerals, bananas, coconuts, scrap metals, pearls, animal wax, nispero gum, ipecac root, and rubber. Exports of wheat flour, firearms, and ammunition are prohibited. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except for most payments to Rho- desia. A travel tax of 4 per cent is levied on air and sea tickets bought in Panama or on such tickets purchased for travelers commencing their journey in Panama. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents, except for most payments to Rhodesia. Several foreign-supervised banks are authorized to conduct business only with nonresi- dents. Gold Residents may freely hold gold in any form at home and abroad and may freely negotiate gold in any form with resi- dents or nonresidents at home and abroad. Imports and ex- ports of gold in any form other than jewelry carried as personal effects by travelers are subject to license if made by residents other than the monetary authorities; import licenses are issued freely by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry and export licenses by the Ministry of Finance and Treasury. Exports of unworked gold produced in Panama are subject to an export duty of 1 per cent ad valorem, and exports of gold coins (other than U.S. coins, which are exempt) to a duty of Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.736662 gram of fine gold per Panama- nian Balboa, corresponding to B 1.20635 = SDR 1 or B 1.00 = US$1. Panama does not avail itself of wider margins. U.S. currency notes and coins circulate freely in Panama, and local currency is represented only by limited amounts of silver balboas and subsidiary coins and a commemorative 20- balboa silver coin. Exchange transactions by commercial banks are based mainly on New York market quotations. Panama has no exchange restrictions on foreign payments, with the exception of a prohibition on payments to Rhodesia other than those for pensions or for humanitarian, educa- tional, medical, or informational purposes. On November 26, 1946, Panama notified the Fund that it accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Most import and export licenses are issued by the Price Regulation Office, a semiautonomous institution of the Pana- manian Government. The Price Regulation Office is responsi- ble for the implementation of restrictions on imports of commodities that compete with national production and on certain exports. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry determines the import quotas for commodities listed in trade agreements, and the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Development, jointly with the Price Regulation Office, those for agricultural commodities temporarily in short supply. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Quotas are imposed on imports of commodities competing with present or pro- spective domestic production; some of these are not being licensed. Import licensing also applies to imports of various foods. Other imports are free. Payments abroad may be made freely. A tax of 6 per cent on the f.o.b. value is levied, in addition to import duty, on imports of all dutiable goods other than specified pharmaceutical products and foodstuffs, for which the rate is 2% per cent and 3% per cent, respectively. Authorization is required for exports of coffee in any form, PARAGUAY Exchange Rate System On March 1, 1956, a new par value for the Paraguayan Guarani was established by Paraguay w i th the Fund. How- ever, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. Exchange transactions take place in a dual exchange market. Transactions in the official exchange market (mercado libre de cambio) must be carried out through the Central Bank (for all government transactions) or an authorized commercial bank; these transactions take place at a rate of 0 126 per US$1, subject to taxes and commissions. Transactions in the fluctuating free market (mercado libre fluctuante de cambio) are conducted through licensed foreign exchange houses at a f luc tua t ing rate which on December 31, 1973 was about 0 131 per US$1 buying, and 0 134 per US$1 selling. All purchases and sales of exchange by banks are subject to a tax of 1V2 per cent, except transactions w i th foreign embassies and diplomats; transactions w i th meat packing plants; and transactions relating to investments in Paraguay that are covered by Law No. 216 of November 9, 1970. In addition, banks charge a commission of 2 per cent on all sales of foreign exchange. There are no forward ex- change facilities. The transactions settled in the official exchange market are exports and imports (except unrecorded border trade), trade-connected current invisibles, all government transac- tions, registered private capital transactions, and related profit remittances. All other transactions are channeled through the fluctuating free market, unless settlements are effected under reciprocal credit agreements w i th LAFTA countries. The authorized banks, but not the exchange houses, are required to sell 30 per cent of their gross foreign exchange receipts in specified currencies * to the Central Bank. Administration of Control The Central Bank of Paraguay determines foreign ex- change policy and supervises the foreign exchange transac- tions carried out by commercial banks and authorized foreign exchange houses. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements. Pay- ments between Paraguay and Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Co- lombia, Mexico, and Peru may be made th rough accounts which the Central Bank of Paraguay and the other central banks concerned ma in ta in w i th each other, within the frame- work of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few commodities are prohibited. 2 Certain 1 Argen t ine pesos, Belgian francs, Brazilian cruzeiros, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 These include sugar, rice, f lour, and certain other agricultural products and foodstuffs, certain petroleum products, cement, certain textiles, and certain wire and wire products. 344 other items require an import license; these are ma in ly narcot- ics and arms and ammun i t ion. All other imports are free of quan t i ta t ive restriction and licensing. Imports of most com- modities are subject to an advance deposit of 100 per cent of the f.o.b. value, which is retained for 120 days, or if the deposit is made after the date of shipment, 180 days, or for nonexempt commodities imported through the Spanish free zone in Paraguay, 90 days. Advance deposits are not required for, inter alia, public sector imports, imports by foreign diplo- mats and by foreign staff of certain international organiza- tions, fuel and petroleum derivatives, certain machinery, agricultural equipment, wheat, and newsprint from any source, imports from neighboring countries (including Uru- guay), and imports from other LAFTA countries of items included in the Paraguayan concession list (the National List). The Central Bank has authority to grant exemptions on a case-by-case basis. Surcharges, calculated on the c.i.f. value, are payable on most imports even if no foreign exchange payment takes place. An import surcharge of 36 per cent applies to most general imports from any source; however, for goods origi- nating in LAFTA countries and included in the Paraguayan National List the rate ranges from 3 per cent to 30 per cent, and for certain other LAFTA goods (mainly pharmaceuti- cals) in a special list the rate is 8 per cent. Fuel derived from petroleum is subject to a surcharge of 15 per cent (10 per cent for neighboring countries, including Uruguay). There is an additional surcharge of 5 per cent on imports from all sources of telephone and telegraph equipment, television receivers, and radios and record players and their parts and accessories. Commodities that are exempt from surcharge generally are also exempt from advance deposit. These surcharges are collected by the banks at the time of delivery of the documents for customs clearance or when the import payment is made, whichever is earlier. The following are the principal exemptions from surcharge: wheat; crude petroleum; equipment for petroleum exploration and exploi- tation; agricultural tractors; imports for the Government; imports for religious, charitable, cultural, or educational pur- poses; imports by foreign diplomats and certain international organizations; Spanish agricultural and industrial machinery and implements imported through the Spanish free zone in Paraguay; agricultural machinery and equipment for the Na- tional Wheat Program; books and periodicals; and imports for investments under the new Capital Investment Law No. 216. Imports of investment goods and of raw materials for export industries receive exemption on a case-by-case basis. In addition to the above surcharges, a tariff surcharge is levied on certain imports by virtue of Law No. 1334/67, which implemented Decree-Law No. 451 of March 31, 1967, and Law No. 10 of August 29, 1968. On goods that are not exempt, it is 12-24 per cent (8-16 per cent for certain goods subject to LAFTA concessions) and is levied on the c.i.f. value, which is calculated as follows: the f.o.b. value plus 10 per cent for imports from neighboring countries and the f.o.b. value plus 20 per cent for imports from other countries.
