Not for Redistribution PERU Exchange Rate System On December 18, 1946, a par value for the Peruvian Sol was established by Peru with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. There is a dual exchange market with two fixed ex- change rates, an exchange certificate market rate applying to all trade transactions and specified nontrade transactions, including the principal capital movements, and a draft market rate for services and most other nontrade transactions. The foreign exchange requirements of the public sector are met entirely through the certificate market. Export proceeds must be converted into exchange certifi- cates, which are valid for three days and are issued by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru in U.S. dollars only. These exchange certificates may be used, only through the interme- diary of commercial banks, to pay for imports (f.o.b.) and for certain nontrade transactions. Generally, no exchange certifi- cates are issued against export proceeds surrendered by the public sector, nor are certificates used to cover foreign pay- ments of the public sector, since normally the Central Reserve Bank buys and sells foreign exchange direct from and to government agencies at the certificate rate. When approved applications for certificates exceed the supply, the Central Reserve Bank sells foreign exchange at the certificate market rate without any delay. All foreign exchange receipts that are not required to be surrendered at the certificate rate must be sold in the draft market, in which only the government- owned Banco de la Nation and its authorized agents operate. Access to the draft market is controlled and purchases of foreign exchange are permitted only for specified payments not eligible for exchange at the certificate rate. The banks are required to quote a single rate for buying and selling certificates, but they may charge a commission of y4 of 1 per cent, buying and selling, on transactions in the draft market. On December 31, 1973 the certificate market rate was S/. 38.70 per US$1 (buying and selling) and the draft market rate was S /. 43.38 buying and S /. 43.50 selling, per US$1. A stamp tax of 1 per cent is payable on most outward remittances. Peru formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from Febru- ary 15, 1961. Administration of Control Export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Foreign Trade in the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. * The Cen- tral Reserve Bank controls the use of certificates for import payments. It also authorizes the use of certificates for non- trade transactions; for profit remittances by branches of for- eign companies, prior approval by the Ministry of Economy and Finance must be obtained in addition. All imports of, and most payments for services by, the public sector require the 1 On January 1, 1974 the Government established the Ministry of Com- merce, to be responsible for activities formerly supervised by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce; the latter was renamed the M in is try of Indu s t ry and Tourism. approval of the Board for Foreign Transactions of the Public Sector and a resolution of the Ministry of Economy and Finance; a similar Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector approves import payments by the private sec- tor on the basis of import authorizations issued by the compe- tent sectoral ministries. Borrowing abroad by the public sector as well as borrowing abroad by the private sector with a government guarantee are subject to prior approval by the High Committee of the External Debt, upon favorable recom- mendation by the National Planning Institute and by the Permanent Commission on External Credits in the Ministry of Economy and Finance. Prescription of Currency In principle, all export proceeds must be received in con- vertible currencies; 2 exchange certificates at present are only issued in U.S. dollars, but the Central Reserve Bank is em- powered to issue certificates denominated in any convertible currency. Settlements in respect of trade transactions with Hungary and Poland must be made through special accounts denominated in U.S. dollars, which have been established under bilateral payments agreements. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force. Payments between Peru and Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Venezuela may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru and the other central banks concerned, within the framework of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system. Imports and Import Payments The import of a number of consumer goods that are consid- ered nonessential is prohibited from any source other than LAFTA countries. Moreover, the import of a large number of manufactures included in the National Register of Manu- factured Products requires the approval of the customs au- thorities, which is granted only in exceptional circumstances. Private sector imports require the prior authorization of the competent sectoral ministry on the basis of an annual import application submitted by the importer. The Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector allocates exchange in ac- cordance with the import applications approved by the sec- toral ministries. Public sector agencies may not place import orders without the prior approval of the Commission on External Transactions and the Ministry of Economy and Finance. Certain agricultural commodities, such as rice and wheat, may be imported only by, or within quotas set by, the Public Company for Agricultural Services (EPSA), and crude petroleum and petroleum derivatives only by PETROPERU, a government agency. Certain industrial raw materials may be imported only by the National Enterprise for Industrial Mar- keting (ENCI), and the National Fertilizer Service (FER- 2 The proceeds must be received in the currency in which the contract is expressed if it is one of the following currencies: Belgian francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, or U.S. dollars. Otherwise, export proceeds must be received in U.S. dollars. 347 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU TIPERU) has the exclusive right to import and market agricul- tural fertilizers. Payments for the f.o.b. value of private sector imports, whether under documentary letters of credit or on a documentary collection basis, and for interest charges on foreign import credits, may be made at the certificate ex- change rate; however, payments for freight and import-re- lated banking charges other than interest must be made at the draft market rate. Transport insurance contracts for imported goods must be placed with national insurance companies unless a specific exemption from this requirement is obtained from the Banco de la Nacion, in which case premium pay- ments are made at the draft market rate. The full c.i.f. value of public sector imports may be paid with certificates. The use of certificates for import payments requires the prior authorization of the Central Reserve Bank, which pro- vides the foreign exchange to the commercial banks against delivery of the certificates. The commercial banks must pre- sent evidence that the entire amount represented by the certif- icates will be used for the importation of merchandise. The relevant shipping documents and the bill of lading must be forwarded to a commercial bank and presented to the Central Reserve Bank for registration and validation. Submission of import contracts or other evidence support- ing the transaction is required for advance import payments when the shipping documents are not available; in addition, the intermediary bank must provide a guarantee equal to the sol value of the advance payment. If the shipping documents are not presented within 30 days after the utilization of the foreign exchange, the Central Reserve Bank will collect the guarantee and refund this sum only when the required docu- ments have been presented. Minimum credit terms have been prescribed for imports of capital goods valued at over US$10,000 f.o.b. At least 80 per cent of the value of such imports must be financed through loans from suppliers or other foreign creditors or from the Peruvian state develop- ment banks, to be repaid in accordance with minimum credit terms set by the Board for Foreign Transactions of the Pri- vate Sector. The state development banks may only provide such financing for national enterprises and these loans, al- though repayable in soles, must carry an exchange rate guar- antee. The Central Reserve Bank may authorize the sale of exchange certificates only for partial advance payments of up to 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value of private sector capital goods imports (20 per cent of the c.i.f. value for public sector im- ports). These capital goods imports must be covered by irrev- ocable documentary credits and the intermediary bank must guarantee refunding of the foreign currency if the import is not effected by the time the relevant documentary credit ex- pires. A maritime freight tax of 4 per cent of the ocean freight charges is levied on goods imported by sea other than certain agricultural and medical products, books, and coins. Public sector imports must, in principle, be shipped in Peruvian vessels. Payments for Invisibles Authorization is required in order to pay for invisibles w i th certificates or at the certificate rate. The transactions in invisi- 348 bles that are eligible for the certificate market include govern- ment payments, profit remittances by branches of foreign companies operating in Peru, dividend remittances to foreign shareholders (provided that the original investment took place after May 15, 1970 at the certificate rate), and interest payments on those loans for which amortization may be transferred through the certificate market. Remittances of net profits, including depletion and depreciation allowances, re- quire a resolution of the Ministry of Economy and Finance, a prior tax clearance, and the visa of the Central Reserve Bank. Moreover, new foreign investments must be registered with the Ministry of Indus try and Commerce (but see foot- note 1) in order to have access to the certificate market for profit remittances and to enjoy tax incentives under Peru's incentive laws. Remittances of profits on foreign capital in- vested in Peru are limited to 14 per cent a year; foreign-owned enterprises may not pay royalties under new contracts to a foreign parent company or its affiliates; and the effective interest rate on a new loan from a foreign parent company or its foreign affiliate may not exceed by more than 3 per cent the prevailing interest rate for first-class assets in the money market of the country in whose currency the transaction is denominated. Exchange for payments that are not eligible for exchange certificates must be obtained in the draft market, subject to the prior authorization of the Banco de la Nacion. For payments in respect of a large number of current invisi- bles the sale of foreign exchange is authorized freely, either by the Banco de la Nacion or its agents, provided evidence is presented that genuine current payments are involved. These categories include import freight charges, the remuneration of technicians hired abroad, interest on loans for which amorti- zation payments are permitted to be transferred through the draft market, and payments for royalties, patents, trade- marks, insurance premiums, rental income, pensions, and commissions. For certain other payments basic allocations have been established up to which foreign exchange is sold freely. These categories include expenses abroad connected with tourist and business travel, study, and family mainte- nance. The basic limit up to which foreign exchange for tourist travel may be sold is the equivalent of S/. 1,000 a person a day for a maximum of 30 days in any one calendar year for travel to a Latin American country, and of S /. 1,200 a person a day for the same maximum period to other countries. The Banco de la Nacion fixes basic maximum amounts of foreign exchange which may be purchased annually by each eligible company for business travel abroad by its officials. There is a travel tax, which takes the form of a tax on a traveler's acquisition of goods and services abroad (including the cost of passages and fares) of 10 per cent on amounts up to the daily limits specified above, and of 50 per cent on any amounts in excess of these limits; the minimum amount pay- able is S /. 50 a day for each day spent abroad. Exempt are residents traveling on official business and foreign diplomats. The tax is paid prior to departure on the basis of a sworn declaration specifying separately the amount of the fare, the value of anticipated services to be received, and daily ex- penses. Air and sea passages are in addition subject to a 7 per cent ad valorem tax (3 per cent for economy class fares). ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Foreign nationals resident in Peru must obtain a special travel permit for business travel abroad (permiso especial de salida y reingreso). Such permits cost S /. 1,000 and are valid for six months. The export of domestic currency in excess of S/. 1,000 by travelers is prohibited, but the Central Reserve Bank grants exemptions in special circumstances. Exports and Export Proceeds The Banco Minero del Peru has a monopoly over the ex- port of precious metals, uncut precious stones, and pearls, and the Empresa Minera del Peru (MINEROPERU) has a mo- nopoly over all other mineral exports. The Empresa Publica de Comercializacion de Aceite y Harina de Pescado (EPCHAP) has a monopoly over exports of fish meal, fish oil, and fish for human consumption. Coffee exports are controlled by EPSA. Exports of fish meal and fish oil are suspended. 3 All exports are subject to license to assure the necessary supply of export proceeds to the certificate market. Traditional ex- ports must be sold against an irrevocable letter of credit confirmed by a bank established in Peru; the latter must surrender the foreign exchange proceeds within ten working days of payment. In special cases, and with the authorization of the Central Reserve Bank and the Directorate of Foreign Trade, exports may be sold against sight drafts, provided that payment is received w i th in 180 days of shipment. Exporters of nontraditional exports or local handicraft ar- ticles are granted transferable tax credit certificates (CATs) equivalent to 15-30 per cent of the c.i.f. value (of the f.o.b. value when the goods are shipped in foreign vessels). These certificates may be used by the exporter in payment of his tax obligations or may be sold to other taxpayers, who may use them for the same purpose. The Banco de la Nacion adminis- ters an export credit guarantee program and the Industrial Bank provides or arranges export finance for nontraditional exports. Proceeds from Invisibles Most public sector entities other than the state banks must surrender their full receipts at the certificate rate; the excep- tions are earnings from services provided by the Peruvian Shipping Company (Compania Peruana de Vapores or CPV) and the Peruvian Airline Company (AEROPERU), which are eligible for the draft market rate. All other receipts from invisibles must be sold in the draft market. Travelers may not bring in more than S /. 1,000 in Peruvian currency, but the Central Reserve Bank grants exemptions in special circum- stances. Capital All outward capital transfers require prior approval. In addition to government payments, certain capital payments on private account may be effected through the certificate market. The use of exchange certificates may be authorized for the amortization of foreign loans contracted by the private sector, provided that the foreign exchange proceeds of the loan have been surrendered to the Central Reserve Bank. 'These exports were resumed in March 1974. PERU Where such debt was contracted before October 9, 1967, certificate exchange may be allotted by the Central Reserve Bank only to public utility enterprises, to earners of foreign exchange, for payment of debts to international organiza- tions, and for payments of debts guaranteed by the State. Payments in connection with all loans received before June 17, 1971 and not channeled through the certificate mar- ket must be transferred through the draft market. The pro- ceeds of all foreign loans received after June 17, 1971 must be converted in the certificate market; amortization and ser- vice payments in respect of these loans are also settled through the certificate market. All exchange receipts that are not required to be sold in the certificate market must be sold in the draft market. Only the Banco de la Nacion may receive funds originating abroad for deposit to foreign currency accounts maintained in the name of nonresidents; these funds and the accrued interest thereon may be freely disposed of by the depositor and are exempt from income and inheritance taxes until De- cember 31, 1978. Foreign investment in Peru is governed by Decree-Law No. 18900 of June 30, 1971, which ratified the Andean Common Market's policy on the treatment of foreign capital, by De- cree-Law No. 18999 of October 19, 1971, and by Decree-Law No. 19232, Decree-Law No. 19307, Decree-Law No. 19971, and the legislation ruling the Peruvian exchange system. All foreign investments in Peru require the prior approval of the competent authorities with a view to channeling such invest- ments to projects considered essential for the country's devel- opment. If they wish to enjoy for their products the advantages deriving from the duty-free program of the Carta- gena Agreement, foreign companies incorporated in Peru as at July 1, 1971 have to agree, within a period of 3 years, to the gradual acquisition by national investors of shares in such companies so as to transfer them to mixed or national compa- nies during a maximum period of 15 years following the entering into effect of this regime. For this purpose, mixed companies are defined as those in which national investors hold between 51 per cent and 80 per cent of the capital, while national companies are those in which at least 80 per cent of the capital is owned by national investors. Upon expiration of the 3-year period, the participation of national investors in the capital of an enterprise has to amount to not less than 15 per cent; this participation must increase to at least 45 per cent after 10 years and to at least 51 per cent at the end of the 15-year period. In the case of foreign companies estab- lished in Peru after June 30, 1971, the 15 per cent participa- tion by national investors must be secured at the time of the initiation of production. Foreign investments in firms en- gaged in basic industries and in those which export at least 80 per cent of their production to countries outside the An- dean Common Market are exempt from the gradual transfer requirement to mixed companies; however, these enterprises do not benefit from the duty-free program of the Cartagena Agreement. All insurance and reinsurance companies that are not branches of foreign firms must become national enterprises by June 30, 1974, and all insurance and reinsurance compa- 349 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU nies established in Peru after July 17, 1973, must be com- pletely owned by national investors. Investment in the mining sector is governed by the General Mining Law (Decree-Law No. 18880) of June 8, 1971, which replaced the Mining Code of May 12, 1950. Companies hold- ing mining concessions may enter into mining contracts with the Government providing for special incentives and guaran- tees or may constitute mixed enterprises with government participation of at least 25 per cent. Under the regime of mining contracts, the Government may grant to m in ing con- cessionaires initiating large-scale investment programs tax incentives and guaranteed availability of foreign exchange for transfers of (1) recovery of investment; (2) interest payments if the rate does not exceed the prevailing rate for similar loans in the financial market from which the loans originate; (3) payments for justified services; and (4) reasonable profit re- mittances, together with guaranteed access to the most favor- able exchange rate. Mixed mining enterprises may receive all the benefits and incentives which may be granted by special contract and, in addition, special tax reductions. Gold The marketing of precious metals and their import and export are governed by Decree-Law No. 18882 of June 15, 1971 and Supreme Decree No. 065-71-EF of the same date. The import and export of gold and certain other precious metals and of precious stones are the monopoly of the Banco Minero del Peru. All imports and exports of gold are settled in the certificate market. The authorities do not make foreign exchange available for imports of gold other than by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users. Domestic sales and purchases of gold may be carried out by industrial and professional users, pro- vided that they hold licenses issued by the Banco Minero del Peru, but only M INEROPERU is authorized to make the initial purchase of newly mined gold and other precious metals. Residents traveling abroad may not take out jewelry valued at over S/. 50,000 unless it has been registered with the customs (S/. 15,000 for trips to bordering countries). Changes during 1973 During 1973, the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in both exchange markets remained unchanged. A number of commodities were added to the National Register of Manufactured Products. January 1. Decree-Law No. 19620 of November 28, 1972 came into effect. It replaced the stamp taxes on goods and services with a single ad valorem tax, levied at various rates, on production, imports, exports, wholesaling, and services. The standard rate on exports was 3 per cent, with a reduced rate of 2 per cent for refined and unrefined minerals and a full exemption for nontraditional exports. The standard rate on imports was 15 per cent, with a reduced rate of 1 per cent for some essentials, a rate of 25 per cent for some luxu ry goods, and a full exemption for certain food and livestock items. The rate applicable to international air fares was 7 per cent for first class or 3 per cent for economy class. 350 January 1. Decree-Law No. 19852 of December 26, 1972 came into effect. It introduced a new customs tariff using the customs nomenclature of the Andean Group. The ad valorem import tax of 2 per cent and the 10 per cent import surcharge were consolidated with the existing ad valorem rates. January 23. Decree-Law No. 19897 introduced the require- ment of a special travel permit for business travel abroad by foreign nationals resident in Peru. March 9. Ministerial Resolution No. 257-73-EF/74 ex- empted those mining companies whose taxes were fixed under contracts w i th the Government of Peru, from the import and export taxes imposed by Decree-Law No. 19620 of Novem- ber 28, 1972. March 21. Supreme Resolution No. 0033-73-PE lifted the suspension of exports of fish meal and fish oil that had been imposed on October 1, 1972, and required that 30 per cent of the quan t i ty exported must be reserved for the fu lf i l lment of contracts signed prior to October 1, 1972. March 23. Central Reserve Bank Circular No. 08-73- EF/90 required tha t, when loans and other external financial obligations fa l l ing under the certificate market regime were contracted in Belgian francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, or Swiss francs, or when export proceeds were received in one of these currencies, the currency in which the transaction was effected must be turned over to the Central Reserve Bank for conver- sion at the certificate market rate. April 3. Decree-Law No. 19971 authorized the state devel- opment banks to utilize foreign lines of credit previously approved by the Central Reserve Bank, in order to finance capital goods imports by national enterprises, i.e., companies in which at least 80 per cent of the capital is owned by national investors. These loans to national enterprises had to conform to the m in imum credit terms for capital goods im- ports established by the Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector and, although repayable in soles, had to carry an exchange rate guarantee. April 13. Decree-Law No. 19988 provided that the opera- tions of decentralized public bodies engaged in foreign busi- ness in the fields of trade, finance, and industry could be governed by the practices of international commerce and by the rules of in terna t ional law, without prejudice to the current system of approval in Peru. Thus Peruvian national law now recognized expressly that the decentralized public bodies (the Central Reserve Bank, the Banco de la Nacion, the state development banks, and other public organizations that con- clude external financial agreements) could accept the laws and courts of a foreign country, whether the country with which the contract was concluded or any th ird countries chosen by the contracting parties. A basic condition was that these contracts were concluded outside Peru. State contracts concluded in Peru w i th foreign untertakings continued to be affected by Article 17 of the Constitution, which requires foreign companies and persons who contract w i th the state to acknowledge the laws and tribunals of Peru. The decree-law did not affect contracts made by the Cen- tral Government or by the local governments (municipal- ities), even if these were represented by their financial agent, the Banco de la Nacion. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution April 17. Supreme Decree No. 008-73-IC/DC gave the Na- tional Fertilizer Service (SENAFER) the exclusive right to im- port and market agricultural fertilizers. May 8. Decree-Laws Nos. 19999 and 20000 were published which nationalized all firms engaged in anchovy f ish ing or in the production of fish meal and fish oil. A state agency, PESCAPERU, was established with certain monopoly func- tions in the fisheries sector. May 15. Decree-Law No. 20019 stipulated that transport insurance contracts for private sector imports must be ob- tained from national insurance companies, unless a specific exemption from this requirement was obtained from the Banco de la Nacion. Public sector imports had to be insured through the Banco de la Nacion. When private sector import insurance policies were written in a foreign currency by na- tional companies, the premiums had to be paid at the draft market rate but any foreign exchange received in payment of claims had to be turned over to the Central Reserve Bank and converted at the certificate rate. All foreign exchange transac- tions resulting from public sector import insurance were ef- fected at the certificate rate. The Banco de la Nacion could authorize national insurance and reinsurance firms to open foreign exchange accounts with it and these accounts would be governed by the regulations of the draft market. May 22. Decree-Law No. 20030 shifted the foreign cur- rency earnings of the national airline AEROPERU from the certificate market to the draft market. (Similar action had been taken for the CPV by Decree-Law No. 19586 of October 24, 1972.) May 22. Decree-Law No. 20031 (which amended Article 9 of Decree-Law No. 17710) and Supreme Decree No. 092-73-EF (which amended Articles 18 and 20 of the regula- tions of Decree-Law No. 17710) stipulated that payments for the f.o.b. value of private sector imports and for interest charges on foreign import credits could be made at the certifi- cate exchange rate, while payments for freight and im- port-related banking charges other than interest had to be made at the draft market rate. The full c.i.f. value of public sector imports, however, could be paid with exchange certifi- cates. (Before May 15, 1973, the full c.i.f. value of private sector imports was also eligible for transfer at the certificate rate.) In the case of advance payments for imports without the relevant shipping documents and bill of lading, the import contracts and other documents supporting the transaction had to be presented to the Central Reserve Bank and the intermediary bank had to grant a guarantee equal to the sol value of the advance payment. If the shipping documents were not presented within 30 days after the utilization of the foreign exchange, the Central Reserve Bank would collect the guarantee and refund this sum only after the required docu- ments had been presented. In the case of capital goods im- ports, the Central Reserve Bank could only authorize partial advance payments of up to 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value (20 per cent of the c.i.f. value for public sector imports). The capital goods imports must be covered by an irrevocable documentary credit and the pertinent sales contract; the bank filing the application had to guarantee the refunding of the PERU foreign currency if the goods had not been imported by the time the relevant documentary credit expired. Salaries and other payments for services contracted abroad were to be transferred at the draft market rate, unless the services were contracted by or for a public sector entity. (Previously, technicians' salaries and other such payments were transferred at the certificate rate.) Exchange certificates could be used for the payment of interest on foreign borrow- ing by exporting firms (provided the proceeds of the loan were submitted to the Central Reserve Bank on account of fu tu re exports) and for the local office administrative expen- ditures of international credit institutions (provided prior documentation of mon th ly expenses had been submitted to the Central Reserve Bank). May 29. Supreme Decree No. 095-73-EF provided that insurance firms established in Peru could issue policies in foreign currencies for transport insurance on imports and exports, for insurance contracted by nonresidents when the premiums were paid in foreign currency, for insuring capital goods financed by suppliers' credits when the supplier so required, and for other justified cases authorized by the Banco de la Nacion. This supreme decree also set for th the conditions governing the operation of foreign currency ac- counts held by insurance and reinsurance firms with the Banco de la Nacion. May 29. All insurance and reinsurance companies established in Peru after July 17, 1973, had to be 100 per cent owned by national investors. Investment and reinvestment by insurance compa- nies were subject to Article 42 of Decree-Law No. 18900 of June 30, 1971, which ratified the Andean Common Mar- ket's policy on the treatment of foreign capital. Insurance and reinsurance companies with foreign shareholdings greater than 20 per cent of their subscribed capital could only effect their foreign exchange operations through accounts main- tained with the Banco de la Nacion. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.227864 gram of fine gold per Philippine Peso, corresponding to P 1 = SDR 0.256410. All exchange transactions take place in a free market. The Bankers' Associ- ation establishes daily a "guiding rate"; during 1973 this rate appreciated from P 6.78 to about P 6.74 per U.S. dollar. In spot transactions with their customers, commercial banks are required by the Association to observe certain margins. The maximum and minimum spot buying rates are l/2 of 1 per cent and 1 per cent below the guiding rate, respectively. The mini- mum and maximum spot selling rates are % of 1 per cent and 1 PHILIPPINES Payments for Invisibles Virtually all payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. In prin- ciple, all other payments are permitted, without prior ap- proval of the Central Bank, provided that amounts of more than US$100 are substantiated by documentary evidence re- garding the purpose and the amount applied for. However, there are certain limits and regulations established by the Central Bank for purchases of foreign exchange for travel abroad by residents, remittances for educational expenses, maintenance and expenses of dependents abroad of residents, remittances of profits, dividends, and interest, royalties, and film and other rentals (see below). Exchange for travel abroad is made available as follows: (1) US$25 a day, up to a maxi- mum of US$750 a trip (for exporters an additional represen- tation allowance of US$500) for each person for business or professional travel; (2) US$500 a year for each adu lt resident for nonbusiness travel to Africa, North and South America, Australia, Europe, Japan, the Middle East, and New Zealand; and (3) US$200 a year for each adult resident for nonbusiness travel to Guam, Hong Kong, Okinawa, the Re- public of China, or any other neighboring country. Foreign travel by Philippine citizens, however, is not normally permit- ted. The following limits apply to exchange for educational expenses abroad: for studies in the United States, US$250 a month for living and other out-of-school expenses, plus the cost of tu i t ion, books, laboratory fees, and other school charges; for studies in Australia, Europe, Japan, and New Zealand, US$200 a month; and for studies in other areas, US$150 a mon th. Any scholarship allowances are deducted from these amounts. Remittances for educational expenses and student maintenance abroad are allowed only to students working for a degree at duly accredited colleges or universi- ties. The following limits apply for remittances to dependents of residents: US$250 a month for each dependent living in the United States; US$200 a month for each dependent living in Australia, Europe, Japan, and New Zealand; and US$100 a month for each dependent living in other areas. The mainte- nance allowances for dependents are allowed only for close relatives under certain conditions prescribed by the Central Bank. Remittances of profits and dividends (net of taxes) accru- ing to nonresidents out of net profits realized beginning Janu- ary 1, 1973, are permitted in full, provided that remittances are not financed from domestic credit resources. Remittances of royalties or rentals on patents, trademarks, and copyrights are freely permitted (net of taxes) for contracts registered with the Central Bank, provided that (1) the royalties do not ex- ceed 5 per cent of the wholesale price of the commodity which is manufactured locally under the royalty contract (2 per cent in the case of marketing service contracts), and (2) contracts do not exceed five-year terms and do not include restrictions on the export of the product. Remittances of the producer's shares of earnings made on motion-picture films and rentals on television films are freely permitted, provided generally that the shares or rentals do not exceed 60 per cent of net proceeds from films. 354 Foreign exchange within the above limits may be pur- chased, without prior approval of the Central Bank, for cur- rent payments for invisibles administratively withheld prior to November 26, 1969. Applications for certain invisibles for which no basic allowance has been set are considered on their merits by the Central Bank. No person may take out or export from the Philippines foreign currency or any other foreign exchange except as authorized by the Central Bank. Residents may take out, as part of their travel allowance, up to US$100 in foreign bank- notes. Nonresident travelers may take out any amount of foreign currency that they had previously brought in and declared, m inus any amounts converted into pesos. Resident and nonresident travelers require prior authorization from the Central Bank to take out more than P 500 in domestic notes and coins or checks, money orders, and other bills of exchange drawn in pesos. Citizens of the Philippines and permanent resident aliens, when traveling abroad, must pay a travel tax of P 400 for first-class ship or plane tickets or P 300 for any other ticket. Exempt are, among others, foreign diplomatic staff and Filipino Muslims making their first pil- grimage to Mecca. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia of petroleum products and military equipment and supplies are prohibited. Exports of certain strategic materials and items deemed essential for industrial- ization and economic development are also prohibited. Oth- erwise, exports are generally not restricted, but they are regulated to ensure that the foreign exchange proceeds are surrendered to an authorized agent of the Central Bank. Au- thorized agent banks issue the necessary export permits upon registration of the exporter's report of foreign sales (except export permits for gold, which are issued by the Central Bank); reports of foreign sales for copra and coconut oil, however, are approved for registration only by the Central Bank. Authorized agent banks must sell to the Central Bank 10 per cent of their exchange receipts from export bills. As a general rule, no commodity may be exported unless it is covered by a draft drawn in one of the prescribed curren- cies and unless collection of the proceeds will be undertaken by an authorized agent bank; however, payment by means of telegraphic transfer, check, or mail transfer may be allowed. Payments for exports on a cash, collection, or consignment basis must be arranged through an authorized agent bank, which must specifically contract with the exporter to buy the exchange proceeds. No shipment of exports will be allowed by the customs unless a certificate is issued by a bank stating that payment has been received or arranged by the bank. Proceeds from exports must be received in the prescribed currencies within 30 days from the date of shipment (or within such period as may be established in special cases) and surrendered to the agent bank within 3 business days of re- ceipt. An irrevocable letter of credit is required for exports of scrap metals, copra, and coconut oil, and for all exports to Guam, Hong Kong, the Republic of China, Indonesia, and Japan. Exports of perishable commodities to Hong Kong require prepayment. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Under an "export deduction" scheme, export-oriented in- dustries are allowed, subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank, to use a part of their export proceeds for the repayment of the loans obtained for their imports of machin- ery, equipment, raw materials, and other requirements. An export tax is levied on the f.o.b. value of major exports. The rate is 10 per cent for logs, 6 per cent for copra, centrifu- gal sugar, and copper ore and concentrates, and 4 per cent for gold, molasses, coconut oil, dessicated coconut, iron ore and concentrates, chromite ore and concentrates, copra meal or cake, unmanufactured abaca, unmanufactured tobacco, ve- neer core and sheets, plywood, lumber, canned pineapples, shrimps and prawns, bunker fuel oil, bananas, cement clinker, Portland cement, and petroleum pitch and residues. Export trade with socialist and communist countries au- thorized under Executive Order No. 384 is handled through NETRACOR. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles must be sold within three business days by the recipient to an authorized agent bank. Philippine nationals employed abroad are permitted to open U.S. dollar deposit accounts with the Central Bank or authorized agent banks, in which they may retain any U.S. dollars they remit to the Philippines. To be eligible for credit to such accounts at the Central Bank, earnings must be transferred through Philippine diplomatic or consular establishments. Under a foreign currency deposit scheme, inward remittances by resi- dents or nonresidents of foreign currencies for deposit in numbered foreign currency accounts are exempt from surren- der requirements, provided that the remittances do not repre- sent current earnings or income of residents nor payments by nonresidents pursuant to contractual obligations. Balances in such accounts are freely transferable abroad. Travelers may freely bring in any amount of foreign currency and up to P 500 in domestic notes and coins and checks, money orders, and other bills of exchange drawn in pesos, of which not more than P 50 may consist of Philippine coins. Capital All inward and outward capital movements, w i th the ex- ception of certain transactions related to financing of interna- tional trade (see below), are subject to the prior and specific approval of the Central Bank. Virtually all payments and transfers to Rhodesia are prohibited. For the purpose of the approval of new inward foreign investments (in kind or in cash) as well as new foreign borrowings, preference is given to projects approved by the BOI, export-oriented industries, and other (nonexport-oriented) industries not utilizing do- mestic credit resources. Foreign direct cash investments made after March 15,1973 and registered with the Central Bank are freely repatriable, except investments in domestic commercial banks, which if made after March 31, 1973, are freely repatri- able and if made before that date are repatriable according to the schedule in (4) below. There are certain restrictions on sales of foreign exchange for the repatriation of foreign direct cash investments made before March 16, 1973 and non-cash investments made after March 15, 1973, depending on the PHILIPPINES category of industry where the investment is made, as follows: (1) export-oriented industries certified by the Central Bank— repatriable in fu ll but no annual installment to exceed the applicant's share in the net foreign exchange earnings of the firm in the preceding year; (2) enterprises registered with the BOI, producing import substitutes or exports but not in- cluded in (1) above —repatriable in three equal annual install- ments starting one year after the liquidation of investment, but no annual installment to be more than total net foreign exchange earnings in the preceding year; (3) enterprises regis- tered with the BOI, not included in (2) above and not utilizing domestic credit resources—in four equal annual installments starting one year after liquidation of investments; (4) remain- ing industries —repatriation according to the following sched- ule: US$0.25 million or less, five equal annual installments after liquidation; USSO.25-0.5 million, seven equal annual installments after liquidation; and over US$0.5 million, nine equal annual installments after liquidation. During the period between the date of investments and repatriation, liquidation proceeds may be reinvested, subject to approval by the Cen- tral Bank, in foreign currency deposits under Circular No. 343, government securities, or shares of stock in export-ori- ented industries registered with the BOI or certified by the Central Bank. Commercial banks may not receive credit from abroad other than credit arising from normal international trade transactions. Residents may obtain suppliers* credits from abroad provided that repayment terms are w i th in the limits prescribed by the Central Bank. The ma tur i ty may not be less than 5 years for amounts up to $250,000 (with certain excep- tions) not less than 8 years for amounts between $250,000 and $500,000 and not less than 12 years for amounts greater than $500,000. For export industries, amounts exceeding $500,000 are approved if the credit has a maturity of at least 8 years, inclusive of a 3-year grace period on repayment of principal; and for amounts less than US$ 150,000, 3 or 4 year maturities may be permitted depending on the amount of credit and the type of export indus try. Interest rates may not be more than 2 per cent above the prime rate of the lending country. Appli- cations are not approved if the proposed project expands capacity in an indus try deemed to be overcrowded, or for firms which are in arrears with government financial institu- tions. Sales of foreign exchange for amortization of loans are permitted in accordance with the terms of loan contracts approved by the Central Bank. The same applies for loan contracts registered with the Central Bank prior to Novem- ber 26, 1969. For those not falling under these two categories, prior approval by the Central Bank is required for sales of foreign exchange for repayment of loans. Emigrants may repatriate up to US$5,000, subject to verifi- cation by the Central Bank. The remaining liquid assets may be w i thdrawn in five years beginning one year from emigra- tion. Except as otherwise specifically authorized, resident per- sons, firms, or corporations may not enter into any contract or transaction which may involve settlement in foreign ex- change, or involving any assets belonging to them expressed in foreign currencies or payable or deliverable abroad. This restriction also applies to contracts or transactions involving 355 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES assets w i th in the Philippines belonging to a nonresident per- son, firm, or corporation, and to their exportation or importa- tion. Detailed regulations are in force concerning transactions in securities between residents and nonresidents. Under the Investment Incentives Act of 1967, all investors in enterprises registered with the BOI are guaranteed the right to repatriate their investments, and to remit earnings thereon and sums needed to meet payments of principal and interest on foreign loans; they are also guaranteed freedom from ex- propriation and requisition. There are different arrangements for "pioneer investments" and "preferred investments"; the former are granted certain incentives over and above those given to preferred investments. Normally, enterprises owned or controlled by foreigners are permitted to operate only in "pioneer areas of invest- ment," and normally at least 60 per cent of the voting capital stock of registered enterprises in "preferred areas of invest- ment" (mainly investments related to the exploitation of ex- port-oriented natural resources and the manufac tur ing of import substitutes) must be owned by Philippine nationals. By virtue of the Laurel-Langley Agreement, U.S. citizens, corporations, and associations are given the same status for this purpose as Philippine citizens until July 1974. Under the Foreign Investment Law of 1968, new enter- prises in which investment by non-Filipinos exceeds 30 per cent and which are not covered by the Investment Incentives Act must obtain au thor i ty from the BOI in order to engage in any economic activity in the Philippines. If purchases of shares of common stock by foreign nationals would reduce Philippine ownership in a firm to less than 30 per cent, per- mission from the BOI must first be obtained. Gold Producers of gold must sell their entire ou tput to the Cen- tral Bank at the equivalent of US$42.22 an ounce (calculated at P 3.90 per U.S. dollar) to be eligible for assistance under the Gold Indus t ry Assistance Act (Republic Act No. 3089, as amended by Republic Act No. 6364 of August 5, 1971), irrespective of whether this gold is a by-product or the princi- pal or only product of their operations. However, gold pro- ducers who wish to take advantage of the floating exchange rate (the "guiding rate") in lieu of the subsidy must export their gold production, subject to prior licensing by the Cen- tral Bank. Exports of gold (as principal product) are subject to an export tax at a rate of 4 per cent. Residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to purchase gold abroad in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Central Bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and in- dustrial users. Changes during 1973 January 1. A revised customs tariff based on the Brussels Tariff Nomenclature went into effect. The basic rates of du ty were 10, 20, 30, 50, 70, and 100 per cent. The President was empowered, acting on the advice of the newly created Na- 356 tional Economic Development Authority, to adjust the rates of import du ty, and to introduce protective duties, import quotas, and import prohibitions. January 1. Export proceeds from shrimps and prawns and from gold became subject to the stabilization tax at the rate of 4 per cent. January 17. Authorized agent banks no longer were per- mitted to reconvert in to U.S. dollars any portion of the peso proceeds of U.S. Treasury dollar checks encashed by Philip- pine residents holding "privilege and ration cards." February 14. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the "guiding rate" was maintained unchanged at about P 6.78 = US$1. February 16. Payments for the import of completely knocked-down new as well as used motorcycles for assembly and of spare or replacement parts for motorcycles were made subject to prior approval by the Central Bank. February 19. Presidential Decree No. 131 reduced the with- holding tax on interest on foreign loans from 35 per cent to 15 per cent for interest earned beginning from January 1, 1973. February 26. Central Bank Circular No. 364 required resi- dent persons and corporations to remit to the Philippines in foreign currencies acceptable to the Central Bank all foreign exchange earnings from invisibles, whether receivable in the Philippines or through representatives abroad, within 15 days from the date of establishing ownership. Only amounts eligi- ble for deposit under the foreign currency deposit scheme were exempt from this requirement. Regulations were issued for the reporting to the Central Bank by resident persons or corporations of all foreign exchange earnings from invisibles. March 16. Central Bank Circular No. 365 provided that foreign investments made after March 15, 1973 and registered with the Central Bank were freely repatriable. The Central Bank issued revised regulations governing repatriation of for- eign investments existing as of March 15, 1973 in different categories of industries as follows: (1) export-oriented indus- tries certified by the Central Bank —repatriable in full but no annual installment to exceed the applicant's share in the net foreign exchange earnings of the firm in the preceding year; (2) enterprises registered with the BOI, producing import substitutes or exports but not included in (1) above—repatri- able in three equal annual installments starting one year after the liquidation of investment, but no annual installment to be more than the total net foreign exchange earnings in the preceding year; (3) enterprises registered with the BOI, not included in (2) above and not utilizing domestic credit re- sources—in four equal annual installments starting one year after liquidation of investments; (4) remaining industries — repatriation according to the following schedule: US$0.25 million or less, five equal annual installments after liquida- tion; US$0.25-0.5 million, seven equal annual installments after liquidation; and over US$0.5 million, nine equal annual installments after liquidation. During the period between the liquidation of investments and repatriation, liquidation proceeds could be reinvested, subject to approval by the Central Bank, in foreign currency deposits under Circular No. 343, government securities, or ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution shares of stock in export-oriented industries registered w i th the BOI or certified by the Central Bank. March 16. Central Bank Circular No. 365 removed the limit of 25 per cent of the equity participation (net of taxes) on the remittance of profits and dividends earned in certain industries. Profits and dividends accruing to nonresidents out of net profits realized beginning January 1, 1973 and thereafter could, net of taxes, be remitted in fu ll at the prevailing ex- change rate. The backlog of profits and dividends resulting from the 25 per cent restriction was remittable subject to two conditions: (1) the remittance should not be financed by do- mestic borrowing, and (2) depending on the amount, the Central Bank might stagger the remittance over a period of two years. March 16. Resolution No. 470 of the Monetary Board permitted local banks to swap certain foreign cash invest- ments w i th the Central Bank for pesos, but w i thout forward cover, for a m in imum period of three months and a maximum period of three years. Included in this were foreign cash in- vestments made after March 15, 1973 in (1) export-oriented industries certified by the Central Bank, (2) enterprises regis- tered with the BOI, or (3) Philippine securities approved by and registered with the Central Bank and listed on the local stock exchange. Such cash investments were repatriable in full, minus any losses, at any time, subject to the terms and conditions of the swap arrangement between the handling bank and the Central Bank. April 4. All exports of grains and their by-products were banned, except for scientific and experimental purposes as approved by the National Grain Authority. Exports of ipil- ipil, feather meal, and yeast were also banned, except as au- thorized by the Secretary of Agriculture. May 28. Central Bank regulations governing the required m in imum repayment periods for suppliers' credits from abroad were relaxed for (1) export-oriented industries certi- fied by the Central Bank and industries registered with the BOI under the Export Incentives Act, and (2) pioneer indus- tries approved by the BOI and enterprises engaged primarily in producing for exports, as follows: In category (1)— amounts up to US$50,000, three years; over US$50,000 to US$150,000, four years; and over US$150,000 to US$250,000, f ive years. In category (2) —up to US$25,000, three years; over US$25,000 to US$100,000, four years; and over US$100,000 to US$250,000, five years. Formerly, mini- mum five-year repayment terms were required for all credits up to US$250,000. June 16. Presidential Decree No. 218 introduced incentive guidelines for the establishment in the Philippines of regional headquarters by multinational corporations. July 1. The stabilization tax of 6 per cent or 4 per cent on proceeds from certain major exports was replaced by an ex- port tax at the same rates, with the exception that the tax rate for logs was raised from 6 per cent to 10 per cent. Since the stabilization tax involved multiple currency practices, this action implied the unification of the exchange rate structure. August 7. The Central Bank issued guidelines regarding the implementation of quantitative restrictions being imposed on PHILIPPINES the export of cement, plywood, lumber, copra, and coconut oil. August 8. Circular No. 375 of the Central Bank established regulations governing the repatriation of foreign investments (including investments in foreign exchange by nonresident Philippine citizens) in domestic commercial banks, as follows: (1) Investments existing as of May 31, 1973 as approved by and registered with the Central Bank would be repatriable according to the following schedule: US$0.25 million or less, five equal annual installments after liquidation; over US$0.25 to US$0.5 million, seven equal annual installments after liqui- dation; and over US$0.5 million, nine equal annual install- ments after liquidation. (2) Cash investments made after May 31, 1973 and after approval by and registration with the Central Bank would be repatriable in full, minus any losses, at any time at the prevailing exchange rate. August 9. The Philippines acceded provisionally to the GATT. August 21. All payments for freight charges for imports loaded on board Philippine flag vessels and /or alien flag vessels operated or chartered by Philippine residents were permitted to be made in the Philippines in pesos or U.S. dollars. Philippine resident operators or charterers were re- quired to accept pesos offered as payment in the Philippines for such freight. October 15. Central Bank Circular No. 265, as amended, permitted resident individuals and firms to export and im- port, and permitted travelers to take out or bring in, up to P 500 in Philippine notes and coins or checks, money orders, and other bills of exchange drawn in pesos. For larger amounts, prior authorization from the Central Bank was re- quired. October 26. The Central Bank took steps to ensure advance scrutiny of all foreign borrowing by official financial institu- tions. November 8. Exports of all petroleum products, with the exception of limited sale of fuel to foreign ships and airlines, required prior authorization by the Oil Industry Commission. November 20. The stipulation that remittance of the back- log of profits and dividends from 1972 and preceding years might be staggered by the Central Bank over a two-year period was withdrawn. Immediate lump sum remittance was to be permitted for all applications made before January 31, 1974, provided that actual remittance was made before April 1, 1974. However, the condition prohibiting the use of domestic credit to finance the remittance was retained. December 7. The 50 per cent limitation on the remittance of royalties or rentals on patents, trademarks, and copyrights was removed for contracts registered with the Central Bank and the full amount, net of taxes, became freely remittable provided that (1) the contracts did not exceed five-year terms and did not include restrictive terms regarding export of the product, and (2) the "manufacturing" royalty rate did not exceed 5 per cent (2 per cent in case of "marketing" services such as brand names or trademarks) of the wholesale price of product. A similar 50 per cent limit on the remittance of the producer's shares of earnings made on motion-picture films and rentals on television films was also removed, provided generally that the shares or rentals did not exceed 60 per cent 357 ©International Monetary Fund. Any existing contracts would be given full remittance rights, in- eluding unremitted amounts under former regulations. 358 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0309103 gram of fine gold per Portu- guese Escudo. A central rate of Esc 25.50 per US$1 has been established, corresponding to Esc 30.7619 = SDR 1, and Portugal avails itself of wider margins. Since March 19, 1973, however, no announced margins have been observed and all spot transactions between the escudo and other currencies (except those of the overseas provinces) have taken place at fluctuating rates. On December 31, 1973, the authorized banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were Esc 25.728 and Esc 25.956, respectively, per US$1. Neither the Bank of Portugal nor the commercial banks charge buy- ing and selling commissions but there is a tax of 0.15 per cent on all sales of foreign exchange. l For settlements w i th countries with which Portugal has bilateral payments agree- ments, 2 the U.S. dollar rate applies to transactions in "agree- ment dollars," while fixed exchange rates apply to other agreement currencies. Authorized banks may deal in foreign exchange with the Bank of Portugal. They are also normally allowed to deal in foreign exchange with banks abroad at the rates prevailing in the Portuguese foreign exchange market, but they are not expected to solicit such transactions in foreign markets and may be required to jus t ify the amounts of their sales of escu- dos to nonresidents. They are not allowed to buy and sell foreign exchange among themselves, or to enter into arbitrage operations in foreign markets. In dealing with their custom- ers, the authorized banks buy and sell foreign exchange in convertible currencies for their own account; their purchases and sales of bilateral agreement currencies are made for the account of the Bank of Portugal. Purchases and sales of un- quoted currencies can only be made through an authorized bank acting on a commission basis. Banks are required to obtain the prior approval of the Bank of Portugal to accept deposits in foreign currencies from residents or nonresidents and to obtain short-term credits abroad. The banks may use their foreign exchange holdings for all authorized purposes, but the Ministry of Finance may set limits on their foreign exchange resources and in certain circumstances may require that foreign exchange assets be sold to the Bank of Portugal; since December 31,1971, the net foreign asset positions of the authorized banks have been subject to ceilings and since May 31, 1972 their gross foreign exchange holdings have been subject to ceilings. Capital held abroad by residents in the form of foreign exchange that is not subject to surrender requirements may be transferred to other residents through authorized commer- cial banks at official rates of exchange. Decree-Law No. 44699 of 1963 forbids direct transactions in foreign exchange between residents who are private persons. 1 The currencies dealt with in the official exchange market and quoted by the Bank of Portugal are Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, South African rand, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, and Israel. Settlements with Greece and Turkey are also channeled through special accounts. There is no forward exchange market, but authorized banks may enter into forward transactions with individual customers; the exchange rates may not be higher than the spot buying rate or lower than the spot selling rate of the same date, but the size of the commission is not prescribed. The commercial banks may cover open positions by entering in to swap transactions with the Bank of Portugal. The escudos issued in the overseas territories are at par with the metropolitan escudo. The parity for the Macao pa- taca is Esc 5.015 = pataca 1. Interterritorial payments are subject to transfer charges collected by the credit institutions concerned which may not exceed 0.6 per cent; this limit is 0.3 per cent for payments resulting from transactions in foreign currencies and settled through another overseas territory or through metropolitan Portugal. Interterritorial payments are also subject to a service charge. In addition, interterritorial payments which require the direct intervention of the Bank of Portugal as agent of either the interterritorial clearing sys- tem or the interterritorial payments system are subject to a service charge of 0.15 per cent payable to the Bank of Portu- gal. Exchange Control Territory Portugal and the Portuguese overseas territories (Angola, Cape Verde Islands, Macao, Mozambique, Portuguese Guinea, Sao Tome e Principe Islands, and Timor) constitute a single exchange control territory, the Portuguese Monetary Area or Escudo Area. W i th in the Escudo Area, interter- ritorial payments are subject to exchange control (except in Macao); they may be made directly through commercial banks or channeled through special accounts maintained by the Bank of Portugal (which is reserve bank of the Escudo Area, agent of the clearing system, and agent of the Monetary Fund of the Area) and the Exchange Funds of the individual overseas territories (either under the interterritorial payments system or the interterritorial clearing system). Decree-Law No. 41,403 of November 1957 and Decree-Law No. 44,016 of November 1961 provide that the foreign exchange regula- tions of metropolitan Portugal shall be applied in the overseas territories, subject to any local adjustments that may be nec- essary. Current payments from metropolitan Portugal to the overseas territories are in principle unrestricted, as are current payments to metropolitan Portugal from most of the overseas territories. In Angola and Mozambique, however, transac- tions involving payments to metropolitan Portugal as well as to foreign countries are subject at present to a system of priorities. Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Bank of Portu- gal on behalf of the Ministry of Finance, with the assistance of the commercial banks authorized for this purpose. Trade control policy is formulated by the Commission of Economic Coordination in the Ministry of Economy. A Di- rectorate-General of Commerce in the Ministry of Economy administers the trade controls; import and export licenses 359 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL ("bulletins") are issued by the Foreign Trade Division, oper- ating within the office of the Directorate-General, or by other executive departments duly authorized. Licenses for imports of certain goods included in the negative list are issued by the economic coordination departments within the Ministry of Economy. Practically all foreign trade transactions are sub- ject to registration with the Ministry of Economy. Prescription of Currency Transactions with countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements may be settled in any of the currencies quoted by the Bank of Portugal (see footnote 1), or, for Portuguese exports, in escudos to the debit of a Demand Foreign Account in Escudos (see section on Nonres- ident Accounts, below). Transactions with countries w i th which Portugal has bilateral payments agreements (see foot- note 2) are settled through clearing accounts maintained in U.S. dollars (for Greece, Israel, and Turkey), or in escudos or the currency of the partner country (for Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, and Hungary). In exceptional cases, pay- ments to nonresidents may be made by crediting escudos to a nonresident account, subject to prior approval by the Bank of Portugal. Payments between the overseas territories and foreign countries may be made either direct through the au- thorized banks of the territories concerned, or by means of the interterritorial clearing system, through metropolitan Portu- gal or another overseas territory. W i th in the Escudo Area, payments to metropolitan Portugal must be made in metro- politan escudos, while payments to the overseas territories may be made either in metropolitan escudos or in the cur- rency of the creditor country. Nonresident Accounts The main categories of nonresident accounts are described below. "Foreign Accounts in Escudos" in the name of persons resident or domiciled in countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements or arrangements: These accounts are divided into (1) "Time Foreign Accounts in Escudos," for which the opening, debiting, and crediting are subject to special advance authorization of the Bank of Portugal, and (2) "Demand Foreign Accounts in Escudos," which may be opened, debited, and credited w i thout prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal for (a) payments for transactions expressed in escudos and duly authorized in that currency, for imports and exports of goods, services, and capital between metropolitan Portugal and foreign countries, 3 (b) purchases or sales of escudos against the for- eign currencies quoted by the Bank of Portugal, 4 (c) pur- chases or sales of foreign currencies quoted by the Bank of Portugal against escudos, and (d) transfers between these accounts. For all other debit and credit operations, authoriza- tion of the Bank of Portugal is required. 3 However, the in tent of the monetary directives in force is to exclude the escudo from payments to nonresidents, and the Bank of Portugal authorizes such payments in escudos on ly in exceptional cases. 4 Sales of escudos are subject to the proviso that the commercial bank concerned may be required to inform the Bank of Portugal of the na tu re of the transaction for which escudos are required. 360 The granting of credit in the form of overdrafts on the above accounts requires the authorization of the Bank of Portugal and for amounts exceeding Esc 50 million with a ma tu r i ty exceeding one year the approval of the Ministry of Finance is also required. "Foreign Accounts in Escudos" in the name of persons resident or domiciled in countries with which Portugal has bilateral payments agreements or arrangements: These ac- counts are opened, debited, and credited according to instruc- tions issued by the Bank of Portugal. There are also provisions for resident and nonresident ac- counts in foreign currencies, but these accounts are of limited importance. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain products are prohibited, mainly for rea- sons of health, public order, and the prevention of commer- cial fraud. Any physical or juridical entity may be an importer; importers must be certified by the Corporation of Commerce and must pay income taxes regularly. Most imports consigned from and originating in the Portu- guese overseas territories are free of restriction. A registration procedure is applied, however, for payment control purposes, and certificates of origin are required to ensure that goods originating in foreign countries do not enter Portugal via overseas territories. Certain products, such as cotton and some oilseed products, may be imported freely from the Por- tuguese overseas territories after local industrial demand has been satisfied, but are subject to quantitative restrictions when imported from third countries. Special regulations are applied to sugar; imports from foreign countries take place only if supplies from overseas territories are insufficient. Almost all imports from outside the Portuguese Monetary Area are effected on the basis of "bulletins." For imports free of quan t i ta t ive restriction, the bulletin serves a statistical pur- pose and enables the importer to obtain the necessary foreign exchange as specified in the bulletin. For imports subject to restriction, the bulletin is equivalent to an import license. The validity of the bulletin is normally 180 days, but extensions are often granted. Baggage and imports of merchandise whose value does not exceed Esc 25,000 do not require a bulletin, provided they are not expressly excluded from this exemption. Payments for imports already cleared through customs require the approval of the Bank of Portugal when made after the validity of the bulletin. Payments beyond one year af ter customs clearance always require the approval of the Bank of Portugal. GoodB-not on the so-called negative list may be imported freely from most countries that are members of the GATT. The negative list includes certain foodstuffs, other agricultural products, certain natural or manufactured raw materials, some textile fibers, and a small number of finished products, including motor vehicles; the items on the negative list are subject to quantitative restrictions for protec- tive reasons or under special regimes. A somewhat more ex- tensive negative list applies to Japan. The GATT liberalization does not apply to Ghana, India, and Nigeria; imports from these GATT members of goods liberalized if imported from other GATT countries are subject to individ- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ual authorization, which is granted on the merits of the case. Nonliberalized imports from countries that are GATT mem- bers are admitted either under global or bilateral quotas or under individual authorization. All imports from countries that are not members of the GATT are based on individual authorizations; imports from Eastern European countries are generally licensed restrictively or in accordance w i th bilateral agreements. There are bilateral quotas for specified agricultural imports from certain EFTA countries. Imports of nonliberalized in- dustrial products, except for certain protected steel products and automobiles, are free of quan t i ta t ive restriction when originating in EFTA or EEC countries. Special legislation provides that automobiles must be assembled in Portugal. Imports of passenger automobiles of EFTA origin are al- lowed up to 150 units a year for each producer, while those of non-EFTA origin are allowed up to 15 un i ts a producer a year for those makes not assembled in Portugal and, for other makes, up to 2 per cent of the number of passenger automo- biles of the same make that were assembled in Portugal in the preceding year. Imports of commercial vehicles for special purposes are free of restrictions. Imports of completely knocked-down vehicles from EFTA and EEC countries are free of restrictions, and allocations for imports from other GATT countries are available under special open licenses, subject to the use of certain m in imum percentages of domes- tic components. Payments for Invisibles Payments to the Portuguese overseas territories for current invisibles may be made freely through authorized banks. Such payments to foreign countries are also generally free of quan- titative restrictions, but for most transactions ceilings are specified for amounts of foreign exchange that authorized banks may grant freely. For payments to countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements, the authorized banks may grant any amount of foreign exchange for expenditures incidental to trade; up to the equivalent of Esc 50,000 a person a year for tourism; 5 and up to the equivalent of Esc 100,000 for most transactions in invisibles not mentioned above, including income on imported capital. For payments to countries with which Portugal has bilateral payments agreements, the authorized banks may effect freely payments for invisibles listed in the respective payments agreements. Application must be made to the Bank of Portugal for ex- change for payments of items not referred to above and for payments in excess of the above-mentioned limits. Travelers may take out freely domestic and foreign bank- notes and foreign coins for their travel expenses; exports of notes and coins for other purposes require authorization from the Bank of Portugal. 5 Upon verification of the genuineness of the transaction, the Bank of Portugal authorizes additional exchange for persons wishing to travel abroad who have already used up their annual allocation. PORTUGAL Exports and Export Proceeds Exports and re-exports are effected on the basis of "bulle- tins" (similar to the import bulletins). Export bulletins for exports to Angola and Mozambique are issued only on evi- dence that the importer has already obtained an import bulle- t in. 6 For exports to other overseas provinces and to foreign countries, export bulletins are issued freely, with few excep- tions; the primary purpose of this procedure is to enforce the prescription of currency and surrender regulations. The ex- port of a few domestically produced goods is restricted, ma in ly to assure adequate supplies to domestic industries and to avoid depletion of local resources. Baggage and exports and re-exports of merchandise whose value does not exceed Esc 25,000 do not require a bulletin, provided they are not expressly excluded from this exemption. Exporters are required to sell to an authorized bank, within the period stipulated in the export bulletin, the total amount of the export proceeds, in the foreign currency indicated in the bulletin, if payment is not received from a Demand Foreign Account in Escudos. The Bank of Portugal may, however, authorize the deduction of commission expenses abroad, and freight, insurance, or other charges pertaining to exports, from the total amount of the export proceeds subject to sur- render. Proceeds from Invisibles Portuguese residents may receive freely payments up to Esc 500,000 for invisibles from residents of countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements. Also, payments from residents of countries with which Portu- gal does have payments agreements may be received freely for invisibles listed in the payments agreements. Receipts on ac- count of all other invisibles require authorization by the Bank of Portugal, which is granted without restriction once the proposed operation proves to be real and licit. Receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. Travelers may bring in freely domestic and foreign bank- notes and coins for their travel expenses; imports of notes and coins for other purposes require authorization from the Bank of Portugal. Authorized banks are not permitted to receive or to pay domestic or foreign banknotes or coins for the settle- ment of external transactions. Capital With the exception of personal capital exports up to Esc 100,000 for each transfer from Portugal (inheritances, settlements, dowries, and gifts to relatives), capital transfers between Portugal and its overseas territories are subject to prior authorization by the Bank of Portugal; approval is also required from the authorities of the territory concerned. When the amount exceeds Esc 50 million, the approval of the Minister of Finance and of the Minister of Overseas Territo- 8 This provision was based on Decree No. 551 /71 of December 15, 1971, which was revoked by Decree-Law No. 187/74 of May 6, 1974. However, prior registration continued to be required for exports to Angola and Mozambique.
