How- ever, no exchange transactions take place at the par value. The South African Reserve Bank quotes a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.4900 per R 1. Exchange rates are based on the Reserve Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar against rand (US$1.4937 buying and US$1.4862 selling, per R 1) and the London market rates for the currencies con- cerned against the U.S. dollar. Subject to certain limitations, authorized dealers are permitted to conduct forward ex- change operations among themselves and with overseas banks. The Reserve Bank provides forward cover in U.S. dollars only; such cover is given to authorized dealers at a nominal charge of 1 per cent per annum, for normal trade transactions only. The commercial banks' spot rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1973 were US$1.4937 buy ing, and US$1.4862 selling, per R 1. South Africa formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement as of September 15, 1973. Exchange Control Territory For purposes of control over transactions in securities, residents of Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland are regarded as nonresidents. Otherwise, there are virtually no exchange or trade restrictions between the Republic of South Africa (de- fined for exchange control purposes as including South West Africa), Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland, and these are regarded as forming, w i th the Republic of South Africa, a single exchange control territory, the Rand Monetary Area. Administration of Control Import and export licenses are issued by the Director of Imports and Exports acting on behalf of the Secretary for Commerce. Exchange licensing is the responsibility of the Treasury, which has delegated this au tho r i ty to the South African Reserve Bank; in turn, the Reserve Bank has dele- gated to the commercial banks much of its licensing power. Appropriate exchange for licensed imports is made available by the authorized dealers upon presentation of suitable docu- mentary evidence. Prescription of Currency South Africa has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. All countries outside the Rand Monetary Area constitute the Nonresident Area. 1 Settlements within the Rand Monetary Area take place in rand only. Settlements with residents of the 1 In the application of the Securities Control Notices, however, the Nonresident Area comprises all countries outside South Africa, and thus includes Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. Correspondingly, there are two definitions of resident status for exchange control purposes. 382 Nonresident Area, except Rhodesia, may be made in rand to and from a nonresident account and in any specified cur- rency 2 and, for outgoing payments only, in any other foreign currency. 3 Settlements with Rhodesia may be made in rand to and from a local Rhodesian or other nonresident account, in Rhodesian currency and, for inward payments only, in any specified currency. Nonresident Accounts The rand accounts of residents outside the Rand Monetary Area are divided in to Rhodesian Accounts, Nonresident Ac- counts, and Blocked Accounts. Rhodesian Accounts are held by persons, firms, or compa- nies (including banks) resident, domiciled, or registered in Rhodesia. They may be credited with all authorized payments by South African residents, with the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South Africa of Rhodesian currency and of any specified currency, and w i th payments from local Non- resident or Rhodesian Accounts. They may be debited for payments for exports to Rhodesia and other payments due by Rhodesian residents to South African residents, for payments to the account holder while he is temporarily resident in South Africa for short periods, for payments to other local Rhodesian Accounts, and for the cost of purchases of Rhode- sian currency. Nonresident Accounts are held by persons, firms, or compa- nies (including banks) resident, domiciled, or registered out- side Rhodesia and the Rand Monetary Area. They may be credited w i th all authorized payments by South African resi- dents, w i th the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South Africa of specified currency, and with payments from other Nonresident Accounts in South Africa. They may be debited for payments to South African residents for any pur- pose; for payments to nonresidents for any purpose, i.e., by transfer to a local Nonresident or Rhodesian Account or for remittance to any coun try outside the Rand Monetary Area; for the cost of purchases of any foreign currency; and for payments to the account holder while he is temporarily resi- dent in South Africa for short periods. Blocked Accounts arc held by nonresidents of South Africa and are subject to exchange control restrictions. 4 They repre- sent ma in ly the proceeds from sales of South African securi- ties by a nonresident of South Africa to a resident. Such proceeds may not be transferred from South Africa or to another Blocked Account in South Africa, but may be re- tained on deposit w i th an authorized dealer, used within cer- tain limits for the holder's l iv ing expenses while visiting South Africa, or reinvested in securities which are quoted locally; 2 Aus tra l ian dollars, Aus tr ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche m a rk, Fiji dollars, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Ind i an rupees, I ta l ian lire, Japanese yen, Kenya shillings, Malagasy francs, Malawi kwacha, Netherlands guilders, New Zealand dollars, Norwegian kroner, Pakistan rupees, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Seychelles rupees, Spanish pesetas, Sri Lanka rupees, Swedish k rone r, Swiss francs, Uganda shillings, U.S. dollars, za'ires, and Zambian kwacha. 3 Foreign currency is any currency other than currency that is legal tender in South Africa. 4 Un l ike the other types of nonresident rand accounts, Blocked Accounts can also be held by residents of Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution such securities may be exported and sold abroad. If invested in government, municipal, or public utility bonds, the pro- ceeds on redemption at maturity are freely transferable to the nonresident owner, provided that he had held the securities for a continuous period of at least five years to redemption. Blocked rand may also be used to subscribe to a special issue, made available by the Government to nonresidents of South Africa only, of five-year transferable bonds offered by tender on a discount basis and repayable at face value in foreign currencies applicable to the domicile of the holder. In special cases, blocked rand may be used for direct investment in manufacturing enterprises. Emigrants' assets that exceed the permissible transferable amount, and the proceeds of South African securities held by immigrants prior to their arrival in South Africa or acquired abroad within three years of their arrival, are also blocked, but favorable consideration is given to the release of such immigrants' funds (see section on Capi- tal, below). Imports and Import Payments All importers of goods requiring import licenses must be registered with the Director of Imports and Exports. Most licenses allow the importation of a range of commodities, but they are, in general, to be used for goods as prescribed on the relevant import permit. Import licenses are valid for imports from any country. Imports free of license include (1) all goods imported from Botswana, Lesotho, or Swaziland and (2) all goods imported from Rhodesia, Malawi, and Zambia that were grown, produced, or manufactured in those countries. The Import Control Regulations for 1974, as announced in November 1973, distinguish generally between the following broad categories of imports: (1) Goods which may be imported without an import per- mit. This free list contains 650 tariff headings or subheadings and corresponds to some 15.7 per cent of 1973 imports. (2) Goods which may be imported only under permit but subject to automatic licensing for bona fide merchants and manufacturers. These fall under an unspecified number of tariff headings or subheadings and correspond to 70 per cent of 1973 imports. (3) Goods which may be imported only under permit and for which global quotas are determined from time to time. These account for about 7.5 per cent of 1973 imports. (4) Goods which may be imported only under permit and for which specific permits authorizing the import of these goods individually are issued. They cover some 6.8 per cent of 1973 imports. Provided that licensing regulations are respected and upon presentation to his bank of the necessary consignment docu- ments (proof of importation), an importer is automatically granted exchange to pay for the import. Payments for Invisibles There are no restrictions on payments and transfers for current international transactions. All payments to nonresi- dents of the Rand Monetary Area for current invisibles re- quire exchange licenses. Authority is, however, delegated to the commercial banks to approve certain payments without SOUTH AFRICA limitation and others up to established limits. For current income payments, such as declared dividends, profits, royal- ties, etc., that accrue in South Africa, approval is given by the authorized banks without reference to the Reserve Bank, pro- vided that the relative royalty agreement was approved by the Reserve Bank and the profits or dividends to be remitted by nonresident-owned branches and subsidiaries are based on profits earned since December 31, 1959 and their remittance does not involve the use of local credit facilities. Favorable consideration is, however, given by the Reserve Bank to such transfers where the use of local credit facilities is not regarded as excessive. Income derived from securities acquired with blocked funds or otherwise held by nonresidents is freely transferable to the owner's country of residence. Limited amounts of exchange to pay for membership fees, family maintenance, etc., are authorized. The basic allowance for tourist travel in a year is R 2,000 for an adult and R 800 for a child under the age of 12. Separately, there is another annual basic exchange allocation of R 350 for an adult (R 150 for a child under 12) for travel to Malawi, Rhodesia, Zaire, Zam- bia, and Portuguese East and West Africa. Applications for larger amounts are considered on their merits by the Reserve Bank. Residents leaving South Africa for destinations outside the Rand Monetary Area may take out not more than the equiva- lent of R 200 in banknotes. South African Reserve Bank notes, however, may not exceed R 50 but are not regarded as being part of the basic travel allowance. Foreign visitors leav- ing South Africa within 12 months after arrival may take with them up to R 50 in Reserve Bank notes and any amount of foreign notes which they brought into the country or obtained from the disposal of instruments of exchange that they brought to and exchanged in South Africa. These limitations on the export of Reserve Bank notes do not apply in the case of Bantu returning to neighboring countries, who are permit- ted to take with them reasonable amounts in the form of banknotes representing their earnings in South Africa. There are no limitations on the export of domestic currency to Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of commodities considered as being in relatively short supply, or for which domestic prices are substantially lower than those obtainable overseas, require licenses irre- spective of destination (with the exception of exports to Bo- tswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland). Certain other goods are controlled for strategic reasons only, and permits are required for their export to all destinations but no import certificate is required where the goods are exported to the United King- dom, any Commonwealth country, any British colony, pro- tectorate, or trust territory, or the United States. The re-export of imported goods to countries outside the Rand Monetary Area is controlled to prevent commodity and ex- change arbitrage. Unless otherwise permitted, all export proceeds must be surrendered within six months from the date of shipment and 30 days from the date of collection. 383 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SOUTH AFRICA Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered w i th in 30 days from the date of their acquisition, unless exemption is obtained. Upon entry from countries outside the Rand Mone- tary Area, residents and nonresidents may bring in R 50 in South African Reserve Bank notes. There are no limitations on the import of domestic currency from Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. Capital* Inward capital transfers require exchange control ap- proval; all inward loan transfers require specific approval, while inward transfers in respect of equity capital are freely permitted. Foreign exchange accruing to residents from capi- tal transfers and transactions must be surrendered. Outward transfers of capital by residents to destinations outside the Rand Monetary Area require the approval of the South Afri- can Reserve Bank and are usually not allowed; when fa l l ing under the Securities Control Notices, transfers to Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland also require prior approval. Local borrowing by nonresident-owned or nonresident-controlled firms is subject to limitation. Transfers by residents for the purchase of South African (or other) shares on the external stock exchanges are generally not permitted (except in amounts not exceeding R 2,000 for each shareholder, to allow South African residents to exercise rights arising from exist- ing holdings of shares in foreign companies quoted only on foreign stock exchanges), although South African stockbro- kers may engage in arbitrage transactions in securities, sub- ject to certain conditions designed to prevent any net ou tf low of exchange. Applications by South African residents to re- tain in, or transfer to, neighboring territories (this term ex- cludes Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland) funds for bona fide long-term investment in specific development projects or for the expansion of existing projects that are owned or con- trolled by South Africans are considered by the South African Reserve Bank and the Treasury on their merits. For three years after their arrival in South Africa, immigrants may dispose of their foreign assets held outside the Rand Mone- tary Area and also invest in South African securities abroad. However, the proceeds from the sale of all South African securities brought in by immigrants are blocked; the blocking is normally for at least three years, but the restriction may be removed on amounts up to R 20,000 or more, to enable the immigrant to set up a home and to meet current living ex- penses. The proceeds of the sale of South African securities by nonresidents of South Africa to residents must be credited to Blocked Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). The following payments related to nonresident capi- tal may be carried out by the authorized banks w i thout refer- ence to the South African Reserve Bank: transfers to nonresidents of South Africa of the proceeds on ma tu r i ty of government, municipal, and public u t i l i ty bonds and national 5 For purposes of the application of the Securities Control Notices, a nonresident is defined as a person whose normal place of residence or domicile is outside South Africa. For all other exchange control purposes, a nonresident is a person whose normal place of residence or domicile is outside the Rand Mone tary Area. 384 savings certificates, provided that they were registered in the name of the nonresident transferee (who was not an emigrant) on June 16, 1961, or, if the stocks were acquired after June 16, 1961, provided that they are registered continuously in the beneficial owner's name for a period of not less than five years to redemption; normal capital repayments to nonresi- dents of South Africa by certain "dying" mines in regular periodic installments not exceeding in any one year 10 per cent of the nominal value per share; transfers to nonresi- dent owners of any balance of up to R 50 left over from the reinvestment of blocked funds; and transfers of up to R 20,000 to a nonresident beneficiary from the proceeds of legacies from estates in South Africa that hold no foreign assets. Emigrant families whose assets do not exceed R 20,000 may have R 10,000 transferred outside South Africa as a settling-in allowance, and those with greater assets may have 50 per cent of their assets, up to R 30,000, transferred; any balance exceeding the permissible transferable amount is blocked. Emigrants may, however, utilize such blocked funds up to an amount of R 30,000 a family unit to subscribe to the five-year nonresident bonds issued by the Government on a tender basis (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). The South African Reserve Bank approves transfers of repayments at ma tur i ty to nonresident holders of mortgage bonds registered in their names on or before June 16, 1961. Favorable consideration is given for the transfer by nonresi- dent-owned branches and subsidiaries of open or approved loan account balances or undistributed current profits, or for the transfer of any dividends by them, provided that the remittance does not involve the use of local credit facilities. The physical export from South Africa of nonresident-owned securities is permitted, except by emigrants in excess of their settling-in allowance. There are normally three ways in which holders of blocked rand (including holders resident in Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland) can repatriate funds from South Africa: (1) by taking up special nonresident bonds issued by the Govern- ment (see above)—these mature in five years, when the re- demption proceeds may be withdrawn at the official rate; (2) by holding certain government, municipal, and public utility bonds and national savings certificates for at least five years to redemption, when the proceeds can be transferred abroad at the official rate; and (3) by exporting South African shares bought on the Johannesburg stock exchange, provided that they have been restrictively endorsed, and selling them out- side South Africa at a price which may involve a premium or a discount on the South African quotation; on December 31, 1973, the corresponding discount on blocked rand was about 21 per cent. Gold Residents of South Africa may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in South Africa for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents of South Africa other than the mone- tary authorities, authorized dealers, registered gold produc- ers, and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. All exports of gold require the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution prior approval of the Reserve Bank; the approval au thor i ty has been delegated to authorized dealers in respect of exports of jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler (sub- ject to a written declaration to the effect that the jewelry will be brought back to South Africa on the traveler's return) and in respect of exports of gold jewelry by manufac tur ing jewel- ers (subject, except for exports to Malawi, Rhodesia, and Zambia, to a written declaration that the articles are in fu l ly manufactured form and that the gold content of each does not exceed 75 per cent of the selling price to the ultimate con- signee). Furthermore, authorized dealers may without refer- ence to the Reserve Bank allow residents to export for numismatic purposes currency coins, including gold coins, up to R 300 for each applicant during a calendar year. The gold-mining industry sells its ou tput to the Reserve Bank, except for sales effected on the industry's behalf in the free market. The Mint from time to time strikes gold coins that are legal tender but do not circulate freely in South Africa as currency; these are made available in limited numbers to resident collec- tors, while the bulk is sold in other countries. Imports of gold are confined mainly to coins for numis- matic purposes and to certain types of jewelry. Changes during 1973 February 14. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the par value of the South African rand was maintained in terms of gold. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar, previously R 0.782891 = US$1, became R 0.704603 = US$1. The South African Re- serve Bank announced a middle rate for the U.S. dollar of R 1 = US$1.4193, and its fixed rates for the U.S. dollar were changed to US$1.4229 buy ing and US$1.4157 selling, per R 1. February 27. Authorized dealers were instructed hence- for th not to depart from the fixed public telegraphic transfer rates of exchange for U.S. dollars quoted by the South Afri- can Reserve Bank in their transactions with customers. Two permissible exceptions were indicated where authorized deal- ers could continue to accord a concession of Vie of 1 per cent in the spot rate, and foreign correspondent banks could be granted the same concession in the buying rate for the pur- pose of funding local rand accounts. (On April 25, this con- cession was extended also to the selling rate). Authorized dealers were, furthermore, obliged to observe as a minimum the Reserve Bank's fixed U.S. dollar rates in their computa- tions of exchange rates for other specified currencies. March 2. Exchange transactions were suspended. They were resumed on March 19, when the Reserve Bank was prepared again to buy and sell U.S. dollars at the rates it quoted prior to the suspension. March 7. A further relaxation of import restrictions came into effect. Some 120 items were added to the list of goods which could be imported without license. About 27 commod- ity groups which formerly could be imported only under individual specific licenses were transferred to the global quota list and certain other items were moved from the global quota list to the list of goods subject to automatic licenses. SOUTH AFRICA Additional quotas were announced as follows: for clothing, quotas were revised upward by 40 per cent of 1972 allocations and a fur ther 80 per cent increase was to be issued in August 1973. A fu r ther allocation of 40 per cent was also issued for consumer goods and all alcoholic beverages except for whis- key, for which the total additional allocation was 80 per cent. For confectionery the additional allocation was 80 per cent of 1972 allocations and fur ther allocations for confectionery and consumer goods would be made available later in the year. May 10. It was announced that the Banks Act would be amended to permit statutory control over the size of foreign shareholdings in South African banks. Foreign-controlled banks or bank holding companies would, in consultation with the Minister of Finance, have to reduce the foreign sharehold- ing w i th in a reasonable period to at most 50 per cent, and any foreign shareholding would eventually have to be reduced to 10 per cent. An existing foreign shareholding in a South African bank of more than 10 per cent and less than 50 per cent could not be increased and any additional share issues were to be sold only to South Africans. Furthermore, South African branches of foreign insurance companies would be required to incorporate locally within a specified period of time, and only insurers incorporated and registered under the Insurance Act would be permitted to conduct business in South Africa. Foreign shareholdings in South African discount houses would be limited to 10 per cent. By the end of the year, no legislation had yet been enacted to give effect to this policy statement. June 5. The South African Reserve Bank henceforth quoted a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$ 1.4900 per R 1. New official buying and selling rates were set at US$1.4937 and US$1.4862, respectively, per R 1. The par value was maintained in terms of gold. June 25. The Hong Kong dollar was added to the list of specified currencies. July 16. Blocked rand held by emigrants could henceforth be used to cover the holder's living expenses while visiting South Africa. This facility was limited to R 2,000 for each family unit a calendar year at the rate of R 20 a day for each adult (R 10 a day for each child under 12). They could also be utilized to cover the local payment of the emigrants' fares in respect of travel direct to South Africa and /or direct from South Africa to their new country of domicile. July 16. Two additional facilities for the allocation of ex- change for business travel were introduced. One provided for an omnibus application to be submitted by any individual firm to the Reserve Bank, while the other involved the grant- ing to individual companies by the Reserve Bank of an overall limit for allocation, at the company's discretion, of the foreign exchange authorized to its individual representatives. July 16. The rules governing remittances for study pur- poses were eased. July 16. The rules governing the transfer by life insurance offices of life policies from South African registers to a regis- ter in any country outside the Republic were eased. August 16. An additional 66 types of import items were transferred to the free list. Supplementary allocations of li- censes were announced as follows: 80 per cent for consumer 385 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SOUTH AFRICA goods, clothing, and whiskey; and 40 per cent for other alco- holic beverages and confectionery. August 31. Exports of seed cotton and cotton lint were brought under licensing control. Licenses were not normally issued. September 1. The rules governing the import and export of South African Reserve Bank notes were simplified and tight- ened. Henceforth residents going to other countries outside the Rand Monetary Area could take out R 50 in South Afri- can Reserve Bank notes and bring in the same amount on return. Visitors to South Africa from countries outside the Rand Monetary Area also were permitted to bring in and take out R 50 in South African Reserve Bank notes. September 15. South Africa formally accepted the obliga- tions of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree- ment. November 16. Further relaxations of import restrictions were announced. Fifty-one types of commodities were added to the free list. Control over 13 types of commodities subject to specific license was relaxed, either by a shift to global quotas or to issuance of specific licenses to meet the full reasonable requirements of importers. For 1974, an initial permit allocation equivalent to 60 per cent of total 1973 allocations would be issued for consumer goods, clothing, confectionery, and alcoholic beverages. In accordance with normal practice, additional permit allocations for 1974 would be considered during May 1974. November 27. It was announced tha t, while foreign-con- trolled banks would still be required to reduce foreign share- holdings to 50 per cent by 1983, they would not be obliged to reduce them further to 10 per cent. December 7. It was announced that, upon request by the South African Government, the International Monetary Fund had reviewed its decision on the policy of sales of South African gold to the Fund which had been adopted on Decem- ber 30, 1969, and had decided to terminate it. 386 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0126953 gram of f ine gold per Spanish Peseta, corresponding to Ptas 70 = SDR 1, and Spain avails itself of wider margins. The official intervention limits are Ptas 56.7237 buying, and Ptas 59.3350 selling, per US$1. The official buying and selling rates of the Bank of Spain on December 31, 1973 were Ptas 56.73 and Ptas 57.60 per US$1. l Official buying and selling rates for specified currencies 2 are fixed daily by the Bank of Spain acting in consultation with the authorized banks. Purchases and sales of clearing currencies are centralized in the Bank of Spain, which pub- lishes the rates at which it settles the transactions it carries out direct. These rates are the same as the prevailing rates for the U.S. dollar. The Bank of Spain also quotes buying and selling rates for banknotes in specified foreign currencies on a weekly basis. Authorized banks are allowed to operate in foreign mar- kets for spot transactions and forward transactions related to commercial transactions for up to 360 days; forward transac- tions with customers are restricted to currencies admitted to the Madrid foreign exchange market and to permitted import and export transactions with a ma tur i ty up to 360 days. Exchange Control Territory The Peninsular Territories of the Spanish State, the Canary Islands, the Balearic Islands, Ceuta, Melilla, and Spanish Sahara constitute a single exchange control territory, the Spanish Monetary Area. Administration of Control The guidelines on foreign exchange policy are formulated by an interministerial commission. The Ministry of Com- merce is in charge of all administrative functions connected with the exchange control. The Bank of Spain is in charge of the operative functions (basically, the handling of the external reserves). Trade controls are administered by the Ministry of Com- merce. This Ministry also is in charge of the controls over Spanish investment abroad, private Spanish borrowing abroad, foreign financing of imports, and the registration of foreign investments in Spain. Technology contracts must be registered with the Ministry of Industry. Prescription of Currency Settlements on account of merchandise transactions and invisibles other than those with bilateral payments agreement countries may be made in any specified cu r rency ,2 but in practice they are usually made in the currency determined on 1 With effect from January 22, 1974 Spain ceased to observe, for the time being, the previously announced margins for the U.S. dollar. As a result, the peseta appreciated in terms of the U.S. dollar. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. the basis of the country of origin or destination. Settlements with bilateral payments agreement countries3 are made through agreement accounts expressed in U.S. dollars. Nonresident Accounts There are six types of nonresident accounts: Foreign Ac- counts in Pesetas for Payments in Spain (A Accounts), For- eign Accounts in Convertible Pesetas (B Accounts), External Accounts in Internal Pesetas, Nonresident Accounts in Con- vertible Foreign Currencies, Bank Accounts in Pesetas with Andorra, and Emigrants* Accounts. A Accounts may freely be credited with (1) the countervalue in pesetas of convertible currencies sold on the Spanish for- eign exchange market; (2) amounts transferred from other A Accounts; (3) amounts transferred from B Accounts; and (4) any interest payable on the account concerned. These ac- counts may freely be debited for (1) any payment in pesetas in favor of Spanish juridical persons and Spanish or foreign physical persons habitually resident in Spain; and (2) trans- fers to other A Accounts. Debits for the purchase of foreign currency for remittance abroad are not permitted. B Accounts may freely be credited with (1) any peseta col- lections generated in Spain that under existing rules are trans- ferable abroad under powers delegated to authorized banks; (2) amounts transferred from other B Accounts; and (3) any interest payable on the account concerned. The crediting of amounts originating from A Accounts is prohibited. B Ac- counts may be freely debited for (1) the countervalue in pese- tas of foreign currency acquired on the Spanish foreign exchange market; (2) transfers to other B Accounts; and (3) transfers to A Accounts. All other entries on A or B Accounts require the prior authorization of the Bank of Spain. Private banks are required to make special noninter- est-bearing deposits in cash at the Bank of Spain, in an amount equivalent to 100 per cent of the increases after Octo- ber 18, 1971 in nonresident-held deposits in A and B Ac- counts (demand deposits, savings account deposits, or time deposits at less than three months' notice), and in an amount equivalent to 50 per cent of the increases in such deposits when held for three months or more (100 per cent of any increase after February 7, 1973). Furthermore, banks are pro- hibited from paying interest on any nonresident-held peseta deposits in A or B Accounts, whether demand, time, or sav- ings deposits. External Accounts in Internal Pesetas are designed to hold funds accruing in Spain to nonresidents that are not transfer- able abroad ("blocked pesetas"). Balances are freely negotia- ble between nonresidents holding such accounts; if the recipient of pesetas does not hold an account of this type, he needs prior approval to open one. These accounts may be credited freely with (1) capital gains realized on the sale by a nonresident to a resident of Spanish real estate originally 3 Colombia, Cuba, Eastern Germany, Egypt, and Equatorial Guinea. With effect from January 1, 1974 settlements w i th Eastern Germany took place in convertible currencies. 387 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN acquired with convertible foreign currency or with pesetas from an A Account, a B Account, or an External Account in Convertible Pesetas; (2) the full proceeds of the sale by a nonresident to a resident of Spanish real estate originally acquired with pesetas from an External Account in Internal Pesetas; (3) with receipts from the National Lottery (when no evidence is submitted that the ticket was acquired with for- eign exchange); (4) with interest received on balances held in these accounts; and (5) with transfers from any other Exter- nal Accounts in Internal Pesetas. They may be debited for (1) payments of personal expenses in Spain of the account holder and his close relatives (managers' personal expenses if the account is opened in the name of a juridical person); (2) the purchase of bonds and shares quoted on the stock exchange; (3) the purchase for the use of the account holder of town and country properties that do not represent investment for com- mercial, industrial, or agricultural purposes; (4) the purchase of National Lottery tickets; and (5) transfers to any other External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. All other entries on these accounts require prior authorization and the accounts may not be overdrawn. Nonresident Accounts in Convertible Foreign Currencies may be held by nonresident foreign nationals, nonresident Spanish nationals, and nonresident firms or banks; resident foreign nationals may maintain such accounts only if opened before January 1, 1968. The deposits may be either sight or time deposits. The accounts may be credited with convertible currencies quoted in the Spanish exchange market and with any amount of interest. They may be debited freely for recon- version into the currency initially deposited, for the purchase of other convertible currencies quoted in the Spanish ex- change market, and for conversion into pesetas, including the transfers to an A Account or a B Account. Overdrafts are prohibited except for mail credits in favor of foreign banks. Emigrants' Accounts—Since October 29, 1970, commercial banks have been authorized to open savings accounts in con- vertible pesetas for Spaniards working abroad. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Most imports are admitted under the following arrangements: (1) free im- ports, (2) global quotas, (3) state trading, and (4) individual licensing, also referred to as the "bilateral import regime." All imports require either an import license or an "import decla- ration" issued by the Directorate-General of Tariff Policy and Imports. Provided that import prices are not considered ab- normal, import declarations are issued freely for a large num- ber of goods (mostly foodstuffs not under state trading, raw materials, capital goods, and spare parts, but also some con- sumer goods) included in an import free list that applies to most countries with which Spain has no bilateral payments agreements; the free list also applies to specified imports from Iran and Japan. 4 All other imports require licenses. There are global quotas for specified imports from countries to which the free list applies, but licenses are usually 4 The import free list does not apply to the payments agreement countries (except Egypt) or to Afghanistan, Albania, Andorra, Bhutan, People's Republic of China, North Korea, Laos, Mongolia, Nepal, North Viet-Nam, San Marino, Tibet, and U.S.S.R. 388 granted for larger amounts. 5 With certain exceptions, the global quota regime also applies to goods of Japanese origin. Licenses for specified imports from Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R. are issued freely. Imports of raw cotton, certain other agricultural prod- ucts, some raw materials, petroleum products, and tobacco are state traded; some goods formally listed as being subject to state trading, such as feedgrains, may in fact be freely imported by private traders. Imports of certain agricultural products that are free of quantitative restriction and previ- ously were state traded are subject to variable import levies. Import subsidies are paid on certain foodstuffs and specified other essential commodities. Exchange in the appropriate currency to pay for authorized imports is granted freely. Ex- cept for capital goods, suppliers' credit for imports is not normally permitted to exceed 90 days. All import transac- tions must be domiciled with an authorized bank, and the import payment must be made through the intermediary of the bank of domiciliation; exempt from domiciliation are transactions whose value is less than Ptas 500,000 provided that payment is to be made within one year. Payments for Invisibles All transfers abroad and payments by residents in favor of nonresidents on account of current invisibles are subject to authorization, for the purpose of checking capital transac- tions. Payments up to Ptas 5,000 for any purpose may be made freely. For a large proportion of invisibles, the banks are authorized to sell foreign exchange freely, provided that the request is supported by appropriate documents. For cer- tain services transfers may be made freely up to a pre-estab- lished amount; for transfers which exceed that amount licenses are required which are granted freely. Holders of Spanish securities (excluding securities issued by private companies and acquired through direct subscrip- tion) may freely transfer abroad accrued interest, dividends, and proceeds from the disposal of subscription rights; the securities must have been purchased with convertible pesetas, with pesetas resulting from the sale of foreign exchange quoted in the Spanish foreign exchange market, or with pese- tas released on or after June 1, 1972 from External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. Profits and dividends on direct invest- ments are also transferable abroad without restriction. A general license permits the reinsurance abroad of risks in- sured in Spain with Spanish firms or with foreign insurance companies operating in Spain. Insurance contracts abroad may not be concluded, except where they concern exports and imports of goods. There is a basic tourist exchange allowance of Ptas 75,000 a person a year; however, amounts in excess of this limit are approved freely for bona fide tourist expenses. The authorized banks are also permitted to sell the equivalent of Ptas 2,000 a day for business trips, up to the equivalent of Ptas 100,000 a person for each trip. For larger amounts, the banks must apply for approval, which is granted freely for this purpose. 5 There are separate global quotas for imports of the same commodities from EEC countries. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Travelers may take with them Ptas 10,000 in notes of the Bank of Spain. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports are subject to prior licensing by the Director- ate-General of Exportation. Exports to all destinations of olives for oil production are suspended, while other types of olives may be exported freely. All export proceeds must be sold in the exchange market or to the Bank of Spain through authorized banks. Certain agricultural exports are subject to an export tax. Proceeds from Invisibles All exchange proceeds from invisibles must be sold in the exchange market or to the Bank of Spain through authorized banks. Travelers may bring in a maximum of Ptas 50,000 in notes of the Bank of Spain. Capital Foreign capital participation in Spanish industries of up to 50 per cent of the capital of the enterprise is exempt from authorization, while investment that exceeds 50 per cent re- quires the authorization of the Council of Ministers; for par- ticipation in Spanish shipping companies, the former ratio is 40 per cent. All investment in a few specified industrial and agricultural sectors requires prior authorization by the Gov- ernment. Foreign investment is not permitted in Spanish en- terprises whose activity is directly connected with national defense, public information, and certain public services. Foreign investment for the purpose of modernizing, ex- panding, and establishing Spanish enterprises may be effected either by transferring currencies that are negotiable in the Madrid exchange market, by using convertible pesetas, by bringing in capital goods, by reinvesting profits or capital transferable under the Foreign Investment Law, or by provid- ing know-how, patents, or licenses. All technology contracts require prior registration with the Ministry of Industry. Proceeds, including capital appreciation, from the liquida- tion of foreign direct investments made for the purpose of establishing, modernizing, and expanding Spanish enterprises may be transferred freely. Purchases by nonresidents of shares in most Spanish com- panies, as specified in Decree No. 701 of April 18, 1963 (including investment trusts but excluding those companies whose activity is directly connected with national defense, public information, and certain public services) are permitted freely. This applies to shares acquired by Spaniards resident abroad, as well as by resident or nonresident foreigners, either with convertible pesetas or with pesetas resulting from the conversion of foreign currencies negotiable in the Spanish exchange market. Proceeds, including capital gains, from the liquidation of such shares may be transferred abroad at any time, or used for further purchases of shares. The above ap- plies also to bonds and other fixed-income securities repre- senting debts of Spanish companies; there is no limit on bond holdings. SPAIN Investment in Spanish real estate by nonresidents is freely permitted if financed with pesetas derived from convertible currencies or from balances in nonresident peseta accounts (A or B Accounts). The Bank of Spain has empowered autho- rized banks to provide the investor with a document certify- ing that he owns such pesetas; this is the only requirement for official registration of the change in ownership. Certain in- vestments in real estate may also be financed from External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. Irrespective of the method of financing, country properties purchased may not exceed 4 hectares of irrigated land or 20 hectares of unirrigated land. When Spanish real estate is sold to a resident, the full sale proceeds are transferable if the initial purchase was financed with pesetas from External Accounts in Internal Pesetas, but only the capital gain over the registered purchase price is transferable if the initial purchase was financed with convert- ible foreign currency or with pesetas from an External Ac- count in Convertible Pesetas, an A Account, or a B Account. Outward capital transfers by residents require approval. Requests by firms to invest abroad in the same line of busi- ness are granted rather liberally, provided that the investment contributes to the expansion of Spanish exports; this includes participation in foreign enterprises. No authorization is re- quired for such investments when undertaken by Spanish enterprises with net assets in Spain of at least Ptas 100 mil- lion, provided that the firm's total foreign investments do not exceed 40 per cent of its assets in Spain. Other direct invest- ments are subject to more severe restrictions. Portfolio invest- ments by all residents and purchases of real estate abroad by private persons are severely restricted. However, registered investment funds with assets of at least Ptas 1 billion are permitted to place up to 10 per cent of their assets in foreign securities that are officially quoted on specified stock ex- changes abroad. Approval of requests by residents to grant loans to non- residents is based on criteria similar to those applied to resi- dents' requests to make direct investments abroad. Suppli- ers' credits from Spanish residents to nonresidents require authorization by the Directorate-General of Exportation; such authorization accompanies the export license. Before issuing the license, the Bank of Spain may be consulted about the granting of the credit. There has been no experience with the issuing of bonds in the Spanish capital market by nonresidents, nor with short-term credits granted by Spanish banks to nonresidents other than certain export credit granted direct to foreign importers. Credits to nonresidents for transactions with Spain may, however, be authorized by the Ministry of Com- merce. Also, the authorized banks may extend various types of credit to nonresidents, provided that this credit is financed with funds deposited in Spain in nonresident convertible cur- rency accounts; some forms of such credit do not require prior approval by the Ministry of Commerce. Local borrow- ing at medium term or long term by Spanish firms with foreign participation in excess of 25 per cent is subject to special directives. For transfers abroad of inheritances and dowries, authori- zations are granted liberally when small amounts are in- volved. 389 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Spain for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. By law, only the Bank of Spain is allowed to import or export gold; industrial requirements are met by imports effected by the Bank of Spain. There is a global quota for imports of gold from member countries of the EEC. Changes during 1973 During the year import duties and compensatory duties on many commodities were temporarily reduced or suspended. January 1. Following the expiration of the bilateral pay- ments agreements with Bulgaria, Hungary, and Romania, settlements with these countries were placed on a convertible currency basis. January 2. Imports of various foods tuffs were liberalized. January 24. The global quotas for 1973 were published. Their total value was over Ptas 17.6 billion. February 7. All day-to-day increases in credit balances on External Accounts in Convertible Pesetas, and renewed fixed deposits on such accounts, became subject to a reserve re- quirement of 100 per cent. Remittances of Spanish workers abroad were exempt. February 8. The Minister of Finance was empowered to authorize industrial banks to acquire more than 50 per cent of the capital of foreign banks and financial institutions. The 50 per cent limit on participations in other juridical persons remained in force. February 17. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, Spain maintained its par value in terms of gold and continued to avail itself of wider margins. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar, previ- ously Ptas 64.4737 = US$1, became Ptas 58.0264 = US$1. New intervention limits were set of Ptas 56.7237 buying, and Ptas 59.3350 selling, per US$1. (Subsequently, the official buying and selling rates within these limits were modified on several occasions.) February. Bulgaria, Hungary, and Romania were included among the countries to which the import free list and the global import quotas were applicable. March 1. Decree No. 48771973 was published easing, w i th effect from March 22, the restrictions on outward direct in- vestment and simplifying approval procedures for such in- vestment. No special authorization would be required for registered Spanish exporting enterprises with net assets in Spain of at least Ptas 100 million, provided a firm's total foreign participation did not exceed 40 per cent of its net assets in Spain and that the companies in which they partici- pated were engaged in their own line of business. March 13. Exchange risk guarantees for importers and exporters were introduced. They were available only for cur- rencies officially quoted in Madrid and restricted to losses of more than 3 per cent arising from the devaluation of the foreign currency concerned. Any exchange profits, however, 390 had to be surrendered to the insuring agency, the Spanish Export Credit Insurance Company. March 13. Authorized banks were empowered to conclude forward exchange transactions with resident importers and exporters for periods of up to one year; previously the limit was six months. March 17. Two types of nonresident peseta accounts, For- eign Accounts in Pesetas for Payments in Spain (A Accounts) and Foreign Accounts in Convertible Pesetas (B Accounts), were introduced to replace the External Accounts in Convert- ible Pesetas. A Accounts could be credited with the proceeds of convertible foreign exchange remitted from abroad and sold on the exchange market in Spain, but could be debited only for payments in pesetas to residents, not for the repur- chase of foreign exchange. B Accounts could be debited for payments in pesetas to residents and for purchases of convert- ible foreign currency for remittance abroad but could be cred- ited only w i th pesetas generated in Spain and qualifying for remittance under existing exchange control regulations. Transfers from B Accounts to A Accounts were freely permit- ted, as were transfers between B Accounts or between A Accounts, but transfers from A Accounts to B Accounts were prohibited. Any day-to-day increase in credit balances in A or B Ac- counts was subject to the 100 per cent reserve requirement previously applicable to External Accounts in Convertible Pesetas. The interest prohibition applicable to the latter was extended to both A and B Accounts. All External Accounts in Convertible Pesetas were redesig- nated as B Accounts, so that balances remained freely trans- ferable abroad through the purchase of convertible foreign currencies. March 23. Registered investment funds and closed-end in- vestment companies w i th assets or net share capital of at least Ptas 1 billion were permitted by a general authorization, with effect from April 1, to place up to 10 per cent of their assets or net share capital in securities listed on specified stock exchanges abroad. Purchases had to be spread over a ten-mon th period beginning April 1, at a maximum rate of 1 per cent a mon th. Implementing regulations were issued on July 20. Foreign securities so acquired could be negotiated in Spain between the funds and investment companies con- cerned. March 24. The basic exchange allowance for tourist travel was increased from the equivalent of Ptas 50,000 a person a year to the equivalent of Ptas 75,000 a person a year. The amount of domestic banknotes that travelers could export was increased from Ptas 3,000 to Ptas 10,000. April 9. The bilateral payments agreement with the Syrian Arab Republic expired. May 14. The Syrian Arab Republic was included among the countries to which the import free list and the global import quotas were applicable. June 5. Most import duties were reduced with effect from June 7. The average reduction was about 10 per cent. June 9. Imports of specified products were liberalized "for as long as present economic conditions continued." July 18. Additional imports were liberalized. They in- cluded sulphur, lead, tractors, television sets, radios, tape ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution recorders, and motor vehicles other than passenger automo- biles. (Imports of automobiles were not liberalized in 1973.) July 24. A new mining law, Law No. 22/1973 of July 21 was published. Section VIII dealt with participation by for- eign physical and juridical persons; such participation would generally be limited to 49 per cent of any rights granted. July 26. Decree No. 1794/1973 established a Direction General de Transacciones Exteriores within the Ministry of Commerce to control residents' overseas transactions (other than financial credits), foreign investment in Spain, and in- vestment abroad by residents. July 27. Decree-Law No. 6/1973 of July 17 and Decree No. 1791/1973 of July 26 were published. They abolished the Spanish Foreign Exchange Institute (IEME) and the Oficina de Coordination y Programacion Economica (OCYPE). Some of the exchange control functions of IEME were taken over by the Bank of Spain, and all other functions were transferred to the Ministry of Commerce. After this reorganization, the division of functions was as follows: The Directorate-General of External Transactions assumed the administrative functions of IEME. These in- cluded the authorization and control of inward and outward remittances and of the bank accounts of nonresidents, and the authorization and registration of foreign guarantees for pe- seta debts; the Directorate-General would also be responsible for the authorization and control of foreign currency borrow- ing by residents for purposes of financing trade transactions. The Council for External Investments, presided over by the Undersecretary of Commerce, took over the responsibilities of OCYPE, including the processing of applications for in- ward investments with majority control by nonresidents. The Bank of Spain continued to be responsible for the day-to-day management of the foreign exchange reserves and for official settlements and movements in foreign currencies (including the control over the official exchange rates and the interven- tion points in the foreign exchange market). It would also be responsible for the authorization of foreign currency loans to residents for nontrade purposes. August 18. Imports of cocoa and cocoa products ceased to be subject to state trading and were liberalized. September 14. It was announced that imports of certain basic foodstuffs would be liberalized, while exports of such SPAIN commodities would be suspended or become subject to levies. Ptas 3.2 billion was made available for additional imports of various other commodities by official agencies. September 21. Decree No. 2343/1973 regulated the transfer of foreign technology to Spanish enterprises. Registration of authorized contracts with the Ministry of Industry (Director- ate-General of Industrial Promotion and Technology) be- came a prerequisite for the transfer of royalties and fees. October 11. Decree No. 2495/1973 tightened the controls over inward direct investment. While previously foreign par- ticipation in 18 industries was exempt from authorization up to 100 per cent of the capital of the company concerned, and for other industries foreign participation was exempt only up to 50 per cent of capital, henceforth foreign participation in excess of 50 per cent of the capital in all industries required prior authorization. Decree No. 701/1963 of April 18, 1963 amending the Foreign Investment Law of July 20, 1959 was revoked. October 15. Exports of olive oil in bulk and of rice were suspended. October 20. Exports of petroleum products were sus- pended. October 31. The domiciliation floor for imports was raised from Ptas 100,000 to Ptas 500,000. November 1. The liberalization of imports of certain indus- trial products, introduced on November 3, 1972 for a period of one year, was extended indefinitely. November 3. A Resolution of the Directorate-General of External Transactions permitted authorized banks to accept and grant a guarantee or 0wz/with respect to permitted exter- nal trade, invisibles from or in favor of nonresidents, and capital transactions. November 30. Decree-Law No. 13/1973 reorganized the Comisaria General de Abastecimientos y Transportes. December 1. An anti-inflation plan for 1974 was an- nounced. It provided for additional import liberalization and export restriction measures. December 19. Import duties on virtually all goods were reduced by 5 percentage points, for three months. December 21. Agreement was reached with Eastern Ger- many to place settlements on a convertible currency basis with effect from January 1, 1974. 391 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SRI LANKA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.149297 gram of fine gold per Sri Lanka Rupee, or SL Rs 5.95237 = SDR 1; no exchange transactions take place at exchange rates based on the par value. The Sri Lanka rupee is pegged to sterling at the rate of SL Rs 15.60 = £ stg. 1 and the exchange rate system for the time being is based on this official rate for sterling, which is floating in terms of the U.S. dollar and other major currencies. Another effective rate of SL Rs 25.74 = £ stg. 1 arises from transactions in Foreign Exchange Entitlement Certificates (henceforth called certificates), which exporters of nontradi- tional exports (i.e., exports other than tea, rubber, and major coconut products but including green tea and instant tea) and most other earners or recipients of foreign exchange are enti- tled to receive upon surrender of foreign exchange earned; on December 31, 1973 the corresponding exchange rate for the U.S. dollar was SL Rs 11.1284 = US$1. Nonresident travel- ers when converting foreign exchange into Sri Lanka rupees at the official rate may also receive either corresponding cer- tificates or their cash value in rupees. The certificates are denominated in Sri Lanka rupees and are issued with a face value equivalent at the official rate to the foreign exchange surrendered; they are transferable within 30 days of the date of issue and may also be surrendered to the commercial banks for encashment at a price of SL Rs 65 per SL Rs 100 in certificates. Additional certificates are sold by commercial banks on behalf of the Central Bank of Ceylon upon demand and at the same price; such certificates are not transferable. Certificates with a face value corresponding at the official rate to the amount of foreign exchange required must be surren- dered when purchasing foreign exchange for payments in respect of most imports and most invisibles. The commercial banks deal in certificates for up to four months forward, at SL Rs 66 selling, and SL Rs 64 buying, per SL Rs 100 certificate; transactions are permitted only when relating to anticipated genuine payments and receipts in foreign ex- change to which the certificate requirements or privileges are applicable. The official exchange rate is applicable to receipts from major exports and to payments for "A category" imports (most staple food items, fertilizers, drugs, and certain other imports classified as essentials), as well as some invisibles. The Central Bank deals in U.S. dollars, sterling, and Indian rupees only. While its rates for sterling and the Indian rupee are fixed, the Central Bank determines exchange parities for some 20 other foreign currencies, including the U.S. dollar, from time to time on the basis of London market rates for those currencies. Rates for other foreign currencies are deter- mined by commercial banks, also on the basis of London market rates. On December 31, 1973 the Central Bank's buy- ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were SL Rs 6.7425 and SL Rs 6.745, respectively, per US$1. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Department of Exchange Control of the Central Bank of Ceylon as agent of 392 the Government. A foreign exchange budget, including an import program, is drawn up annually by the Ministry of Planning and Economic Affairs. All remittances of foreign exchange in Sri Lanka must be made through banks autho- rized to carry out operations in foreign currencies in accor- dance with the exchange control procedures prescribed by the Controller of Exchange. Remittances may also be made through post offices, under permits issued by the Controller of Exchange. Licenses for most imports of the industrial sec- tor, both private and public, are issued by the Actual Users Division of the Ministry of Industries and Scientific Affairs. Otherwise, import and export licensing is handled by the Controller of Imports and Exports. Prescription of Currency Sri Lanka has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Payments to countries that prior to June 23, 1972 were Scheduled Territo- ries may continue to be made in the currencies of such countries, and receipts from such countries continue to be acceptable in the currencies of such countries. Settlements with ten countries with which Sri Lanka has bilateral payments agreements 1 and with Egypt must be made through the relevant special accounts. Payments to all other countries except Rhodesia may be made by crediting sterling or Sri Lanka rupees to a sterling External Account or an External Rupee Account, or in the currency of the creditor country. Furthermore, payments for imports not originating in countries with which bilateral payments agree- ments are in force (nor in Rhodesia) may be made in any foreign currency, i.e., any currency other than the Sri Lanka rupee. Receipts from all other countries except Rhodesia may be accepted in sterling or Sri Lanka rupees from a sterling External Account or an External Rupee Account, in any specified currency, 2 or in any other External Account Area currency marketable in the United Kingdom, i.e., freely ex- changeable for sterling. Transactions involving deviations from the general procedures require the prior approval of the Controller of Exchange. Special procedures apply to settle- ments with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts may be held in Sri Lanka by banks, corporations, or persons residing abroad. Transfers of bal- ances in these accounts to Sterling Area Accounts or External Accounts require approval. Blocked Accounts are used for holding funds that may not be transferred abroad and that are owned by nonresidents, repatriates, and emigrants. Such funds, unless they originate 1 Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, North Korea, Poland, Romania, Syrian Arab Republic, and U.S.S.R. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution from payments for imports, may be used in Sri Lanka for prescribed investments. Proceeds from the liquidation of such investments must be credited to Blocked Accounts. Also re- tained in Blocked Accounts is a proportion of local currency earnings, derived from the exhibition of foreign-owned films, if the takings exceed the amount specified in the import li- cense; such retained funds may be used by the owner for certain specified purposes, including the making of films in Sri Lanka. Special Accounts may be maintained in Sri Lanka by na- tionals of Sri Lanka working abroad. Credits to the accounts are limited to the proceeds of remittances from abroad (inclu- sive of the value of the certificates to which the remittances entitle the holder) but the accounts may be freely debited for payments within Sri Lanka. Balances in such accounts are exempt from wealth tax, and income arising from investments made out of such balances is exempt from income tax. Imports and Import Payments All imports of goods originating in or shipped from Rhode- sia are prohibited. Except for imports by the Food Commis- sioner's Department and certain minor imports (such as trade samples, gifts of up to SL Rs 250, and books up to certain specified amounts for each consignment), all imports require individual licenses. All imports are subject to quota restrictions. They are divided into two groups —the A category and the B category. Imports in the A category broadly comprise basic necessities, Western Pharmaceuticals, fertilizers, books and periodicals, and two-wheeled tractors. The B category includes all re- maining imports. The value and composition of imports are established by an annual import program. Imports of many nonessential items or goods similar to locally produced items are either prohibited or considerably restricted. The right to import is restricted to government depart- ments, government-sponsored corporations, and registered importers, although private individuals are allowed to import certain commodities for their own use, subject to special authorization. Imports of specified commodities 3 are re- stricted to government or state corporations, the Cooperative Wholesale Establishment, or the Lanka Salu Sala Ltd.; these commodities are referred to as "reserved items." In order to allocate foreign exchange, applicants for import licenses are divided into three groups: (1) actual users of industrial raw materials, machinery, etc., (2) those who import other goods for their own use and not for resale, and (3) established importers who import goods for trading purposes. Public sector imports shipped or transshipped from places served by vessels of the Ceylon Shipping Corporation must be carried in vessels owned or chartered by the Corporation, whenever such shipping space is available. 3 These include mainly rice, wheat, flour (except corn flour), unrefined sugar, refined sugar, Maldive fish, dried fish, cumin seed, masoor dhal, dried chilies, coriander, pulses, yeast and baking powder, garlic, fennel seed, mathe seed, turmeric, dates, sultanas and raisins, cement, fish meal, corn, caustic soda, cotton yarn, newsprint and other paper products, petroleum products, and textiles and manufactures of textile materials. SRI LANKA Holders of funds in Convertible Rupee Accounts may use these for certain imports, subject to approval by the Control- ler of Imports and Exports. An authorized dealer may approve an application to remit foreign exchange or to credit a nonresident account when the applicant furnishes or undertakes to furnish, evidence of im- portation and the cost of the goods together with a valid importer's copy and an exchange control copy of the import license. Payment for imports in the B category requires, in addition to the rupee equivalent of the foreign exchange in- volved, surrender of certificates with a face value equal to the rupee payment; imports in the A category do not require the surrender of certificates. Import licenses for certain imports (primarily food products, industrial raw materials, and ma- chinery) are subject to a minimum deferred payment term. Letters of credit against such licenses may be opened pro- vided that drafts are drawn payable not earlier than 6 or 12 months after the shipment in accordance with the terms of the import license. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require exchange control per- mission and, with certain exceptions, require surrender of certificates corresponding to the full amount of the foreign payment. Exempt from surrender of certificates are (1) certain official travel expenditures abroad; 4 (2) expenditures for cer- tain approved courses of study abroad; (3) remittances abroad by nonnationals for family maintenance; (4) certain provident fund contributions and life insurance premiums; (5) pensions and the final remittance, on retirement, of provident and pension funds; (6) expenditures of foreign embassies, official international organizations, and foreign diplomatic personnel; and (7) other expenditures abroad specifically ex- empted from the certificate surrender requirement by the Controller of Exchange. The remittance of life insurance premiums on policies in foreign currencies purchased by nonnationals residing tempo- rarily in Sri Lanka is permitted, and such policies are consid- ered as part of the assets available to them on retirement. Foreign exchange for personal travel abroad is only granted for furloughs of nonnationals. Business travel is gen- erally limited to travel for the promotion of exports and of tourism, and exchange up to a maximum of £ stg. 10 a day for a maximum period of 30 days is allowed in such cases. Exchange for educational expenses is allocated only for certain courses of study that will be of positive value to the country and that are not available in Sri Lanka; allocations are subject to the approval of the Minister of Finance, acting on the personal recommendation of the Minister of Educa- tion. For study in educational institutions in "Asian group" countries, 5 exchange up to a maximum of SL Rs 250 a month for undergraduate studies or up to SL Rs 450 a month for postgraduate studies is allowed, as well as SL Rs 250 a year 4 When met out of the budget allocations for a government department or ministry, a state corporation, or an institution exempt from the operation of the certificate scheme. 5 The "Asian group" is listed as Aden, Afghanistan, the East African region, Brunei, Burma, Egypt, Hong Kong, India, Indochina, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Malaysia, Pakistan, Persian Gulf Sheikdoms, Saudi Arabia, Syrian Arab Republic, Thailand, and Turkey. 393 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SRI LANKA for books plus actual fees. For study in the United Kingdom, foreign exchange is made available at £ stg. 45 a month for undergraduate studies, and at £ stg. 60 a mon th for postgrad- uate studies, plus actual fees, and £ stg. 25 a year for the cost of books. Following the devaluation of the pound sterling in Novem- ber 1967, students in countries whose currencies were not devalued were allowed supplementary remittances to enable them to receive the same amount as previously in the currency concerned. For study in such countries (other than the United States and Canada), the maximum allowable is £ stg. 53 a month for undergraduate studies and £ stg. 70 a month for postgraduate studies; the maximum for the United States and Canada is US$225 a month and US$240 a month for under- graduate and postgraduate studies, respectively (in addition to an annual book allowance and actual fees). For travel and other expenses for medical reasons, ex- change is authorized if a certificate is produced from a medi- cal specialist in Sri Lanka and supported by the Director of Health Services that equally effective treatment cannot be obtained in Sri Lanka; the amount authorized will depend on the estimated cost, as certified by the specialist. Indian and Pakistani nationals are permitted to remit for family maintenance a maximum of SL Rs 750 a mon th or one third of their gross monthly income, whichever is less. Other foreign nationals are permitted to remit £ stg. 85 a month for a wife, £ stg. 80 for a boy in a public school, £ stg. 70 for a girl in a public school, £ stg. 60 for a child in a preparatory school, £ stg. 25 for other children, and £ stg. 45 a month less monthly income abroad for an employed child, up to a maxi- mum of two thirds of the gross monthly income when depen- dents are direct ones. For other dependents, this ceiling is one third of the gross monthly income. When the amount claimed on this basis exceeds one third of the gross mon th ly income, the excess will be treated as an anticipatory transfer to be set off against the amount the repatriate is entitled to remit upon departure. Temporary residents on short-term contracts are allowed to remit up to two thirds of their gross monthly income. Nationals of Sri Lanka are not granted exchange for family remittances. Commissions up to 5 per cent of the c.i.f. value are allowed on export orders secured through agents abroad. No remit- tances for insurance on exports are permitted; these must be covered with the Insurance Corporation of Sri Lanka. Holders of funds in Convertible Rupee Accounts may use these funds for travel expenditures and other current invisi- bles, subject to approval by the Controller of Exchange. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign exchange de- clared to the customs at the time of entry; they may not take out Sri Lanka currency notes and coins. Residents may take out Sri Lanka or foreign currency notes and coins not exceed- ing the equivalent of SL Rs 50 a person (SL Rs 25 for children under 12) once in 12 months, provided that they have been granted exchange for travel. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Permits issued by the Controller of Exchange are required for all commercial 394 exports, and exports to countries with which Sri Lanka main- tains bilateral payments agreements are subject to the ap- proval of the Director of Commerce. The export of some items is banned, and that of certain others requires export licenses issued by the relevant government agency. Rubber exports to the People's Republic of China, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R. are under state trading. The State Gem Corporation has the exclusive right to export gems and ex- ports of private exporters are handled in their name by the Corporation. Re-exports of nonmonetary gold, silver, and diamonds are allowed only in special circumstances. The Controller of Exchange issues the permit for a com- mercial export when he is satisfied that payment representing fair value for the goods has been or will be received in Sri Lanka by approved methods of payment and, usually, within six months from the date of shipment. Foreign exchange proceeds from exports must be surrendered. There are special arrangements, however, for gems and nontraditional exports. Exporters may maintain special accounts, designated Con- vertible Rupee Accounts. These may be credited with 25 per cent of the f.o.b. Sri Lanka rupee value (inclusive of certifi- cates) of the net export proceeds of gems and with 3 per cent of the f.o.b. value of nontraditional exports. Debits to the accounts are permitted for imports, travel abroad, and other payments which are not of a capital nature. Exporters of all goods other than tea (including instant tea), rubber, coconut oil, copra, desiccated coconut, and fresh coconuts are entitled to receive certificates with a face value in Sri Lanka rupees equal to the f.o.b. value of exports, upon surrender to an authorized bank of the foreign exchange actu- ally earned. Exporters can use these certificates as supporting documents when buying foreign exchange for payment of imports, or for other payments abroad, which require the surrender of certificates. Certificates are freely transferable within 30 days from the date of issue; they have to be surren- dered to the monetary authorities or an authorized bank before the expiry of that period. Certificates are not transfer- able thereafter, but the holders can use them when making foreign exchange payments within seven months from the date of issue; at the end of the seven-month period, the valid- ity of the certificate lapses. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange proceeds from invisibles must be surren- dered. Receipts under the following headings entitle the recip- ient to obtain certificates w i th a face value equivalent to the value of the foreign exchange surrendered to an authorized bank: (1) travel receipts; (2) insurance receipts; (3) investment income; (4) private transfers and donations; (5) small savings remitted to Sri Lanka by workers abroad; 6 (6) miscellaneous other inward remittances as determined, on a case-by-case basis, by the Controller of Exchange. Nonresident travelers 8 Since December 17, 1971 Sri Lanka nationals employed abroad and not availing themselves of the Special Accounts scheme for small savings introduced on February 6, 1971 may be required to remit to Sri Lanka a specified percentage of their annual earnings, if these exceed specified amounts. Compliance may be required for annual passport renewal. The funds remitted are entitled to certificates upon conversion but may not be used for impor ts or paymen ts abroad. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution are eligible to receive certificates corresponding to the amount of foreign exchange converted with authorized dealers; alter- natively, the latter may pay the traveler, in addition to the rupee equivalent of the foreign exchange sold, the cash value of the certificate. Part of the Sri Lanka rupee equivalent of certain proceeds from invisibles may be credited to Convertible Rupee Ac- counts; this proportion is 3 per cent of gross foreign exchange earnings from tourism, 25 per cent of foreign exchange earn- ings from professional and consultancy services performed by individuals, and 3 per cent of the proceeds from such services performed by firms, companies, etc. A traveler entering Sri Lanka must declare his holdings, including currency notes and coins. The amount of foreign funds that may be carried into Sri Lanka in the form of travel credit instruments is not restricted. The import of Sri Lanka, Indian, and Pakistan currency is not permitted; however, Sri Lanka notes in denominations of SL Rs 10 or less may be imported up to SL Rs 50, provided that evidence of prior export of such notes by the same traveler is produced. Other currency notes and coins may be taken in without restriction. Capital Investments of foreign capital are permitted in projects which are specifically approved by the Government, or, where the capital is drawn from a Blocked Account in Sri Lanka, in prescribed Ceylonese investments, including shares of public companies incorporated in Sri Lanka; capital trans- fers for direct investment in Sri Lanka are entitled to receive certificates upon conversion of the foreign exchange into ru- pees. Proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments in approved projects other than investments made from Blocked Accounts may be repatriated, along with capital appreciation; transfers require surrender of certificates. Pro- ceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments not ap- proved by the Government may not be transferred abroad, but they may be reinvested in prescribed investments; the current income thereon may be remitted abroad. New foreign investments in Sri Lanka that are considered and approved by the Foreign Investment Advisory Commit- tee of the Ministry of Planning and Economic Affairs are also granted special facilities in respect of remittances and taxa- tion. Investments abroad by residents are not normally per- mitted.
