They may be debited for payments to residents of Trinidad and Tobago; for transfers to other External Ac- counts; and for purchases of foreign currencies. The funds in these accounts are treated as equivalent to External Account sterling or any other foreign currency and may be transferred freely between residents of countries outside Trinidad and Tobago, w i th the exception that transfers f rom External Ac- counts held by residents of the Sterling Area to any coun try outside Trinidad and Tobago other than that of the hold- er's residence are conditional upon the Central Bank being satisfied that the exchange control authorities of the holder's coun t ry of residence do not object. Blocked Accounts may be credited w i th funds that may not be credited to External Accounts (e.g., proceeds from the sale by a nonresident of capital assets in Trinidad and Tobago, or proceeds from the sale of sterling securities). The use of bal- ances in Blocked Accounts is subject to authorization. Blocked funds may be reinvested in local securities which are not redeemable either optionally or con trac tua l ly w i th in four years from the date of acquisition. The income from such securities, and the proceeds at ma tu r i ty of any that are re- deemable, may be credited to an External Account. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Rhodesia are prohibited and no licenses are issued for imports from South Africa. Most imports from other countries are free of quan t i ta t ive restriction. For import control purposes, countries are divided in to two groups: (1) Albania, Bulgaria, the People's Republic of China, Czecho- slovakia, Eastern Germany, Hunga ry, Nor th Korea, Poland, Romania, Yugoslavia, and the U.S.S.R.; and (2) all other countries except Rhodesia and South Africa. The import regulations include prohibition or stringent control, state trad ing, ind iv idual licensing, and open general license arrangements. (1) Some of the main imports that are prohibited or are subject to stringent control are cosmetics, saccharin, coffee and cocoa beans, mechanical gambling devices, beer in con- tainers other than ten-ounce glass bottles and cans, and com- plete passenger automobiles. Firearms, ammun i t ion, narcotics, and certain other goods are either prohibited or rigidly controlled for security and health reasons. (2) Certain products covered by the Agricultural Market- ing Protocol of the Caribbean Free Trade Association (CARIFTA), as well as imported rice in bulk are the only commodities subject to state trading. This rice is normally imported from Guyana under government contracts, at agreed prices. 6 (3) All commodities other than those specified under (1) and (2) above are imported under either an individual license or an open general license arrangement. As indicated below, 6 Packaged rice may be imported th rough normal commercial channels, but such impo r ts are not usua l ly allowed f rom countries other th an Guyana unless the contracted supplies are not fo r thcom ing. 428 the scope of the arrangement depends on the countries from which the commodities are imported. (a) Imports from Albania, Bulgaria, the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, North Korea, Poland, Romania, Yugoslavia, and the U.S.S.R. All imports from these countries require a specific license. In practice, licenses are granted freely for imports from Czecho- slovakia, Poland, and Yugoslavia of commodities not on the "negative" list mentioned under (b) below. For the other countries in this group, licenses are granted only for essential goods. (b) Imports from all other countries except Rhodesia and South Africa. For imports from these countries, a "negative" list is published which lists all goods subject to individual licensing. (Specific licenses are usually not required for the importation of such goods, however, when they qualify for preferential treatment w i th in CARIFTA or the Caribbean Common Market; Trinidad and Tobago is a member of both.) All other goods may be imported under open general license. The "negative" list comprises over 400 tariff items. Licenses for these items may be issued by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, depending on the supply position of the domestic indus t ry. Whenever restrictions are applied on imports from countries other than those under (a) above, no discrimination is practiced because of the country of origin or the currency involved, with the exception that CARIFTA and Caribbean Common Market commitments are taken into account. Payments for all imports require an exchange license. If prescription of currency regulations are complied with, ex- change licenses are granted without restriction or undue delay whenever the authorities are satisfied that no unauthorized capital transfer is involved. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles require the specific ap- proval of the authorities. Applications for foreign exchange must be supported by appropriate documentary evidence. As a matter of policy, no restrictions are imposed on pay- ments for current international transactions, except where payments to Rhodesia and South Africa are concerned. Un- der au thor i ty delegated by the Government, the authorized banks may approve applications for foreign exchange within prescribed limits for certain invisibles. When additional amounts are needed, the approval of the authorities is re- quired and this is granted provided that unauthorized capital transfers are not involved. The basic allowance for tourist travel is TT$ 1,200 a person a year. Residents and nonresidents may take out Trinidad and Tobago notes up to the equivalent of TT$50. Travelers who are regarded as residents of Trinidad and Tobago may export part or all of their basic travel allowance (TT$ 1,200) in for- eign currency notes. Nonresidents visiting Trinidad and To- bago may, on departure, take out foreign currency notes up to the amount brought in by them. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited and no licenses are issued for exports to South Africa. Exports of certain listed goods require an individual license. The list includes some foods tuffs, arms and explosives, animals, gold, and petroleum and petroleum products produced in Trinidad and Tobago, as well as specified products (about 40 tariff items) not pro- duced there. Exports of all other commodities are permitted by an open general license. General licenses have been issued to permit petroleum companies to export without specific licenses. Export proceeds received in foreign currencies must be surrendered, but exporters of certain goods, notably petro- leum, may be authorized to retain abroad a portion of their proceeds. In practice, the petroleum companies operating in Trinidad and Tobago repatriate foreign exchange to the ex- tent of their local currency needs. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from current invisibles received in foreign curren- cies must be surrendered. Insurance, shipping, and similar companies operating in Trinidad and Tobago are usually authorized to maintain operating accounts for receipts and expenditures in foreign currency which are inherent parts of their businesses. These companies give periodic accounts of their exchange transactions to the authorities. Residents and nonresidents may bring in Trinidad and Tobago currency notes up to the equivalent of TT$50. For- eign currency notes may be imported freely by residents and nonresidents. Capital Capital transfers from Trinidad and Tobago require ap- proval and generally are restricted. However, repayment of commercial credits and transfers of legacies are permitted freely, and gifts to nonresidents and emigration allowances are approved up to specified limits. Furthermore, as a matter of policy, capital transfers to other CARIFTA countries are permitted liberally. For transactions in securities, 14 authorized depositories have been appointed in Trinidad and Tobago. Restrictions are placed on the import and export of all securities other than securities expressed in Trinidad and Tobago dollars. Contractual amortization on sterling securities is permit- ted, and also on mortgages and other loans if the original borrowing occurred prior to September 1939 or was subse- quently approved by the exchange control authorities. Proceeds from the sale of securities or other investments owned by nonresidents of Trinidad and Tobago may not ordinarily be transferred and are eligible for credit only to a Blocked Account (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above); however, approval is often given to residents to pur- chase such assets. Nonresident capital invested in Trinidad and Tobago after January 1950 may be repatriated together with capital gains, provided that the investment has been approved by the Government. TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO Residents may transfer prescribed securities to persons res- ident outside Trinidad and Tobago, with the prior approval of the exchange control authorities, provided that the full proceeds of sale are received in foreign currency or sterling from an External Account in any other part of the Sterling Area. Foreign exchange is not normally provided for portfo- lio investment by residents in foreign securities, but when securities are sold or redeemed in a market outside Trinidad and Tobago, the proceeds may either be brought in and sold to an authorized dealer at the official market rate of exchange, or, with the prior approval of the exchange control authori- ties, be invested outside Trinidad and Tobago in similar secu- rities. Nonresidents may sell local securities, provided that the proceeds are credited to a Blocked Account or are reinvested in other local securities which are either irredeemable or not redeemable within four years from the date of purchase. The laws of Trinidad and Tobago do not discriminate be- tween nationals and foreigners in the formation and operation of companies in that country. Foreigners are required, how- ever, to obtain a license under the Aliens (Landholding) Ordi- nance in order to hold interest in real estate or to hold shares in local companies. Prospective foreign investors must obtain approval for their project from the authorities in Trinidad and Tobago in order to be able to repatriate capital and capital gains. The proposed project must satisfy the authori- ties that it will be either a net earner or a net saver of any currency other than the Trinidad and Tobago dollar (not necessarily the original currency of investment) or, alterna- tively, that if any loss is involved it can be justified in terms of other benefits to the country. Since 1950, the Government has enacted basic incentive legislation designed to attract domestic and foreign invest- ment in manufacturing and in import-substitution industries. This provides for the granting of certain concessions to indus- tries declared to be pioneer industries, i.e., industries which have not previously existed in Trinidad and Tobago or which are not being conducted on a commercial scale, or any indus- try for which there are favorable prospects for fu ture develop- ment. Every pioneer manufacturer is entitled to temporary relief from import duties and taxes and to other privileges. The proceeds (including capital gains) realized from part or all of a direct capital investment made after January 1, 1950 by a nonresident of Trinidad and Tobago in an approved project may, if desired, be repatriated at any time. The invest- ment may have been, or may be, made in one or more of the following ways: in foreign currency (including sterling) ap- propriate to the investor's country of residence; in sterling eligible for remittance to the nonresident investor; or in goods and services supplied from the country of the investor. This right to repatriate funds is, however, subject to the following conditions: (1) The right will not normally apply to the purchase of shares on a stock exchange unless this purchase formed an integral part of an approved capital investment project. (2) When an investment did not require permission under the exchange control regulations, e.g., when it was made through a local branch, the right will be allowed only if the 429 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO investor obtained exchange control approval of his project at the time the investment was made. There are limitations on the extent to which banks may grant finance to nonresident individuals and firms (other than residents of other CARIFTA countries) and to nonresi- dent-controlled local companies. Such companies are nor- mally required to raise any local capital needed to supplement their assets by issuing either shares or bonds to residents of Trinidad and Tobago. Each commercial bank must ma in ta in the mon th ly average of its net foreign exchange position w i th in a specified quan t i ta t ive ceiling. Gold Gold is defined by the Exchange Control Act, 1970 as gold coin and bullion. The regulations provide tha t, except w i th specific exemptions and permissions granted by the Minister of Finance: (1) one party to every transaction in gold between residents must be an authorized bank; (2) gold held by resi- dents must be surrendered to an authorized bank; and (3) gold may not be taken or sent out of Trinidad and Tobago. Residents are permitted in appropriate cases, however, to purchase, hold, or sell gold coins in Trinidad and Tobago for numismatic purposes. Control on the import and export of gold is administered by the Ministry of Indus t ry and Commerce by regulations scheduled under the Trade Ordinance, 1958. Imports of gold jewelry are on open general license, but imports of gold other than jewelry are subject to specific import licenses issued by the Ministry of Indus t ry and Commerce; such licenses are not normally issued except to the monetary authorities and au- thorized industrial users. Exports of gold, whether jewelry or otherwise, are subject to specific export licenses issued by the Ministry of Indus t ry and Commerce; such licenses for gold other than jewelry are not normally granted except to the monetary authorities. Imports of unrefined gold are subject to import du ty at 5 per cent (preferential du ty) or 15 per cent (general du ty), and those of par t ly worked gold at 15 per cent (preferential du ty) or 25 per cent (general du ty). They are free of purchase tax. Changes during 1973 During the year several commodities were added to those requ ir ing a specific import license. January 16. Not for Redistribution TUNISIA Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.69271 grams of f ine gold per Tunisian Dinar, corresponding to D 0.525 = SDR 1 or D 0.435197 = US$1, and Tunisia avails itself of wider margins. Buy ing and selling rates for the French f ranc (the commercial f ranc and the financial franc) and certain other convertible curren- cies l are fixed daily by the Central Bank of Tunisia. The buying and selling rates of the authorized banks are identical with those of the Central Bank. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Central Bank, including the authorization of payments for imports and in- visibles; some authority is delegated to the authorized banks. Trade control is administered by the Directorate of Trade of the Ministry of National Economy which, in collaboration with the Central Bank, establishes import quotas and issues import and export licenses. Suppliers1 credits are screened by the Directorate-General of External Finance in the Ministry of Finance. Prescription of Currency For payment purposes, countries are classified as follows: (1) the French Franc Area; (2) the bilateral group, comprising countries with which Tunisia has concluded bilateral pay- ments agreements (Bulgaria, the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Egypt, Eastern Germany, Hungary, India, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R. 2) and (3) the area of convertibility, comprising all other countries. Settlements with the French Franc Area generally take place in French francs, although the Central Bank may authorize or prescribe the use of other currencies. Settlements with countries in the bilateral group are made in clearing dollars with Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Egypt, Eastern Germany, Hungary, Poland, and Romania, in rupees with India, in Tunisian dinars w i th the U.S.S.R. (for certain linked transactions), and in Swiss agreement francs with the People's Republic of China; settle- ments with countries in the area of convertibility are generally made in convertible currencies quoted by the Central Bank (see footnote 1) or in convertible Tunisian dinars through the Foreign Accounts of residents of those countries. Payments for imports must normally be made, in accordance w i th the foregoing, on the basis of the country of origin. Certain settle- ments between Tunisia and Morocco may be effected through accounts at the two central banks. Under a triangular com- pensation agreement with Bulgaria and India, settlements are made in Indian rupees through a Special Account at the Bank of Bulgaria. Payments to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Libyan dinars, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 With effect from January 1, 1974 settlements with Bulgaria, Czechoslova- kia, Hungary, Poland, and U.S.S.R. took place in convertible currencies. Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dinars may be held by residents of countries w i th which Tunisia does not maintain payments agreements. They may be credited freely with au- thorized payments by residents to the holders of the accounts and w i th dinar proceeds from sales to the Central Bank of convertible currencies (except banknotes); all other credits require prior authorization. They may be debited freely for payments of any k ind in Tunisia (irrespective of the country of residence of the nonresident payor), for transfers to other Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dinars or to Foreign Ac- counts in Bilateral Dinars, and for the purchase of any foreign currency from the Central Bank. Transfers between these accounts and from these accounts to Foreign Accounts in Bilateral Dinars may be made freely. Foreign Accounts in Bilateral Dinars may be held by resi- dents of countries of the bilateral group and are designated according to the holder's coun try of residence. They may be credited freely with dinar proceeds from sales to the Central Bank of convertible currencies, w i th transfers from other For- eign Accounts in Bilateral Dinars related to the same coun try, and w i th transfers from Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dinars; all other credits require prior authorization. They may be debited freely for the purchase from the Central Bank of the currency of the coun try to which the account relates, for all payments in Tunisia (subject to proper residential status of payor and beneficiary), and for local living expenses of persons resident in the coun try to which the account re- lates. Transfers between Foreign Accounts in Bilateral Dinars related to the same country may also be made freely. Foreign Accounts in Foreign Currencies may be established by nonresidents by transfers of convertible foreign currencies. They may also be credited with the proceeds of checks or travelers checks expressed in convertible currencies. Funds in these accounts may at any time be transferred abroad and they may also be sold to the Central Bank. Capital Accounts may be held by residents of any coun try. The opening of a Capital Account by a nonresident of Tuni- sian nationality or his spouse must be authorized by the Central Bank. Foreign banks may hold global Capital Ac- counts for their nonresident customers. Subject to certain conditions, Capital Accounts may be credited, w i thout prior approval of the Central Bank, w i th the proceeds of the sale on the stock exchange of Tunisian securities, amortization on Tunisian securities, the sales proceeds of real estate or rights to real estate situated in Tunisia, and with any bank balances that are not transferable under the rules of the Central Bank. Subject to certain conditions, these accounts may be debited for the purchase of Tunisian securities, participations in com- panies, and real estate. Irrespective of the holder's country of residence, Capital Accounts may freely be debited for living expenses in Tunisia of the holder and his family, up to D 50 a person a week, subject to a limit of D 1,000 for each family a year. Some of the above operations may be made freely through the intermediary of authorized banks, while certain others (e.g., debits resulting from the purchase of business concerns or securities not quoted on the Tunisian stock ex- 431 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TUNISIA change and all credits not relating to real estate transactions) require the authorization of the Central Bank. Internal Accounts of Nonresidents are intended ma in ly for foreigners staying temporarily in Tunisia and ga in fu l ly em- ployed there; the opening of these accounts requires the ap- proval of the Central Bank. Internal Nonresident Export Accounts (comptes INRE) are used for the salaries of foreign nationals employed in enter- prises covered by Law No. 72-38, which provides for certain export incentives. Suspense Accounts are used for the purpose of crediting all proceeds accruing in Tunisia to nonresidents which may not be credited to other nonresident accounts either in accor- dance w i th a general or an individual license of the Central Bank of Tunisia. These accounts may also be credited upon departure w i th bank balances and sales proceeds of real estate owned by foreign nationals leaving Tunisia permanently; the transfer abroad of such funds is normally permitted in accor- dance w i th rules applied by the Central Bank and the remain- der is directed to a Capital Account. Subject to certain conditions, Suspense Accounts may be debited w i thout the prior authorization of the Central Bank in respect of pur- chases of Tunisian securities, subscriptions to issues of short-term debentures or bonds, payments to the Tunisian Government or public ins t i tu t ions, and settlement of l iv ing expenses incurred in Tunisia by the account holder (irrespec- t ive of his coun t ry of residence) or his fam i ly up to D 50 a person a week and not exceeding D 1,000 a year for any one fam i ly. All other debits to these accounts require the ind iv id- ual authorization of the Central Bank of Tunisia. Savings Accounts in Foreign Currency may be maintained w i th the Postal Administration in the names of Tunisian nationals who are working abroad. These accounts may be credited w i th the countervalue of a portion of the holder's foreign currency earnings. They may be debited freely. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, and the fo l low ing does not apply to these countries. W i th the exception of imports originating in the French Franc Area, all impor ts require import licenses, importers' cards, import certificates, or annual import authorizations. All import applications must be submitted for the approval (avis technique) of the competent m in is t ry or government agency. The prior approval of the M in is t ry of Finance is required for all imports, irrespective of origin, that are fi- nanced w i th suppliers' credits. Import licenses must be ap- proved by the Directorate of Trade of the Ministry of National Economy and by the Central Bank, which au thor- izes the corresponding payment. Imports f rom the French Franc Area require a payments authorization from the Cen- tral Bank, an importers' card, an import certificate, or an annual import authorization. In practice, however, all appli- cations for payments authorizations are submitted by the Central Bank to the Directorate of Trade for prior endorse- ment. 432 Certain imports are regulated by arrangements which ap- ply to all countries: (1) "Prohibited" imports may be licensed in exceptional circumstances, at the discretion of the authori- ties. (2) Some commodities or groups of commodities are licensed against annual global quotas. (3) Certain spare parts and a few other commodities may be imported free of license against the presentation of an importer's card up to D 500 a year for each importer. (4) Some commodities or groups of commodities may be imported freely and without license by industrialists, craftsmen, and farmers for their own use, and by merchants w i th in their line of trade, against an "import certificate." (5) Imports required by manufacturers for their own use or by certain agencies are licensed under annual import authorizations. Bilateral quotas are fixed annually for certain imports from France not covered by any of the f ive arrangements outlined above. Imports under these quotas require licenses. The quo- tas cover such goods as perfumery and cosmetics, toilet soap, clothing, air conditioners, washing and drying machines, and automobiles. In addition, special procedures apply to certain other imports from France that are affected by Tunisia's Association Agreement with the EEC; such commodities also require a license when imported from France (see below). All imports not covered by one of the arrangements de- scribed above, when originating in countries outside the French Franc Area with which Tunisia does not maintain bilateral payments agreements, are regulated as follows (sub- ject to fu r ther special arrangements that apply to imports from EEC countries): import licenses for goods included in a liberalized list are in principle issued freely, while all other goods are licensed w i th in quotas under bilateral trade agree- ments, w i th in global quotas, or on a more discretionary basis when originating in countries w i th which no agreement is in force. 3 In addition to the above arrangements, there are certain special procedures for imports of specified goods originating in member countries of the EEC. Impor ts from countries w i th which Tunisia maintains bi- lateral payments agreements are licensed within bilaterally agreed quota limits unless the goods are among the few for which global quotas have been set. Imports of specified com- modities are licensed in such a manner as to ensure the utiliza- tion of tied foreign aid. Certain commodities are imported under state trading. These include goods subject to government monopolies, e.g., tobacco, matches, playing cards, and imports from the United States under U.S. P.L. 480. In addition, certain gov- ernment agencies, of which the main one is the Office du Commerce, have been granted a monopoly over the import of commodities fa l l ing within their sphere of activity (coffee, tea, sugar, specified fru i ts, etc.). Moreover, certain other com- modities, such as timber, paper, and certain metallurgical products, may be imported only by importers who are mem- bers of an importers' association. Imports by such associa- 3 Countries w i th which bilateral trade agreements are in force include most European OECD countries, in addition to the countries w i th which payments agreements have been concluded (see section on Prescription of Currency, above). ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution tions and by state agencies are subject to the same licensing arrangements as those applicable to private imports. To obtain an import license, importers must be listed in the commercial register and must have received a code number. All import documents invo lv ing payments must be domiciled (registered) w i th an authorized bank. In addition to customs duties, a number of import taxes are applied. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require the approval of the Central Bank; for some invisibles this au tho r i ty has been delegated to the authorized banks. Payments for a number of current invisibles are approved freely, provided that they are properly documented. These include various payments related to international trade (e.g., port services, warehousing, commissions, brokerage, and charges and prof i ts related to transit operations) and pay- ments for processing, repair, assembly, royalties, patents and trademarks, taxes, fines, and court expenses, as well as pay- ments of interest and amortization arising from contractual obligations to nonresidents. Approval is also given for remit- tances of profits and dividends due to nonresidents. In addition, exporters holding balances on EFAC accounts (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below) may use these freely for expenditures abroad in connection w i th par- ticipation in international trade fairs, and for customs duties and other expenses related to shipment of exports to France. Exporters as well as hotel owners may use EFAC balances freely for pub l ic i ty expenses abroad, and up to fixed limits (see below) for certain other expenses. Enterprises producing for export and covered by Law No. 72-38 may freely make certain payments for invisibles; amoun ts credited to the Busi- ness Travel Accounts of resident firms covered by Law No. 72-38 in convertible dinars may be used for business travel up to D 4,000 a year for each enterprise. Payments for certain other current invisibles are approved up to fixed limits. Residents traveling abroad as tourists are entitled once a year to an exchange allocation equivalent to D 50 a person (D 25 for children under ten). The allocation for s tudy abroad is D 70 a mon th. Exporters holding EFAC accounts may use such balances up to the equivalent of D 2,000 a year for business travel abroad, and hotel owners may use balances in EFAC accounts w i thout l im i t; the use of excess amounts by exporters may be approved by the Central Bank in certain circumstances, depending on the magn i tude of their exports. Foreign nationals employed under contract may transfer up to 50 per cent of their net basic wages or salaries, subject to a maximum of D 150 a mon th if their fam i ly lives in Tunisia. Foreign experts employed by the public sector may transfer abroad their mon th ly salaries up to the limits laid down in their contracts. Foreign salaried workers born in Tunisia may transfer 30 per cent of their net basic salaries, up to D 80 a mon th. The export of Tunisian banknotes is prohibited. Unless Central Bank permission is obtained, the reconversion of do- mestic banknotes by nonresident travelers is restricted to 30 per cent of the amount of foreign currency previously sold, subject to a maximum of D 100. TUNISIA Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Certain exports are liberalized. Nonliberalized exports require an export authorization when sold to the French Franc Area and an export license when sold outside that Area. The export of wine is the monopoly of the Office du Vin and the export of cereals is the monopoly of the Office des Cereales. The export of olive oil is the monopoly of the Office National de 1'Huile. With the exception noted below, all export proceeds must be repatriated, normally within 15 days from the date payment is due if no credit is extended. Exporters and hotel owners may have credited to special EFAC (Exportations-Frais Accessoires) accounts denomi- nated either in convertible dinars or in bilateral dinars the equivalent in dinars of a part of their export proceeds. For exporters the limits are 4 per cent if export proceeds are repatriated more than 30 days af ter shipment of the merchan- dise, and 6 per cent if repatriation occurs within 30 days following shipment. For hotel owners, credits are limited to 4 per cent of their foreign exchange proceeds. Under the provisions of Law No. 72-38 of April 27, 1972, nonresident manufac tur ing enterprises (i.e., enterprises whose capital is held by nonresidents and has been consti- tuted to the extent of at least 66 per cent through the import of convertible currencies) producing exclusively for export are exempt from the requirement of repatriation and surrender of export proceeds; this requirement is not applicable to exports to payments agreement countries. Proceeds from Invisibles Residents must repatriate and surrender all amounts de- rived from services rendered to persons resident abroad, in- cluding residents of the French Franc Area, and also all other income or proceeds from invisibles received from countries outside the French Franc Area. However, Tunisian nationals who are work ing abroad may retain the countervalue of their foreign currency earnings in convertible d inar accounts. For- eign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) may be brought in freely; nonresident travelers wishing to re-export the equiv- alent of over D 500 must make a currency declaration upon en try. The import of Tunisian banknotes is prohibited. Capital All nonresidents, including residents of other countries of the French Franc Area, who wish to invest in Tunisia are required to obtain the prior approval of the Tunisian authori- ties in order to secure the guarantee for the transfer of princi- pal of, and current earnings from, such investments. Foreign investment in Tunisia may obtain certain benefits provided for by the Investment Code (Law No. 69-35) of June 26, 1969. These include a number of tax facilities as well as a guarantee of the right to repatriate capital and to transfer profits. Furthermore, Law No. 72-38 of April 27, 1972 pro- vides for various special benefits for nonresident manufactur- ing enterprises, including an exemption from the repatriation requirement in respect of export proceeds. 433 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TUNISIA All foreign nationals who have been residents of Tunisia may upon leaving Tunisia permanently have their domestic bank balances credited to Suspense Accounts; the same ap- plies to all proceeds from the liquidation of foreign invest- ments not covered by a transfer guarantee (e.g., personal real estate). The conversion into foreign exchange of the amounts deposited is normally permitted in accordance w i th rules ap- plied by the Central Bank. All capital transfers by residents require the approval of the Central Bank. The purchase by Tunisian residents of foreign securities on foreign stock exchanges is, in principle, forbidden; in some instances, authorization is granted for a resident to subscribe abroad to a share issue by an enterprise in which he is already a shareholder. Gold Five gold coins issued for commemorative purposes are legal tender. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Tunisia for num isma t ic purposes. W i th this exception, resi- dents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. By v ir tue of Law No. 63-46 of December 19, 1963, the Central Bank has a monopoly over the import of gold in the form of coins, ingots, or bars. Only dentists and specified cooperatives of industrial users are eligible to purchase gold from the Central Bank. The export of gold is prohibited. Changes during 1973 January 16. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited; imports of old, used and reconditioned, defective, substandard, soiled, or poor-quality goods are forb idden, except w i th the authoriza- tion of the M in is t ry of Commerce. All commercial imports require import licenses, which are valid for f ive mon ths, and, generally, goods must be cleared th rough the customs w i th in f ive mon ths. Import licenses are issued to registered import- ers (import merchants), industrialists (manufac turers import- ing for their own needs), state economic enterprises, and government departments. Private individuals and corporate bodies are required to secure an "importer's certificate" issued by the M in i s t ry of Commerce before subm i t t ing applications th rough the authorized banks for licenses to import goods for commercial purposes. The importer's tax status is taken in to consideration when gran t ing such certificates. However, ex- porters, m ine operators, shipowners, bu i ld ing contractors who have under taken the construction of state establish- ments, tourist establishments, and registered manufac turers are not required to secure an "importer's certificate" for im- ports to be used exclusively for their own needs; a certificate establishing their qualification is issued by the respective pub- lic au tho r i ty, i.e., the Chambers of Commerce and Indu s t ry, the Exporters Un ion, or the M in i s t ry of Tourism and In fo r- mation. Most goods are imported in accordance w i th the provisions of import programs, which are planned for one year. The import programs, wh ich inc lude commodities financed w i th funds from the U.S. Agency for In te rna t ional Development (AID), classify impor ts in two categories: (1) an annual list of liberalized goods, consisting of two parts (lists I and II), for which import licenses are issued freely; and (2) a list of goods subject to global quotas published annua l ly. Imports of goods that do not appear on any of these lists are prohib- ited; certain of these commodities, however, may be imported when specifically authorized by the M in is try of Commerce. The list of liberalized goods and the list of global quotas app ly, in principle, only to imports f rom countries other than those w i th which Turkey has bilateral payments agree- ments; 5 goods not included in either of these two import lists may not be imported under the bilateral quotas. For some goods on the liberalized and global quota lists, importers 5 When permitting imports of goods on the liberalized or quota lists f rom nonpaymen ts agreement, non-OECD countries, the M in i s t ry of Commerce takes the balance of trade and paymen ts w i th these countries i n to account. 435 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY have the option of applying for exchange allocations from U.S. AID funds for orders exceeding US$10,000 in value; there are no goods on these lists, however, that may be im- ported only w i th U.S. AID funds and only from the United States. Certain imports from member countries of the EEC are included in a list of liberalized items consolidated to the EEC and are free of quan t i ta t ive restriction; most of the items on this list are included in liberalized lists I and II, while the remainder is included in the quota list. Applications for import licenses for goods on the liberal- ized lists may be submitted at any time to authorized banks, which transfer them to the M in is try of Commerce (or other public au tho r i ty indicated) for examination and prepare the import licenses and forward these to the Central Bank for approval on the M in is try's instructions. For certain liberal- ized goods, the prior approval of the m in is t ry concerned is also required. There are special arrangements administered by the Minis- try of Commerce to facilitate priority allocation of foreign exchange for imports of raw materials and supplementary materials required for export production. The list of import quotas contains quotas for registered importers and for industrialists. Quotas for industrialists are allocated annua l ly and for importers semiannually. Imports on the quota list can be subdivided in to two broad categories — impor ts which do not, and imports which do, require a permit from a specified public body. Foreign exchange alloca- tions for quota imports w i th in the quan t i ta t ive l im it estab- lished for each quo ta item are made by the Central Bank for impor ts not requiring a permit, and by the M in is try of Com- merce (on the advice of the responsible au tho r i ty) for those requiring a permit. Some of the quota imports also require a certificate conf irm ing that the articles are not manufac tured by local indu s t ry and do not exist in the local market in su f f ic ient qu an t i ty and qua l i ty; the required certificate is the responsibility of the M in is try of Indu s t ry and Technology, which may delegate au tho r i ty to the Chambers of Commerce and Indu s t ry. Registered importers have to submit their applications for goods not requiring a permit th rough an authorized bank and the Central Bank to the M in is t ry of Commerce du r ing the f irst mon th of each semester. No single importer may apply for more than 50 per cent of half of the quota set for any particular commodity; exceptions are possible when this amount does not cover the price of one un i t. Upon examina- tion of applications, the Ministry of Commerce instructs the Central Bank to issue a foreign exchange allocation letter valid for four months, and an import license must be secured f rom the Central Bank w i th in the period of validity of the foreign exchange allocation letter. Applications for imports against industrialists' quotas where no permit is required have to be submitted through the Chambers of Commerce and Indu s t ry to the M in is try of Commerce in April of each year. Applications for quota imports requiring a permit from a specified public au thor i ty must be submitted to the responsi- ble body each semester by importers and each year by indus- trialists. Upon examination of the application, the M in is try 436 of Commerce instructs the responsible body to issue a foreign exchange allocation valid for four mon ths but not longer than one mon th beyond the period of effectiveness of the quota list. An import license must then be secured from the Central Bank dur ing the period of validity of the exchange allocation. Under a system of pre-import price control, which has been suspended but not abolished, imports are to be made at the best ru l ing world market prices. For this purpose, whenever the system is reinstated, a certificate must be obtained from the Office of Price Registration and Control after issuance of the import license or the certificate of foreign exchange alloca- tion. However, public sector imports of goods on liberaliza- tion list I may be authorized by the Central Bank without a price conformity certificate. The import license permits the necessary foreign exchange payment to be made. Payments for imports may be made against letters of credit, documents, or goods (i.e., upon cus- toms clearance). However, for imports financed from U.S. AID funds, 6 payments may be made only against a letter of credit. When the payment is to be made against a letter of credit, registered importers and industrialists are required to prepay in local currency, at the time of application for an import license, the equivalent of the foreign exchange for which they have applied. For payments against documents or against goods (for goods on liberalized list II, the global quota list, and on bilateral quota lists), importers and indus- trialists are required to prepay half of the value of the imports w i th the application for an import license; this requirement has been suspended but not abolished. Importers are required to make the foreign exchange trans- fer w i th in four mon ths from the date of the import license for payments against documents and w i th in two mon ths from the date of customs clearance for payments against goods. Imports from bilateral agreement countries are subject to separate quotas. These are established only for commodities that appear on the liberalization or global quota lists. The import licensing procedure for goods from these countries is the same as for imports under global quotas, except that applications under the bilateral quotas specified in each agreement are submitted by the Central Bank or the responsi- ble public au tho r i ty to the Ministry of Commerce on a mon th ly basis. Guarantee deposits for imports, whether financed from U.S. AID funds or not, are payable in advance, generally as follows: for goods on liberalized list I, 25 per cent of the value of the merchandise is payab le ,7 and for items on list II, 10 per cent; for imports under global quotas, 10 per cent of the value of the import application is payable for goods on im- porters' quotas, and 2.5 per cent for industrialists' quotas and export manufacturers. 8 For imports under bilateral quotas the rate of guarantee deposit depends on the list on which the goods are included if imported from a nonagreement country, but a rate of 10 per cent is applied to quotas which are not 8 The special regime app ly ing to imports financed by the AID was terminated w i th effect from Janua ry 3, 1974. 7 For fertilizers, ammonia, and breeding animals, the rate is 1 per cent. 8 A deposit of 50 per cent applies to items on list I and to items not on any list and not requ ir ing a permit of the M in i s t ry of Commerce, when imported under the Transitional Agreement w i th the EEC; items included in list II and those requiring permission from the M in i s t ry of Commerce when imported under that Agreement require a deposit of 20 per cent. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution included in industrialists' quotas to be fixed by the M in i s t ry of Commerce for agreement countries and all of the quotas indicated in the listed import quo tas for which there exists no control au tho r i ty. Guarantee deposits are payable irrespective of the method of paymen t. The public sector (except for AID imports of some enterprises and ins t i tu t ions in that sector) is exempt, however, and in many cases industrialists make a symbolic deposit of 1 per cent (on imports under investment quotas set aside for their use and applicable to convertible currency countries only), or 10 per cent (on imports under investment quotas in bilateral agreements). An "additional deposit" of 100 per cent is payable for imports on a letter of credit basis, but no "additional deposit" is required for imports on a col- lection basis. For imports to be financed from U.S. AID funds (see foot- note 6), a guarantee payment of 10 per cent, but not to exceed LT 100,000, is payable for imports of the public sector other than central government agencies, irrespective of whether the goods are included in the liberalization list or the quota list. The deposit remains blocked un t il the goods have been cleared through customs and the foreign supplier paid; it is then refunded to the importer. The guarantee deposits col- lected are transferred weekly to an account held by the Cen- tral Bank in the name of the authorized bank. Should imports not be made in conformity with the regulations, a part of the guarantee deposit corresponding to up to 10 per cent of the value of such imports is forfeited to the Treasury. 9 Private compensation transactions are not permitted in any form, except that the M in is try of Commerce is authorized to conclude agreements to dispose of goods acquired th rough suppor t ing purchases made by the State. Impor ts w i thout an allocation of foreign exchange may be permitted by the customs authorities, the Central Bank, or the M in i s t ry of Finance, under certain conditions. Travelers domiciled in Turkey may bring in for personal or professional (but noncommercial) use goods and machinery w i th a l im it of LT 3,000, in addition to personal effects. Separate l im i ts and conditions apply to imports of goods for personal use, and of professional instruments and machines, by persons hav ing resided abroad for employment or study; these limits and conditions vary w i th the stay abroad and with the trans- fer to Turkey of foreign exchange. Companies or cooperatives formed in Turkey by residents temporarily wo rk ing abroad may import inves tment goods to the extent of the foreign exchange invested. TURKEY tourists may import goods and machinery for their personal or fam i ly use. Foreign contractors may temporarily import machinery, vehicles, and scientific ins t rumen ts w i thout requesting an al- location of foreign exchange, provided that the goods are proved to be necessary for their operations in Turkey and may not be imported on a temporary basis under the relevant customs regulations. Foreign companies established in Tur- key may import spare parts not intended for new investments without requesting an allocation of foreign exchange, pro- vided that the goods are necessary for their operations. All such imports require the permission of the exchange control authorities. Goods imported on these terms must not be sold to th ird parties in Turkey. Import of an automobile 10 without payment of foreign exchange may be permitted by the Central Bank or the Minis- try of Finance, provided that certain conditions are met relat- ing to residence abroad and to remittance and sale to authorized banks in Turkey of foreign exchange. Automobiles imported w i thout a foreign exchange alloca- tion may be sold to residents by the Turkish nationals who have imported them. Foreign diplomats in Turkey may sell their automobiles to Turkish residents provided that the nec- essary import duties are paid at the time of the sale, that Turkish diplomats in the seller's coun try are granted recipro- cal privileges, and that proceeds from such sales are not transferred abroad. Foreign officials, other than diplomats, may not sell to Turkish nationals any automobiles imported d u ty free under special agreements. Other foreign nationals resident in Turkey may import automobiles under certain conditions, but they must be exported af ter three years; how- ever, this three-year period may be extended, and the Minis- try of Finance may also permit the sale of such cars to the State Supply Office or to nonp ro f it organizations. With these exceptions, automobiles and any other commodities that have been imported du ty free may not be sold to residents. In addition to customs du ty, imported goods are subject to the following charges: (1) a customs surcharge of 15 per cent of the applicable customs du ty; (2) a stamp du ty of 9.0 per cent or 9.5 per cent of the declared value, depending on the type of commodity; ll (3) a quay du ty of 5 per cent on the sum of c.i.f. value, customs du ty, customs surcharge, stamp du ty, and customs clearance expenses; and (4) a production tax ranging generally from 10 per cent to 75 per cent on the sum of c.i.f. value, customs du ty, customs surcharge, stamp du ty, customs clearing expenses, and quay du ty. The quay d u ty is not payable on goods imported by air. Payments for Invisibles Paymen ts for invisibles require exchange licenses which usua l ly are issued by the Central Bank. These are granted liberally for the following purposes, provided that applica- tions are accompanied by specified documents: payments re- lated to trade (including shipping costs and expenditures 10 Automobiles are not inc luded in the import program. 11 The s tamp d u ty is 10 per cent for impor ts f rom countries th at are not members of the GATT, and 100 per cent for imports made by special permission but not con fo rm ing to the provisions of the Customs Law, the Foreign Trade Regime, and s im i lar legislation and regulations. 437 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY connected w i th other freight charges), subscriptions to news- papers and periodicals, purchases of books, payments for registration fees, advertising expenses, consulate income, pay- ments by the Government, payments by the Post Office Ad- ministration and similar state ins t i tu t ions, banks' commissions and expenses, a proportion of insurance compa- nies' payments, specified technical assistance, repair and as- sembly expenses, and legal fees for commercial transactions. The transfer of income related to foreign investments ap- proved under the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Inves tment is permitted freely. Interest on long-term loans and credits extended by nonresidents to enterprises in Turkey ( inc lud ing those of an agricultural na ture) may be granted transferab i l i ty between foreign nationals both in Turkey and abroad. Turkish citizens are not allowed to leave the coun t ry w i th- out hav ing obtained an allocation of exchange for travel, but this does not app ly to foreign nationals residing in Turkey. Tourist travel is restricted, in effect, to four trips a person a year, except for travel to Cyprus. The allowance of exchange for tourist travel is up to the equivalent of US$800 a calendar year; travelers are not allowed to leave the coun t ry unless they are carrying at least the equivalent of US$200 in foreign exchange (US$110 for persons under 18 years of age, the purchase of this amount not being manda tory). Turkish citi- zens traveling to Cyprus may obtain an exchange allocation equivalent to up to US$400 on request; this does not affect their right to claim the tourist travel allowance. Exchange for business travel is granted w i th in the limits of annual quotas, which vary according to the taxable income of the applicant f irm. For exporting companies, the l im it is related to their export proceeds. Exchange for travel abroad for other pur- poses (e.g., education, participation in international meetings, fairs, athletic meets, and so fo r th, and personal business) is sold up to specified limits. In addition, persons who can certify that it is necessary for them to travel abroad for medi- cal trea tment may purchase the necessary foreign exchange. A tax of 50 per cent (minimum of LT 500) is payable on the purchase against payment in Turkish liras of tickets for foreign travel, and on baggage charges. The LT 500 m in imum is not applicable to Turkish citizens leaving to work abroad. Travelers are permitted to take out LT 100 in Turk ish banknotes and coins. Nonresidents may take out w i thout any restriction the unspent portion of the foreign exchange which they brought in. Nonresident travelers who wish to reconvert Turkish liras in to foreign currency when leaving the coun t ry are required to present a document showing that foreign exchange had previously been sold to an authorized dealer in Turkey. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. All exports destined to bilateral countries, 12 exports of a few commodities to any destination, 13 re-exports irrespective of destination, and tem- 12 Expor ts of specified perishables to these countries are authorized by the customs offices; export licenses must be delivered to customs w i t h in f ive days of expor t. 13 Cereals, certain minerals such as mo lybdenum, wo l f ram, and iron ore, articles made of precious metals or stones, vegetable oils, oilseeds, skins, fertilizers, cattle, meat, and t imbe r. 438 porary exports require an export license in order to prevent re-exports and to assure adequate supplies for the domestic market. Commercial export prices must conform to the checklist of prices fixed at intervals by the M in is try of Com- merce on the basis of prices obtaining in domestic and foreign markets. For this purpose, exporters must apply for price registration to a professional organization designated by the M in is t ry of Commerce w i th in f ive working days (three work- ing days in the case of hazelnuts) of a sale, 14 together w i th a statement of income earned and income and corporation taxes paid during the last three years. The professional orga- nization will not accept for registration applications not con- fo rm ing to the checklist of prices. When registering sales, due consideration is given to delivery time, quan t i ty, sales condi- tions, the income earned by the exporter on his commercial activities in the course of the last three years, and income and corporation taxes assessed dur ing the same period. For exports requiring a license, the price registration appli- cation is submitted by the responsible au thor i ty to the Minis- try of Commerce; approved price registration bills constitute export licenses. Exporters in the public sector may apply direct to the M in is t ry of Commerce for price registration and export licenses. In issuing licenses for exports to bilateral agreement countries, export quotas are fixed by the Ministry. Exports must be started w i th in 30 to 180 days of registration, depending on the type of goods, sales contracts, and country of designation. Circulation certificates for exports to member countries of the EEC benefiting from preferential customs and tax trea tment are issued by the Customs Au tho r i ty. Exporters are required to sell to a bank in Turkey the foreign exchange proceeds of goods exported w i th in three mon ths from the date of export or w i th in ten days f rom the date on which the foreign exchange is placed at their disposal. They are permitted to export a specified list of commodities on nine-month credit terms, however, against payment in convertible currency and subject to a bank guarantee. For- ward sales may be made on ly when payment is to be received in convertible currencies; price con fo rm i ty for forward sales is required at the time the export contract is concluded. Under an export tax rebate scheme, direct and indirect taxes paid are refunded when manufactures or products are exported. There are basically four rates of refund: 5, 10, 20, and 25 per cent of specified direct and indirect taxes. How- ever, 10 percentage points more in tax refunds is granted to exporters who sell more than US$1.2 million of goods benefit- ing from a re fund. Reduced rates of refund apply for certain goods when exported to bilateral payments agreement countries, and other goods exported to these countries do not qu a l i fy for a tax re fund. In addition, vary ing provisional rates of re fund exist. The tax refund must not exceed the amount of indirect taxes and charges actually paid. Other tax incen- tives include the exemption of export earnings from income and corporation taxes and the exemption of export goods f rom the production tax. Proceeds from Invisibles Firms or individuals not in the category of authorized insti- tu t ions cannot accept more than the equivalent of US$100 from foreign tourists and are required to surrender any ex- change earnings in the form of foreign banknotes and travel- ers checks to an authorized bank within ten days. Otherwise, foreign exchange accruing to residents for services rendered by them to nonresidents must be surrendered to an autho- rized exchange dealer within three months from the date on which the service was rendered or w i th in ten days from the date of acquisition of the exchange. Remittances from Turk- ish workers abroad are sold to the Central Bank at LT 10.50 per U.S. dollar (but see footnote 2); when the Turkish lira equivalent is credited to a bank account in Turkey, an addi- tional amount of 33 V3 per cent is immediately credited to the account representing three years' interest at 11.11 per cent per annum resulting in an effective exchange rate of LT 14.00 per U.S. dollar. 1S The amounts deposited plus the interest can be w i thdrawn at any time. Foreign travelers wishing to take out articles with a value exceeding LT 2,000 must show proof that they have converted foreign exchange to cover the portion of the cost exceeding this limit. The import of Turkish banknotes and coins by travelers (whether of Turkish or foreign nationality) is limited to LT 100. The import of foreign currency by travelers is unre- stricted. Capital Foreign investments in Turkey require approval. Capital transfers abroad by residents and capital transactions be- tween residents and nonresidents are subject to the approval of the exchange control authorities. Residents are not nor- mally permitted to acquire foreign securities or real estate. With the exception of certain investments made in accor- dance with the provisions of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Investments (No. 6224) or the Petroleum Law (No. 6326, as amended), foreign companies and contractors who wish to do business in Turkey must import the required capital and operating funds in the form of foreign exchange, although under certain conditions blocked funds may be used for investment in the tourist industry as well as certain other industries. Borrowing in Turkish liras by such foreign compa- nies and contractors is subject to quotas set by the Ministry of Finance in accordance with their equity capital in Turkey, but special facilities exist for borrowing from the "Blocked Currencies Fund" at the Central Bank. Blocked funds are those accrued or accruing to nonresi- dents but not transferable under the existing exchange con- trol regulations. These include the sales proceeds of real estate situated in Turkey and owned by nonresident physical or juridical persons, insofar as the property is not covered by Law No. 6224 or Law No. 6326. Except for approved invest- ments, nonresidents may not convert into foreign currency 15 Changed on May 14, 1974 to LT 13.50 per US$1. TURKEY any assets or balances owned by them, or earnings accruing to them; all earnings are blocked but if, at the end of the calendar year, such earnings are less than LT 10,000, the amount involved is deblocked. Subject to individual permis- sion, blocked assets and balances may be utilized w i th in Tur- key, e.g., for the payment of taxes, insurance, and maintenance and repair of property; and for l iv ing expenses of up to LT 9,000 a mon th for each beneficiary for owners of such funds or their authorized representatives, and up to LT 5,000 for certain relatives. Normally, such blocked funds may not be transferred to others except by legal succession. The investment of blocked funds in the tourist indus t ry is subject to the following conditions: (1) there must be a contri- bution in new foreign exchange or imported equipment equal to at least 50 per cent of the blocked funds to be used and (2) the investor must undertake not to request transfer for at least f ive years of that part of the capital financed by means of the blocked funds. Blocked funds used in this manner are consid- ered as foreign capital imported under the Law for the En- couragement of Foreign Investments. A portion of 75 per cent of any holder's blocked funds can be transferred to the Blocked Currencies Fund at the Central Bank, from which nonresidents may receive credits for their partner companies' investment requirements in Turkey, pro- vided the permission of the Ministry of Finance is obtained. Dividends and profits derived from these credits have to be blocked again and are nontransferrable. Balances on nonresident accounts established at the Cen- tral Bank in accordance w i th the Paris Agreement on Com- mercial Debts Owed by Residents of Turkey (1959) may be used either partially or who l ly by the creditors for investment or to pay expenses in Turkey at any time prior to the date, established under the Agreement, when the balances may be transferred. The use of these balances for investment purposes is subject to the provisions of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Investments. However, invested funds and income related thereto may not be transferred abroad before the transfer date established under the Agreement, except for investment in the export industries or in other industries earning foreign exchange; in such instances the equivalent of up to 25 per cent of the investment may be transferred annu- ally. Foreign capital invested in Turkey under the terms of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Investments is ac- corded preferential treatment, provided that the enterprise in which the investment is to be made is deemed to contribute to the economic development of the country, or will operate in a field of activity open to Turkish private enterprise and will not entail monopoly or special privilege. Under this law, all or part of the invested capital or foreign loans may be remitted abroad in the original currency of the capital. Upon application, the M in is try of Finance guarantees the transfer of dividends and of the proceeds from the sale or liquidation of shares or stock certificates registered on the books of com- panies established under the law. Such registered shares or stock certificates are freely transferable between foreign na- tionals, both in Turkey and abroad, and between foreign nationals and residents. The transfer guarantees pass on to 439 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY the new owner, provided that his name is notified to the M in is try of Finance; if the shares or stock certificates are sold to a resident, however, they must be presented to the M in i s t ry of Finance for cancellation of the guarantees. The capital and interest on long-term loans and credits extended by nonresi- dents to enterprises in Turkey (including those of an agricul- tural character) may be accorded the same transfer benefits. Foreign capital imported under the Petroleum Law is ac- corded additional preferential treatment. By v i r tue of a policy statement of December 1971, Turkish participation in new foreign investments no longer is subject to a m in imum of 51 per cent. In addition to investments under Law No. 6224, foreign investments outside the petroleum sector may be made "under the mone tary regulations," in which case the investor does not enjoy any t rans fer facilities for earnings or l iqu ida t ion proceeds. Transactions in securities, inc lud ing their export and im- port, require approval when nonresident interests are in- volved. Nonresidents are permitted to open noninterest-bearing foreign exchange deposit accounts w i th Turkish banks. Non- residents can no longer open or credit demand accounts in convertible Turkish liras, a l though existing balances can be maintained. The deadlines for the termination of time depos- its in convertible Turkish liras varies between Ju ly 2, 1973 and April 3, 1976, depending on the end-use of the counter- part domestic bank credit. However, time deposits w i th ma- tu r i ty dates going beyond the deadlines specified for the d ifferent end-uses of the counterpart domestic bank credit are permitted to run their fu ll term. No exchange guarantee exists for demand deposits af ter April 3, 1973 and for time deposits af ter the original ma tu r i ty date. Banks have been granted certain general permissions al- lowing them to borrow convertible currencies from nonresi- dents for relending to nonresidents. The total amount of private and public sector borrowing abroad from private sources, inc lud ing supplier credits, is determined in an annual program by the M in is t ry of Finance, which also specifies the eligible sectors and projects. The M in is t ry of Finance, af ter consultation w i th other ministries if appropriate, is authorized to approve such credits and to issue a guarantee of the transferab i l i ty of the foreign ex- change. It is up to the intermediating bank to guarantee the repayment in lira. Turkish borrowers pay that bank the pre- vailing domestic interest rate; the excess over the interest rate payable to the foreign lender, net of a bank ing commission, is credited to an "Interest Equalization Fund'* established in the Central Bank. Regulations issued by the M in is try of Fi- nance specify tha t, w i th certain exceptions, such credits must not amount to more than 60 per cent of the total cost of a project, their ma tu r i ty must not be less than two years, and the rate of interest must not exceed the Euro-dollar rate (LIBOR rate) by more than 1 per cent. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Turkey for num isma t ic purposes. W i th this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized indus tr ial users 440 are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad; any unworked gold held in Tur- key, however, may be presented for m in t ing by the State M in t. Impor ts and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the M in is try of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and in- dustrial users. Changes during 1973 January 1. The additional protocol signed between Turkey and the EEC on November 23, 1970 came into force. Some of its provisions had already been put in to effect by virtue of a provisional agreement on September 1, 1971. The financial protocol under which the EEC would contribute to the devel- opment of the Turkish economy through the European In- vestment Bank also came in to force. January 1. The reduced rates of stamp du ty of 9 per cent and 9.5 per cent, depending on the type of commodity, were made applicable to imports from all contracting parties to the GATT. Previously, they were applied only to goods imported under the Provisional Agreement w i th the EEC, while the rate was 10 per cent for imports from other sources. January 3. More restrictive directives for the approval of new inward direct investment came into force. Subsequently, domestic bank credit (against convertible currency deposits held in Turkey) to firms whose head offices are located abroad was suspended. January 3. Foreign physical and juridical persons not resi- dent or established in Turkey could no longer open or credit demand accounts in convertible Turkish liras, although exist- ing balances could be maintained; with effect from April 3, 1973 such foreign persons would have to liquidate their time deposits maintained in convertible Turkish liras. However, nonresidents now were permitted to open noninterest-bearing foreign exchange deposit accounts with Turkish banks. January 3. Regulations were issued governing private and public sector borrowing abroad from private sources, for spe- cific investment projects and through the intermediary of banks in Turkey (Decree No. 7/5399). (Excluded were credits to the Republic of Turkey from foreign governments and government agencies and from international agencies.) The max imum total amount of such borrowing in any calendar year, as well as the sectors and projects eligible for it, would be specified in an Annual Program. The Ministry of Finance, af ter consultation w i th other ministries if appropriate, was authorized to approve such credits and to issue a guarantee of the transferab i l i ty of the foreign exchange. It would be the responsibility of the intermediating bank to guarantee the repayment in lira. Turkish borrowers would pay the bank prevailing domestic interest rates; the excess over the interest rate payable to the foreign lender would be credited (after deduction of the banking commission, which could not ex- ceed 1 percentage point) to an "Interest Equalization Fund" to be established in the Central Bank and to be used to provide low interest credit to priority projects. In a com- mun ique, the Ministry of Finance specified tha t, with certain exceptions, such credits could not exceed 60 per cent of the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution amount of any project, the ma tur i ty could not be less than two years, and the rate of interest could not exceed the Euro-dollar rate by more than 1 per cent. January 4. The 1973 import program was published, repre- senting some fu r th er liberalization of the import system. To- tal imports in 1973 were programmed to be US$1,600 million, wh ich included US$720 million for liberalized goods, US$450 million for quota goods, and US$115 million for imports from bilateral agreement countries. The three main import lists were considerably revised, particularly by the transfer of inves tment goods from the quota list to liberaliza- tion list II. Some of the revisions were designed to make the import regime conform to the liberalization list consolidated to the EEC. Import guarantee deposit rates were reduced f rom 40 per cent to 20 per cent for liberalization list II, f rom 25 per cent to 20 per cent for importers' quotas under the quota list, and from 10 per cent to 5 per cent for industrial- ists' quotas under the quota list. Commodities on liberaliza- t ion list II and on all import quo ta lists were permitted, subject to an additional deposit of 50 per cent, to be imported on payment against goods or payment against documents terms; formerly they could only be imported under letters of credit. The ratio of import quotas exempt from processing of applications by an official body was increased from 20 per cent to 50 per cent of total quota allocations. January 24. The exchange rate applied to proceeds from tobacco exports was changed from LT 13 to LT 14 per US$1. February 1. The l im it applying to the free importation by travelers domiciled in Turkey of goods and machinery (in addition to personal effects) for personal or professional (but noncommercial) use was raised from LT 2,500 to LT 3,000. February 16. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, Turkey maintained its central rate unchanged at LT 14 = US$1 and continued to avail itself of wider margins. The special exchange rate of LT 13 = US$1 applying to seven traditional export products was continued, but the Government announced its decision to abolish it effec t ive August 1, 1973 and instead to apply un i fo rm ly the central rate of LT 14 = US$1. February 16. The rates of rebate under the export tax rebate scheme were changed from 10, 15, 25, 30, 35, and 40 per cent of specified direct and indirect taxes to 5, 10, 20, 25, 30, and 35 per cent. March 5. The Central Bank suspended transactions in the fo l low ing currencies: Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, deutsche mark, French francs, Netherlands guilders, and Swiss francs. Transactions were resumed on March 21. March 5. Turkey imposed a temporary ban on imports of commodities for which payment was stipulated in Austrian schillings, deutsche mark, French francs, Netherlands guil- ders, or Swiss francs. This ban was l if ted on March 21. March 23. The deadline for the termination of convertible lira time deposit accounts (previously set at April 3, 1973) was extended to different dates depending on the end-use of the counterpart domestic bank credit, as follows: credits to finance fixed investments for sectors included in the General Encouragement Table in the 1973 Annual Program —April 3, 1976; operational credits for sectors included in the General Encouragement Table in the 1973 Annual Program —April 3, TURKEY 1975; credits for investments in sectors not included in the General Encouragement Table —April 3, 1974; all other cred- its —July 2, 1973. Credits so extended would not be permitted to be changed in to another type of credit un t il the expiry of the extended term. However, time deposits with maturity dates going beyond the dates specified above in relation to d ifferent types of domestic end-use, were permitted to run their fu ll term. The exchange guarantee that had previously been in effect was w i thdrawn from demand deposits effective April 3, 1973 and from time deposits after the expiry of their existing term, i.e., time deposits extended in accordance with regulations issued on March 23, 1973 would cease to have an exchange guarantee for the extended part of the term. The net effect of this series of measures was to give the authorities greater selective control over the end-use of this type of external borrowing, to phase out the exchange guaran- tee, and to facilitate a gradual reduction in the total amount of convertible lira deposits. March 31. The bilateral payments agreement w i th Roma- nia expired. April 18. A law came in to force revising the regulations for the petroleum indus t ry. It provided for a priority position for the state-owned petroleum company, TPAO, and established a new agency, the Turkish Petroleum Directorate, to control all oil operations and oversee crude imports. June 14. The regulations regarding the deblocking and the utilization w i th in Turkey of blocked assets and balances were eased. June 19. The export regime for 1973 was announced. Ex- ports of cattle and fresh, chilled, or frozen beef, as well as exports of timber, were made subject to licensing. June 30. A supplementary protocol to the Association Agreement between the EEC and Turkey, consequent on the accession of the United Kingdom, Ireland, and Denmark to the EEC, was signed. It came in to force on January 1, 1974 and made these three countries parties to the Association Agreement between the EEC and Turkey. July 2. Guarantee deposits for imports were reduced as follows: for goods on liberalized list I from 50 per cent to 25 per cent of the value of the merchandise; for goods on liberal- ized list II from 20 per cent to 10 per cent; for imports under global quotas, from 20 per cent to 10 per cent for goods on importers' quotas and from 5 per cent to 2.5 per cent for industrialists' quotas and export manufacturers. Moreover, payments for imports on liberalized list I were permitted to be made also against documents or goods, while previously letters of credit were obligatory. July 12. Foreign exchange allocations for various types of current invisibles were increased. Turkish citizens were al- lowed to make tourist trips abroad several times a year (in effect four times) instead of once a year, and the exchange allocation for this purpose was increased from US$400 to US$800 a person a calendar year. Special permits no longer were required to employ the services of foreign technicians and experts. Foreign currency allocations henceforth were made available not only for freight charges in connection with the transportation of goods by sea but also for expenditures connected with other freight charges. 441 ©International Monetary Fund. The prescription of currency rules for exports were changed as follows: Exports to Austria, Belgium, Den- mark, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, I ta ly, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom had to be paid for either in the currency of the impor t ing coun t ry or in the currency of any other coun t ry in this group. Supplier credits from abroad were made subject to regulations corresponding to those introduced on Janu- ary 3, 1973 for pr iva te and public borrowing abroad f rom private sources. August 25. A package of economic policy measures was introduced to ease domestic price pressures. A supp lemen tary quota of US$250 million was announced for imports of goods in short supply. Exports of some agricultural products were prohibited, while exports of other agricultural products and of syn the t ic yarn and fibers were made subject to export licensing. For a number of commodities ( inc lud ing cement, lumber, margarine, sunflower-seed oil, cottonseed oil, an imal feed, and cereals), it was ruled that domestic requirements would take priority over export considerations and that they could be subjected to export restrictions. The tax rebate ra- tios were lowered for several export products. Import du ty reductions or exemptions were announced for a number of goods, inc lud ing cereals and wool. Moreover, the additional deposit of 50 per cent was abol- ished that previously was applicable to goods on liberalized list II, on the global quo ta list, and on quo ta lists established w i th bilateral agreement countries, when such goods were imported on the basis of payment against goods or payments against documents. August 25. The pre- import price control system was abol- ished. The post-import price registration remained in force. August 25.
