Subsequently the par i ty was fixed at LT 14 = US$1, i.e., the existing central rate. September 9. A decree was issued providing an exchange risk guarantee as follows: If goods covered by a license or a registration certificate issued in accordance w i th the export regulations were effectively exported w i th in 45 days of the date of issue, the purchase of the foreign exchange proceeds would be made at the rate of exchange in force on the issue date of the license or the registration certificate, even if lower than the rate prevailing on the date of shipment. October 12. A number of measures were introduced modi- fy ing the export tax rebate scheme. Thus, fru i ts and vegeta- bles were included in the scheme, w i th rates of rebate ranging f rom 5 per cent to 15 per cent. October 13. A "Blocked Currencies Fund" was established at the Central Bank. Each nonresident holder of blocked liras could t rans fer 75 per cent of these liras to the new Fund. Subject to prior permission from the M in is t ry of Finance, the nonresidents concerned could receive credits from the Blocked Currencies Fund to f inance their own investment requirements in Turkey or those of their affiliates in Turkey. Interest rates on such credits were to be the prevailing rates for domestic bank credit in Turkey. Dividends and profits derived from investments financed w i th these credits would be non transferab le and were to be credited to blocked lira accounts. Previously, blocked liras could only be used for investments in the tourist indu s t ry in Turkey or for personal expenditures in Turkey. November 23. Applications for credits had to be made to the Ministry of Finance w i th in one mon th of the date on which the funds were credited to a blocked account. Prior to the application, the part of the balance that exceeded the portion to be used as a credit must be deposited in a Provisional Blocked Ac- count opened w i th the Central Bank. Accrued interest had to be deposited in the Blocked Currencies Fund w i th in 15 days. 442 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.103133 gram of f ine gold per Uganda Shilling, corresponding to U Sh 8.61675 = SDR 1. A central rate of U Sh 6.90000 = US$1 has been established, and Uganda avails itself of wider margins. l The Bank of Uganda does not deal in foreign currencies 2 other than sterling, U.S. dollars, and deutsche mark; its rates for the U.S. dollar are based on the central rate, and its rates for sterling and deut- sche mark are based on the previous day's New York rates against the U.S. dollar. On December 31, 1973, the Bank's buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were U Sh 6.8978 and U Sh 6.9044, respectively. Authorized commercial banks in Uganda deal in all specified currencies 3 and base their rates on the previous day's closing rates against the U.S. dollar in London, except for Kenya shillings and Tanzania shillings, which are dealt in at par. Authorized banks may freely deal forward w i th customers in sterling, U.S. dollars, and other currencies, provided that there is an unde r ly ing approved import or export contract and that the term of the forward contract does not exceed three mon ths; contracts for longer periods require exchange control approval. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Uganda on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Impo rt and export control is administered by the M in is t ry of Commerce and Indu s t ry under the External Trade Act and by the Bank of Uganda. The Minister of Commerce and Indu s t ry has powers to prohibit imports and exports. Certain import and export transactions may be undertaken by the State Trading Corpo- ra t ion. 4 Together w i th Kenya and Tanzania, Uganda is part of the East African currency area but exchange control is applied to both Kenya and Tanzania. Nonresident Accounts Sterling Area Accounts are held by residents of other Ster- l ing Area countries except Kenya and Tanzania. They may be credited freely w i th all authorized payments to such Sterling Area countries by Ugandan residents, w i th transfers from other Sterling Area Accounts, w i th transfers from External Accounts, and w i th the proceeds from sales to an authorized dealer in Uganda of any foreign currency or gold by residents of any other coun t ry in the Sterling Area except Kenya and Tanzania. They may be debited freely for payments for ex- ports to other countries in the Sterling Area and other pay- ments due by residents of other countries in the Sterling Area to Ugandan residents, for payments to residents of other countries in the Sterling Area for any purpose, for transfers to other Sterling Area Accounts in Uganda, for purchases of any Sterling Area currency, and for w i thd rawa ls by the ac- count holder while he is temporarily resident in Uganda; provided that permission of the appropriate exchange control authorities in a Sterling Area coun t ry has been obtained, Sterling Area Accounts may exceptionally be debited for transfers to External Accounts in Uganda or elsewhere in the Sterling Area, and for purchases in Uganda of any non-Ster- l ing Area currency or gold. They may be credited freely w i th authorized payments to such countries by residents of Uganda, w i th transfers from other External Accounts, and w i th the proceeds from sales of any non-Sterling Area currency (other than Israel, Portu- guese, or Rhodesian currency) and gold by nonresidents of the Sterling Area to authorized dealers; provided that the permission of the appropriate exchange control authorities in 443 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA a Sterling Area coun try has been obtained, External Ac- counts may also be credited w i th transfers from Sterling Area Accounts. They may be debited freely for payments to resi- dents of the Sterling Area, for transfers to other External Accounts in Uganda or in any other Sterling Area coun try, and for purchases of non-Sterling Area currencies from au- thorized dealers. Nontransferable funds of persons not resident in Uganda are credited to Blocked Accounts. Subject to prior approval, balances on Blocked Accounts may be used for the purchase in Uganda of specified bonds and shares issued in Uganda; the redemption proceeds of government bonds so acquired are transferable beginning f ive years from the date of pur- chase. Subject to ind iv idual permission, such balances may also be used for payments to residents not related to export transactions. Transfers between Blocked Accounts in Uganda, and to Blocked Accounts in Kenya and Tanzania, require prior approval. All Blocked Accounts must be held w i th the Uganda Commercial Bank. Imports and Import Payments All permitted imports require approval by the Bank of Uganda. Mon th ly allocations of foreign exchange for imports are limited to a total of U Sh 100 million. Some imports from all sources are prohibited for reasons of public policy; imports prohibited for other reasons include passenger automobiles, cotton fabrics, blankets, electrical home refrigerators, transis- tor radios, and matches. All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited and imports from Por- tuguese-controlled territories in Africa are not being licensed. Impo r ts norma l ly must be purchased direct from the coun t ry of origin. Some imports of manufac tured goods f rom Kenya and Tanzania are subject to transfer taxes. Documentary evidence showing that the goods have been imported in to Uganda must be forwarded to the exchange control authorities w i th in six mon ths from the date of pay- men t. Payments for nonessential imports are normally made a f ter arrival of the goods, but advance payment is permitted for essential goods. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries are subject to ap- proval by the Bank of Uganda and those to Portugal (and its overseas territories), Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohib- ited. The basic allowance for travel outside Uganda is the equivalent of U Sh 2,000 a person every three years, which may be taken out in foreign banknotes. The allowance is available for travel to any coun try except Kenya and Tanza- nia, for which normally holiday facilities of up to U Sh 500 a person a year are available, and Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa, for which no allocation is granted. Salaried noncitizens recruited f rom outside East Africa may obtain allocations for travel outside East Africa at the time of their overseas leave. No foreign exchange is released for nursery, primary, and secondary education abroad except for children of diplomats, technical assistance personnel, nonnationals work ing in Uganda on overseas terms, nonna t ional missionaries, and 444 other special cases. Facilities exist whereby salaried foreign nationals may dur ing their stay in Uganda remit to their coun try of origin up to 33V3 per cent of their gross monthly earnings, to cover fam i ly maintenance, savings, etc., provided that they are on a contract of employment which includes a f i rm commitment to leave Uganda upon expiry of the con- tract. The export of Uganda banknotes and coins by travelers is prohibited, except that travelers to Kenya and Tanzania may take out U Sh 100 in Uganda currency. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require licenses and may be restricted to ensure sufficient supplies for consumption in Uganda. All exports to Israel, South Africa, the Portuguese-controlled territories in Africa, and Rhodesia are prohibited. The State Trading Cor- poration has a monopoly over the export of edible oils. Export proceeds in specified currencies (see footnote 3) must be collected w i th in six mon ths of exportation and of- fered to an authorized bank in Uganda for conversion into Uganda shillings. Coffee, cotton, and hides and skins are subject to export du ty. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies (see foot- note 3) must be sold to an authorized bank. The import of Uganda banknotes and coins by travelers is prohibited, ex- cept that returning Ugandan residents may bring in U Sh 100 a person. Travelers may freely bring in foreign currency notes and foreign currency travelers checks. Capital Capital transfers to all countries are restricted and those to Israel, Portugal (and its overseas territories), Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Residents of Uganda, however, may be granted exemptions from the deposit and surrender requirements in respect of foreign assets for specified Sterling Area assets held prior to June 11, 1965. Capital transfers require individual exchange control ap- proval. Residents of Uganda leaving permanently may nor- mally transfer their assets up to the equivalent of U Sh 50,000. The allowance is reduced by the amount of insurance premi- ums remitted after 1965 outside the facilities for remit- tance of savings. A fu r ther transfer of up to the equivalent of U Sh 20,000 upon each anniversary of the emigrant's depar- ture is allowed. All remaining funds must be credited to a Blocked Account and may either be invested in certain ap- proved securities or held on deposit with the Uganda Com- mercial Bank in Uganda; such funds become transferable after f ive years. The income from such investments is transfer- able also during the period when the funds are blocked. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Uganda; to secure guaranteed repatriation, however, it is necessary to obtain "approved status" for the investment in terms of the Foreign Investments (Protection) Act, 1964, which in normal circumstances is given freely. Foreign and domestic investment in specified types of production require ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution approval under the East African Industrial Licensing Act and the Uganda Licensing Act, 1969. Dividends and profits due to nonresidents from normal trading operations and distrib- uted by companies operating in Uganda are in principle trans- ferable. All imports and exports of securities require approval. Ap- proval is freely granted for the purchase by nonresidents of Ugandan securities, provided that payment is received in an appropriate manner. The income from such securities is re- mittable, and the proceeds on resale are normally remittable also. Purchases of securities outside Uganda by residents are not normally permitted. A resident of Uganda may not send, as a gift, to any country more than U Sh 100 a year without specific exchange control approval. With minor exceptions, prior exchange control approval is required for loans or overdraft facilities granted to a nonresi- dent or to a body corporate resident in Uganda which is by any means controlled, whether directly or indirectly, by per- sons resident outside Uganda. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Uganda for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in Uganda in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the per- sonal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Minis- try of Finance. Export licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. The import of the following from all sources is subject to individual licensing: jewelry of gold, silver, or platinum; goldsmiths' or silversmiths' wares, includ- ing set gems; bullion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coins. Import licenses for gold bullion (ingots, bars, or sheets), gold jewelry, and gold coins are issued to goldsmiths only and are issued restrictively. Changes during 1973 January 1. Not for Redistribution Exchange Rate System'" Exports and Export Proceeds UNITED ARAB EMIRATES l The currency of the United Arab Emirates is the Dirham, which is defined as equivalent to 0.186621 gram of fine gold, i.e., Dh 1 = SDR 0.21. No par value for the dirham has yet been established w i th the Fund. The United Arab Emirates Currency Board establishes daily quotations for the deutsche mark, the pound sterling, the Swiss franc, and the U.S. dollar; these quotations are derived from the previous day's closing U.S. dollar-sterling rate in London. The Board deals w i th commercial banks only. Administration of Control There is neither exchange control legislation nor an ex- change control au tho r i ty in the United Arab Emirates, and there are no registration requirements for inward or ou tward transfers. The United Arab Emirates has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regula- tions continues to be regarded as a coun try of the Overseas Sterling Area. Import and export licenses, where required, are issued by the authorities of the Emirate concerned. Prescription of Currency All settlements w i th Israel are prohibited. No other pre- scription of currency requirements are in force. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. Exports to Israel are prohibited. Exports of petroleum from Abu Dhabi and Dubai to the Netherlands and the United States have been suspended. V i r tua l ly all other com- modities may be exported freely, w i thout an export license, to any other destination; each Emirate establishes its own export regulations. There are no requirements attached to receipts f rom exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surrendered, and they may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no requirements attached to receipts from cur- rent invisibles. Travelers may br ing in any amount in foreign or domestic banknotes. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents. Transac- tions and settlements invo lv ing Israel, however, are prohib- i ted. Prof i ts on foreign capital invested in the Un i ted Arab Emirates may be remitted freely. Gold Residents and nonresidents, inc lud ing private persons, may freely and w i thout license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. They may also, w i thout a license and w i thout payment of any customs du ty or tax, impo rt and export gold in any form. Transactions invo lv ing Israel, however, are prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Changes during 1973 Imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are pro- hibited, as are imports of products manufac tured by foreign companies blacklisted by the Arab League. Impor ts of a few commodities are prohibited from all sources for moral, health, or security reasons. V ir tua l ly all other commodities may be freely imported w i thout an import license; each Emir- ate establishes its own import regulations. There are no re- strictions on the ava i lab i l i ty of foreign exchange for paymen ts in respect of permitted imports. Payments for Invisibles All payments for current invisibles may be made freely, except to Israel. Since June 23, 1972, however, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the pound w i th in announced margins, and therefore all transactions in the official exchange market, except those in currencies ma in ta in ing a fixed relationship w i th sterling, take place at a f luc tua t ing exchange rate. The closing selling and buy ing rates in the foreign exchange mar- ket for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1973 were US$2.3232 and US$2.3237 per £1, respectively. Authorized banks are allowed to engage in spot and for- ward exchange transactions in any currencies, except Rhode- sian currency, subject to the observance of l im i ts on open positions and the accumulation of spot foreign exchange. Forward rates may f luc tua te under the influence of market forces; transactions w i th resident customers may be entered in to only for approved purposes, where there is an unde r ly ing commercial contract (or where an exporter is tendering for an overseas export contract), and in the currency of the contract. There is also a market in which the foreign currency pro- ceeds 1 (referred to as investment currency) resulting ma in ly from the sale outside the Scheduled Territories (the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, the Republic of I re land ,2 and Gibraltar) of foreign currency securities,3 of direct investments held in non-EEC non-Scheduled Territo- ries outside the Overseas Sterling Area (but see footnote 14), and of most personal residential property situated outside the Scheduled Territories may be negotiated at freely determined rates, usually a t trac t ing a premium over the official market rate (but see footnote 14); at the end of 1973, that premium was about 39V2 per cent calculated at £1 = US$2.60, or about 241/2 per cent calculated at the ru l ing U.S. dollar rate in the official exchange market, the middle closing rate on Decem- ber 31 being £1 = US$1.8671. These funds are available for reinvestment in marketable foreign currency securities, for approved purchases of personal residential property in countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rho- desia, and for approved direct investments in non-Scheduled Territories outside the Overseas Sterling Area (but see foot- note 14). The authorized banks may deal among themselves and w i th residents and nonresidents in foreign notes and coins (other than Rhodesian currency) at free market rates of ex- change. S ter l ing securities are defined as securities payable solely in s ter l ing, Irish pounds, or G ibra l tar currency. The term "securities" includes certificates of deposit and treasury bills. 448 In general, the United Kingdom does not impose restric- tions on transactions between residents of the United King- dom and residents of the Scheduled Territories. Exchange control applies ma in ly to transactions with residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories. The non-Sched- uled Territories for administrative purposes are divided as follows: (1) the other member countries of the EEC, except the Republic of Ireland; (2) the Overseas Sterling Area (OSA), i.e., the countries other than the Republic of Ireland and Gibraltar which as at June 22, 1972 were treated as Scheduled Territories;4 (3) Rhodesia; and (4) all other countries, usually referred to as the Rest of the Non-Sched- uled Territories (RNST). Administration of Control Exchange control in the United Kingdom is administered by the Bank of England on behalf of the U.K. Treasury. However, practically all commercial banks are authorized to approve most current payments requiring exchange control permission. The licensing of imports and exports is handled by the Department of Trade and Indus t ry. Prescription of Currency Receipts from Scheduled Territories may be in sterling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency; those from other countries, w i th the exception of Rhodesia, must be in sterling from an External Account or in any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency), which must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless permission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Payments to Sched- uled Territories may be made in sterling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency; payments to other countries, with the exception of Rhodesia, may be made by crediting sterling to an External Account or in any foreign currency except Rho- desian currency. For security reasons, settlements w i th Rhodesia are subject to special regulations generally prescribing the use of Rhode- sian Accounts, Suspense Accounts, or, in certain circum- stances, the Rhodesian Special Account w i th the Standard Bank, London. However, unless specifically included among the permitted debits to Rhodesian Accounts, all commercial payments, except those in respect of exports, due from per- sons resident in Rhodesia to residents of the United Kingdom must be received either in a foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or, w i th the specific permission of the 4 The Overseas Sterling Area thus comprises Aus tra l ia, Bahamas, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Barbados, Belize, Bermuda, Botswana, British Indian Ocean Territory, Br i t ish Solomon Islands Protectorate, British Virgin Islands, Brunei, Cayman Islands, Cyprus, Falkland Islands and Dependencies, Fiji, The Gambia, Ghana, Gilbert and Ellice Islands Colony, Guyana, Hong Kong, Iceland, Ind ia and Sikkim, Jamaica, Jordan, Kenya, Kuwa i t, Leeward Islands, Lesotho, Malawi, Malaysia, Maldive Islands, Malta, Mauritius and Depen- dency, Nau ru, New Zealand, Nigeria, Oman, Pakistan, Pit cairn Islands, Qatar, St. Helena and Dependencies, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Singapore, South Africa, South West Africa (Namibia), Sri Lanka, Swaziland, Tanzania, Tonga, Trinidad and Tobago, Turks and Caicos Islands, Uganda, United Arab Emirates, Western Samoa, W indwa rd Islands, People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, and Zambia. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Account; authorized payments for exports from the United Kingdom to Rhodesia must be received in advance of ship- ment in a foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency, or, w i th the specific approval of the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Account. Persons normally resi- dent in Rhodesia who are living temporarily in the United Kingdom as students or workers may open Temporary Resi- dent Accounts in sterling w i th authorized banks in the United Kingdom; debits to such accounts are generally permitted on ly for living expenses within the United Kingdom. Nonresident Accounts The sterling accounts of residents of other Scheduled Terri- tories are treated in the same way as those of residents of the United Kingdom. Thus, for transfers between Scheduled Ter- ritories no U .K. exchange control permission is required; for payments to other countries by residents of any Scheduled Territory, the authorized banks are required to ensure that the payment has the approval of the exchange control author- ity in the territory concerned. External Accounts. With the exception of Rhodesian Ac- counts and the Rhodesian Special Account (see below), the sterling accounts of nonresidents with banks in the United Kingdom, i.e., those of residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories, are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized payments by residents of Scheduled Territories, w i th transfers from other External Accounts, with the proceeds from sales of gold or foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency (including banknotes), and with sterling banknotes mailed from outside the Scheduled Territories. External Accounts may be debited, subject to general or special permission, for payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories, for transfers to other External Accounts, for transfers to Rhodesian Accounts other than in payment for certain goods exported from Rho- desia, for payments in cash in the United Kingdom, and for purchases of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian cur- rency (including banknotes) or gold. Rhodesian Accounts. These accounts are applicable to resi- dents of Rhodesia only. Permitted credits include transfers from External Accounts, provided that the bank has no rea- son to believe that the payment is for a purpose prohibited by the Southern Rhodesia (United Nations Sanctions) (No. 2) Order 1968; payments by residents of Scheduled Territo- ries other than the United Kingdom to residents of Rhodesia, subject to the approval of the exchange control authority in the territory concerned; and payments by U.K. residents to residents of Rhodesia in respect of (1) the sale of foreign currencies other than Rhodesian currency, (2) the discount or ma tu r i ty proceeds of U.K. treasury bills, (3) permitted im- ports from Rhodesia which have entered customs in the United Kingdom, (4) insurance and freight charges resulting from permitted trade between Rhodesia and any Scheduled Territory, (5) insurance claims directly related to such permit- ted trade, (6) pensions and widows' annuities where asso- ciated with the deceased husband's employment, (7) charges and fees relating to patents, designs, and trademarks regis- UNITED KINGDOM tered in Rhodesia, Zambia, or Malawi, and (8) ma tur i ty pro- ceeds of certain endowment insurance policies. Permitted debits include transfers to the Rhodesian Special Account in respect of pensions and widows' annuities; pay- ments for living expenses in the United Kingdom of persons resident in Rhodesia and their families; authorized purchases of U.K. sterling securities to be held for the account holder; purchases in the United Kingdom of treasury bills to be held for the account holder; payments to residents of the Sched- uled Territories for (1) interest on and repayment of outstand- ing personal loans, advances, and overdrafts granted before November 11, 1965, (2) patents, designs, trademarks, and royalties, (3) distributions from Rhodesian estates and trusts, and (4) subscriptions to newspapers and other periodicals; and payments to U.K. residents for (a) expenses arising out of property in the United Kingdom owned on or before No- vember 11, 1965, (b) taxes, (c) educational fees and incidental expenses, (d) insurance premiums and capital and annuity payments on personal policies taken out on or before Novem- ber 11, 1965, (e) medical fees, (f) gifts and maintenance not exceeding £250 for any one payment, to individuals and reli- gious, medical, educational, and charitable organizations, and subscriptions to such organizations, (g) contributions to pension funds provided the person was a member of the fund before November 11, 1965 or before taking up residence in Rhodesia after that date, and (h) bank and safe custody charges. Transfers between Rhodesian Accounts and from Rhodesian Accounts to External Accounts are not normally allowed. Suspense Accounts. Unless eligible for credit to Rhodesian Accounts or to the Rhodesian Special Account, payments to persons resident in Rhodesia must be withheld unless the Bank of England directs otherwise; the funds may be placed on Suspense Accounts and, except with specific permission, may only be (1) used to meet U.K. tax payments and safe custody charges due on the monies in question, or (2) placed on deposit with banks or other financial institutions in the name of the U.K. resident by whom they are held. Permission is normally given for residents of Rhodesia to use Suspense Account monies to purchase U.K. sterling securities on a recognized stock exchange in the United Kingdom and to purchase U.K. treasury bills and savings bonds and certifi- cates. Permission is only given for them to purchase Rhode- sian or foreign currency securities, however, when the funds for the purchase are derived from the sale proceeds of other Rhodesian or foreign currency securities, respectively. The Rhodesian Special Account. This is an account oper- ated by the Rhodesia Pensions Office staff in London and maintained with the Standard Bank, London. Pensions and associated payments due to beneficiaries in Rhodesia from residents of the Scheduled Territories and the Overseas Ster- ling Area, and pensions due from Rhodesia to residents of the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, and most parts of the Overseas Sterling Area are normally settled through this account. Corresponding transfers from Rhodesian Accounts in the names of individuals to the Rhodesian Special Account are freely permitted. Permission is not normally given for payments of any other nature to be credited to the Rhodesian Special Account. Subject to specific approval by the Bank of 449 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM England, any balance on the Special Account may be used to meet the cost of permitted exports to Rhodesia from the Scheduled Territories and the Overseas Sterling Area and of services provided by residents of the Scheduled Territories and the Overseas Sterling Area for account of persons resi- dent in Rhodesia. Imports and Import Payments For import licensing purposes countries outside the United Kingdom other than Rhodesia5 are divided in to eight groups: the Mediterranean Area ,6 the Non-Community A rea ,7 the Non-CEFTA Area, 8 the Dollar Area, 9 Japan, 10 Romania, the Eastern Area, ll and all other countries. Imports from countries other than Rhodesia are admitted under an Open General Import License without restriction, w i th the following exceptions: (1) from all other countries, seven commodities or groups of commodities; 12 (2) from the Dollar Area only, four commodities or groups of commodi- ties; (3) from Japan only, certain textiles; (4) from the Non-CEFTA Area only, one commodity; (5) from the Non-Community Area only, one commodity; (6) from Roma- nia only, two commodities; and (7) from the Eastern Area only, n ine commodities or groups of commodities. Most arti- cles subject to import licensing can be imported in limited quantities under bilateral or global quotas. A few articles may be imported under open individual licenses, i.e., w i thout limit as to quan t i ty or value. Imports of cereals and cereal prod- ucts, beef and veal, mu t ton and lamb, poultry meat, and dairy products other than butter and cheese are subject to mini- mum import prices enforced through autonomously imposed variable import levies. Imports of many other agricultural, horticultural, and livestock products are subject to EEC reg- ulations. Once licensing requirements have been met to import from countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rho- desia, whether under Open General Import License or some other form of license, U.K. residents may purchase foreign currency or credit sterling to an External Account to pay for the import, provided that evidence of customs en t ry is sub- mitted or evidence that the goods have been dispatched to the United Kingdom or are to be dispatched immediately on receipt of payment.
