Exchange control forms are not required for pay- ments to residents of the Scheduled Territories, neither are they required for payments to residents of other countries, unless the payment represents part or final settlement for goods for which the total amount payable exceeds £5,000, and evidence of importation cannot be presented to the bank before making the remittance. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of other Scheduled Territories may be made freely. Payments to residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories require exchange control authorization, which (except for payments to resi- dents of Rhodesia)13 is granted freely for all purposes other than sterling usance credits to finance trade directly between principals resident in non-Scheduled Territories outside the Overseas Sterling Area, subject to the presentation of sup- porting evidence. The completion of an exchange control form is required for payments exceeding £1,000 or its equiva- lent. Authorized banks are permitted to approve applications for transfers on account of many categories of current invisi- bles without any limitation, and for other categories up to established limits. Applications for payments in excess of these limits or for purposes for which no delegation of author- ity has been granted are approved by the Bank of England, provided that no unauthorized capital ou tf low is involved. Authorized banks may dispatch sterling banknotes to non- residents except residents of Rhodesia against payment in sterling from an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. For any type of travel outside the Scheduled Territories (except to Rhodesia), U.K. residents can obtain on demand from banks and authorized travel agents foreign exchange up to the equivalent of £300 a person a trip; for travel for busi- ness or professional reasons, an allowance of £40 a day up to a maximum of £2,000 for any one journey can be authorized by banks and certain authorized travel agents. Applications for additional amounts are approved by the Bank of England unless there is reason to suspect that the exchange is to be used for purposes other than genuine travel expenditure. The cost of accommodation, fares, etc., can be paid for w i thout limit in the United Kingdom. Travel exchange purchased in the United Kingdom must normally be recorded in the trav- eler's passport. Under arrangements agreed w i th certain banks, personal checks may be cashed abroad for travel pur- poses, up to £30 a check, if backed by check cards. Credit cards may be used freely to settle travel expenses. Resident travelers may take out up to £300 in foreign currency notes. Any unused travel exchange expressed in foreign currency may be retained for a period of one mon th from the date of 13 For security reasons, v i r tua l ly all cu r rent payments to Rhodesia are prohibited, except when these result f rom permitted trade in goods. Consider- ation is, however, given to remittances on a limited basis to relieve hardship and to remittances of a con t inu ing n a tu re by charitable, religious, medical, and educational organizations for both current purposes (where similar remittances were made prior to November 11, 1965) or to meet capital expenditure in the educational and medical fields. Small personal g i f ts are also permitted where human i ta r ian grounds exist for the purpose. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution return to the United Kingdom. Banks have au thor i ty to ap- prove applications by U.K. residents who wish to open for- eign currency accounts outside the Scheduled Territories for the receipt of travel funds for use during their stay abroad. Travel facilities expressed in sterling may be held for six months from the date of issue or for one month from the date of return to the United Kingdom, if later. In addition, resi- dent travelers may take with them up to £25 in U .K. and other Scheduled Territory banknotes, which may be ex- changed or spent abroad only for travel expenditure; but those traveling direct to the Republic of Ireland, the Channel Islands, or the Isle of Man may take out any amount. Visitors to the United Kingdom are, in addition, allowed to take out any notes that they brought in with them, other than notes in excess of £25 expressed in the currencies of the United Kingdom or the Republic or Ireland. Authorized banks are permitted to approve, w i th in certain limits and subject to the submission of appropriate documen- tary evidence of the amounts due, applications to pay fees, accommodation charges, and all incidental expenses arising from the education of U.K. residents outside the Scheduled Territories. Special regulations apply to all travel to Rhodesia. For approved official and essential business journeys the Bank of England will authorize the issue of foreign currency at a rate of up to £10 a day w i th a maximum of £300. Facilities for private travel are authorized only where there are compas- sionate grounds. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are subject to licensing control and licenses are normally issued only for the permitted exceptions (medical and educational supplies, foodstuffs where these are special medical preparations, newsfilm and photographs, and documentary and printed matter less than 100 years old) and for equipment for the essential replacement needs of the Rho- desian Railways and the Central African Power Corporation. V ir tua l ly all exports to other destinations are free of export control and no exchange control forms are normally required. Exporters to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia must normally obtain appropriate pay- ment w i th in six months of shipment; special exchange control permission to collect at a later date is required only where the exporter extends credit for more than six mon ths w i thout cover from the Export Credits Guarantee Department (ECGD). Receipts in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless the recipient has obtained specific permission to credit them to a retained currency ac- count (subject to supervision) or permission has been given for them to be used for some other purpose. Permitted ex- ports to Rhodesia must be paid for prior to shipment in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency or, if specific permission is granted by the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Account. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts in foreign currencies on account of invisibles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank, unless recipients of UNITED KINGDOM such currencies have permission to credit them to a retained currency account or to use them for some other purpose. British and other banknotes may be brought into the United Kingdom freely. Capital1* Residents of the United Kingdom who receive foreign cur- rency other than Rhodesian currency from certain capital account sources (mainly the sale or redemption of foreign currency securities and the sale or liquidation of direct invest- ments held outside the Scheduled Territories, Overseas Ster- ling Area, and EEC or of personal residential property situated outside the Scheduled Territories) may, in certain circumstances and w i th permission, use the exchange (which is regarded as investment currency once permission has been given) for the purchase of marketable foreign currency securi- ties, the purchase of personal residential property outside the Scheduled Territories, or the making of approved direct in- vestments (in practice only those outside the Overseas Ster- ling Area); they may also sell the exchange for sterling to other residents to be used for the same purposes. If permis- sion is not forthcoming, the foreign currency must be offered for sale at the rates ruling in the official market to an autho- rized bank in the United Kingdom. If permission is granted, however, the equivalent in foreign currency of 25 per cent of the proceeds must normally be sold to an authorized bank for sterling at the official market rate of exchange. 15»16 This "25 per cent requirement" is not applicable, however, to the pro- ceeds from the sale or redemption of foreign currency securi- ties payable solely in an Overseas Sterling Area currency or payable in such a currency and sterling (but see footnote 14). In certain circumstances, residents of the United Kingdom who are foreign nationals and who have obtained exemption from their liabilities under the Exchange Control Act in re- 14 W i th effect from March 27, 1974 a number of changes in exchange control rules for direct and portfolio investment were introduced. Their main effect was the termination of certain preferen t ial t rea tment accorded to the Overseas Sterling Area and the EEC. (1) The rules governing f inance for ou twa rd direct investment in the Overseas S ter l ing Area and the EEC became the same as those already app ly ing to other non-Scheduled Territories. Official exchange henceforth was available on ly for "super-criterion" projects and U .K. compa- nies were normally expected to finance new investments in the Overseas Sterling Area and the EEC by borrowing foreign currency or by one of the other permitted methods not involving the use of official exchange. (2) U .K. companies henceforth were expected normally to arrange for the repatriation to the United Kingdom of not less than two th irds of the net taxed earnings of their OSA subsidiaries, a requirement already observed w i th regard to subsidiaries in other non-Scheduled Territories ( inc lud ing the EEC). (3) The proceeds of sales and l iqu ida t ions of direct investments in non-Scheduled Territories outside both the EEC and the Overseas Sterling Area ceased to be eligible for sale in the inves tment currency market and had to be offered for sale for s ter l ing at the current market rate of exchange, as previously applicable to realization proceeds in EEC and Overseas Sterling Area countries. (4) Proceeds accruing to U .K. residents from the redemption or sale proceeds of securities payable or optionally payable in Overseas Sterling Area currencies became subject to the same 25 per cent surrender rules applicable to such proceeds of securities payable or optionally payable in non-Sterling Area currencies. 15 Where currency is received from similar sources by residents of other Scheduled Territories, permission may also be given for such funds to be regarded as investment currency; in this case, the 25 per cent requirement would norma l ly app ly, but for securities owned prior to April 7, 1965, or any o ther foreign currency securities derived therefrom by way of "switches," the requirement applies on ly on ou t r ight sales for s ter l ing or for reinvestment in s ter l ing securities. 18 The fu ll amount of the currency proceeds is normally permitted to be sold as inves tment currency when a residential property has been held for private use; when it has been held as an inves tmen t, however, the proceeds are not normally eligible to be treated as investment currency. 451 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM spect of assets denominated in the currency of the country of their nationality may obtain permission for the sale proceeds of exempted securities to be sold for sterling in the investment currency market up to 75 per cent of the amount concerned. In rare circumstances, exempted cash balances may also be sold as investment currency. There are no restrictions on capital transfers by residents of the United Kingdom into the beneficial ownership of resi- dents of other Scheduled Territories. All capital transfers by residents to countries outside the Scheduled Territories require approval. Each individual resi- dent of the United Kingdom may, from his own resources, make cash gifts or personal loans not exceeding a total of £1,000, or the equivalent in foreign currency, during each calendar year to residents of the Overseas Sterling Area, as well as a fu r ther £300 or the equivalent to residents of other countries outside the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesia; additional amounts may be allowed under appropriate cir- cumstances. The cash gifts allowance is noncumulative and is not transferable from one resident to another. A resident of the United Kingdom w i th dependents who are established residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia may make payments from his own resources not exceeding £2,000 a year to support those dependents. Such payments, which may be gifts or loans, are outside the cash g ift scheme and do not prejudice the normal cash gift allowances. For security reasons, no capital transfers are allowed to Rhodesia, whether in the form of direct investment or of the purchase of Rhodesian securities, or by any other means, except to relatives, or other Rhodesian residents where hu- manitarian reasons are given, to the extent of £75 during any period of two years. Direct investments in the Overseas Sterling Area require approval; this is normally granted and for approved projects foreign currency is made available without limitation at offi- cial market rates of exchange. For direct investments in non-Scheduled Territories out- side the Overseas Sterling Area and the EEC, official ex- change is normally made available only for certain projects directly concerned w i th promoting exports of goods and ser- vices where the prospective benefit to the U.K. balance of payments is expected to equal or exceed the total cost of the investment within 18 months and to continue thereafter; this benefit will normally occur by way of additional export re- ceipts, but may also arise from profits and other foreign currency receipts that would not take place without the in- vestment. For such projects ("super-criterion" projects), offi- cial exchange may be made available up to £250,000 or 50 per cent of the total investment, whichever is larger; any balance must be financed by foreign currency borrowing, the use of investment currency, the export free of payment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade forming an integral part of the investment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresidents on appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an overseas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U.K. parent company, or by approved profit retention. Direct investment other than for super-criterion projects is considered on the basis that its capital cost should not fall 452 directly upon the U.K. official foreign exchange reserves at least un t il an equivalent amount has been received in the United Kingdom by way of benefits arising from the invest- ments; such investments can normally be financed by foreign currency borrowing, the use of investment currency, the ex- port free of payment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade forming an integral part of the investment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresidents on appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an overseas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U.K. parent company, or by approved profit retention. The permitted proportion of retained foreign currency earnings normally is one third of net earnings after taxes, applied on a global basis where more than one subsid- iary is involved. There is no limit on earnings which may be retained in a subsidiary in the Overseas Sterling Area (but see footnote 14). The same rules apply to direct investment in non-Sched- uled Territories that are member countries of the EEC, with the exception that official exchange up to £1 million a project a year can be used to finance all new approved direct invest- ments in member countries of the EEC (but see footnote 14). The purchase of foreign currency securities outside the Scheduled Territories must be financed either with invest- ment currency or with foreign currency borrowing. Such bor- rowing is freely permitted when undertaken by or through U.K. professional security managers, and the resale of foreign currency securities acquired in this manner is exempt from the "25 per cent requirement" until the loan portfolio is liqui- dated and the profit repatriated. Purchases of marketable foreign currency securities with investment currency are freely permitted by virtue of certain general permissions granted to banks, stockbrokers, and other authorized deposi- tories. Purchases from other residents may also be effected with sterling on The Stock Exchange (sterling prices reflect the prevailing investment currency premium). The purchase by U.K. residents of a house or apartment for personal use in countries outside the Scheduled Territories requires specific approval and must be made either from an- other Scheduled Territory resident for sterling or another Scheduled Territory currency or from a nonresident of the Scheduled Territories with investment currency; payment for attendant expenses and improvements, but not maintenance, must also be made with investment currency. (As an excep- tion to this rule, residents temporarily employed in the Over- seas Sterling Area or member countries of the EEC may be authorized to purchase necessary accommodation at current official market rates of exchange.) Approval is normally lim- ited to one property a family; purchases of investment cur- rency are normally limited to reasonable amounts and may be made before exchange control approval is received pro- vided that the funds are held by an authorized depository and that a formal application is lodged to purchase the property within six months. All proceeds from the realization, redemption, or maturity of sterling capital assets (including direct investments) owned by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories other than resi- dents of Rhodesia are remittable at the official rate of ex- change. Payments to nonresident beneficiaries are authorized freely in respect of inheritances due from the estates of de- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ceased residents; capital payments under life and other insur- ance policies taken up by nonresidents w i th resident insur- ance companies are also authorized freely. Residents of the United Kingdom who leave with the in- tention of residing for at least three years in a country outside the Scheduled Territories and apply to transfer their assets are, on their departure from the United Kingdom, regarded for exchange control purposes as nonresidents, and, w i th the following exceptions, their assets are treated accordingly. Re- patriates (non-Scheduled Territory nationals, other than Rhodesians, who having been resident in the United King- dom return to take up residence in their country of national- ity) may normally transfer all their sterling assets abroad at the official rate of exchange. Other residents leaving to take up residence in countries outside the Scheduled Territories and the Overseas Sterling Area except Rhodesia are allowed on departure to transfer for a family unit up to £5,000 through the official foreign exchange market and may export any foreign currency securities they hold; the remaining de- clared assets in excess of £5,000 are restricted for a four-year period from the date of the departing person's redesignation as a nonresident. U.K. residents taking up residence and employment in member countries of the EEC, however, may, with specific approval, transfer sterling assets at the official rate of exchange in excess of the £5,000 limit where this is necessary in order to ensure their freedom to take up the employment in question. For emigration to the Overseas Sterling Area, the basic settling-in allowance is £20,000 (with a similar concession for those taking up employment), also available at the official rate of exchange, and holdings of foreign currency securities are exportable. During the four-year period the restricted funds may be disposed of for foreign currencies other than Rhodesian currency through the investment currency market, or may be invested in sterling securities which are quoted on The Stock Exchange, the income therefrom being freely re- mittable through the official exchange market. After the four-year period any remaining assets are transferable in ac- cordance with the rules then applicable to the assets of a nonresident; at present, the transfer at the official rate of exchange is normally allowed. The participation of foreign capital as a direct investment in the United Kingdom is subject to individual authorization, which is normally granted, provided that adequate capital for the project is supplied in an approved manner of payment (see section on Prescription of Currency, above) or by the import of goods and services; the foreign currency received must be surrendered at rates ruling in the official market unless per- mission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Cases involving the take-over of existing companies that by their size or nature constitute a vital part of British industry are considered on their merits. Permissions given for direct investments in the United Kingdom by nonresidents normally are, unless otherwise agreed with the Bank of Eng- land, conditional on the consideration being paid in sterling from an External Account or in foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) and, where nonresidents (other than residents of the EEC and the Overseas Sterling Area) have a controlling interest, on any subsequent finance being pro- UNITED KINGDOM vided in foreign currency at least in proportion to the nonresi- dent interest in the equity of the company. Foreign firms and foreign individuals must obtain permis- sion from the Treasury in order to raise capital in the United Kingdom, and U.K. resident subsidiaries of foreign compa- nies are required to obtain consent before issuing shares or other securities to nonresidents. U.K. residents also need permission to lend to U.K. companies controlled by nonresi- dents. Such permission is normally given for sterling lending for the purpose of financing the company's day-to-day busi- ness, but is not normally given for any expansion of manufac- turing capacity except for companies whose activities are regarded as bringing special advantages to the U.K. econ- omy. There are three important exceptions to these principles: (1) Unlimited sterling finance in the United Kingdom is nor- mally allowed to U.K. companies in which any nonresidents have less than a controlling interest, except to companies which are purely vehicles for portfolio investment. (2) U.K. companies controlled by residents of the EEC or the Overseas Sterling Area that are not purely vehicles for portfolio invest- ment are normally allowed unlimited sterling finance for their operations anywhere in the United Kingdom. (3) U.K. com- panies controlled by residents of any non-EEC country out- side both the Scheduled Territories and the Overseas Sterling Area are upon application allowed similar facilities in respect of new expenditure in the areas of the United Kingdom which qualify for special government assistance (the assisted areas), while their requests in respect of new expenditure in other areas of the United Kingdom are considered on their merits. U.K. banks are prohibited from providing sterling loans or overdrafts to persons resident outside the Scheduled Territo- ries and the Overseas Sterling Area for the purpose of financ- ing trade between non-Scheduled Territories, but sterling lending to residents of the Overseas Sterling Area to finance trade with such non-Scheduled Territories is unrestricted. Borrowing by U.K. residents from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories to finance expenditure in the United Kingdom is subject to restriction. Private sector U.K. resi- dents other than authorized banks normally are not permit- ted to borrow foreign currency from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories for conversion into sterling for use in the United Kingdom, or to finance current payments to non- residents of the Scheduled Territories, unless the term of the borrowing is at least two years (five years in the case of borrowing for personal consumption, property development, or financial transactions); exporters, merchants, and certain commodity traders are, however, permitted to borrow foreign currency for shorter periods from authorized banks to finance their sales. Public sector bodies normally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency unless the term of the foreign borrowing is at least five years. Authorized banks must not lend foreign currency to U.K. residents other than authorized banks for any other purpose without prior reference to the Bank of England. Under certain permissions delegated to authorized deposi- tories, transactions in securities of most types may generally be carried out freely between residents of the United King- dom, except that transactions in Rhodesian securities may only be effected on The Stock Exchange. Residents are nor- 453 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM mally permitted, subject to certain conditions, to sell foreign currency securities outside the Scheduled Territories and, af- ter 25 per cent of the proceeds has been sold to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange where appropri- ate (see above), to reinvest the balance of the exchange pro- ceeds (investment currency) in other marketable foreign currency securities, or to sell the exchange to other residents for such investments or for certain approved direct invest- ments outside the Scheduled Territories. When foreign cur- rency securities expressed in currencies other than Overseas Sterling Area currencies are sold on The Stock Exchange for sterling, an amount of investment currency in the form of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be purchased in the investment currency market for resale to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange. Professional dealers mak ing a "book" may on application be exempt from the 25 per cent requirement in respect of transactions on the "book." Investment currency held for a continuous period of 6 mon ths ceases to be investment cur- rency unless an amount of investment currency in the form of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) equiva- lent to 25 per cent of the amount held is, at the end of the 6-month period, sold to an authorized bank at the current market rate in the official foreign exchange market, except for certain authorities for the purchase of private property out- side the Scheduled Territories where investment currency may be retained for up to 18 mon ths w i thout the 25 per cent requirement being imposed. Investment currency may on ly be retained as investment currency for a max imum of 12 months, after which period any amount remaining must be offered for sale to an authorized bank at the current market rate in the official foreign exchange market. 17 Professional security managers acting on their own behalf and for clients are permitted, subject to certain conditions, to borrow foreign currency for the purpose of mak ing portfolio investments in marketable foreign currency securities. U.K. jobbers and other security dealers may, with permission, ar- range day-to-day borrowing of foreign currency, whether from U.K. banks or from nonresidents, to finance a "book" in foreign currency securities, but not to finance holdings of such securities as investments. Residents of other Scheduled Territories are not prevented by the U.K. regulations from buy ing and selling sterling secu- rities in the United Kingdom; they may also buy and sell, subject to certain conditions, Rhodesian securities on The Stock Exchange, but they must obtain the permission of the U.K. authorities to buy and sell other securities in the United Kingdom. Permission is required for all transfers of securities in the United Kingdom in which a nonresident of the Scheduled Territories is involved as either transferor or transferee, but most transfers are covered by a general au thor i ty. In most cases, U.K. companies may issue sterling securities (including 17 Inves tment currency may be invested temporarily in short-term govern- ment bonds (with up to six mon ths to run before f inal m a t u r i t y) or in s ix -mon th treasury bills or other forms of recognized short-term money-market paper ( inc lud ing certificates of deposit) w i thout incu r r ing the need to comply w i th the 25 per cent requirement on resale of the paper. 454 bearer securities) under a general permission given by the U.K. authorities. Nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories except Rhode- sian residents may buy sterling securities on The Stock Ex- change against payment in foreign currency or in sterling from an External Account. Securities so purchased may be exported from the United Kingdom. Foreign currency securi- ties may be bought and sold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories on The Stock Exchange for settlement in foreign currency or, in certain circumstances, for settlement in ster- ling w i thout the benefit of the investment currency premium. Nonresidents must obtain permission to buy securities in the United Kingdom other than on The Stock Exchange, whether or not the securities are quoted on a stock exchange. Nonresi- dents other than Rhodesian residents may sell sterling securi- ties in the United Kingdom for sterling which may be held on External Account or, alternatively, the proceeds may be transferred abroad at official market rates. All transactions in securities by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia require the specific approval of the Bank of England. Except in respect of U.K. companies controlled by nonresi- dents of the Scheduled Territories (where Bank of England consent is required), warran ts issued by registrars, company secretaries, and paying agents in respect of capital payments on matured securities registered in the names of nonresidents other than Rhodesian residents may be dispatched freely to addresses outside the Scheduled Territories. These warrants may be paid by crediting sterling to an External Account. Authorized banks may freely accept foreign currencies from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories for deposit; such deposits may be re-lent to other nonresidents or switched in to sterling and made available to domestic bor- rowers who have permission. Ind iv idual ceilings are set on each bank's overall open position in foreign currencies and on the amount of spot assets which may be held against forward liabilities in foreign currencies. The Bank of England has au tho r i ty to call for differential Special Deposits, but this au tho r i ty has not so far been invoked. Gold Residents of the Un i ted Kingdom may freely buy, hold, or sell domestic and foreign gold coins. With this exception, residents of the United Kingdom other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not permitted to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, whether at home or abroad, unless they are specifically or generally permitted to do so. Permission is granted restrictively and is generally limited to established genuine domestic requirements for industrial and profes- sional purposes (including the manu fac tu re of gold medals, medallions, etc.). The M int from time to time strikes gold sovereigns. Al- though legal tender, these do not circulate in the United Kingdom. Gold coins which are legal tender have also been issued in Jersey and the Isle of Man. Except under license granted by the Treasury, it is an offense to melt down or break up any metal coin which is for the time being current in the United Kingdom or which, ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution having been current there, has at any time after May 16, 1969 ceased to be so. The import by any resident of the United Kingdom of gold bullion, gold coins, and gold medals, medallions, tablets or other pieces in pictorial relief or bearing inscriptions is on Open General Import License, from all sources except Rho- desia, but the holding of, or dealing w i th, bullion is subject to restrictions, as stated above. The export of gold bullion and all gold coins requires prior exchange control approval. Au- thor i ty has been given to authorized dealers in gold to issue licenses in respect of exports of gold bullion and coin pur- chased by any non-Scheduled Territory resident in the Lon- don gold market against payment in External Account sterling or foreign currency. A license is required from the Department of Trade and Indus try for the export of gold (and other) jewelry, etc., containing diamonds. The export of gold in manufactured form over 100 years old and valued at £4,000 and over also requires a license from the Department of Trade and Industry. Manufactures of gold other than medals, medallions, tab- lets or other pieces in pictorial relief or bearing inscriptions may be imported without quantitative restriction under Open General Import License from all sources except Rhodesia. There is a free gold market in London in which gold bars are freely traded among (1) authorized dealers in gold, (2) any nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories, and (3) residents of the Overseas Sterling Area who are sellers of new production. The U.K. authorities do not intervene in the market as either buyers or sellers. A commission of l/4 of 1 per cent is charged on all purchases; there is no commission on sales. Authorized banks may enter into forward transactions in gold without prior permission from the Bank of England. Banks may also finance purchases of gold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories by lending foreign exchange and accept gold as collateral for advances in foreign currencies or External Ac- count sterling to nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories. Changes during 1973 January 1. The United Kingdom became a member of the EEC. The Anglo-Irish Free Trade Agreement remained in force. January 1. Gibraltar was reinstated as a Scheduled Terri- tory under the Exchange Control Act, 1947. January 1. Additional goods could be imported from the Eastern Area under the Open General Import License. Most had been on open individual license. January 1. Licensing arrangements for cotton yarn and woven cotton textiles from restricted sources were modified. For goods exported on or after this date there would be no global quota, and cotton yarn and woven cotton textiles from all restricted sources would be imported under country quo- tas. Cotton textiles from Israel were placed on Open General Import License. (Certain imports from those Mediterranean countries which had agreements with the EEC would, no later than April 1, 1973, enter the United Kingdom free of quota restrictions.) January 1. An Open General License came into effect which eliminated quantitative restrictions on exports to other UNITED KINGDOM EEC countries of certain nonferrous materials. Another Open General License dealt w i th exports to all destinations except Rhodesia of certain iron and steel scrap; the existing arrange- ments for export controls on iron and steel scrap were ex- tended. January 1. The ECGD offered increased credit insurance cover (up to 40 per cent of the main contract) and widened financial facilities for exporters' subcontracts placed in mem- ber countries of the EEC. January 1. The remaining quan t i ta t ive restrictions on im- ports of industrial goods of EEC origin were removed, as were those on certain agricultural products originating in member countries of the enlarged EEC. (Most remaining restrictions on agricultural products f rom these sources were removed on February 1, 1973.) Quantitative restrictions on imports of certain ju te goods from Austria, Finland, Iceland, Portugal, Sweden, and Switzerland also were removed. January 1. The United Kingdom gave notice of termination w i th effect from February 1, 1973 of the U .K. Bacon Market Sharing Unders tand ing. January 1. The Bank of England's new rules on mergers and participations in the bank ing field came in to operation. January 11. Authorized depositories acting on behalf of residents of the United Kingdom in tend ing to purchase a specific property situated in the non-Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia for private use were permitted to acquire sufficient investment currency for this purpose before the in tend ing purchaser received exchange control approval, pro- vided that a formal application had been made or would be lodged within six mon ths. The special facilities for the pur- chase of property for private use by U .K. residents who were, or were to be, temporarily employed in Norway, were w i th- drawn. January 25. Re turn ing resident travelers, whatever the pe- riod of absence from the United Kingdom, were permitted to retain any unused travel facilities expressed in foreign cur- rency for a period of one mon th f rom the date of return to the United Kingdom. This brought the rules into line with those applied to the surrender of unused foreign currency obtained abroad by the use of a check guarantee card. Fur- thermore, banks were given delegated au tho r i ty enabling them to approve applications by U.K. residents who wish to open foreign currency accounts in the non-Scheduled Territo- ries other than Rhodesia for the receipt of travel funds for use during their stay abroad. January 26. The Channel Islands were brought within the scope of restrictions on exports of manuscripts, documents, and other archives over 70 years old. January 31. Authorized banks' au tho r i ty to approve cer- tain income payments due to nonresidents under trusts and settlements was extended to include payments of income un- der certain settlements inter vivos created before June 23, 1972. January 31. The trade agreements w i th Australia, Canada, India, New Zealand, Pakistan, and South Africa, including the remaining provisions concerning Sterling Area prefer- ences of the Ottawa Agreement of 1932, expired. January 31. Residents of the United Kingdom could upon application make, within their cash gift allowances of £1,000 455 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM and £300 a year, personal loans as well as outright gifts to nonresidents other than persons resident in Rhodesia. The au thor i ty to banks previously related only to outright gifts. January 31. A resident of the United Kingdom w i th depen- dents who were established residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia could make pay- ments from his own resources not exceeding £2,000 a year to support those dependents. Such payments, which could be gifts or loans, were outside the cash gift scheme and would not prejudice the normal cash gift allowances. Banks were given au tho r i ty to approve such payments. Their au thor i ty previously related only to remittances for the support of de- pendent relatives by persons of non-Scheduled Territory na- t iona l i ty who were, for exchange control purposes, resident in the United Kingdom. February 1. Exports of cast iron scrap were restricted. February 1. Following the adoption by the United King- dom of the EEC Common Agricultural Policy, quan t i ta t ive import restrictions were removed from a number of agricul- tu ral products inc lud ing m i lk, butter, apples, and sugar, irre- spective of origin. February 12. The exchange market was formally closed. It reopened on February 13 and sterling continued to float. February 19. Imports of certain handloom cotton textiles were placed on Open General Import License. March 2. The exchange market was formally closed. It reopened on March 19. March 6. The Treasury reintroduced a fac i l i ty terminated on March 22, 1972 under which it was prepared to provide exchange cover for U.S. dollar borrowing by certain public bodies (nationalized industries and local authorities). The prescribed m in imum ma tur i ty for such borrowing, previously ten years, now was f ive years. Public sector bodies would remain able to borrow in foreign currency w i thout cover subject to obtaining exchange control consent. March 12. The Bank of England announced that agreement had been reached with the banks and the finance houses on a scheme for the application of differential special deposits in respect of domestic and overseas liabilities. (No differential calls for special deposits were made in 1973.) March 19. New exchange rate margin arrangements be- tween certain European currencies came in to operation, based on a decision of the Council of Ministers of the EEC. The United Kingdom did not participate in these arrange- ments and sterling continued to float. March 21. A supplementary quota was established for im- ports of bananas from the Dollar Area. Further increases were announced in June, August, October, and November. March 25. The member exchanges of the Federation of Stock Exchanges in Great Britain and Ireland amalgamated in to a single organization called The Stock Exchange. March 30. Exports of potatoes were restricted. March 31. Cotton textiles from Ireland and Portugal were placed on Open General Import License, provided that the goods were not consigned to the United Kingdom from any source subject to U.K. import restrictions. March 31. For statistical purposes only, specific licenses were required for imports of specified woven polyester-cotton textiles from most sources subject to quan t i ta t ive restrictions 456 for cotton textiles. Licenses were freely issued, except for imports originating in the Eastern Area, Hong Kong, Japan, the Republic of Korea, or the Republic of China. (In July the Department of Trade and Indus t ry advised importers that no guarantee could be given that licenses would continue to be freely available.) April 1. The first of five successive reductions of 20 per cent of import duties on goods originating in EEC member countries took place. (The second reduction occurred on Jan- uary 1, 1974.) Import duties on industrial goods other than those subject to contractual margins of Commonwealth pref- erence were reduced to 80 per cent of the rate applied at January 1, 1972. April 1. The United Kingdom gave effect to its tariff obliga- tions under the Agreements between the European Commu- nities and Austria, Poland, Portugal, Sweden, and Switzerland. In addition, the Community arrangements for trade with Finland and Norway were put into effect until such time as Agreements w i th those two countries come into force. April 1. A value-added tax was introduced. The general rate was 10 per cent. The purchase tax was abolished. April 1. Additional cotton textiles were placed on Open General Import License. May 4. New regulations in respect of gold bullion were issued formally removing certain restrictions imposed when the London gold market reopened on April 1, 1968. They related to (1) authorized dealers in gold entering into forward transactions in gold; (2) authorized banks financing pur- chases of gold by nonresidents by lending foreign currency; and (3) authorized banks accepting gold as collateral against advances of foreign currency to nonresident customers. All of these acts previously required the prior permission of the Bank of England, which had already been freely given for some time. In addition, the directive was revoked which stip- ulated that authorized dealers could make delivery of gold bullion only against payment. May 21. Exports of iron and steel scrap to countries other than EEC member countries were restricted. Since January 1, such exports to all destinations other than Rhodesia had been unrestricted. May 22. The Bank of England announced two measures relaxing the restrictions on sterling lending to nonresidents. It would consider applications by U.K. companies and branches which were not vehicles for portfolio investment and which were controlled by either residents of member countries of the EEC or residents of the Overseas Sterling Area who were themselves controlled directly or indirectly by residents in other countries outside the Scheduled Territories, to raise in the United Kingdom all the finance required for their operations in the United Kingdom. May 25. Certain textiles and textile products originating in the Eastern Area were placed on Open General Import Li- cense. June 4. The Oils, Seeds and Fats Commodity Scheme came into operation; it also covered copra, and the separate facili- ties of the Copra Scheme ceased to be available. The new scheme expanded the Vegetable Oil Scheme arrangements to include dealings, inter alia, in soybean oil, sunflower-seed oil, ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution coconut oil, and marine and animal oils and fats. Participants were allowed to settle between themselves in foreign currency for oils, seeds, and fats originating in non-Scheduled Territo- ries. June 29. Crude petroleum, petroleum products, and natu- ral gas from Eastern Area countries other than Romania were placed under Open General Import License; previously, im- ports from those sources were not permitted. July 1. Restrictions on exports of potatoes and sugar were lifted. July 16. A new Open General Import License came into effect; it did not involve any additional liberalization. July 25. EEC quota restrictions were applied to exports to th ird countries of certain nonferrous scrap materials. August 16. Revised quota levels were announced for im- ports of woven cotton textiles from the Republic of China, Egypt, India, and Pakistan. September 3. A soybean oil futures contract expressed in U.S. dollars was introduced on the London Vegetable Oil Terminal Market. New exchange control rules came in to ef- fect applicable to dealings in such contracts on the London market or on terminal markets abroad. September 6. The Treasury announced that the Govern- ment had undertaken to continue to guarantee certain official sterling reserves of Sterling Area countries for a fur ther six-month period from September 24, the expiration date of the existing guarantee agreements. In broad terms, the guar- antee would be available to holders who maintained in their reserves the minimum sterling proportions set for the pur- poses of their Sterling Agreements or who held amounts obtained by applying those proportions to actual reserve holdings on September 24. An upper limit to the amounts covered by the guarantee was set by reference to the level of holdings on September 24. The guarantee was given at US$2.4213, the average of the exchange rates at noon on the three working days up to and including September 6. The balances eligible for a guarantee payment were official ster- ling reserves held on September 24, 1973 or the last working day of March 1974, whichever were the less, after deduction (as formerly) of an amount equivalent to any official holdings of U.K. equities or 10 per cent of total official external re- serves, whichever was the greater. September 17. A mild arabica coffee futures contract ex- pressed in U.S. dollars was introduced on the London Coffee Terminal Market. New exchange control rules came into ef- fect for dealings in such contracts on the London market or on terminal markets abroad. October 1. Coffee and coffee extract were placed on Open General Import License. October 1. Imports of cocoa beans and cocoa products originating in and consigned from nonmember countries of the International Cocoa Agreement became subject to indi- vidual licensing. October 1. Exports of iron and steel scrap to all destinations were brought under specific license and restricted by quota. October 12. Authorized banks which had approved applica- tions for redesignation from emigrants no longer had to refer to the Bank of England before making available to such emigrants, within their basic emigration allowance, the pro- UNITED KINGDOM ceeds from the sale of declared assets realized after redesigna- tion, provided that any increase in the value of the assets did not take the persons concerned over their basic allowance. October 12. Authorized banks having submitted applica- tions to the Bank of England on behalf of persons who had left the United Kingdom to take up established residence in countries outside the Scheduled Territories, could before their redesignation as nonresidents make available to such persons, without affecting their basic allowance, any income accruing from declared assets, provided that such income accrued to them after the date of their departure from the United King- dom or after the date on which their application for emigra- tion facilities was dispatched to the Bank of England, whichever was the later. October 19. Existing regulations and approval policies were amended to facilitate certain forms of borrowing abroad. (1) The m in imum maturity normally prescribed for foreign cur- rency borrowing for domestic use or to finance current pay- ments to nonresidents was reduced for the private sector from five years to two years; this reduction also applied to the undrawn portions of such loans authorized previously. Appli- cations for borrowing under the two-year rule would be con- sidered by the Bank of England in the light of its guidance to U.K. banks with respect to their lending in sterling; the guidelines in force involved restraint on lending for property development, for private consumption (other than house pur- chase), and for financial transactions. (2) The Treasury's ex- change risk guarantee on foreign currency borrowing by public sector entities, which had previously been limited to dollar loans, was extended to borrowings in other foreign currencies, but the five-year minimum maturity remained in force. (3) The qualification for covered borrowing by local authorities was modified. While the previous guidelines ex- tended only to those authorities which, at a qualifying date in 1972, had gross loan debt of £100 million or more, that qualifying date was now brought forward by one year. October 24. Exports of crude petroleum and petroleum products were placed under export control. Initially, exports were permitted under Open General License, but from No- vember 12 such exports to any destination were controlled by individual licenses. November 1. A large increase in the Cuban cigar quota was announced for 1974. November 9. The permission given to U.K. residents to make payments to residents of the Overseas Sterling Area due under contracts issued or entered into before June 23, 1972 was withdrawn. Any payments still outstanding which could not be completed under existing permissions were to be re- ferred to the Bank of England. November 23. Tariff changes under the second stage in the transition toward the EEC tariff structure were announced, to be effective January 1, 1974. They included the first move toward alignment on the common external tariff. Simulta- neously, tariffs on imports from the developed members of the Commonwealth and on processed foodstuffs from other developed countries would be raised. December 10. Public sector bodies borrowing foreign cur- rency under the Treasury's exchange risk facility were permit- ted to retain a portion of the difference between the applicable 457 ©International Monetary Fund. Administration of Control The Treasury Department deals w i th license applications invo lv ing financial or commercial transactions directly or in- directly w i th Cuba, Nor th Korea, Rhodesia, and Nor th Viet-Nam, or their nationals, as specified under the Foreign Assets Control Regulations, the Cuban Assets Control Regu- lations, and the Rhodesian Sanctions Regulations. It also deals w i th license applications invo lv ing the blocked accounts in the United States of the People's Republic of China under the Foreign Assets Control Regulations. The Foreign Direct Investment Program (FDIP)l is administered by the Office of Foreign Direct Investments (OFDI) in the Department of Commerce. The Federal Reserve Board administers the Vol- un ta ry Foreign Credit Restraint Program for banks and other financial ins t i tu t ions (VFCRP). * The Bureau of Customs of the Treasury Department administers import quotas; such quotas, however, are generally established and allocated by other agencies. Import quotas on specified dairy products are administered by the Department of Agriculture through the issuance of import licenses. The import quotas on sugar are allotted among eligible exporting countries in accordance with a statutory formula administered by the Department of Agriculture and are prorated among eligible importers under regulations administered by that Department. Allocations and licenses for imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products are issued by the Department of the Interior. For items subject to export control other than crude petroleum and petroleum products the Department of Commerce is, in general, the responsible au thor i ty. The law provides that the fo l low ing cannot be designated as less developed countries: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Federal Republic of Germany, Hong Kong, I ta ly, Japan, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Monaco, Netherlands, New Zealand, No rway, South Africa, San Marino, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, and United Kingdom. The VFCRP has resulted in the establishment of "guide- lines" for U.S. banks, U.S. agencies and branches of foreign banks, and U.S. nonbank financial institutions in respect of their foreign assets. Federal Reserve member banks must meet marginal re- serve requirements of 8 per cent on large-denomination time deposits (US$100,000 and above) and related instruments, including Euro-dollars; certain large nonmember banks and agencies and branches of foreign banks comply voluntarily, at the request of the Federal Reserve Board. The mandatory FDIP has placed restraints on direct in- vestment by setting annual limits on net capital outflow plus reinvested earnings, and limiting the amount of certain types of short-term financial assets held abroad by direct inves- tors.8 A direct investor is defined as a person within the United States who directly or indirectly controls, owns, or acquires 10 per cent or more of the voting power or right to receive income of a foreign national. Three regional ceilings are enforced on the making of direct investment during any year by direct investors which do not elect the minimum world-wide allowable; 9 one for less developed countries;10 one for other countries judged to be dependent on a substan- tial continuing inf low of capital that cannot be adequately met from non-U.S. sources;11 and one for all other coun- tries. 12 However, direct investors are virtually free to finance new or additional direct investments with long-term funds and rolled-over short-term funds borrowed in any foreign country except Canada. Canada is exempt from all balance of payments restraints, except for the application of the IET to some transactions. Gold Residents may import, purchase, hold, and sell for numis- matic purposes domestic and foreign gold coins minted be- fore 1960. Gold coins minted after 1959 may be held if they have been determined to be of recognized special value to collectors. Licenses are required to import any gold coins minted after 1959, and these are not normally issued. The import of counterfeit coins and restrikes is prohibited. Gold bullion may not be held in the United States except by monetary authorities and licensed industrial, professional, and artistic users. The purchase or holding of gold abroad by U.S. citizens and firms is also prohibited except under license 8 Where the regulations require a company to repatriate more income than is allowed by host coun try laws or by business circumstance, such as joint ownership situations, specific relief may be granted by the OFDI. 9 A single m in imum allowable of US$6 million world-wide was permitted un t il November 27, 1973, when it was increased to US$10 million. 10 As defined for the purposes of the IET (see footnote 7). They are referred to as Schedule B countries. 12 Referred to as Schedule C countries. These are ma in ly continental Eastern and Western European countries and South Africa. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution for industrial, professional, or artistic use. Licensing author- ity is vested in the Secretary of the Treasury. Producers of gold may sell their output at free market prices either to licensed industrial users or abroad (except to monetary au- thorities). Gold may be freely imported by licensed users within the limitations of their authorized inventory holding. A license is required for the export of gold except gold recov- ered from natural deposits in the United States which may be exported without license. Commercial imports of gold jewelry are free of quantitative restriction. Imports and exports of gold coins and gold bul- lion are free of customs du ty and other fiscal charges. Domes- tic sales of jewelry, including gold jewelry, are subject to excise du ty at the rate of 15 per cent, while domestic sales of gold in any other form, including rare gold coins, are free of fiscal charges. The use of the international reserve assets of the United States has been limited to settlement of outstanding obliga- tions and, in cooperation with the International Monetary Fund, to other situations that might arise in which such use could contribute to international monetary stability and the interests of the United States. Changes during 1973 January 1. The suspension of quota restrictions on meat imports was extended to the end of 1973. January 1. All import limits on No. 2 heating oil were removed for the period to April 30, 1973. The quota for imports of crude and unfinished oil and finished products for the Eastern United States was increased to 2.7 million barrels a day for 1973. January 2. The following changes in the FDIP were an- nounced: (1) credits extended by direct investors to their affiliated foreign nationals with respect to the export sale or lease of qualifying U.S. goods and services on normal com- mercial terms would be exempted under the FDIP regula- tions; (2) the alternative minimum positive direct investment allowables would be consolidated into a single world-wide minimum allowable of US$6 million a year; and (3) as in the 1971 and 1972 program years, direct investors would be al- lowed to count certain transactions effected in the first two months of 1974 for purposes of computing their 1973 pro- gram compliance in respect of the repatriation of foreign claims. (Since in accordance with (1) the extension of qualify- ing export credits would be exempt from charge under the FDIP after December 31, 1972, repayments of such credits to the direct investor after that date would not be counted as negative transfers of capital for 1973 or subsequent compli- ance years.) The exemption of qualifying export credits would eliminate any substantial distinction between the FDIP and the other U.S. capital controls in the treatment of extension of export financing. January 8. Amendments published on December 9, 1972 to the Antidumping Regulations came into effect. On the same date, the Treasury imposed a countervailing duty on imports from a manufacturer enjoying subsidies in his home country. UNITED STATES January 10-11. Direct export subsidies for lard, broilers, and wheat flour were terminated. As a result, direct subsidies on the export of farm products were being paid only on peanuts, the domestic production of which also received sub- sidies. February 12. The United States informed the International Monetary Fund that the President was requesting that the Congress authorize a proposal to the Fund that there be a 10 per cent reduction in the par value of the dollar from SDR 0.921053 to SDR 0.828948 (equivalent to US$42.222222 a f ine ounce of gold). The anticipated change in the par value of the dollar was reflected in international markets at once (see also October 18, below). February 12. It was announced that the IET and the FDIP would be terminated at the latest by December 31, 1974 and that the Federal Reserve Board would consider comparable steps for the VFCRP. This intention was reaffirmed on March 16, 1973 when the U.S. authorities emphasized that the phasing out of the controls on long-term capital outflows by the end of 1974 was intended to coincide with a strong improvement in the U.S. balance of payments position and that any steps taken during the interim period toward their elimination would take due account of exchange market con- ditions and balance of payments trends. February 12. It was announced that the President would send shortly to the Congress proposals for comprehensive trade legislation. March 15. The import price break level for cheese under quota was raised from 47 cents a pound f.o.b. to 69 cents a pound f.o.b. The President asked the Tariff Commission to investigate the need for a temporary increase in cheese import quotas and to report its findings by April 7. March 25. The President issued a proclamation permitting the Oil Policy Committee to grant oil company requests for import licenses without regard to the quota of 250,000 barrels a day. April 10. The President signed into law a 15-month exten- sion of the IET, up to June 30,1974. Although technically the tax had expired on April 1, most brokers agreed to continue collecting it in anticipation of congressional action. The ex- tension was retroactive to April 1. The IET was amended as follows: (1) securities newly is- sued by foreigners to finance foreign direct investment in the United States were exempted, provided that the foreign in- vestment was for a minimum period of ten years and that at least 50 per cent of the total cost was financed from abroad; (2) certain securities sold to foreigners which were subject to IET when sold to U.S. residents were exempted from U.S. estate taxes; and (3) the exemption for less developed countries was limited to corporations that have significant operations within such countries, thereby excluding shipping companies registered in developing countries but owned by nonresidents and obtaining a substantial portion of their in- come from operations outside such countries. April 10. The President transmitted to Congress the Trade Reform Act of 1973 as well as a companion bill amending the Federal Trade Commission Act and the Webb-Pomerene Act. Proposals for a system of generalized tariff preferences in favor of developing countries were included. 461 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES April 23. It was announced that Federal Reserve System Regulations D, M, and Q were being amended as follows: (1) The reserve requirements on member banks' Euro-dollar bor- rowings and foreign branch loans to U.S. residents were w i th immediate effect reduced from 20 per cent to 8 per cent. 13 (2) The reserve-free bases were being phased out over a period of approximately eight months. (3) The limitations on the rates of interest which member banks may pay on a single ma tu r i ty deposit of US$100,000 or more were suspended, regardless of ma tur i ty (previously, the ceilings were suspended only for maturities of 30-89 days; interest payments on deposits w i th a m a tu r i ty of less than 30 days, other than official fund s, remained prohibited). The purpose was to align the treatment of Euro-dollar borrowings w i th that accorded large certifi- cates of deposit and other bank-related commercial paper, which were not subject to an 8 per cent marginal reserve requirement. May 16. The Federal Reserve Board asked key nonmember banks for their cooperation in conforming to the new regula- tions issued the same day. Specifically, such banks were re- quested to hold reserve deposits against increases in large certificates of deposit. May 24. The OFDI announced substantially improved benefits for direct investors selling their equ i ty securities abroad for cash or exchanging them for the stock or assets of a foreign company held by a large number of foreign nation- als. Previously, only the proceeds of long-term foreign bor- rowing (mainly issues of bonds and convertible bonds, but not issues of shares) and under certain circumstances ex- changes of equity shares could be used as an offset to positive direct investment. Under the new specific authorization pol- icy, a direct investor could be specifically authorized to make positive direct investment in addition to its "Subpart E" al- lowables, in recognition of an equity transaction in which foreign nationals (other than Canadians) obtained the direct investor's securities for investment. For those of its shares 13 There was an exemption from the reserve requirement where a corporate headquarters in the United States borrowed Euro-dollars for use outside the Un i ted States in order to comply w i th OFDI regulations. The Federal Reserve Board term ina ted t h is exemption on February 11, 1974. 462 sold that qualified for this relief, the direct investor would normally be granted a specific authorization in an amount up to 90 per cent of the net proceeds of the sale, and for those of its shares exchanged that qualified, the direct investor would normally be granted a specific authorization in an amount up to 90 per cent of the value of the shares based on their market value on the date they were transferred to the foreign nationals. There was also a relaxation of various rules covering the exchange by a direct investor of its equity shares for the stock or assets of a foreign en t i ty held by a small number of foreign nationals; among other things, for such an exchange transac- tion that qualified for relief, the direct investor would nor- mally be granted a specific authorization for an amount equal to 100 per cent of the value of its shares exchanged, but the direct investor would be charged w i th a transfer of capital in any year in which the original foreign recipients disposed of any of the shares. Previously, the overseas issuance of equity securities had been permitted as an offset only on a limited basis, because of the d i f f i cu l ty of monitoring the resale of any such securities to U.S. residents. The OFDI announced that although compliance with the FDIP was measured on the basis of the calendar year, a direct investor might deduct from positive direct in- vestment made dur ing 1973 an amount equal to any available proceeds of long-term foreign borrowing or of borrowing from the direct investor's overseas finance subsidiary made on or before February 28, 1974, that were "allocated" to such positive direct investment on or before that date (provided that the proceeds, as of February 28, 1974, were not held, directly or indirectly, in any form of foreign property). This decision was in line with the practice which started late in 1971 of allowing direct investors two additional mon ths for compliance on a calendar year basis. July 19. The Federal Reserve Board amended the VFCRP to request U.S. agencies and branches of foreign banks to observe specific lending ceilings under the VFCRP, stating that the lack of a specific guideline had produced some un- evenness in observance of the VFCRP. The ceiling of a U.S. agency or branch of a foreign bank that held US$ 1 million in foreign assets would be equal to its holdings of foreign assets on June 30, 1973 of types subject to restraint under the guidelines less any decrease (or plus any increase) in its liabili- ties to foreigners subsequent to June 30, 1973. Subsequent to that date any increase in such assets should be at least matched by an increase in foreign liabilities; correspondingly, any increase in such liabilities should be accompanied by at least an equal reduction in such assets. The guidelines, as amended, thus permitted the ins t i tu t ions concerned to in- crease their claims on non-U.S. residents to the extent that they increased the amount of funds they borrowed from their own parent banks and from other non-U.S. sources; this did not change the degree of restraint affec t ing these ins t i tu t ions. Previously, the guidelines had asked merely that the ins t i tu- UNITED STATES tions concerned act in conformity w i th the spirit of the VFCRP guidelines and to consult w i th the Federal Reserve Bank in the ir district; since December 1, 1971 they had also been asked to submit mon th ly reports on their foreign asset positions. It was announced that the United States was mak ing new ad jus tmen ts in the various programs that re- strained capital outflows: (1) The IET would be reduced from the existing rate of approximately 0.75 per cent to the equivalent of 0.25 per cent; the new rate schedule would be applicable to trades and acquisitions of foreign stocks or obligations made after De- cember 31, 1973. 464 (2) The following liberalization in the FDIP would be effec- tive for 1974: (a) The m in imum world-wide allowable avail- able to smaller direct investors would be raised from US$10 m i l l ion to US$20 m i l l ion, (b) The earnings allowable would be increased from 60 per cent to 100 per cent of foreign a f f i l ia te earnings for either 1973 or 1974, at the direct inves- tor's election. This would permit compliance with the regula- tions w i thout the necessity of foreign earnings remittance, (c) A new "debt repayment allowable" would be added to the regulations, which would authorize a direct investor to repay 20 per cent of its total outstanding foreign borrowing allo- cated to positive direct investment as of the end of the 1973 compliance year. This repayment allowable would be in addi- tion to the m in imum, historical, and earnings allowables. The m in imum, historical, and earnings allowables would not, however, be available for debt repayment and direct investors would not be permitted to reduce outstanding foreign debt below 80 per cent of the amount allocated effective as of year-end 1973. The regulations would operate to permit re- payment of specific outstanding debt obligations, but direct investors would be required to refinance aggregate repay- ments in excess of the 20 per cent repayment allowable. Relief for borrowing hardship situations would continue to be avail- able through specific authorization. (3) The fo l low ing amendments to the VFCRP guidelines would be effective January 1, 1974: (a) The ceiling for each commercial bank was increased to US$10 million or to an amount of 4 per cent above the ceiling in effect immediately prior to the present revision, whichever was higher, (b) The request that banks refrain from making nonexpert loans with maturities of over one year to residents of the developed countries of continental Western Europe was eliminated, (c) U.S. agencies and branches of foreign banks would have a ceiling of at least US$10 million for making foreign loans and other investments of types restrained under the Program, whereas the existing m in imum ceiling was US$1 million, (d) Agencies and branches would be able to recalculate the "base net foreign position," which determined the relationship be- tween their foreign lending and foreign borrowing, by using 96 per cent of their foreign liabilities for June 30,1973. (e) The restraint against term loans to the developed countries of continental Western Europe would be dropped for agencies and branches, as it was being dropped for banks, (f) The ceiling of each nonbank financial institution would be in- creased to an amount 5 per cent above that in effect at the end of 1972 or to US$2 million, whichever was higher, (g) The request that nonbank financial ins t i tu t ions refrain from in- creasing their loans and investments in the developed countries of continental Western Europe beyond the amount held at the end of 1968 was eliminated.
