Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA Exchange System No par value for the currency of Upper Volta has been established w i th the Fund. The un it of currency is the CFA Franc, l which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transactions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02, free of commission. Exchange transactions relating to foreign countries, i.e., countries other than France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area, take place in a dual exchange market at rates based on the fixed rate for the French f ranc and the Paris exchange rate for the foreign currency concerned in either the official exchange market or the financial f ranc mar- ket. Settlements eligible for the official exchange market are payments and receipts in respect of imports, exports, and most other current transactions, as well as all current pay- ments by or in favor of domestic and foreign public authori- ties and public bodies. All other settlements with foreign countries, as well as transactions in banknotes of foreign countries and banknotes issued by the BCEAO, take place through the financial franc market at freely fluctuating rates. The principal current payments and receipts channeled through the financial franc market are those relating to travel expenses, capital earnings, workers' remittances, fam i ly re- mittances, and study abroad. Exchange rates for certain Eu- ropean currencies in the official market are based on par values and central rates; the effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar in this market is not confined w i th in any announced margins. W i th the exception of those relating to gold, Upper Vol- ta's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France (as defined above) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked w i th the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account (Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Senegal, and Togo). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Upper Volta itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only w i th for- eign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Bureau in the Directorate of the Treasury and of Public Ac- counts in the Ministry of Finance and Commerce, which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or of- fering for sale of foreign securities in Upper Volta, inward direct investment and all outward investment, and the solicit- ing of funds in Upper Volta for placement in foreign 1 The CFA f ranc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de TOuest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Dahomey, Ivo ry Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Vo l ta. countries. The approval au tho r i ty in respect of exchange con- trol, except for imports and exports of gold and business travel allocations in excess of CFAF 400,000 has been dele- gated to the BCEAO and, within limits specified in the ex- change control regulations, to authorized intermediaries. The BCEAO also is authorized to collect, either direct or through the intermediary of banks, financial institutions, the Postal Administration, and notaries public, any information neces- sary to compile the balance of payments statistics. All ex- change transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks, the Postal Administra- tion, or the BCEAO. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Commerce at the Ministry of Finance and Commerce. Import attestations for liberalized commodi- ties are made out by the importer himself and are visaed by the customs. Prescription of Currency Upper Volta is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Opera- tions Account w i th the French Treasury; settlements with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs or French francs. Certain settlements with Ghana are made through special accounts. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign or Financial Accounts in Francs. All settlements w i th Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO banknotes may be credited to Financial Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Ouagadougou by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that ma in ta ins an Operations Account with the French Treasury is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports originating in or shipped from Portugal, Rhode- sia, and South Africa are prohibited. Imports from countries in the French Franc Area may in principle be made freely, although exceptionally special regulations may be issued. Im- ports from EEC countries, with minor exceptions, are liberal- ized and require only an import attestation. Most imports from other countries are subject to licensing. Imports from non-EEC countries outside the French Franc Area are admit- ted in accordance w i th an annual import program, deter- mined each year by the Directorate of Commerce. Under this program, global quotas are established up to which import 465 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA licenses are issued for specified commodities. Impo r ts f rom Ghana are subject to special regulations. All import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled w i th an authorized bank when their value ex- ceeds CFAF 500,000. The import licenses or import attesta- tions entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documen- tary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Mo- naco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to exchange control approval, which for many invisibles has been delegated to the authorized banks. All payments to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Authorized banks and the Postal Adm in is tra t ion have been empowered to make transfers to foreign countries freely, on behalf of residents, up to CFAF 50,000 a t rans fe r. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted free ly when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted. Residents trave l ing for tourism to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equiva- lent to CFAF 175,000 a person a t r ip (CFAF 87,500 for children under ten) for any number of trips a year; any foreign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 remaining a f ter return to Upper Volta must be surrendered. The basic allocation for travel abroad for business purposes is the equ iva lent of CFAF 20,000 a day, w i th a max imum of CFAF 400,000 a trip. Resident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a max imum of CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by any in s t i tu te of issue that ma in ta ins an Operations Account w i th the French Treasury. Resident travelers to other countries of the French Franc Area may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes, but if their destination is not to a member coun t ry of the West African Monetary Union, they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may freely take out, in addition to any means of payment established in the ir name abroad, foreign banknotes up to the equivalent of CFAF 175,000 or, subject to the submission of appropriation (if it was either declared upon en t ry or acquired by drawing on a Financial Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency or by exchange of foreign travelers checks, etc.), any larger amoun t. They may also take out any foreign means of payment other than banknotes acquired in Upper Volta by debit to a Finan- cial Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency, again subject to submission of documentation. Finally, they may take out freely up to CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO bank- notes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by Opera- tions Account countries. 466 Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to countries of the French Franc Area may be made freely but for statistical purposes certain agricultural products require a license f rom the Directorate of Commerce. Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohib- ited. Exports to all other countries are permitted freely but some also require a license. Certain commodities can be ex- ported in special circumstances only. Exports to Ghana are subject to special regulations. Export proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Operations Account coun t ry must be surrendered w i th in two mon ths of the date on wh ich the payment falls due (the due date stipu- lated in the commercial contract, which must not, in princi- ple, be later than 180 days a f ter arrival of the goods at their destination). All export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled w i th an authorized bank when the ir va lue exceeds CFAF 500,000, and the exporter must sign a foreign exchange comm i tment and submit a customs cer t if ica t ion. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles w i th France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amoun ts due f rom residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries f rom foreign assets must be collected and surrendered w i th in two mon ths of the due date. Such proceeds and earnings must not be received in or f rom Portugal, Rhodesia, or South Africa. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of bankno tes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue ma in ta in ing an Operations Ac- count w i th the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign bankno tes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. Resident travelers must w i th in eight days a f ter re tu rn surrender to an authorized bank any foreign means of payment in excess of CFAF 5,000 that they bring in. Capital All capital movements between Upper Volta and Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Capital move- men ts between Upper Volta and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital trans- fers to all o ther countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted f ree ly. Special controls (additional to any exchange control re- qu i remen ts that may be applicable) are ma in ta ined over bor- row ing abroad, over inwa rd direct inves tment and all ou twa rd inves tmen t, and over the issuing, advertising, or o f fe r ing for sale of foreign securities in Upper Volta; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to pay- men ts or receipts. W i th the exception of those over foreign securities in Upper Volta, the control measures do not apply to relations w i th France (as defined above), Monaco, the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution other member countries of the West African Monetary Un- ion, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special con- trols do apply also to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All investments abroad by residents of Upper Volta require prior authorization by the Minister of F inance .2 Foreign direct investments in Upper Volta 3 must be declared to the Minister of Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two mon ths from receipt of the declaration du r ing which he may request the postponement of the projects sub- mitted to him. The total or partial liquidation of either type of investment also is subject to prior declaration to the Minis- ter. Both the mak ing and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Upper Volta investments abroad or foreign investments in Upper Volta, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and the BCEAO w i th in 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments im- plying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign secu- rities in Upper Volta requires prior authorization by the Min- ister of Finance. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection w i th (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Upper Volta Government and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issue, offering for sale, or sale in Upper Volta has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constitut- ing a direct investment, which are subject to prior declara- tion, as indicated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial f irms to finance transactions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports in to or exports from Upper Volta, or by approved international trad ing houses to finance international mer- chanting transactions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, inc lud ing the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 100 million for any one borrower, provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate and that the proceeds are immediately surrendered by the sale of foreign currency on the exchange market or debited to a Foreign Account in Francs. The repayment of loans not cons t i tu t ing a direct investment requires the special authorization of the Minister 2 Inc lud ing those made th rough the intermediary of foreign companies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Upper Volta and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Upper Volta. 3 In c lud ing those made by companies in Upper Volta th at are directly or ind irec t ly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Upper Volta of foreign companies. UPPER VOLTA if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Lending abroad is subject on ly to exchange control autho- rization by the BCEAO, acting on behalf of the Minister of Finance. The lending of CFA francs to nonresidents for peri- ods of up to two years, however, is freely permitted. Ordinance No. 70-074/PRES/PL-TP of December 31, 1970, the Investment Code, provides preferential treatment for foreign investment in Upper Volta. Two preferential cate- gories (A and B) are established, in accordance w i th which preferential treatment w i th respect to stable rates of taxes, duties, and other fiscal charges may be accorded to specified enterprises for periods of up to 25 years. The benefits under Category B are far more liberal than those under Category A; they are negotiable between the investor and the Govern- men t, and the enterprise accorded such benefits must be of exceptional importance to the development of the coun try. Law No. 25 /61 / AN set up an assistance fund for new indus- tries. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Upper Volta. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other coun t ry require prior authorization by the External Finance Bureau in the Ministry of Finance and Commerce. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufac tured articles containing a minor qu an t i ty of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold objects up to a combined weight of 500 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declara- tion. Changes during 1973 January 29. Not for Redistribution Exchange Rate System Imports and Import Payments URUGUAY On October 7, 1960 a par value for the Uruguayan Peso was established by Uruguay w i th the Fund; however, ex- change transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. There is a dual exchange market, consisting of a commercial market and a financial market. Payments and receipts in respect of imports, exports, fre igh t, and insurance on imports and exports, and most public sector exchange operations are settled in the commer- cial marke t, where the exchange rates are fixed (although adjusted from time to time), while all other permitted ex- change transactions take place in the financial market, in which the exchange rates fluctuate. On December 31, 1973 the buy ing and selling rates in the commercial market were Ur$928 and Ur$937 per US$1, respectively, and those in the financial market were Ur$925 and Ur$930 per US$1, respec- tively. The Central Bank supplies foreign exchange to the com- mercial banks for imports, and the proceeds from exports (valued at the officially assessed price or aforo where applica- ble) must be surrendered to the monetary authorities. l Com- mercial banks operate on their own account in the financial market, but are not permitted to exceed their overbought positions (in terms of U.S. dollars) of February 29, 1972 and must surrender any excess exchange holdings to the Central Bank. The application of exchange taxes (detracciones or reten- ciones) to the proceeds from certain traditional exports and the payment of subsidies through tax credit certificates (rein- tegros) on proceeds from certain nontraditional exports give rise to various effective buying rates that d iffer from the commercial market buying rate. Administration of Control Exchange transactions are carried out through authorized banks, bank ing houses, and the monetary authorities. The latter collect import surcharges and export taxes, hold the special deposits required for certain imports, and receive ex- port and import registrations. Prescription of Currency Payments between Uruguay and the countries w i th which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agreements may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, w i th in the framework of the LAFTA mu l t i la t- eral clearing system; these countries are Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru, and Venezuela.2 Settlements w i th other countries are made in U.S. dollars or other con- vertible currencies. 1 On March 1, 1967, a new Central Bank was established but some operations are still being carried out on its behalf by the Bank of the Republic. The term "monetary authorities" as used here refers to both banks taken together. 2 A reciprocal credit agreement w i th Brazil came i n to effect on June 1, 1974. All imports are subject to registration prior to the placing of orders abroad. The registrations are generally valid for 180 days, within which period goods must be cleared through customs. Certain imports are temporarily prohibited. Most imports are subject to an import surcharge (recargo), a special deposit (consignation), and /or prescribed terms of payment. Goods are classified in to nine categories; goods in one cate- gory bear no surcharge; goods in the other categories are subject to surcharges of 10, 30, 40, 60, 75, 90, 150, or 225 per cent, payable at the time of registration. Imports from LAFTA countries receive a full or partial exemption from the surcharges. Many imports are subject to special deposits in Uruguayan pesos of a certain percentage of the c.i.f. value; the deposit must be lodged w i th the monetary authorities at the time of registration and is refundable upon application after six months. For the second half of 1973, imports by each importer in each surcharge category up to 160 per cent of the U.S. dollar value of his import declarations (denuncias de importation) exempt from special deposits during the second half of 1971 were exempt from special deposits; in addition, special depos- its were waived for imports up to 69 per cent of individual imports in 1970 of certain special categories of imports. For imports in excess of the margin exempt from special deposits, the required deposit rate varied depending on the surcharge category applicable as of July 21, 1971. For imports free of surcharge, or imports w i th surcharges as of that date of up to 30 per cent, the special deposit was 450 per cent (315 per cent for imports from LAFTA countries; for imports with surcharges of more than 30 per cent and up to 90 per cent the rate was 900 per cent (630 per cent for imports from LAFTA countries); and for imports with surcharges above 90 per cent, the rate was 1,200 per cent (840 per cent for imports from LAFTA countries). The regime of special deposits is not applicable to goods designated as capital goods by Decree No. 482/971 of Au- gust 3, 1971. Imports by the public sector that have been approved by the Central Bank and imports financed with external loans at maturities specified below are among those exempt from special deposits. Most imports are subject, in addition to any customs du ty required, to an additional import du ty of 18 per cent of the c.i.f. value, payable upon customs clearance. The tax is not applied to imports originating in GATT or LAFTA countries, nor to imports of specified agencies and public institutions; in addition, an exemption of 100 per cent, 85 per cent, or 40 per cent of the applicable tax is provided for specified imports. All imports valued at over US$1.82 are subject to consular charges of Vie of 1 per cent of the peso amount resulting from the conversion of the f.o.b. value at a rate of Ur$55 per US$1; the amount of the charges is payable in foreign exchange at a rate of U r$l = US$2.10 (at a rate of U r$l = US$1 for private imports of petroleum and petro- leum products, alcohol, and tetraethyl lead, at a rate of Ur$l = US$0.50 for imports of the same commodities by the 469 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY Administration National de Combustibles, Alcohol y Portland (ANCAP) —the state oil and alcohol monopoly, and at a rate of U r$l = US$1.05 for certain other imports by ANCAP). 3 Special deposits and surcharges in most cases are calcu- lated either on assumed c.i.f. prices (aforos) established for many commodities or on the actual c.i.f. value, whichever is higher. In a few cases, the calculation is based on an officially assessed price, which usually is expressed in U.S. dollars per kilogram. Sales of foreign exchange for most private sector imports are prohibited unless m in imum f inanc ing requirements are fu lf i l led. At the end of 1973, foreign exchange was made available by the banking system for imports of goods other than capital goods on ly when payable 180 days or more a f ter the date of shipment; for capital goods valued at US$10,000 or less, c.i.f., the m in imum terms were two years, and for those in excess of US$10,000 f ive years, in either case applica- ble to 80 per cent of the c.i.f. value. For imports for wh ich f inanc ing under these conditions could not be obtained, the Central Bank could authorize the sale of exchange on a case-by-case basis. The sale of exchange was made at the earliest 15 days prior to the m a tu r i ty date. Provided that the importer had deposited the peso equivalent of the transaction w i th in 30 days after the date of approval of the application for customs clearance, the sale was made at the rate of ex- change in effect on the date of the deposit; for importers not mak ing the deposit w i th in the 30-day period, however, the sale of exchange was made at the rate in effect on the date of payment. In 1971 special arrangements were applied to certain other import payments and an exchange rate guarantee was given subject to the lodging of a peso deposit. Certain arrears have arisen in the implementation of these and subsequent ar- rangements. Payments for Invisibles Freight and insurance on imports and exports are settled in the commercial market. All other payments for invisibles are settled at the financial rate. There are basic exchange allowances for certain current invisibles. Thus, for tourism and other travel, the allocations (including fares) are as fol- lows: for travel to Argentina, $a 1,000 a person a trip; to Brazil, Cr$600 a person a trip; to Chile and Paraguay, either $a 1,750 or Cr$ 1,200 a person a trip; to other South American countries, US$25 a person a day, subject to a max imum of US$500 a person a trip; and to all other countries, US$30 a day, subject to a maximum of US$900 a person a trip. Tickets for foreign travel are subject to a stamp tax of Ur$100. Exchange for fam i ly remittances is restricted to close rela- tives w i th permanent residence abroad and is subject to a maximum of US$150 a mon th for each recipient and remittor, no recipient or remittor being permitted to receive or effect a remittance more than once a mon th. The sale of foreign exchange for students on scholarships abroad is limited to an amount per mon th no greater than the difference between 3 These charges are equivalent to 11.55 per cent, 5.50 per cen t, 2.75 per cen t, and 5.775 per cent, respectively. 470 US$500 and the amount of the mon th ly scholarship. For certain other invisibles, exchange is granted for the fu ll amoun ts due. Payments for other specified types of invisibles may, in principle, be made freely th rough the financial mar- ket, subject to the regulations issued by the Central Bank. However, at the end of 1973 imp lemen t ing regulations gov- erning sales of exchange for some of these had not yet been issued. For such transactions (remittances relating to the re- patriation of direct inves tmen ts and head office expenses), the f inanc ial market remained effectively closed. Remittances of p ro f i ts and dividends were limited to 10 per cent per annum of the invested capital expressed in the currency of origin. There are no l im i ta t ions on the export of foreign or domes- tic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds The proceeds of the principal exports are subject to taxes (detracciones or retenciones), which are w i thhe ld by the mon- etary au thor i t ies on the basis of either the f.o.b. value or the aforo value of the commodity concerned. The tax is stipulated in pesos per un it of export commod i ty, but it may not be more than 50 per cent or less than 0.01 per cent of the peso proceeds of the export, except that for exports of meat the stipulated max imum is 25 per cent while for wool the permitted limits are 2 per cent and 35 per cent of the f.o.b. value. The exchange proceeds of trad i t ional exports subject to taxes must be sur- rendered in f u ll to the mone tary au thor i t ies not later than 30 days a f ter shipment has been authorized (75 per cent for certain leather products); the proceeds from exports of non- trad i t ional products must be surrendered w i th in 60 days if the sale is on a cash basis (75 days for certain leather goods) or w i th in 210 days if the sale is made on credit. For certain exports, inc lud ing wool and hides, m in imum f.o.b. values (m in imum surrender prices or aforos) expressed in U.S. dol- lars per kilogram have been established for various grades and types. Subsidies in the form of tax credit certificates (reintegros) of up to 40 per cent of the f.o.b. value are granted on certain non t rad i t ional exports. Exports of certain types of beef and dairy cows, wool ewes, specified minerals ( inc lud ing iron, copper, zinc, a lum inum, and nickel), and protein concentrates used for animal feed are prohibited. As at the end of 1973 exports of certain animal fa ts, all types of sheepskin, an imal bristle, greasy wool, and skirted greasy wool were also temporarily prohibited. Ex- ports of wheat, sorghum, corn, and sunf lower seeds are pro- hibited f rom time to time. Proceeds from Invisibles All proceeds f rom invisibles may be held, utilized, or sold to the bank ing system. Department stores, hotels, and other tourist establishments are authorized to accept foreign cur- rencies at the rate preva i l ing in the f inanc ial marke t; the proceeds must be sold th rough the bank ing system. There are no l im i ta t ions on the import of foreign or domestic bank- notes. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Capital4 Inward capital transfers by either residents or nonresidents may be made freely through the bank ing system, and the exchange may be sold in the financial market anonymous ly; if the seller of foreign exchange identifies himself, however, he is entitled to repurchase in the financial market on any f u t u re date the same amount of foreign exchange. Exchange rate guarantees are in effect available on certain inward capital transfers, whether made by residents or nonresidents; these consist of swaps w i th the Central Bank. Outward capital transfers are subject to prior authorization; those of resi- dent-owned capital are restricted. All obligations in excess of US$1,000 that are contracted abroad by the private sector must be declared w i th in 30 days of the date of the contract. In addition, all foreign currency loans extended to the private sector by either foreign sources or domestic banks must be registered w i th the Central Bank w i th in 30 days of the signing of the contract in order to be eligible for servicing through the commercial market. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Uruguay or abroad, provided that the transactions are registered. Gold may be exported only if accompanied by evidence of prior importation. Any private purchases abroad for nonindustrial use, however, must be financed f rom the buyer's own exchange holdings. Imports and exports of gold for industrial use are settled through the commercial marke t. Changes during 1973 January 1. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.265275 gram of f ine gold per Venezuelan Bolivar. No transactions take place at the par value. Ex- change transactions take place at the following rates. 1 The Central Bank of Venezuela purchases proceeds of the petro- leum and iron ore exporting companies at the rate of Bs 4.20 per US$ 1. Any proceeds from exports of cacao and coffee that are offered for sale to the Central Bank must be purchased by it at the rate of Bs 4.285 per US$1. The Central Bank sells exchange to the Government and its agencies and to the commercial banks (for sales to the public only) at Bs 4.285 per US$1 .2 The commercial banks purchase foreign exchange from the public at rates close to Bs 4.28 per US$1. Commercial banks must sell exchange to the public at Bs 4.30 per US$1 for all transactions; foreign banks may on ly sell foreign exchange that has not been obtained from the Central Bank. Some foreign exchange is also negotiated on the two stock ex- changes, where buy ing and selling rates usually are s l igh t ly below Bs 4.30 per US$1. Exchange houses are permitted to deal only in banknotes, coins, and travelers checks. The Cen- tral Bank offers swap facilities under which it buys U.S. dol- lars at Bs 4.27 and resells at Bs 4.30 after 180 days. Administration of Control There is no exchange control mechanism. Import and ex- port licenses, when required, are generally issued by the Min- istry of Development or the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, depending on the commodity. Under the terms of an agreement between the Government and the Central Bank, the latter has the responsibility of ensuring that a subsidy is applied to imports of wheat for human consumption and to certain exports of coffee and cacao. Prescription of Currency Payments between Venezuela and Argentina, Chile, Co- lombia, the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Peru, and Uruguay may be made through accounts maintained w i th each other by the Central Bank of Venezuela and the central banks of the countries concerned. Proceeds from exports of petroleum and petroleum derivatives must not be received through these accounts. Otherwise, no prescription of currency require- ments are in force. Imports and Import Payments The import of certain goods is either prohibited or reserved for the Government; these include fu l ly assembled automo- biles, certain textiles, coffee, citrus fru i t, bananas, pineapples, melons, salt, opium, cigarette paper, natural pearls, and matches. In addition, a few other commodities require import licenses; quan t i ta t ive restrictions applicable irrespective of 1 The exchange rates given (except those for the Central Bank's swap transactions) are those applicable to sight d ra f ts on New York. 2 The Central Bank does not sell foreign exchange to the public but does sell m inor amoun ts to its staff and certain government officials, at the Bs 4.30 rate, for travel expenses and personal remittances. 474 origin are maintained on these items for protective purposes. Licenses are valid for all countries except Rhodesia and South Africa. Import licenses for some products are issued on the condition that the importer has purchased domestic products equal to a prescribed percentage of the quan t i ty import (con- tingentamiento). Imports of wheat for human consumption receive a subsidy of 25.55 per cent of the f.o.b. value, calculated at Bs 4.30 per US$1; they require an import license, and the Central Bank's Import Subsidy Office establishes eligibility for the subsidy. All other commodities are free from import licens- ing. Imports from Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Import payments may be made freely. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles may be made freely; private sector purchases of exchange for this purpose are made from commercial banks or exchange houses. Resident and nonresi- dent travelers must on departure pay a travel tax of Bs 80 a person a trip; exemptions exist for children under seven, for- eign tourists, Venezuelan and foreign diplomats, and person- nel of international organizations. Travelers may freely export domestic and foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain fu rs and hides, scrap metals, and a few other commodities are prohibited. Licenses are required for the exportation of many other commodities, except petro- leum. Most export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Develop- ment, but those for coffee and cacao are granted by the Minis- try of Agriculture and Livestock. Exports of products containing subsidized imported wheat are subject to special arrangements to ensure that the subsidy received is repaid. The export of gold and precious stones requires an export license issued by the M in is try of Finance. The petroleum and iron ore exporting companies must surrender to the Central Bank export proceeds, to the extent of their local currency requirements (including taxes), at a rate of Bs 4.20 per US$1. Otherwise, there are no surrender requirements for export proceeds or other exchange receipts. Exporters of coffee and cacao may (but need not) sell exchange proceeds to the Cen- tral Bank at Bs 4.285 per US$1; they may receive an export subsidy calculated to prevent the f.o.b. bolivar prices of these products in Venezuelan ports from fa l l ing below specified m in imum amounts regardless of external prices for these products. Eligibility for this subsidy is maintained even if the exchange proceeds are not surrendered. In principle, the ben- efit of these arrangements based on guaranteed minimum prices may be extended to firms processing domestic coffee or cacao for export. All exports to Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited, as are exports of petroleum and m i l i ta ry equipment to the People's Republic of China and Nor th Korea. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles are freely disposable. Travelers may freely import domestic and foreign currency, w i th the exception that the Currency Law prohibits the im- portation for commercial purposes of foreign coins other than gold coins. The importation of Venezuelan gold coins is re- served for the Central Bank. Capital All capital transfers are permitted freely. Brokerage activ- ity in Venezuela, however, in shares or un i ts of foreign invest- ment trusts or mutual funds is prohibited. There is no registration procedure for incoming capital. The Central Bank regulates bank credit to nonresidents and companies whose capital is more than 50 per cent owned by physical persons or companies that are resident or domiciled abroad. The General Banking Law of December 30, 1970 authorizes the Government to regulate bank credit to companies whose capital is more than 40 per cent owned by nonresident or foreign physical persons or companies. This law also provides special regulations for foreign banks operating in Venezuela. Gold Venezuelan gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold coins in Venezuela for numismatic and investment purposes. The Central Bank does not deal in gold with the public, but gold coins, medal- lions, and bars are freely negotiated between licensed import- ers, exchange houses, and the public. Commercial banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and w i th other residents but do not normally deal in gold w i th the public. Imports and exports of monetary gold are reserved for the Central Bank, as is the import of gold coins that are legal VENEZUELA tender in Venezuela. Other imports and exports of gold re- qu ire licenses. Imports require licenses from the Ministry of Finance and in certain cases also from the Ministry of Devel- opment, while exports are licensed by the M in is try of Finance only. The law prescribes a license for all imports and exports of gold by anyone not registered at the M in is try of Develop- ment as an industrial user, but in practice imports and ex- ports by private persons are permitted free of license. Imports of gold coins and of gold bars and ingots weighing more than 12 kilograms are free of customs du ty; all other gold imports are subject to du ty at vary ing rates. All imports of nonmone- tary gold are subject to consular duties ranging from 2 per cent to 3V2 per cent ad valorem. Changes during 1973 February 13. Venezuela became a signatory to the Carta- gena Agreement of the Andean Group. It forma l ly became a member of the Group late in 1973. February 19. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, Venezuela changed the buy ing rate of Bs 4.30 per U.S. dollar to Bs 4.20 and that of Bs 4.385 per U.S. dollar to Bs 4.285. All other buy ing and selling rates were also appreciated by 10 centavos per US$1. May 1. A new customs ta r i ff based on the Brussels Tariff Nomenclature came in to force. The number of items subject to import licensing was reduced from 580 to about 100. September 26. An Export Incentive Law was promulgated. It provided for the promotion of nontraditional exports by a system of bearer tax credit certificates (CATs) that were freely negotiable. The law came in to effect on September 28. September 26. A law was promulgated creating an Export Finance Fund. It provided for credit facilities for exports of nontraditional goods and services of national origin that were considered to have priority for economic development pur- poses. The law came in to effect on September 28. 475 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM used for investment. Their use is subject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Investments financed from Capital Accounts generally are not covered by the In- vestment Law of 1963 (see section on Capital, below), and proceeds from the liquidation of such investments are cred- ited to Capital Accounts unless the Ministry of National Economy has declared them eligible for the privileges of the law. Balances in Capital Accounts are negotiable between nonresident foreigners. Imports and Import Payments The bulk of imports comes under one of three headings: (1) imports financed with funds from the U.S. Agency for In- ternational Development (AID); (2) imports financed from Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange resources; and (3) "third- country-financed imports," i.e., imports financed with French, German, and Japanese loans, or French export credit. In principle, products imported under the AID pro- grams are not included among imports that are financed otherwise. However, when AID financing proves insufficient for obtaining imports of essential products, such imports may be financed from Viet-Nam's official exchange reserves. Many imports are prohibited. Except for those commodities also financed by the U.S. AID programs and prohibited commodities, all imports fi- nanced w i th Viet-Nam's own exchange are effected through the "Import Credit" procedure, under which they are exempt from license. All other imports require licenses. Certain im- ports are subject to advance deposits and /or import sur- charges. Some imports are permitted without foreign exchange (sans Exchange Rate System 1 No par value for the Vietnamese Piastre has been estab- lished w i th the Fund. The exchange rate structure is based on an official rate and a special rate, both of which may be adjusted from time to time; on December 31, 1973 these rates stood at VNS550 and VN$455, respectively, per US$1. Dif- ferent effective exchange rates arise from the application of certain subsidies and commissions. Payments and receipts must be effected through the autho- rized banks. Authorized banks are allowed to engage in for- ward buy ing or selling of foreign exchange in the domestic or foreign exchange markets, but only in relation to payments for imports and only in certain specified currencies. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the National Bank of Viet-Nam (Directorate-General of Exchange). Most remit- tances must have the prior approval of the Directorate-Gen- eral of Exchange; the au thor i ty to approve some payments for private invisibles has been delegated to the authorized banks. Imports financed by U.S. aid require licenses and are subject to special contracts or procurement procedures. Import li- censes are issued by the Ministry of Economy (Directorate of Commercial Aid) and are countersigned by the National Bank (Directorate of Foreign Aid). Licenses are generally not required for imports financed w i th Viet-Nam's own ex- change. Prescription of Currency With the exception of import payments under the French credit insurance program, all payments must be made in U.S. dollars. Proceeds from exports to France, the Federal Repub- lic of Germany, Japan, and the United Kingdom must be received in the currency of the country concerned. Other receipts may be accepted either in a currency quoted by the National Bank (deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen, or pounds sterling) or in any other convertible currency, provided that prior to repatriation such other currencies are converted in to a currency quoted by the National Bank. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may maintain accounts with banks, subject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Nonresident Accounts in Free Piastres may be freely cred- ited with the proceeds from the sale of convertible exchange and may be freely debited for most payments to residents. A category of nonresident accounts, Capital Accounts, covers piastres owned by nonresident foreigners that may not be transferred abroad. Balances in Capital Accounts may be 1 Following the replacement of equalization taxes (taxes de perequation) by import surcharges on December 29, 1973, exchange subsidies for exports were eliminated in Janua ry 1974 and replaced by a subsidy not invo lv ing a mu l t ip le currency practice. On Janua ry 12, 1974 the special exchange rate for certain tied commod i ty aid impor ts from the United States was eliminated and replaced by a fiscal subsidy outside the scope of the exchange system. As a result of these modifications, the exchange rate was un if ied at VNS560 per US$1. 476 imports under suppliers' credits are subject to a different type of deposit (consignation). Payments for Invisibles Most payments for invisibles require approval by the Directorate-General of Exchange. Students approved by a special commission are granted US$80 a mon th for study in the Republic of China or Hong Kong and US$150 a month for study elsewhere; they are also granted allocations for tuition and medical fees and for extraordinary expenses. Stu- dents participating in short-term training courses abroad are granted up to US$130 a month. Foreign specialists employed in Viet-Nam may transfer up to 50 per cent of their salary every month, but not more than US$600 a mon th. In principle, foreign firms are generally permitted to trans- fer up to 70 per cent of their net annual profit after tax, after examination of their accounts and after deduction of any losses in previous years. Profit transfers by foreign enterprises established or expanded between February 14, 1963 and June 2, 1972 under the terms of the 1963 Investment Law are governed by the provisions of that law unless they meet the requirements of the "Foreign Exchange Working Capital Sys- tem" (see section on Capital, below). Although dividends declared in Viet-Nam and accruing to nonresidents and for- eign residents may in principle be transferred abroad, under the terms of the 1963 Investment Law transfers of profits and dividends are limited to 20 per cent annually of the declared capital. Net annual profits after tax from projects covered by the new Investment Law, Law No. 4 /72, may be transferred without limit. Each resident authorized to travel abroad is entitled to purchase the following amounts of foreign exchange at the official rate: travelers to the Khmer Republic and Laos US$30 a day, with a maximum of US$300 a person a trip, and travelers to other countries US$40 a day, with a maximum of US$2,400 a person a trip. The allocations mentioned may be supplemented by the equivalent of US$40 in foreign bank- notes. Travelers are permitted to take with them up to VN$5,000 in Vietnamese banknotes. Foreign exchange not used by foreign travelers may be re-exported. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports do not require a license; they must be domi- ciled (registered) with an authorized bank, however, which is responsible for the repatriation of the foreign exchange. All exports to communist countries, exports to any destination of manufactured or semimanufactured products originally im- ported into Viet-Nam, gold, rice, rice products, and certain other items are prohibited; the prohibition does not apply to imported goods that have been processed in Viet-Nam, pro- vided that the value added corresponds to, or exceeds, a specified proportion of the export price. Exporters are al- lowed to retain in EFAC (Exportations-Frais Accessoires) accounts 10 per cent of their total export proceeds for the settlement of incidental expenses related to the export trans- action. Most exports enjoy subsidies on the basis of the de- clared export value in terms of Vietnamese piastres. VIET-NAM Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered at the official rate. Foreign military personnel and official U.S. civilian person- nel serving in Viet-Nam are paid in scrip ("military payment certificates" or MPCs), which can be exchanged for piastres at the official rate only through special official channels (mili- tary banking facilities). They are not permitted to possess foreign banknotes or travelers checks in Viet-Nam, but there are military banking facilities under which eligible foreign persons may open accounts in piastres, MPCs, or U.S. dollars at two U.S. banks in Saigon. A traveler entering Viet-Nam may bring in any amount of foreign exchange and up to VN$5,000 in Vietnamese bank- notes. Foreign military and civilian personnel (government officials) must surrender on arrival any foreign banknotes they bring into Viet-Nam. Capital Under general regulations, capital may be imported with- out formalities, but foreign investors must register their capi- tal with the Vietnamese authorities and agree on the terms of the investment in order to be able to repatriate their capital and to transfer profits. Under the Investment Law of 1963, special benefits could be accorded to new foreign investments in those sectors of the economy that are given high priority. The minimum investment in agriculture was established at VN$0.5 million, and in industry at VN$1 million. Imports of equipment and spare parts needed by foreign undertakings covered by the law were exempt from customs duties. Foreign technicians employed by these enterprises were exempt from income tax for 2 years. Foreign investments were free of taxes on profit, securities, and real estate for specified periods of time. The new investments were not subject to any national- ization measures for the first 15 years from the date of the written authorization granted to the investor; they were ac- corded the same treatment as that applicable to domestic investments. The law provided for the transfer of profits at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent of the invested capital, and for the repatriation of the original investment after 5 years at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent if the capital was newly imported (after 20 years for investment of foreign-owned cap- ital previously held in Viet-Nam). A new Investment Law promulgated on June 2, 1972 has superseded the Investment Law of 1963. The provisions of the 1963 law, however, are still applicable to the enterprises which were governed by them. Under the new law, which mainly adds new fiscal benefits to the provisions of the 1963 law, fiscal incentives are granted to new investments whether financed in Vietnamese currency or in foreign exchange brought from abroad, provided that (1) the investments are made in a "priority sector" and (2) that the initial capital is over VN$10 million in the primary sector and over VN$20 million in the secondary and tertiary sectors. Besides fiscal exemptions the foreign enterprises enjoying the benefits of the law are authorized (1) to transfer abroad total net annual profits and (2) to repatriate after five years of operation the capital invested, in annual installments of 20 per cent. 477 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM Investments not covered by either Investment Law nor by the regime described in the following paragraph are subject to the regulations and case-to-case decisions of the Director- ate-General of Exchange, which normally authorizes the transfer of up to 70 per cent of net annual profits after taxes but does not permit disinvestment; such investments are not eligible for the above-mentioned tax exemptions. Under a "Foreign Exchange Working Capital System," for- eign capital imported in the form of direct investment or as medium-term and long-term credit in cash or in kind may be registered with the National Bank and treated as follows. Capital must be brought from abroad and sold through au- thorized banks, where it is credited to a "Foreign Exchange Working Account.'* Profits, dividends, and interest on such capital may be transferred annually up to a maximum of 20 per cent of the registered amount and repatriation may be made up to an annual maximum of 25 per cent of the regis- tered capital. Imports and exports of capital normally are made at the official rate. Gold Within Viet-Nam, the holding of gold and all transactions in gold are subject to licensing, but the controls are not rigidly enforced and unlicensed holdings of gold by individu- als are tolerated. Only the National Bank is empowered to import and export gold. All domestic transactions in gold are subject to a luxury tax of 10 per cent on the sale value or the manufacturing cost. The export of gold by physical or juridi- cal persons other than the National Bank is prohibited. The import of gold by physical or juridical persons other than the Table of Exchange Rates (as at December 31, 1973 )2 National Bank is also prohibited, with the following excep- tions: (1) Vietnamese settled in Laos may, when returning to Viet-Nam, bring in up to 13 taels 4 of gold in the form of jewelry; (2) residents may import gold without allocation of foreign exchange, provided that they have an import license and pay a customs du ty of 130 per cent and an equalization tax of VNS100 per US$1; (3) nonresidents may, without allo- cation of foreign exchange, bring in to Viet-Nam any quan- t i ty of gold, provided that its en try is declared and that it is deposited in safe custody with an authorized bank; the util- ization of such gold is subject to prior authorization by the Directorate-General of Exchange, and if it is sold in Viet-Nam, the sales proceeds must be credited to a Capital Account. Not for Redistribution Exchange Rate System Payments for Invisibles WESTERN SAMOA No par value for the Western Samoa Tala has been estab- lished w i th the Fund. A central rate of WS$1 = US$1.67736 has been established, corresponding to 1.23565 grams of f ine gold or SDR 1.39045, respectively, per WS$1. The interven- tion currency is the U.S. dollar and Western Samoa avails itself of wider margins. On December 31, 1973, the Bank of Western Samoa's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$1.6617 and US$1.6396, respectively, per WS$1. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Minister of Fi- nance operating as the exchange control au thor i ty; the Minis- ter may delegate his approval au tho r i ty to the Financial Secretary, who in turn may delegate part of his powers to authorized banks. All payments to nonresidents of Western Samoa require the approval of the Ministry of Finance. The M in is try, however, has delegated to the Bank of Western Samoa, the only authorized bank, au tho r i ty to approve cer- tain payments up to any amount and certain other payments up to specified amounts. Prescription of Currency Western Samoa has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Most settlements with Sterling Area territories take place in Ster- ling Area currencies, but there are no prescriptions as to the currencies in which payments to or from nonresidents of Western Samoa must be made or received. Nonresident Accounts Payments for certain invisibles, such as overseas contrac- tual obligations and insurance, are approved automatically by the Bank of Western Samoa up to any amount or within limits determined by the Ministry of Finance. Payments in excess of these limits as well as payments for all other invisi- bles require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance. Remittances in respect of study abroad are freely authorized. The Ministry of Finance approves up to any amount the transfer of genuine income derived locally from pensions, rents, interests, and dividends by persons permanently resi- dent overseas. Residents traveling to American Samoa, whether for business or private purposes, are entitled to a foreign currency allowance equivalent to US$50 a person a quarter; an additional allowance of US$15 a day is provided to cover hotel expenses. The basic travel allowance for other countries is equivalent to WS$10 a person a day, subject to a limit of WS$ 1,000. The Ministry of Finance grants supple- mentary allocations when evidence of genuine need is pro- vided. Resident travelers may take out foreign banknotes, as part of their foreign currency allowance, up to WS$20 a per- son a trip. Resident and nonresident travelers may take out any amount in domestic currency. Exports and Export Proceeds V ir tua l ly all exports require the prior approval of the Min- is try of Finance. Exports may be prohibited by the Director of Agriculture on grounds of low quality, or by order of the Head of State to alleviate domestic shortages. Copra exports are controlled by the Copra Board and banana exports by the Produce Marketing Division of the Ministry of Agriculture. Export proceeds must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa w i th in a reasonable time after shipment. Where excep- tional circumstances exist, the Ministry of Finance may waive this requirement for certain export items. No distinction is made between the accounts of residents and nonresidents of Western Samoa. Proceeds from Invisibles Imports and Import Payments The import of a few commodities is prohibited from all sources for reasons of security or health. Other commodities may be imported from any source. Each licensed commercial importer receives an annual allocation of foreign exchange, to be taken up on a quarterly basis, which may be used freely for the import of any commodity that is not prohibited except automobiles. The allocations are made by the Ministry of Finance and communicated to the Bank of Western Samoa; the la t ter automatically provides the foreign exchange re- quired for import payments upon submission of documentary evidence. Persons who are not licensed importers may import any commodity freely up to WS$100 a person a year but require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance for imports of higher value. The import of motor vehicles, other than for exclusive use in plantation work, requires an advance deposit of 50 per cent of the retail value. 480 All receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa. Resident travelers must on return sell to the Bank all foreign currency brought in. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign and domestic banknotes. Capital All outward capital transfers by residents require the spe- cific approval of the Ministry of Finance and capital received by residents must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa. Inward capital remittances do not normally require approval, but borrowing abroad by nonbank residents does. The transfer of legacies from estates of deceased local resi- dents due to beneficiaries permanently residing overseas is approved up to a limit of WS$ 10,000 a year. The Bank of Western Samoa approves transfers of gifts to relatives and dependents, either for special fam i ly occasions or by way of maintenance, up to WS$200 a year for each family group. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Foreign investments in specified activities in Western Samoa are encouraged. The Enterprises Incentive Act No. 27 /1965, as amended in 1969, makes provision for the granting of certain relief of customs duties, income tax, and business license fees to persons engaged in approved enterprises. Both the repatriation of capital and profit remittances on foreign capital are subject to approval by the Minister of Finance; such approval is normally granted. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form. There are no restrictions on imports or exports of gold in any form. Changes during 1973 January 1. Foreign exchange allocations for importers came in to effect which were set at levels below those of 1972. Subsequently, additional allocations were granted which brought 1973 allocations up to about the 1972 level. February 20. Following the announcement that the U.S. WESTERN SAMOA dollar was being devalued, the Western Samoa tala remained pegged to the New Zealand dollar, at the previously existing ratio of WS$0.8076 = $NZ 1. The par value of the latter currency was maintained in terms of gold. As a result, the tala appreciated in terms of the U.S. dollar. The buying and sell- ing rates for the U.S. dollar, previously US$1.4937 and US$1.4662 per WS$1, became US$1.6617 and US$1.6396 per WS$1. May 10. Not for Redistribution Exchange Rate System Exports and Export Proceeds YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC The currency of the Yemen Arab Republic is the Yemen Rial, which is issued by the Central Bank of Yemen. No par value has been established with the Fund. All transactions take place in a free market at a f luc tua t ing exchange rate. On December 31, 1973 the rate for the U.S. dollar was about YRls 4.50 per US$1. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered on behalf of the Minister of Economy by the Central Bank of Yemen, which has the au tho r i ty to grant exchange licenses and licenses for imports and exports. The only commercial banks and authorized deal- ers are the Yemen Bank for Reconstruction and Development and four branches of foreign commercial banks. Prescription of Currency Settlements under bilateral payments arrangements l are made in the currencies and through the accounts provided for by these arrangements. Otherwise, settlements are usually made in pounds sterling or U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Israel are prohibited. Imports of a few com- modities are reserved for the Government. All other imports require import licenses. These are issued freely for all com- modities for which government agencies or firms with govern- ment participation do not have the exclusive right of importation. In addition to a license, the importation of cer- tain commodities requires the permission of the competent m in is try or, for certain textiles, of the Sanaa Textile Factory. Imports that are financed by the importer w i th his own for- eign exchange held abroad also require an import license. Importers who have obtained an import license may obtain the necessary foreign exchange from the local banks or the free market. In addition to the applicable customs du ty, im- ports are subject to a defense tax of 5 per cent ad valorem and a statistical tax of 2 per cent ad valorem. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles may be made freely when financed from foreign currency accounts held at home or abroad by exporters of goods or services, or when effected in foreign banknotes. All other payments in respect of invisibles require an exchange license issued by the Central Bank. Such licenses are issued freely for virtually all current invisibles, including tourist travel. Travelers may freely take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. 1 The Yemen A rab Republic ma in ta ins a bilateral payments arrangement w i th Egyp t. 482 Exports to Israel are prohibited. For statistical purposes only, all exports require registration forms, which are issued freely by banks; export licenses are not required. Exporters are not required to surrender the foreign exchange proceeds; these may be retained in foreign currency accounts with do- mestic banks. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered but may be retained in foreign currency accounts with domestic com- mercial banks. Travelers may freely bring in any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Capital In principle, all capital transfers require prior approval and capital proceeds must be surrendered; in practice, no restric- tions are imposed on inward or outward capital transfers. Both domestic and foreign investment are regulated by Law No. 13 of 1970. Foreign investors in the Yemen Arab Repub- lic are free to transfer abroad any desired proportion of their net profits after taxes or of their capital. Gold A 20-rial gold coin has been issued, which is not legal tender and does not circulate in the Yemen Arab Republic. By virtue of Ministerial Decree No. 21 /1973 residents are free to purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in the Yemen Arab Republic and to import or export gold in any form without an import, export or exchange license. Changes during 1973 February. Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the Yemen authorities decided to allow the rate of the rial to be deter- mined by market forces. Previously, the rate had been stable for some time at YRls 5.00 = US$1. By February 25, the rial had appreciated in the free market to about YRls 4.50 per U.S. dollar. The Central Bank then announced its intention to stabilize the rate at this level, provided that only a mini- mum of market intervention was required to do so. March 14. Pending the promulgation of a law that would formally repeal certain regulations that were no longer being enforced (see August 15, below), the Central Bank issued a circular providing the following: (1) All private imports henceforth required an import li- cense; previously, imports financed by a private importer with his own foreign exchange held abroad were exempt from licensing. (2) Banks no longer required the prior approval of the Central Bank to make payments for current invisibles, pro- vided these were financed out of foreign currency accounts, whether held at home or abroad, or settled in foreign bank- notes. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN Exchange Rate System The currency of the People's Democratic Republic of Ye- men is the Yemeni Dinar, which is issued by the Bank of Yemen and is defined as equivalent to 2.13281 grams of f ine gold. No par value for the Yemeni dinar has been established w i th the Fund. The central rate is YD 1 = US$2.89524 or US$1 = YD 0.345395. On December 31, 1973, the National Bank of Yemen's buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were YD 0.343 and YD 0.350. Administration of Control The administration of exchange control is carried out by the Bank of Yemen's (the central bank) General Department for Exchange Control through the Foreign Exchange Com- mittee, which has delegated certain powers to the Director of Exchange Control, a member of the Committee. The Ministry of Economy and Indus t ry issues import and export licenses; those for gold and other precious metals require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Exchange transactions must be carried out through the intermediary of authorized dealers (licensed commercial banks approved by the Director of Exchange Control); at present the only com- mercial bank and authorized dealer is the National Bank of Yemen. Except for payments for imports against letters of credit or documents, which may be approved by the autho- rized dealer, and for payments by the oil refinery, all pay- ments for imports (including those of precious metals) require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Two public corporations and a semipublic corporation are en- gaged in foreign trade (see section on Imports and Import Payments, below). The oil refinery is treated as a resident entity but in its operation generally is not affected by the existing exchange and trade controls. Prescription of Currency The People's Democratic Republic of Yemen has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Over- seas Sterling Area. Exchange transactions must be carried out th rough the intermediary of authorized dealers in accordance w i th prescription of currency regulations that are in certain respects similar to those applicable in the United Kingdom. All payments to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Export proceeds and certain receipts from invisibles must be received in prescribed currencies * and surrendered to authorized deal- ers. Payments for imports must be made in prescribed curren- cies. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts may be held by certain persons not resident in the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen. The 1 Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, deutsche ma rk, French francs, I ta l ian lire, Ne ther lands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 484 principal type of nonresident account is the External Account in Yemeni Dinars. External Accounts may be credited with proceeds from convertible foreign currency transferred from abroad, with bank interest payable on such accounts, and with balances from other External Accounts. Transfers from abroad must be in the form of bank drafts; the accounts cannot be credited with payments in the form of foreign banknotes (unless they have been declared to the customs on entry), or with locally raised or locally earned funds. External Accounts may be debited for any payments to residents, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for payments abroad in any convertible currency. Transfers abroad from Nonresident Accounts in Yemeni dinars require the prior approval of the Exchange Control Department. The Foreign Exchange Committee may direct any payment to a nonresi- dent to a Blocked Account. Except with the Committee's prior approval, Blocked Accounts may be debited only for purchases of specified securities. Imports and Import Payments With minor exceptions, all imports other than those of the oil refinery require individual licenses. Most overland mer- chanting trade with the Yemen Arab Republic is also exempt from the licensing requirements. There are special regulations governing merchanting trade with neighboring countries. Im- ports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. An import program is drawn up annually, but its quotas are operated flexibly. Payments for imports on a c.& f. basis against letters of credit or documentary drafts can be made by authorized dealers w i thout the prior approval of the Director of Ex- change Control; most other forms of payment for imports require no approval. Insurance on imports must be effected locally. A Board of Trade is in charge of the trading activities of the nationalized companies. The National Company for For- eign Trade has a monopoly over imports of flour, sugar, wheat, rice, ghee, cooking oil, tea, and cigarettes. The Na- tional Import Company Ltd. imports certain consumer goods not mentioned in Law No. 37 of 1969. The National Com- pany for Home Trade is the sole importer of automobiles and other vehicles, all government requirements, and most re- quirements of the public hospitals, as well as other specified items. Imports into and exports from the free port zones within the port of Aden are free of exchange and trade con- trols (except in respect of transactions between these zones and the rest of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen) and are exempt from customs duties. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. The basic exchange allowance for tourism, which residents may take up without applying for exchange control approval, is the equivalent of YD 125 a person a trip in travelers checks, drafts, and foreign notes and coins (50 per cent of this amount for children under ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ten). 2 Allowances for other types of travel are granted on the merits of the application. Foreign employees of approved enterprises and the oil refinery are allowed to remit abroad up to 50 per cent and three eighths, respectively, of their total earnings (net of taxes). All insurance is nationalized; existing policies have been transferred to the National Insurance and Reinsurance Company, and payments abroad in respect of premiums are not permitted. Travelers may take out the equivalent of YD 5 in domestic banknotes and up to the equivalent of YD 125 in travelers checks, foreign banknotes, or other foreign means of payment. Furthermore, nonresi- dents may take out any foreign exchange declared upon en t ry. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports, including petroleum products, are exempt from licenses. All exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohib- ited. Except for exports to the Yemen Arab Republic speci- fied by the Foreign Exchange Committee, export proceeds must be received in prescribed currencies within six months of shipment and must be sold to authorized dealers upon receipt. The proceeds of exports or re-exports to the Yemen Arab Republic may be surrendered in the national currency of the importing country. Proceeds from Invisibles All claims of residents for services rendered to nonresidents must be collected in foreign currency (or received from an External Account) when due and surrendered to authorized dealers. Travelers may freely bring in foreign banknotes but not more than YD 5 in domestic currency. Capital V ir tua l ly all capital payments and transactions require prior approval. Expatriates are normally permitted upon de- parture to remit their liquid funds to their country of perma- nent residence. PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN Industrial Investment (Law No. 23 of May 14, 1971) may be granted exemptions from import du ty and various other tax facilities. All remittances abroad of interest and profits require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. Profit remit- tances abroad by foreign firms under Law No. 23 also are subject to the Exchange Control Law (Law No. 16) and in any one year should not normally exceed 50 per cent of the accrued net profit. Beginning five years after production has started, the net value of the enterprise (calculated on the basis of actual or book value or surrender or liquidation value, whichever is less) is transferable at the rate of 25 per cent a year; if an expatriate national or foreign investor encounters difficulties, however, his capital may be retransferred six months after en t ry. Interest due on any loans obtained abroad after the firm concerned has been established may also be remitted, provided that all duties, taxes, and other govern- ment dues have been paid. Gold Only the monetary authorities and authorized dealers may purchase, hold, or sell gold bullion. Licensed goldsmiths may purchase, hold, and sell other unworked gold and gold coins and ornaments. Other residents may hold gold only in the form of ornaments or numismatic coins. Exports and imports of gold by registered goldsmiths require licenses issued by the Ministry of Economy and Industry (General Department for Foreign Trade); in certain cases, the consent of the Foreign Exchange Committee must also be obtained. Travelers may bring in or take out reasonable amounts of gold, in the form of ornaments only (not exceeding YD 250 in value for incom- ing travelers and not exceeding YD 100 for departing travel- ers). Imports and exports of gold by travelers are subject only to customs control, but incoming travelers must sell to an authorized dealer any gold coins or bullion they carry.
