Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0433330 gram of f ine gold per Yugoslav Dinar, corresponding to Din 20.508 = SDR 1 or Din 17 = US$1. However, since July 12, 1973 the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the dinar within announced margins and therefore all transactions, except for receipts and payments effected under the procedures set fo r th for certain countries with which Yugoslavia has bilateral payments agreements, take place at a f luc tua t ing exchange rate. The buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in the foreign exchange market in Belgrade on December 31, 1973 were Din 15.58 and Din 15.63 per US$1, respectively. The foreign exchange market is limited to spot transactions between au- thorized business banks and the National Bank of Yugosla- via. The currencies dealt in are Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guil- ders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. Administration of Control On the basis of laws governing these matters, the Federal Executive Council prescribes the general provisions in respect of foreign trade and exchange transactions. The Federal Sec- retariat for Foreign Trade, by virtue of these general provi- sions, establishes rules and regulations, makes decisions governing commercial transactions, and issues import and export licenses when required. It is also charged w i th securing balanced trade with payments agreement countries. The Fed- eral Secretariat for Finance prescribes the specific provisions governing exchange transactions. This Secretariat and the National Bank of Yugoslavia administer the exchange con- trols. The National Bank prescribes the methods of payment to and from foreign countries; it also licenses compensation transactions. All foreign exchange transactions must be carried out through the National Bank or an authorized bank. The latter are of three types. Fully authorized banks, which must have a minimum credit fund of Din 500 million and deposits of at least Din 1,000 million, may engage in all foreign exchange transactions in Yugoslavia and abroad, as well as in foreign credit operations (including the granting of guarantees). Lim- ited authorized banks, which must have a m in imum credit fund amounting to Din 100 million and deposits of at least Din 200 million, may conduct foreign exchange operations in Yugoslavia only; they may neither keep foreign exchange accounts abroad nor engage in foreign credit operations, ex- cept through the intermediary of a fu l ly authorized credit bank. Authorized exchange offices may only deal in foreign banknotes and travelers checks; this status is open to all commercial and savings banks, hotels, and specifically autho- rized tourist agencies. Commercial exports and imports may be effected by all economic organizations (both producing and trading under- takings) registered for this purpose. Registration is effected automatically, provided that certain conditions, including the 486 provision of m in imum working capital for trade enterprises, are fulfilled. Economic organizations that are not registered to conduct foreign trade channel their orders through eco- nomic organizations which export a n d / or import on their own behalf. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Yugoslavia has bilateral payments agreements are made in the currencies and according to the procedures set forth in those agreements. If no agreement exists, settlement is usually made in a convert- ible currency. Yugoslavia has payments agreements requiring settlements through bilateral accounts as follows: (1) in U.S. dollars w i th Afghanistan, Albania, Algeria, Brazil, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Ghana, Greece, Hun- gary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R.; (2) in the partner country's currency with Iraq. Certain settlements with Bangladesh, Colombia, Mexico, and Pakistan take place through special accounts. A degree of multilateralization of payments is provided under the bilateral payments agree- ments w i th Afghan is tan, Ghana, Hungary, and Iraq. Nonresident Accounts Foreign juridical and physical persons may maintain ac- counts denominated in foreign exchange and in dinars in Yugoslavia according to the following rules. Foreigners resi- dent outside Yugoslavia may freely open accounts in convert- ible currencies in Yugoslavia. Foreign missions and foreigners resident in Yugoslavia may freely open with authorized banks accounts expressed in foreign currencies or dinars. Foreign exchange accounts in convertible currencies of nonresident juridical and physical persons are kept in the currency deposited. * Balances on these accounts may be used for all payments in Yugoslavia, in dinars or in the currency concerned, and abroad, in any convertible currency. Trans- fers from these accounts are free if made in the currency in which the account is kept; outward transfers in other convert- ible currencies are subject to the account-holding bank being prepared to make the necessary conversion. Nonresident foreign exchange accounts in bilateral curren- cies may be opened only for certain foreign juridical and physical persons resident in Yugoslavia and subject to prior approval by the National Bank. Balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugoslavia or for retransfer to the bilateral country to which the account is related. Foreign juridical and physical persons may freely open nonresident accounts in convertible dinars with authorized banks. Such accounts can be credited freely w i th amounts whose transfer in convertible currency has been authorized and they may be debited freely for permitted payments in 1 Accounts may be denominated in any of the fo l low ing currencies: Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, Finnish ma rkkaa, French francs, I ta l ian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds s ter l ing, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. Other convertible currencies must be converted in to one or more of the foregoing currencies. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Yugoslavia and for transfer abroad in the convertible cur- rency of the account holder's country of domicile. Nonresident juridical and physical persons may also open other dinar accounts w i th authorized banks. These other ac- counts may be credited with dinars acquired in Yugoslavia in accordance with the existing regulations or subject to the approval of the National Bank of Yugoslavia. Balances are, in principle, nontransferable and may be spent in Yugoslavia only for noncommercial payments by the account holder or by members of his close family, or by the owner and staff of foreign firms if the account holder is a foreign juridical per- son. If balances on these accounts derive from copyright royalties or from work performed in Yugoslavia by foreign- ers, from pensions and disability allowances of persons who have emigrated from Yugoslavia, or from alimony payments, transfers may be effected in accordance with the existing regulations. Resident nationals may maintain foreign exchange ac- counts or foreign exchange savings deposits in convertible currencies with any authorized bank, provided that they orig- inate from receipts specified in the relevant regulations. These accounts are kept in the currency deposited, are interest bear- ing, and interest is paid partly in the foreign currency depos- ited and partly in dinars. Foreign exchange accounts may be retained for an indefinite period of time and may be drawn upon freely for payments in Yugoslavia and abroad on behalf of the account holder or his immediate family; balances are not transferable to other persons or accounts (see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, below). Yugoslav emigrants resid- ing abroad and former emigrants returning to Yugoslavia may also open foreign exchange accounts in Yugoslavia that may be used freely for payments in Yugoslavia or abroad. Foreign exchange accounts in bilateral currencies may be maintained by resident nationals. In the case of currencies of Eastern European countries 2 and Mongolia the accounts are denominated in dollars of account; for other bilateral curren- cies the accounts are kept in the currency deposited. In gen- eral, balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugoslavia or for retransfers to the bilateral country to which the account is related. Imports and Import Payments Commercial imports may be effected only by economic organizations registered as participating in foreign trade. In addition to economic organizations specializing in foreign trade, most major industrial producers are registered. The import of certain basic foodstuffs, such as wheat, rice, coffee, lard, edible oils, and sugar, is carried out by economic organi- zations that have been selected by the Federal Office for Food Reserves, on the basis of public bids. For most commodities import licenses are not required. All commodities included in the foreign trade nomenclature are classified in five categories, largely in accordance with the manner in which exchange is made available: LB—liberalized goods; DL—goods liberalized under special license; GDK — goods imported under global exchange quotas; RK and DK YUGOSLAVIA —goods subject to individual quotas (RK if individual quo- tas are fixed by quan t i ty and DK if they are fixed in dinars); and D —imports subject to ad hoc licensing. Goods in the LB category are mainly raw materials, food- stuffs, and spare parts, but they also include some consumer goods; at the end of 1973, 4,394 items (out of a total of 7,578) were classified under LB. Protective equipment for workers and all other goods not specifically included in the GDK, RK, DK, or D lists were also liberalized and free from any quantitative restriction. Imports of LB commodities ac- counted for 28.3 per cent of total imports in 1972, and 51.6 per cent of total imports in 1973. Exchange for payments for LB imports from the convertible currency area is made avail- able freely in any convertible currency appropriate to the exporting country. Payments for imports of liberalized goods from payments agreement countries must be made in the manner prescribed in the relevant payments agreement and may be restricted according to the availability of funds in the appropriate clearing account. DL goods comprise certain previously restricted consumer items, such as tape recorders and watches, whose 1972 import value was negligible. Special licenses are required for these items for statistical and recording purposes. The Secretariat for Foreign Trade is obliged to issue the license within 20 days from the date of application. Once the license is obtained the importer may freely acquire foreign exchange for the import payment in the same manner as for LB goods. At the end of 1973, 20 items were liberalized under the DL regime, and imports of these items corresponded in 1973 to 0.3 per cent of total imports. The GDK list comprises raw materials, most capital equip- ment, and most of those consumer goods not liberalized un- der the LB and DL regimes. In 1972 imports of commodities that were on this list amounted to 46 per cent of total imports, and in 1973 imports of the same items amounted to 21.2 per cent of total imports. Such imports can be made under several different procedures. Those for nonconsumer goods are as follows: Each importer of raw materials and other reproduc- tion materials receives a global foreign exchange quota and may use the exchange so allocated to purchase any such goods listed as GDK. For certain imports by the metalwork- ing, shipbuilding, and electrical industries, the authority to use the allocated foreign exchange quota is dependent on the exports that the importers have made (import-export l ink- ing). 3 Major exporters, i.e., exporters whose exports settled in convertible currency account for more than 51 per cent of their total sales proceeds, are permitted to pay freely for imports of raw materials and other reproduction materials for their own needs. Payment for imports of capital goods on the GDK list may be financed from specific exchange allocations; a considerable portion may be freely financed from retention quota funds (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below), funds originating in depreciation allowances, and credits obtained abroad, including suppliers' credits. The spe- cific exchange allocations are limited mainly to large invest- ment projects, including public utilities; the amounts are determined by the Federal Assembly. Economic organiza- 2 Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Poland, Romania, and U.S.S.R. 3 The system of export-import l ink ing arrangements was terminated w i th effect from January 1, 1974. 487 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA tions may acquire foreign exchange at a predetermined pro- portion of their annual depreciation allowance, a ratio that varies according to the economic sector involved. Imports under commodity quotas (list RK or list DK), mainly selected agricultural and mineral products (such as wheat, sugar, rice, coffee, and salt) but also machine tools and certain plastics, are subject to quotas established for each commodity and cannot be imported under any other proce- dure. The quotas are established either in physical quantities (RK) or in dinars (DK). There are separate quotas in each case for imports from convertible area countries and pay- ments agreement countries; their allocation among importers is decided by negotiations among the economic organiza- tions. 4 Imports of RK and DK items amounted to about 21 per cent of total imports in 1972 and about 20.6 per cent of total imports in 1973. Exchange is provided automatically for payments for imports of goods subject to the RK and DK regime, but only up to a predetermined quan t i ty or amount for each item. Goods in list D comprise gunpowder, ammun i t ion, opium, motor vehicles, tractors, certain textile fibers and yarns, tele- vision sets, railroad rolling stock, and aircraft. Import li- censes are required only for list D commodities. These licenses automatically entitle an enterprise to purchase the requisite foreign exchange. Imports of D items accounted for 4.7 per cent of total imports in 1972 and 6.5 per cent of total imports in 1973. For certain goods there is an additional requirement, irre- spective of those set out above, of a special import license ("accordance") issued by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. At the end of 1973 these goods were 61 LB items, 6 GDK items, 4 RK items, and 2 DK items. For all items concerned, the Secretariat may prescribe direct importation from the country of origin; these items include a wide range of tropical foodstuffs and fruits, raw materials, fats, oils, and textiles, as well as tin and raw cotton. Private persons who are Yugoslav nationals and hold for- eign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks may use these funds freely to import goods intended for their own use or for the use of close relatives residing with them, regardless of the import regime for the goods. Also, Yugoslavs returning from work abroad and nonresidents residing in Yugoslavia for more than three mon ths may import goods up to Din 50,000 intended for their personal needs or the needs of their own household, provided such goods were paid for from the sav- ings from their foreign earnings; such savings may be held abroad or in foreign exchange accounts w i th Yugoslav banks. As an exception to the foregoing, owners of foreign ex- change accounts and Yugoslav nationals work ing abroad may import automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, mopeds, and bicycles, together w i th mounted motors and essential spare parts for these vehicles, provided that importation is effected through a registered enterprise and payment is made through 4 In principle, any such allocation among importers must be agreed upon among economic organizations w i th in the Federal Economic Chamber. If the importers are unable to agree among themselves, the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade is authorized to decide on the d is t r ibu t ion. Imports of coffee, wheat, sugar, rice, and salt for final consumption are administered by the Federal Office for Food Reserves, which is authorized to select the most competitive importer from among registered importers. 488 a foreign exchange account held at a Yugoslav bank. Yugo- slav and foreign nationals are exempt from this prescribed manner of payment and method of importation, however, under the following circumstances: when they return for per- manent residence in Yugoslavia, provided that they have spent at least f ive years abroad; when a vehicle is inherited; when a motor vehicle is purchased out of an insurance indem- n i ty received for a motor vehicle that has been destroyed and had originally been paid for in foreign currency; and if they have spent at least two years abroad continuously and have owned a vehicle for at least two years. Yugoslav citizens returning from a tourist trip abroad may import any amount of goods intended for the needs of their household. However, if the value of the goods exceeds Din 1,000, these goods must be handed over, at the customs office at the point of en try, to a domestic forwarder for deliv- ery to the owner's address; such delivery cannot be made unless the customs duties are paid. Compensation transactions are only authorized in excep- tional circumstances; in both 1972 and 1973 they accounted for less than 1 per cent of total imports. Many agricultural commodities and foodstuffs are subject to variable import levies. A 1 per cent special tax for customs evidence and a 3 per cent equalization tax ("contingency tax") are payable on all commodities not exempt from customs du ty. In addition, an import surcharge of 6 per cent of the c.i.f. value at the border has to be paid for all dutiable com- modities, with the exception that the surcharge has been re- duced to 2 per cent for capital equipment for the development of basic primary product industries, and for certain essential items such as butter, wheat flour, hides, and raw cotton. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to merchandise transac- tions, including transportation, are fu l ly liberalized. Ex- change to cover export promotion expenses abroad is made freely available to exporters. Pensions, wages, and salaries are transferable under certain conditions. Payments in respect of royalties and alimony granted by court order are freely trans- ferable, but if a payment is to be made to a country with which Yugoslavia maintains bilateral payments arrange- ments, then such payments may be made only if the agree- ment in question provides for this to be done on a reciprocal basis. Authorized banks may sell foreign currency up to the equivalent of Din 600 for remittances for court and other fees abroad and for specified personal expenses. The National Bank may authorize the sale of any amount of foreign ex- change for the foregoing and for unspecified purposes when justified in light of the circumstances. Purchases of services abroad, as well as spare parts, fuel, etc., by Yugoslav enterprises involved in international freight and passenger transportation are liberalized. There is no basic exchange allowance for tourist travel abroad. However, travel agencies may sell organized tours abroad against payment in dinars up to an amount equivalent to 50 per cent of their individual retention quotas. The Na- tional Bank may also authorize travel agencies to sell foreign exchange for both group and individual travel abroad. Pay- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ments for other invisibles may be made from the remitter's own foreign exchange funds (e.g., from retention quotas, or, when made by various social and sociopolitical organizations, from specific annual allocations). Not more than Din 500 in domestic currency, in denominations of Din 50 or less, may be taken out by travelers. Foreign travelers may bring in and take out any amount in foreign exchange w i thout de- claring it. Exports and Export Proceeds In principle, exports are free of control, except for certain raw materials that are in short supply on the domestic market (including petroleum and petroleum derivatives and certain livestock) and certain other materials such as gunpowder, weapons, and narcotic drugs. Exports to countries w i th which Yugoslavia has a bilateral payments agreement are subject to approval by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade ("accordance"). Such approval may be given for a group of commodities or for all commodities to be exported w i th in a certain period (global approval). Permission to ex- port to bilateral countries may be made conditional on an under tak ing to import from such countries. In accordance w i th bilateral arrangements, Yugoslavia restrains exports of certain commodities to France, the Federal Republic of Ger- many, Sweden, and the United States. A preferential export regime exists for economic organizations recognized as "major exporters." 5 Proceeds from exports must be repatriated w i th in 90 days from the date of exportation, unless specific approval is granted to deviate from this rule. The surrender of these proceeds is not required. The full export proceeds may be credited to foreign exchange sight deposit accounts which the exporter ma in ta ins with an authorized bank of his choice; separate accounts must be established for each currency. Ex- change on these accounts may either be used, subject to the relevant regulations, for payments for imports and invisibles or be sold to an authorized bank. Retention quotas may be used to pay for imports of certain consumer goods if such imports are made by economic organizations that are in the catering and tourist industries or are engaged in setting up trade fairs, and by film enterprises; such imports are also permitted as consignment stocks. The part of the export proceeds that remains at the free disposal of the exporter for payments abroad is referred to as the retention quota; the remainder may be retained indefi- nitely or used for certain payments abroad, but cannot earn interest. The permitted retention rate is 20 per cent for all export earnings from goods and services, with the exception that rates of 45 per cent and 100 per cent, respectively, apply to foreign exchange earnings of tourist agencies, hotels, etc., and to receipts of Yugoslav enterprises operating abroad. In some instances (services rendered to foreign tourists and sales of newly mined gold to the National Bank), sales against payment in dinars are regarded as exports for retention quota purposes. Producing enterprises selling specified consumer 5 The concept of "major exporters" was abolished with effect from Janu- ary 1, 1974. YUGOSLAVIA goods in Yugoslavia for foreign currency may retain 20 per cent of the foreign exchange thus earned. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be repatriated within 60 days from the date on which the claim is payable, except that profits earned in foreign exchange by Yugoslav organizations from construction activities abroad must be repatriated w i th in 90 days following the date of completion of the project. The performance of construction and engineering services in payments agreement countries is subject to an "accordance" issued by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. Receipts from services are eligible for retention quo- tas. Exchange proceeds may be used for payments abroad connected with the activities of the economic organization concerned, including payments for purchases of equipment and other material for its own needs. The retained exchange is not transferable to economic organizations other than those with which the recipients are cooperating in technical and business matters, but it can always be sold to authorized banks. If the exchange is used to pay for imports, the usual import procedures apply. Residents who, while employed abroad, deposited their savings in foreign savings banks and obtained a "savings book," may withdraw their balances in the form of foreign exchange when in Yugoslavia. Residents may hold interest-bearing foreign currency ac- counts in Yugoslavia. The accounts may be credited with the fu ll amount of a person's savings from per diem allowances, salaries, and other earnings abroad, and from fellowships, royalties, and inheritances. They may also be credited with 50 per cent of the amount of foreign exchange accruing from pensions, disability allowances, alimony, and grants received from abroad, and w i th the full amount of foreign exchange accruing from indemnities and insurance. These accounts may be used freely for the personal needs of the account holder and of close members of his family; they are not trans- ferable to other persons or accounts and may be retained for an indefinite period of time. Authorized trade organizations may sell manufactured goods to foreign tourists in Yugoslavia against payment in foreign exchange at a discount of 10 per cent, representing the exemption from turnover taxes. This discount is granted only on purchases in authorized shops' against checks expressed in foreign currencies or against certain foreign banknotes. Not more than Din 500 in Yugoslav banknotes, in denomi- nations of Din 50 or less, may be brought in by travelers. Capital Foreign loans and credits may be freely contracted by fully authorized banks and economic organizations, with the ex- ceptions that no consumer goods may be imported on de- ferred payment terms, and that no foreign financial credits may be taken up whose repayment terms include a grace period of less than two years. All other inward or outward transfers of a capital nature by residents or nonresidents re- quire individual licenses. Foreign loans and credits must be recorded with the Na- tional Banks of the republics. Loans must ordinarily be repaid 489 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA w i th foreign exchange that is either obtained by the economic organization concerned as export retention quotas and for- eign exchange amortization (depreciation) allocations or ac- quired from banks according to the regulations governing the foreign trade regime. Credits in the former category are subject to prior dinar deposit requirements; the deposits are noninterest bearing and are held w i th the National Banks of the republics un t il fu ll repayment of the foreign credits. For financial credits and foreign exchange deposits received by business banks for the account of nonresidents, the f ive basic rates of deposit in tro- duced in April 1972 range from 1 per cent for maturities over ten years to 40 per cent for maturities of less than two years. However, as a temporary measure beginning in mid-Decem- ber 1972, a dinar deposit requirement of 75 per cent was required for all financial credits and foreign exchange depos- its by nonresidents regardless of ma tu r i ty. For credits for importation of capital goods, the deposit rates at the end of 1973 were 20 per cent for credits w i th a ma tu r i ty up to two years; 10 per cent for credits between three and five years; and 1 per cent for credits w i th a ma tur i ty over five years. How- ever, if the capital goods were imported for investments in underdeveloped regions of Yugoslavia, the latter deposit rates were 10 per cent for credits w i th a ma tu r i ty up to three years and 1 per cent for credits with a ma tu r i ty in excess of three years. For foreign credits of any k ind guaranteed by Yugoslav commercial banks, a dinar deposit of 5 per cent was required which yielded no interest and was held to ma tu r i ty of the loan. Certain foreign credits are specifically exempted from the foregoing deposit requirements; these include credits from specified international financial organizations, credits con- tracted for or on behalf of the Federal Government or the National Bank of Yugoslavia, and credits contracted for the importation of equipment intended for high-priority sectors and activities as defined by Decisions of the Federal Execu- tive Council. Foreign credits repayable with foreign exchange acquired according to the regulations governing the foreign trade re- gime are trade credits for raw materials and intermediate goods, usually w i th a ma tu r i ty of up to 360 days; counterpart payments in dinars must be made according to National Bank regulations in force at the time. At the end of 1973, the requirement was a 66 per cent downpayment, w i th the re- ma in ing 34 per cent payable 30 days before final ma tu r i ty of the credit. Exceptions were (1) that for imports of raw materi- als subject to import quotas (RK) and imports of capital goods and equipment to be incorporated into projects and ships under export contracts, a deposit of 100 per cent must be made 30 days prior to repayment of the credit; and (2) that certain basic raw materials (such as crude oil, wool, and raw cotton) were exempt from dinar counterpart requirements. Foreigners may invest in certain Yugoslav economic orga- nizations but only through joint ventures; such foreign invest- ment is limited to 49 per cent of the organization's capital. Profit transfers abroad may be financed from the retention quota and, in addition, profit transfers are permitted up to one third of the jo int venture's foreign currency earnings from exports of goods and services. If the law governing joint 490 ventures were to be amended, the legal provisions in force on the date of registration of a jo int venture would continue to be applied dur ing the entire l ife of the investment contract, if the foreign investor so desires or, at the latter's option, any more favorable provisions of the amended legislation would be applied. Foreign firms are permitted to establish represen- tational offices in Yugoslavia. Foreign juridical and physical persons are permitted to purchase bonds issued by Yugoslav enterprises, sociopolitical communities, and other sociolegal persons. The investment income earned abroad by Yugoslav eco- nomic organizations must be repatriated within 90 days; how- ever, when repatriated the profits are governed by the regulations for retention quotas. Residents are obliged to repatriate and, w i th the exception of inheritances, to surren- der all foreign exchange held or accruing abroad on capital account. Outward capital transfers by residents who are physical persons are not approved. Economic organizations wishing to participate in foreign enterprises may be allowed under spe- cial conditions, by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade and the Federal Secretariat for Finance, to export the neces- sary capital. Also, a Decision of the Federal Executive Coun- cil of October 14, 1955 requires the Yugoslav authorities to continue to permit the remittance of inheritances to citizens of the United States, provided that the remittance is requested w i th in three years from the date of distribution of the estate. Gold The National Bank has issued certain commemorative gold coins, which are not legal tender. Foreign travelers are freely permitted to import and export these coins, subject to cus- toms declaration and, for exports, subject to proof that they have been purchased in Yugoslavia. Residents who are pri- vate persons may hold gold coins in Yugoslavia, which may be sold to the National Bank of Yugoslavia or to any autho- rized bank, and they may freely hold, purchase, import, and sell gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Domestic economic organizations that have been regis- tered as trad ing in gold may import gold jewelry under the GDK import regime; they may freely export gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Authorized banks may freely export gold coins. Sales of newly mined gold to the National Bank of Yugoslavia against payment in dinars (calculated by apply- ing the rate of Din 17 per U.S. dollar to a price of US$42.22 an ounce) are regarded as exports and entitle the seller to a retention quota of 20 per cent in convertible foreign exchange. Other domestic sales of newly mined gold by the producers may be made at a price which equals the average quotation in free gold markets abroad. Domestic economic organiza- tions using gold for their normal activities may purchase gold from domestic producers or abroad on the basis of quotas allocated to each individually. Other domestic sales of newly mined gold by the producers may be made at a price which equals the average quotation in free gold markets abroad. Following the termination on December 31, 1972 of the bilateral payments agreements w i th Hunga ry and India, settlements w i th these countries henceforth took place in convertible currencies. January 1. A new import category was established —goods liberalized under special license (DL). It comprised a few GDK, RK, or DK items such as tape recorders and watches, that previously were severely restricted. January L The rates established for allocations of foreign exchange to enterprises in respect of their annual depreciation allowances were modified; the applicable rates for enterprises in many lines of activities were increased. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.77734 grams of fine gold per Zaire, corresponding to Z 0.5 = SDR 1. A central rate of Z 1 = US$2, corresponding to Z 0.603176 = SDR 1, has been established, and Zaire avails itself of wider margins. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar. The Bank of Zaire (the central bank) quotes an official rate of exchange for the Belgian franc based on the rate for the zaire quoted on the official exchange market in Brussels. The buying and selling rates for other quoted currencies, except the U.S. dollar, the French franc, and the CFA franc, also are based on official market rates in Brussels. For the U.S. dollar, the Bank of Zaire quotes a fixed rate of Z 1 = US$2, buying and selling. Quotations for the French franc and the CFA franc are based on daily quotations for the zai're in the official exchange mar- ket in Paris. Forward exchange transactions are prohibited. Administration of Control The Bank of Zaire has regulatory authority over all foreign trade and payments. Specifically, the Bank has discretionary power to authorize payments and receipts in foreign exchange by residents of Zaire, and to permit the importation, exporta- tion, and transit of goods. Prescription of Currency Payments from nonresidents must be received in listed con- vertible currencies quoted daily by the Bank of Zaire. * Spe- cial authorization for the acceptance of other currency may only be given in respect of currencies that can be exchanged freely without a discount. Payments to nonresidents must be made in the listed currencies. However, certain settlements with Burundi, Rwanda, and Uganda are made through spe- cial accounts. Nonresident Accounts There are three categories of nonresident accounts: Non- resident Accounts in Zaires, Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts, and Convertible Accounts in Zaires. Nonresident Accounts in Zaires may only be debited with the approval of the Bank of Zaire. Such accounts, when opened by diplomatic missions and international organiza- tions established in Zaire, may be debited freely but may be credited only with the proceeds of sales of foreign currency and with payments made by the Government. Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts may be credited for any permitted payment in foreign currency; they may be debited freely for transfers to accounts abroad or to Resident and Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts, and for sales of foreign currency against domestic currency. Nonresident Zairian nationals require special authorization from the cen- 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, CFA francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. tral bank to open these accounts with authorized banks; non- resident foreigners may open them freely. Convertible Accounts in Zaires may be credited in accor- dance with Circular No. 131 2 and debited freely for conver- sion into foreign currency or for any payments in domestic currency. Such accounts may be held by residents and nonres- idents but must not be credited with payments for exports of goods or services. Imports and Import Payments The importation of a number of goods is prohibited on grounds of public policy; these are mainly arms, ammunition, narcotics, and juke boxes. Import licenses, which must be submitted to the Bank of Zaire for prior approval, are only required for a few goods on list A (these include jewelry, precious stones, precious metals, gold coins, rubber tires, sugar, portland cement, mineral water, works of art, and antiques). The central bank has issued a general import and payments license which for all other goods guarantees the availability of foreign exchange when payments fall due, pro- vided that the importer files an import declaration with his bank following the actual placing of the order and provided that invoice price and quality have been verified and found acceptable by the foreign correspondents of the Zairian Con- trol Office. Applications for import licenses, whether requiring foreign exchange or not, are made out at authorized banks; these forward the applications to the central bank after certifica- tion. After approval of the application by the central bank, which is given in the form of a visa, the import license applica- tion is returned to the intermediary authorized bank for vali- dation. Import licenses are validated by the authorized banks with- out undue delay and remain valid for customs clearance for six months starting from the first day of the month following that in which validation by the commercial bank takes place. Foreign exchange is made available for all licensed imports, the validated license constituting at the same time an ex- change license; for payments purposes, the license remains valid as long as the relevant payments have not been com- pleted. The counterpart of the value of goods imported under the Belgian food aid program, the U.S. import support pro- gram, and the agricultural aid program must be deposited within 120 to 180 days after their shipment. All imports are subject to a statistical tax of 3 per cent ad valorem. In addition, most imports, irrespective of origin, are subject to a temporary import surcharge of either 5 per cent or 20 per cent ad valorem on the c.i.f. value. Payments for Invisibles Policy related to payments for invisibles is formulated by the central bank. Certain payments are subject to authoriza- tion by the central bank, which is given or refused on a 2 Conversion of foreign currency at the official rate, transfer from another Convertible Account in Zaires, or authorized payments by residents to nonresidents. 493 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE nondiscriminatory basis; the approval au thor i ty for other current payments has been delegated to the authorized banks. The central bank will not authorize exchange for the payment of commissions in favor of shippers or purchasing agents or, except for imports payable on arrival, and provided that the supplier has arranged it, for insurance on imports. Further- more, imports and exports between Zaire and ports in Bel- gium, Germany, the Netherlands, and the Scandinavian countries must be shipped in vessels participating in the con- ference of the Associated Central West Africa Lines. Banks are not authorized to pay in foreign currency the maritime freight on shipments that do not meet these regulations, un- less an immediate discount is obtained on the invoice, and in the case of exports, banks are not authorized to validate export declarations unless these are marked accordingly. All other payments for services performed by nonresidents are in principle authorized. Transfers abroad of salaries of foreign nationals, however, are restricted; for each enterprise con- cerned, their amount cannot exceed the countervalue in zai'res of the amount spent on such transfers in 1972. Transfers in respect of certain administrative expenses abroad by enter- prises, interest on private loans, and certain portions of insur- ance premiums are, as a rule, authorized. Net profits of firms w i th foreign capital participation are transferable up to an amount proportionate to that participation. Transfers of roy- alties require the prior approval of the Service de la Pro- priete Industrielle. Fares for travel abroad may be paid in Zaire in local cur- rency. Zai'rian nationals traveling abroad may buy foreign exchange in amounts depending on the duration of the jour- ney, up to the equivalent of Z 400 a trip; applications exceed- ing this amount are subject to individual approval by the central bank. The export of domestic banknotes and coins is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may take out any foreign means of payment declared upon en try, minus the equivalent, at the official rate, of Z 20 for each day spent in Za'ire. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports not covered by general license require individ- ual declarations. Banks are normally authorized to approve such declarations, in which exporters undertake to collect the exchange proceeds. The declaration must specify the na ture of the merchandise to be exported, the price, and the currency in which payment is to be received. Export declarations are normally valid for three months; within this period, the pro- ceeds must be received and surrendered. Most exports of minerals are subject to special regulations to take in to ac- count the time required for processing abroad. For mineral products exported by the Generate des Carrieres et Mines du Zaire (GECAMINES), a provisional payment of a variable por- tion of the shipment's estimated value has to be received and surrendered within 8 days after shipment. For diamond ex- ports, two thirds of the value established at a preliminary examination in Zaire must be surrendered before the ship- ment is dispatched. Export proceeds from coffee must be surrendered w i th in 45 days after shipment. Receipts from other agricultural exports must generally be repatriated 494 within three months of validation. The exportation of coffee is a monopoly of the National Coffee Office. Minimum export prices have been established for coffee, tea, ivory, and certain other commodities. All exports are subject to a statistical tax of 1 per cent ad valorem, and all commodities except cement are subject to export duties. Proceeds from Invisibles All exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. The import of domestic banknotes and coins is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign means of payment and may take out on departure the amount declared on entry, less the equivalent of Z 20 a calendar day spent in Zaire. Capital The repatriation of new foreign capital brought in under the provisions of the Investment Code (Ordinance-Law No. 69-032 of June 26, 1969) is guaranteed, as is the transfer of prof i ts and dividends on such capital. With minor exceptions, other transfers abroad of capital owned by residents or non- residents are not permitted. Gratuitous transfers of real estate are subject to approval by executive ordinance. When the local currency part is paid by the debtor, amortization on foreign loans can be transferred in accordance with the terms of contracts that the central bank has endorsed to guarantee the availability of exchange for such transfers. The foreign currency assets of the authorized banks are not permitted to exceed their short-term liabilities in foreign currencies. Gold Residents other than the monetary authorities, producers of gold, and industrial users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. The import and export of gold in any form, except jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler, require the prior approval of the central bank. Producers are required to sell 10 per cent of their production to the central bank at the official gold price. Changes during 1973 January 1. Transfers of salaries by expatriate employees, limited since 1971 to 50 per cent of net salaries after tax, were limited, for each enterprise, to the amount of the countervalue in za'ires spent on such transfers in 1972. January 5. Law No. 73-009 reserved import and export operations, transport business, and wholesale and retail trade for Zai'rian nationals and for companies registered in Zaire whose entire capital was held by Zai'rian citizens. Cer- tain exemptions could, however, be granted. February 1. Law No. 73-006 of January 5 increased import duties on many commodities. It also raised the rate of the temporary import surcharge from 5 per cent to 20 per cent for specified luxury goods, and exempted specified textile products and some other items from this tax. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE February 13. Bank of Zaire Circular No. 143 made imports of mineral water, soft drinks, and beer subject to licensing. February 14. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, Zaire maintained its central rate unchanged at Z 1 = US$2, and continued to avail itself of wider margins. March 8. Imports by airfreight became subject to prior approval by the Bank of Zaire. March 20. The payments agreement signed in February 1973 by the Bank of Zaire and the Bank of the Republic of Burundi came into operation. AprilS. Circular No. 144 made imports of portland cement subject to licensing. May 11. Circular No. 145 made imports of certain baby foods, works of art, and antiques subject to licensing. June 27. Imports valued at Z 200 or less and not intended for resale were exempted from the prior visa from the So- ciete Generale de Surveillance. The same exemption, irrespec- tive of intended resale, was extended to industrial spare parts and to medicines. November 30. It was announced that all plantations, agri- cultural enterprises, stone quarries, and diamond m in ing en- terprises would have to be transferred to Zai'rian ownership. State participation in the m in ing sector would be expanded. All transport insurance on exports had to be placed with the national insurance company, the Societe Nationale d'Assu- rance (SONAS). The Compagnie Maritime du Zaire would be dissolved and replaced by a new company, La Compagnie Maritime Zai'roise, which would be given a monopoly over all export shipping and over the transportation of government imports. The Zairianization of domestic and foreign trade would be accelerated. (It was subsequently clarified that the Zairianization measures would not affect recent or f u t u re foreign investments in the coun try .) 495 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.14592 grams of f ine gold per Zambian Kwacha, corresponding to K 1 = SDR 1.28948, and Zambia avails itself of wider margins. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, is K 1 = US$1.55556 or US$1 = K 0.642856. The Bank of Zambia maintains fixed buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar. These rates are V ie of 1 per cent below parity for buying (US$1 = K 0.64246) and presentation of the relevant documents to an authorized bank. Prior approval by the Bank of Zambia, however, is necessary for payments to Rhodesia and South Africa in excess of K 20,000; payments for imports from Rhodesia and South Africa are not normally permitted unless no alternative source of supply is available. Unless prior permission is other- wise obtained, all imports must be paid for within six months of the date of importation. All dutiable imports are subject to a customs surcharge of 10 per cent ad valorem. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes, such as travel, is provided by the commercial banks without prior reference to the exchange control authorities, except when payments and transfers in excess of K 20,000 to Rhodesia or South Africa are involved. Special reduced allocations apply to payments for invisibles to Rhodesia. For other countries, exchange is granted as follows. The basic exchange allowance for travel is K 20 a day for an adult, with a maximum of K 600 for each period of two calendar years, and K 10 a day for each child under 12 years of age, with a maximum of K 300 for two calendar years. Exchange is provided, subject to certain lim- its, for other purposes such as education, medical treatment, and business travel. Applications for amounts exceeding the limits may in certain circumstances be granted by the ex- change control authorities if they are satisfied that excep- tional treatment is justified. Applications for remittance abroad of part or all of pay- ments for advertising, management, accounting, administra- tive, engineering, and consulting services rendered to residents by nonresidents are subject to individual approval by the Bank of Zambia, which generally grants the required permission, provided that the fees charged are reasonable and that these services cannot be provided domestically.2 Profits and dividends of subsidiaries and branches of companies whose head offices are situated outside Zambia may be trans- ferred abroad up to 30 per cent of the nonresident share of the equity capital or one half of net profits accruing to the nonresident owners of incorporated companies, whichever is smaller. 3 Foreign companies operating in Zambia may remit declared profits and dividends once a year after the end of the accounting year. The remittance of depreciation allowances is not permitted. Remittances of rents to nonresidents are re- stricted to 50 per cent of net annual rental income. Foreign nationals employed in Zambia on a contract basis and re- cruited after December 4, 1971 are allowed to remit to their country of domicile a third of their annual earnings. Foreign nationals recruited before December 4, 1971 and still em- ployed on a contract entered into prior to that date are al- lowed to remit to their country of domicile one half of their annual earnings. Foreign nationals availing themselves of these arrangements are not entitled to the regular allowances 2 Services rendered by a parent company abroad to its branch or wholly owned subsidiary in Zambia are not generally approved. 3 An auditor's certificate must be submitted to the effect that the amount sought to be transferred represents bona fide realized profits derived from the year's operations after full provision has been made for local taxation. The profit and loss account and balance sheet for the year in respect of which application is being made must also be submitted. ZAMBIA for travel, education, maintenance, etc. To facilitate payments of small amounts, individuals are freely permitted to remit abroad up to K 10 a month for purposes normally approved by the exchange control authorities (including family mainte- nance). Travelers may not take out more than K 10 in Zambian currency and the equivalent of K 20 in foreign currency notes. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports valued at over K 50 require a license; minerals, however, are exported under general agreements with the mining companies. Most exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Certain commodities are subject to licensing mainly to ensure domestic supplies of needed goods and of certain strategic materials, such as implements of war, lead in any form, cer- tain minerals, petroleum products, certain rough and uncut precious stones, scrap and old metals, and ju te bags. For most goods, however, export licenses are issued freely, and some goods are covered by an open general license. Export proceeds in foreign currency appropriate to the country of destination must be offered for sale to an authorized bank within six months of the date of shipment; the foreign ex- change proceeds of copper exports, however, must be credited to a Bank of Zambia account in London upon receipt. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any currency must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes that may be imported by travelers, except that travelers from Zaire are allowed to im- port only up to the equivalent of K 20. The import of Zam- bian currency is limited to K 10 for each traveler, except travelers from Zaire, who are allowed up to K 20. Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted but all bor- rowing outside Zambia requires the approval of the exchange control authorities. Outward transfers of capital are con- trolled, but nonresidents are normally permitted to repatriate their investments when they have satisfied the authorities that the original investment was made with funds brought into the country from sources outside Zambia. Local borrowing by companies controlled either directly or indirectly from out- side Zambia is restricted to a debt/equity ratio of 1 to 2. However, the Bank of Zambia permits borrowings in excess of this limit for certain priority sectors of the economy, pro- vided the borrowings secure higher employment opportuni- ties and /or savings of foreign exchange. In general, residents are not permitted to transfer capital abroad and, with certain exceptions, are required to offer for sale to an authorized bank any foreign exchange which ac- crues to them. As a special measure, however, residents may purchase Zambian securities quoted on recognized stock ex- changes abroad, provided that the securities so acquired are registered in the names of specified nominees and that in the event of subsequent disposal of these securities the sales pro- 497 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA ceeds are repatriated. All income earned from these invest- ments must be repatriated. Emigrants are granted exchange as follows: (1) Persons 50 years of age and over are allowed K 8,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of K 5,000. (2) Married persons under 50 are allowed K 4,000 on departure, together with K 250 for each child, up to a maximum of K 5,000 for a family un i t. Thereafter, annual transfers of K 3,000, together with K 250 for each child, up to a maximum of K 4,000 for a family unit are permitted. (3) Unmarried persons under 50 are al- lowed K 2,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of K 1,500. In addition to their emigration allowance, emi- grants may remit gratuities, compensation payments, and terminal benefits up to a maximum of K 8,000 on departure, and up to K 5,000 as annual transfers. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Zambia for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require exchange control ap- proval as well as import or export licenses issued by the Minister of Trade and Industry; such licenses are not nor- mally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Gold-bear- ing slime is exported by copper companies as a by-product for refining and sale abroad. Foreign exchange for imports of gold may only be provided with the permission of the Bank of Zambia. Changes during 1973 January 10. Following the announcement that Rhodesia was closing the border with Zambia, all imports and exports via Rhodesia were suspended. January 12. All payments and transfers to Rhodesia, South Africa, Mozambique, and Angola required the prior approval of the Bank of Zambia. Approval was given to all bona fide transactions after screening to prevent illegal capital f l ight and to prevent payments for imports being made before the arrival of goods. Previously, certain payments to these countries, such as payments for imports and freight and in- surance, could be made by the authorized dealers w i thout reference to the Bank of Zambia. January 12. In order to prevent unauthorized payments and transfers to Rhodesia, South Africa, Mozambique, and Angola via third countries, all payments and transfers in excess of K 20,000 to other countries also required the prior approval of the Bank of Zambia. Approval was given after scrutiny of the authenticity of the transaction. January 25. The Bank of Zambia terminated the prior approval requirement for exchange transactions w i th Mo- zambique and Angola, provided the transactions were for K 20,000 or less. The Bank of Zambia also allowed autho- rized dealers to make payments and remittances for pensions, maintenance of relatives, and repatriation of earnings to resi- dents of Rhodesia and South Africa w i thout prior reference 498 to the exchange control authorities, provided applications had been made prior to January 10, 1973. Approval was given liberally to such remittances requested after January 11,1973. January 27. The import surcharge applicable to all dutiable imports was increased from 5 per cent to 10 per cent ad valorem. February 2. The Open General License, which covered im- ports of personal effects, diplomatic shipments, samples, min- ing necessities, parcel post, air freighted goods, and government stores, was revoked. At the same time a list of goods exempt from individual licensing was announced; it covered personal effects, samples, diplomatic shipments, and transport vehicles entering Zambia temporarily. Residents had previously been allowed to import without an individual license any goods, the value of which did not exceed K 25 once a mon th; this facility was now limited to goods for personal use and consumption, provided their value did not exceed K 50 once every 90 days. February 8. A new import control system was introduced, covering all imports except the exempted items listed under February 2, above. It replaced the mon th ly quota system. All public and private sector imports became subject to foreign exchange allocations established by the Ministry of Trade and Indus t ry at the beginning of each quarter. (Under the previous import licensing system, the mon th ly guideline did not affect government imports, imports of the m in ing compa- nies, or imports from the People's Republic of China.) In addition to the Ministry of Trade and Indus try, eight desig- nated agencies were authorized to process initial applications for foreign exchange. February 9. The Bank of Zambia notified authorized deal- ers that it would again consider approval for payments for imports from South Africa before arrival of the goods. February 12. The Ministry of Trade and Indus try pub- lished a list of ten passenger car models which could be imported in to Zambia. In order to conserve foreign exchange and enable proper servicing, no other models would be li- censed. February 15. Following the announcement that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, Zambia maintained the gold value of its currency. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar, previously K 1 = US$1.40, became K 1 = US$1.55556. Zambia continued to avail itself of wider mar- gins. February 19. The import prohibition imposed on 11 com- modities on January 24, 1972 was removed. The remaining prohibition on the import of four types of agricultural com- modities was removed on August 17. March 21. The restriction imposed on January 10, 1972 on local borrowing by companies controlled from outside Zam- bia was eased. The Bank of Zambia announced that it would permit borrowings in excess of a deb t /equ i ty ratio of 1 to 2 for certain priority sectors, provided the borrowings secured higher employment opportunities a n d / or savings of foreign exchange. April 24. The scope of the January 12 measures (see above) was fu r ther reduced to cover only payments and transfers to Rhodesia and South Africa in excess of K 20,000. ©International Monetary Fund. Previously, most of their foreign exchange transactions, including remittances of prof- its, dividends, and rents, did not require such approval. The existing restrictions on remittances of profits, dividends, and rents would be applicable also to these m in ing companies, September 12.
